title: A Trial for Libby?
description: Somehow I doubt that Dick Cheney is going to take my advice and explain his role in the Wilson affair (I resist calling it the Plame affair or Plamegate, because Valerie Plame Wilson herself goes by Wilson, not Plame). I think hes going to hunker down and try to wait out the storm. Its unclear if he can get away with that. Plenty of reporters are trying to get to the bottom of this.

title: Northern Ireland Paramilitary Group Disbands
description: The Protestant paramilitary organization known as the Loyalist Volunteer Force announced that it had ordered its members to cease operations and had disbanded. In a statement, the group said its action was a "direct response" to the Irish Republican Army's recent decision to end its 36-year armed campaign against Britain and destroy its weapons. Its action also followed by a day a formal end to the long-running feud between the Loyalist Volunteer Force and a larger rival group, the Ulster Volunteer Force. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Diseases Now in the Past, and New Ones Up Ahead
description: We owe it all to the milkmaids. In 1796, when smallpox was rampant, Edward Jenner noticed that the women who milked cows for a living contracted cowpox on their hands but seemed never to come down with deadly smallpox. He wondered if the milder illness protected them from the killer disease, and the idea for vaccines was born (vaccinia being the name of a virus that causes cowpox).

title: Mayoral Debate
description: Fernando Ferrer and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will hold their second and last debate of the mayoral race tonight at 7. The hourlong debate will be broadcast live on WNBC-TV, Channel 4.

description: In 1899, the New York Public Library received a query from a Miss Frank E. Buttolph, who wanted to know if it would add restaurant menus to its growing collections.

On "Three Wishes" and "Extreme Makeover: Home Edition," viewers glide effortlessly through a well-packaged tableau of poignant need and extravagant succor, with lots of swelling music and slow-motion hugging, and the messy, boring bits airbrushed out.

Personal Income Rises, but Fuel Prices Take a Bite in Spending
description: Consumer spending rose 0.5 percent and personal incomes rose 1.7 in September, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. But after adjusting for inflation, spending dropped for a second month, the first back-to-back decline in 15 years and a sign that rising fuel costs left Americans with less money for other purchases.

description: This N.B.A. season is an opportunity for a lot of people to prove themselves.

title: But Will It Stop Cancer?
description: Bernyce Edwards's daughter was 42 in 1997 when she died of breast cancer. It was just 69 days from diagnosis to death. And through her shock and grief, Ms. Edwards had a terrible worry: what if she got breast cancer, too?

title: Labor Dept. Is Rebuked Over Pact With Wal-Mart
description: The Labor Department's inspector general strongly criticized department officials yesterday for "serious breakdowns" in procedures involving an agreement promising Wal-Mart Stores 15 days' notice before labor investigators would inspect its stores for child labor violations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEIZNER, OSCAR
description: WEIZNER--Oscar. The New York Philharmonic mourns the passing, on October 29, of Oscar Weizner, 83, a violinist with the Orchestra from 1962 until his retirement in 2003. A native of Dresden, Germany, he came to the U.S. in 1938 and subsequently performed with the Pittsburgh Symphony, the Radio City Music Hall orchestra, and The Metropolitan Opera Orchestra before joining the Philharmonic. "A violinist was what I wanted to be, to play in a fine orchestra," he once said. Our condolences to his wife, Judith, his children William Weizner and Denise Weizner Mananas, and family. Lorin Maazel, Music Director Members of the Orchestra Paul B. Guenther, Chairman Zarin Mehta, Pres/Exec. Dir. Members of the Staff

Restoring Medici Splendor, One Stitch at a Time
description: The scene was less fine art than sweatshop, the kind of backbreaking labor that would have been common four centuries ago. In the textile conservation department of the Metropolitan Museum one day last week, four women hunched over "The Gathering of Manna," a rare Medici tapestry with a papal lineage that will be unveiled tomorrow in the Italian Renaissance gallery.

title: Discount Fares to the Caribbean
description: Spirit Airlines is offering one-way fares to the Caribbean for a promotional base rate of $9.Customers have until 11:59 p.m. on Nov. 7 to buy their tickets, which must be used between Nov. 10 and Dec. 14. International fares may require government taxes and fees up to $125 for a round trip. Travel dates for the $9 fares are limited, and can be found at www.spiritair.com, where tickets must be bought.

title: Chairman Nominee May Bring a New Openness to the Fed
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 - If Ben S. Bernanke has his way, the Federal Reserve is likely to become more open, less mysterious and perhaps less intriguing than it is right now.

title: 30 Years Later, Still Run Citywide
description: The idea started with Ted Corbitt and George Spitz, two distance runners with vision. It was refined by Fred Lebow, who became marathon running's extraordinary idea man. It caught the attention of Percy Sutton, then the Manhattan borough president, who found seed money from the Rudins, the real estate family.

title: Eager Retailers Can't Wait for Thanksgiving; They're Starting Christmas Now
description: CHILDREN may not have finished sorting the treats from the tricks, but their parents are already being bombarded by retailers eager to hasten the Christmas shopping season.

Scientists Link a Prolific Gene Tree to the Manchu Conquerors of China
description: Geneticists have identified a major lineage of Y chromosomes in populations of northern China that they believe may mark the bearers as descendants of one of the Manchu conquerors who founded the Qing dynasty and ruled China from 1644 to 1911.

title: Small plane loses control on landing in heavy rain
Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Sex-Offender Court Is Planned
description: A special court that will handle only sex offense cases will be running by the beginning of next year, the Westchester County executive, Andrew J. Spano, announced yesterday. The plan for the court, which is expected to result in tougher, more consistent sentences for sex offenders, was proposed in 2002 but moved forward only yesterday after the State Legislature approved $250,000 in funds. Modeled on courts that hear domestic violence and drug offenses, the new court will handle up to 120 cases a year, Mr. Spano said. It will also provide victims with counseling and other services. Anahad O'Connor (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article last Tuesday about the presumed death of an oarsman in a collision between a racing shell and a motorboat in the Harlem River misstated the relationship of a colleague who described the victim's daily rowing routine. The colleague, Ken Cohen, was the business partner of the rower, Jim H. Runsdorf, not his boss, at Pantheon Financial, a Manhattan real estate investment company. The article also misstated the condition of the shell after the accident. It was indeed damaged.

title: Owners and General Managers Have Their Eyes Wide Shut
description: THE asylum doors have blown open, and the keepers, not the inmates, are running wild. This time, it's not the players who are out of control; it's the owners and in some instances the general managers.

description: FRIEDBERG -- Martin Har vey, the Lee Strasberg of improvisational comedy, died October 30, 2005. Graveside service today, 10AM, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, L.I. A memorial to be announced.

title: Thomas Hopes Knicks Will Be Able to Get There From Here
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Oct. 31 - From the draft in June, Isiah Thomas drew excitement. After he hired Larry Brown in July, he inspired hope. With his acquisition of Eddy Curry in October, he raised expectations.

title: Iran's Threat to Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Invisible New Yorkers: Crispin Cortes and James De La Vega
description: Crispin Cortes, left, and James De La Vega created illustrations to complement their portraits. Mr. De La Vega's storefront artists' studio on Lexington Avenue and East 104th Street was a local gathering spot where his mother, Elsie Matos, was a muse for artists like Mr. Cortes. The storefront has moved, to the East Village.

title: Liberty Mutual Chooses Hill, Holliday Agency
description: The Liberty Mutual Group in Boston yesterday named Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, to handle its insurance advertising, which had been handled for seven years by Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York, part of MDC Partners. Spending was estimated at $60 million.

title: Fair Lending in the Senate
description: It's not every day that a foreign affairs issue comes up in the same context as unfair lending practices, which can strip borrowers of hard-won assets and drive people into bankruptcy. But given the 30-state investigation of the lending practices of the Ameriquest Capital Corporation, a mortgage behemoth, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee was right to delay a vote to confirm the company's chairman as ambassador to the Netherlands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'ROURKE, ANNABELLE T.
description: O'ROURKE--Annabelle T. Of Bronxville, on October 30, 2005. Wife of the late Dr. James J. O'Rourke. Mother of Ann Keenan, Kevin C. O'Rourke, James J. O'Rouke Jr., Ellen Watson, and Brian C. O'Rourke. Grandmother of 10. Calling hours at The Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 6 to 8 PM Wednesday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Thursday, November 3 at 10 AM.

title: Program: Complex Modernists; Degree of Difficulty: Medium
description: It was startling to see so many empty seats at Zankel Hall for the Sunday afternoon concert by the Met Chamber Ensemble. For years these programs, planned and presided over by the conductor James Levine, have been hugely popular despite highish ticket prices. But this time many potential ticket-buyers were probably intimidated by the program, which offered recent works by two formidably complex modernists: Charles Wuorinen and Elliott Carter. The whole first half of this two-and-a-half-hour concert was taken up by Mr. Wuorinen's "Dante Trilogy," a 70-minute work in three parts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ISRAEL, LAWRENCE J.
description: ISRAEL--Lawrence J. Peacefully, on October 30. Age 87 years. Beloved husband of the late Beulah. Adored father of Shelly Zirkes and Bret. Loving grandfather of Valerie and Linda. Caring greatgrandfather of Samantha and Alexa. NYU graduate. W.W. II Navy veteran, and partner in the architectural firm of Copeland, Novak & Israel in Manhattan. Till last week he taught Interior Design at the Fashion Institute of Technology. Longtime resident of Freeport. Trustee of the former Union Reform Temple. Services will be at "Gutterman's," 175 North Long Beach Road, Tuesday, 1 PM.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: Republican Party Chairman Quits
description: The chairman of the state Republican Party, William A. Hamzy, 39, a state representative from Plymouth, resigned yesterday, saying he needed to "refocus his attention on his law practice and continuing to serve as state representative." For months, party loyalists have described strained relations between the governor's chief of staff, M. Lisa Moody, and the state party. Mr. Hamzy declined to comment, but Gov. M. Jodi Rell, who announced her candidacy two weeks ago, said she understood that his priorities had changed since his father's death in September. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the possibility that the next Supreme Court nominee after Harriet E. Miers could face a confrontation in the Senate misstated the number of senators needed to block a full vote on a nominee. It is 41, not 40.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZLOTNICK, SONIA
description: ZLOTNICK -- Sonia. Passed away on October 30, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Nathan. Devoted mother of Jay, Fred and Naomi Groman. Dear sister of Raya Kane and Samuel Goldin. Cherished grandmother of Ben, Micah, Jessica, Nicole and Lindsay and great-grandmother of Michaela. Services Tuesday 11:45 am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, 100 Raoul Wallenberg Place SW, Washington, DC 20024 or Buckelew Programs, 914 Mission Ave., San Rafael, CA 94901.

title: Qwest Expected to Announce a Settlement
description: Qwest Communications International, the telecommunications company, is expected to announce as early as this morning a $400 million settlement of its largest shareholder lawsuits relating to an accounting scandal during the dot.com boom, a person briefed on the deal said yesterday.

Lewis Libby Jr. Two longtime aides to Mr. Cheney, both of whom were questioned in the C.I.A. leak investigation, were named to take on Mr. Libby's duties.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Interest in Maker of Car Windshields
description: The Nippon Sheet Glass Company, Japan's second-biggest glass maker, said it might bid for Pilkington of Britain, the world's largest maker of car windshields, as demand for auto glass surges in China and other markets. Discussions are at "a very preliminary stage," Nippon Sheet Glass, which already owns 20 percent of Pilkington, said in a statement, without disclosing how much it might pay.

Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Oct. 21 about Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's efforts to play a bigger role in redeveloping Lower Manhattan misattributed the statement that Larry A. Silverstein, the developer who holds the lease to the World Trade Center site, objects to an excess of retail space there because it would interfere with his plans to build offices. The comment was made by officials of the Port Authority, which owns the site, not by Mr. Silverstein. Through a spokeswoman, Mr. Silverstein said he had never publicly expressed such a sentiment and in fact supported substantial and expedited retail development at the site.

title: Bush Calls for $7.1 Billion to Prepare for Bird Flu Threat
description: President Bush today unveiled a strategy to combat the threat of an avian flu pandemic, calling for $7.1 billion in emergency spending to stockpile reserves of medicines and to press ahead with the development of a new vaccine.

description: To show support for the city of New Orleans, the French culture minister, Renaud Donnedieu de Vabres, and the president of the Louvre, Henri Loyrette, are planning to visit New Orleans on Friday to announce a series of cultural initiatives. Among the projects expected to be announced is an exhibition of some 50 works of art lent by the Louvre to the New Orleans Museum of Art for an exhibition tentatively scheduled for late 2006 or early 2007.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDSTEIN, FANNIE (KAVESH)
description: GOLDSTEIN -- Fannie (Kavesh). Of Canton, MA. formerly of New York, entered into rest October 29, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Frank E. Goldstein. Devoted mother of Harriet Finkelstein of Boston, MA. Loving aunt of many nieces and nephews. Graveside services at Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Glendale NY on Tuesday, November 1, at 1:00 P.M. Memorial observance will be private. Remembrances in her memory may be made to the Hillcrest Jewish Center Library Fund 183-02 Union Turnpike, Flushing, NY 11366. description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 - Democrats invoked a rarely used rule today that sent the Senate into a two-hour closed session, infuriating Republicans but producing an agreement for a bipartisan look at whether the Republican leadership was dragging its feet on a promised inquiry into the Bush administration's use of prewar intelligence on Iraq.

description: Nine New Jersey hospitals without cardiac surgery units will be allowed to perform elective angioplasty for the first time next year under a decision announced yesterday by New Jersey's health commissioner.

description: Vladimir Feltsman has adopted an ascetic look, with closely cropped silver hair and beard, a black high-collared suit and a stony, sometimes dour expression that seemed particularly well suited to staring down latecomers to his Carnegie Hall recital on Sunday afternoon. To go with this spare look -- and perhaps to counteract it -- Mr. Feltsman offered a ferocious brand of pianism and considerable interpretive audacity.

Jets Are Looking for a Turnaround
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Oct. 31 - Their bye in the rearview mirror, the Jets returned to practice Monday focused on trying to salvage their season. On one of the offense's first snaps in five days, Vinny Testaverde lofted a pass that soared toward a cloudless sky and landed in the hands of a receiver. For Jets fans searching for vestiges of hope, this was a good place to start.

He goes on to say that Douglas R. Forrester "doesn't support embryonic stem cell research, therefore I don't think he supports people like me and doctors who say a cure is coming."

Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Bigger Budget Surplus Than Expected
description: New York State is on track to end the year with a $1 billion surplus, $400 million more than anticipated, the Pataki administration said yesterday. But John F. Cape, the state budget director, said the state still faced a $2.5 billion deficit next year. News of the surplus prompted State Senator Joseph L. Bruno, a Republican, to renew his calls for cuts in the gasoline sales tax and help for people with rising heating fuel costs. He said he expected the surplus to be even larger than the administration is saying, and questioned the size of next year's deficit, saying the administration had been "wrong, wrong, wrong" in the past. Michael Cooper (NYT)

World Briefing | Europe: Spain: Royal Birth Brings New Calls For Constitutional Change
description: Prince Felipe, the heir to the Spanish throne, announced that his wife, Letizia, had given birth to their first child, a girl named Leonor, who, as things stand now, could one day become queen unless she has a brother. The birth immediately led to calls to change the Constitution's favoritism of male heirs to the crown. Prime Minister Jos Luis Rodrguez Zapatero has promised to introduce legislation that would allow a first-born daughter to become queen even if she has a younger brother, and the proposal appears to have broad support in Parliament. Felipe and Letizia, above, married in May 2004. Renwick McLean (NYT)

title: Sergeant May Face Court-Martial in Deaths of 2 G.I.'s in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 1 - An investigating officer for the American military has recommended that a staff sergeant face court-martial in the deaths of two American soldiers last spring, the American military announced today.

Democratic Judge Is Removed From DeLay Case
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 1 - A Texas court agreed today that a Democratic judge should be removed from Representative Tom Delay's criminal trial because of the judge's contributions to Democratic candidates and causes.

title: The Computer Will See You Now (Feel Better?)
description: These days I often find myself looking away from my patients. The reason is that I am furiously typing the details of their office visits into the computer, thereby providing essential information to other doctors and staff members at the hospital.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Tsutsumi Brothers Will Bid for Railway
description: Yuji and Seiji Tsutsumi said they would bid as much as 560 billion yen ($4.84 billion) for Seibu Railway, which their family founded, challenging a plan by creditors to sell a stake to Cerberus Capital Management of New York. The brothers will offer 1,150 yen to 1,300 yen a share for Seibu, an operator of railways in suburban Tokyo, Yuji Tsutsumi, 63, said at a news briefing in Tokyo. Seibu and its closely held parent Kokudo own about 80 hotels as well as golf courses and ski resorts.

title: Montreal Wakes Up in Busy Third Period
description: For two periods, the two best players on the ice at Madison Square Garden last night were wearing masks. The goalies for the Rangers and the Montreal Canadiens were perfect to that point, marking only the fourth time this season that a game entered the third period scoreless.

title: National Briefings
description: SOUTHWEST

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Delay's Fund Paid Fees To Giuliani's Law Firm
description: A legal defense fund for Representative Tom DeLay of Texas paid $100,000 in fees recently to the Houston-based law firm that Rudolph W. Giuliani joined as a name partner last spring. Associates of Mr. Giuliani said he had not personally advised or worked for Mr. DeLay, who has been indicted in a campaign finance investigation in Texas and is also under scrutiny in a federal investigation of a Washington lobbyist. The fund's trustee, Brent C. Perry, said that the firm, formerly Bracewell & Patterson, has represented Mr. DeLay since 2000, well before Mr. Giuliani joined. Patrick D. Healy (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SALTON, JUSTINE AUGUSTA
description: SALTON--Justine Augusta. The Horace Mann School is deeply saddened by the sudden death of Justine Salton '90. Her kindness, her sense of humor and thoughtfulness toward her friends and Horace Mann School are acknowledged by all. Our heartfelt condolences go to her husband, Raphael Allison, her mother, Edith Salton, her sister, Gillian Salton '86, her brother, William Salton, and the rest of her family. She will be greatly missed. Dr. Thomas M. Kelly Head of School Robert J. Katz '65 Chair, Board of Trustees

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: More Violence In Paris Suburb
description: Clashes between the police and gangs of youths continued for a fourth straight night in the Paris suburb of Clichy-sous-Bois. Six police officers were injured. The interior minister, Nicolas Sarkozy, pledged to increase security in the district, a poor area with a large immigrant population. He also confirmed reports that a tear gas grenade had been fired toward a local mosque and said an investigation was under way. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Waitz Summons Her Will to Win a Different Race
description: NOT surprisingly, the name Tedy Bruschi did not ring a bell for Grete Waitz, who is not much of a pro football fan and has, since April, been in her native Norway, far from her second home in Florida, waging her own battle in the trenches against a blitzing opponent she never saw coming.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Deflation Expected to End by March
description: Japan's central bank said a seven-year bout of deflation would end in March, increasing the chances that policy makers will raise interest rates from almost zero. The chances that the bank will cut the amount of money it pumps into the economy and raise rates will increase in the next fiscal year, the bank said in a statement. A return of inflation will support growth by allowing companies to increase prices, corporate earnings and wages. Japan has had four recessions since 1991.

title: Zanzibar vote fraud charged
Corrections
description: An article on Sept. 23 about the stabbing deaths of a mother and two children in their apartment in Jersey City included an erroneous given name from prosecutors for one child and misspelled the given name of the other. They were D'Artagnania and De'Quan Wilson, both 11, not Tanya and Daquan. (The errors came to light last week during the preparation of an article about the arrest of a suspect.)

title: Puppets Help Evoke China's History of Love and War
description: For Marco Polo in the 13th century as for Ezra Pound in the 20th, China was "Cathay," a land of mythic wonders. For the American-born director and writer Ping Chong, to visit China and make theater in the West meant exploring myth and history, joining Asian and Western traditions. The result is "Cathay: Three Tales of China," playing at the New Victory Theater through Nov. 13. It is enchanting.

title: Who Has the Rights to 'Weekend at Bernie's?'
description: Who Has the Rights To 'Weekend at Bernie's'?

title: Let's Have a Big Hand For ...
description: Whatever you think of Samuel Alito Jr. for the Supreme Court, you have to give President Bush credit for great timing. Just when Americans couldn't bear one more look at the Wilsons mugging for the camera or Scooter Libby hobbling on crutches, he's given TV viewers a new face and a new battle.

title: A Happy Family Is Stalked by Heartbreak as a Daughter Wastes Herself Away
description: The wonderful world of disease appears to be the new frontier in musical theater, both uptown and down. On Broadway, the hapless hero of Joe Brooks's "In My Life" struggles with both Tourette's syndrome and a brain tumor. And in "Normal," a new musical from the Transport Group at the Connelly Theater in the East Village, a nuclear family faces apocalypse when teenage Polly starts skipping dessert, and lunch and dinner, too. Yep, it's an anorexia-themed musical comedy.

title: The workplace: Nice wages, short hours, and for life
German Socialist to Quit; Coalition in Doubt
description: FRANKFURT, Oct. 31 - Negotiations to form a new German government were thrown into jeopardy Monday when the leader of one of the two main parties said he would step down after losing an internal power struggle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FOLEY, VIRGINIA REID MERRIAM
description: FOLEY--Virginia Reid Merriam. Of Westport, CT, on October 29, 2005. Loving wife of Donald Foley, mother of Stephen, Ann and David. A Memorial service will be held on Thursday, November 3, 2005 at 11:00 AM in Trinity Episcopal Church, 651 Pequot Avenue, Southport, CT.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Off-Duty Officer Arrested
description: An off-duty police sergeant was arrested early yesterday and charged with driving while intoxicated, the police said. A passer-by saw the sergeant, Joseph Kissone, driving erratically along Fulton Street in East New York about 2 a.m. and alerted an officer who was patrolling the area, the police said. The officer pulled Sergeant Kissone over in front of a tire shop and arrested him after noticing that he was unsteady on his feet, the police said. Sergeant Kissone, an 11-year veteran who is assigned to Manhattan courts, has been suspended, the police said. Fernanda Santos (NYT)

title: Sometimes Big Brother Is a Protector
description: WELL, government officials can't say they have not been warned.

title: MTV Is Expected to Appoint Media Strategist as President
description: With an eye on a rapidly changing media environment, MTV Networks is expected to announce today that it has hired a prominent media strategist, Michael J. Wolf, a managing partner in the consulting firm of McKinsey & Company, as its president and chief operating officer.

title: Option No. 3
description: To the Editor:Re "Topping Off a Physical: How Far Is Too Far" (Cases, Oct. 25): As a woman wearing a wig in the aftermath of chemotherapy, I found Dr. Kent Sepkowitz's column "Topping Off a Physical" both touching and disturbing.

title: A Wordy Widower With a Past
description: The Sea By John Banville 195 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $23.

title: A New Weapon for Wal-Mart: A War Room
description: BENTONVILLE, Ark., Oct. 26 - Inside a stuffy, windowless room here, veterans of the 2004 Bush and Kerry presidential campaigns sit, stand and pace around six plastic folding tables. Open containers of pistachio nuts and tropical trail mix compete for space with laptops and BlackBerries. CNN flickers on a television in the corner.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ELKIN, MILTON, M.D.
description: ELKIN--Milton, M.D. Beloved husband of the late Gloria Elkin. Loving father of Phil Elkin, Karen Segall and Laura Friedman, and grandfather of David, Michael, Suzanna, Steven, Jessica and Craig. Services will be held at 9:30 AM on Thursday, November 3, at Chapel in the Woods, Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave., White Plains, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

Data Security Laws Seem Likely, So Consumers and Businesses Vie to Shape Them
description: It has been a bad year for data security.

Cheney Fills Posts of Indicted Former Aide
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 - The White House on Monday made its first personnel moves since the indictment on Friday of Vice President Dick Cheney's chief of staff, I. Lewis Libby Jr., naming two longtime aides to Mr. Cheney, both of whom were questioned in the C.I.A. leak investigation, to take on Mr. Libby's duties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COMET, ISRAEL
description: COMET--Israel. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the brother and brother-inlaw of our members, Theodore and Shoshana Comet. May their entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion & Jerusalem. Ari Berman, Rabbi Joseph S. Kaplan, President Paulette Papilsky, Sisterhood

title: Reining in Welfare, but at a Lower Volume
description: In the past week, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has given two addresses outlining his vision for welfare and after-school care. But until then, during nearly four years in office, he did not deliver a single speech on foster care. He dished out only one meal at a city soup kitchen.

title: Novartis to buy rest of Chiron
Paid Notice: Deaths   CUDDEBACK, ROBERT
description: CUDDEBACK -- Robert. Of Glen Cove, NY, died Sunday, October 30, at the age of 76. Beloved husband of 38 years to Katherine. Beloved father to Cheryl, Robert, Brad and John. Favorite grandfather, great-grandfather, brother, uncle and cousin. Best friend to many, friend to all. Graduate of Kent School and Brown University. 2nd Lieutenant in US Army. An icon in the maritime shipping industry, and a proud member of the Founders Club of the petrochemical industry. More than anything, he loved being with family and friends, and we loved being with him. A true gentleman, he lived life. Memorial service at Locust Valley Reformed Church, on Saturday, November 5, at 9:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Kent School, Kent, CT. 06757.

title: A Kindly Death, a Joyous Muse, a Buoyant Poet-Cavalier
description: Cast changes call forth not only images of the new but also memories of the old. Great past Joffrey Ballet interpreters of the central role of Death in "The Green Table" hovered as Isaac Stappas danced the character on Saturday afternoon in a performance by American Ballet Theater at City Center. Another ghost was Mr. Stappas himself, not long ago one of the newest and lowliest of the Ballet Theater corps dancers. That was also true of Melanie Hamrick, a highly promising young corps dancer who made role debuts in "Les Sylphides" and "Apollo" on Friday and Saturday nights.

description: The Wizard of Oz

title: Federal Report Says Delays in Cockpit Made Teterboro Crash Worse
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 - The corporate jet that went off the end of a runway at Teterboro Airport on Feb. 2, overweight and imbalanced, was tantalizingly close to being able to take off, according to documents released Monday. The crash was made worse, however, because the pilots delayed using the thrust reversers, according to investigators.

title: Copper bubble feared
Koizumi Shuffles His Cabinet, Narrowing Field of Successors
description: TOKYO, Oct. 31 - Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi appointed several leading conservative figures to top positions in a new cabinet on Monday, narrowing the field of potential candidates to succeed him as prime minister next year.

description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 - The 1991 abortion case on which the confirmation of Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. to the Supreme Court may hinge arrived at his Philadelphia-based federal appeals court at a moment of great ferment in the development of abortion law.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BURSTEIN, ROBERT
description: BURSTEIN--Robert. Born in Newark, NJ on May 24, 1924, died after a long illness on October 31. Cherished husband of Janet, father of Mark and Julie, father-in-law of David Calle and Mark Maben, grandfather of Zeke & Micah Maben. Bob served as a navigator in the US Army Air Corp in WWII, attended City College and earned graduate degrees in business administration and law at the University of Michigan and NYU on the GI Bill. He headed his own accounting firm in Jersey City, worked whole heartedly for Civil Rights and Jewish communal organizations, served as president of the Hebrew Home in Bayonne for many years, and took no prisoners among the early bird tennis players in Verona, NJ. Funeral services will be held 1PM today at the Plaza Funeral Home in NYC. For information 212-769-4400. The family will be accepting visitors at 390 Riverside Dr., #

title: Rulings That Are Lucid and Methodically Based
description: The reasoning in Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr.'s decisions is mostly methodical, dry and respectful of precedent, but the technical quality of his writing can mask bold and solidly conservative conclusions on issues like abortion, gun control and the death penalty.

title: Terror Blasts Cast a Pall Over Hindu Festival in India
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 1 - The traditionally vibrant festival of light celebrations here were subdued today, as many residents stayed away from markets and public places across the city in the wake of the weekend terror bombings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TAYLOR, JOAN KENNEDY
description: TAYLOR -- Joan Kennedy. Age 78, on October 29th, 2005. Beloved wife of the late David J. Dawson. Dear mother of Michael Cook. Devoted daughter of the late Deems Taylor and Mary Kennedy. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Wednesday, November 2nd, 4-7 PM. Services Friday, November 4th at the First Congregational Church of Stockbridge, MA, 3 PM.

title: Malawi Is Burning, and Deforestation Erodes Economy
description: MALOSA, Malawi - Lovely and lissome, the masuku tree rises maybe 35 feet at maturity, its wood the hue of a rare steak, its branches dotted with sweet golfball-size fruits that ferment into a tasty wine.

title: U.S. Approval Is Expected Soon for Sale of Guidant
description: Johnson & Johnson's proposed acquisition of the Guidant Corporation is expected to be approved by the Federal Trade Commission as early as today, executives involved in the deal said yesterday.

title: U.N. TELLS SYRIA TO STOP IMPEDING SLAYING INQUIRY
description: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 31 - The Security Council voted unanimously on Monday to compel Syria to stop obstructing a United Nations investigation into the assassination of the former Lebanese prime minister Rafik Hariri or face unspecified "further action."

title: 2 Camps, Playing Down Nuances, Stake Out Firm Stands
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 - The selection of Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. for the Supreme Court drew immediate opposition on Monday from abortion rights groups who argued that he would fundamentally shift the balance of the court and open the door to major new restrictions on abortion.

title: Earnings: Strong sales lift earnings
Paid Notice: Deaths   BOWES, JOHN GARLAND
description: BOWES--John Garland. Born August 30, 1928, died at his home in San Francisco, Wednesday, October 26, 2005. A successful entrepreneur and avid art collector, Mr. Bowes is survived by his wife, Frances Fay Bowes, daughters, Alexandra Bowes of San Francisco, Diana Bowes Weller of Westport, CT and Elena Marano of London, UK, his brother, William Bowes of San Francisco, and nine grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 4 PM, Wednesday, November 2nd, at Grace Cathedral in San Francisco. Memorials may be made to the DIA Center for the Arts and the University of California, San Francisco, Cardiology Department.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISL, EDWIN L. JR.
description: WEISL--Edwin L. Jr. On October 27. Died after a long illness. Beloved husband of the late Barbara B. Weisl. Loving father of Angela Jane Weisl. Funeral services Thursday, 10 am, at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89 Street. For further information, please call Frank E. Campbell, the Funeral Chapel, 212-288-3500.

title: Brazil chief received funds from Cuba, report alleges
Blast Aimed at U.S. Convoy Kills Afghan
description: An Afghan civilian was killed and four others were wounded when a bomb apparently aimed at a United States military convoy exploded on the edge of the eastern city of Jalalabad, a police official said. The bomb was on a bicycle and went off at noon, just after the convoy had passed. There were no American casualties, said a spokesman for the Jalalabad police chief.

title: Separated at the Bench
description: Madison, Wis. - NO sooner did we learn that President Bush had chosen Samuel Alito to replace Justice Sandra Day O'Connor on the Supreme Court than commentators began blurting: "Scalito!" Judge Alito, a man of stellar credentials and 15 years on the federal bench, has long endured the witticism that connects his lyrical surname to that of Justice Antonin Scalia. The names blend mellifluously and both men are considered conservatives, so why should we give up the clever nickname?

title: Paul Reynard, 78, Art Teacher And Painter in New York, Dies
description: Correction Appended

title: 4 Prisoners Die as Kyrgyz Troops Quell Jail Disorders
description: MOLDOVANOVKA, Kyrgyzstan, Nov. 1 - Special forces soldiers stormed prisons in this Central Asian nation today, restoring at least the appearance of order to a federal penitentiary system that had partly slipped from government control last month. Four prisoners were killed, the authorities said.

title: The President's Myths
description: To the Editor:

title: Asia and Mideast help lift UBS 71%
Accounting complaint in a Spanish utility takeover battle
7 More U.S. Deaths in Iraq End a Lethal Month
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Oct. 31 - The military announced the deaths of seven American soldiers and marines near Baghdad on Monday, making October the fourth deadliest month for troops here since the war began.

title: The Digital Money Mill
description: Now looms a wolfish assault in sheep's clothing: the Online Freedom of Speech Act, which House Republican leaders are suddenly planning to put to a vote on Wednesday so politicians can abuse the Internet as an unregulated outlet for multimillion-dollar advertising campaigns. The bill, put on a fast track in the hope that nobody notices outside the political-industrial complex, would exempt the Internet from the hard-won three-year-old reform law that stopped federal officials from tapping corporations, unions and fat cats for unregulated donations in the quid pro quo marketplace.

title: Cuba Accused of Illegal Campaign Gifts in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 31 - During Luiz Incio Lula da Silva's successful presidential campaign in 2002, his Workers' Party received up to $3 million in illegal campaign contributions from the government of Cuba, according to the cover story in the current issue of Brazil's leading weekly newsmagazine.

title: Earnings: Americas bolster net
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Wal-Mart Recruits Political Veterans As a Rapid-Response Team to Critics Seeking to maintain a positive image, particularly among middle-class consumers, Wal-Mart is taking a page from the modern political playbook. Under fire from well-organized opponents who have hammered the retailer over its wages, health insurance and treatment of workers, Wal-Mart has quietly recruited former presidential advisers to set up a rapid-response public relations team in Arkansas. [Page A1.]

title: Briefly: In hint at succession, Koizumi fills key posts
A Warning to Syria
description: The Bush administration was wise to choose multilateral diplomacy over divisive belligerence yesterday in the United Nations Security Council's vote on Syria. As a result, the Council sent a strong and unanimous demand that Damascus stop stonewalling the inquiry into last February's murder of a former Lebanese prime minister, Rafik Hariri.

title: Taking a Cue From Four Novelists
description: Melissa Briggs's "Book Dances" is intriguingly conceived. Four scenes from four famous novels are staged in different parts of the First Unitarian Church in Brooklyn Heights and presented in turn to four circulating groups from the audience. Happily, on Saturday night, the effect was as interesting as the premise. Ms. Briggs does not try to recreate literal scenes from her chosen novels -- Tolstoy's "Anna Karenina," Steinbeck's "East of Eden," Ayn Rand's "Fountainhead" and J. D. Salinger's "Franny and Zooey" -- but rather uses certain themes or narrative threads as inspiration for highly pictorial, choreographic tableaus.

title: Love connections of yore
Patient applications flood worldwide stem cell research center
Dispute Leaves U.S. Executive in Chinese Legal Netherworld
description: BEIJING, Oct. 31 - David Ji, a Chinese-American electronics entrepreneur, spent two months in custody enduring all-night interrogation sessions, but his stubbornness and occasional flashes of sarcasm infuriated his Chinese captors.

title: Corrections
description: The TV Watch column last Tuesday, about "The Colbert Report" on Comedy Central, misstated the "word of the day" invented for the show's feature "The Word." It was "truthiness," not "trustiness."

title: Centuries of warming envisioned for globe
The Mets Keep Trachsel, but They Pass on Looper
description: The Mets allowed a glimpse into their off-season thinking yesterday when they declined reliever Braden Looper's option and exercised that of Steve Trachsel.

title: Hungarian Courtship Rites With Plenty of Rough Stuff
description: The csardas folk dance caused quite a stir 200 years ago in Central Europe, according to the Hungarian expert Kalman Dreisziger. Perhaps all those skirt-swirling women and boot-slapping men brought uncomfortable visions of lusty Gypsies to aristocratic minds more accustomed to waltzes and polkas.

title: Is New York Worth a Trip? Oui
description: IT may have been only one more review among many, but when Michelin announced its first ratings for restaurants in New York City yesterday morning, superstar chefs and proprietors reacted with joyous tears, resignation and, in some cases, dismay.

title: Some Victims Untreated Three Weeks After Quake
description: Correction Appended

title: Physics Laureate Hopes to Help Students Over the Science Blahs
description: BOULDER, Colo. - The Nobel laureate Carl E. Wieman may have won the highest honor in science, but he spends a big part of his life teaching physics to undergraduates at the University of Colorado.

title: Lenovo posts profit gain after deal with IBM
News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: The Arts, Briefly; 'Anatomy' Is Destiny
description: Even without a new episode of "Desperate Housewives" on its schedule, ABC beat all the other networks on Sunday. Its "Grey's Anatomy," during which Meredith (Ellen Pompeo) found out that Dr. Shepherd (Patrick Dempsey, below) was ditching her to go back to his wife, was the night's most popular show, with an estimated 17.09 million viewers. That was the comedic hospital soap opera's smallest audience of the season, but since its lead-in, "Housewives" (14.79 million), was a rerun, its ratings represented the ability of "Grey's" to stand alone. "Extreme Makeover: Home Edition" (16.8 million) also contributed to ABC's victory. It drew the second highest 18-to-49 rating for the night ("Grey's" topped that category). Without a new "Housewives" to contend with at 9 p.m., a repeat of "Law & Order: Criminal Intent" (13.8 million) brought in that show's best ratings in more than seven months and helped NBC place second among total viewers over all. Fox was No. 2 in the 18-to-49 demographic, helped by a football spillover into prime time. For computer-bound fans of television news, NBC plans to broadcast its "Nightly News" online at MSNBC.com beginning at 10 p.m. Eastern Time on Monday. KATE AURTHUR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAFTER, MARIONELISE
description: RAFTER--Marionelise. Of Bay Shore, NY, formerly of West Islip, NY, died at home with her family on October 30, 2005. Beloved wife of James Philbin, devoted mother to her four daughters, Anne (AJ) Schmidt, Elizabeth Rafter Cibley, Kathryn Rafter and Susan Rafter. Loving grandmother to Cyndi Asch, Cathy Poe, John Schmidt, Carol Downey, Maggie Lampasona, Casey Cousins and Chip Schmidt. She also leaves behind nine cherished great grandchildren, and many loving friends. Marionelise attended St. Lawrence University, received a B.S. from Columbia University, and graduated from the Presbyterian Hospital School of Nursing where she became a faculty member. While raising her family, she kept active in nursing through volunteer work for the Red Cross-organizing blood drives and running blood pressure screening clinics, and volunteering at Good Samaritan Hospital -- training nurses' aides and sitting on the Good Samaritan College Scholarship selection committee. She was also an active member of the Babylon Yacht Club and the Babylon Business and Professional Womens Association. Friends are invited to a memorial service to be held at Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Highway, West Islip on Thursday, November 3, 2005 from 11 AM -12 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Good Shepherd Hospice, 4747-20 Nesconset Highway, Port Jefferson Station, New York 11776.

title: Sports Briefing: PRO BASKETBALL; PLANINIC TO STAY WITH NETS
description: The Nets exercised their fourth-year option on guard Zoran Planinic yesterday, meaning he will be signed through the 2006-7 season. General Manager Ed Stefanski said the Nets were pleased with the improvement that Planinic, a 6-foot-7 Croat, has shown over the past two seasons. The Nets hope that Planinic, whom they drafted with the 22nd pick in the 2003 draft, will become a more consistent player. He can play on the wing, but he also has the ball-handling skills to play point guard. "The key word we've always talked about Z is being consistent," Stefanski said. Center Jason Collins participated in his first full-speed practice yesterday after sitting out the past two and a half weeks to recover from knee surgery and said he would try to play in tomorrow night's season opener at home against the Milwaukee Bucks. Gordon Chiesa, a Nets assistant, resigned, citing family considerations. John Eligon

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KING, LUCINDA S.
description: KING--Lucinda S. Age 96, formerly of Honolulu, on October 30th, 2005, in Manhattan. Service Friday, November 4th, 7PM at Broadway United Church of Christ, Broadway at 93rd Street, NYC.

title: Briefly: 3 people are stabbed near the White House
Paid Notice: Deaths   GARY, ARTHUR JAMES
description: GARY--Arthur James. A former NBC broadcaster, died at his home in New York City Monday October 31, 2005. He was 91 years old. The cause was leukemia, said his wife, Rosemary Chodorov Gary. During the glorious days of radio, and on into the television era, the sonorous voice of Arthur Gary could be heard broadcasting everything from news to weekly dramas. His work spanned from 1936 to 1984. Born in New York in 1914, he graduated from New York University and became part of the growth of the communications industry under the leadership of David Sarnoff. A private memorial will be announced at a later date.

title: What Is Organic? Powerful Players Want a Say
description: Customers at McDonald's restaurants in New England are about to get something a little different when they order coffee. Through a deal with Green Mountain Coffee Roasters and Newman's Own, McDonald's will soon be serving a coffee that comes from organic beans and is certified Fair Trade because it meets higher standards in the treatment of coffee workers.

description: Woody Allen on Woody Allen

title: Panel Recommends Major Tax Law Changes
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 - President Bush's advisory commission on taxes unanimously recommended a vastly simplified tax system today that would limit the deduction of interest payments on large mortgages and erase other tax breaks that many Americans enjoy.

title: Traces from bombs tested in New Delhi
Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, DANIEL M.
description: COHEN -- Daniel M. Ave Atque Vale. Best of the Best. Beloved husband of Hon. Maxine K. Duberstein, father of Elizabeth and Cathrine, grandfather to Joshua and Jessica Troy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LICHTENBERG, HAROLD G.
description: LICHTENBERG--Harold G. June 2, 1924 to October 30, 2005 of Woodmere, New York and Boca Raton, Florida. Devoted husband of the late Laura. Loving father of Maxine Gerson, Jeffrey, Peter (Jamie) and Susie Blumenfeld (Todd) and PopPop to Jessica, Jordan, Ryan, Brett, Nicole, Katie & Jennie. Veteran of WW II. He was the owner of Lichtenberg Buick for over forty years and past president of the 5 Boro Buick Dealers. A Queens College graduate. Devoted to family, friends, loyal employees and the St. Louis Cardinals. HGL, we will love you and miss you forever.

title: Stormy, Courtly or Mercurial, as the Occasion Warrants
description: The Mandelring Quartet, from Germany, has won a handful of prizes since the early 1990's and has made a handful of recordings that range from standard repertory to rarities by Georges Onslow and contemporary works by Berthold Goldschmidt and Allan Pettersson. It should be better known in the United States, and the Frick Collection has been doing its part on the quartet's behalf: on Sunday afternoon, the collection presented it in its round chamber music room for the third time since 1994.

title: Corrections
description: The Critics' Choice column yesterday about new CD's included a publicist's erroneous reference to the label for "All That I Am," by Santana. The album is on Arista, not J.

title: Another Lost Opportunity
description: The nomination of Samuel Alito Jr. to the Supreme Court raises a lot of questions about the judge's attitudes toward federalism, privacy and civil rights. But it has already answered one big question about President Bush. Anyone wondering whether the almost endless setbacks and embarrassments the White House has suffered over the last year would cause Mr. Bush to fix his style of governing should realize that the answer is: no.

title: Koreas may unify teams for Olympics and Asia Games

description: Ending a 17-year-old case that somehow mixed psychotherapy, heavy metal, a globe-trotting private eye and an Upper West Side homeless shelter, the former manager of the glam-rock band Kiss agreed yesterday to pay $162,000 to his former wife.

description: Who and what is Wigan Athletic, and what is it doing in second place in the English Premier League, 9 points behind the defending champion Chelsea and ahead of the heavy hitters Manchester United and Arsenal?

title: A Romantic Shostakovich Beside the Older, Dour One
description: Shostakovich lived two lives in music: one to survive in a public world, the other to survive in a private one. The first saved his neck, the second his sanity. If the bigger pieces made their way between personal conviction and Soviet orthodoxy, it was the chamber music, some of it not intended for immediate public consumption, that allowed the composer to keep his thoughts to himself.

description: Sprint Nextel will announce a deal to offer cellphone services with the nation's three largest cable television operators as early as tomorrow, according to people briefed on the deal.

Mr. Bloomberg has released his first confrontational advertisement of the campaign, and Mr. Ferrer introduced his toughest television commercial against the incumbent.

title: U.S. Army Helicopter Apparently Fired On in Pakistan

description: New York University is facing a strike next week by its graduate student teaching assistants, who lost their union representation in August and are trying to win it back.

description: ESTORIL, Portugal, Oct. 31 - There has not been much excitement in the quarterfinals of the world bridge championships here, though two teams from the Netherlands had close calls Monday.

Guests include Earth, Wind & Fire (above), Alicia Keys, Usher and Mary J. Blige.

title: Torture's role in Chinese justice
Corrections
description: A contents entry in Weekend on Friday about a proposal for a joint venture with the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation to build a museum in Hong Kong misidentified the French museum involved. It is the Pompidou Center, not the Louvre.

title: Diseases Now in the Past, and New Ones Up Ahead
description: We owe it all to the milkmaids. In 1796, when smallpox was rampant, Edward Jenner noticed that the women who milked cows for a living contracted cowpox on their hands but seemed never to come down with deadly smallpox. He wondered if the milder illness protected them from the killer disease, and the idea for vaccines was born (vaccinia being the name of a virus that causes cowpox).

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Lottery Grand Prizes Backed By Guarantee
description: The state lottery commission adopted rules guaranteeing that grand prize winners would be paid no less than the advertised jackpot and possibly more should ticket sales exceed expectations. Jackpots falling short of the advertised prize would be made whole by transferring receipts from smaller lotteries, the commission said. The commission's top manager resigned this year after he acknowledged inflating estimates of the grand prize in an effort to encourage ticket sales, which had been sagging. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Growth in Business Travel Seen
description: GROWTH IN BUSINESS TRAVEL SEEN -- Business travel continues to rebound, and increased globalization is driving demand for long-haul air travel and international hotel space, American Express Business Travel said last week in its annual forecast. One highlight was that domestic published coach air fares should rise 5 to 8 percent next year over this year's average. That is partly because airlines, including those in bankruptcy protection, have cut domestic schedules and capacity, said Prashanth Kuchibhotla, the senior manager for air procurement for eClipse Advisers, an American Express subsidiary. Another trend, he said, is that business travelers are seeing some changes in policy as corporate travel departments -- reacting to a simplification in fare structures begun by Delta Air Lines and matched by major rivals early this year -- are allowing more use of unrestricted, fully refundable tickets.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Five Hurt In Upper East Side Fire
description: Five people were injured and dozens of residents were forced to flee their homes when flames engulfed an apartment at a high-rise on the Upper East Side early last evening, fire officials said. The blaze broke out about 5:45 p.m. in the living room of a ninth-floor apartment at 65 East 96th Street and was brought under control a half-hour after firefighters arrived at the scene, officials said. In all, 78 firefighters battled the fire, which halted traffic on 96th Street between Madison and Park Avenues at the height of the evening rush, officials said. Three of the people treated at local hospitals for minor injuries were firefighters, The cause of the fire remained under investigation last night. Fernanda Santos (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Drug Combination For Flu Is Proposed
description: Scarce supplies of the antiviral drug Tamiflu might be extended as much as 100 percent by using it in combination with a second drug in the event of a pandemic of influenza, the journal Nature reported. That drug is probenecid, which has been used since World War II to increase the longevity of antibiotics and other drugs in the body by slowing their excretion in urine. The journal credited the proposal to Dr. Joe Howton, medical director at the Adventist Medical Center in Portland, Ore., who said he got the idea recently after reading a 2002 study on drug interactions by Tamiflu's manufacturer, Roche. But Dick Thompson, a spokesman for the World Health Organization, said, "We need a lot more data before we can draw any public health recommendations based on this idea," and added that investigations of ways to extend use of Tamiflu had shown "nothing tangible." Lawrence K. Altman (NYT)

title: Colombia Government Threatens Death Squad
description: Colombia's government, embarrassed by disclosures that its secret police unit was preparing to sell intelligence to right-wing paramilitaries, warned that it would begin military strikes against the largest death squad, the United Self-Defense Forces of Colombia, unless it disarmed by the end of the year. The group suspended demobilizations in October to protest the jailing of one of its leaders, while still trafficking cocaine and infiltrating government institutions, like the secret police. The government's warning came a day after a third high official of the secret police, Enrique Ariza, was forced to resign. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PIFER, ALAN
description: PIFER--Alan. We deeply mourn the loss of Alan Pifer, past president of Carnegie Corporation of New York, who passed away on October 31 at the age of 84. Throughout Pifer's career, his focus was on social justice and the rights of disadvantaged groups, including women. In particular, beginning in the 1970s, Pifer was instrumental in reinstituting Carnegie Corporation's involvement in South Africa after a long hiatus and led the foundation in supporting the formation of public interest law projects in South Africa that challenged apartheid policies. These organizations continue to have a lasting impact on South African society. Pifer formally assumed the Corporation presidency in 1967, succeeding John W. Gardner who left to become HEW Secretary. Under Pifer's leadership, the Corporation renewed its commitment to early childhood education, supporting research and applications of experimental and demonstration programs that later provided evidence of the positive long-term effects of high-quality early education, particularly for disadvantaged students. Carnegie Corporation also promoted educational children's television, which launched Sesame Street. Other landmarks achieved under Pifer's leadership include recommendations from the Carnegie Commission on Educational Television, which were adopted in the Public Broadcasting Act of 1968. After retiring from Carnegie Corporation in 1982, Pifer continued his public service by remaining focused on social inequality, heading the Aging Society Project that studied the social consequences that might develop as America's aging population reached retirement age. Pifer also established the University of Cape Town Fund, which raised funds in the United States to support black students at the South African university and promote activities to aid the advancement and welfare of blacks. Many other organizations and governmental agencies also benefited from his guidance and his wisdom. Pifer was a leader in philanthropy and the nonprofit world, and his legacy will always be insitutional transparency, accountability and the highest ethical standards. Helene Kaplan, Chair, and the Carnegie Corporation of New York Board of Trustees Vartan Gregorian, President, and the staff of Carnegie Corporation of New York Carnegie Corporation of New York Board of Trustees Emeritus

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Audit Report Lifts Yukos Shares
description: Shares of Yukos rose in response to a newspaper report that an early draft of an audit by Deloitte & Touche, which has not been released yet, shows that Siberian oil fields confiscated from Yukos last year amid a tax dispute are worth three times what a state-owned company paid for them. Earlier estimates by Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein and J. P. Morgan Chase had put the fields' value at about twice the $9.4 billion that the state company, Rosneft, paid for a 77 percent stake. The new audit estimates the fields, run by the Yuganskneftegaz production unit, are worth $32 billion, according to the Vedomosti newspaper.

Many viewed him as not just a lame duck but a dead duck. Pundits and politicians predicted that the country would drift aimlessly for the last two years of his term. The Soviet Union would become more adventurous abroad. And a Democrat would next win the presidency.

description: An article and picture caption on Sunday about scandals in the second term of presidencies referred incorrectly in some copies to Vice Adm. John M. Poindexter, who resigned from the Reagan White House in the Iran-contra scandal. He was national security adviser, not chief of staff.

title: New Jersey Is O.K.? Sorry, Slogan Taken
description: O.K., so maybe New Jersey didn't hit the marketing jackpot when it paid a New York image and branding consultant $260,000 for research and a new slogan and ended up with the Rodney Dangerfield of state boasts: "New Jersey: We'll Win You Over." (Apparent runner-up: "New Jersey: Not as Bad as You Think.")

title: Jury Begins to Deliberate Vioxx Case
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 1 - After seven weeks of testimony and often heated legal wrangling, a jury of six women and three men began deliberations here on Tuesday in Humeston v. Merck, the second Vioxx-related lawsuit to go to trial.

title: Prosecution Denied Request in Norman Case
description: The judge in the corruption case against Clarence Norman Jr., the former Brooklyn Democratic Party leader, denied yesterday the prosecution's request to tell the jury at Mr. Norman's approaching trial about two accusations of wrongdoing for which he was never charged.

title: China setting new limits on bank ownership
Toshiba Takes a Risk to Push Its DVD Technology
description: TOKYO - In the high-stakes battle with Sony over whose format will power the next generation of DVD players, Toshiba has adopted a potentially perilous strategy: encouraging low-cost Chinese competitors to crank out machines using its standard, known as HD-DVD.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Saturday with an article about Wal-Mart's efforts to provide health care to more employees misstated the surname of the patient at a clinic in a Wal-Mart store near Orlando, Fla. He is Josh Hashbarger, not Reyes.

title: Letter from New York: Battle against bird flu must start at its source
Johnson Threatens to Drop Plan to Buy Guidant
description: Johnson & Johnson said today that it would abandon its $25.4 billion plan to buy the Guidant Corporation unless the manufacturer of heart devices agrees to substantially renegotiate the terms of that deal.

title: Text of Fed Statement on Interest Rates
description: Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Fed's monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to raise its benchmark interest rates a quarter-point:
