title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BECKHARD, VERA
description: BECKHARD--Vera, 93, died in her home peacefully on November 1. A Holocaust survivor, she is survived by her cherished family; daughter Eva, her son and daughtersin-law Jerry, Ellie and Margo; her eight grandchildren, Susan, Ellen, Karen, Richard, Anita, Tom, Liz and Jane, and her nine great-grandchildren, Kim, Lisa, Julia, Aaron, Adam, Olivia, Alex, Carter and Bobby. She was loving, strong, and an inspiration. Always loved, she will be forever missed. Funeral service, Riverside Memorial Chapel on November 3 at 11:30AM.

title: Broadway's One-Night Stand With Elvis Costello as Muse
description: Old stereotypes die hard. A picture of the Broadway performer as an innocent, apple-cheeked goody-goody caroling "The Sound of Music" has been synonymous with Broadway for so long that a sickly aura of sweetness and light still hovers around the image of the modern theater singer.

title: Honoring Rosa Parks
description: To the Editor:

title: Detainee Policy Sharply Divides Bush Officials
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 - The Bush administration is embroiled in a sharp internal debate over whether a new set of Defense Department standards for handling terror suspects should adopt language from the Geneva Conventions prohibiting "cruel," "humiliating" and "degrading" treatment, administration officials say.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mount Vernon: Ex-Official Charged With Forgery
description: A retired state liquor authority investigator, Joseph Penn, of Yonkers, has been charged with second-degree forgery. Jeanine F. Pirro, the Westchester County district attorney, said that Mr. Penn sold a fake temporary operating permit for about $1,800 to a Mount Vernon business owner who did not know the permit was fake. Mr. Penn has pleaded not guilty. Anahad O'Connor (NYT)

title: Locations: Lands of Milk, Nuts and Ghee
description: HERE are some places in the New York metropolitan area to buy good mithai:

title: Outcry as Jakarta tries to revive paper industry
National Briefing | Washington: Ohio Republican To Retire
description: Representative Michael G. Oxley, an Ohio Republican who is chairman of the House Financial Services Committee, said he would not seek re-election next year. Mr. Oxley, left, who has served 25 years in Congress, became the head of the committee in 2001. Along with Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, a Democrat from Maryland, who also announced his retirement this year after nearly three decades on Capitol Hill, Mr. Oxley helped write broad legislation in 2002 that called for companies to be more accountable and transparent in their business and financial practices. Mr. Oxley, 61, was a lawyer and a special agent in the Federal Bureau of Investigation before being elected to represent the Fourth District of Ohio in 1981. John Files (NYT)

title: Blair ally quits cabinet a 2nd time amid scandal
UBS Posts 71% Profit Increase on Rise in Oil-Related Wealth
description: GENEVA, Nov. 1 - UBS, Europe's largest bank, reported a 71 percent increase in third-quarter profit Tuesday, benefiting from a boom in oil-related wealth in the Middle East and Asia.

title: Democrats force closed Senate session on Iraq inquiry
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: American Automakers' Market Share Slips to Lowest U.S. Level in History General Motors, Ford and Chrysler held the smallest share of the American auto market ever in October, a month that used to be an industrywide celebration of new car introductions and brisk sales. [Page C1.]

title: Corrections
description: A credit last Wednesday with a recipe for meat stock and piccolo bollito misto, with an article about cooking with bones, misspelled the given name of the cookbook author who created it. He is Giuliano Hazan, as the article said, not Guiliano.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANKEL, JEROME
description: FRANKEL - Jerome. We mourn the loss of our dear friend and send our heartfelt condolences to his family. The Solomon Schechter School of Queens

title: Iraqi Government Asks Hussein's Officers to Return to Military
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 2 - The Iraqi government called today for the return of junior officers from the disbanded army of Saddam Hussein, openly reversing a controversial American directive issued in 2003.

title: The Polite Way To Find the Olive In Your Martini
description: In the 1920's, fanciful party picks were all the rage; flappers skewered the olives in their martinis with them. At the Triple Pier Antiques Show this weekend and next, dealers will sell vintage cocktail picks in sets with whimsical holders, made in France, like the carved leaf with silver picks, left. Others include a miniature bar with picks topped with tiny highball glasses. These sets are rare and often costly, at $90 to $1,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVI, HAROLD H. III.
description: LEVI--Harold H. III. Age 66 of Armonk, NY and Jupiter, FL, on October 31, 2005. Devoted husband of Ann. Loving father of Andy and Loren and father-in-law of Cindy and Neil. Brother of Douglas and Michael. Proud Poppie of Jared, Chase, Harris, Jordan and Charlie. His love of his family will always be remembered by everyone who knew him. We love you "H" and will miss you forever. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, November 3, at Congregation Emanu-El in Rye, NY at 11 AM. The family will be sitting on Thursday and Friday. Contributions may be made to a cancer charity of your choice.

title: Candidates Sharpen Barbs in Discussing Dropout Rate
description: In their debate, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg clashed with his opponent, Fernando Ferrer, on the dropout rate in New York City schools after being questioned on the issue by Jay DeDapper of WNBC-TV, Channel 4, in reference to remarks on the issue by the schools chancellor, Joel I. Klein.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Nortel Settles Dispute Over Chief
description: Nortel Networks will pay Motorola $11.5 million to settle a lawsuit against its new chief executive, Mike S. Zafirovski. Motorola filed the suit against Mr. Zafirovski, who resigned as its president and chief operating officer in January, contending that his new position at Nortel violated a separation agreement. Nortel said late Monday that Motorola had withdrawn the case in exchange for the payment and a long list of conditions. Among other things, Mr. Zafirovski, who begins on Nov. 15, will not be able to hire Motorola employees or deal with some Nortel customers who also buy equipment from Motorola until July 2006.

title: What to Do With a Wine of Many Flavors? Add Another Flavor
description: TOO bad the season for black truffles is still a month or two away. I would love to use them in a dish to complement the California Rhone blends. The first whiff of several of the wines suggested fresh black truffles to me.

title: Key rates
description: In percent

title: Judge Deals a Setback to Grasso
description: A New York state judge indicated yesterday that he would deny a motion by Richard A. Grasso, the former New York Stock Exchange chairman, to limit a lawsuit that seeks the return of more than $100 million of Mr. Grasso's compensation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEYER, TRUDE (NEE NASSAU)
description: MEYER--Trude (nee Nassau) January 1, 1910, at 95. Beloved mother of Rita and Ronny Meyer. Devoted wife of Allen. Loving daughter of Rose and Louis Nassau and Tetta to Lewis and Harold Nassau. Charter member and former vice president of neighborhood chapter of B'nai B'rith and member of the East Midwood Jewish Center. Kind and caring friend to so many. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, November 3 at 11 A.M. at Sherman's Funeral Home, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, between Avenue I and J, in Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISL, EDWIN L., JR.
description: WEISL--Edwin L., Jr. The Robert Lehman Foundation, its Directors and Associates, and the staff of the Robert Lehman Collection at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, mourn the death of our beloved colleague. Eddie brought to life a multifaceted, informed enthusiasm that was the wonder and envy of us all, along with a great courage in the face of an implacable illness. He was trained as a lawyer, but it was in the study of Late Medieval and Early Renaissance Italian painting that he found his joy and vocation, both as a scholar and connoisseur in his own right, and as a patron of a number of notable scholarly efforts in the field. It is perhaps our greatest sorrow that Eddie did not live to see the great Fra Angelico exhibition now in the Lehman Wing at the Metropolitan Museum, a show that would have excited his every instinct as scholarconnoisseur, although he was at least able to see and discuss the catalogue. Our condolences go out to his family and friends, most especially his daughter-and our colleague--Angela. We won't ever forget him. Philip H. Isles, President, Robert Lehman Foundation Laurence Kanter, Curator, Robert Lehman Collection, Metropolitan Museum of Art

title: 2 New Approaches May Reduce Cervical Cancer Deaths for Poor
description: For women with a high risk of cervical cancer and limited access to health care, two new, simplified types of screening may be more useful than the usual preventive methods, doctors are reporting today.

title: Welcome to Oklahoma. Please Stay Awhile.
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 1 - As J. R. Smith punctuated his breakaway with a reverse jam to give the Hornets a 20-point lead over the Sacramento Kings in the third quarter, the capacity crowd jumped from its seats and let loose a rim-rattling yell that had been building for weeks, if not years.

title: Two Companies Differ in Style but Not in Brio
description: Correction Appended

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Recent Sale $15.25 million

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Increase In New York City Work Fatalities
description: More workers were killed in New York City last year than in 2003, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. A bureau report said that 107 people were killed at work in 2004 -- up from 94 in 2003, but still far fewer than the 191 killed in 1993, the highest number since the survey started in 1992. Homicide was the leading cause last year, responsible for 29 fatalities. Falls, which caused 19 deaths, were second, followed by 15 suicides. With 28 deaths, construction workers had the most fatalities, followed by retail workers, with 13, and accommodation and food service employees, with 12.

title: Microsoft Introduces Web Services, Competing With Google and Yahoo
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1 - Microsoft introduced on Tuesday two new advertising-supported Web services, Windows Live and Office Live, as a direct response to the formidable challenges posed by its major competitors, Google and Yahoo.

title: (No Fury Like) A Valley Girl Scorned
description: Jason, the cad who famously leaves his wife, Medea, for a younger woman, has been portrayed over the last two millenniums as, among other things, a social climber, a politician and a hunk. But the Jean Cocteau Repertory's strained production of the Euripides tragedy may be the first time that he evokes a singer from a heavy metal band.

title: In Cheney's New Chief, a Bureaucratic Master
description: Correction Appended

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bids Cleared for Stock Exchange
description: British regulators opened the door to a takeover of the London Stock Exchange. After a seven-month review, the Competition Commission said that either the pan-European exchange Euronext or Deutsche Brse of Germany could acquire the London exchange, as long as they maintained the independence of the exchange's back-office clearing functions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ELKIN, MILTON, M.D.
description: ELKIN--Milton, M.D. Beloved husband of the late Gloria Elkin. Loving father of Phil Elkin, Karen Segall and Laura Friedman, and grandfather of David, Michael, Suzanna, Steven, Jessica and Craig. Services will be held at 9:30 AM on Thursday, November 3, at Chapel in the Woods, Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave., White Plains, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association.

title: German Social Democrats Choose New Leader
description: BERLIN, Nov.2 - Germany's Social Democrats moved swiftly today to try to limit the political damage of the past 48 hours by nominating a new, moderate leader from eastern Germany, and Angela Merkel's conservatives, contending with their own dramas, breathed an almost palpable sigh of relief.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Proposal For 39-Cent Stamps
description: The Postal Rate Commission recommended a 2-cent rate increase for first-class stamps, to 39 cents from 37 cents. The recommendation, which must also be approved by the Board of Governors at the Postal Service, is expected to take effect early next year. The service said in April that it needed a broad 5.4 percent rate increase, which would also include raising the cost of sending other types of mail, to offset rising costs and because Congress has required that it place $3.1 billion a year into an escrow fund. The service, which has sought to block that requirement, said in September that it would record a $1.8 billion deficiency in 2006. Mailing rates last increased in June 2002. John Files (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: U.S. Helicopter May Have Taken Fire
description: A United States Army helicopter aiding the earthquake relief effort reported that it might have been fired on in the Pakistani-controlled part of Kashmir, and both the American military and the Pakistani government are investigating, the American Embassy said. The helicopter, a CH-47 Chinook cargo aircraft, was carrying aid supplies when the crew spotted what appeared to be a rocket-propelled grenade fired from the ground. The helicopter was not hit. Pakistani officials said the helicopter crew might have seen a blast from dynamite being used to clear blocked roads in the area. Salman Masood (NYT)

title: Thousands Pay Final Respects to Rosa Parks in Detroit
description: Rosa Parks, the unassuming seamstress whose small act of defiance on a city bus 50 years ago helped spark the modern civil rights movement, was memorialized today in Detroit in a lavish funeral service attended by thousands of dignitaries and ordinary people.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEILAND, IRVING
description: WEILAND - Irving. Passed away on October 27, 2005. He was the beloved husband of the late Anne Weiland and devoted father of Andrew, Edward, and Ellen Williams. He was the cherished grandfather of Sarah Holland, Dan Weiland, Jeffrey Weiland, Sophie Williams and Julia Williams. He was the greatgrandfather of Lucy Holland, Ella Holland and Audrey Holland. He was a humanist and role model for his family and friends. His intelligence and unconditional love will be missed by all of us. Private services were held Sunday, October 30, 2005.

title: A presence to savorin 'As You Desire Me'
In the Fief of the Assads, Friends Melt Away
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, Nov. 1 - Syrian officials have been saying for years that they have closed down all the offices of Palestinian factions working here in the capital city, as the United States and the Europeans, among others, have insisted. They are all gone, they say: Hamas, Islamic Jihad, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine and others.

title: China halts poultry, related imports from 14 countries
Endre Marton, 95, Dies; Reported on the '56 Uprising in Hungary
description: Endre Marton, a prize-winning journalist who sent the first account of the Hungarian uprising of 1956 just weeks after serving a year in prison for covering the events preceding it, died yesterday at the home of a daughter in Manhattan. He was 95.

title: Charles and Camilla, in Low-Key U.S. Debut
description: Prince Charles and Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall, co-stars in the longest-running British entertainment since "Upstairs Downstairs" and now one that the children can finally be permitted to watch, began a week's visit to the United States in New York yesterday, their first official overseas tour since their marriage last April.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Winner Certified In Surrogate Race
description: The New York City Board of Election said yesterday that it had recertified Margarita Lpez Torres as the winner of a Brooklyn Surrogate Court judgeship. The board said she won by 205 votes over Diana A. Johnson, a State Supreme Court justice. Ms. Lpez Torres, a Criminal Court judge, was certified as the winner last month by 102 votes. But the State Supreme Court's Appellate Division, ruling on a suit brought by Ms. Johnson, ordered a recount of about 900 disputed ballots. The recount doubled the victory margin. Jonathan P. Hicks (NYT)

title: British government offers concessions on anti-terror bill
Judge in DeLay Case Is Ordered to Recuse Himself
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 1 - A Texas judge opposed by Representative Tom DeLay as a partisan Democrat was removed from hearing Mr. DeLay's money-laundering and conspiracy case on Tuesday after a courtroom battle over his impartiality.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SMITH, RICHARD B., ESQ.
description: SMITH--Richard B., Esq. November 2, 2003 Most beloved and always in my heart. PHS

title: Tea at the Carlyle, for the Very Small
description: Several afternoons a week, Bemelmans Bar in the Carlyle hotel on upper Madison Avenue is for children (and their adult guests). Ludwig Bemelmans, who decorated the room, wrote the Madeline children's books. So among the lunch and afternoon tea offerings are 12 little shrimps in two straight lines, just like the girls in the books. There are also an Eiffel Tower sundae, piano music and storytelling. The Madeline Experience, from noon to 4 p.m. Wednesdays through Sundays, is $30 a person: (212) 744-1600.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Debut For Electronic Passports
description: Germany has begun to issue new electronic passports with biometric data, the Interior Ministry said. The new "e-Pass" contains a digital photograph on a chip; starting in March 2007, the chip will also feature fingerprints. Germany is one of the first European countries to issue the new passports, which the United States requires visitors to carry for visa-free visits. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: An Elevator to Your Floor, With No Local Stops
description: Correction Appended

title: Aetna to Pay for Program to Manage Depression
description: A widely tested approach to diagnosing and treating depression, one of the nation's most prevalent and costliest afflictions, is moving into the mainstream of insurance coverage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ELLIOTT, JOHN JR.
description: ELLIOTT -- John Jr. The Browning School notes with sadness the death of "Jock" Elliott '38. With his brother "Oz" '41, he was a mainstay of the Browning Alumni Association and a living link to the school's past. Their father, John Elliott '08, was one of John A. Browning's first students. Jock's generosity of spirit and civic commitment will be deeply missed. James S. Chanos President of the Board Stephen M. Clement, III Headmaster Jeffrey M. Landes '83 President, Alumni Assoc.

title: Ex-Official at Wal-Mart Wins Ruling
description: A judge in Arkansas yesterday tossed out part of Wal-Mart's lawsuit against its former vice chairman, Thomas M. Coughlin, citing an agreement that bars the former executive and the company from suing each other. Mr. Coughlin has been accused by Wal-Mart of misusing up to $500,000 of company money.

title: A Fast, Versatile Italian Import
description: TO the list of imported dishes that are easier to make than we Americans have been led to believe, you can add polenta.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Calendar column on Oct. 19 about Poke, a Japanese restaurant on the Upper East Side of Manhattan rated 26 for food in the 2006 Zagat Survey for New York City, misstated the guide's top score. It is 30, not 28.

title: Profit Higher For P.& G. and Colgate
description: The Procter & Gamble Company and the Colgate-Palmolive Company reported higher quarterly profit yesterday as they benefited from raising prices on consumer products.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUTTLEWORTH, EDWIN
description: SHUTTLEWORTH--Edwin. We honor the memory of Ted Shuttleworth, a central figure of the Quogue community for decades, who in addition to his service to the village made all that knew him more aware of nature, the environment, the beauty of our surroundings. Judy and George Carmany

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENFIELD, MAURICE
description: ROSENFIELD--Maurice. Age 91, of Glencoe, IL, Lawyer and Film and Theatrical Producer. Producer of the movie, "Bang The Drum Slowly" and the plays "Barnum" and "Singin' in the Rain"(New York and London) as well as numerous other productions. His wife Lois of 54 years predeceased him two years ago. Father of Andrew (Betsy Bergman) and James; grandfather of Zak, Alex, Lannie and Jake; loving and caring friend of many in Chicago and Palm Springs. Memorial Service Wednesday, 11 A.M. at Am Shalom, 840 Vernon Avenue, Glencoe, IL. In lieu of flowers, contributions to The Ravinia Music Festival Association, 400 Iris Lane, Highland Park 60035. Info., The Goldman Funeral Group, 847-478-1600.

title: Congress Is Warned of Veto If Insurance Funding Is Cut
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 - The Bush administration threatened Tuesday to veto a huge budget bill if Congress withdrew $10 billion set aside for health insurance companies participating in the Medicare program.

title: The Fed Lifts Rates Again, Despite Rise in Fuel Price
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 - Undaunted by back-to-back hurricanes and higher oil prices, the Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates on Tuesday for the 12th time in a row and made it clear that more increases were on the way.

title: Mets Seek Top Closer To Fill Gap In Bullpen
description: Hardly anything is certain about the Mets' off-season plans. It is impossible to tell whether they will acquire the power hitter they want or an experienced first baseman or another catcher. But as soon as the Mets declined Braden Looper's $5.5 million option Monday, they assured themselves of at least one thing: They will enter spring training with someone else as their closer.

title: U.N. Sets Day To Remember The Holocaust
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 1 - The General Assembly adopted a resolution on Tuesday to establish an annual day to commemorate victims of the Holocaust, reject denials that the genocide occurred and urge countries to educate their citizens about the World War II killings.

title: Astronomers Say They Are on the Verge of Seeing a Black Hole
description: Astronomers said they had moved one notch closer to seeing the unseeable today.

title: UN access to Iranian atom work reported

description: LICHTENBERG--Harold G. June 2, 1924 to October 30, 2005 of Woodmere, New York and Boca Raton, Florida. Devoted husband of the late Laura. Loving father of Maxine Gerson, Jeffrey, Peter (Jamie) and Susie Blumenfeld (Todd) and PopPop to Jessica, Jordan, Ryan, Brett, Nicole, Katie & Jennie. Veteran of WW II. He was the owner of Lichtenberg Buick for over forty years and past president of the 5 Boro Buick Dealers. A Queens College graduate. Devoted to family, friends, loyal employees and the St. Louis Cardinals. HGL, we will love you and miss you forever.

title: Are Schools Passing or Failing? Now There's a Third Choice ... Both
description: OUR leaders in Washington and the state capitals have not trusted teachers, principals and superintendents to grade and assess their own students rigorously. And so, over the last decade, politicians have enacted many new testing and rating systems -- most notably the federal No Child Left Behind Law in 2002 -- to ensure that there is an accurate and scientific measure of how students and schools perform.

title: Judge Alito: The Right Choice for the Court?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Choreographer Takes a Page From Four Books
description: Melissa Briggs's "Book Dances" is intriguingly conceived. Four scenes from four famous works of fiction are staged in different parts of the First Unitarian Church in Brooklyn Heights and presented in turn to four circulating groups from the audience. Happily, on Saturday night, the effect was as interesting as the premise. Ms. Briggs does not try to recreate literal scenes from her chosen books -- Tolstoy's "Anna Karenina," Steinbeck's "East of Eden," Ayn Rand's "Fountainhead" and J. D. Salinger's "Franny and Zooey" -- but rather uses certain themes or narrative threads as inspiration for highly pictorial choreographic tableaus.

title: Button Up Your Overcoat...
description: THESE days have been uncommonly mild for autumn, but Derek Ivery insists on wearing a sweater and jacket over his tall and very thin frame. He cannot get sick. He has things to do.

title: Briefly: Political turmoil erupts again in deadly protests
Skitch Henderson, 'Tonight' Show Conductor, Dies at 87
description: Skitch Henderson, the conductor, pianist and radio and television entertainer who provided both music and repartee for the "Tonight" show from 1954 to 1966 and who founded and led the New York Pops , died on Tuesday at his home in New Milford, Conn. He was 87.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the James Beard Foundation's new board of trustees misspelled the surname of a member, the president of Clicquot Inc. She is Mireille Guiliano, not Giuliano.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "This is a period when we've just got to take the medicine and swallow it."

title: Corzine's Mix: BoldAmbitions, Rough Edges

title: A New York First for a Key Figure in Kenyan Running
description: As running goes, Paul Tergat was relatively old when he ran in his first race, at 20, and in his first major international competition three years later.

title: Inquiry on Lobbyist Widens to Senior Officials; Senate Hearing Is Today
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 - Investigators have expanded their inquiries into the activities of the lobbyist Jack Abramoff to include his efforts to pressure Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton and other senior Interior Department officials on behalf of Indian tribes with gambling interests, lawyers involved in the investigations said in interviews this week.

title: InterActive Profit Off
description: IAC/InterActiveCorp, the television and Internet-services company led by Barry Diller, said yesterday that third-quarter profit fell 25 percent on costs of spinning off the Expedia travel business.

title: Two Men Who Did the Right Thing
description: It was simple on its face, but as deeply layered as the gesture it memorialized.

title: Detecting Tutor's Hand in Applicant's Essay
description: It is the bane of college admissions officers: the highly polished, professionally edited personal essay that barely reflects the thinking or writing, let alone the personality, of a 17-year-old high school student.

title: Audiences Love a Minimalist Ring Cycle; Critics Arent Sure
description: PARIS, Nov. 1 - Productions of Wagner's "Ring des Nibelungen" have one thing in common: rarely do director, designer, conductor, orchestra and singers all emerge unscathed. The reason is simple. Audiences and critics often embark on this four-opera cycle with firm views on how its immense musical and mythical universe should look and sound.

title: Honoring Rosa Parks
description: To the Editor:

title: Vanguard triples fund investment minimum
Arts, Briefly; ABC Wins With Football
description: November sweeps begin tomorrow, and the networks will be pulling out all their tricks to lure viewers. But on Monday, they showed a lot of repeats; viewing was also down because of Halloween. With little original competition, an exciting game on "Monday Night Football" easily led ABC to a victory for the night among total viewers and 18-to-49-year-olds. CBS, normally No. 1 in viewers on Monday, offered only reruns, and came in second. Fox broadcast a new episode of "Prison Break" (8.96 million), preceded by a repeat of that series at 8 p.m. Its audience of 5.4 million was better than the one drawn in that time period by new episodes of "Arrested Development" and "Kitchen Confidential." Week 6 of the fall season ended on Sunday, and CBS placed first among total viewers and among 18-to-49-year-olds. CBS has ranked No. 1 among total viewers all six weeks of the new season, which no network has done since NBC in 1988. KATE AURTHUR

title: For Sale: Our Permanent Collection
description: UNTIL recently, a triad of standing women, signature works in bronze by the Swiss modern sculptor Alberto Giacometti, graced the permanent collection galleries of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. But now only two remain. The third, a likeness of the artist's wife, is one of 42 Impressionist and modern works from its "permanent" collection that the museum plans to sell at Sotheby's today and tomorrow. These sales are the latest sign that we can no longer depend on our cultural institutions to protect and preserve the public patrimony.

title: From the Land of Grapes, A Different Spirit
description: When Leslie Rudd, the owner of Rudd Winery in Oakville, Calif., bought Edge Hill, a winery in St. Helena, Calif., that was founded in 1882, he discovered a building on the land that bore a well-worn sign, Registered Distillery No. 209. That heartened Mr. Rudd, who wanted to make a gin at the winery. "There are 400 vodkas out there, but gin drinkers are neglected," he said.

title: Senators Concerned on Uzbekistan Party Leader
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 1 - Echoing international concern about the arrest and suspected abuse of an opposition leader in Uzbekistan, two American senators introduced a resolution on Tuesday calling on the Uzbek government to ensure that the detained politician is treated fairly and in accordance with his human rights.

title: Viacom, Preparing to Divide Itself, Exceeds Profit Forecast
description: As it prepares to split into two public companies, Viacom announced yesterday that it had swung to a profit for the third quarter. Its revenue also rose, led by strong results at its cable networks unit, which includes MTV and Nickelodeon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LANG, ANICUTSA
description: LANG--Anicutsa. Died October 29, 2005 in Rishon-Lezion, Israel. Beloved wife of Igo; mother of Shlomo and his wife Laura, grandmother of Talia. Services 12:30PM today at Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Paramus, N.J.

title: In Council Race, Surgeon Takes On Former Miller Aide
description: As Joel M. Zinberg asked voters along York Avenue for their support on a recent morning, he was stopped by a woman who asked him the question that has become a staple of his campaign:

title: Jobs and Joblessness on the Gulf Coast
description: The White House announced last week that it would reinstate the Davis-Bacon Act, the law that guarantees that construction workers on federally financed projects be paid at least the minimum prevailing wage. In an executive proclamation shortly after Hurricane Katrina, President Bush had revoked the law's wage protections for workers in storm-struck parts of Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama and Florida. Let's hope this reversal is the start of a trend because more wrongs need righting.

title: Skewering Tradition to Sell a New Battery to the Young
description: PANASONIC is betting that offbeat characters called Oxymites can help pull off a mighty feat: persuade younger consumers to buy a new brand of battery.

title: Risk of Avian Flu Could Send Poultry Indoors
description: THE Agriculture Department is discussing the possibility that poultry raised outdoors -- pasture-raised, free-range or organic -- would have to be confined indoors if the avian flu makes its way to the United States. But some poultry farmers say they will keep their chickens outside.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RONAN, THOMAS P.
description: RONAN--Thomas P., 96. Died on October 31. He retired in 1978 after 35 years as a political reporter and foreign correspondent for The New York Times. This gentle man, famous for his abundance of understanding, insight, wisdom and outstanding professionalism as a journalist, enjoyed warm friendships wherever he worked and lived, which included New York City, London, Rye, New York, and Kennett Square, Philadelphia. He is survived by his wife, Patricia, of Kennett Square, daughters, Catherine and Laura, son Stephen, and two grandchildren, Sophia and Michael. Funeral Mass is at St. Patrick Church, Kennett Square, on Thursday, November 3.

title: U.A.B. Ends Three-Game Skid
description: MEMPHIS, Tenn. (AP) -- Darrell Hackney threw for 334 yards and four touchdowns, and Corey White ran for a career-high 200 yards, leading UAB to a 37-20 victory over Memphis on Tuesday night.

description: WHEN it comes to new computers, the easiest part seems to be whipping out your credit card to pay for it. Unless, of course, you get one as a gift.

title: Australian leader puts nation on terror alert
Open the Vault, My Phone Is Ringing!
description: REMEMBER when merely owning a cellphone set you apart from the crowd? You were a man of mystery. You would set it on the bar and bystanders would eye you enviously. Men would call the bartender over, point to you, and whisper, "I'll have what he's having."

title: A new route into Softbank
Bloomberg Gets Personal in War of Television Ads
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has issued a rare, personal response to a Fernando Ferrer commercial that mockingly paints him as beholden to President Bush, releasing an ad of his own in which he directly tells viewers, "It really comes down to this: I answer to you, the people of New York."

title: The Two Koreas Agree to Field a Unified Olympic Team in 2008
description: TOKYO, Wednesday, Nov. 2 - Moving closer toward their longtime goal of fielding a unified Olympic team, South and North Korea agreed in principle on Tuesday to have their athletes compete together at the 2008 Olympic Games in Beijing.

title: THE BIG 3 WANT A BIG 4TH
description: Jason Kidd, Richard Jefferson and Vince Carter -- the big three on the Nets -- are certainly the team's best players.

title: Icahn Investment in BKF
description: The investor Carl C. Icahn disclosed yesterday that he had purchased a 16 percent stake in the BKF Capital Group, parent company of the money manager John A. Levin & Company, setting off an 11 percent increase in BKF's share price.

title: Climate Study Warns of Warming and Losses of Arctic Tundra
description: If emissions of heat-trapping gases continue to accumulate in the atmosphere at the current rate, there may be many centuries of warming and a near total loss of Arctic tundra, according to a new climate study.

title: To Avert Protests, Bolivia Schedules Presidential Elections
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, Nov. 2 - Resolving a stalemate in Bolivia that threatened to prompt paralyzing protests, President Eduardo RodrAguez decreed Tuesday that elections for president and Congress will be held Dec. 18, paving the way for the political transformation of the isolated Andean country.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCOTT, ZELDA
description: SCOTT--Zelda. On November 1 at age 88. Beloved wife of the late Milton; loving mother of Diana, Stuart, and David, and grandmother of Zoe, Sean, and Joshua; devoted sister of Helen Rosenfield, and the late Ethel Rubinrott, Lottie Wallach, and Sarah Goldstein. Graduate of Brooklyn College, retired administrator at the N.Y. Bank for Savings. Services at Sinai Chapels, Queens, Wednesday 10AM, 718-445-0300.

title: A new route into Softbank
Hardaway, on Inactive List, Still Expects Some Action
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 1 - Toward the end of practice Tuesday, the Knicks separated into two groups and shot baskets at each end of the court. But one player did not seem to fit in. At a third basket, near midcourt, Penny Hardaway practiced alone.

title: Beyond Hope in a Bottle: New Devices Offer Beauty in a Box
description: WELLBOX, a new home-use beauty device for $1,595 that promises to firm up your skin, looks like a vacuum cleaner for the future. Housed in a sleek white pod, it has a suction hose, nozzles of different sizes and a digital control panel that regulates its intensity. Rolled along the face or limbs, the nozzle suctions, compresses and releases the skin; the action is also supposed to break up cellulite.

title: Bush Faces Tough Time in South America
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 1 - If George W. Bush is expecting some respite from his troubles at home during a four-day visit to Argentina and Brazil that begins Thursday, he is in for a very rude awakening.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about plans by Al Jazeera, the Arabic broadcaster, to introduce an English-language news channel mis-stated the maker of "Control Room," a documentary about the network. It was Noujaim Films, not Al Jazeera.

title: Revenge Seen as Motive in Slaying
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 1 - A 25-year-old man was shot to death in the courtyard of a public housing complex here on Monday night, struck in the chest, neck and upper arm by five shots, the police said.

title: Tony Jackson, 65, Who Led St. John's Basketball, Dies
description: Tony Jackson, a brilliant jump shooter and a two-time all-American who led St. John's University to the championships of the National Invitation Tournament and the Holiday Festival in an era when those tournaments showcased college basketball's finest talent, died Friday in Brooklyn. He was 65.

title: Time Warner profit soars and share buyback raised
Sassy, Flippant Charm, With Strings Attached
description: "This is my wedding dress," announced Sheryl Crow, decked out Monday night in a form-fitting white frock, adding, "It's Halloween, right?" The hit maker famous for her wounded but cool insouciance thus dispensed with tabloid buzz about her betrothal to the cyclist Lance Armstrong. But traces of the romance were noticeable. Ms. Crow's disco ball of an engagement ring sparkled in the spotlight, and midshow, Mr. Armstrong, the Tour de France winner, emerged from the wings to hand her a guitar and plant a lingering kiss.

title: Jumpy Enough to Chew a Chair? Try DogCatRadio
description: "Remember, be kind to your mailman," said Jane Harris, a disc jockey. Then she softened her voice until it was a little insinuating: "He only wants to deliver the mail."

title: Pakistan Increases Quake Toll to More Than 73,000
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 2 - The death toll from the Oct. 8 earthquake has risen to 73,276, with more than 69,000 people severely injured, Pakistan's relief commissioner said today.

title: After Miers Failure, White House Begins Aggressive Effort to Sell New Court Choice
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 - The White House rolled out an aggressive campaign on Tuesday to try to sell the Senate and the American public on Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr., President Bush's choice to succeed Justice Sandra Day O'Connor on the Supreme Court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ADRIAN, HELEN L.
description: ADRIAN--Helen L. On October 30, 2005 of Syosset, NY. Beloved wife of the late Robert J. Loving mother of Dean, Catherine and the late Monica. Reposing Beney Funeral Home, Inc., of Syosset, 79 Berry Hill Rd. Visiting Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Thursday, 9 AM, St. Edward Confessor Church, Syosset, New York. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Both Corzine and Forrester Hammer On Old Issues
description: NEWARK, Nov. 1 - Adhering to familiar lines of attack on the usual hot-button issues of property taxes, corruption and transportation, Senator Jon S. Corzine and Douglas R. Forrester traded barbs on Tuesday night in the latest debate in their race to be New Jersey's next governor.

title: His Love of Words Rivals His Contempt for Critics
description: DUBLIN - Not everyone was thrilled by the decision last month to give the Man Booker Prize, Britain's most influential literary award, to "The Sea" by the Irish novelist John Banville. To begin with, two of the five Booker judges vehemently preferred another book, Kazuo Ishiguro's "Never Let Me Go."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STRATTON, RICHARD A.
description: STRATTON--Richard A. Age 58, of Franklin Lakes, NJ, died on Monday, October 31, 2005 surrounded by his loving family. He will remain in the hearts of his devoted wife Lori, his children Marlena, Anna, Nicholas, Christina, Matthew & his grandchildren Gillian and Isabel. Beloved son of Patricia and the late Donald (1963). Born in Newburgh, NY, graduate of Manhattan College, longtime executive of Nabors Industries. He will be profoundly missed by many friends and family all of whom consider themselves fortunate to have been touched by him. Funeral Mass Friday November 4, 10 AM at St. Paul RC Church in Ramsey. Family and friends are invited to visit on Thursday, November 3 at Van Emburgh - Sneider Funeral Home, 109 Darlington Ave. Ramsey. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations to be made to Weill Medical College Center for Lymphoma and Myeloma, 525 East 68th Street, Starr 341, NY, NY 10021, to the attention of Dr. Richard Furman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLEMAN, JOHN W., MD
description: COLEMAN--John W., MD, Born Jersey City, NJ. Age 66, of New York City and Ocean Port, NJ, died Saturday, October 29, 2005. Dr. Coleman was a Clinical Associate Professor of Urology at the Joan & Sanford Weill Medical College of Cornell University, New York Presbyterian Hospital. U.S. Navy Veteran 1966-1968. Vietnam Veteran. Served as Lieutentant in the U.S. Navy Medical Corp. Served on the LPH 839 Carrier. Survived by his beloved Rely. Devoted father of John III, Diane Simon and Mari Kim Novak. Loving grandfather of four grandchildren. Funeral service Saturday, 9AM, from the Volk Leber Funeral Home, 789 Teaneck Rd., Teaneck, NJ then to Holy Trinity RC Church, Hackensack, NJ for a 10AM Mass of Christian Burial. Family and friends are invited to visit on Thursday, 128pm, at the John Krtil Funeral Home, 70th and 1st Avenue, NY, NY, and on Friday, 6-9PM at the Volk Leber Funeral Home in Teaneck. In lieu of flowers, the family kindly requests donations be made in Dr. Coleman's honor to The Pediatric Urology Fund, C/O New York Presbyterian Hospital, 525 East 68th Street, Starr-900, NY, NY 10021.

title: Style Meets Function, and Technology Gets a Human Touch
description: Correction Appended

title: Panel Urges Big Cut in Mortgage Deduction
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 - President Bush's advisory commission on taxes unanimously recommended a vastly simplified tax system on Tuesday that would limit the deduction of interest payments on large mortgages and erase other tax breaks that many Americans enjoy.

title: Corrections
description: The $25 and Under column on Aug. 31, about the Thai restaurant Zabb Queens, misstated its address. It is at 71-28 Roosevelt Aveneue in Jackson Heights. The reviewer discovered the error when he dined there last week.

description: To the Editor:

title: Remember That Mushroom Cloud?
description: The indictment of Lewis Libby on charges of lying to a grand jury about the outing of Valerie Wilson has focused attention on the lengths to which the Bush administration went in 2003 to try to distract the public from this central fact: American soldiers found a lot of things in Iraq, including a well-armed insurgency their bosses never anticipated, but they did not find weapons of mass destruction.

title: Just a Drill, but Flu Shots Were Real, and Popular
description: The city's health department offered free flu vaccines yesterday to anyone who showed up at a clinic in Chelsea. It was an experiment to simulate what might happen during a major outbreak, and the answer seemed to be: plenty of waiting.

title: 10 Ways to Please Us, the Customers
description: DEAR electronics makers,

title: When Giving a Tech Gift, Slip in the Receipt
description: DON'T like the new sweater? It goes back either to the store or to the depths of the closet.

title: World Briefing | Oceania: Australia: Inquiry In Oil-For-Food Allegation
description: Reversing an earlier decision, Prime Minister John Howard has ordered an inquiry into allegations that the Australian Wheat Board made payments of more than $200 million to Saddam Hussein's government under the oil-for-food aid program in Iraq. The payments were made through a Jordanian trucking company, Alia, according to a report issued last week by an investigative panel commissioned by the United Nations and led by Paul A. Volcker. Raymond Bonner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WENZEL, ALICE NEWMAN
description: WENZEL--Alice Newman, on October 31, after many years of dealing with adult normal pressure hydrocephalis and emphysema. She was the center of life and love for husband John and daughters Emily and Abby. Grandmother of Bianca and Sophia, mother-in-law of Mark, sister of Rita Kolsby (Edwin). Sister-in-law of Patricia Lord and Peggy Schofield. Alice loved her cousins and many nieces and nephews. She was Cornell Phi Beta Kappa 1947, and Smith MSW 1954. She beautifully balanced family life with a career in family therapy, primarily at Family Service Association of Nassau. Alice was a longtime resident of Sea Cliff and more recently of Manhasset and Tucson. A memorial service for family and friends TBA. Contributions may be made to Planned Parenthood of Nassau County, 516-750-2600.

title: Blair Ally Resigns in Britain Amid 2nd Scandal
description: LONDON, Nov. 2 - David Blunkett, a senior cabinet minister and a close ally of Prime Minister Tony Blair's, resigned from the government today after acknowledging mistakes in the way he had handled private business interests.

title: Security Concerns in Travels to Distant Shores
description: Imaginary voyages to Southeast Asia linked two short but satisfying pieces on a program of intelligently conceived, image-filled dance by the choreographers Paz Tanjuaquio and Joyce S. Lim at St. Mark's Church on Friday night.

title: Attacks Escalate in Final Debate of Mayor's Race
description: In their second and final debate of the 2005 mayor's race, Michael R. Bloomberg last night belittled his Democratic challenger, Fernando Ferrer, as a serial complainer who lacked serious solutions to improve the public schools, the city's economy or the quality of life in New York.

title: Briefly: New Orleans repairs are found wanting
Paid Notice: Deaths   GORDON, ROBERT E., MD.
description: GORDON--Robert E., MD. The faculty of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology of New York Medical College and the administration of the Medical College, note with great sadness the death of Robert E. Gordon, M.D. We offer our deepest sympathies to his family. Dr. Gordon was a remarkable clinician, a superb teacher, a truly talented surgeon and a loyal faculty member. Bob was also my best friend. James R. Jones, M.D. Professor Emeritus Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, New York Medical College

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TURNEY, JEAN
description: TURNEY--Jean. Beloved wife of Alex Devoted mother of Mark, Ruth Krasner and the late Anita. Also survived by seven grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. You will always be remembered, loved and deeply missed. Our lives will not be the same without you. Services Friday, 1 PM, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Sex, Cinema and the Senate

title: The Daughter Is Going Mad, So the Mom Makes It Worse
description: The fatal weapon is the least toxic of the key ingredients in "A Mother, a Daughter and a Gun," the migraine-inducing comedy by Barra Grant that screeched open at Dodger Stages last night. Watching the talented actresses Veanne Cox and Olympia Dukakis flay each other for two hours with insults and accusations posing as repartee ranks among the more debilitating theatergoing experiences of the current season.

title: G.O.P. Reaches To Other Party On Court Pick
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 - Facing deep Democratic skepticism over the choice of Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. for the Supreme Court, the Bush administration turned quickly on Tuesday to moderate Democrats who could be crucial to the confirmation as the two sides braced for a polarizing fight over Judge Alito's legal views.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Oct. 25 about the settlement between Icann, which oversees the assignment of network addresses, and VeriSign, which controls the.com and .net domains, misstated the plan for long-term control of Icann when it was started by the Clinton administration. It was to become an independent organization, not turned over to an international agency.

title: Woman Is Assaulted by Man Setting Fires Outside Her Apartment
description: A man wearing firefighter's gear sexually assaulted a 34-year-old woman on Monday evening after setting fires outside her Manhattan apartment to trick her into opening her door, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REISNER, MARTHA
description: REISNER--Martha. Of Ewing Township, New Jersey, formerly of New York City on November 1, 2005. Daughter of the late Josef & Josephine Hamburger, sister of the late Daniel Hamburger and Adolf (Ilse) Hamburger, beloved wife of the late Curt Reisner, devoted mother of Jeffrey (Linda) Reisner, dear sister of Hugo (Hanna) Hamburger, cherished grandmother of Sharon ReisnerRude and husband Michael Rude, Barbara Reisner and husband William Tompkins, great-grandmother of Owen Tompkins. Services Wednesday 1 PM at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY. For Info: Orland's Ewing Memorial Chapel: 609-883-1400.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HART, WILLIAM
description: HART--William. The Board of Trustees of The Heckscher Foundation for Children mourn the passing of our extraordinary Trustee, Bill Hart, who served with distinction on our Board for over 37 years. His wise counsel, judgement and commitment to the welfare of children and families in need will be missed by all of our Board and by the thousands of people whose lives he touched. Our condolences go out to Jeanie and the entire Hart family. Virginia Sloane, President Heckscher Foundation for Children

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEMEL, HILDA L.
description: SEMEL--Hilda L. On Nov. 1, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Simon. Devoted sister of the late Murray Levins, Nettie Levins, Anne Levine and Rose Levins. She is survived by her loving nephew David Levins, niece Maxine Hirsch and Dr. Joel Hirsch & great-nephew Jeremy Hirsch. Her love and kindness to her family will never be forgotten. She will live in our hearts forever. Services private.

title: Israeli Airstrike in Gaza Kills 2 Palestinians, One at Top of Its List of Most Wanted Terrorists
description: JERUSALEM, Wednesday, Nov. 2 - An Israeli airstrike near Gaza City killed two wanted Palestinians on Tuesday, including one whom Israel had singled out as a top priority.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KIRSHNER, HERBERT J.
description: KIRSHNER--Herbert J. Always in my heart. Kathy

title: Higher Tax Rates for Most, Breaks for Some
description: The primary proposal by President Bush's tax advisory commission should please stock market investors, taxpayers in the very highest bracket and families with many children. But it may not be so popular with investors in bonds, entrepreneurs, farmers, owners of expensive homes, people in places with high local taxes and charitable donors.

title: A Little Easier Getting Around Downtown
description: Correction Appended

title: Turin Organizers Confident Ticket Sales Will Increase Soon
description: The organizers of the Winter Olympics in Turin, Italy, say they are pleased with the preparations and excitement in their city 100 days before the start of the Games, but their next mission is to get the rest of Italy caught up in their enthusiasm.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Man And Woman Fatally Shot
description: A truck driver shot his estranged wife in the head on Monday night, then fatally shot himself, the police said. They withheld the couple's identity yesterday pending notification of the families. The couple's daughter, 21, found their bodies and a gun yesterday morning in the bedroom of the woman's apartment at 1760 Watson Avenue, the police said. A neighbor, Miguel Gonzalez, said the couple was often together recently, but, "You could tell they weren't together-together." Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,019 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: The President's Pandemic Plan
description: President Bush announced a $7.1 billion strategy yesterday to cope with a possible influenza pandemic, whether caused by the much-feared bird flu, which has killed some 60 people in Southeast Asia, or some other strain not yet detected. Although the president offered little that was new or surprising about ways to prepare for the worst, his speech put the imprimatur of the White House, and a substantial budget request, behind this important issue.

title: Senate Panel Told of Errors in New Orleans Levee Failures
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 - Critical levees that were supposed to protect New Orleans from hurricanes failed because the soil beneath them was weak and the construction did not compensate for the soil problems - and possibly because of "malfeasance" during the construction process, engineering experts told a Senate panel here today.

title: Metro Briefs
description: NEW YORK

title: Pakistan raises official quake toll
Turning the Online Store Into a Multiplex
description: YOU know that the online holiday shopping scene has changed when Wal-Mart is featuring fashion videos on its Web site.

title: What Happened to That Cloud of Dust?
description: It remains one of the most powerful images of the day the twin towers fell -- a towering cloud of angry gray dust that rose up from the debris and raged through the canyons of Lower Manhattan, blotting out the sun and choking everything, and everyone, in its way.

title: An Old-Fashioned American Standby, Fish Sauce and All
description: IN my youth, chicken was simple. Usually, it was served on Friday night. Bought whole or cut up to order by local butchers, it was either roasted; baked with a cornflake coating; served cacciatore or  la king; or, as a real treat, Southern-fried. For guests, my mother might prepare chicken with curry, that exotic spice. And on Sunday night there was chicken chop suey at a Chinese restaurant.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: ASPEN -- This urban ski lodge has delayed its opening until Tuesday. Were they waiting until the weather suggested a need for boots and shearling? It has a painted forest mural, a working fireplace and dishes like bison sliders with chipotle ketchup and cedar-plank salmon. The chef, Gaby Hakman, below, has made quite an adjustment; her last job was in Miami Beach: 30 West 22nd Street, (212) 645-5040.

title: Treatment of suspects is heated U.S. issue
One Teen's Gigantic Contribution to the Internet
description: A few weeks ago, "CBS News Sunday Morning" broadcast my profile of four people who've made gigantic, culture-changing contributions to the Internet while still in their teens.

description: Correction Appended

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the selection of Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. as an associate justice on the Supreme Court misstated the position he held in the Justice Department during the Reagan administration. He was a deputy assistant attorney general, not deputy attorney general.

title: Day Care Owner Gets Community Service in Baby's Death
description: The former owner of an overcrowded Queens day care center where an infant suffocated in his crib under a pile of toys last year pleaded guilty yesterday to reckless endangerment, in a deal carrying a sentence of 1,250 hours of community service.

title: Pakistan quake toll rises
Acquisitions Help to Narrow Loss at Sun
description: Sun Microsystems, the maker of computer servers and software, reported yesterday that its quarterly revenues rose slightly and that its net loss narrowed as it benefited from two acquisitions.

title: Audiences Love a Minimalist 'Ring' Cycle; Critics Aren't Sure
description: PARIS, Nov. 1 - Productions of Wagner's "Ring des Nibelungen" have one thing in common: rarely do director, designer, conductor, orchestra and singers all emerge unscathed. The reason is simple. Audiences and critics often embark on this four-opera cycle with firm views on how its immense musical and mythical universe should look and sound.

title: Letter from New York: Battle against bird flu must start at its source
Paid Notice: Deaths   BOWES, JOHN GARLAND
description: BOWES--John Garland. Born August 30, 1928, died at his home in San Francisco, Wednesday, October 26, 2005. A successful entrepreneur and avid art collector, Mr. Bowes is survived by his wife, Frances Fay Bowes, daughters, Alexandra Bowes of San Francisco, Diana Bowes Weller of Westport, CT and Elena Marano of London, UK, his brother, William Bowes of San Francisco, and nine grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 4 PM, Wednesday, November 2nd, at Grace Cathedral in San Francisco. Memorials may be made to the DIA Center for the Arts and the University of California, San Francisco, Cardiology Department.

title: Bush Announces Plan to Prepare for Flu Epidemic
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 - President Bush announced Tuesday that he would ask Congress for $7.1 billion to prepare the nation for the possibility of a worldwide outbreak of deadly flu. Most of the money would be spent on research and a national stockpile of vaccines and antiviral drugs.

title: 3 Bach Cantatas, Ranging From the Simple to the Complex
description: Colorful tapestries and small figures of lyrical beauty filled the Metropolitan Museum's medieval sculpture hall: not only the permanent displays there, but also, on Monday night, the music of three Bach cantatas. This was the inauguration of a new two-part Bach series offered at the museum by the chamber ensemble Orpheus, which, like some of the stone saints around the room, conspicuously lacks a head -- in Orpheus' case, a conductor.

title: A Son of Ireland Seeks a Father's Forgiveness
description: Correction Appended

World Business Briefing | Americas: Bermuda: Executive at Reinsurer Resigns
description: RenaissanceRe Holdings, the reinsurer, said its chief executive, James N. Stanard, had resigned amid a Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry into the company's earnings restatement. Neill A. Currie, an executive vice president who co-founded the company in 1993, succeeded Mr. Stanard as chief executive, while W. James MacGinnitie assumed his post as nonexecutive chairman, RenaissanceRe said. Marty Merritt, who had been the company's controller until April, has left the company, and the chief financial officer, John M. Lummis, will retire next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VAN BERGEN, ELIZABETH ''BETTY''
description: VAN BERGEN--Elizabeth "Betty"--a remarkable woman and treasured aunt, cousin, friend and sister-died in Manhattan on Monday, October 31, at the age of 87. She was married to the late Charles Van Bergen and was the sister of the late Sally (King) Shull Fritsch. For many years Betty was active in the National Council of Jewish Women. She is survived by nieces Sally (Shull) Miltenberger, Diane (MacDonald) Katsikas, Katie (MacDonald) Ferguson and Meg (MacDonald) Brager; nephews Michael Shull and Peter Shull; and cousins Meta Querns, Paul Starke, Nick Suhr and Paul Suhr. She was beloved by her many great nieces and great nephews and their families. A memorial service will be held Friday, November 4 at 11 AM at All Saints Episcopal Church, 230 East 60th Street, New York. Interment will be at Cedar Lawn Cemetery, East Hampton, Saturday, November 5 at noon. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the East Hampton Library, 159 Main Street, East Hampton, NY 11937 or the NCJWNY Section Children's Literacy Program, 820 Second Avenue, New York, NY 10017-4504.

title: Probe faults top officerson death in Ivory Coast
In New Orleans, Fewer Visitors to Honor the Dead
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 1 - Holt Cemetery, one of the poorest and most poorly tended burial grounds in New Orleans, was submerged in floodwater after Hurricane Katrina ravaged the city on Aug. 29. Afterward, its markers were left askew, its grasses browned and lifeless.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CASTALDI, FILOMENA M. (CORTELLINI)
description: CASTALDI -- Filomena M. (Cortellini). 81 years, at Princeton Care Center, on October 30, 2005. Wife of the late Ralph J. Mother of Teresa M. Castaldi Morton and Andrew R. Castaldi and his wife Elizabeth. Grandmother of Andrew Emil Castaldi. For information call M. David DeMarco Funeral Home, Monroe Twp., New Jersey 732-521-0555 For directions, demarcofuneralhome.com Memorial donations to the Make-A-Wish Foundation.

title: Superreviewers: People Who Spend Lots of Time Playing With Products
description: BRETT JIU, a financial analyst in New York, is the gadget guy his family and friends consult when buying electronics. And a few other people hang on his words too -- 13,000 Amazon.com customers, for instance, have said that the 887 reviews he has posted on that site have been helpful, a figure that makes him the 38th-ranked critic there.

title: A Knight Ridder Shareholder Demands That Chain Be Sold
description: Knight Ridder, the publisher of 32 daily newspapers including The Miami Herald and The Philadelphia Inquirer, has come under fire from its largest shareholder, which yesterday demanded that the company put itself up for sale.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Ethiopia: Police Kill 6 Protesters
description: Riot police officers clashed with opposition supporters at a demonstration in Addis Ababa, killing at least six people and wounding dozens more, as parliamentary elections held in May continued to divide the country. The Coalition for Unity and Democracy has been boycotting Ethiopia's lower house of Parliament because it says the ruling party rigged the results. In recent days, the opposition party has accused the government of detaining many of its top leaders. During similar anti-government protests in June, security forces killed 36 people. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Invisible New Yorkers
description: Crispin Cortes, left, and James De La Vega created artwork to complement their portraits. Mr. De La Vega's storefront artists' studio on East 104th Street was a local gathering spot where his mother, Elsie Matos, was a muse for artists like Mr. Cortes. The storefront has moved, to the East Village. Their stories can be seen at nytimes.com/nyregion. LENS

"We always go to the electronics section," said Ms. Carr, who lives in North Vancouver, British Columbia. "They want to look at the latest games for PlayStation 2 and check out the MP3 players."

He was a deputy assistant attorney general, not deputy attorney general. (Go to Article)

description: When I open a tin of Falls Brook Organic Farm's Hungarian paprika, the aroma transports me back to Szeged, a paprika-making center in Hungary. Amelia Hunt, an owner of the farm in Lyme, Conn., hand-harvests Boldog peppers, dries and grinds them, and packs them in airtight cans.

description: Correction Appended

title: U.S. to Intensify Its Training in Iraq to Battle Insurgents
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 - Gen. George W. Casey Jr., the top American commander in Iraq, is so concerned that the military's counterinsurgency training must be sharpened in the face of increasingly flexible and deadly attackers that he has ordered the formation of a new school in Iraq for officers, according to senior military officials.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the James Beard Foundation's new board of trustees misspelled the surname of a member, the president of Clicquot Inc. She is Mireille Guiliano, not Giuliano.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ACS, SANDOR
description: ACS--Sandor. Passed away Monday, October 24, 2005, age 72. Memorial service at Greenwich House Music School, 46 Barrow St., Monday, November 14, 7-9PM.

title: For the Most Part, Far From the Modeling Crowd
description: For five seasons, Tyra Banks has taught television viewers that being a supermodel really isn't as easy as it looks. "America's Next Top Model," her UPN modeling contest, has yet to anoint a successor to Gisele Bndchen, but it has always succeeded in explaining that striking a pose is more than just sitting pretty.

title: Nearly a Year After the Tsunami, Sri Lanka Strife Flares
description: BATTICALOA, Sri Lanka - Nearly a year since the tsunami devastated the nation, a fresh wave of political violence is sweeping across eastern Sri Lanka. Armed factions vie for supremacy, assassinations and abductions go on in broad daylight and parents squirrel away their children for fear they will be conscripted into battle.

title: Lloyd Bochner, 81, Actor of Stage, Screen and TV, Dies
description: Lloyd Bochner, a classically trained actor who played suave heroes and villains for more than 50 years in theater, television and film, died Saturday at his home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 81.

description: HOUSTON, Nov. 1 - Jamie Olis, a former midlevel executive at Dynegy who was sentenced last year to 24 years in prison for accounting fraud, can breathe a little easier.

title: Making the Right Connections for Holiday Presents
description: CONSIDER the tie. Before buying one as a holiday present, you could spend hours browsing the racks, pondering the recipient's tastes, favorite color, fabric. Or you could buy one that you like, because a tie's a tie and if the person doesn't like it he won't wear it anyway.

description: When word leaked out three years ago that a German family was negotiating the sale of a celebrated Holbein painting to the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles, government officials in Berlin moved swiftly and angrily to block the purchase.

title: Decisions Offer Clues to CourtPick's View of Divisive Issues

Leone (who questioned both plans) served as state treasurer. It was Brendan T. Byrne, not Richard J. Hughes.

title: Arab League Plan for Hussein Exile Went Sour, Arab Leader Says
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, Nov. 1 - Months before the invasion of Iraq, Saddam Hussein tentatively accepted a proposal to go into exile and avert war, but Arab leaders scuttled the deal, unable to reach consensus on it, senior officials in the United Arab Emirates said this week.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about efforts by aides to Vice President Dick Cheney to gather information about a trip to Niger by a former envoy misidentified an official who was referred to only as a "principal deputy" in the indictment of I. Lewis Libby Jr., Mr. Cheney's chief of staff. It was Eric Edelman -- not John Hannah -- whom Mr. Libby spoke to by telephone in June 2003 about whether information about the trip by the former envoy, Joseph C. Wilson IV, could be shared with reporters. (Mr. Hannah did serve as principal deputy, but not until May 2005.)

title: Chinese peasants to get more rights

description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 1 - By all accounts, Sidney Crosby has more than lived up to his billing one month into his first N.H.L. season.

title: In Bridge Title Matches, Men's U.S.A. 1 Holds Fast
description: ESTORIL, Portugal, Nov. 1 - The eagerly awaited clash between the two United States Bermuda Bowl teams at the world bridge championships here is at the halfway stage, 48 boards played out of 96. The U.S.A. 1 defending champions -- Nick Nickell, Dick Freeman, Bob Hamman, Paul Soloway, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell -- have won all three sessions, giving them the lead by 126 international match points to 81. The odds are against U.S.A. 2 (Russ Ekeblad, Ron Rubin, Eric Greco, Geoff Hampson, Fred Gitelman and Brad Moss), but with a favorable tail wind, they could win the match.

title: In Detroit, Thousands Honor Rosa Parks
description: DETROIT, Nov. 2 - In this, Rosa Parks's adopted hometown, the first row on hundreds of city buses sat empty today, saved for the memory of Mrs. Parks and all she had done on another bus miles from here 50 years ago.

title: Video Games Are Facing Soft Demand
description: Electronic Arts yesterday became the second major video game maker this week to warn that it was seeing soft demand from retailers as it heads into the holiday season.

title: Fall Auction Season Opens With a Record for Lautrec
description: A portrait of a red-haired laundress staring soulfully out a window, painted by Toulouse-Lautrec in 1886-87, sold to an anonymous telephone bidder for $22.4 million last night at Christie's sale of Impressionist and modern art. The evening opened the fall season's two weeks of back-to-back auctions, and the price was not only a record for the artist at auction but also an affirmation that today's rich still want to display their wealth on their walls.

title: Big Drop In October For Detroit
description: DETROIT, Nov. 1 - October, which is the start of the new model year, used to be a month for the auto industry to celebrate. This year, it was a month for Detroit to forget.

title: Where the Rhone Bends to the West
description: BACK in the late 1980's, when California was otherwise settling into a two-tone cabernet sauvignon and chardonnay funk, a small group of winemakers were bucking the trend. They sought inspiration not from Bordeaux and Burgundy, as so many others had, but from the intense, spicy wines of the Rhone Valley, the home of Hermitage, Cte-Rtie and Chteauneuf-du-Pape.

title: Tea at the Carlyle, for the Very Small
description: Several afternoons a week, Bemelmans Bar in the Carlyle hotel on upper Madison Avenue is for children (and their adult guests). Ludwig Bemelmans, who decorated the room, wrote the Madeline children's books. So among the lunch and afternoon tea offerings are 12 little shrimps in two straight lines, just like the girls in the books. There are also an Eiffel Tower sundae, piano music and storytelling. The Madeline Experience, from noon to 4 p.m. Wednesdays through Sundays, is $30 a person: (212) 744-1600. FOOD STUFF

title: Copper's Recent Declines Stir Talk of Boom's End
description: LONDON - FOR much of the year, copper prices climbed steadily, driven by a housing boom in the United States and demand from the rapidly industrializing economies of India and China. Supply disruptions further fed the price gains.

Each had a contract that expired at midnight Monday, but as the witching hour approached, Brian Cashman was trick-or-treating with his young children at home in Connecticut, his workday with the Yankees complete; Theo Epstein was resigning from the job he had once dreamed of having in Boston.

One of those buildings is in Beijing -- China's Ministry of Science and Technology, at 55 Yuyuantan Nanlu Street.

title: Excerpts From Notable Dissents
Paid Notice: Deaths   BAKER, WILLIAM O.
description: BAKER--William O. The Board of Trustees, faculty, students, and staff of The Rockefeller University deeply mourn the passing of our cherished friend, Dr. William O. Baker. A man of remarkable abilities and compassionate humanism, Bill Baker was a vital force in shaping The Rockefeller University over the course of four decades, as Trustee and then Board Chairman, and finally as Chairman Emeritus. It was our great privilege to award him an honorary degree in 1990 and the David Rockefeller Award for Extraordinary Service to the University in 1997. His memory lives on in the numerous outstanding scientists he recruited to the University (including two Nobel laureates), the research building and two residential towers constructed on his watch, and the William O. Baker Graduate Fellowships, established in his honor by The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation. Bill Baker possessed one of the most broad-gauged, deep, and penetrating minds of the 20th Century. Equally remarkable was his eloquent and extraordinarily beautiful use of the English language in writing and in speech. As head of Bell Labs, he was responsible for directing programs that led to such technological wonders as the laser, digital computing, cellular telephones, and superconducting magnets. What Bell Labs achieved under his leadership, during an extraordinary period of technological growth and development, created an entirely new paradigm for the enlightened corporation. Bill Baker once wrote that "humanism and science coexist, occasionally connect, but rarely conjoin." In him, they did indeed conjoin. His humanism and compassion, as well as his kind and gracious way of treating others, has had a lasting impact on so many lives and is part of the cultural fabric we cherish at The Rockefeller University. He and his beloved Frances, who predeceased him, embodied all that is best in human nature and the human spirit. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to their son, Joseph, and everyone whose life he touched. Paul Nurse, President Joshua Lederberg and Torsten Wiesel, Presidents Emeritus Thomas Sakmar, Former Acting President Russell Carson, Chairman Richard Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman The Rockefeller University

Sacramento leaders from both parties did so much mutual back-scratching and line-drawing after the 2000 census that none of the 153 Congressional and state legislative seats contested last year changed party hands.

With the trade, the block's owner, the bond investor Bill Gross, will finish what is believed to be the first complete collection of 19th-century United States stamps ever assembled.
