title: That May 6 Column
description: The indictment of Scooter Libby has called attention to my May 6, 2003, column, in which I wrote about the Niger uranium events. Some bloggers on the right have been fuming about the column  and since Im big on Cheney opening windows and being transparent, heres my effort to do the same. (By the way, Ive tinkered with this entry and added material since I first put this up.)First, heres the relevant chunk of that column:Im told by a person involved in the Niger caper that more than a year ago the vice presidents office asked for an investigation of the uranium deal, so a former U.S. ambassador to Africa was dispatched to Niger. In February 2002, according to someone present at the meetings, that envoy reported to the C.I.A. and State Department that the information was unequivocally wrong and that the documents had been forged. The envoy reported, for example, that a Niger minister whose signature was on one of the documents had in fact been out of office for more than a decade. In addition, the Niger mining program was structured so that the uranium diversion had been impossible. The envoys debunking of the forgery was passed around the administration and seemed to be accepted  except that President Bush and the State Department kept citing it anyway. Its disingenuous for the State Department people to say they were bamboozled because they knew about this for a year, one insider said. The envoy is, of course, Ambassador Wilson, and he has outed himself as one of the sources for that column (yes, there were others). One of the criticisms from the right is that I say that the vice president dispatched Wilson to Niger, but thats incorrect. The wording in the column is simply that Cheney asked for more information about the uranium deal, and then the former ambassador was dispatched. And thats what happened. In fairness, though, it is true that Cheney apparently didnt know that Wilson had been dispatched. If Id known that I would have said so. And in a later column I said Wilson had been dispatched at the behest of Cheneys office; its true that he was sent in response to Cheneys prodding, but that wording wasnt choice because it can easily be read to mean that Cheney asked for the trip.The better objection is that the references to the documents themselves make it sound as if the envoy may have had the documents in possession, while in fact he didnt. The U.S. didnt obtain the documents themselves until the fall of that year. But we did then have the information in them, including the full text and the names of the ministers who signed the contracts. And Wilson was briefed on the details of the contracts in his meeting with C.I.A. and State Department experts on Feb. 19, 2003. As the Senate Intelligence Committee report says: The INR analysts meeting notes and electronic mail (e-mail) from other participants indicate that INR explained its skepticism that the alleged uranium contract could possibly be carried out.The INR analysts notes also indicate that specific details of the classified report on the Iraq-Niger uranium deal were discussed at the meeting, as well as whether analysts believed it was plausible that Niger would be capable of delivering such a large quantity of uranium to Iraq. So could Wilson have debunked documents that he hadnt seen? Well, yes. If he knew details of the contract and reported back that it was implausible, sure. Did he? By the spring of 2003, the problems in the signatures of the documents had been pointed out, but I dont see much evidence that they had been noted in 2002 by Wilson or anybody else. Rather, the debunking of the contract was based mostly on the implausibility of obtaining uranium in Niger because of the way the industry was structured. So Wilson has said that he misspoke when he made references to the documents to me and to two other journalists.Theres also a suggestion from the right that Wilson was wildly spinning me and others and exaggerating how strongly he debunked the deal. The Senate Intelligence Committee Report is very harsh on Wilson, and theres a sense in spookdom that it came down too hard on him and was based on interviews with too few people. The C.I.A. seems to have thought that a Niger uranium deal was conceivable but not very likely, while at State the intelligence bureau (INR) was sure that it never happened. But it does seem to be true that Wilson claims to have debunked the Niger deal more firmly than some people remember him debunking it.As for the quote about the State Department and bamboozlement, I think thats stands up well. The State Department accepted from the start that the Niger deal was phony. Indeed, an INR report saying so was circulated to the White House and elsewhere in February 2002. And apparently the information from Wilsons trip was also sent to the White House, although it didnt seem to make much of a splash and theres no evidence that Cheney saw it.So where does that leave us? I think that the attacks on Wilson are overdone. He clearly was wrong in any hinting that he had seen the documents, but he has acknowledged that. He may have exaggerated how strongly he debunked the documents, but that seems to depend a bit on who was listening.Then theres a separate question of whether Valerie Wilson was responsible for sending him to Niger. His critics have said that she was the key player in getting him the trip, and theyve cited the letter she wrote. He has cited various counter-arguments and other authorities. I havent done my own reporting on that issue, and so I wont get into it. More generally, I find the attacks on a private citizen like Wilson rather distasteful. Sure, he injected himself into the public arena with his op-ed column and TV appearances, and so some scrutiny is fair. But I figure its more important to examine and probe the credibility of, say, the vice president than a retired ambassador. And the fact is that his wifes career at CIA has been destroyed; shes never going to be Rome Station Chief. Incidentally, when the White House did once raise the issue of my Niger reporting with me, the senior official who complained did not argue that any of this was incorrect. Rather, he noted that Bushs reference in the State of the Union address was to Africa rather than to Niger  and that even if the Niger connection was fraudulent, there were possible linkages to other African countries like Congo that could have made Bushs 16 words technically correct. That was a very flimsy branch, and the official gave up the argument pretty quickly.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Five Admit To Drug Conspiracy
description: Four men and a woman pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiracy to distribute the drug OxyContin between Newark and drug dealers in Connecticut and Boston, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney. The members of the group, who were arrested on June 6, admitted to obtaining the drug in Newark and supplying other dealers from April 2002 to November 2004. They face up to 20 years in federal prison, prosecutors said.

description: WILDER--Steven. The Board of Directors, staff and clients of We Can are deeply saddened by the passing of Board member and Chair, Steven Wilder. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family and many friends. Robert J. Sann, Executive Director

Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDEN, HERBERT LINCOLN
description: GOLDEN--Herbert Lincoln. 91. Of Laurel, NY, died peacefully at home on October 31 of lung and heart conditions. A journalist with the Philadelphia Record and Variety, officer with United States Navy on two oceans in W.W. II. At Bankers Trust Co., worked with post-war Hollywood film industry and other entertainment media until retirement at 79. Survived by wife, Mary Cox Golden, 7 stepchildren, 11 step-grandchildren, one nephew. His second wife, Elizabeth Atkinson Golden, and first wife, Gertrude Fisher Golden, predeceased him. Memorial service in Laurel, November 12. Memorial donations to Peconic Land Trust, P.O. Box 1776, Southampton, NY 11969.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHURCH, JOHN CYRIL THATCHER
description: CHURCH--John Cyril Thatcher, 69, died on October 27, 2005, was born in New York City. Educated at Cornell University and Carlton College. Lived and worked all over the world and known as a great linguist. He leaves behind his loving wife Maria and siblings Dale, Marilyn, Valentine and William.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Killer Said To Admit To 12 Other Murders
description: A man found guilty last week of the rape and murder of an Alabama woman has confessed to the murders of 12 other people in four states, a representative of the Mobile County Sheriff's Office said. Calling the man, Jeremy B. Jones, a "facile liar" and a "monster who would kill without remorse," the authorities released the names of three men and nine women they say Mr. Jones, above, has admitted killing. He is also suspected in the killings of four other women in Atlanta. A jury has recommended death for Mr. Jones.

title: General Chien's Hothouse
description: The Miele Speed oven (above right) aims to satisfy a New York fantasy. It can microwave foil takeout containers without sparking, and can use convection heat to sear, bake, roast or broil a hunk of meat or a cherry pie, speeding things up with microwaves. Arthur Tanturri, president of Chelsea Fine Custom Kitchens, says the do-all wall unit is ideal where space is short and looks are important. (He normally hides clients' microwave ovens behind doors.) He has it for $2,599 (chelseakitchens.com); for other dealers, mieleusa.com. Just 24 inches wide, the Speed oven comes with stainless steel trim so it can stack as neatly over wider wall ovens as it does over the one shown.

The total is 123 percent above what FIFA, soccer's world governing body, received for the 2002 and 2006 World Cup rights in the United States.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Kashmir: Suicide Car Bomb Kills 5
description: Suspected Islamic militants carried out a suicide car bombing in the capital of the India-administered portion of Kashmir, killing five people including a policeman and three civilians. A caller to local news agencies claiming to speak for a banned Pakistan-based Islamic militant group, Jaish-e-Muhammad, said it had carried out the attack. The bombing was the latest in a series of attacks by militants since the Oct. 8 earthquake that killed more than 74,000 people in Pakistan, India and Kashmir. A multiple bombing in New Delhi, the Indian capital, on Saturday killed at least 60 people.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: More Limits Put on Bank Stakes
description: Bank of America and other foreign institutions that have invested a combined $13 billion in China's banks will be required to hold their shares for at least three years and will not be allowed to buy stakes in more than two lenders, an official of the banking regulator said. The restrictions, in addition to a 25 percent foreign ownership cap, are aimed at safeguarding financial stability and preventing overseas dominance of the banking industry, Tang Shuangning, vice chairman of the China Banking Regulatory Commission, said in a speech in Beijing yesterday.

In the Bermuda Bowl, U.S.A. 2 made a run during the penultimate session, gaining 35 international match points to 3 over the first 15 boards, but U.S.A. 1 recovered 15 unanswered points over the last three deals to regain an 18-imp advantage. During the final set, inaccurate bidding and play cost U.S.A. 2 a lot of points, and U.S.A. 1, the defending champions, cruised into the final 211-172.

John Palmiotto, 16, was killed after the 2005 Nissan Altima he was driving struck two parked cars and a tree and flipped onto its side in front of 80-19 155th Avenue, the police said. The accident occurred about 10:40 p.m., the police said. Mr. Palmiotto, of Lynbrook, was taken to Brookdale Hospital, where he was pronounced dead. Five passengers were taken to hospitals, where they were in serious but stable condition yesterday, the police said.

title: Decorators Who Do Not Live By Markups Alone
description: Carl Bradford Stibolt, a marketing consultant, and Reynaldo Gonzalez, an interior designer, have formed Pret-a-Habiter, offering decorating services to New Yorkers at flat fees. (Decorators often charge markups on work and furnishings.) They have a four-step program: choosing a style, coming up with a floor plan -- one of theirs is shown below -- selecting and ordering furniture, and final styling. They charge $2,500 to $5,000 for all four steps, less if the client chooses to go only as far as a plan. They offer other services, like designing kitchens or renovating bathrooms, at $125 an hour; pret-a-habiter.biz or (212) 627-4667.

title: Arts, Briefly; Destiny's Child Hits No. 1 With 'No. 1's'
description: A hits compilation by Destiny's Child, left, called "No. 1's" (Sony) eked its way to the top of the Billboard album chart in a particularly slow week of sales. The album sold 113,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan, and, with few major new releases as competition, became Destiny's Child's second to top the chart. Nickelback's "All the Right Reasons" (Roadrunner/Island Def Jam) was close behind with 102,000 sales, and Martina McBride's "Timeless" (RCA), a collection of classic country songs, stood at No. 3. Farther down the chart, the country singer Joe Nichols's "III" (Universal South) came in at No. 7 in its first week of release, and Bette Midler opened at No. 10 with "Bette Midler Sings the Peggy Lee Songbook" (Columbia). BEN SISARIO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ARDITTI, FRED
description: ARDITTI--Fred. Noted economist and chief economist of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME) from 1980 to 1982, died October 30 of pancreatic cancer. Dr. Arditti pioneered futures contracts that transformed how businesses and individuals manage risk, most notably the CME's Eurodollar futures, the world's most actively traded futures contact. The Eurodollar contract was the first futures instrument based on "cash settlement," a seminal feature of its incredible success. Dr. Arditti returned to the CME in 1997 to assume a leadership role in the development of the exchange's weather derivatives market, its Research, Marketing and Clearing functions, as well as its electronic trading business, which now account for approximately 75% of all its trade. Fred Arditti's 40-year career exemplifies his commitment to financial market innovation as recognized by the CME's award named in his honor. His achievements embody the kind of innovative thinking and practical benefit to commerce and markets that this award strives to honor. William F. Sharpe, the 1990 Nobel Laureate in economics, became the first recipient of the Fred Arditti Innovation Award in 2004. In his many activities outside of CME, Dr. Arditti taught courses in futures and options at a number of prestigious universities, both in the U.S. and abroad and has been published in various academic journals. His book "Derivatives: A Comprehensive Resource for Futures, Interest Rate Swaps and Mortgage Securities," are among the most assigned books on the subject in many universities. A native New Yorker, Dr. Arditti was born and raised in the Bronx. He received his Undergraduate degree in Electrical Engineering, and his PhD. in Economics from M.I.T. in 1966. At the time of his death at age 66, Dr. Arditti was a tenured professor of Finance at DePaul University, having retired from the position of Senior Executive Vice President of the CME in March 2000. A life-long Yankee fan, Dr. Arditti lived in Chicago, and is survived by his mother, Marie Arditti, his children Elizabeth (Johnson) and her husband Bart, Annie Arditti and David Arditti. Additionally, he leaves behind his sisters Lee Lereah and Terry Suskauer. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Vickie Maurer Nursing Excellence Award at Northwestern Memorial Hospital Department of Oncology, 675 N. St. Claire Street, Chicago, IL 60611.

Paid Notice: Deaths   RUBIN, MARVIN K.
description: RUBIN--Marvin K. November 1, 2005. Beloved husband of the late Sylvia. Devoted father of Stella Rubin. Loving brother of Norma Fredrics. Graduate of City College Class of 1938 and NYU College of Dentistry Class of 1942. After graduation, Dr. Rubin served in the US Air Force. He opened his dental office in 1946 and remained in private practice for fifty years. He taught at NYU College of Dentistry and was Chairman of the New York State Council on Dental Education. In retirement, Dr. Rubin pursued his interest in painting and wrote his memoir, "Word of Mouth". Memorial service Friday, November 4, 2005, 10AM, at the 92nd St. Y Art Gallery. Donations in his memory may be made to the 92nd Street Y.

The former officer, Stanley Street, used his status to get bank workers to discuss security procedures and then robbed the banks later. Mr. Street took more than $137,000 in the 2004 robberies. He told the authorities that he had needed the money to make payroll on a private security company he was starting.

Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mordekhay Levy, 40, of North Woodmere, was arrested after detectives seized $2,000 and four truckloads of counterfeit Ford parts from Black and Yellow Major Auto Parts on 54th Avenue, Mr. Brown said. He said that Mr. Levy was also charged in November 2004 with selling counterfeit Ford parts and is awaiting trial. If convicted, Mr. Levy could face up to 15 years in prison. His lawyer, Marvin E. description: KENNY--Ann Selina (O'Hagan), 68. Of New York City, NY and Stuart, FL, formerly of Congers, NY died peacefully in her home on Monday, October 31, 2005. Born in NYC she was the second daughter of the late Philip and Rosina (Bradley) O'Hagan formerly of Buncrana, Donegal, Ireland. She is survived by her loving husband of 45 years, Daniel P. Kenny, her four children and their spousesDaniel P. Kenny (Maugha) of Glen Rock, NJ, George C. Kenny (Jacqueline) of Summit, NJ, Nancy M. Mulligan (Mark) and Brian J. Kenny (Kellie) of Califon, NJ and nine grandchildren-Kaleigh and Bryn of Glen Rock, Isabelle, Hayden and Quinn of Summit, NJ, Finn and Niamh of Roslindale, MA and Maeve and Owen of Califon, NJ. She also is survived by her four siblings and their spouses; Margaret Ferguson, George O'Hagan, Philip O'Hagan and James O'Hagan (Deborah) along with many cousins, nieces, nephews, and dear friends. Ann attended and graduated from St. Helena's High School, Misericordia Hospital School of Nursing and St. Thomas Aquinas College. She was an active member of St. Paul's Parish in Congers, NY, and worked as a visiting nurse for the Rockland County Health Department. Ann led a life devoted to her family and friends she will be missed by the many people whose lives she touched deeply. In lieu of flowers donations to the N.Y. Visiting Nurse Service or Sloan-Kettering W.B.A.

description: BOURNE--Beebe, on November 1, 2005. Beloved daughter of the late Saul and the late Bonnie Bourne. Survived by her loving Marco Berrocal. She was a renowned independent music publisher of Bourne Company. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St, Thursday, November 3, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Service Friday, November 4, 2PM at St. Jean Baptiste Church, 184 E. 76 St. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Lighthouse International Music School, Sol & Lillian Goldman Building, 111 East 59th Street, New York, New York 10022.

title: Former Cheney Aide Pleads Not Guilty in C.I.A. Leak Case
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 - Flanked by an expanded team of trial lawyers, I. Lewis Libby pleaded not guilty to obstruction and perjury charges today in a case that lawyers on both sides acknowledged could stretch well into next year because of complications over access to classified material.

title: I feel your pain, Scooter
Special Care, or Standard Practice?
description: To the Editor:

title: CNN Ousts Evening Anchor and Embraces Rising Star
description: CNN yesterday ousted its longtime prime-time anchor, Aaron Brown, in favor of Anderson Cooper, who received extensive media attention over his coverage of Hurricane Katrina.

title: Novartis Would Consider U.S. Vaccine Plant, Chief Says
description: GENEVA, Nov. 2 - The chief executive of the Swiss drug company Novartis, Dr. Daniel L. Vasella, said on Wednesday that the company would consider building a vaccine production plant in the United States amid concern that its deal for the Chiron Corporation would leave the United States overly reliant on foreign companies for flu vaccine supplies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHURIN, EVELYN (BUNNY)
description: SCHURIN--Evelyn (Bunny). Age 92. Beloved wife of the late Herman, mother of Ronald and the late John, and mother-in-law of Emily and Marilyn. Devoted grandmother of Laura and her husband Rick Schluger, Richard Schurin & his wife Maureen, and Karla, Zachary and Matthew Schurin. Loving great-grandmother of Jacqueline & Harrison Schluger and R. Matthew & Jonathan Schurin. Service is at 11 A.M. on Friday, November 4, Fairchild Sons, 1570 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, NY.

title: Germany's Snarled Politics
description: Less than two weeks before they're supposed to form a coalition of the left and right, which in turn is supposed to pull Germany out of its perilous economic times, German politicians still can't seem to work out a formula for consensus government.

title: Riots in Paris
Treating Skin of Color With Know-How
description: ERICKA DUNLAP, Miss America 2004, retired her crown last year, but she has not moved out of the spotlight. Her new career as a country singer still requires her to maintain a flawless complexion. So when acne flares up, she flies from her home in Nashville to Washington for treatment at the Cultura Cosmetic Medical Spa.

title: Upstart Comedians Goofing on Andy
description: Correction Appended

title: Amsterdam secret: A den of antiquity
Cholera Cases Raise Fears in Pakistan's Remote Quake Area
description: CHINARI, Pakistan, Nov. 3 - Two children with cholera were brought to a Japanese Red Cross medical tent in this mountain town today, doctors said, raising fears that the grim conditions among the homeless and injured survivors of the Oct. 8 earthquake were deteriorating further as winter sets in.

title: Corrections
description: A credit on Oct. 26 with a picture of two museum visitors on the bus where Rosa Parks made civil rights history misspelled the surname of the photographer. (The same spelling error also occurred five previous times this year, with pictures of his in various sections of The Times.) He is Fabrizio Costantini, not Constantini.

title: Agent Expected to Lead Unit of Paramount
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 - Paramount Pictures is expected on Thursday to name the talent agent John Lesher, whose clients include film directors like Martin Scorsese and David O. Russell, to be the president of its struggling Paramount Classics specialty division, people briefed on the negotiations said.

title: Judge Upholds Conviction in Terror Case
description: A federal judge in Manhattan refused yesterday to overturn the 2001 convictions of a former aide to Osama bin Laden in a major terrorism case, but he sharply criticized the United States Marshals Service for suppressing evidence and then trying to hide what it had done.

title: Ex-Interior Deputy Testifies Lobbyist Offered Him Job
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 - The former No. 2 official at the Interior Department acknowledged to Congressional investigators on Wednesday that he had received a job offer while at the department from the lobbyist Jack Abramoff and that he had other contacts with Mr. Abramoff, the focus of a corruption inquiry.

title: U.S. Forest Service Will Impose Standards for Off-Road Vehicles
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 - The United States Forest Service announced Wednesday that it would begin a nationwide process of designating which trails are suitable for use by off-road vehicles, a move intended to limit damage to national forests.

title: Poverty and Superstition Hinder Drive to Block Bird Flu at Source
description: PREY ROGNIENG, Cambodia - When the half-starved chickens started dying this summer and the barefoot children developed fevers here in this village of thatched huts and emerald rice fields, residents were terrified and deeply divided about the cause of their misfortune.

title: Deutsche Telekom to Trim German Payroll by 19,000
description: BERLIN, Nov. 2 - Deutsche Telekom, the largest phone company in Europe, said Wednesday that it would cut 19,000 jobs from its German payroll over the next three years as it struggles to cope with what changes in the telecommunications sector.

title: Secrets and Shame
description: Ultimately the whole truth will come out and historians will have their say, and Americans will look in the mirror and be ashamed.

title: Rights Suit Is Filed Over Maryland Arsons
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 2 - Lawyers representing 32 homeowners in a southern Maryland subdivision heavily damaged by arsons last December filed a federal lawsuit Wednesday, asserting that the fires were racially motivated and violated the homeowners' civil rights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EILENBERG, DR. MORRIS
description: EILENBERG -- Dr. Morris. Husband of Bernice. Father of Rita, Carol. Brother of Perle, Frankie. Grandfather, great-grandfather.

title: Trading Drink and Drugs for Sweat and Blisters
description: Of all the jittery runners who will be shuffling near the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge on Sunday morning, anxious to hear the starting cannon for the New York City Marathon, Curtis Jenkins may be the most improbable.

title: How Colorado Got Its Government Back
description: In 1992, to the unmitigated glee of antitax types everywhere, Colorado voters amended the State Constitution to impose the nation's strictest tax and spending limits. On Tuesday, they decided that government was worth paying for after all. By roughly 52 percent to 48 percent, they voted to suspend the fiscal limits for the next five years and told the state to keep $3.7 billion that would have otherwise been refunded to taxpayers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STRUHL, BETTY NEE SARDEN
description: STRUHL--Betty nee Sarden, of Teaneck, NJ on November 1, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Archie. Devoted mother of Paul, Marcia (Dr. Bernard) Schwartz, Stuart and Morton. Loving grandmother of Arianne Schwartz, Aaron & Arielle Struhl. Graveside services Thursday 2 PM Cedar Park Cemetery, Emerson, NJ. "Gutterman - Musicant" for further info 800-522-0588.

title: When Glory Grows Distant and Faded
description: Boston - THE Knicks are a public trust. Larry Brown understands. When the Knicks are playing well -- that is to say, intelligently, if we can remember back that far -- it is as if the subways are running on time, the stoplights are coordinated, the garbage has been collected. All is right with the world, a tribute to our genius.

title: From Queens to Hollywood,with help from Dublin
Hard-line Iranians retiring 40 top diplomats
A damper on WTO talks?
Love the Riches, Lose the Rags
description: ONCE upon a time, Cinderella was one of the humblest souls in the world of children's entertainment. Named for the soot she constantly swept from her wicked stepfamily's hearth, she befriended rodents and warbled patiently until she was rescued by her fairy godmother and her prince.

title: Call Me a Wheelchair-Friendly Taxi. You're a Wheelchair-Friendly Taxi.
description: "Designing the Taxi," a free exhibition opening today at the Parsons design school, offers 20 ideas for improving New York taxis, including a wheelchair-friendly version powered by gasoline and electricity, above, by Hybrid Product Design in New York. Other models have a belted pull-down seat for children and a global positioning system with a screen for passengers. Michael Levine, who owns one of the largest taxi fleets in the city, suggested redesigning the entire system: "Instead of having 12,000 yellow cabs with no radios, which only pick up street hails, and 35,000 liveries that can't pick up street hails legally and can only take radio calls, have 25,000 yellow cabs that do both." The exhibition was organized by the nonprofit Design Trust for Public Space and runs through Jan. 15 at 2 West 13th Street; (212) 229-8919 or parsons.newschool.edu.

title: The Beefy Prince Is Back, Along With the Fog
description: Listeners of good will may differ, perhaps violently, about why Puccini's "Turandot" has tenaciously held its place in the standard repertory. It has an uncommonly dim libretto, even by operatic standards, and a paucity of great arias nestled amid two and a half hours of brass-heavy, faux-exotic scoring and purposeless pageantry.

title: You Saw The Magazine, Now Read The Ceiling
description: Fans of Nest, the quirky design quarterly that shut down last year, can sate their eccentric appetites at the new Jason Jacques gallery, on two floors of an 1870 town house at 29 East 73rd Street. Mr. Jacques (above, on stairs) commissioned Nest's founder and editor, Joseph Holtzman (foreground) to design the gallery with his offbeat top-to-bottom decorative flourishes. Ceilings painted in a blue and white pattern by Patrick O'Brien, a Maryland artist, recall the crackled glaze of pottery; walls are bordello red and acid green; and one room (top right) has curtains made by Mr. Holtzman from fabric covered with sunflowers. He wrapped the cords of hanging lights with more than 60,000 red and bottle-green crystal beads, and painted radiators black and electric blue. "It's so not a white box," he said. Indeed, explained Mr. Jacques, who specializes in Art Nouveau and japonist ceramics, it reflects their "mutual passion for the 19th-century eclectic sensibility." An exhibition through Dec. 31, "Masterpieces of French Art Pottery, 1885-1910," includes 40 rare works like those shown at right; from left, an Albert Dammouse floral vase ($75,000); a Joseph Mougin vase with jewel-like glass cabochons ($40,000); an Auguste Delaherche charger ($18,000); and a monumental vase by Georges Hoentschel ($550,000 for a pair). By appointment; (212) 535-7500 or jasonjacques.com.

title: Samsung sets goal of doubling sales by '10
World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Central Bank Raises Key Rate
description: Norway's central bank raised its main interest rate by a quarter percentage point, to 2.25 percent, the second increase in four months, to cool economic growth, the bank said yesterday. The Norwegian central bank increased borrowing costs by a similar margin on June 30, the first such move in three years.

description: A credit on Oct. 26 with a picture of two museum visitors on the bus where Rosa Parks made civil rights history misspelled the surname of the photographer. (The same spelling error also occurred five previous times this year, with pictures of his in various sections of The Times.) He is Fabrizio Costantini, not Constantini.

title: Large Gift to End Yale Music School Tuition
description: Anonymous donors have promised $100 million to the Yale School of Music, which is one of the largest gifts ever pledged to a music school and will allow students to attend without tuition, Yale said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A credit on Oct. 26 with a picture of two museum visitors on the bus where Rosa Parks made civil rights history misspelled the surname of the photographer. (The same spelling error also occurred five previous times this year, with pictures of his in various sections of The Times.) He is Fabrizio Costantini, not Constantini.

title: A dose of reality; Axis of evil
World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Potential Suitor for Eircom
description: The Eircom Group, Ireland's biggest phone operator, said yesterday that it had received a takeover approach, driving up the company's share price and raising its stock market value to 2.6 billion euros ($3.1 billion). Eircom, based in Dublin, did not identify the suitor, though speculation has focused mainly on Swisscom as the most likely bidder. Eircom's stock rose 0.35 euro (42 cents), or 17 percent, to 2.42 euros ($2.91) in London. Eircom joins O2 of Britain and TDC of Denmark as takeover targets in Europe's phone industry.

title: Democrats Seek a Shift to Issues That Will Favor Them
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 - The Democratic decision to bushwhack Senate Republicans this week with a surprise procedural maneuver reflected a larger political strategy to shift the terrain to issues that Democrats believe will play to their common advantage in the 2006 elections.

title: Big Media a Tough Sell to Jittery Investors
description: The media moguls are busier than ever. In the last few months, Rupert Murdoch, the News Corporation chairman, has announced a series of Web deals including the purchase of Myspace.com, a social networking site. Time Warner is in talks to sell a stake in a suddenly hot AOL.

title: Corrections
description: The Short Cuts column in Business Day on Saturday about questionable sales tactics involving chimney sweeps misidentified a national organization on chimney safety at one point. It is the Chimney Safety Institute of America, not the Chimney Sweep Institute of America. The column also misstated the Web address of the National Chimney Sweep Guild. It is www.ncsg.org.

title: Tortured logic
Chirac Appeals for Calm as Violent Protests Shake Paris's Suburbs
description: PARIS, Nov. 2 - President Jacques Chirac appealed for calm on Wednesday after six nights of violence in this city's immigrant-heavy northern suburbs threatened to spiral into a political crisis.

title: A Spanish Town Withers With the Olive, Its Tree of Life
description: CAMBIL, Spain - The anxiety in this town begins to make sense after a short drive up the main road, as the homes and plazas give way to orchards with seemingly endless rows of olive trees.

title: Royal Couple Find Friends at White House and a School
description: Correction Appended

title: Overcoming Fears of Mir and Picasso
description: ON my walls is a collection of art that can best be described as eclectic.

title: A Tiny Tower of Sound, and One Ring Controls It All
description: Looking like a high-tech pepper mill, the BeoSound 3 is actually a transistor radio. And a portable music system. And an alarm clock.

title: Corrections
description: The Vital Signs column in Science Times on Tuesday carried an erroneous byline. The writer was Nicholas Bakalar.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMETANA, JOHN A. JR.
description: SMETANA--John A. Jr. of Wainscott, NY and Palm Beach, FL. Born Derry, PA February 5, 1928. Cherished husband of the late Virginia and his beloved late Julianne. Died of heart condition on October 31, 2005 at the residence of his close friends. A Veteran in the U.S. Navy, Submariner Service, attended St. Vincent College and St. John University Law School. Served as Kings County Assistant District Attorney and had years of notable service to the City of New York. John's sharp wit, blunt honesty and sincere friendship will be missed by all. Reposing at the Beney Funeral Home, Inc. of Syosset, 79 Berry Hill Rd. Visiting Thursday 6-9 P.M. Religious service 8:00 P.M.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HARRINGTON, DONALD SZANTHO
description: HARRINGTON--Donald Szantho, Minister Emeritus of The Community Church of NY Unitarian Universalist died on September 16 in Romania at age 91. A memorial service will be held at Community Church, 40 East 35th Street, telephone 212.683.4988, on November 6 at 11 AM. His ministry in NYC began in 1944 as colleague with John Haynes Holmes, and he retired as Sr. Minister in 1982. He was a Beloved Pastor; Pioneer for Universal Religion and interfaith understanding; Activist for social justice and civil rights; Champion of Unitarian Universalist merger and denominational leader; author and WQXR radio preacher; Theologian on the frontiers of science and religion, and institution builder. His wider ministry and community leadership included service as Founding Chair of the American Committee on Africa, President of the United World Federalists, Inc., and Chairman of the Liberal Party of NYS. He is survived by the Rev. Aniko Szantho Harrington, his wife of 21 years, by his daughter Loni Hancock of Berkeley, CA. and his son David Harrington of Santa Fe, NM from his marriage of 43 years to Rev. Vilma Szantho Harrington, who predeceased him in 1982, and by five grandchildren, four great grandchildren; and three stepdaughters and their families.

title: Jury absolves Merck & Co. in Vioxx user's heart attack
Giants Don't Dismiss 49ers
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 3 - The Giants insist they will not underestimate the 2-5 San Francisco 49ers on Sunday, in part because they know the 49ers beat 5-1 Tampa Bay in their last game, and in part because it is November and the Giants have not won a game on the road.

title: One man's effort to stir up a revolution in Indian food
Toast of Paris Captivates New York, Too
description: ON Oct. 4, the eve of his spring runway show during the height of Paris Fashion Week, Olivier Theyskens logged onto a computer in his studio to check out what Nicolas Ghesquiere had shown that morning at Balenciaga. The way Mr. Theyskens described that moment last week, miming the frantic dance of fingers across a keyboard, was like a lotto junkie checking the morning numbers.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: No Teachers' Raise, But A Bonus For Some
description: Teachers with demonstrated skills in educating low-income students will receive merit pay from a new $10 million fund announced by Gov. Rick Perry. The program, which will use federal money, will initially cover 100 Texas schools, although Mr. Perry said he would ask the Legislature for $25 million to cover 250 additional campuses. Mr. Perry, a Republican, said the plan was made necessary by the Legislature's refusal to raise teachers' salaries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, RICHARD
description: GOLDSTEIN--Richard. Kauff McClain & McGuire mourn the passing of Richard Goldstein, our esteemed former partner, and extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Pat, his children and grandchildren.

title: A Thought for Interior
description: We would like to note, with pleasure, some Congressional common sense -- bipartisan common sense -- on the misguided draft of a new management policy for the national parks. Last week, six Republican senators told Interior Secretary Gale Norton that they were unhappy with the way the proposed changes de-emphasized the fundamental goal of preserving the parks. And on Tuesday, the Senate's national parks subcommittee heard balanced testimony about the changes the Interior Department is planning. The Bush administration's arguments for revising the management policy left some committee members skeptical. "Frankly," said Ken Salazar, a Colorado Democrat, "we don't understand what the true motivation was."

title: Ending Stalemate, Bolivian Leader Schedules Elections for Dec. 18
description: BOGOT, Colombia, Nov. 2 - President Eduardo Rodrguez of Bolivia has announced that presidential and congressional elections will be held Dec. 18, resolving a stalemate that had threatened to cause paralyzing street protests and paving the way for Bolivia, an isolated Andean country, to make a political transformation.

title: TechBrief: Eircom stock soars
The Third Reich in Power, 1933-1939
Simon & Schuster Editor Resigns
description: Michael V. Korda will step down at the end of the year as editor in chief of Simon & Schuster's trade books imprint, a post he has held since 1968, the company said yesterday. He will remain as editor in chief emeritus, editing the books of about a half dozen writers, including David McCullough, Larry McMurtry and Mary Higgins Clark.

title: Our Allies in Iran
description: Washington - WHEN Iran's new president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, called last week for Israel to be "wiped off the map," he raised fears not only abroad but also at home, particularly among Iran's sizeable, democratically minded middle class. The new president's confrontational tone threatens to deepen the isolation of Iran's democrats, pushing them further behind his long shadow. Western powers have a dual challenge: to find a way to engage this population even as they struggle to address the new president's inflammatory rhetoric.

title: PGA Tour Points Plan Seeks to Add Final Pop
description: The PGA Tour's adoption of a new season-long points system and late-summer playoff starting in 2007 is a naked pitch for more television money, which is not necessarily a bad thing. Every league or sports governing body is entitled to remake itself for extra cash, and the PGA Tour is not alone.

title: When That Old Feeling Creeps Up on You
description: I WAS 20 the first time I felt Old. My friend Eliot called to tell me that we were officially Old because he had just bought the new Playboy and the centerfold model was only 19. We're older than the Playboy centerfold, he said. We are Old.

title: Checking the Tires, Not to Mention the Marble Nude
description: With their gleaming taxis still dripping from the carwash, and their outfits looking like their Sunday best, hundreds of Newark's airport cabdrivers showed up at the Newark Museum on Monday for their mandatory twice-yearly vehicle inspection.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOSEPH, ANDREW MARK
description: JOSEPH--Andrew Mark. Age 59, left us on November 1, 2005 in NYC. Loving and beloved husband to Terry for 37 years. Retired as NYC Deputy Comptroller for Budget, former associate director NYS Financial Control Board, former official Social Services Employees Union Local 371. He held an MBA from Baruch College and a BA from Queens College. Andy loved mentoring young people, traveling, scuba diving, art and music. Andy was so knowledgeable about history that he could talk about Alexander the Great and Shakespeare as though they were his friends. He was the man you'd talk to when you needed to know anything. A thirty year Hodgkin's disease survivor, he lived each day to the fullest. Andy is irreplaceable to us all. He will be remembered forever by his many friends, relatives and colleagues. The world is a better place because of Andy. Funeral services will be held Sunday, November 6 at 1:15 Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76 St. Charitable contributions preferred.

title: Close Ally of Blair Resigns Again in Scandal
description: LONDON, Nov. 2 - David Blunkett, a senior cabinet minister and close ally of Prime Minister Tony Blair, resigned from the government on Wednesday after acknowledging mistakes in the way he handled private business interests.

title: 'Calm' prompts revival of Germany-Israel tours
Mothers may get boost of brain power
Liquor Ads Move to Satellite Radio
description: SIRIUS SATELLITE RADIO is joining the growing ranks of media outlets that accept liquor advertising, as it begins running musical commercials for Tanqueray gin.

title: 'Paranoid Style,' Updated
description: To the Editor:

title: United Nations Opens Door to Painting Planned to Unite World
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 2 - The United Nations has rarely allowed its once-sleek lobbies, plazas, ramps or rooftops to become exhibition spaces for large-scale, independent works of art, let alone personal, site-specific installations.

title: Editor of Financial Times Quits; Differences With Pearson Cited
description: LONDON, Nov. 3 - The editor of The Financial Times, Andrew Gowers, resigned today over "strategic differences" with Pearson, the international business newspaper's British owner. Pearson named Lionel Barber, editor of the newspaper's American edition, to succeed Mr. Gowers.

title: Sellout Crowd Sees the Nets Stumble
description: Correction Appended

title: INSIDE
description: Poverty and Superstition Hinder Efforts on Bird Flu Besa Korn, left, talking about sick children in her Cambodian village, where some feared bird flu and others blamed sorcery by a woman who was later killed. Officials say poverty and ignorance hinder health steps. PAGE A20

title: Goodbye, My Sweet Deduction
description: There are no cows more sacred in the tax code than the deductions for mortgage interest and property taxes. Together, they add up to at least a $75 billion annual subsidy for housing and homeowners. President Bush, in establishing his advisory panel on tax reform, specifically asked the group to preserve support for home ownership.

title: The Unlikely Progress of a Barely Motivated Underachiever
description: Adam Carolla defies economics. He is paid to preside over two television series that are basically celebrations of sloth. He's vaguely famous, faintly funny and barely motivated, and yet he is exploding into a franchise.

title: Adidas lifts profit forecast
Sending Culture Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: $13.7 Million for a Picasso at Sotheby's
description: It's been more than 15 years since a sale of Impressionist and modern art from various owners surpassed an auction house's expectations, but that's what happened at Sotheby's last night. Riding the crest of Christie's solid sale on Tuesday, collectors shopped and shopped, paying strong prices for everything from bucolic Impressionist landscapes to hard-edged Cubist compositions.

title: Other Views: Deccan Herald, South China Morning Post, The Guardian
A Streetcar Named St. Charles, Bearing Gifts for the Hungry
description: A New Orleans version of toile de Jouy, the popular fabric with French country scenes, has drawings of symbols of the city like the St. Charles Avenue streetcar and the steamboat Natchez. The toile, a cotton-linen blend 53 inches wide, was designed by Bryan Batt, a Broadway actor and an owner of Hazelnut, a gift shop in Uptown New Orleans. Through the end of the year the shop will donate a portion of sales of the fabric (and accessories decorated with the same drawings) to nonprofit groups like Second Harvest of Greater New Orleans, which distributes food to those in need. The toile comes in red, green, blue or black on off-white, or brown on tan; $36 a yard from hazelnutneworleans.com or (504) 891-2424. MARIANNE ROHRLICH CURRENTS: FABRIC

title: Al Qaeda in Iraq Threatens to Kill Diplomat and Driver
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 3 - The Islamic militant group Al Qaeda in Iraq announced in an Internet posting today that it would kill a Moroccan diplomat and his driver who were kidnapped in Baghdad last month.

title: Corrections
description: The Vital Signs column in Science Times on Tuesday carried an erroneous byline. The writer was Nicholas Bakalar.

title: Administration's Flu Plan Gets Mixed Reception in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 - The Bush administration's long-awaited plan to deal with the threat of pandemic flu received a mixed reception on Capitol Hill Wednesday, as senators chided top health officials as taking too long and questioned their spending priorities.

title: Buyer's Remorse Is Causing Some Palpitations at Johnson
description: Johnson & Johnson's stumble in the purchase of the Guidant Corporation, the medical device maker, illustrates the perils of designing a corporate strategy around acquisitions.

description: Lottery Numbers

title: Jury Rules Merck Is Not Liable for Heart Attack of Vioxx User
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 3 - The drug giant Merck won decisively today in the second Vioxx-related personal injury case to go to trial, an outcome that legal experts say could slow the flood of lawsuits against the company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISL, EDWIN L., JR.
description: WEISL--Edwin L., Jr. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the loss of this devoted benefactor and good friend, who for more than three decades generously supported the Museum and played an important role in the Robert Lehman Foundation's work with the Metropolitan. We extend our condolences to his family, colleagues, and friends. James R. Houghton Chairman Philippe de Montebello Director Emily K. Rafferty President

title: Boy is shot as he holds a toy gun
Acquisition helps lift Telefnica Mviles net
There's good stuff happening in Russia, too

Corrections
description: A front-page Man in the News article on Tuesday about Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. referred incorrectly to Larry Lustberg, who said that if Judge Alito is confirmed for the Supreme Court his decisions will move it to the right. Mr. Lustberg is a former assistant federal public defender, who now practices as a criminal defense lawyer; he is not a former federal prosecutor.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Skitch Henderson, 87, 'Tonight' Show Bandleader, Dies
description: Skitch Henderson, the conductor, pianist and radio and television entertainer who provided music and repartee for the "Tonight" show in the 1950's and 60's and who founded and led the New York Pops, died on Tuesday at his home in New Milford, Conn. He was 87.

title: World Briefing: Asia, Europe, Africa, Americas
description: ASIA

title: Arts, Briefly; It's Over for 'Over There'
description: Normally, television networks and cable channels don't publicize the fact that they have canceled a show, but FX announced on Tuesday that it was not renewing "Over There" for a second season. The ratings for the series, which dramatized the current Iraq war and was created by Steven Bochco and Chris Gerolmo, fell precipitously over its 13-episode run. The show started strong, with an audience of 4.1 million watching its premiere in July, but the next week's episode lost 1.5 million of those viewers. The finale, on Oct. 26, delivered an audience of 1.35 million. In comparison, FX's "Nip/Tuck," the surreal soap opera about plastic surgeons in Miami, is averaging 4.1 million total viewers during its third season, accompanied by strong 18-to-49 ratings. KATE AURTHUR

title: IPod on Board: Two Ways, the Direct Route and an Alternate
description: There are two main approaches to using an iPod to play music in the car. One is to wire the iPod directly to the stereo system. The second is to use an FM transmitter and an empty frequency on the car radio dial.

title: Old Memo Ties Bronx School to Church Sex Scandal
description: All Hallows High School in the Bronx is a handsome brown-brick structure overlooking a park off the Grand Concourse, home to 530 students and to a reputation for academic success. Its link to a notoriously abusive orphanage in Canada, 1,500 miles away and long demolished, seems hard to fathom.

title: Specs: Touring the Bat Cave
description: CHIP KIDD gathered his furnishings in a 10-year spree. Sources included antique and consignment shops in Manhattan, San Francisco and Chicago, the Conran Shop in Manhattan and Sotheby's.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCOTT, ZELDA
description: SCOTT--Zelda. On November 1 at age 88. Beloved wife of the late Milton; loving mother of Diana, Stuart, and David, and grandmother of Zoe, Sean, and Joshua; devoted sister of Helen Rosenfield, and the late Ethel Rubinrott, Lottie Wallach, and Sarah Goldstein. Graduate of Brooklyn College, retired administrator at the N.Y. Bank for Savings. Services at Sinai Chapels, Queens, Wednesday 10AM, 718-445-0300.

title: China to Drop Urbanite-Peasant Legal Differences
description: BEIJING, Nov. 2 - China plans to abolish legal distinctions between urban residents and peasants in 11 provinces as the government tries to slow the country's surging wealth gap and reduce social unrest, state media said Wednesday.

title: Troubled Maker of Heart Devices May Lose Suitor
description: Johnson & Johnson yesterday threatened to abandon its plan to acquire the Guidant Corporation, a troubled heart device maker, setting the stage for a financial and legal confrontation between the companies over the $25.4 billion deal.

title: The Harry da Reid Code
description: Harry Reid sits alone at his kitchen table at 4 a.m., writing important notes in crayon on the outside of envelopes. It's been four weeks since he launched his personal investigation into the Republican plot to manipulate intelligence to trick the American people into believing Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction.

title: Libby to make first court appearance since indictment
A Rap Minister Works the Aisles
description: A FEW things you should know about Rev Run, the rapper and minister and dad who stars in the new MTV reality show "Run's House."

title: Arts, Briefly; XM Satellite: Terrestrial Radio's Country Cousin
description: New York ordinarily doesn't have a country radio station, but until tomorrow it will, temporarily, when the city-owned WNYE-FM (91.5) will simulcast part of XM Satellite Radio's country channel Highway 16. "Country music is a vital part of American culture, and we think it's important to offer country music to New York radio listeners," said Eric Logan, the XM executive vice president for programming. The programming is part of XM's programming partnership with the Country Music Association in advance of its awards ceremony in Madison Square Garden on Nov. 15. WNYE will also carry Country Music Association programming up to the awards. PHIL SWEETLAND

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STRATTON, RICHARD A.
description: STRATTON--Richard A. Age 58, of Franklin Lakes, NJ, died on Monday, October 31, 2005 surrounded by his loving family. He will remain in the hearts of his devoted wife Lori, his children Marlena, Anna, Nicholas, Christina, Matthew & his grandchildren Gillian and Isabel. Beloved son of Patricia and the late Donald (1963). Born in Newburgh, NY, graduate of Manhattan College, longtime executive of Nabors Industries. He will be profoundly missed by many friends and family all of whom consider themselves fortunate to have been touched by him. Funeral Mass Friday November 4, 10 AM at St. Paul RC Church in Ramsey. Family and friends are invited to visit on Thursday, November 3 from 2-4 and 7-9pm at Van Emburgh - Sneider Funeral Home, 109 Darlington Ave. Ramsey. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations to be made to Weill Medical College Center for Lymphoma and Myeloma, 525 East 68th Street, Starr 341, NY, NY 10021, to the attention of Dr. Richard Furman.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 21 about divisions in the United Methodist Church over its policy on gays referred incorrectly to votes by the church's General Conference on a rule to ban "self-avowed, practicing homosexuals" from the ministry. It was passed by a margin of 640 to 317 at the 2000 conference, and by a margin of 674 to 262 at the 2004 conference. The margin was not "slimmer and slimmer" at each conference. (Go to Article)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Unemployment Drops Again
description: Unemployment in Germany, Europe's largest economy, declined for the sixth month in seven in October as companies hired part-time workers, adding to signs that economic growth is gathering pace. The number of unemployed people, adjusted for seasonal swings, fell by 36,000, to 4.8 million, the Federal Labor Agency said yesterday. The jobless rate fell to 11.6 percent from 11.7 percent.

description: The only live music today at Radio City Music Hall was this: A lonesome saxophone player, belting out "Joy to the World" on the street to the accompaniment of Midtown traffic.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: 5 Policemen Killed In Attack
description: Insurgents killed five Afghan government policemen in an ambush on their patrol in the southern province of Helmand, in an area of frequent attacks by Taliban supporters and drug gangs, officials said. The elusive leader of the Taliban, Mullah Muhammad Omar, called on Afghans to continue a jihad against United States-led forces in Afghanistan. In an e-mail message sent to The Associated Press, he said, "I call upon the Muslim nation to be united against the clever occupation force until the aggressors leave our soil."

title: Rare defector to N. Korea returns home to Japan
Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Worker Falls To Death
description: A construction worker fell to his death from the third floor of an unfinished building in Brooklyn early yesterday, the police said. The man, Heng Zheng, 50, who lived in Chinatown, was pronounced dead at the scene, the police said. His employer told investigators that Mr. Zheng had been placing cinderblocks on the third floor of the unfinished residential building at 207 South First Street in Williamsburg when he fell. After the accident, the Department of Buildings issued two citations to the construction company, Leeco Construction Corporation, including one for not placing guard rails on the open floors, a department spokeswoman said. Kareem Fahim (NYT)

title: Iraq Asks Return of Some Officers of Hussein Army
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 2 - The Iraqi government called Wednesday for the return of junior officers from the disbanded army of Saddam Hussein, openly reversing an American directive issued in 2003.

title: New York and Boston
description: AS its name implies, Addict, a boutique scheduled to open next Wednesday in Greenwich Village, will offer seemingly irresistible women's fashions like skinny jeans by Sass & Bide, cocktail dresses by Barbara Bui, T-shirts by Clu, and stilettos by Donna Karan. Suede black pumps by Christian Lacroix and elbow-length leather gloves trimmed with fur by Edena Palazzo will be exclusive to the shop. At 20 East 12th Street, between University Place and Fifth Avenue, (212) 920-6953.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAKER, DR. WILLIAM O.
description: BAKER--Dr. William O. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Fund for New Jersey mourn the passing of our dear friend and esteemed colleague, Dr. William O. Baker. A Trustee for 30 years and then Emeritus, it was our privilege to share responsibility with him for the stewardship of the Foundation. His wisdom, breadth of experience and unique insight into the dynamics of our society were enormous assets to us. We extend our sincerest sympathy to his son Joseph and family. Leonard Lieberman Chairman Joseph C. Cornwall Chairman Emeritus Mark M. Murphy, President

title: Calling the Ocean's Bluff
description: WHEN Michael and Eleanore Kennedy's gray-shingled house, which overlooks the ocean just west of Georgica Pond in Wainscott, N.Y., was built in the late 1870's, it stood behind three rows of dunes. The hurricane of 1938, which made a direct hit on Long Island, took out the first row, and the ocean has been chewing away ever since.

title: Autopsy Does Not Worry Curry
description: BOSTON, Nov. 2 - The Knicks' Eddy Curry said Wednesday that he had nothing in common with Jason Collier, the Atlanta Hawks center who died on Oct. 15.

title: National Briefing | South: Alabama: Fine Reduced In Fatal Mine Explosions
description: An administrative law judge ruled Tuesday that government regulators hade not proved that the operator of a mine where 13 people were killed in 2001 was guilty of major safety violations. The judge, David F. Barbour, reduced the fine against Jim Walter Resources Inc. to $3,000 from $435,000, saying the company's violations were minor. The Mine Safety and Health Administration had charged that more serious problems, including improper roof supports and a failure to prevent the buildup of volatile gas and coal dust, contributed to the deaths. Many of those who died in the September 2001 explosions at the mine, in Brookwood, Ala., were trying to rescue co-workers.

title: At 9/11 Site, Design and Expense Collide
description: BENEATH a veneer of seamlessness, tension is evident between the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation and the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation as important -- and expensive -- construction questions begin to arise.

title: PGA Points Race to Make the Rich Richer
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 2 - After years of having its autumn tournaments languish in the glare of pro and college football and the baseball postseason, the PGA Tour announced a restructured schedule Wednesday. The slate will be highlighted by a season-long points race and a four-tournament championship series near the end of the season.

title: With Cleanup Crew's Arrival, Ferrer Event Is Thwarted Again

title: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Fujimori Trying To Form Political Alliance
description: Peru's former president, Alberto Fujimori, who is living in exile in Japan but says he will return to Lima to run for president next year, is trying to forge an alliance with two small political groups in Peru. Mr. Fujimori, who is wanted in Peru on corruption and rights violations, is hoping that his Si Cumple party can work with Cambio 90 and Nueva Mayora to stage his comeback. The former president, who ruled Peru with an iron hand until he fled during a corruption scandal in 2000, has until January to register his candidacy.

title: Haydn and Beethoven, in Equal Measure
description: The Hungarian pianist Andras Schiff came to Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday night with handfuls of Haydn and Beethoven in equal measure. The Beethoven was the timelier of the two, and not only for the composer's uncanny way of sounding contemporary. Mr. Schiff is also recording the entire cycle of Beethoven Sonatas in chronological order for the ECM label, and the first volume has just been released.

description: TRINKOFF--Irwin H. Passed away in his home in Valeria on November 1, 2005. Dearest and loving husband of Maxine, father of Lloyd, Donna and Alexandra, grandfather of Daniel, Jonathan, Kyra, Ben, Zach and Dylan, brother of Burt and brother-in-law of Arline, father-in-law of Jan and Jeff. Irwin was a man of great loyalty with a keen sense of humor and a wonderful poet. He will be missed by his family and friends. The funeral is at Hellman Garlick Memorial Chapel, 1300 Pleasantville Road in Briarcliff, November 3, 12 noon.

A memorial service will be held at 12 noon, Sunday, November 6, at Navesink Country Club, Middletown, NJ.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Parents To Direct Teenager's Cancer Care
description: A state judge, clarifying an order he issued Monday, returned full discretion over the medical care of a 13-year-old cancer patient to her parents. The order, by Judge Jack Hunter of Texas District Court in Corpus Christi, takes effect when the child, Katie Wernecke, completes a chemotherapy regimen now under way. The Texas Human Services Department took custody of Katie in June after her parents objected to radiation therapy urged by doctors who were treating her for Hodgkin's disease. Katie's father, Edward Wernecke, said that the treatments would harm her and that he preferred to pursue alternative remedies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CERUSSI, ANNE T.
description: CERUSSI--Anne T. Died on November 2, 2005, after a short illness. She was 78 and lived in Rye, NY. She is survived by her sons, Michael A. Jr. of Greenwich, CT and Thomas F. of Darien, CT; daughters, Rosemary Ferrer of Greenwich, CT and Nancy A. McEnaney of Ridgefield, Ct; brothers John O'Brien, Thomas O'Brien and Cornelius O'Brien; sisters, Mary Mahon, Loretta Duffy and Kathleen Mullarkey and ten grandchildren. Her husband, Michael, and a son, Ernest, predeceased her. The family will receive friends on Friday, November 4, 2005, from 2PM to 4PM and from 6PM to 9PM at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Raod, Rye, NY. A Mass of Christian Burial will take place on Saturday, November 5, 2005 at 9:45 AM at the Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WENZEL, ALICE NEWMAN
description: WENZEL--Alice Newman, on October 31, after many years of dealing with adult normal pressure hydrocephalis and emphysema. She was the center of life and love for husband John and daughters Emily and Abby. Grandmother of Bianca and Sophia, mother-in-law of Mark, sister of Rita Kolsby (Edwin). Sister-in-law of Patricia Lord and Peggy Schofield. Alice loved her cousins and many nieces and nephews. She was Cornell Phi Beta Kappa 1947, and Smith MSW 1954. She beautifully balanced family life with a career in family therapy, primarily at Family Service Association of Nassau. Alice was a longtime resident of Sea Cliff and more recently of Manhasset and Tucson. A memorial service for family and friends TBA. Contributions may be made to Planned Parenthood of Nassau County, 516-750-2600.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Labor Leaders Criticize Transit Agency
description: The Transport Workers Union and Public Advocate Betsy Gotbaum yesterday criticized a decision by New York City Transit to reassign 177 maintenance workers from elevated structures to track cleaning, saying that many of the stations still need repairs. Charles F. Seaton, an agency spokesman, said the workers were rehabilitating elevated stations until transit officials determined "they weren't cost-competitive." They are now clearing debris from tracks and applying grout to prevent water from seeping onto the rails, he said. The union's main three-year contract with the agency expires on Dec. 15, and both sides have exchanged criticisms recently. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: Too Up-to-Date to Stay in the Attic
description: PAINTED furniture -- with fanciful finishes like country scenes, geometric patterns and fake wood grains -- is popular now for the same reason as in the 18th and 19th centuries: it mixes well. Decorators are using painted pieces to add interest to contemporary interiors. For those who like the look but aren't interested in investing in an antique, there are reproductions and modern interpretations made with old-fashioned techniques. Painted pieces have long been used as accents, said Stacy Hollander, the curator of "Surface Attraction," an exhibition of painted furniture through March 26 at the American Folk Art Museum, 45 West 53rd Street. In the 19th century, "it was common to see fanciful painted pieces mixed in with much more formal furniture," she said. "Painting on furniture supposedly delighted the eye and stimulated the brain."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HENDERSON, SKITCH
description: HENDERSON -- Skitch. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with profound sorrow the passing of its beloved friend, the renowned pianist and conductor Skitch Henderson, on November 1, 2005 in New Milford, Connecticut at the age of 87. Mr. Henderson was a deeply valued member of our Steinway Artist family for nearly sixty years. The Founder and Music Director of The New York Pops, Skitch Henderson was one of the most recognized musical personalities in America. His career included appearances with orchestras throughout the world, and his collaboration with such artists as Judy Garland, Frank Sinatra, and Bing Crosby was legendary. He became known to millions throughout America as music director at NBC Television, where he conducted the Tonight show and the Today show orchestras, introducing the use of classical music in variety programming. Mr. Henderson was a featured artist in Steinway & Sons' Centennial concert at Carnegie Hall in 1953, and his devotion to the Steinway piano and to our firm knew no bounds. Though our lives have been forever enriched by his music, his ebullient spirit will be sorely missed. To Ruth and to his children and grandchildren, we extend our love and our heartfelt condolences. -Bruce A. Stevens, President -Peter B. Goodrich, V.P. Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

description: JOSEPH--Andrew. The officers and staff of the Social Service Employees Union Local 371 express their profound sadness at the untimely passing of Andy Joseph, union activist, officer, colleague and longtime friend. Andy's keen mind for numbers and political analysis, as well as his ability to inspire and mobilize others, made an enormous contribution to the history of the union. He remained a close friend and ally throughout his distinguished career. We extend our love and deepest sympathy to his wife, Terry. Charles Ensley, President Officers and Staff, SSEU Local 371

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CERUSSI, ANNE T.
description: CERUSSI--Anne T. Died on November 2, 2005, after a short illness. She was 78 and lived in Rye, NY. She is survived by her sons, Michael A. Jr. of Greenwich, CT and Thomas F. of Darien, CT; daughters, Rosemary Ferrer of Greenwich, CT and Nancy A. McEnaney of Ridgefield, Ct; brothers John O'Brien, Thomas O'Brien and Cornelius O'Brien; sisters, Mary Mahon, Loretta Duffy and Kathleen Mullarkey and ten grandchildren. Her husband, Michael, and a son, Ernest, predeceased her. The family will receive friends on Friday, November 4, 2005, from 2PM to 4PM and from 6PM to 9PM at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Raod, Rye, NY. A Mass of Christian Burial will take place on Saturday, November 5, 2005 at 9:45 AM at the Church of the Resurrection, 910 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to the Westchester Leukemia and Lymphoma Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DRADDY, JOAN H.
description: DRADDY--Joan H. On November 2, 2005, of Manhasset, NY. Beloved wife of the late Cyril Francis Draddy. Dear mother of Daniel, Stephanie and Sue and the late Timothy. Calling hours at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, Saturday evening 7-9 & Sunday 3-5 & 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Monday 10 AM, St. Mary's RC Church, Manhasset with interment to follow in Nassau Knolls Cemetery.

title: A Mercurial Conceptualist Who Remains an Enigma
description: PHILADELPHIA - The sculptor, photographer, filmmaker, Duchampian trickster, wacky inventor, eccentric scholar, rock singer and songwriter Rodney Graham is a nutty professor of contemporary art. Though far from unknown, the Vancouver-based conceptualist has produced so many kinds of art during the last three decades that he remains something of an enigma.

title: Prospects for Revising the Guidant-Johnson Deal Dim
description: The prospects that Johnson & Johnson will reach a new agreement to buy Guidant appeared to diminish yesterday, with people involved in the talks expressing for the first time skepticism that the companies will be able to resuscitate the transaction.

title: NASA Needs $5 Billion More for Shuttles, Director Says
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 - The National Aeronautics and Space Administration needs up to $5 billion more than previously budgeted to operate the space shuttle before the program ends in 2010, and it is looking for ways to reduce the shortfall, Michael D. Griffin, the agency administrator, said Thursday.

Corrections
description: A theater review on Wednesday about "The Salvage Shop," at the Storm Theater on West 46th Street, misidentified the actor who plays Sylvie at one point. He is David Little. (Paul Anthony McGrane, as noted elsewhere in the review, plays Eddie, Sylvie's son.)

title: Refusing to Coast on 7 Infamous Words
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Oct. 28 - Ruth Richardson and Reuben Briggs were seated near each other at a theater here, but other than a shared admiration for the evening's featured performer -- George Carlin -- they did not appear to have much else in common.

title: An Organic Drift
description: Organic food has become a very big business, with a 20 percent annual growth rate in sales in recent years. But popularity has come at a price. Ever since 2002, when the Department of Agriculture began its program of national organic certification, there has been a steady lobbying effort to weaken standards in a way that makes it easier for the giant food companies, which often use synthetic substances in processing, to enter the organic market.

title: Learning the Ropes of Cowhide and Pigskin
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 3 - For Cody Pickett, his hometown is more than the place he was raised. It is who he is.

title: Excited and Wary, Investors Look at China
description: SAN FRANCISCO - WHEN Joe Schoendorf, a Silicon Valley venture capitalist, was in Shanghai a few years ago to hear a pitch from a Chinese start-up company, he sensed something familiar. He interrupted the meeting, walked to the window and pulled back the curtains.

title: Europe Looking Into Report of C.I.A. Jails
description: BERLIN, Nov. 3 - The European Union said Thursday that it would "seek more information" on allegations that a member country and a would-be member might have been sites of secret American jails for suspected members of Al Qaeda. The European Commission, the organization's executive arm, stopped short of starting a formal investigation.

title: St. John's Seeks Spark From Familiar Name
description: There wasn't much excitement the last few seasons at a half-empty Madison Square Garden when St. John's played. Bad teams have a hard time filling seats. Coach Norm Roberts's mission is to change that, and he hopes to do so this season with the help of a spindly freshman whose father once brought toughness and energy to the very same Garden floor when wearing a Knicks uniform.

title: For Former Cowboys, Race Team Is No Snap
description: FORT WORTH, Nov. 3 - The two-time season champion Terry Labonte and the journeyman Tony Raines were introduced Thursday as the initial driving team for Hall of Fame Racing, the Nascar Nextel Cup entry owned by the former Dallas Cowboys quarterbacks Roger Staubach and Troy Aikman that plans to begin racing next year.

title: Investing: In Europe, a beta shift
World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Hudson's Bay Is Eliminating 825 Jobs
description: The Hudson's Bay Company said that it was cutting about 825 management and administrative positions and realigning senior leadership in an effort to reduce costs. An entity controlled by the American investor Jerry Zucker, Hudson's Bay's largest shareholder, has made a hostile bid of 14.75 Canadian dollars a share, which the company said it was assessing.

title: 36 Hours in San Jose, Calif.
description: SAN Jose passed San Francisco in population over a decade ago, but even though it's the high-tech capital of Silicon Valley, it still has a hard time competing for attention with its brassy, glamorous neighbor to the north. In the Bay Area itself, however, what used to feel like a rivalry no longer does. San Francisco, Oakland and San Jose have all grown together into one extended city full of interconnections, sharing liberal politics, a flair for innovation, a rich culinary tradition and a laughing disdain for the notion that the East Coast is the center of the world. And like any other part of the Bay Area, San Jose has attracted more than its share of creative oddballs who made their marks in colorful ways.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A letter on Wednesday from River Edge, N.J., about the nomination of Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. to the Supreme Court referred imprecisely to a Pennsylvania abortion law on which Judge Alito wrote an opinion. It would have required a woman (with certain exceptions) to notify her husband before an abortion, not to obtain his consent.

title: 32 Years Later, Rape Victim Confronts Attack Suspect in Court Again
description: Her testimony began with silence, and for a long moment she appeared overwhelmed with pain.

title: 'Blue Boy' for a Living; Landscapes for Pleasure
description: NEW HAVEN - Best known as a society portraitist (think of "Blue Boy," his sleek, princely picture of one Master Jonathan Buttall), the English painter Thomas Gainsborough (1727-88) really yearned to do landscapes, regarding his portrait practice as a bread-and-butter operation. As a young man, untutored in art but working in London with the French engraver and illustrator Hubert Gravelot, he developed an interest in Dutch landscapes by Hobbema, van Ruisdael, van Ostade and others.

title: Panthers Hope to Find Themselves in Tampa Bay
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Nov. 2 - The Carolina Panthers tempered all the preseason Super Bowl talk by opening with a 1-2 record. After quieting the hype, the Panthers followed with a 4-0 run that once again raised expectations.

title: Defending Imperial Nudity
description: Hans Christian Andersen understood bad rulers. "The Emperor's New Suit" doesn't end with everyone acclaiming the little boy for telling the truth. It ends with the emperor and his officials refusing to admit their mistake.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Jury in the Second Vioxx Trial Absolves Merck in a Product Liability Suit The drug company Merck won decisively in the second Vioxx-related personal injury case to go to trial, an outcome that legal experts say could slow the flood of lawsuits against the company. After deliberating for about nine hours over three days, a jury in New Jersey found by an 8-1 vote that Merck was not at fault in a product liability suit over Vioxx, a pain medicine that was subsequently taken off the market. [Page A1.]

title: New Medicare Plan Presents a Drug Benefit Conundrum
description: Correction Appended

title: Here, Men Are the Vessels That Decant Women's Woes
description: What do we expect when an all-male troupe performs Shakespeare? The equivalent of Bach played on period instruments, a glimpse of authenticity and the delight of making what is familiar new and surprising. What about the mix of serious technique and trompe l'oeil comedy -- the kind we see when the men of Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo become sylphs in pointe shoes, white tulle and wings?

title: High Desert and High Culture in the Old Southwest
description: ENTHUSIASTIC skiers and hikers, Vance du Rivage and Joy Cunningham spent several winter holidays in Vail, Colo., before visiting northern New Mexico in 1999. They fell in love with the area's landscape of high desert and mountains. Just as captivating was the social environment. New Mexico has no racial majority, and its Hispanic and Indian heritages are a strong presence.

title: A Would-Be Las Vegas Rolls the Dice
description: AFTER winning several thousand dollars at the blackjack table, Sam May, 26, a lawyer from Costa Mesa, Calif., strode past the burly bouncer and was whisked 26 floors above the casino floor. With 50 Cent blaring through giant speakers, he and four friends were escorted to a booth marked "reserved" next to the retro-futuristic dance floor, where a gaggle of buxom women were vying for attention.
