title: Senate Votes $1.66 Billion for Storm-Displaced Pupils
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 - After years of bitter, often partisan clashes on broadening federal assistance to private and parochial schools, the Senate approved by a unanimous voice vote on Thursday a $1.66 billion aid package for public and private schools across the country that have taken in students displaced by Hurricane Katrina.

title: 'Da Vinci Code' Losing Best-Seller Status
description: After more than two years spent dominating the New York Times best-seller list, "The Da Vinci Code," by Dan Brown, is dropping off the list, at least temporarily. In the week ended Oct. 29, "The Da Vinci Code" ranked 16th in The Times's statistically weighted survey of almost 4,000 bookstores and wholesalers serving 50,000 other retailers. Therefore, it will be missing from the list of the top 15 best-selling books, to be published in the Nov. 13 edition of The Times Book Review. On the list to be published this Sunday, which is currently available online at www.nytimes.com, "The Da Vinci Code" ranks No. 12, in its 136th consecutive week on the list. The decline, while somewhat related to an inevitable lag in sales for a book that has been out so long, can also be traced to the publication in recent weeks of a raft of new highly anticipated books from authors like Patricia Cornwell, Danielle Steel and Nicholas Sparks. All of the books ahead of "Da Vinci" on the list have been on sale for five weeks or less. Doubleday, the book's publisher, is weighing when to release the book in paperback, a decision likely to be influenced by the release of the "Da Vinci Code" film, currently scheduled for May.

title: A Look Inside the Outsize Company That Is the Biggest Retailer on the Planet
description: Robert Greenwald's "Wal-Mart: The High Cost of Low Price" is not "Fahrenheit 9/11." There are no goofy takeoffs of old television series. You won't see H. Lee Scott Jr., the chief executive of Wal-Mart, the largest retailer on the planet, practicing his golf swing or making revealing comments on camera.

title: The Capitol's Revolting Door
description: A Senate hearing has provided a rarefied look at Washington's ever-whirring carousel for business lobbyists and government appointees, who spin back and forth between the private and public sectors in a blur of opportunism. The Interior Department's former deputy secretary, Steven Griles -- who had been tapped for that job by the Bush administration when he worked as a lobbyist for the mining industry -- was accused of using his government post to carry out the bidding of Jack Abramoff, the indicted power lobbyist who sought favorable Interior rulings for Indian-tribe clients vying for casinos.

title: Berlusconi Says He Was Target of Bomber
description: In an interview with the newspaper Libero, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi said he had been "the object of a direct threat" by a potential suicide bomber at a sports stadium. He said there had been "a kamikaze at the stadium against me" but gave no other details. A spokesman in the prime minister's office in Rome declined to comment. Brian Wingfield (NYT)

title: Without Fanfare, Building of New Trade Center Starts
description: When are they ever going to start building the new World Trade Center?

title: Tufts Is Getting Gift of $100 Million, With Rare Strings
description: Pierre M. Omidyar, the founder of eBay, and his wife, Pamela, gave $100 million to Tufts University this week, with some unusual strings attached.

title: INSIDE
description: House Vote on Treatment Of Detainees Is Delayed The House Republican leadership delayed a vote on a proposed ban against cruel and degrading treatment of prisoners in American custody, and Democrats called it an effort to spare the vice president a defeat. Democrats had planned to offer a motion to endorse language in a military spending bill that would prohibit abusive treatment. PAGE A25

Ford to Subsidize Ethanol Pumps in Midwest
description: Ford, in partnership with the ethanol producer VeraSun Energy, plans to announce today that it will subsidize the installation of ethanol fuel pumps at gas stations around the Midwest. Ford also said it would increase the number of vehicles it builds that can burn fuel with as much as 85 percent ethanol.

title: Rejuvenated Rangers Win as Brodeur Sits
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 3 - It had been nearly a dozen years since the Devils faced the Rangers without Martin Brodeur in goal.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: One Shot And Six Assaulted In Dispute
description: One person was shot and six others were assaulted in an apartment in Bushwick early yesterday morning. Three men entered the apartment, at 316 Suydam Street, about 3:30 a.m. and demanded cash, the police said. The men shot a 17-year-old man in the shoulder and assaulted four men and two women inside the apartment. The shooting victim was in critical condition at Elmhurst Hospital Center yesterday.

Mother-in-law of Brian Cohen, Itzik Levin and Margo Manspeizer. Dear sister of Ann Saunder and Harvey Halem. Cherished grandmother of Yarden, Jacob, Tal, Shai, Kfir, Adam, Gili, Allison and Ori.

title: Yitzhak Rabin: The longing for peace did not die with him
Italy's Top Spy Names Freelance Agent as Source of Forged Niger-Iraq Uranium Documents
description: ROME, Nov. 3 - Italy's spymaster identified an Italian occasional spy named Rocco Martino on Thursday as the disseminator of forged documents that described efforts by Iraq to buy uranium ore from Niger for a nuclear weapons program, three lawmakers said Thursday.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Prince Charles's visit to Washington with his wife, Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall, referred incorrectly in some copies to the name in a toast that Charles gave at a White House dinner. He said that when he visited the White House in 1970, the press was "busy trying to marry me off to Tricia Nixon" -- not "Patricia." (Patricia was the given name of both Tricia and her mother, who was known as Pat.)

title: In Short Order, Oracle Loses One of Three Co-Presidents
description: Gregory B. Maffei, the chief financial officer and a co-president of the Oracle Corporation, resigned unexpectedly yesterday, less than five months after he joined the company.

title: EU meets with China on trade
To Fight Rising Prices, Fed Nominee May Need New Weapons
description: Early in his tenure as chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan declared that the risk of too much inflation was so considerable that he would "err more on the side of restrictiveness than of stimulus."

title: Web to world
World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: Latin Assets Benefit Telefnica Unit
description: Telefnica Mviles, Spain's largest cellular company, said its profit rose 24 percent as revenue from Latin America more than doubled after its $5.85 billion takeover of BellSouth's wireless units in that region. Third-quarter net income rose to 614.9 million euros ($742 million) from 496.1 million euros a year earlier, Telefnica Mviles said. Sales rose 46 percent, to 4.29 billion euros.

title: China and Vietnam report new bird-flu cases
A Mind-Bending Head Trip (All Legal)
description: LOS ANGELES - "Ecstasy" is the trippy, messy, highly entertaining survey put together by Paul Schimmel of the Museum of Contemporary Art here. It sprawls through the Geffen Contemporary, the museum's cavernous warehouse in Little Tokyo, which too often begs for attention but is now jammed with blissed-out mobs.

title: National Briefing | Mid-Atlantic: Pennsylvania: Governor Speaks Out On Strike
description: On the fourth day of a transit strike in Philadelphia, Gov. Edward G. Rendell said he would begin prodding the two sides to reach an agreement if talks remain stalled through the weekend. The cost of health care has been the main sticking point in negotiations, with the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority demanding that union members pay 5 percent of their health premiums. In a statement, Mr. Rendell, a Democrat, said he considered it "only fair" that union workers pay for some of their health insurance, though he stopped short of endorsing management's proposal. James Dao (NYT)

title: U.S. Starts Well in Bridge Match
description: ESTORIL, Portugal, Nov. 3 - In the Bermuda Bowl final at the world bridge championships here on Thursday, 48 of the 128 boards were played, with U.S.A. 1, the defending champions, outdoing Italy, winning all three sessions. By day's end, the Americans enjoyed a lead of 31 international match points, 105-74.

title: Better BlackBerry
In Intelligent Design Case, a Cause in Search of a Lawsuit
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 3 - For years, a lawyer for the Thomas More Law Center in Michigan visited school boards around the country searching for one willing to challenge evolution by teaching intelligent design, and to face a risky, high-profile trial.

title: AHEAD | Salsa Festivals; A Dance That Spans the World
description: THE infectious rhythm of Latin music has created salsa-dancing aficionados across the globe. Here in the United States, salsa congresses and festivals are generating tropical heat as the winter months draw near.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Contract Proposed For Detectives
description: In the latest of several city labor agreements, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday announced a tentative settlement that would raise salaries for the 5,500-member Detectives Endowment Association by about 17 percent over four years. The terms, which union members must ratify, are similar to those accepted by union officials for firefighters and sanitation workers. The detectives would accept changes including longer workdays, and would receive pay raises phased in until 2008.

title: Advisory Service Urges Vote Against Interpublic Directors
description: An institutional investor advisory service has recommended that shareholders of the troubled Interpublic Group of Companies withhold their votes for three directors who are seeking re-election at the company's annual meeting on Nov. 14.

title: Chirac dedicates memorial at site of Nazi camp
Rebel Attacks Kill at Least 16 in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 4 - Insurgent attacks across central Iraq, including one in which the attackers disguised themselves as women, left at least 16 dead today as Shiite Arabs across the country began celebrating the end of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan.

title: Militants Vow to Kill Envoy and Driver Seized in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 3 - The Islamic militant group Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia announced in an Internet posting on Thursday that it would kill a Moroccan diplomat and driver who were kidnapped in Iraq on the highway from Jordan last month.

title: William L. McLaughlin Dies at 77; Helped Measure Radiation
description: William L. McLaughlin, a radiation scientist who devised accurate and widely used methods for measuring the radiation absorbed by cancer patients and by many foods and commercial products, died Oct. 26 at his home in Lexington, Va. He was 77.

title: Behind the Iraq-Niger connection
Former Aide Didn't Disclose Involvement in C.I.A. Case
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 - Eric S. Edelman, an under secretary of defense and former deputy national security adviser to Vice President Dick Cheney, "would have been well advised" to tell Congress this spring about his "involvement" with the investigation into the C.I.A. leak case, the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee said in a statement on Thursday.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Teachers Approve Contract Deal:
description: New York City's public-school teachers have approved a 52-month contract agreement with the Bloomberg administration that calls for raises of 15 percent, ends some seniority rights in filling positions and creates a new master teacher position. But in a sign of the teachers' continuing anger with the Bloomberg administration and, in some cases, frustration with their own union leadership, the teachers showed far less support than they had for prior contracts. Only 63 percent voted in favor of the deal, compared with 94 percent who approved the previous contract, in 2002. In a statement, the union president, Randi Weingarten said: "It is my hope that with this agreement, we can put the bitterness of the last few years behind us." Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg issued a statement describing himself as "pleased" by the vote.

title: Pakistani Leader Delays F-16 Buy for Quake
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 4 - President Pervez Musharraf said today that Pakistan would postpone the purchase of F-16 fighters from the United States as his country tries to grapple with the massive devastation of the Oct. 8 earthquake, which has claimed more than 73,000 lives.

title: Roundup: Sorenstam scores 8 birdies in Japan

Could it be Dr. John? Leon Russell? Is that a Texas or a Louisiana twang? What year are we in? 1973?

title: Arts, Briefly; Wilson Plays Canceled
description: In a sudden change, the Signature Theater Company announced yesterday that it would not present several productions of plays by August Wilson during the 2006-7 season, following a request from the late author's estate. Mr. Wilson, a two-time Pulitzer Prizewinner for drama who is considered the country's greatest African-American playwrights, died of cancer on Oct. 2 at the age of 60. A statement released yesterday said that the Signature had been informed that the Wilson estate "couldn't continue to grant rights at this time." James Houghton, the artistic director of the company, said that he was very disappointed but that "we respect the wishes of Mr. Wilson's estate." John Breglio, the estate's lawyer, said that the decision was no reflection on the Signature, but that Mr. Wilson's death had necessitated a period of taking stock as well as sorting through a number of proposals to commemorate the playwright's work. JESSE McKINLEY

In the Bay Area itself, however, what used to feel like a rivalry no longer does. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Workers' Compensation May Change
description: Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday renewed his call to overhaul the state's workers' compensation system, warning that the system's cost endangers businesses. The governor called for increasing injured workers' benefits, but capping the time that workers with permanent but partial disabilities can collect benefits. Business leaders praised the proposal, but Denis M. Hughes, the president of the state's A.F.L.-C.I.O., said it appeared to make it harder for injured workers to receive benefits. Assemblywoman Susan V. John, the Assembly's labor committee chairwoman, said she hoped the proposal would lead to a re-examination of the system, which she said failed workers and employees.

title: People: Quincy Jones, Garrison Keillor, Dennis Quaid
Hotel Reopenings
description: While larger full-service hotels reopened well before the city at large, New Orleans's smaller guesthouses and bed-and-breakfast operations have also been quick to return, although some have had a more difficult time than others.

title: Where's That Veto Threat?
description: Twice this year, President Bush has stood on the world stage and promised to sharply increase development assistance to poor nations. At the Group of 8 summit meeting in Scotland in July, Mr. Bush pledged to double aid to Africa by 2010, compared with the level in 2004. And at a United Nations summit meeting in New York in September, he said, "I call on the world's nations to implement the Monterrey Consensus," which calls for rich countries to increase their spending on development aid to 0.7 percent of gross national product by 2015.

title: Mayor Wins Wide Praise for Initiatives on Housing

Koch -- a $3 billion, five-year plan to begin to tackle New York City's housing shortage by producing 65,000 apartments and homes for New Yorkers with low and moderate incomes.

A Bargain With a Hollywood Devil, Followed by a Computer Date With an Archangel

Spewed with the slippery charm of a master of spin, his Orwellian double talk could stand as a cynical prophecy for our time.

description: KarstadtQuelle, Germany's biggest department store operator, reported a third-quarter profit, helped by cost cuts and asset sales. Analysts had expected a loss. Net income was 18.2 million euros ($22 million), in contrast to a loss of 1.23 billion euros a year earlier, the chief executive, Thomas Middelhoff, said in Dsseldorf. Mr. Middelhoff, who took over in May, has been selling outlets and cutting jobs after the retailer posted a record loss of 1.63 billion euros in 2004.

title: Performance Art Gets Its Biennial
description: Performance art may be getting its unruly, influential, shamanistic act together. At the moment, it seems to be the art world's medium of choice. Admired for its purity and subversive spirit, it is ubiquitous in gallery and museum exhibitions, whether on its own or as an active ingredient in video, installation art, sound art and photography. And performance art -- also known as performance -- is often the ghost in the machine in even the most static of objects; there is hardly a work of art with a scratchable surface that can't be assigned so-called performative aspects.

title: The Listings: Nov. 4 -- Nov. 10; BEBO VALDS
description: The triumphant re-emergence of elderly Cuban musicians has become something of a clich in recent years. But the pianist and composer Bebo Valds, above, has more than earned his late acclaim. During the 1950's, Mr. Valds was musical director of the Tropicana nightclub in Havana and a top-flight bandleader and sideman; he lays claim to inventing the batanga rhythm. His career took a turn with his defection in 1960; after settling in Stockholm, he spent three decades in obscurity. What brought him back was an invitation from the alto saxophonist Paquito D'Rivera to create what would become the 1995 album "Bebo Rides Again" (Universal Latino). A follow-up album, "El Arte Del Sabor" (Blue Note) reunited Mr. Valds with the great bassist Israel Lpez(known as Cachao) and won a Grammy Award. Mr. Valds received even wider exposure in "Calle 54," a 2000 documentary by Fernando Trueba, and on a subsequent run of albums produced by Mr. Trueba and Nat Chediak. The best known, "Lgrimas Negras" (Calle 54), was a rapturous meeting with the Spanish flamenco singer Diego El Cigala; the latest, "Bebo de Cuba" (Calle 54), is a brilliantly sprawling showcase, featuring a coterie of highly skilled New York musicians in both arranged and ad hoc settings. At the Village Vanguard -- a setting more familiar to the pianist Chucho Valds, his son -- Mr. Valds, now 87, will cast a more intimate spell. Backed by the bassist Javier Colina, a partner from the Cigala project, he will attest to the majesty of Latin music, but light-handedly, with a genuine jazz touch. (Tuesday through Nov. 13, 9 p.m., Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at 11th Street, West Village, (212) 255-4037; cover, $35, with a $10 minimum.)

title: A First Hearing for a Glass Symphony
description: Philip Glass's most glamorous projects these last 25 years have been operas, which he has composed plentifully and on virtually every conceivable subject, from historical figures to science fiction. But Mr. Glass has been building up his symphonic catalog as well, largely through the encouragement of Dennis Russell Davies, a conductor who has championed Mr. Glass's music since the early 1980's. It wasn't until 1992 that Mr. Glass wrote a work he called a symphony, and that was a tentative step: he based that first effort on themes from David Bowie and Brian Eno's "Low."

title: Tinkering With Success
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 3 - He was an only child in a lonely pursuit, a boy who used to consider golf clubs his friends. Tiger Woods learned early the unique emotions that came from taking divots on beat-up driving ranges, the errant swings that bred frustration, the flush connections that seemed to say, maybe this game can be had after all.

title: 'In Cold Blood'
description: The release of Bennett Miller's "Capote" has given Film Forum an excuse to screen a new print of Richard Brooks's "In Cold Blood." That movie, released in 1967 -- remarkably soon after the publication of Truman Capote's book and the execution of its two main characters -- is well worth revisiting. Filmed in some of the places in Kansas where the events depicted actually happened (including the penitentiary where Perry Smith and Dick Hickock were executed and the house where their victims lived and died), "In Cold Blood" is a potent and atmospheric example of noir-tinged naturalism. Conrad Hall's black-and-white cinematography takes us into a shadowy world of irrational evil, while Quincy Jones's score provides a hint of human warmth to the bleak landscape. Scott Wilson and Robert Blake (above right, with Mr. Wilson) play the killers, and John Forsythe plays Alvin Dewey, the investigator played by Chris Cooper in "Capote." Together, the movies, separated by almost 40 years, offer some intriguing meshes and contrasts. In some ways, Philip Seymour Hoffman as Capote provides the piece of "In Cold Blood" that has always been missing, but "In Cold Blood," on the screen and on the page, remains terrifyingly complete and coherent unto itself. (Through Tuesday, 209 West Houston Street, west of Avenue of the Americas, South Village, (212) 727-8110.)

title: Fold 'Em Before Poker Can Hold 'Em
description: IF Alex Rodriguez so desperately needs the competition fix of a poker game after six-plus months of baseball, there are numerous places he could go that would not put him and his sport at risk and would make him appear community-minded with a youth-conscious and hands-on -- so to speak -- approach.

The kids supposedly want the shiny new 3-D, computer-generated critters and monsters and have no appetite for old-fashioned drawn and tinted cels. Evidence for this trend has been found in the lackluster performance of some of Disney's recent animated features, which seemed not to be capturing the imaginations of audiences enchanted by Buzz Lightyear and Shrek.

Underlying that adage is a certain American confidence that whatever we lack in preparing our kids with strong fundamentals in math and science, we make up for by encouraging our best students to be independent, creative thinkers.

Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Senator Blocks M.T.A. Bus Purchase
description: State Senator Dean G. Skelos, left, who sits on a panel overseeing the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's construction budget, has vetoed a $148.9 million adjustment that would have allowed the authority to buy new express buses. In a letter on Wednesday, Mr. Skelos, a Nassau County Republican, said he could not allow the purchase because New York City had not completed the transfer of several city-subsidized bus companies to the authority's control. Mr. Skelos, a critic of the authority's plan to offer fare discounts to subway and bus riders during the holiday season, said he would reconsider his decision after the transfers are completed. His decision could delay for several months the purchase of the buses.

The Listings: Nov. 4 -- Nov. 10; 'NATURE'S LITTLE HELPERS'
description: They are repulsive little mutants, yet like E.T., Steven Spielberg's famous extraterrrestrial, they can be quite lovable. Quirkily modified humanimals, they have features ranging from hominid to rodent, with expanses of hairless skin. Some get cuddly with people; others bare feral teeth. These could-be-real creatures, revealed in sculptures and photographs, spring from the mind of Patricia Piccinini, an Australian artist concerned with new reproductive technologies. She calls her beasties "Nature's Little Helpers" for their role in "assisting" endangered Australian wildlife. One is the winsome little "Surrogate," a smiling, potbellied being sculptured in silicon and acrylic resin whose function is to incubate the fetuses of the endangered northern hairy-nosed wombat until the wombat can cope with a less friendly environment. Another is the scary, snarling "Bodyguard (for the Golden Helmeted Honeyeater)," envisioned by the artist as a protector for a small yellow-and-black bird. The monkeylike physique of "Bodyguard" enables it to swing quickly from tree to tree to scare off predators; its ferocious fangs can act as sap-releasers for the bird's nutrition. Others in the Piccinini menagerie bond more mysteriously with humans (endangered species, too, come to think of it), like the cute little quadruped (above) that has sprung onto the shoulders of a startled woman to embrace her face and hair, or the peculiar but loving nanny with bony spine plates and blobby growths on (her?) back, who snuggles protectively with a sleeping child. Finally, a human-to-human relationship is seen in the out-of-the-loop Neanderthal mom who suckles a newly minted 21st-century infant out of rote motherly instinct. A little harder to fathom are Ms. Piccinini's "Cyclepups," modified embryonic motorcycles in which biological processes are seen as affecting technology. Still, lovers of car culture will understand the need to nurture these creatures, too. (Robert Miller Gallery, 524 West 26th Street, Chelsea, (212) 366-4774, through Nov. 26.)

In Paris, Tough Talk Isn't Enough
description: The suburbs of Paris have a long history of violent uprisings by enraged residents. But the nightly clashes in the grimy northeastern environs over the past week have been grimly contemporary. The rioters torching cars and pelting the police are mainly the sons of African and Arab immigrants, most of them Muslims, who have never been integrated into French society, who work for the lowest wages and who live in ghettos rife with crime.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CUDDEBACK, ROBERT
description: CUDDEBACK -- Robert. Of Glen Cove, NY, died Sunday, October 30, at the age of 76. Beloved husband of 38 years to Katherine. Beloved father to Cheryl, Robert, Brad and John. Favorite grandfather, great-grandfather, brother, uncle and cousin. Best friend to many, friend to all. Graduate of Kent School and Brown University. 2nd Lieutenant in US Army. An icon in the maritime shipping industry, and a proud member of the Founders Club of the petrochemical industry. More than anything, he loved being with family and friends, and we loved being with him. A true gentleman, he lived life. Memorial service at Locust Valley Reformed Church, on Saturday, November 5, at 9:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Kent School, Kent, CT. 06757.

title: Spanish Parliament Backs Catalonia Autonomy
description: Parliament agreed to consider a proposal by the wealthy northeastern region of Catalonia for greater autonomy from Madrid. The lawmakers voted 197 to 146 to open negotiations over the proposal, and the hours of passionate speeches preceding the vote underscored the seriousness of the debate ahead. A final vote is not expected until next year. The proposal calls for transferring an array of powers, like tax collection, away from the central government. One of its most controversial elements is a reference to Catalonia as a "nation." In the debate leading up to the parliamentary vote, Prime Minister Jos Luis Rodrguez Zapatero, above, who has been reluctant to explain in detail his views on the proposal, appeared to choose a middle ground. "Catalonia has a national identity," he said. "That is compatible with the Constitution." Renwick McLean (NYT)

title: Treasures Emerge From Field of the Dead at Maidanek
description: LUBLIN, Poland, Oct. 31 - Adam Frydman shut his heavy-lidded eyes and vividly recalled his first glimpse of this unplowed field 62 years ago. He was 20 and had just arrived from the Warsaw ghetto with his father and brother. He imagined hundreds of Polish Jews huddled behind barbed wire fences. He heard barking dogs. He inhaled the unmistakable smell of death. When he got his bearings, he pointed unambiguously.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STACK, MAURICE D.
description: STACK--Maurice D. Of Point Lookout, NY and West Palm Beach, died November 3. Loving and beloved husband of the late Catherine (O'Connor), loving father of Mary Jane Platt, Eileen Hennegan, Peter Stack and Clare Richer and beloved "Maury" to eight grandchildren. He was the son of the late Maurice and Margaret Stack, and brother of the late Marie Stack. He graduated from LaSalle Academy, attended the University of Notre Dame, received a BA from Manhattan College and an MBA from Harvard Business School. He served in the Army during World War II as a Major in the Corps of Engineers. He retired from the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company as Chairman of the Finance Committee and a member of the Board of Trustees. Other business-related activities included board positions with the Union Square Savings Bank, United States and Foreign Securities Corporation, and membership in the American Bureau of Shipping. He was very active in a number of charitable boards including St. Vincent's Hospital, the Investment Committee of the United States Olympic Committee, the Pension Committee of the Sisters of Charity, the boards of the College of Mount St. Vincent, Havens Relief Fund Society, the National YWCA, and the Society for the Propagation of the Faith. He was a Knight of Malta and a member of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick. He was a true gentleman and he will be missed by his family and friends. Reposing after 2PM Saturday at Charles J. O'Shea Funeral Home, 603 Wantagh Ave. (Exit 28 NSS Pkwy.), Wantagh. Funeral Mass Monday, 10:30AM, at Our Lady of Miraculous Medal RC Church, Point Lookout, LI. Interment Calverton National Cemetery, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Vincent's Catholic Medical Center Foundation, 170 W. 12th St., SPB 125, NY NY 10011. Family will receive friends Saturday 2-5PM and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9PM.

The police did not release the names of the men or the towns and did not disclose whether the men were suspected of having links to the Irish Republican Army. Police officials in Ireland and Northern Ireland have publicly blamed the I.R.A. for the cash robbery, Britain's biggest. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HENDERSON, SKITCH
description: HENDERSON -- Skitch. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with profound sorrow the passing of its beloved friend, the renowned pianist and conductor Skitch Henderson, on November 1, 2005 in New Milford, Connecticut at the age of 87. Mr. Henderson was a deeply valued member of our Steinway Artist family for nearly sixty years. The Founder and Music Director of The New York Pops, Skitch Henderson was one of the most recognized musical personalities in America. His career included appearances with orchestras throughout the world, and his collaboration with such artists as Judy Garland, Frank Sinatra, and Bing Crosby was legendary. He became known to millions throughout America as music director at NBC Television, where he conducted the Tonight show and the Today show orchestras, introducing the use of classical music in variety programming. Mr. Henderson was a featured artist in Steinway & Sons' Centennial concert at Carnegie Hall in 1953, and his devotion to the Steinway piano and to our firm knew no bounds. Though our lives have been forever enriched by his music, his ebullient spirit will be sorely missed. To Ruth and to his children and grandchildren, we extend our love and our heartfelt condolences. -Bruce A. Stevens, President -Peter B. Goodrich, V.P. Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

title: The Listings: Nov. 4 -- Nov. 10; MAKING MUSIC: MEREDITH MONK
description: Meredith Monk's unforgettable approach to the voice begins where classical vocal technique ends. The method she invented is sometimes called "extended vocal technique," but this bland phrase hardly hints at the striking, extraterrestrial vocabulary of sighs, squeals and glottal acrobatics that Ms. Monk has been refining for decades. Working over the years as a vocalist (as well as a dancer, choreographer and inventor of site-specific installations), Ms. Monk has understandably relied on her own ensemble or close colleagues to execute her ideas, but that tight circle may finally be expanding. In January, she will lead a professional training workshop at Carnegie Hall, teaching her recondite craft to 16 students, and anyone else who wants to listen in. And on Sunday in Zankel Hall, Ms. Monk's work will receive a marathon four-hour tribute as adventurous performers try to wrap their minds, instruments and vocal cords around her radical language. The parade will include Bjork, John Zorn, DJ Spooky, Ursula Oppens, Bruce Brubaker, Alarm Will Sound and the Bang on a Can All-Stars, as well as Ms. Monk and her own ensemble, of course. John Schaefer, of WYNC, moderates. (2 p.m., Zankel Hall, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800; sold out. A second Monk tribute with Theo Bleckmann, the Axis Dance Company and the Pacific Mozart Ensemble is to take place Wednesday at 7 p.m., Winter Garden, World Financial Center, West Street, Lower Manhattan, (212) 945-0505; free.)

title: The Authority at the Authority, Embracing Dullness
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. - WHITE shirt, tame tie, nerdy specs, wallflower proclivities: Anthony R. Coscia, chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, wears his distance from the Robert Moses-type table-slammers who preceded him in the upper echelon of metropolitan policy makers and power brokers like a disclaimer. The spotlight makes him cringe. Flesh-pressing and glad-handing are akin to sipping hemlock. He is, by nature, an inept fund-raiser. Let the charismatic guys run for office; Mr. Coscia prefers to be part of the scaffolding, an articulate infrastructure player.

title: Financial and Family Troubles, With Claws and Melted Butter

With an astutely chosen ensemble led by Danny Aiello and Jane Curtin, it has integrity up to its eyeballs. But integrity and accuracy of detail are not synonymous with clarity or dramatic weight. Mr. Jordan, who wrote, directed and produced this semiautobiographical film, is so close to his material that he often gets lost in it.

title: Turning Up the Charm and the Eye Contact
description: For a British heartthrob seeking stateside fame, there's a nagging concern: when in your concert do you sing the anguished songs about war crimes? One of the oft-noted biographical selling points of James Blunt, a falsetto-voiced 28-year-old singer-songwriter, has been the Kosovo peacekeeping stint that inspired his recent British hit "No Bravery." A piano ballad that doubles as grisly reportage, it lends weight to Mr. Blunt's other hits, like the more traditionally lovelorn British smash "You're Beautiful."

title: Arts, Briefly; MoMA Curator Resigns
description: After more than 14 years in the department of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art, the chief curator Terence Riley announced yesterday in an e-mail message to the staff and trustees that he would resign effective March 15. "As we approach the 75th anniversary of the museum's first exhibition of architecture, I think it is an appropriate moment to make a change and bring in new voices and new thoughts," the message said. In an interview, Mr. Riley, right, said he would continue to work with Glenn D. Lowry, the museum's director, as an adviser on museum initiatives, including the completion of the education building. Mr. Riley will also spend more time on K/R, his architecture firm, he said, and teach architecture at Harvard University. He is also talking with a new architecture and design museum in Spain ("I can't say where") about a project there. "With the opening of the new building, I really felt a corner had been turned in a certain sense," Mr. Riley said of the remodeled MoMA that opened last November. In an interview, Mr. Lowry said he and Mr. Riley had spent the last year talking about the possibility of the curator's moving on. Mr. Lowry praised Mr. Riley for doing "a terrific job" with acquisitions and exhibitions. FELICIA R. LEE

Devoted husband of the late Dorothy, adoring father of Jeffrey, Bonnie, Stephan and the late Pamela. Honored grandfather of Rachel, Joshua, Heather, and Michael, joyous great grandfather of Tamar. An extraordinary man of many dimensions. He was honored, respected and loved by all those he touched. A devoted family man of strongly held beliefs, high moral fiber and great charity. title: National Briefing | South: Arkansas: Poultry And Water Quality
description: Attorney General Mike Beebe asked the United States Supreme Court to intervene in a dispute involving Oklahoma water quality regulations that he said threatened the Arkansas poultry industry and violated federal law. A lawsuit filed by Mr. Beebe's Oklahoma counterpart, Drew Edmondson, seeks damages from eight Arkansas poultry farms for allegedly polluting the Illinois River, which serves as a water supply for eastern Oklahoma. Mr. Beebe said that Mr. Edmondson's lawsuit would improperly impose Oklahoma regulations on Arkansas residents, and that an existing compact between the two states was the appropriate forum for resolving the conflict. Mr. Edmondson said he would ask the Supreme Court to dismiss Mr. Beebe's petition. Steve Barnes (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about the hunger crisis in Malawi and neighboring nations misstated the amount of southern Africa relief contributed to the World Food Program this year by the United States Agency for International Development. While the agency did contribute $48 million in response to the food program's emergency appeal for southern Africa, it also provided the food program with $33 million in earlier contributions, as well as $7 million to a consortium of global charities working on the hunger crisis.

title: Musicians' Union Files Complaint Against Radio City Owner
description: The union representing musicians at Radio City Music Hall said yesterday that it had filed a complaint claiming that Radio City's owner was trying to "personally extort" a public apology regarding their continuing contract dispute, which has already cast a shadow over the annual "Christmas Spectacular."

title: FEMA Calls 60,000 Houses in Storm Area Beyond Repair
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 - Using a sophisticated satellite inspection system, FEMA has declared 60,000 houses in New Orleans and other communities hit hardest by Hurricane Katrina damaged beyond repair, clearing the way for homeowners there to receive the maximum federal aid.

title: It's All Downhill After Introductions
description: The opening image of the Larry Brown era at Madison Square Garden was understated but poignant. As a short video tribute to Brown, the Knicks' new coach, played on the scoreboard last evening, he shifted awkwardly from side to side near the home team's bench.

title: Politics in Azerbaijan: Two Sides of the Coin
description: To the Editor:

title: Still Ruling His Empire of Dirt and Pain
description: Of course Trent Reznor wore black when Nine Inch Nails played Madison Square Garden on Thursday night. Since the band's debut album in 1989, on which Mr. Reznor played nearly all the instruments, he has been rock's voice of rage, bitterness and inconsolable despair, lashing out both at the world that betrays him and at his own malignant soul. While his lyrics are blunt -- "After everything I've done, I hate myself for what I've become" -- his music has been a fusion of punk impact, electronic textures, dance-music propulsion and enough melodic interludes to make the rest seem more brutal.

title: A Human Doll Caught Up in Patterns (Pay No Attention to the Mouse)
description: David Grenke envisions his oddly named company, ThingsezIsee'em, as a vehicle for unconventional multimedia work. In "Tongues," seen Thursday at the TBG Theater, Mr. Grenke staged a new version of the Sam Shepard and Joseph Chaikin play, first performed in 1978. It was his second foray into such material; in 2001, he created a rendition of "Savage/Love."

title: As Multimillionaires Duel, Corzine Outspends Forrester
description: TRENTON, Nov. 4 - Senator Jon S. Corzine has spent $43 million so far in the race to become New Jersey's next governor, outpacing his opponent, Douglas R. Forrester, who has put $29 million of his own money into the campaign.

title: Home Building Loses Its Commanding Lead in Setting Economy's Pace
description: THE building of houses, which buoyed the American economy during the 2001 recession and then spurred the recovery, is no longer leading the economy up.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDSTEIN, MARVIN J.
description: GOLDSTEIN--Marvin J. The staff and partners of Kleinfeld Bridal Corporation are deeply saddened by the sudden death of their friend, partner and counselor--a man of impeccable integrity, decency and intelligence. There will be a significant void in our lives. We extend our deepest condolences to Linda, Aimee and William. Kleinfeld Bridal Corporation Wayne Rogers, Chairman and Co-CEO Ronald R. Rothstein, Co-CEO Mara Urshel, President

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about Waldemar Nielsen, an expert on the workings of charitable foundations, misspelled the name of the director of the Foundation Center, which helps those seeking grants. She is Sara L. Engelhardt. Not Sarah L. Englehardt.

title: Court Nominee Has Paper Trail Businesses Like
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 - Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. has reliably favored big-business litigants as he has pushed the federal appeals court in Philadelphia in a conservative direction.

title: U.S. Should Repay Millions to Iraq, a U.N. Audit Finds
description: An auditing board sponsored by the United Nations recommended yesterday that the United States repay as much as $208 million to the Iraqi government for contracting work in 2003 and 2004 assigned to Kellogg, Brown & Root, the Halliburton subsidiary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CAPELIN, ESTELLE
description: CAPELIN - Estelle. Temple Beth-El of Great Neck records with profound sorrow the passing of our longtime Temple member, Estelle Capelin. We extend heartfelt sympathy to her bereaved family. Franklin S. Abrams, Pres. Jerome K. Davidson, Rabbi

title: Tellers Are on the Front Line of the Recovery in New Orleans
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 2 - One afternoon last week, Barbara and Robert Emelle, lifelong residents of New Orleans who have spent most of the last two months in Los Angeles, experienced a small touch of the familiar in a world otherwise turned upside down and inside out.

title: Today's Top Games
description: Tennessee (3-4) at No. 8 Notre Dame (5-2) 2:30 p.m., NBC

title: The Candidates Go Multilingual
description: Both candidates for mayor are using foreign-language ads to broaden their reach. An advertisement for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has a first in New York City politics: a mayor speaking Mandarin in a campaign commercial to make his case for re-election. It is one of several ads in which the mayor speaks a foreign language, including Urdu, Russian and Cantonese, to plead his case. This ad is running on Chinese-language cable-TV stations. A 30-second television ad for Fernando Ferrer, called "Aramina," in which his wife addresses the audience, is among several Spanish-language ads currently being broadcast.

title: Energy Galore, but Still No Catch for Jets Rookie
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 4 - Joel Dreessen doesn't plan on buying a new pickup anytime soon. He admits that his 1993 Ford F-150 is no longer fashionable, but he says that it suits him just fine. The New York traffic, however, is something the Jets' third-string tight end could do without.

title: The Candidates Go Multilingual
description: Both candidates for mayor are using foreign-language ads to broaden their reach. An advertisement for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has a first in New York City politics: a mayor speaking Mandarin in a campaign commercial to make his case for re-election. It is one of several ads in which the mayor speaks a foreign language, including Urdu, Russian and Cantonese, to plead his case. This ad is running on Chinese-language cable-TV stations. A 30-second television ad for Fernando Ferrer, called "Aramina," in which his wife addresses the audience, is among several Spanish-language ads currently being broadcast.

title: New Rule on G.E. Board
description: The General Electric Company has adopted a provision that would make it easier for shareholders to force out directors in corporate governance disputes, the company said yesterday.

title: Our Love-Hate Relationship With Wal-Mart
description: Correction Appended

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about the impact of the new Medicare drug coverage on retirees who have drug insurance from their former employers referred imprecisely to SBC Communications' policy. SBC is allowing employees to retain the rest of their company-sponsored health benefits even if they enroll in a Medicare drug plan; it is not requiring retirees to choose between company-sponsored health benefits and the Medicare plan.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about PresidentBushAs trip to Argentina for asummit meeting of Western Hemisphereleaders misstated the givenname of a Nobel Peace Prize winnerwho was one of the leaders of a protestmarch outside the meeting. He isAdolfo PArez Esquivel, not Alfonso. (Go to Article)

title: R. C. Gorman, Painter of Strong Navajo Women, Dies
description: R. C. Gorman, an internationally prominent Navajo artist whose portraits of voluptuous women in flowing traditional dress embodied the American Southwest for collectors around the world, died on Thursday at a hospital in Albuquerque. A longtime resident of Taos, N.M., he was believed to be in his mid-70's.

title: Este Lauder Makes a Play for Youth
description: Harpriya Sidhu, 26, a recent dental school graduate from Weehawken, N.J., is a faithful luxury consumer. Ms. Sidhu buys only Gucci or Burberry purses, Tiffany jewelry and cosmetics from Chanel or Kiehl's. Este Lauder was never a name that got her attention, because it is one of those brands "that are so mainstream," she said.

title: Close Encounters: Amorous, Amorphous and Abstract
description: The arresting figure of a platinum-blond, cropped-haired woman holding a strapless dress in front of her naked body boded well for the Marie-Christine Giordano Dance Company's "Nurtured or Neutered," which opened at the TriBeCa Performing Arts Center on Thursday night. As Marilyn Monroe's languorous rendition of "She Acts Like a Woman Should" wafted through the air, the woman -- Ms. Giordano herself -- gradually crumpled her body into a crouch, a quizzical expression on her fine-boned face.

title: Free Trade Begins at Home
description: It was 11 years ago that Bill Clinton stood on a stage in Miami flanked by the leaders of 33 North and South American countries and proposed a hemispheric free trade agreement that would stretch from Alaska to Tierra del Fuego. The Free Trade Area of the Americas, to be completed by 2005, would be the largest in the world, encompassing 850 million people with $13 trillion in purchasing power, its backers said.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SANOFF, DANNY
description: SANOFF--Danny. It's been a sad three years. Miss you so much. Love, Mom

title: Spain's African Enclaves Are Migrants' Portals to Europe
description: NADOR, Morocco - Zakaria Chouaib peered from his rocky perch on Mount Gourougou toward a stone and stucco settlement below. He had traveled overland about 2,000 miles from Ghana, largely on foot, to arrive within sight of his goal: an eightsquare-mile patch of Spanish territory on Africa's Mediterranean coast called Melilla.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Thursday about the New York Comedy Festival misspelled the surname of a comedian who is performing in it. He is Patrice Oneal, not O'Neal.

title: How to Stop the Flu in Midflight
description: To the Editor:

title: A Libby Lawyer Long Used to the Legal Spotlight
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 - While his latest celebrity client was being processed and fingerprinted Thursday morning, Theodore V. Wells Jr. paced the lobby at the federal courthouse here, flashing his trademark smile and chatting with reporters and other lawyers.

title: Hearing Date for Alito Leaves Bush Disappointed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 - President Bush said Friday that he was disappointed with the January date set by Senate Republican leaders for hearings on the Supreme Court nomination of Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr.

title: Metro Briefs
description: NEW YORK

title: Changing Course (Perhaps) on Housing
description: Public outrage over President Bush's mishandling of the Katrina disaster has forced the administration to back away -- if only temporarily -- from a deeply wrongheaded policy on low-income housing. In New Orleans this week, Housing and Urban Development Secretary Alphonso Jackson announced with great fanfare that the government would tear down some of the most unlivable high-density public housing in the country and replace it with model lower-density housing, which will probably serve mixed-income residents.

title: The Shoe Fits, So Giambi Goes Back on the Billboard
description: Jason Giambi won two awards as the American League comeback player of the year this season. Fans voted for one and players voted for the other. Now, Giambi is winning over Madison Avenue, too.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (HBO) MEET THE FOCKERS -- (2004). This sequel to "Meet the Parents" made a bundle at the box office last year, and not just because it was Barbra Streisand's first movie in eight years. She and Dustin Hoffman (above) star as the enthusiastically free-spirited parents of Greg Focker (BenStiller). Greg is bringing his girlfriend's parents (Robert De Niro and Blythe Danner) home for the first time, and they're a little stuffy in comparison.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: RWE Plans to Sell Two Water Utilities
description: RWE, Europe's third-largest utility, plans to sell Thames Water of London and the American Water Works Company of New Jersey, abandoning a five-year, $17 billion expansion that drew investments away from growing energy markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ATLAS, BRETT
description: ATLAS--Brett, of Huntington, NY, at age 24. Devoted son of Gayle and Stephen. Beloved brother of Craig. Cherished grandson of Theodore Dziedzic. Services Sunday, 2 PM, at I.J. Morris, Inc., 46 Greenwich St., Hempstead, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STACK, MAURICE D.
description: STACK--Maurice D. Of Point Lookout, NY and West Palm Beach, died November 3. Loving and beloved husband of the late Catherine (O'Connor), loving father of Mary Jane Platt, Eileen Hennegan, Peter Stack and Clare Richer and beloved "Maury" to eight grandchildren. He was the son of the late Maurice and Margaret Stack, and brother of the late Marie Stack. He graduated from LaSalle Academy, attended the University of Notre Dame, received a BA from Manhattan College and an MBA from Harvard Business School. He served in the Army during World War II as a Major in the Corps of Engineers. He retired from the Atlantic Mutual Insurance Company as Chairman of the Finance Committee and a member of the Board of Trustees. Other business-related activities included board positions with the Union Square Savings Bank, United States and Foreign Securities Corporation, and membership in the American Bureau of Shipping. He was very active in a number of charitable boards including St. Vincent's Hospital, the Investment Committee of the United States Olympic Committee, the Pension Committee of the Sisters of Charity, the boards of the College of Mount St. Vincent, Havens Relief Fund Society, the National YWCA, and the Society for the Propagation of the Faith. He was a Knight of Malta and a member of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick. He was a true gentleman and he will be missed by his family and friends. Reposing after 2PM Saturday at Charles J. O'Shea Funeral Home, 603 Wantagh Ave. (Exit 28 NSS Pkwy.), Wantagh. Funeral Mass Monday, 10:30AM, at Our Lady of Miraculous Medal RC Church, Point Lookout, LI. Interment Calverton National Cemetery, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Vincent's Catholic Medical Center Foundation, 170 W. 12th St., SPB 125, NY NY 10011. Family will receive friends Saturday 2-5PM and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9PM.

title: Spending Inquiry for Top Official on Broadcasting
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 - Kenneth Y. Tomlinson, the head of the federal agency that oversees most government broadcasts to foreign countries, including the Voice of America and Radio Free Europe, is the subject of an inquiry into accusations of misuse of federal money and the use of phantom or unqualified employees, officials involved in that examination said on Friday.

title: Immigrant Rioting Flares in France for Ninth Night
description: AULNAY-SOUS-BOIS, France, Nov. 4 - France's worst urban violence in a decade exploded for a ninth night on Friday as bands of youths roamed the immigrant-heavy, working-class suburbs of Paris, setting fire to dozens of cars and buildings while the government struggled over the violence and the underlying frustrations fueling it.

title: President Has Little to Say About Questions on Rove
description: MAR DEL PLATA, Argentina, Nov. 4 - President Bush was asked four times on Friday about Karl Rove and the C.I.A. leak investigation, and four times he refused to answer.

title: Intimidating Bets, and the All-In Equalizer
description: The young studs of poker no longer play very much stud. The five-card and seven-card versions of that game are played with predetermined bet sizes; along with five-card draw, they were the most popular forms of poker until 20 or 30 years ago. Today the flop games have taken over: pot-limit Omaha; limit, pot-limit and no-limit hold'em; and, most of all, no-limit hold'em tournaments.

title: Iraq's Lethal Traffic: Warning! Anarchy Ahead
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 4 - It was Monday morning in one of the world's most dangerous cities, and already the traffic was causing a peculiar, decidedly nonmechanical sort of breakdown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALDBAUER, ROBERT T.
description: WALDBAUER -- Robert T. Died suddenly November 3 at age 83. Flew valiantly as Army Air Force pilot 218 combat missions over the Hump in World War II. Dedicated public servant in Village of Patchogue, Suffolk County, including sixteen years as mayor. Served in many public capacities including Congressional District Field Representative for Otis G. Pike, Board member of MTA and NYS Power Authority. Owner George Waldbauer & Sons automotive wholesale business, devoted husband of sixty years to the late Marie Hemmel. Loving father to Carol, Nancy, Penny & Tad and grandfather to five. Services Monday, November 7, 10AM, Patchogue Congregational Church, 95 East Main St. Visiting Saturday and Sunday Ruland Funeral Home, Patchogue, N.Y. Donations to Ohio University Foundation, P.O. Box 869, Athens, Ohio 45701.

title: Congressman Subpoenaed in Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 - Representative Bob Ney, the Ohio Republican who is chairman of the House Administration Committee, was subpoenaed this week for documents and testimony in the federal corruption investigation of the Republican lobbyist Jack Abramoff, House officials announced Friday.

title: Hemisphere Summit Marred by Violent Anti-Bush Protests
description: MAR DEL PLATA, Argentina, Nov. 4 - President Bush's troubles trailed him to an international summit meeting here on Friday as anti-Bush protesters turned violent just blocks from the gathering site, and Hugo Chvez, Venezuela's fiery populist leader, rallied a soccer stadium filled with at least 25,000 people against the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PEREIRA, ANA
description: PEREIRA--Ana. The Heritage Health and Housing, Inc. Board of Directors and staff join the Pereira family in mourning the loss of our beloved Ana Pereira. She was 72. As Executive Director of Heritage Housing and Community Services--an organization she helped to found 28 years ago--Ms. Pereira was a champion to New York's neediest. Her vision, drive and determination transformed a storefront operation into a widely respected service and development agency, which delivered service-enriched housing services to the homeless and those with special needs. Under her vision and leadership, Heritage helped the city become a warmer place for those who have been historically disenfranchised. Today, as we mourn her, we are also entrenched and steeped in our commitment to continue the vision and extend ourselves caring for those who remain in need, assuring quality of care, forever building on a legacy of love and devotion. Charitable contributions in honor of Ms. Pereira's legacy can be made to the Ana Pereira Memorial Endowment Fund, 416 W. 127 St, New York, N.Y. 10027. Funeral will be held Saturday, November 5, 10AM at St. James Presbyterian Church, 141 St. and St. Nicholas Ave. The Repast will be held at Heritage Health and Housing, Inc., 416 W. 127 St, New York, N.Y. 10027. For additional information please call 212-866-2600. The Heritage Health Housing, Inc. Board of Directors and Staff

title: The Time Is Wrong for Tax Cuts
description: Before Hurricane Katrina, Congressional Republicans seemed unstoppable in their drive to cut taxes by an additional $70 billion in the next five years. Now some of the moderates are thinking twice. They fear the cost at a time when the country is already borrowing hundreds of billions of dollars -- most of it from foreigners -- to pay for things like war, hurricane recovery and flu vaccine. And they fear voters' disapproval if they cut taxes for wealthy taxpayers after gutting programs for the poor. (The tax cuts are scheduled to come up just after the current round of spending cuts.)

title: A Speedier Crane Creeps Up Leader Board
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 4 - Ben Crane has been working on his swing change, namely speeding up the time it takes for his clubface to meet his golf ball.

title: As President, Clinton Says, She'd Top Me
description: Bill Clinton told an Israeli television station yesterday that Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton would make a better president of the United States in some ways than he did.

title: Carter Shrugs Off Boos as Nets Silence Toronto
description: TORONTO, Nov. 4 - This time last year, things would have been much different for Vince Carter.

title: Internal Conflict Threatens to Split Opposition Party in Zimbabwe
description: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 4 - Zimbabwe's opposition party appeared to be on the verge of a potentially fatal split on Friday as a top official accused the party's leader of ignoring and intimidating his critics within the organization and condoning acts of violence against them.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: 3 Charged As Terror Suspects
description: Three men arrested in southern England last month were charged under antiterrorism laws. Two were accused of conspiracy to murder and to cause an explosion. One, Waseem Mughal, 22, had a "recipe" for rocket propellant and a DVD titled "Martyrdom Operations Vest," prosecutors said. He was also said to have papers with the phrases "welcome to jihad" and "hospital attack." The other, Younis Tsouli, also 22, was accused of keeping instructions for building a car bomb on a computer. The third man, Tariq al-Daour, 19, was charged with conspiracy to obtain money for terrorist purposes. No further details were made public. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: San Francisco Gun Vote: Tough Law or Thin Gesture?
description: SAN FRANCISCO - With warring gangs igniting a surge in homicides here in the last year, voters on Tuesday will consider a sweeping proposal to curb the violence: the nation's strictest municipal gun control ordinances, a measure that would ban possession, sale and manufacture of handguns and ammunition within city limits.

title: Running as if They Were Neck and Neck
description: Entering the final days before the election, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he would not scale back his campaigning, even though the latest polls show him continuing to maintain a big lead over his Democratic challenger, Fernando Ferrer.

title: Connecticut Finds a Portrait, So a Prisoner Need Not Pose
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 4 - His face is fresh, his eyes confident. It was, after all, long before the downfall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCUS, ELLENTUCK, JEANNE
description: MARCUS - ELLENTUCK -Jeanne. Of Riverdale, died November 3. If you met her for only five minutes, you fell in love with her. Funeral at 1:30 PM, Sunday, November 6, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, NYC, 212-769-4400.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: African Exile's Asylum Under Review
description: Spain is considering revoking political asylum for Severo Moto Nsa, the opposition leader from Equatorial Guinea, because of his suspected involvement in violent activities in his tiny, oil-rich homeland and for presenting an unspecified threat to Spanish security, a Spanish official said. The government has given him 15 days to respond to the allegations. Mr. Moto, who was granted asylum by Spain in 1986, has been accused by Equatorial Guinea of participating in a coup attempt against President Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo last year. Mr. Moto, who would not be expelled to Equatorial Guinea or any other country that could not guarantee his safety, is one of many political exiles from Equatorial Guinea living in Spain, which ruled Equatorial Guinea as a colony until 1968. Renwick McLean (NYT)

title: G Train to Lose All Conductors; Transit Union Opposes Move
description: New York City Transit intends to operate the G line without a conductor at all times starting on Dec. 11, a move certain to inflame tensions with the city's major transit union.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Commemorations For Rabin Begin
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOLLO, JEROME JAY
description: BOLLO--Jerome Jay. Of Southampton, New York, on November 4, 2005. Survived by his devoted wife, Grace, of 41 years; daughter, Geraldine Bollo-Goldstein; sons, Michael and Paul. Loving grandfather of four. Graduated from Manhattan College and served four years with the Army Air Corps during World War II in the Pacific Theatre and flew 55 missions. Reposing at the O'Connell Funeral Home, 30 Little Plains Rd., Southampton, NY, Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial, on Monday 10 AM at Sacred Hearts of Jesus & Mary R.C. Church in Southampton. Interment Southampton Cemetery.

title: That Flurry of Ballot Questions
description: Government by referendum should come with a warning: vote yes at your own risk. Measures placed on the ballot by citizen initiatives are by their nature missing the devil of the details. The questions are designed to be brief, often to the point of being misleading or confusing. When the list is interminable, as it is in some states this year, the overwhelmed voter might be best advised to just say no.

title: Rivals Try to Talk Policy, but Sex Remains Topic A
description: Questions about both candidates' personal lives dominated the New Jersey governor's race for the third day yesterday, but Douglas R. Forrester and Senator Jon S. Corzine tried to talk about policy issues.

title: He Speaks Pigeon Poetry; They Coo, Too
description: IN a glorified garage of a storefront in the Bronx, the talk is pigeon. It's always pigeon. If you don't speak pigeon -- if you don't know your tippler from your dropper -- then hack a piece off that cheese pastry on the counter, sweep the feathers from an available chair, sit down and listen up.

title: Just Hang On a Second
description: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia - SOMETIME between the opening seconds of Tuesday and the closing ones of Friday in Geneva, the world's greatest watch-making center, a decision will be made that has profound consequences for our way of telling time. What's in question is the fate of the leap second.

title: Fashioning Deadly Fiascos
description: I've said it before and I'll say it again: Men are simply not biologically suited to hold higher office. The Bush administration has proved that once and for all.

title: Researchers Look to Create a Synthesis of Art and Science for the 21st Century
description: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 29 - As an actor and a founder of the politically active Electronic Disturbance Theater, Ricardo R. Dominguez is an unlikely faculty member at the nanoscience, wireless and supercomputing laboratory that opened its doors here on the campus of the University of California, San Diego, on Oct. 28.

title: The Independence Charade
description: Perhaps we should start at the bottom line. Don't vote for any candidates on the Independence Party row in Tuesday's elections. The Independence Party in New York City is not about independence. Just the opposite. It is about dependence on one man, Fred Newman, a former Marxist who is now a psychotherapist, and who has manipulated politicians, workers and voters into thinking that they are participating in a genuine political party.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: West Bank: Al Jazeera Cameraman Held
description: An Israeli Arab, Nabil al-Mazzawi, working as a cameraman for Al Jazeera television, was detained for several hours by Israeli soldiers who were breaking up a weekly demonstration in Bilin against the construction of Israel's separation barrier there. About 20 demonstrators chained themselves to a metal barrier and scuffled with soldiers and police officers who tried to remove them. Shireen Abu Aqleh, a correspondent for Al Jazeera, said Mr. Mazzawi had been arrested and hit as he filmed an Israeli border guard beating a demonstrator. The police said Mr. Mazzawi had hit a policeman but released him without charges. Steven Erlanger (NYT)

Also survived by many beloved nieces, nephews and cousins. Reposing John J. Barrett Funeral Home, 424 W. 51 St., NYC, Saturday 4-8 and Sunday 11-3. Interment Monday, 11 AM, Elm Grove Cemetery, Mystic, CT. Donations may be made to the Actors' Fund.

description: LANDO--Robert. The Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Robert Lando. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Patti, and their family. Jack Sussman, President Joseph Lehman, Secretary

title: Unbeaten Colts Look To Settle Old Score
description: Tony Dungy knew the topic of conversation would be Monday night's meeting between the Indianapolis Colts and the New England Patriots.

title: Detroit Gets Its October Sales Numbers and Winces
description: HIGHER energy prices are bruising American automakers, worrying consumers and hobbling manufacturers, as several events made clear this week. But energy costs are not yet causing inflation to accelerate appreciably, the Federal Reserve concluded.

title: France Reconnects to an Old Acquaintance, la Nouvelle Orlans
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 4 - It's been just over 200 years since the French gave up on their unloved, swampy corner of North America here, but some piece of it has continued to inhabit the Gallic imagination ever since.

title: Is Bird Flu Drug Really So Vexing? Debating the Difficulty of Tamiflu
description: If a bird flu pandemic breaks out, the world's ability to fight back may come down to an ancient Chinese cooking spice -- or the perseverance of people like Professor Frost.

description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRADY, HELENA REAL
description: BRADY--Helena Real. Age 75 passed away Wednesday, November 2, 2005 at her home in St. Augustine, FL. Helena was an extraordinary person. She was a model of courage, decorum, integrity and honesty. The list of her academic awards and accomplishments is too long to recite here, but they range from the Fordham University Gold Medal for "leadership, scholarship and character" awarded to the outstanding graduating senior to inclusion in Who's Who. She conducted worldwide tours for students at Pace University in New York City where she was a professor of political science, international relations and history. She was dedicated to her students and was known as the "go-to" professor if a student had academic or even personal problems. Students not even in her classes would seek her out for counsel and advice. Helena's excellence in teaching was recognized when she received a university award for excellence in teaching. She did not confine her contributions to just the classroom. She was also very active in community service, serving on youth boards and in county agencies that helped the poor and needy, including the Red Cross where she achieved lifetime membership. Helena truly had a compassionate, full and active life, one which will surely earn her a place in heaven. Helena is survived by her loving husband, Gene Brady. Helena's family will receive friends Saturday and Sunday between the hours of 5-7 PM at Craig Funeral Home. A funeral mass will take place Monday at 9 AM at St. Anastasia Catholic Church. For information, contact Craig Funeral Home and Crematory, St. Augustine, FL.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the dissenting opinions of Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. included an erroneous reference to his dissents in decisions that were later reversed by the Supreme Court, from Frank Cross, a law professor who has compiled a database tracking Supreme Court review of appellate decisions. Alex Kozinski of the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit has dissented in the greatest number of appellate cases that were later reversed by the Supreme Court, not Judge Alito, who ranks third in such dissents.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in Business Day yesterday with an article about the resignation of Andrew Gowers as the editor of The Financial Times was published in error. It showed Richard Lambert, a previous editor, not Mr. Gowers.

title: Keflezighi Looks to End Drought for U.S. Men
description: In a frantic race to the starting line, the organizers of the New York City Marathon have been obtaining weather updates with the same frequency and urgency as runners receiving split times. Thank heavens for Doppler radar, which has a good track record for predicting when the clouds will hover and where the sun will shine.

title: Finding Community in Virtual Town Squares
description: I had a blast at my cousin's wedding in Brooklyn last Saturday, but have to admit that sometime between the hora and the cake-cutting, I found myself drifting off a bit, thinking: "Wow, the Blood Elves in the new World of Warcraft expansion pack sound pretty cool. I wonder what's going on in Anaheim?"

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEFELIPPO, OLGA
description: DeFELIPPO--Olga. On November 3, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Natale J. DeFelippo. Loving mother of Joseph, Vivienne and Dr. Noel P. DeFelippo. Adored grandmother of Michael and Peter DeFelippo. Brooklyn College graduate 1937. Pioneer and advocate for the developmentally disabled. A founder and executive director of the Guild for Exceptional Children. Visiting hours November 6, 2-5PM and 79PM at McLaughlin & Sons Funeral Home, 9620 3rd Ave., Brooklyn, NY. Mass of Christian burial at St. Patrick's Church, 4th Ave., Brooklyn, 9:30 A.M. on November 7. Please omit flowers. If you wish, contributions can be made to the Guild for Exceptional Children, 260 68th Street, Brooklyn, NY 11220.

title: Minibus Driver Leaves Chaos in His Wake
description: A minivan school bus carrying four preschoolers and a matron and driven at high speed by a man wanted on a drug charge veered into the wrong lane on a Brooklyn street yesterday and plowed into parked cars, a traffic light, a concrete pillar and a marble-and-iron fence, the police said.

title: The Kind of Shave You Can't Get at Home
description: THE gray-haired master barber Boris Mirzakandov leaned over and pressed the sharp steely blade of his straight razor against my throat. My entire face and body went limp. I closed my eyes. Scents of sandalwood, cloves and black pepper filled my nostrils. I felt the razor scrape a glob of shaving cream from my Adam's apple.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MICHAELS, SYLVIA MANDELKERN
description: MICHAELS--Sylvia Mandelkern. 90, lately of Teresian House Nursing Home (Albany, NY), died on Thursday November 3, 2005. Sylvia was born on 29 December 1915, her family residing at 790 East 152nd Street in the Bronx. She was daughter of Mollie (Esther Malka) Gross (1891-1974) of Nahorce and Joel Hersch (Harry, Herman) Mandelkern (1884-1951) of Kuthorz (now Kutkir). Both 'shtetls' were located near Lemberg, Austria (later Lvov, Poland; now Lviv, Ukraine). Sylvia's maternal grandparents were Hannah Lofton and Shmuel (Reb Schmiel Ellia) Gross. Her paternal grandparents were Zelig Laub Mandelkern (circa 1864-1936) and Yente (Yetta, Yiteleh) Gold, daughter of Schifre and Rafael Gold. Sylvia's first cousins were, paternally: Fancha Mandelkern and Rose (Ruchel) Gelbard (Mendel, 'Max'); and maternally: J. Barney Gross (Hazel), Klara Gruber, Ruchel Pasturnack, Fannie Schwalb (Joseph), and Regina Woolf (Stanley). A lifetime New Yorker, Sylvia's family moved to Bronx, Manhattan, and Brooklyn residences; and around 1921 to Astoria, Queens where they owned and lived above a small grocery store. Sylvia attended PS 6 and JHS 126 in Queens; and Julia Richman High School in Manhattan, which she graduated in 1932. Sylvia also attended college at CCNY, where she met William (Michalefsky) Michaels (1916 -1989), whom she married in 1939. Sylvia is survived by son Richard of Manhattan, son Robert and daughter-in-law Eileen Michaels of Niskayuna, NY; and grandchildren Isaac (17), Valerie (15), and Benjamin (13). Sylvia exhibited unwavering spirit, humor, courage, love of culture and travel, and high ethical standards. She taught these values by example. Graveside funeral services will be held privately at Riverside Cemetery (Rochelle Park, NJ). In lieu of flowers, cash donations may be made to Congregation Gates of Heaven (852 Ashmore Avenue, Schenectady, New York 12309) in memory of Sylvia Michaels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TEDESCO, VITTORIA
description: TEDESCO - Vittoria. 100 years and 6 months on November 4, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Flaviano. Loving and adored mother of Lucia and Anna Tedesco-Garone, and cherished mother-in-law of Vincent T. Garone. She was a loving aunt and greataunt to her family and her extended family: Robert, Jamie, Hanna, and Ryan Young. Her generosity and loving warmth touched the lives of many. She will be profoundly missed and forever remain in the hearts of her devoted family. Family will receive friends Saturday and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. at the Flinch & Bruns Funeral Home, Inc., 34 Hempstead Avenue, (corner Peninsula Blvd) Lynbrook. Funeral mass Monday 9:45 A.M. St Joseph's R.C. Church, Hewlett. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury. Memorial contributions may be made to the Stecher and Horowitz Foundation, 250 W 57 St, Suite 1005, New York, New York 10107.

title: Can an Iron Fist Put Power in Bosnia's Hands?
description: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina - PADDY ASHDOWN sipped his tea, stretched his arm over the back of his chair and looked out his office window at Sarajevo, the capital of Bosnia, a country over which he has held almost absolute authority for three and a half years.

title: The Candidates Go Multilingual
description: Both candidates for mayor are using foreign-language ads to broaden their reach. An advertisement for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has a first in New York City politics: a mayor speaking Mandarin in a campaign commercial to make his case for re-election. It is one of several ads in which the mayor speaks a foreign language, including Urdu, Russian and Cantonese, to plead his case. This ad is running on Chinese-language cable-TV stations. A 30-second television ad for Fernando Ferrer, called "Aramina," in which his wife addresses the audience, is among several Spanish-language ads currently being broadcast.

title: A Day to Think About a Case of Faith-Based Terrorism
description: Today, just in case you had not noticed, is the 400th anniversary of Guy Fawkes Day -- one of the most notable episodes of religion-based terrorism in Anglo-American history.

title: Annan, Citing Talk on Israel, Drops Iran Trip
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 4 - Secretary General Kofi Annan on Friday dropped plans to visit Tehran next week, citing a speech last week in which Iran's president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, said that Israel "must be wiped off the map."

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "It's not easy to host all these countries. It's particularly not easy to host, perhaps, me."

title: National Briefing | New England: Vermont: Court Upholds Dean's Sealing His Papers
description: The Vermont Supreme Court said Howard Dean acted legally when, on leaving office as governor in 2003, he sealed thousands of pages of his papers. The 93 boxes of documents were deemed by Mr. Dean, now the Democratic national chairman, to be covered by executive privilege. They are not to be made public until January 2013. Other Vermont governors have had similar arrangements. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Organic Farming's American Heartland Awaits Royals
description: POINT REYES STATION, Calif., Nov. 3 - Lee de Barros, a Zen Buddhist priest, was contemplating the arrival on Saturday of Prince Charles and the Duchess of Cornwall while reading a book called "The Spiritual Athlete: A Primer for the Inner Life" at Toby's Feed Barn, the all-organic general store here.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAILENSON, FANNIE
description: BAILENSON - Fannie. Con gregation Sons of Israel, Woodmere, records with sorrow the passing of its member and extends condolences to the bereaved family. Bruce Ginsburg, Rabbi Dr. Saul I. Teplitz Rabbi Emeritus Harry S. Katz, President

title: Young Romance Bubbles Up From a Seedy Underworld
description: The Canadian playwright George F. Walker is well known in American theater circles for not being well known. Despite a prolific three-decade career that includes more than 20 plays and a closetful of awards, Mr. Walker is hardly on the radar in the United States. So the Sightlines Theater Company deserves credit for providing a thorough introduction, mounting six of his plays (three readings and three productions) this month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PORTNOY, MEYER
