title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the four Supreme Court justices whom Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. listed as his favorites referred incorrectly to William H. Rehnquist, one of the four. He was an associate justice -- not chief justice -- when he joined a dissenting opinion in Roe v. Wade in 1973. (Mr. Rehnquist, who was listed along with Byron R. White, John M. Harlan and William J. Brennan, did not become chief justice until 1986.)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jersey City: City Drops Plans To Seize Tavern
description: Mayor Jerramiah T. Healy instructed the city's redevelopment agency yesterday to drop its effort to acquire a local tavern by eminent domain and use the property to lengthen a private high school's football field. For nearly five years the agency had been in a legal fight with Cheng Tan, the owner of the Golden Cicada, which backs up to the end zone and goal post of the field at St. Peter's Preparatory School. For the field to meet state regulations it needs to be lengthened by seven yards, according to school officials, who had asked the city for help. But the mayor said, "It is not a valid exercise in eminent domain to take from a private owner and give to another private owner." John Holl (NYT)

description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HENDERSON, SKITCH
description: HENDERSON - Skitch. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with profound sorrow the passing of its beloved friend, the renowned pianist and conductor Skitch Henderson, on November 1, 2005 in New Milford, Connecticut at the age of 87. Mr. Henderson was a deeply valued member of our Steinway Artist family for nearly sixty years. The Founder and Music Director of The New York Pops, Skitch Henderson was one of the most recognized musical personalities in America. His career included appearances with orchestras throughout the world, and his collaboration with such artists as Judy Garland, Frank Sinatra, and Bing Crosby was legendary. He became known to millions throughout America as music director at NBC Television, where he conducted the Tonight show and the Today show orchestras, introducing the use of classical music in variety programming. Mr. Henderson was a featured artist in Steinway & Sons' Centennial concert at Carnegie Hall in 1953, and his devotion to the Steinway piano and to our firm knew no bounds. Though our lives have been forever enriched by his music, his ebullient spirit will be sorely missed. To Ruth and to his children and grandchildren, we extend our love and our heartfelt condolences. -Bruce A. Stevens, President -Peter B. Goodrich, V.P. Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

title: Focusing on Quake Aid, Pakistan Delays F-16 Purchase
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 4 - Gen. Pervez Musharraf, the Pakistani president, said Friday that he would postpone the purchase of F-16 fighter jets from the United States as his country grappled with the devastation caused by the Oct. 8 earthquake, which has claimed more than 73,000 lives.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,031 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FELDMAN, ELAINE ZEITSOFF
description: FELDMAN--Elaine Zeitsoff. On November 3, 2005. Adored wife of Arnold. Cherished aunt to Liz, John & Christina. Beloved friend and cousin. Distinguished graphic designer. She and her zest for life will be missed by all. Funeral services Sunday November 6, 11:30 A.M., at the Riverside Memorial Chapel. Arnold Feldman and Family $(6$)FELDMAN--Elaine Zeitsoff. The Noyac Golf Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of the wife of our esteemed member, Arnold Feldman, and extends sincere sympathy to him and other members of the family. Ted Ronick, President Richard Mathew, Secretary

title: With Republican Party in Shambles, Change Is in the Air
description: For decades shrewd politicians leveraged Brookhaven's booming population and sprawling acreage on Long Island into a Republican powerhouse with statewide reach. Some also exploited the town, lining their pockets in periodic scandals that earned it the unsavory nickname Crookhaven.

title: Arts, Briefly; CBS Sweeps as Nielsen Debugs
description: Nielsen Media Research fixed its processing delays in time for the November sweeps period, which began on Thursday. As a rule, that night belongs to CBS, and this week was no exception: the network won every hour. An audience of 18.43 million saw Brandon's luck run out on "Survivor"; on "CSI" (28.45 million), Grissom (William Petersen, left) exposed bogus bug evidence in court; and Alex Kingston (formerly of "ER") appeared on "Without a Trace" (20.25 million) as the femme fatale wife of a man being held for ransom in Mexico. NBC placed a distant second in both total viewers and the 18-to-49 demographic. "The Apprentice" (11.04 million) delivered its biggest audience of the season, perhaps because of Donald Trump's rash quadruple firing in last week's boardroom, but it's still way down, compared with last season's editions. CBS also ranked first on Wednesday: without a new episode of ABC's "Lost" on the schedule, its "Criminal Minds" was the night's most-watched program, with 16.3 million viewers. That night, an hourlong season premiere of "That 70's Show" (7.83 million) finished a strong first among adults 18 to 49 in the 8 o'clock hour. Overnight Nielsen figures indicated a nearly threefold increase in the New York area audience for the Latin Grammys, seen for the first time on Thursday on the Spanish-language television station Univision 41. The audience for the three-hour broadcast, close-captioned in English, from the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles was put at 626,000, in contrast to the 212,000 viewers who watched it on WCBS-TV last year. KATE AURTHUR

title: In Capital and at the Court, Baseball Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 - First there was John G. Roberts Jr., talking his way to confirmation as chief justice of the United States with the insight that "judges are like umpires."

title: National Briefing | Washington: Medal Of Freedom Winners
description: President Bush has announced that Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, and Muhammad Ali are among the recipients this year of the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the nation's highest civil award. Mr. Bush will present the awards on Wednesday at the White House. The other recipients are Carol Burnett, Aretha Franklin and Andy Griffith, the entertainers; the historian Robert Conquest; Vinton Cerf and Robert Kahn, designers of software code; Paul Harvey, the radio personality; former Representative Sonny Montgomery, Democrat of Mississippi; Gen. Richard B. Myers of the Air Force, former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff; Jack Nicklaus and Frank Robinson, the athletes; and Paul Rusesabagina, who sheltered hundreds of people in hotel rooms in 1994 during the genocide in Rwanda. John Files (NYT)

title: Poll Says Even Quiet Divorces Affect Children's Paths
description: Even in a "good divorce," in which parents amicably minimize their conflicts, children of divorce inhabit a more difficult emotional landscape than those in intact families, according to a new survey of 1,500 people ages 18 t0 35.

title: After 34 Years, His Antiwar Song Is Still Not Out of Style

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about President Bush's trip to Argentina for a summit meeting of Western Hemisphere leaders misstated the given name of a Nobel Peace Prize winner who was one of the leaders of a protest march outside the meeting. He is Adolfo Prez Esquivel, not Alfonso.

description: Bruckner's Fifth Symphony played by the Chicago Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall takes a listener back.

title: BUSINESS BRIEFS
description: Berkshire Hathaway's Profit Falls by Half After Hurricanes Cause $2.99 Billion in Losses Berkshire Hathaway said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings fell by almost half because of insurance losses related to Hurricanes Katrina and Rita. Net income fell to $586 million, or $381 a share, from $1.14 billion, or $739 a share, a year earlier. Berkshire, the investment company run by Warren E. Buffett, said its losses from the hurricanes in the quarter that ended Sept. 30 totaled $2.99 billion, but that figure could change as additional claims are filed. Berkshire, which is based in Omaha, estimated that hurricanes Katrina and Rita had caused $60 billion to $70 billion of losses along the Gulf Coast, "producing the largest catastrophic losses for any quarter in the history of the property/casualty insurance industry." (AP)

title: This Winter, Do Sweat the Small Stuff
description: DON'T let the recent warm spell fool you. It's shaping up to be a more expensive winter -- and not just because of the way rising fuel prices will kick up the cost of filling up your car or heating your home.

title: Senate Votes Again for Ban on Abusing Prisoners
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 - The Senate restated its support on Friday for banning the abusive treatment of prisoners in American custody, and the measure's Republican sponsor chided the House Republican leadership for delaying a vote on it.

title: Peeling Back Folk Rock to Reveal Hidden Jazz
description: Last year, when the jazz singer Karrin Allyson released "Wild for You" (Concord), an album of 1970's soft-rock songs filtered through a jazz sensibility, musical worlds that usually brush elbows without pausing to talk stopped to engage in a deep conversation. They found much in common.

description: Before she and Prince Charles leave our shores, Camilla owes the American people the truth: how many dresses did she pack?

description: Job growth was surprisingly meager last month, the Labor Department reported yesterday, in a sign that business executives have become worried that the economic damage from high energy prices might be growing.

description: BETWEEN them they are worth more than $90 billion, most of it in equities, so when Warren E. Buffett and Bill Gates talk about the stock market it is probably a good idea to listen.

title: With Wagner on Hold, Mets Eye a Left-Hander
description: As the Mets continue their pursuit of the free-agent closer Billy Wagner, their top priority this off-season, they have reached out toward improving other areas of their bullpen. They have inquired about the left-handed reliever Joey Eischen, who spent last season with the Washington Nationals, Eischen's agent, Alan Nero, confirmed yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An events entry in the Spare Times for Children listing of Weekend yesterday included an outdated reference to an event at Makor on West 67th Street. While "Looney Lenny's 10th Birthday Bash" is still scheduled for 11 a.m. tomorrow, the "My Daddy Is Scratchy" concert by Jamie Broza has been postponed from 1 p.m. tomorrow to Feb. 12.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Ferry Pilot's Doctor Gets Probation
description: The former doctor of a Staten Island ferry pilot who passed out before a crash that killed 11 people in 2003 was sentenced to a year of probation yesterday for hiding the pilot's medical problems from the Coast Guard. The doctor, William Tursi, left, pleaded guilty in June to one count of making a false statement by lying on a 2000 medical report filed with the Coast Guard as part of a license renewal application by the pilot, Richard J. Smith. Dr. Tursi admitted that he failed to disclose Mr. Smith's high blood pressure and use of prescription drugs. He could have faced six months in prison under federal sentencing guidelines, but received the lighter sentence. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: On a Mission to Cajole the Pentagon
description: In one of the biggest corporate slugfests, the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, the parent company of Airbus, and the Boeing Company are engaged in a trans-Atlantic trade dispute over government subsidies. In the commercial aviation marketplace, they are going head-to-head with new lineups of innovative aircraft.

title: Northwest Pilots Agree to Temporary Pay Cuts
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 4 - Unions representing Northwest Airlines workers appear to be acquiescing to the carrier's demand for interim annual pay cuts totaling about $840 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NIELSEN, WALDEMAR A.
description: NIELSEN -- Waldemar A. Passed away peacefully on November 2 after a long illness. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Marcia Kaplan Nielsen, his daughter Signe Nielsen, and his granddaughter, Marina Nielsen Galazidis. A Memorial Service will be held on December 2 at the Century Association, 7 W. 43rd St. at 5PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to: Jacob Perlow Hospice/ Harlem Hospice, 1775 Broadway, NY, NY 10019, attn Director of Development.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Condemned Man Walks Out The Door
description: The authorities searched for a death row prisoner who used street clothes and fake identification to walk past four deputies and escape from the Harris County Jail in Houston. The inmate, Charles V. Thompson, 35, was convicted in 1999 of killing his former girlfriend and her companion in Tomball, a Houston suburb. After and an appeal and resentencing, Mr. Thompson was awaiting his return to a state prison when he claimed he had an appointment with his lawyer and was taken to a room where a man was waiting. The authorities said the visitor, whom they are questioning, was not Mr. Thompson's lawyer. The authorities could not say how Mr. Thompson left an interview room or obtained the clothes and an official state credential. Steve Barnes (NYT)

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 - With critics hammering Wal-Mart day after day, the company sponsored an unusual conference on Friday about its impact on America's economy, and it got some good -- and a few not so good -- grades.

title: New Uncertainty About Democrats Holding Seat in Assembly
description: In a typical local election in Crown Heights and Flatbush, Brooklyn, there is little for the Democratic candidate to worry about. But this year's special election for a vacant Assembly seat is far from the typical election contest.

title: Canadian Winemaker Opposes Constellation Bid
description: Vincor, the Canadian winemaker, urged its shareholders to reject a takeover bid of 1.4 billion Canadian dollars ($1.2 billion) from Constellation Brands, the world's largest wine producer. Vincor said late Thursday that the bid, 31 Canadian dollars a share, undervalued the company. Vincor, based in Mississauga, Ontario, said it was talking with other potential buyers, but did not identify them. Vincor reported second-quarter net income yesterday of 14 million Canadian dollars, up from 10.9 million Canadian dollars a year earlier, on sales of 182.6 million Canadian dollars. Constellation is based in Fairport, N.Y. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Alcohol Use by Tour Boat Captain Raises Questions
description: The captain of the tour boat that capsized in Lake George, N.Y., last month, killing 20 people, used alcohol in the days surrounding the accident, federal investigators said yesterday. The finding alarmed the victims' families but could not, experts said, establish whether the captain was under the influence of alcohol at the time of the accident.

description: Correction Appended

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Apartment Searched In Connection With Rape
description: The police broke into an apartment in Kew Gardens last night in connection with the rape of a 34-year-old woman in Chelsea on Monday, investigators said. The attacker had dressed as a fireman and lit two small fires in the hallway to trick the victim into opening her door, the police said. He then drugged her with a chemical-soaked rag and sexually assaulted her in an ordeal that may have lasted several hours, the police said. Neighbors in the Kew Gardens building said the resident of the apartment resembled a police sketch. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Quarterly Net Rises 2.1% at Toyota
description: TOKYO, Nov. 4 - Net income at the Toyota Motor Corporation, the world's No. 2 car company after General Motors, rose 2.1 percent in the most recent quarter on strong sales and a favorable foreign exchange rate, the company said Friday.

description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 4 - The nation's first trial to test the constitutionality of teaching intelligent design as science ended Friday with a lawyer for the Dover school board pronouncing intelligent design "the next great paradigm shift in science."

title: French and American Teams Win at World Championships
description: ESTORIL, Portugal, Nov. 4 - France won the Venice Cup women's event at the world bridge championships on Friday, and the U.S.A. 1 team won the Seniors Bowl.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WICENTOWSKI, SIDNEY
description: WICENTOWSKI--Sidney. On November 4 at the age of 94. Beloved husband of Fannie (Solomon) for 73 years. Dear father of Frances (Matthew) Harris, Eleanor (Burton) Jaffe, David (Jane), Jerrold (Debby). Also survived by eleven grandchildren and eleven great-grandchildren. Loving brother of Gertrude Golding. His many friends and relatives in the United States and Israel will miss him. Services Sunday 1PM at "Riverside - Nassau North Chapels," 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: U.S. Weighs Whether to Open an Era of Rapid H.I.V. Detection in the Home
description: At a free clinic in Philadelphia, Jennifer Brown, 26, spent a recent lunch hour talking to a counselor and waiting anxiously for a small white strip to tell her whether she had the AIDS virus.

title: Celebrating the Horn in Its 'Natural' State
description: The immediate ancestors of the modern horn served as a kind of telegraphy, sending signals between hunting parties on horseback separated in the enthusiasms of the chase. Late in the 17th century, a certain Franz Anton von Sporck, whose love of killing animals equaled his love of music, influenced the transition of this practical instrument into one beautiful for its own sake. A generation later, composers found a permanent place for the horn in orchestras large and small.

title: Strange-Bedfellows Moment in New York State Politics
description: When the owners of Madison Square Garden began a multimillion-dollar campaign to halt the proposed Jets stadium on the West Side of Manhattan, their big-spending ways were closely monitored by civic groups like Common Cause of New York, the League of Women Voters and the New York Public Interest Research Group.

title: Conjuring Visual Magic With Keys, Spears and Furniture
description: The Chocolate Factory is housed in a former paint factory. That kind of incongruity was also found, along with a heaping dose of witty funk and homespun visual magic, in "Drawn," a dance installation that opened on Thursday at the space, a theater and gallery. Put together by the Lower Lights Collective, the two-part work began upstairs and ended downstairs in the handsomely worn two-floor brick building.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Ethiopia: Unrest Spreads Outside Capital
description: Antigovernment protests were reported in towns across Ethiopia as the streets of the capital, Addis Ababa, where violent clashes broke out this week, remained tense and lined with heavily armed soldiers and policemen. In Bahar Dar, northwest of Addis Ababa, protesters tried to set fire to a bus full of European tourists, The Associated Press reported. The police fired in the air and dispersed the rioters. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: INSIDE

title: Alan Pifer Is Dead at 84; Led Carnegie Corporation
description: Alan Pifer, under whose guidance the Carnegie Corporation of New York adjusted its educational focus to a wider context -- social and racial justice -- in the 1960's and 1970's, died on Monday in Shelburne, Vt. A former resident of Greens Farms, Conn., he was 84.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YAROSH, BARBARA
description: YAROSH--Barbara. November 3. Beloved wife of Morrie. Mother to Bruce and Rob. Mother-in-law to Morgan. Grandmother to Zachary and Anna. She will be missed. Services will be private.

description: SOUTHWEST

title: No Time to Rest, He Has to Sell a Football Team
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Nov. 4 - During breaks in Penn State football games this season, the speaker system at Beaver Stadium has played a rhythmic tune, "Kernkraft 400" by a techno group called Zombie Nation, as the scoreboard displays the word "Bounce."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DINCE, BERTRAND A.
description: DINCE--Bertrand A. Passed away at age 76 on November 4, 2005. Father to Adam, son to the late Louis and Evelyn Dince, he is survived by nephews David Dince, William Dince, niece Nancy Kelly, brother Paul and the many who enjoyed his music and talents as a teacher. Services to be held Sunday, November 6th, at 9 AM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Now You See the Conductor (in His Debut); Now You Don't See the Piano
description: There is a lot to control in Alfred Schnittke's quirky and often chaotic Concerto Grosso No. 5 for Violin, Invisible Piano and Orchestra (1990-91), so it was only natural that when the New York Philharmonic performed it on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, several pairs of hands seemed to be holding the reins.

title: Fleeing Suspect Is Killed When a Detective's Gun Discharges, the Police Say
description: A 21-year-old Brooklyn man being sought in the shooting of two men on Thursday morning was killed yesterday during a struggle with a detective when the detective's gun went off, the police said.

title: A Pro-Bug Vote on the Court?
description: MUCH of the attention being paid to Samuel A. Alito Jr., President Bush's second nominee to succeed Sandra Day O'Connor, is focused on a few hot-button issues, led by abortion.

title: Stirred, Not Shaken
description: PRINCETON, N.J. - ON Nov. 1, 1755, a powerful earthquake followed by a tidal wave laid low Lisbon, trapping thousands beneath rubble and ruins. To make matters worse, the hundreds of candles that had been lighted in honor of All Saints' Day at the city's churches toppled over, starting a fire that lasted for days. This succession of calamities occurred with such rapidity and force that Lisbon, as it had been known to plebeians and philosophes, was no more.

title: Location, Location, Location. Research, Research.
description: Three years ago, Matthew Haines was remodeling a five-family brownstone he bought in Harlem when inspiration hit him. "There were all these abandoned buildings that were holding down my rent roll," he recalled saying to himself. "What can I do to make other homeowners comfortable buying here?"

title: The Week in Unrest
description: Photos of protests around the world last week.

title: A Taxi's Second Life
description: New York City cabs that are retired often get put back to work on the streets of Philadelphia and Chicago.

title: Life in Malawi's Prisons
description: In Malawi's high-security prisons, conditions are unbearable, confinements intolerably long, and justice scandalously uneven.

title: The Boyland Dynasty
description: The Boylands arrived dirt-poor from Memphis and have ruled over central Brooklyn politics for 30 years. But a stunning primary loss struck their name from Tuesday's ballot, clouding the dynasty's future.

title: Speaking of Aid
description: Im sure lots of readers will be surprised that the Bush administration is giving so much more aid to poor countries than the Clinton administration did. I mentioned that to Al Franken once in his show, and he immediately responded that thats just the aid that Bush has promised, not delivered, and many liberals think thats the case. In fact, though, Bushs aid hasnt been as extravagant as his talk, but its still impressive: $19 billion in official development assistance actually delivered in 2004, up from the Clinton low of less than $7 billion in 1997 (those are OECD numbers, and the U.S. figure is a bit higher in 97 because it included military aid that the OECD doesnt count). The aid promised in the future is even greater.

title: Darfur
description: Robert Zoellick, the deputy Secretary of State, is setting off soon for his fourth trip to Darfur. Lets hope it does some good.

title: For High-Level Career Advice, Some Job Seekers Go to Church
description: Correction Appended

description: To the Editor:

description: KRIEGEL--Phil. We are deeply saddened by the loss of "Big Phil". You will always be remembered. The Rockmores

title: State Ballot Questions; Yes on Transit Bonds
description: The Rebuild and Renew New York Transportation Bond Act of 2005 -- Question 2 on most ballots -- would revitalize the state's transportation system. This proposal deserves a yes vote from everybody who uses the roads, bridges, rails and buses in all of New York State. It would allow the state to borrow -- upfront and more cheaply than usual -- $2.9 billion for transportation projects over five years. Half the money would go to upstate projects; half would go downstate. It is important because:

title: President Bush Directs Tough Speech at Venezuelan President
description: BRASILIA, Nov. 6 - President Bush delivered a tough speech today aimed at Venezuela's leftist president, Hugo Chavez, calling on Latin America to chose between two competing futures -- an American-supported "vision of hope" versus another that "seeks to roll back the democratic progress of the past two decades."

title: West Bank town is proving ground for Hamas
Senator Hints No Wrongdoing Found on Prewar Intelligence
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 - The chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee strongly hinted today that a coming draft report on prewar intelligence on Iraq would find no evidence of the sort of political manipulation that some Democrats have alleged. He also said the report would be presented to members of his panel this week.

title: The Shy, Egg-Stealing Neighbor You Didn't Know You Had
description: The suburbs, pretty as they may be, are nobody's idea of nature in balance. Sure, they are lush, green places where people and their vehicles get along with flowers, vegetables, songbirds and the littler mammals. But this harmony is enforced with an iron fist. It takes lots of chemicals, artificial irrigation and gas-powered trimming and mowing to keep such an arbitrary ecosystem under control.

title: Self-Mutilation Is the Sincerest Form of Flattery
description: Correction Appended

title: Don't Forget Pizza Money
description: I WAS feeling proud of myself. My oldest child, Marian, had just started college, and the savings plan I had put into place shortly after she was born had paid off: I had enough to pay her tuition and room and board.

title: Comfort to the Enemy
description: Carl has surprised Gary Marion by letting the fugitive Joe Tanzi go. Meanwhile, Louly has spotted an old acquaintance: the gangster Teddy Ritz, who is on his way to Okmulgee.

title: Bush keeps low profile in the CIA leak case
Co-op-Condo Conference
description: The Council of New York Cooperatives and Condominiums will hold its 25th annual Housing Conference on Nov. 13 at Hunter College.

title: A British Landmark Regains Its Splendor
description: The De La Warr Pavilion, an iconic Modernist building in Bexhill-on-Sea, on the south coast of England, has been restored after being closed for 20 months, and was reopened to the public on Oct. 15 as a center for contemporary art and performance.

title: STREETSCAPES/The Museum of the City of New York; Preserving the Past, Planning the Future
description: THE on-again off-again expansion project of the Museum of the City of New York is on again -- and this time it seems to be for certain. Since the early 1990's, the Georgian-style museum, on Fifth Avenue from 103rd to 104th Street, has had different designs on the boards to build into its wide backyard, as was originally planned. Now the project has been reduced from seven stories to two -- but it really is to start next month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SANDHAUS, HAROLD, M.D.
description: SANDHAUS--Harold, M.D. Co-founder of Franklin General Hospital. Beloved husband of 59 years to Helen. Father of Robert, Jody and Jane. Grandfather to eleven grandchildren. Brother of Julius. Donations to Alpha-1 Foundation, 2937 S.W. 27th Ave, Suite 302, Miami, FL. 33133.

title: The Stepson, the Billionaire and the Walt Disney Co.
description: AT the beginning of 2001, Perry Moore embarked on a forbidding quest. Mr. Moore, an executive with an untested movie company called Walden Media, dispatched an impassioned letter to the chief executive of the C. S. Lewis Company, seeking movie rights to the much-loved "Chronicles of Narnia" fantasy novels.

title: 'Two Lives': Aunt Henny and Uncle Shanti
description: TWO LIVES

title: 26.2 Unbearable Miles
description: TODAY, I am sorry to say, I will not be running in the New York City Marathon because I've been out promoting my novel about a man who is running in the New York City Marathon and I didn't have time to train. I didn't run in last year's marathon either because I was busy writing my novel about a man who is running in the New York City Marathon and I didn't have time to train. I did, however, run in the 2003 New York City Marathon. I trained hard for that one. I joined a running group, did stretching exercises, watched my diet and finished in 33,517th place. A half-hour slower than the time of my previous marathon, for which I didn't train as hard.

title: Cafeteria Style
description: On Sunday mornings, the crowds begin rolling into Cleburne Cafeteria on Bissonnet Street in Houston at around 11. The men are dressed in conservative suits, accompanied by women with high, sculptured hairdos. The Catholics arrive first, followed by the Methodists and, later, the Baptists. In the South, where traditions abide, going to a cafeteria after church is a ritual. And in Houston, no cafeteria is more time-honored than Cleburne, which has been serving regional comfort foods like squash casserole and chicken-fried steak for more than six decades.

title: Iran tries to burnish its image
Paid Notice: Deaths   WALDBAUER, ROBERT T.
description: WALDBAUER -- Robert T. Died suddenly November 3 at age 83. Flew valiantly as Army Air Force pilot 218 combat missions over the Hump in World War II. Dedicated public servant in Village of Patchogue, Suffolk County, including sixteen years as mayor. Served in many public capacities including Congressional District Field Representative for Otis G. Pike, Board member of MTA and NYS Power Authority. Owner George Waldbauer & Sons automotive wholesale business, devoted husband of sixty years to the late Marie Hemmel. Loving father to Carol, Nancy, Penny & Tad and grandfather to five. Services Monday, November 7, 10AM, Patchogue Congregational Church, 95 East Main St. Visiting Saturday and Sunday Ruland Funeral Home, Patchogue, N.Y. Donations to Ohio University Foundation, P.O. Box 869, Athens, Ohio 45701.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHL, PETER R.
description: JOHL--Peter R., on November 3rd, 2005. Beloved father of Kirsten Ora and Melanie Kaufman. Devoted grandfather of Max Randolph. Loving brother of John H. and Janet J. Weissman. Also survived by many beloved nieces, nephews and cousins. Reposing John J. Barrett Funeral Home, 424 W. 51 St., NYC, Saturday 4-8 and Sunday 11-3. Interment Monday, 11 AM, Elm Grove Cemetery, Mystic, CT. Donations may be made to the Actors' Fund.

title: Prodding or Pleading, Charities Hit Jackpots
description: Bill Gates is no slouch in the charitable-giving department. Just last week, the foundation he founded with his wife, Melinda Gates, said it would donate $258 million to eradicate malaria, which kills 2,000 African children a day. All told, Mr. Gates has given away 37 percent of his vast fortune, Forbes magazine estimated last year.

title: How the Army Gets What It Wants
description: Yonkers - CAPT. CHE AROSEMENA oversees Army recruiting for 92 public high schools in Westchester and the Bronx. The 2001 No Child Left Behind Act guarantees him and his staff entry to public schools, which would risk losing their federal financing if they barred recruiters. But accomplishing his mission has serious challenges nonetheless.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Dealing Cards, Dealing With Life

title: What Mother Never Taught You: Press Sensor
description: ANY freshman in Physics 101 can tell you how a microwave works: radio waves (at a frequency of around 2.5 gigahertz) are converted to molecular motion when they are absorbed by sugars, fats and water, thus generating heat.

Kashmiri border opening delayed

State Ballot Questions; No on Budget Reform
description: There are two initiatives on the ballot across the state this Tuesday, and both could have a profound effect on the way New York's government operates and how much it will cost taxpayers.

title: Taxing Issues
description: I realize that Connie Mack's answers to Deborah Solomon's questions (Oct. 23) were limited by space, but somehow I feel that they actually reflect the depth of his thought processes. Where will the government get money from? "What money?" The money to run the country. "We'll borrow it." Will we borrow it from the Saudis? "Maybe the Chinese." It would be humorous if the issues were not so important.

title: From Queens to Hollywood, With Help From Dublin
description: LOS ANGELES - FOR all of the action in "Get Rich or Die Tryin' " -- blazing gunplay, tire-screeching getaways, prison-shower knife fights -- there was one memorable face-off that was never committed to celluloid. The antagonists were the film's leading man, the rap superstar Curtis Jackson (known to fans as 50 Cent), and its Irish director, Jim Sheridan. It happened when a mob of teenagers showed up to catch a glimpse of Mr. Jackson while he was shooting a scene on a New York street, and he decided to let them know how much he appreciated their support.

title: Learning Everything About an Apartment
description: Correction Appended

title: WHY WE TRAVEL: GRAND CANYON NATIONAL PARK
description: MATHER OVERLOOK, SEPT. 23, 2005 - Armando Prez, 53, a natural health counselor from Kissimmee, Fla. "Most people go places seeking nature, but when they find it, they don't put down their binoculars, they don't put away their cellphones. They climb up on the platform, look, take photos and stay focused on the photos, the video. They are enchanted by the beauty, but they don't become an integral part of it. I decided to become a part of the landscape. Every time I go to an archaeological site or mountain, I escape from the noise and the crowd, and go alone to some cave, some boulder. I relax, put myself in harmony with Mother Nature, and feel myself becoming the rock, the precipice, the mountain, the sky, the bird squawking and flying overhead. Those are moments that open the door to eternity." As told to Seth Kugel

title: Editor's note, Tulane, New Orleans
description: Do you know what it means to miss Tulane?

description: DO you recognize this man? If so, you're not alone.

title: Get Pellicano
description: Like most Hollywood executives these days, Brad Grey (above), the chairman of Paramount Motion Pictures Group, is tip-toeing as fast as he can from whatever relationship he may have had with Anthony Pellicano. The studio chief has said little publicly about how well he knew this now-infamous P.I.- to-the-stars -- who is near the end of a 30- month sentence for illegal possession of firearms and who may be in danger of more serious jail time in the not too distant future. But in at least one sense, Mr. Grey knew the details of Mr. Pellicano's life quite intimately. At the same time he was employing the detective, in 2001, Mr. Grey was pitching a TV drama based on Mr. Pellicano's adventures in Hollywood -- to HBO and perhaps other places as well. Mr. Pellicano, who is facing probable indictment this month on charges that he engaged in illegal wiretapping and witness tampering on behalf of his many high-level Hollywood clients, was employed numerous times as a private investigator on behalf of Mr. Grey by his lawyer, Bert Fields. And although Mr. Grey's office has said before he had been assured by the government he is only a witness in the investigation, he has been questioned by investigators.

title: Dorm Downloading Made Easy
description: ILLEGALLY downloading a movie is not only risky, it's time-consuming and tedious.

title: U.S. eases China stress on textiles
For Madrileos, Chic and Cheap
description: THE eastern edge of Madrid's central Chueca district is not the best place to find a ceramic sangria pitcher or anything else that smacks of traditional Spain. Until recently, it wasn't the place to go for much of anything except maybe a mod haircut en route to the lively dance clubs and gay bars nearby.

title: Prep School
description: Timeless tools for every kitchen.

title: Corrections
description: A review on Page 26 of the Book Review today, about "First Man: The Life of Neil A. Armstrong," by James R. Hansen, misstates the location of Mr. Armstrong's current home. According to Mr. Hansen, Mr. Armstrong lives in a suburb of Cincinnati, deliberately unidentified in the book, not on a farm near Lebanon, Ohio.

title: State Ballot Questions; Yes on Transit Bonds
description: The Rebuild and Renew New York Transportation Bond Act of 2005 -- Question 2 on most ballots -- is aimed at revitalizing the state's transportation system. It deserves resounding support from everybody who uses the roads, bridges, rails and buses in all of New York State.

title: Sweating the Details of Management
description: THE timing is as dependable as the leaves turning, the weather cooling and the Arizona Cardinals losing. We enter the heart of fall, and publishers bring out their serious management books.

title: Bryant May Be Out of His Element but He's in Lead
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 5 - For a third afternoon at East Lake Golf Club, a course shrouded in the yellow and orange of autumn, Bart Bryant experienced a moment that he called magical.

title: From Rent Control to Rent Stabilization
description: Q. My mother and I have been living in our rent-controlled apartment for 40 years. We pay $644.29 a month, and the apartment is in my mother's name. Recently, the landlord asked if we would be willing to have the apartment put into my name so he can have it changed from rent control to rent stabilization. He said that he is changing the building's heating system and that if we did this, he would not charge us for the improvement. I think he is up to something. Monica Williams, Brooklyn.

title: Riled by Intelligent Design
description: AN astronomy professor at Iowa State University, Guillermo Gonzalez, has become a lightning rod for the national debate on intelligent design and a polarizing figure on campus this semester.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PEREIRA, ANA
description: PEREIRA--Ana. The Heritage Health and Housing, Inc. Board of Directors and staff join the Pereira family in mourning the loss of our beloved Ana Pereira. She was 72. As Executive Director of Heritage Housing and Community Services--an organization she helped to found 28 years ago--Ms. Pereira was a champion to New York's neediest. Her vision, drive and determination transformed a storefront operation into a widely respected service and development agency, which delivered service-enriched housing services to the homeless and those with special needs. Under her vision and leadership, Heritage helped the city become a warmer place for those who have been historically disenfranchised. Today, as we mourn her, we are also entrenched and steeped in our commitment to continue the vision and extend ourselves caring for those who remain in need, assuring quality of care, forever building on a legacy of love and devotion. Charitable contributions in honor of Ms. Pereira's legacy can be made to the Ana Pereira Memorial Endowment Fund, 416 W. 127 St, New York, N.Y. 10027. Funeral will be held Saturday, November 5, 10AM at St. James Presbyterian Church, 141 St. and St. Nicholas Ave. The Repast will be held at Heritage Health and Housing, Inc., 416 W. 127 St, New York, N.Y. 10027. For additional information please call 212-866-2600. The Heritage Health Housing, Inc. Board of Directors and Staff

description: Thirty-three years after it opened as one of the state's premier sites for concerts, sports and other events, and two years after it closed, demolition has begun on the New Haven Coliseum.

title: Prejudice and Pride
description: It is in the early morning that I see the one I have decided to call the Guatemalan. He's smaller, darker, than the others. He stands off to the side, away from the ones who have begun to catcall, hiss and make kissing sounds. These undocumented workers are risking it. Loitering isn't tolerated at this grocery store, with a Starbucks inside, where I like to get my morning coffee. The store caters to wealthy people from Los Angeles who drive up to their second homes on the weekends in the small mountain resort community of Lake Arrowhead.

title: The Fall of The Warrior King
description: It was almost inevitable that Lt. Col. Nathan Sassaman would eventually see his Army career end badly (Dexter Filkins, Oct. 23). As an aggressive, entrepreneurial spirit in a bureaucratic organization, he already had two strikes against him. The fact that he also put loyalty to his men ahead of covering his own behind led to strike three. Sassaman would probably make a hell of a C.E.O. in private industry. Kudos to Dexter Filkins for brilliantly reported insights into why the democratization of Iraq has become almost mission impossible, even for leaders of the caliber of Nathan Sassaman.

description: To the Editor:

title: Small-Check Politics: Did It Work?
description: IN two state Assembly districts, it has been anything but politics as usual this year.

title: Italians Win Bermuda Bowl, Defeating U.S.
description: ESTORIL, Portugal, Nov. 5 - The final of the Bermuda Bowl between Italy and U.S.A.1 was thrilling. When Saturday began, with 32 boards to be played, Italy enjoyed a lead of 8 international match points. After the first 16 deals, the advantage had expanded to 9 imps. After 11 of the last 16 boards, the Italian lead had risen to 16. On board 124, both sides reached five clubs. The Italian pair immediately took their three available tricks, two hearts and one diamond, to defeat the contract.

title: Letters to the editor, Iowa State University, Ames
description: I find it quite disturbing that any professor, and especially a countrywide organization of professors, would denigrate a line of thought and inquiry at a public institution of higher learning. This event, regardless of the issue, sheds light on a disturbing trend in university professors. They fear that which they either cannot understand, or that which they cannot reconcile with their own nave beliefs. The fact that the issue at hand is intelligent design is irrelevant -- the fact that professors are running scared from it is the matter of hilarity.

title: Mayoral Candidates Rally Supporters as Vote Nears
description: On the final Sunday before the election, the New York City mayoral candidates made competing last-minute appeals to voters on the need for change versus the need to stay the course, and both sides made urgent appeals to their supporters to turn out tomorrow despite polls predicting a lopsided victory for the incumbent.

title: Two Teenagers From French Housing Projects Inspired Riots
description: CLICHY-SOUS-BOIS, France, Nov. 6 - Though uncelebrated teenagers in life, in death Zyed Benna, 17, and Bouna Traore, 15, have inspired more than 10 days of riots that have spread from housing projects in the suburbs of Paris to cities and towns across France.

title: Missing G.M.'s Not on Agenda, but Baseball People Do Talk
description: THEY'LL be handing out scorecards tomorrow at the annual general managers meetings at the Hyatt Grand Champions Resort and Spa in Indian Wells, Calif. Couldn't tell many of the teams' general managers without them.

title: The Literary Darwinists
description: Jane Austen first published "Pride and Prejudice" in 1813. She had misgivings about the book, complaining in a letter to her sister that it was "rather too light, and bright, and sparkling." But these qualities may be what make it the most popular of her novels. It tells the story of Elizabeth Bennet, a young woman from a shabby genteel family, who meets Mr. Darcy, an aristocrat. At first, the two dislike each other. Mr. Darcy is arrogant; Elizabeth, clever and cutting. But through a series of encounters that show one to the other in a more appealing light -- as well as Mr. Darcy's intervention when an officer named Wickham runs away with Elizabeth's younger sister Lydia (Darcy bribes the cad to marry Lydia) -- Elizabeth and Darcy come to love each other, to marry and, it is strongly suggested at book's end, to live happily ever after.

title: Big Easy Money
description: I am a hurricane evacuee from New Orleans. My employer decided to continue to pay employees at least through the end of the year or until our place of employment reopens, which will not be soon. I have decided that I am not returning -- to the city or to my job, but I do need some income while I resettle and look for work. Is it ethical to take the salary?

title: One Good Career Deserves Another
description: SUSAN PANISCH has been through two graduate degrees, four career tracks and one corporate training program during her zigzagging career. Of all those, her stint on Wall Street was the low point.

description: FROMM--Henry. 80 years old, passed away on November 4, 2005. Beloved father of Helene (Julian Kalkstein) and Richard (Juany Jardines). "Sunrise at Campobello" was Dore Schary's sentimental tribute to F.D.R. and his battle with polio. "Sunrise at Monticello," Guillermo Reyes's outrageously funny comedy receiving its world premiere here at Playwrights Theater of New Jersey, sets up a buffoonish Thomas Jefferson (T. J. the Man, as he is affectionately called) for a pummeling.

title: At Yale, Paying The Pipers, The Cellists
description: YALE UNIVERSITY has announced that it has received the largest gift in its history, an anonymous bequest of $100 million for the Yale School of Music. The gift is so large and so astonishing that starting next year students will not only be able to attend tuition free, but the school will still have enough money left for other programs.

title: Ethics Lectures for White House Officials
description: MAR DEL PLATA, Argentina, Nov. 5 - Members of President Bush's staff must attend "refresher lectures" next week on ethics and the handling of classified material, White House officials said here on Saturday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SCHWARTZ, DR. MARTIN S.
description: SCHWARTZ --Dr. Martin S. ICAPP (International Conference for Advancement of Private Practice of Clinical Social Work) mourns the recent death of its beloved president, Dr. Martin S. Schwartz. We will never forget him. In his honor we will establish a scholarship to continue his interest in helping young social workers attend our conference.

title: A Flash Drive With a Back Story
description: "ADULT toys" is a loaded term, often associated with stores with flashing red signs and unusually corseted mannequins. But for a sizable contingent of over-18 consumers, the phrase doesn't have salacious connotations: this group's toys of choice are plastic figurines with names like Bearbricks and Devilrobots, designed by Asian artists inspired in equal parts by science fiction and comic books.

title: Sheila Flynn, David Barrett
description: Sheila Vera Flynn and David Edgar Barrett were married yesterday at the Angel Orensanz Foundation for the Arts in New York by the Rev. Janice Smith Ammon, a Presbyterian minister. Anne-Marie Slaughter, a former Harvard law professor who now is the dean of the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton, offered a homily.

title: Shifting Sands Worry Residents in Quogue
description: STACKED up against the devastation Hurricane Katrina caused in New Orleans and along the Gulf Coast, dune-cutting erosion from October storms along three miles of oceanfront in the wealthy Village of Quogue may hardly sound worrisome.

description: December

title: CALENDAR
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Cultural Calendar, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: 'Jeopardy!' Maven Knows From Boethius, and 'Buffy,' Too
description: Maria Wenglinsky taught her French poodle to obey commands in one of her favorite languages, Latin.

title: Dark Star
description: Lentini is an unlikely stop on anybody's Italian itinerary. It's a small, mildly unattractive town 15 miles south of Catania, Sicily's second-largest city. There's a Baroque, wedge-shaped piazza in the middle, and one good restaurant in the tangle of streets, but it's a busy agricultural center, and you wouldn't make the detour to Lentini unless you're in the business of picking, packaging or trucking blood oranges.

title: Signing Up Saddam's Soldiers
description: It is late in the day, but Iraq's ruling coalition of Shiite and Kurdish parties, and their American patrons, are finally showing some realism. The latest sign was last week's plea to mostly Sunni Arab junior officers of Saddam Hussein's disbanded military to enlist in Iraq's new national army. It was a historically stunning move, but one the Baghdad government had to make if there is to be any hope of making the Iraqi Army strong enough to break its dependency on the American forces.

title: When Everyday Chemicals Cause Illness
description: LAST year, Mary Lamielle, of Voorhees, N.J., traveled to Washington for a business meeting. Her room, at the Grand Hyatt, "was perfect," she recalled. But when she ventured into the conference area, she experienced vertigo and breathing problems, which she believed were caused by chlorinated water in the hotel's decorative pools. Within a day, she was so sick, she said, that she couldn't attend the session she had organized on healthy housing for people with disabilities.

title: Amy Levy, Chad Savage
description: Amy Beth Levy and Chad Richard Savage are to be married this evening in Los Angeles. Rabbi David Baron is to officiate at Cicada, a restaurant there.

title: He Still Speaks German, but With a Motown Accent

description: ROMANTIC comedy, the genre that once celebrated the adventurous uncertainty and volatility of love, has in recent years taken the cozy tone of a woman's-magazine article reassuring readers that true love is a smoothly paved road that winds on into a glorious sunset. "Two for the Road" and "Mr. and Mrs. Smith," though seriously flawed, do their best to return the genre to its cosmopolitan priorities.

title: The Changing Face of Diversity
description: SINCE 1998, when Proposition 209 put an end to race-conscious admissions in California's public institutions, the racial balance at the highly competitive University of California, Berkeley, has been the subject of intense scrutiny. Since affirmative action days, the number of "underrepresented" minorities as defined by the U.C. system -- African-Americans, Hispanics and American Indians -- has dropped from 22 percent to about 14 percent. So when the university released enrollment figures, the student-run Daily Californian took note in a front-page article, excerpted below.

description: LONDON - ANYONE who supposes that evolution doesn't happen, or doesn't matter, should spare a thought for H5N1, the virus causing avian flu. If we're unlucky, this virus will give us a nasty demonstration of evolution in action.

title: The Remix; Poetic Frying
description: Can char marks be charming? Mikko Laakkonen thinks so. Laakkonen, a 31-year-old furniture and lifestyle designer from Helsinki, Finland, added some aesthetic flavor to the traditional grill pan by replacing the routine stripes with a distinctive botanical pattern. "My idea was to create a poetic grill pan," Laakkonen said. Made of cast iron with a wooden handle, the Vege skillet received a special mention at this year's SaloneSatellite, an international showcase of young designers that takes place during the Milan furniture fair. Now you can sear with a smile. For information, go to www.selki-asema.fi. KIRK WALSH

title: A Land of Fragile Beauty Emerges After Years of War
description: ON the beach in Sierra Leone, the bonfire was growing. Aside from our group, made up mostly of United Nations and relief workers, there was no sign of human activity for miles. The perfect white sand, the pounding of the waves, the burnt sky that felt close enough to touch -- it was ours alone. When the sun was gone and the moon was bright, we swam, and each stroke was illuminated by brilliant phosphorescence. It was like Hawaii without the tourists.

title: QUOTED
description: "Determining the tone of a work is the most important, and often the most difficult, task in analysis. We need to know how the work judges a questionable action. The Bible does not leave us in moral confusion. Good fiction likewise does not, directly or by implication, call good evil or evil good. It does not leave moral questions unanswered. Its moral viewpoint is that of the Scriptures."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEEN, SIDNEY
description: WEEN--Sidney. We mourn the passing of Sidney Ween on November 3, in the afternoon. Son of the late Samuel and Beatrice, beloved brother of Jerome, Joan, and the late Ruth and Helen. Devoted husband of the late Dorothy, adoring father of Jeffrey, Bonnie, Stephan and the late Pamela. Honored grandfather of Rachel, Joshua, Heather, and Michael, joyous great grandfather of Tamar. An extraordinary man of many dimensions. He was honored, respected and loved by all those he touched. A devoted family man of strongly held beliefs, high moral fiber and great charity. His life and passing were a lesson to all who passed his way. Though he will be deeply missed, his example will be a permanent monument for all to follow. Funeral services Friday November 4, 12 noon, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave at 91 St. Shiva at Sidney Ween's residence, 500 East 77 Street, starting Saturday night. Jeffrey & Bonnie Ween Stephan, Rachel, Joshua, Heather & Tamar Brumberg Michael Kozek

description: SCHWARTZ--Martin S., 80. October 30. Survived by loving partner of 40 years, Martin Rubenstein, sons Randy (Beth) and Caleb, granddaughter Deanna (Mark). World War II veteran, lifelong advocate for gay rights and social equality. Emeritus Professor of Social Work at Virginia Commonwealth University, Past Pres. of the VA. Soc. for Clinical Social Work, Pres. Emeritus of the Intern'l Conference for the Advancement of Private Practice, and an inductee of the Nat'l Acad. of Practitioners. Contributions may be made to the Martin S. Schwartz Scholarship Fund at VCU School of Social Work.

Star Turns: Five Knockouts In the Battle of the Sexes; Rosamund Pike
description: IT'S somehow not surprising to discover that the pretty blond British actress Rosamund Pike plays the piano and cello, speaks French and German and graduated from Oxford with an "upper second" -- the equivalent of our magna cum laude. There's an accomplished intelligence about her on screen, whether she's being demurely magnetic as the eldest of the Bennet sisters in the new "Pride & Prejudice" or doing her best to murder James Bond in "Die Another Day" as the seductive but heartless Miranda Frost.

title: Who Should Redistrict?
description: I disagree with the premise that competitiveness equals meaningfulness (Dean E. Murphy, Oct. 23). If we upend the manufactured protections of a gerrymandered system only by imposing equally manufactured competitiveness, will the result be any more representative of the electorate? Our officials shouldn't be apportioned by any standard. They should be elected.

title: The Terrence Malick Enigma
description: TERRENCE MALICK'S films -- all three of them over 32 years -- are known for their exquisite, tantalizing images: a killer in a black Cadillac racing along a dusty road framed by endless plains in "Badlands"; an isolated farmhouse, lights glowing against a midnight blue sky in "Days of Heaven." But the most mysterious image of all is that of a man in a suit and fedora, who appears briefly in "Badlands" at a house where the killer is hiding. That's Terrence Malick himself, and behind the ordinary, slightly pudgy face is a director with one of the most brilliant and strangest careers in film.

title: Full Circle
description: Style Map | New Delhi: A real city dreams of other worlds, and real city people dream of eating there. New Delhi, the capital of India, certainly has it all -- watering holes and roadside diners, health-food stores and trendy restaurants -- but these places are tucked into neighborhood minimalls, accessible only by car. The exception is Connaught Place, in the heart of the colonial city, with its concentric circles lined higgledy-piggledy with shops and restaurants. It's an urban pantry of desires, from pomegranate syrup to pork sausage, kitsch to nouvelle. SOMINI SENGUPTA

Paid Notice: Deaths   JOSEPH, ANDREW MARK
description: JOSEPH--Andrew Mark. Age 59, left us on November 1, 2005 in NYC. Loving and beloved husband to Terry for 37 years. Retired as NYC Deputy Comptroller for Budget, former associate director NYS Financial Control Board, former official Social Services Employees Union Local 371. He held an MBA from Baruch College and a BA from Queens College. Andy loved mentoring young people, traveling, scuba diving, art and music. Andy was so knowledgeable about history that he could talk about Alexander the Great and Shakespeare as though they were his friends. He was the man you'd talk to when you needed to know anything. A thirty year Hodgkin's disease survivor, he lived each day to the fullest. Andy is irreplaceable to us all. He will be remembered forever by his many friends, relatives and colleagues. The world is a better place because of Andy. Funeral services will be held Sunday, November 6 at 1:15 Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76 St. Charitable contributions preferred.

title: A Doctor for the Future
description: Dr. D. Holmes Morton stood at the front of the red-and-white-striped tent set up in a farm pasture in Lancaster County, Pa. Behind him were a horse and a buggy -- his host's main mode of transportation -- and a whitewashed barn and silo. To his left was a sunken barbecue pit, with 60 chickens cooking inside a homemade wire-mesh spit. Before him were seven families, upward of 50 people. The women wore bonnets and aprons, the men, long pants and long sleeves, in keeping with their Mennonite ways. Many of the youngest were in wheelchairs. One teenage girl had her left heel in her mouth. A boy was chewing on the handout Morton had distributed. It was two pages long and titled "Pretzel Syndrome."
