title: Paperback Row
description: CASE HISTORIES, by Kate Atkinson. (Back Bay/Little, Brown, $13.95.) Three "cold case" mysteries -- a disappearance and two murders -- are given to a private investigator, Jackson Brodie. As he ricochets among the concerns of his new clients, Jackson finds himself barely keeping up with events and hanging on for his life. Our reviewer, Jacqueline Carey, said "Case Histories" "makes most murder-mystery page turners feel as lifeless as the corpses they're strewn with."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEILAND, IRVING
description: WEILAND - Irving. Passed away on October 27, 2005. He was the beloved husband of the late Anne Weiland and devoted father of Andrew, Edward, and Ellen Williams. He was the cherished grandfather of Sarah Holland, Dan Weiland, Jeffrey Weiland, Sophie Williams and Julia Williams. He was the greatgrandfather of Lucy Holland, Ella Holland and Audrey Holland. He was a humanist and role model for his family and friends. His intelligence and unconditional love will be missed by all of us. Private services were held Sunday, October 30, 2005.

title: Reserved
description: Power, as Jimmy Breslin once wrote, is the illusion of power. Few are more dependent upon cultivating the illusion than the chairman of the Federal Reserve. After the last mostly prosperous 18 years, no economic figure in the world is thought to be as influential as Alan Greenspan. Every blessing that has befallen America -- impressive growth rate, high productivity, low inflation -- is laid at Greenspan's door. So, too, our periodic misfortunes, like the occasional bubble or bust or the recent inflationary uptick. Senator John McCain once joked that if he were elected president and Greenspan were to die, he would prop him in his chair and hope no one noticed. But is it possible that no one would notice -- that prosperity, or sound monetary management, at any rate, would go on?

title: Portland, Ore.
description: WHY GO NOW -- At first glance, late fall does not recommend Portland. The sky turns the color of old oysters. Clouds obscure the inspiring Dairy Queen dollop of volcanic Mount Hood until May. Rain drools from eaves.

description: PARIS - IN photographs, Michael Haneke could easily pass for a taciturn Mittel Europa philosophy professor weighed down by gloom and doom. Indeed, his movies are hardly more optimistic. His world -- and, by now, it is possible to speak of a "Haneke world" -- is not a happy place. Violence, guilt and tension pervade the bleak stories he brings to the screen.

title: Sports Exhibitionists Star on the Web
description: IT was late in the game last Sunday between the Green Bay Packers and the Cincinnati Bengals, and the Packer quarterback, Brett Favre, was trying to put together a comeback drive. Favre took the snap and dropped back to pass the football, when suddenly a Bengals fan appeared on the field and snatched it from him. The fan -- the police later identified him as Gregory Gall and described him as drunk -- promptly took off on a 50-yard dash before the police and security officials grabbed him, cuffed him and carted him off to jail.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BJORK, ROBERT WILLIAM
description: BJORK -- Robert William. Died on October 23 following a long and valiant battle with Parkinson's disease. Born in 1926, he grew up in Yonkers, and after law school, returned to New York City where he worked for the next 50 years as a litigator, prosecutor and eventually as a financial consultant and money manager. He graduated from Roosevelt High School, and went on to Princeton in 1944. He entered the Navy in WW II, serving until 1946 in the Pacific. He returned to Princeton where he became one of the founding members of the acapella group, The Tigertones. He went on to Harvard Law School, graduating in 1952. He returned to New York joining the law firm of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett. In 1956, he became an Assistant U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York. He returned to private practice with Skadden Arps Slate Meagher & Flom in 1958. In 1960, he helped start what is now Mackay Shields Financial in pension fund asset management. Since then, he continued to be a money manager and financial consultant, having sat on the boards of five publically held corporations including Gleason Works, Kollmorgen Corporation and others. More recently, he was on the advisory board for Sageworks, and for the last eight years, he has been affiliated with Jefferson Financial Group of Stamford, CT. He was an active member of his church, an avid sportsman and fly fisherman and an enthusiastic alumnus of the Tigertones, his schools and also of Camp Dudley. Trying to stay fit and active in spite of the ravages of Parkinson's disease, he was an example of grace and courage for many. He is survived by his wife, Patricia Hartwell, M.D., his son and daughter-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Bjork of Brooklyn, NY, two grandchildren, and two stepchildren, Alison and Geoffrey Hartwell. There will be a Memorial Service at Stanwich Congregational Church, 237 Taconic Road, Greenwich, CT at 4:30 PM. Friday November 11, with a reception following.

title: Another Woman

title: The Fall of The Warrior King
description: Filkins brilliantly captures the Catch-22 that inevitably plagues every occupying force facing a counterinsurgency. Destroy a house providing cover for enemy fire, and you risk further alienating the civilian population and criticism from human rights advocates; leave the house, and your team faces lethal danger. Having served with the Israeli Army in Gaza during the first intifada, I and many of my colleagues quickly came to the conclusion that the occupation had to end -- not necessarily because of thedamage to the occupied population but because of the harm to the morals and morale of the occupiers.

Star Turns: Five Knockouts In the Battle of the Sexes; Rupert Friend
description: ONLY a few years out of drama school, Rupert Friend is about to make his debut in this country with a hat trick, capping small but pungent parts in "The Libertine" and "Pride & Prejudice" with a leading role opposite Joan Plowright in "Mrs. Palfrey at the Claremont," opening Nov. 25 in New York. Based on the lightly barbed comedy of manners by the British novelist Elizabeth Taylor, "Mrs. Palfrey" revolves around the serendipitous friendship between an elderly widow spending her last years in a London residential hotel and a struggling writer who lives in a shabby basement flat nearby. Mr. Friend's character, Ludo, is nothing if not kind; the friendship begins when he takes Mrs. Palfrey in after seeing her fall on the sidewalk outside his window.

title: Quincy, Wash: Cave B Inn at SageCliffe
description: THE BASICS -- The Cave B Inn at SageCliffe in Eastern Washington's wine country, which opened in April, is the latest project of Dr. Vince Bryan, a retired neurosurgeon, and his wife, Carol. The inn is nestled in their 130-acre vineyard above the Columbia River, where they started making wine in 1980. Next door is the Gorge Amphitheater, a concert space that they opened 20 years ago, but is now owned by the House of Blues. The Bryans, who envision SageCliffe as a retreat for artists and scientists, also plan to build equestrian, golf, theater and culinary facilities.

title: Molto Pistachio
description: "Gelato" is often misunderstood as the Italian word for ice cream. Gelato certainly is Italy's version of ice cream, but it has less cream, less butterfat to bind to air molecules and, therefore, less air than American ice cream. A small cup of gelato typically weighs the same as a cup of ice cream double its size.

Narvaez, who was in the middle of editing "I Believe in America," a feature film about three generations of a Puerto Rican family who, unknown to each other, have been involved in the pro-independence Machetero (cane-cutter) movement.

title: Annals of Tilley
description: There was a time when copies of The New Yorker used to stack up, waiting to be read, in people's houses and apartments. For all of us who remember being stranded, gloriously, in the second and third parts of four-part articles from the late 1960's, there is now "The Complete New Yorker," every issue from 1925 to 2005 on eight DVD's. All that's missing is the musty smell of old magazine stock.

title: Officials bear down on breaking trade impasse
Overheard
description: To friend (verb, transitive): To link one's online profile to another's on Facebook.com, the hugely popular site for students. Widely used in various social dramas, as in: "I friended my new roommate before I got to campus" or "I friended my psych classmates" or "He friended the professor, but I think that's brown-nosing." Etymology: Emerged circa 2003 on the pioneering social networking site Friendster.com.

title: Facing the Future as Archdiocese Settles Abuse Claims
description: JAMES HACKETT was a devout Catholic, an honor student and an altar boy at Blessed Sacrament Church in Hamden in the 1970's. That all changed, he said, in 1977 when he was molested several times by a priest who taught at the school.

title: Killer Couples, Killer Saucers And 'Kiss of Death'; Seven Men From Now
description: TO understand some of the more delicate underpinnings of 50's machismo, all you have to do is look at Randolph Scott's face in Budd Boetticher's spare, lithe 1956 western, "Seven Men From Now." The first of Boetticher's westerns to be released on DVD, "Seven Men" is a superb example of the director's compact construction and feel for landscape. It's also a fine setting for Scott, playing a former sheriff who heads out to find the seven men responsible for a Wells Fargo office holdup in which his wife was shot. She had to find work there after he lost his badge -- his inability to provide for her cost her her life.

title: The Boarding House
description: There is one word that snowboarders apply to any euphoric condition: "epic." It is a state that Marc Morisset, a former pro boarder, knows well. He has experienced it time and again in the mountains of Whistler, in British Columbia, where he has lived for the past 15 years. And he encountered it recently when he climbed a tree on an empty lot in a new Whistler development, which to the civilian eye must have looked like a completely unbuildable pile of rock by the side of the road, and discovered that it afforded tremendous, near panoramic views taking in Mount Fee, Sprout, Rainbow, Mount Currie, Armchair, Wedge, Blackcomb and Whistler. Sweet.

title: First Crush
description: Mark Jones, an avid wine collector from Chicago, dreamed of being a vintner with a property in Napa, Calif. Instead, a business trip to San Francisco led him to Crushpad, a warehouse-style winery designed for urban oenophiles seeking to create their own cru. "I'm making a high-end, robust cabernet with grapes from Stagecoach Vineyard," said Jones, who crushes his own fruit in the 12,000-square-foot building. "My guess is, if you took my wine and put it in front of Robert Parker, he wouldn't be able to tell that an amateur is making it."

They met in the 1980's when Mr. Fagan, a jazz aficionado, took his dancers to New York clubs to hear Mr. Marsalis play. "I knew we could learn from him," Mr. Fagan said in a recent conference call with Mr. Marsalis. "I sensed we saw things the same way." Eventually he invited Mr. Marsalis to a rehearsal at the company's headquarters in Rochester.

title: Look Carefully: The Donor Is in the Details

The manuscripts followed a basic formula: the more dazzling the word and image, the more prominent the church patron. Not content to be anonymous donors, people who commissioned such manuscripts even had their own likenesses incorporated into scenes along with their coats of arms.

This has never been clearer or more disturbing than now, especially when considering the HISTORY CHANNEL's two-part documentary "THE CRUSADES: CRESCENT AND THE CROSS" (Sunday and Monday at 9 p.m.). Roughly 900 years ago, some Christians, inspired by POPE URBAN II, got the idea that their religion was superior to everyone else's and set out to conquer the Muslim world. These re-creation-style documentaries have a tendency to concentrate on the details, battle by battle and general by general. Some meaning would be good, too.

Paid Notice: Deaths   PRITZKER, LEON
description: PRITZKER--Leon. 83. Born June 26, 1922, died November 2, 2005. A loving husband, father and grandfather, passed from this world to live in the house of the Lord, November 2, 2005 in his home. Preceded in death by his brother, Bob Price. He is survived by his wife of 34 years MaryAnne Pritzker, sister Mae Nemeroff, his five children and their families; son William Earl and his wife Tracy with children Michael Leon and Shelby SherriAnne; son David Ronald and his wife Martina with children Sarah Nichole, David Richard, Whitney Justine, Alexandra Patricia Irene, David Jose Reyes, and Eric Martin; son Paul Mark; daughter Carol Ann Browning and her husband Michael with children Ashley Nicole and Megan Elizabeth; son Phillip Joseph and his wife Karen with children Phillip Joseph Jr. and Amie Marie. Leon was a generous and caring man who gave and asked for nothing in return. He was a long time member of Walnut Hill United Methodist Church where he was considered family by many. Leon was born in New York, NY to Harry and Sophia (Greene) Pritzker. After attending New York City College, Leon entered the United States Army and served as a cryptanalyst in World War II from 1943-1946. Leon was a master of seven languages. Upon leaving the Army, he went to work for the Census Bureau where he worked as a Statistician in Washington DC from 1947-1961, and in the Chief Response Research branch from 1961-1967. In 1967 Leon left the Census Bureau to become the Director of Marketing Information Services for Anheuser-Busch, Inc. in St. Louis, MO. In 1973 he became the Director of Management Systems for Anheuser-Busch, Inc. In 1984 he was asked to be the Executive Vice-President of Staff Operations for Campbell Taggart, Inc. Dallas, a newly acquired company by Anheuser-Busch, Inc. In 1990 Leon retired from AnheuserBusch and Campbell Taggart, but consulted for many years thereafter. Leon was well known in the mathematics and statistics communities as well as being a respected food company executive. Leon married his beloved wife MaryAnne E. (Watts) Pritzker on her birthday, December 12, 1970. They have five children and 12 grandchildren, with one greatgrandchild on the way. Leon earned his BS from the City College of New York in 1942. After W.W.II, he earned his Master's from the University of Pennsylvania in 1947. Leon was a member of Sigma Xi and Phi Beta Kappa. Leon Pritzker is listed in the Who's Who in America, Who's Who in the Midwest, and the American Men of Science. Leon was a visiting faculty member of the Case Institute Technical College in Cleveland, OH from 1954-1955, consulted for the Census and Statistical Bureau, Government of Israel, Jerusalem in 1961, and was an Instructor of Statistics for the Government of Turkey, Ankara, in 1967. Leon served with honor in the United States Army from 1943-46. He was a recipient of the Commerce Departments Meritorious Service Award (1954). Leon contributed numerous articles to professional journals and was cited in many other publications. Leon is a Fellow in the American Statistical Association, and member in Operations Research Society, Society for Information Management, International Association of Survey Statisticians, and the Walnut Hill United Methodist Church. Leon taught Sunday school and was a mentor to many of his fellow parishioners. Leon truly lived as if each day was the day that the Lord had made, and rejoiced in each of them. Leon was a wonderful father, husband, grandfather and friend. His passing will leave an unimaginable void on this earth, and he will be dearly missed. A memorial was held to celebrate the life of Leon Pritzker at Walnut Hill United Methodist Church in Dallas on November 4, 2005. A private committal was held at Restland Memorial Park. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to the Walnut Hill United Methodist Church, Salvation Army, or the Red Cross.

title: With Glen Cove's Contaminated Mound Gone, Now What?
description: GLEN COVE - FOR years, the City of Glen Cove has been trying to revitalize its waterfront along Hempstead Harbor and Glen Cove Creek, with ambitious plans for restaurants, a hotel and recreational and cultural attractions on former industrial sites. The city even built a new esplanade to get things started.

title: Evacuation, Then Reconnection
description: TWO days before Hurricane Katrina hit, editors of Tulane's weekly newspaper, The Hullabaloo, were handing out copies of the special orientation issue to arriving freshmen and their parents. At about noon, the college president issued an evacuation order, and by 5 that afternoon the gates of the New Orleans campus were locked. Kate Schafer, the editor in chief, grabbed a handful of copies of the new issue and headed north.

title: REPORTS RELEASED IN TETERBORO CRASH
description: The corporate jet that went off the end of a runway at Teterboro Airport on Feb. 2 was overweight and imbalanced, but was tantalizingly close to being able to take off, according to documents released last Monday. The crash was made worse, however, because the pilots delayed using the thrust reversers, according to investigators. A sheaf of reports released by the National Transportation Safety Board found flaws in split-second decision making just before the crash, which badly injured both of the pilots and two men in a car that the plane hit after crashing through the airport fence. The reports also identified a variety of problems with the training of both pilots and of the cabin aide,' a 22-year-old woman who had previously worked as a model and a waitress. Her brief training did not include handling a fire extinguisher or learning how to instruct passengers to assume a braced position before a crash, the reports said. The plane barreled across the six lanes of Route 46, slammed into parked cars and then hit a warehouse.

title: In Their Diversity, Mourners Honor the Spirit of a Leader
description: POUGHKEEPSIE - IT is not often that a funeral draws such a mix of people: black and white, elected officials and former inmates, college administrators and homeless people. Everyone in tears.

title: The Benefits of Mammograms
description: Long-simmering doubts about the benefits of mammograms to screen women for breast cancer should be dispelled by a new study conducted by seven major research groups. Mammograms have long been recommended as an effective tool for detecting tiny breast tumors so that they can be treated before they become dangerous. But four years ago, an analysis published in a British medical journal found so many flaws in studies that purported to show a benefit from mammography that the results were deemed virtually meaningless. Other experts agreed that the evidence was shaky, but mainstream cancer and medical organizations remained convinced that mammograms save lives.

title: Inside the List
description: TRUMAN'S SHOW: "There are two Truman Capotes," the critic Conrad Knickerbocker wrote on Jan. 16, 1966, reviewing Capote's "In Cold Blood" on the cover of the Book Review. "One is the artful charmer, prone to the gossamer and the exquisite. . . . The other, darker and stronger, is the discoverer of death. . . . He now broods with the austerity of a Greek or an Elizabethan." Almost 40 years later, Capote's book is once again a best seller -- it's at No. 7 on the nonfiction paperback list, in a crisp edition tied into the new movie. (In 1966, the book was a hardcover best seller for more than eight months; it would later spend eight months on the paperback list.) Knickerbocker's review was accompanied by a rambling interview with the author, conducted by George Plimpton. Capote defended the "nonfiction novel," telling Plimpton, "It seems to me that most contemporary novelists, especially the Americans and the French, are too subjective, mesmerized by private demons; they're enraptured by their navels, and confined by a view that ends with their own toes." That sounds like the complaint Tom Wolfe would make two decades later about American fiction, writing in Harper's Magazine. But, interestingly, Capote was no fan of Wolfe's writing, at least not back in 1966. When Plimpton asked him what he thought of the New Journalism, which was then only nascent, Capote defended his turf: "If you mean James Breslin and Tom Wolfe, and that crowd, they have nothing to do with creative journalism -- in the sense that I use the term -- because neither of them, nor any of that school of reporting, have the proper fictional technical equipment."

title: Castles, Caves and Prized Pigs in Southern Spain
description: MY first contact with the Sierra de Aracena came in a tapas bar in Seville, more than an hour's drive from the region. Casa Roman was and remains a cacophonous, atmospheric place full of smoke-streaked oil paintings and wooden stools; of neatly dressed, slick-haired locals; and of tourists trying their best to keep their guidebooks tucked out of sight.

title: 'Bad Santa': A Little Bit of Christmas Jeer
description: TO the unsuspecting, "Bad Santa" may look like just another comedy about a boozing, chain-smoking, fried-bologna-eating, womanizing, child-loathing, suicidal thief. Unreconstructed Scrooges know better: this sustained Bronx cheer from 2003 is a feature-length riposte to all the ho-ho-ho pieties that make much of December such a living hell for some of us. In other words, this is the movie that says, Yes, Virginia, it is O.K. to hate Christmas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ORR, GEORGE, PH.D.
description: ORR--George, Ph.D. Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University is deeply saddened by the loss too soon of its Professor of Molecular Pharmacology and director of its Biodefense Proteomics Research Center. A native of Great Britain, Dr. Orr was a devoted member of the Einstein faculty for more than a quarter-century and an expert in proteomics, the study of the structure and function of proteins. He was an outstanding scientist, teacher, colleague, friend and superb collaborator and will be remembered as a passionate scientist and compassionate human being. He will be greatly missed and we extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Mary, his children, Daniel, Andrew and Jane, and the entire family. Dominick P. Purpura, M.D. The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University

Borrowing a bit of the neo-New Wave sound of groups like the Futureheads, the song self-consciously satirizes the joys of plugging in and making a huge splash -- "We're gonna be the band that writes the song/ That makes Israel and Palestine get along," boasts the band's tuneless lead singer, Eddie Argos, amid other claims, like writing a song "as universal as 'Happy Birthday.' description: ACS--Sandor. Passed away Monday, October 24, 2005, age 72. Memorial service at Greenwich House Music School, 46 Barrow St., Monday, November 14, 7-9PM.

title: Negative Ads: Why They Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Jennifer Tudisco, Eric Flisser
description: Jennifer Lauren Tudisco, the daughter of Gayle and Guy Tudisco of Manhattan, was married last evening to Dr. Eric Dan Flisser, a son of Miriam and Harvey Flisser of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Gordon Tucker officiated at the New York Palace Hotel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEROY, MAXIMILIAN WARNER
description: LeROY--Maximilian Warner. On November 3, 2005. Beloved son of Kay LeRoy and the late Warner LeRoy. Precious brother of Bridget Warner LeRoy, Carolyn Plum LeRoy, and Jennifer Oz LeRoy. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Monday 6-9 P.M. Services Tuesday, 10 A.M. at Temple Emanu-El, 10 East 66 Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues.

title: The Fall of The Warrior King
description: Truly a national tragedy. Democrat or Republican, none of us can afford, as Americans, to lose quite possibly the next George S. Patton. Was there no other way to resolve this?

title: Why the Transportation Fund Is a Life-or-Death Matter
description: EAST BRUNSWICK - THE last time Florence Lotrowski-Goldberg spoke to her husband, he was preparing to leave his office at Lockheed Martin and drive home. She was in the kitchen, contemplating dinner and how it might be improved by one of those miniature chocolate cakes from ShopRite. "We deserve chocolate tonight," she told him, before dashing out to the market. When she thinks back on their offhanded phone conversation now, "I'm so glad we didn't have a fight or anything," she said.

title: Why the President Caters to the Prince
description: When the president of China was scheduled to come to Washington in September, the White House planned a meeting and a quick working lunch -- and then canceled the whole thing because the president had to pay attention to Hurricane Katrina. So why did Charles and Camilla, the not-yet-king and his consort, merit a lunch, a lavish dinner and after-dinner entertainment that included Yo-Yo Ma?

title: Star Turns: Five Knockouts In the Battle of the Sexes; Michelle Williams
description: MICHELLE WILLIAMS, who did a fine screwball turn in this summer's "The Baxter," first displayed her comic gifts while still a teenager in "Dick" (1999), in which she and Kirsten Dunst stumble upon the Watergate scandal and end up being Deep Throat. But except for "Me Without You," a little-seen British film that came out two years later, Ms. Williams hasn't had much of a chance to show what a first-rate dramatic actress she is. Kudos to Ang Lee for casting her as Heath Ledger's wife, Alma, in "Brokeback Mountain" (Dec. 9), which features Mr. Ledger and Jake Gyllenhaal as, respectively, Ennis Del Mar and Jack Twist, young cowboys who violate the macho codes of the American West by falling in love with each other.

title: Be Yourself
description: Smart students leave little to chance for the day of the big test. They get a good night's sleep, eat a good breakfast and dress for success.

title: Going to Portland
description: The Rose City, so frequently dismissed by Seattleites and San Franciscans, fairly crackles with energy.

title: Samuel A. Alito Jr.
description: An examination of several chapters in Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr.'s life suggests he is conservative by temperament, upbringing and experience.

title: The Week: Arrivals and Departures
description: Anderson Cooper ascends, Kenneth Y. Tomlinson goes private and L'homme Michelin hands out stars.

title: Race Day
description: More than 37,000 participants flooded the city's streets for Sunday's New York City Marathon.

title: A Challenging Race
description: Kenya's Paul Tergat held off defending champion Hendrick Ramaala of South Africa to win the New York City Marathon on Sunday.

title: A New Sunni Party Raises Hopes of More Political Participation
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 6 - A group of Iraqi tribal sheiks have formed a political party aimed at capturing votes in a national election in December, one of the first signs that Sunni Arabs outside mainstream parties are moving into grass-roots politics.

title: Safety woes and cost of fuel bring loss at JAL
Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Man Is Shot To Death
description: Two men were shot, one fatally, early yesterday, the police said. The slain man, Kevin Williams, 26, was shot in the face and torso at 163rd Street and Rogers Place, just 100 feet from his home, about 5:30 a.m., the police said, and he died at Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center. Mr. Williams's companion, whom the police did not identify, was shot three times and was listed in stable condition last night at the same hospital, the police said. Fernanda Santos (NYT)

title: Three Yards Away From Big Victory, Jets Can't Reach It
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 6 - Three yards was all that stood between the Jets and a feel-good victory against the San Diego Chargers, an outcome that would take the edge off the injuries two more key members of their offense had sustained Sunday.

title: Corrections
description: A television highlight entry on Wednesday for the film "Touch of Evil" misidentified the character whose future is described by the fortune teller (Marlene Dietrich) as "all used up." It is Capt. Hank Quinlan, played by Orson Welles, not Ramon Miguel Vargas, played by Charlton Heston.

title: Another Choice for Elderly: Charity or Medicare?
description: The pharmaceutical industry's version of a campaign bus, the "Help Is Here Express," has toured 25 states this year to spread the word about charity prescription programs sponsored by drug companies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLBERT, RAYMOND
description: GOLBERT--Raymond. Age 61, on November 5, 2005. Beloved husband of Alice. Devoted father of Maury and Gail; and Joshua and Lori. Cherished Poppy of Samantha, Sophia, Jonathan and Leah. Services Monday, 2 pm, at "The Riverside," 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: On the Lonely Road to Recovery, Inspiration From the Sidewalks of New York
description: From the seat of his bright orange handcycle, Sgt. John Keith stared at the road ahead as he crossed the Queensboro Bridge, sure he could not go on.

title: Arts, Briefly; Superhero News
description: Brad Meltzer, below, an author of thriller novels, has signed an exclusive contract with DC Comics for work to be published next year. Mr. Meltzer was the writer of "Identity Crisis," a seven-part comic-book mystery that forced the DC Comics superheroes to question themselves over their part in a vengeful murder. The series was one of last year's best-selling titles. In other DC news, Jim Lee, one of the most popular artists in comics who has long been associated with the company, is to be a guest of honor at the first New York Comic-Con, to be held at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center from Feb. 24 to 26. Mr. Meltzer is also scheduled to attend. GEORGE GENE GUSTINES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDEN, PHILIP
description: GOLDEN--Philip. Of Rye, NY, died November 4, 2005, age 92. Born in Poland, April 3, 1913, to Samuel & Sophie Golden. A WWII veteran having served in the Army, he worked as an attorney. Beloved husband of the late Harriet Golden. Cherished father of Sid Golden (wife Linda), Rita Fried (husband Stephen), & Audrey Lesser (husband Barry). Loving grandfather of Rayna, Scott, Shanna, Alana, David, Brett (wife Justine) and greatgrandfather of Ava Brooke. Dear brother of Arnold Golden. Funeral Service Tuesday, 12 noon, Zion Memorial Chapel, 785 E. Boston Post Rd, Mamaroneck; 914 381-1809. Interment New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: Strapping on Schmooze Shoes
description: Jane Goldberg knows her tap dance genres and history. But as demonstrated by "Belly Tap for World Peace!," performed Saturday night at the Blue Mountain Gallery in Chelsea, her solo tap and schmooze shows, as she calls them, have always been as much about humor, storytelling and political banter as dancing.

title: For Tourists, a Calmer Paris
description: For a city under siege, Paris, in its center, is oddly pleasant these days. The big department stores throb with shoppers. Strollers throng the Champs-ElysAes. Outdoor cafes buzz with people taking advantage of the unseasonably seductive mid-autumn sun.

title: India and Pakistan open Kashmir border
New Vistas for Visa
description: For years, Visa has advertised itself as the credit card for "everywhere you want to be." Now, Visa is signaling that it wants to be in the wallets of more Hispanic consumers.

title: White House Letter; Far Away From Home, No Rest for a Weary President
description: BRASLIA, Nov. 6 - George W. Bush sometimes seems to be in a Murphy's Law period of his presidency, when everything that can go wrong will go wrong.

title: Treasury Bills Set For This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

title: LOOKING AHEAD
description: JUMP BALL -- In the past few months, Cablevision announced, then dropped plans to go private, and it offered a huge dividend that benefited the controlling shareholders, the Dolan family. Now, it's fighting with the musicians' union over music for the Rockettes. Say this for Cablevision, which reports earnings this week: it's more entertaining than the Knicks. (Monday.)

title: Gene Therapy in a Bottle of Mouthwash
description: Brush your teeth and rinse with gene therapy. That could be the future of oral health care as envisioned by Colgate-Palmolive and Introgen Therapeutics, an Austin, Tex., biotechnology company.

title: From Blue-Collar Boys to Doo-Wop Sensation: A Band's Rise and Fall
description: A rush of vertigo, pleasurable but a little scary, descends around the middle of the second act of "Jersey Boys," the shrink-wrapped musical biography of the pop group the Four Seasons, which opened last night at the August Wilson Theater. This dizziness arrives during the kind of big showbiz moment (category: The Comeback) that anyone familiar with backstage back stories knows all too well.

description: SHUFRO--Lottie. November 5, 2005, age 93. Beloved wife of the late Nathan. Mother of Bernice and sister of Murray, Virginia, the late Bertha and Ralph. Loving grandmother, aunt and great-grandmother. Services today, 2 pm, at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, LI.

title: Grad Students From Abroad on the Increase
description: The number of international students entering American graduate schools rose 1 percent this year, despite a 5 percent drop in applications from foreign students, according to the annual report by the Council of Graduate Schools.

title: Bringing a Couple's Dinner-Table Repartee to MSNBC

description: Guidant, the embattled medical device maker, sued its reluctant acquirer Johnson & Johnson today, signaling that negotiations between the companies had reached a critical impasse and had moved into a more confrontational phase.

description: Correction Appended

title: Hong Kong's Democracy Movement Seeks New Showdown
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 7 - Two years after a democracy movement shook this territory's political establishment and forced the withdrawal of plans for stringent internal security legislation, democracy advocates are once again preparing for a showdown with local leaders and with Beijing.

title: Accounts
description: LiDestri Foods, Fairport, N.Y., named Greenstone/Fontana, Ronkonkoma, N.Y., formerly Topline Advertising, as the national agency for its Santa Fe Packing Company brands. The brands had been handled by the Melville, N.Y., office of Kupper Parker Communications. Spending was estimated at $9 million.

title: John Fowles, British Author of Ambiguous Endings, Dies at 79
description: John Fowles, the British writer whose teasing, multilayered fiction explored the tensions between free will and the constraints of society, even as it played with traditional novelistic conventions and challenged readers to find their own interpretations of his work, died on Saturday at his home in Lyme Regis, England. He was 79.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about Wachovia's plan to become a direct issuer of credit cards misidentified the bank that Wachovia acquired in 2004. It is SouthTrust, not SunTrust. It also misstated the given name of the Wachovia executive who said it would focus on providing cards to its own customers. He is Ben Jenkins, not Brad.

description: ATLANTA, Nov. 6 - The final image of the PGA Tour season is of a man in tan pants and a white shirt, with a homespun swing and a mustache from another time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RINGLER, DR. MILTON
description: RINGLER--Dr. Milton. Farewell dearest friend. We will always treasure and never forget the wonderful times we shared. Our love to Diane and your beloved family. Doris & Norman Tipograph

title: China and U.S. Expected to Reach Deal on Textiles
description: An agreement to limit for three years the surging growth of Chinese textile imports to the United States is expected to be completed as early as this week, Bush administration officials said yesterday.

title: A Marathon Turns Into a Sprint, and a Kenyan Wins It by Just a Step
description: After running 26 miles without deciding yesterday's New York City Marathon, Paul Tergat of Kenya and Hendrick Ramaala of South Africa began a grimly beautiful sprint to the finish.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WIENER, KENNETH
description: WIENER--Kenneth. Beloved brother of Sadie Kaporovsky. Also survived by many loving nieces, nephews and friends. Services Tuesday, 12:30 pm, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: Emile Capouya, 80, Publisher Who Wrote Books Late in Life, Dies
description: Emile Capouya, an essayist, critic and publisher who late in life published his first story collection, "In the Sparrow Hills," died on Oct. 13 at his home in East Meredith, N.Y. He was 80.

title: Many Suitors, and Pitfalls,as AOL Seeks a Partner
description: Microsoft has emerged as the front-runner in the talks surrounding the potential sale of a stake in America Online, two people involved in the negotiations said. But despite a flurry of interest in AOL from Microsoft, Google and others, finding a deal has been harder than Time Warner may have hoped.

title: Dance Preservation Organization Lays Off Most of Staff
description: Since it was founded in 1940, the Dance Notation Bureau has been at the forefront of dance preservation, and it has one of the most important collections of dance scores in the nation. But on Oct. 28, it laid off five of its six staff members, including its executive director, Ilene Fox.

title: John Fowles
description: REVIEWS OF JOHN FOWLES'S BOOKS:A 'The Collector'  (1963)  "[I]n loving attention to detail, in the quick snatch of a significant inflection, there is not a page in this first novel which does not prove that its author is a master storyteller. . . [H]e may well turn out to be a leader in the van of those who, after long absence, will revive the fading art of fiction by bringing back to it the plain excitement of suspense."

title: And the War Goes On
description: The coalition of the clueless that launched the tragically misguided war in Iraq is in complete disarray.

title: Cross-Pollinating the N.F.L. With a Star From 'Stacked'
description: The link between Pamela Anderson and football is slight at best, but Fox Sports made it, ahem, explicit yesterday by bringing Anderson, the star of one of the network's sitcoms, "Stacked," to help with the weighty task of delivering on "Fox NFL Sunday."

title: Despite Big Gap, Mayoral Campaign Blitz Continues
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Fernando Ferrer began a final burst of pre-Election Day campaigning just after 7 this morning, as the mayor urged his supporters not to grow complacent with his huge lead in the polls and the Democratic challenger focused his efforts on trying to avoid an embarrassing defeat, especially among minorities.

title: Coming to terms with China's ascent
Popular Demand
description: LucasArts Entertainment, the juggernaut born in a galaxy far, far away, can probably expect Battlefront II: Modern Combat (above) to surpass the first version of the game, which sold almost 1.8 million copies. The movie side of the franchise has ended with the release of "Star Wars: Episode III -- Revenge of the Sith" on DVD.

title: Yahoo Plans to Connect Services With TiVo
description: Yahoo and TiVo plan to announce a deal today that will connect Yahoo's vast online service to TiVo's set-top boxes, which, in addition to recording television programs, have a largely unused capability to connect to the Internet.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Shove to the Right Path For a Teenager on the Edge
description: The seventh floor of Covenant House in Manhattan resembles a college dorm. A dozen stereos blast music into a hallway where young men come and go with backpacks slung over baggy T-shirts.

title: World Bank Creates $500 Million Loan Plan to Combat Bird Flu
description: GENEVA, Nov.7 - The World Bank announced today the creation of a $500 million loan program aimed at getting money swiftly to poor Southeast Asian countries that are struggling to combat an outbreak of avian flu among birds.

title: Combating Critics' Pans With a Blitzkrieg of Ads
description: If you have watched any television in New York or listened to local radio in the last two weeks, you have probably heard about "In My Life," the new Broadway musical currently at the Music Box Theater. Its commercials, after all, have been everywhere, complete with heartfelt audience testimonials, snippets of cheering crowds and mentions of rave reviews.

title: An Evolutionist's Evolution
description: It may seem that the American Museum of Natural History is cruising for controversy in presenting "Darwin," the most comprehensive exhibition any museum has offered on the naturalist's life and theories. It is a time, after all, when the theory of evolution by natural selection seems as newsworthy as it was back in the days of the Scopes trial 80 years ago.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KERZ, LEO
description: KERZ--Leo. In loving memory of a brilliant and passionate theatre artist whose career spanned two continents. Eternal love from -Louise, Jonathan, Antony and a new generation... Kara, Kaylee, Nicole, Danielle and Leonardo Kerz.

title: A Good Day to Be a Spectator, if Not a Participant
description: A fine day for marathon spectators was not ideal for the runners. But it could have been worse.

title: Manning Giving Giants Something to Believe In
description: San Francisco - IT wasn't until late in the first half that the 49ers had a first down against the Giants, or so much as crossed midfield. Their offense was in the hands of a second-year, fourth-string quarterback named Cody Pickett, who used to be a rodeo star. Yesterday he was lassoed into the picture of a franchise going backward, if not nowhere, at least since the Giants were last here, on the short end of a January 2003 playoff disaster.

title: Wrapping Up, Mayor and Ferrer Ask Voters to Ignore Polls
description: On the final Sunday before the election, the New York City mayoral candidates made competing last-minute appeals to voters on the need for change versus the need to stay the course, and both sides made urgent appeals to their supporters to turn out tomorrow despite polls predicting a lopsided victory for the incumbent.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: The Online Travel Landscape Is Getting Crowded
description: TRAVEL sites like Expedia, Travelocity and Orbitz already have their hands full with airlines and hoteliers -- their "valued partners" -- luring consumers away with sites that look more like full-service travel agencies every day. Now, here come Yahoo and AOL, and maybe even Google.

title: Fujimori is arrested in Chile
Two Leave Fallon To Open an Agency, Toy
description: The two former senior officers of the New York office of Fallon Worldwide have opened their own agency, named Toy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOHN, ROSE
description: KOHN--Rose. We are truly saddened at the passing of our dear friend, Rose Kohn. We extend our deepest sympathy to her loved ones. Terry and Rickey Rackow

title: Will Size Spoil a Cheeky Ad Agency?
description: MIAMI - Alex Bogusky, the 42-year-old creative director of the advertising agency Crispin Porter & Bogusky, is somewhat beleaguered. Sitting in his cluttered office here, surrounded by masks he created for Burger King and other memorabilia from years of ad-making, he recalled a "battle of the bands" at Advertising Week in New York a few weeks earlier. Agencies had pitted their in-house rock bands against each other, and the Crispin band had not been treated well.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: 'Chicken Little' Tops Box Office

title: Terrorism Expert Advised City on Searches
description: Of the cast of characters in the three-month-old decision to search bags and packages brought into the New York City subways, it now appears that the most striking is Richard A. Clarke.

title: INSIDE
description: High in China's Mountains, Capturing the Fleeting Present Cameras distributed by the Nature Conservancy in remote southern China have led to an unusual exhibition at the American Museum of Natural History of photographs by villagers, recording their changing lives. THE ARTS, PAGE E1

title: In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
5 Poems in Movement by an Artist in Between Countries
description: Akemi Takeya is Japanese born and Japanese trained, and she appeared Friday and Saturday nights at the Japan Society. But she has lived in Vienna since 1991, and has been deeply involved in that city's lively performance scene. Yoko Shioya, the Japan Society's director of performing arts, wrote in the program that Ms. Takeya was part of "the diaspora of Japanese artists," creating hybrid work caught between Japan and the host country.

description: To the Editor:

title: Schubert With a Soft Whimper, Mahler With a Bang
description: When Christoph von Dohnanyi left the Cleveland Orchestra three years ago, it was time. When Seiji Ozawa left the Boston Symphony three years ago, it was long past time. That Daniel Barenboim is leaving the Chicago Symphony at the end of this season is a misfortune.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEINGOLD, HERMAN ''HY.''
description: FEINGOLD--Herman "Hy." On November 6, 2005. Adored husband of Phyllis. Cherished father of Eileen Schild (Marvin) and Dr. Robert Feingold (Dr. Jane Levitt). Beloved grandfather of Elise Siegel (Paul), Emily Feingold and Paul Feingold. Loving "PopPop" of great-granddaughter, Sophia Siegel. Funeral services 11 am, November 8, 2005, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels; 516-487-9600.

title: Palestinians' Gift to Peace
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 6 - The parents of a 12-year-old Palestinian boy who was killed by Israeli troops donated the boy's organs for transplant, calling it a gesture for peace.

title: Op-Chart; America's Learning Deficit
description: Henry Levin is a professor of economics and education at Teachers College, Columbia University. Nigel Holmes is a graphic designer.

title: Spinoff Player to Compete in Open-Source Software
description: A Silicon Valley private equity firm plans to announce today that it is buying the Ingres database software from Computer Associates and setting it up as a stand-alone open-source software company.

title: Minivans Safer With Side Air Bags
description: DETROIT, Nov. 6 - A new method of crash-testing minivans showed that Honda, Nissan and Toyota models are among the safest when struck by a sport utility vehicle or a pickup truck, according to a report released Sunday.

title: Behind the Furor, the Last Moments of Two Youths
description: CLICHY-SOUS-BOIS, France, Nov. 6 - In life, they were uncelebrated. In death, Zyed Benna, 17, and Bouna Traore, 15, have inspired more than 10 days of riots that have spread from housing projects in the suburbs of Paris to cities and towns across France.

title: Between Ads and Debate, Determining the Truth

title: A Team Victory for Westchester
description: The Westchester Track Club finished first in the team competition with a total time among its top three runners of 7:12:04. Kassahun Kabiso of the Bronx finished in 19th place in the men's race in 2:18:58, a pace of 5:18 a mile. Abraham Assefa, an Ethiopian who finished fifth in the race in 2000, ran a 2:25:32 for 30th place over all. Retta Feyissa finished in 2:27:34, in 37th place over all.

title: AUTOS ON MONDAY/Design; Love the Hummer? Wear the Fragrance
description: WHEN proud owners say that their latest purchase is "the Cadillac of refrigerators" or "the Porsche of coffee makers," auto marketers no longer dismiss their claims as idle boasting.

title: When Cleaner Air Is a Biblical Obligation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 - In their long and frustrated efforts pushing Congress to pass legislation on global warming, environmentalists are gaining a new ally.

title: The world needs a prefab constitution

description: Can it really be that the Riverside Symphony has been around for a quarter-century? The orchestra, a freelance group that presents a handful of concerts at Alice Tully Hall every year, was started in 1981 by George Rothman, its conductor, and Anthony Korf, its artistic director. Its programs tend to bring together new works, overlooked scores by well-known composers and repertory staples, often with young, promising soloists.
