title: Corrections
description: A theater review in Weekend on Friday about "Sweeney Todd," at the Eugene O'Neill Theater, referred imprecisely to the Dies Irae, from which the show's score was said to take its structural and emotional cues. It is part of the Catholic Mass for the dead, not the Mass itself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRIAN, FRANK
description: BRIAN--Frank. 86. December 12, 1918, to November 5, 2005. Married 65 years to his devoted wife Goldie. Leaves behind two daughters: Natalie (Stanley) & Joyce (Al); three grandchildren: Francine (Marc), Andrew (Stacy) & Matthew; & five great-grandchildren. Most remembered for his strength, fantastic sense of humor and twinkle in his eye. Most beloved by his friends and anyone who was lucky enough to know him. Funeral service 2:15, today, Star of David, Tamarac, FL.

title: Steps and missteps in bird flu fight
If He Has to Lose, Ferrer Wants to Lose With Dignity
description: Fernando Ferrer's campaign for mayor, behind by 30 points in the polls, has expanded into a campaign for dignity, too.

title: U.S. Envoy to Meet Darfur Rebels in Effort to Stem Violence
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 7 - With the Bush administration's Sudan policy in disarray, Deputy Secretary of State Robert B. Zoellick arrived here today for the first in a series of meetings intended to stanch the damage from the death of a Sudanese opposition leader and a surge of new violence in the Western province of Darfur.

title: In New Jersey, a Smiley Sunday at the End of a Mean Campaign
description: TRENTON, Nov. 6 - Even by the bare-knuckled standards of national political campaigns, the contentious race for New Jersey governor between two multimillionaires, United States Senator Jon S. Corzine and Douglas R. Forrester, has been particularly venomous.

title: Bach Preludes and Fugues From Tragedy to Joy
description: Think, improbably, Edward Gorey. The visuals were black-and-white: a slender woman in a black dress trailing scarflike bits, hair in a pompadour, with lidded eyes and white arms and a black concert grand all highlighted against a blood-red backdrop on the Miller Theater's small stage. And while the music was Bach, the playing was so expressive as to be veritably Gothic, so that one had a Gorey-like sense of fragments of quirky anecdote linked together in a collage across a broad canvas.

title: Surge in Violence in Sudan Erodes Hope
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 - After nearly three years of violence in the Darfur region of Sudan that the United States calls genocide, the Bush administration, aid officers and other experts acknowledge that the international efforts to stanch the bloodshed cannot succeed.

title: When Coloradans Rethought the Value of Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: For Some Programs, Season Has Gone Unexpectedly Awry
description: The field of teams contending for the national title has essentially been whittled to three.

title: No Evidence Of Pressure On Iraq Data, Senator Says
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 - With Democrats stepping up their attacks over prewar intelligence on Iraq, the Republican leader of the Senate Intelligence Committee said on Sunday that the panel's initial work had found no evidence of "political manipulation or pressure" in the use of such intelligence.

title: 26 Miles Later, the Last Stride Seals It
description: They ran more than 26 miles and for longer than two hours in the heat and humidity yesterday, and finished shoulder to shoulder in a dead sprint less than a second and only a few feet apart.

title: Native Eyes on a Land South of the Clouds
description: He was herding goats high up the creases of sacred Mount Kawagebo when the morning light seemed right, recalled Ananzhu, an ethnic Tibetan from an isolated village of southern China. So he took out his camera. The scene he captured that day, of an emerald lake beneath two conical, ice-capped peaks, was both stunning and layered with meanings.

title: This Time, Schwarzenegger May Not Get a Hollywood Ending
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 6 - A startling change has come over California's larger-than-life governor, Arnold Schwarzenegger, as voters prepare to head to the polls on Tuesday for an unpopular statewide election. His television advertisements have taken on an uncharacteristic tone of humility. And ordinary people, no longer awed by his Olympian persona, are openly challenging him in public.

title: Exploring the Evolution of a Reclusive Composer
description: If they so choose, composers who are independently wealthy can sidestep pragmatic questions such as what is a sensible length for a piece, or an acceptable degree of difficulty for performers, let alone audiences. They can be true to their vision, however impractical.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Thursday about "Wolf Totem," a best-selling Chinese novel by an author who writes under the name Jiang Rong, referred incorrectly to the film director Peter Jackson. Mr. Jackson has not bought the story rights and does not plan to produce a film based on it.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Joe Bergman joined Heil Brice, Newport Beach, Calif., as senior art director, a new post. He had most recently been associate creative director on the Chevrolet account at the Los Angeles office of Campbell-Ewald, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: Pete Rose Jr. Pleads Guilty in Drug Case
description: Pete Rose Jr., the son of baseball's career hits leader, pleaded guilty this morning before a federal judge in Nashville to charges that he was distributing GBL, a drug sometimes sold as a steroid alternative, to his minor league teammates.

title: Man Fatally Stabbed at Brooklyn Club After Intervening in Conflict
description: A man who showed up uninvited at a birthday party in a Brooklyn nightclub early yesterday fatally stabbed a guest who tried to smooth over a confrontation between the man and the club's bartender, the police and witnesses said.

title: At Times, Buying the Book Just for Its Cover
description: A survey recently released in Britain explored the nooks and crannies of British book snobbery, revealing that Londoners are more likely than other Britons to buy books for the purpose of showing off, that awards have more influence on women's book choices than on men's and that people aged 18 to 29 are six times more likely to have lied about reading a book than those over 50.

title: Supreme Court to Rule on Validity of Military Tribunals
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 - The Supreme Court announced today that it would decide the validity of the military commissions that President Bush wants to use to bring detainees charged with terrorist offenses to trial.

title: Young, at Ease and in Love
description: The Beethoven was spiky; the Berg, expressive. Young artists are often happy to defy expectations and turn music on its head. In Friday's concert of Musicians From Marlboro, the first of three bearing the fruits of the past summer's work to the Metropolitan Museum this season, the reversal was achieved without a trace of self-conscious posing or a deliberate appeal to hipness: it just seemed that the young artists were responding honestly to music they loved.

title: If the Label Says Organic, Is It? (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: And Now to 'Streamline' King Coal's Beheading of Appalachia
description: Six years ago, Jim Weekley, a watchful retiree in Appalachia, became angry enough to defend his seven-tenths-of-an-acre homestead in West Virginia's Pigeon Roost Hollow from a gargantuan mining process with a formidable name -- mountaintop removal -- that tells only half the truth.

title: Beware Your Trail of Digital Fingerprints
description: IT hardly ranks in the annals of "gotcha!" but right-wing blogs were buzzing for at least a few days last week when an unsigned Microsoft Word document was circulated by the Democratic National Committee. The memo referred to the "anti-civil rights and anti-immigrant rulings" of Samuel A. Alito Jr., a federal appeals court judge who has been nominated to the Supreme Court by President Bush.

title: CRITICS' CHOICE: NEW CD'S
description: Kenny Chesney "The Road and the Radio" (BNA/SonyBMG)

title: Lawmakers Call for Limits on F.B.I. Power to Demand Records in Terrorism Investigations
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 - Republicans and Democrats in Congress called on Sunday for greater restrictions on the Federal Bureau of Investigation's ability to demand business and personal records in terrorism investigations without a judge's approval and to retain the records indefinitely.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills 4 American Soldiers at Baghdad Checkpoint
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 7 - A suicide bomber plowed a car loaded with explosives into an American checkpoint here this evening, killing four American soldiers in the single deadliest suicide bombing against an American target in more than four months.

title: Bridge; Stranding South in the Dummy On the Way to a Championship
description: ESTORIL, Portugal, Nov. 5 - The final of the Bermuda Bowl between U.S.A. 1, the defending champions, and Italy was as exciting as everyone had hoped. There was no World Series sweep or Super Bowl rout in this match. When the last day began here on Saturday, the Italians enjoyed a lead of 8 international match points. There were 32 boards to go.

title: 50 Cent Creates a Group Portrait. Of Himself, Naturally
description: Various Artists"Music From and Inspired by 'Get Rich or Die Tryin',' the Motion Picture" (G-Unit/Interscope Records)

title: Accession has brought change to China and WTO
Paid Notice: Deaths   GREGG, WILLIAM PATRICK
description: GREGG--William Patrick. November 4, 2005. Beloved husband of Elizabeth. Loving father of Billy. Cherished grandfather of William. Devoted brother of Helen, Martin, John, the late Joseph, Katherine, Mary and Peter. A WWII veteran and dedicated and respected librarian at the New York Historical Society for 39 years. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call Monday and Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 pm, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, November 9, 10 am, at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Ave at 84th St.

title: Corrections
description: The David Pogue column in Business Day on Thursday about the release of the BlackBerry model 8700c, incorrectly described two features, Bluetooth and the Alt-Esc keystroke. Both were also features of the 7000 series. They are not new to the 8700c.

title: Lama Feels Spirit of City While Testing His Soles
description: Among the runners gathered to meet their supporters at the corner of 69th Street and Central Park West after the New York City Marathon yesterday was an internationally renowned Tibetan lama.

title: Officials Cautious on Violence in Germany and Belgium
description: BERLIN, Nov. 7 - Cars were torched late Sunday night in two German cities, Berlin and Bremen, and in Brussels, in incidents that appeared to be inspired by the communal riots in France, leading European officials to warn that poor and dissatisfied youths of immigrant backgrounds lived all over Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FOONT, SYLVIA (NEE GANG)
description: FOONT--Sylvia (nee Gang). On November 5. Loving and devoted wife of the late William A. Foont. Loving mother, grandmother and greatgrandmother.

title: Arts, Briefly; Ghosts Sweep Friday
description: Ghost Whisperer" anchored CBS's Friday victory in Nielsen's estimates in the second night of the November sweeps. The otherworldly drama, in which Jennifer Love Hewitt, right, sees dead people, drew 12.63 million viewers and was the most popular show of the night. In the month of October, sports ruled the basic cable ratings, particularly if you count WWE wrestling as a sport. ESPN Sunday night football broadcasts were the top three most-watched programs of the month: the New England Patriots' defeat of the Buffalo Bills on Oct. 30 drew 9.7 million, for the top slot of the month. With two baseball playoff games also in the Top 10, ESPN easily ranked first in prime time for October among total viewers, adults 18 to 49 and those 18 to 34. Among the entertainment channels, USA was first in all those measurements, helped by the addition of "WWE Monday Night Raw" to its schedule at the beginning of the month. KATE AURTHUR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HEROLD, BERNARD
description: HEROLD--Bernard. On November 5, 2005, at age 84. Loving husband of Tressa. Devoted father of Paula and Larry and daughter-in-law Michelle. Adoring grandfather of Spencer. He founded the NYSE firm of Bernard Herold and Company Inc, and never stopped going to work every day. He was a born teacher. At the seminars he conducted for CCNY graduate students he would be enthusiastically applauded. He treasured the thank you letters they wrote. He could sell enthusiasm. He had a zest for life and lived it to the fullest. He lived large. He liked to have fun. Services will be on Monday, November 7, at 1 pm, at the Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Cedar Park, and Beth El Cemetaries, Westwood, NJ. Donations in his name can be made to the City College of New York.

title: I Want My Ubiquitous Conglomerate
description: THOSE of us who have reproduced may be forgiven for thinking that MTV Networks owns the set-top box. I flee the teenagers and the bleeped-out invective of MTV's "Real World" in one room only to find an 8-year-old entranced as Nickelodeon's SpongeBob makes crabby patties and a huge racket in another.

title: The Situation in France
description: Craig Smith, the European correspondent for The Times, is in Paris covering the unrest in France. Later today, while he continues to report on the situation, he will answer your questions about what is happening in the suburbs of Paris. Please e-mail your questions and include your name and location.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FERRARI, JOSEPH FRANK
description: FERRARI--Joseph Frank. On November 5, 2005. Of Bayside, NY. Beloved husband of Gertrude. Dear father of John & Joseph. Grandfather of Christopher, Michael, Maggie, Daniel, Nicole & Matthew. Father-in-law of Maureen & Shari. Brother of Toni Cusimano. Calling hours at The Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, on Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 pm. Funeral Mass Wednesday, 10:30 am, Blessed Sacrament R.C. Church, Bayside, with interment to follow in Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Donations in his memory may be made to the New York Foundling Hospital, 590 Avenue of the Americas, New York, NY 10011.

title: HK man jailed in world's first copyright violation case
Paid Notice: Deaths   MENDELSON, MICHAEL
description: MENDELSON--Michael. Age 63, died on Friday, November 4, 2005, in his Manhattan home after a year long struggle with cancer. He is survived by his wife, Mimi, and three children, Gideon, Shara and Lauren; his aunt, Dr. Sonia Sprung; his cousins, Edie Nadler and Jonathan Nadler, and their children, Lisa and Jessica Nadler. He was a man blessed with a vision of the meaningful life, the will to create it, the wisdom to enjoy it, and, above all, the generosity to share it with others. He will live on in the hearts of his adoring family and in the memories of his countless friends. Services to be held, Tuesday, November 8, at 10 AM, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Belichick: Inquiring Mastermind Wants to Know
description: The pads of paper are like little cobblestones that form the path to one of the greatest football minds of his day. New England Patriots Coach Bill Belichick always has those notebooks with him, waiting for something as mundane as a practice schedule or as complex as an offensive system to be revealed, to spark his interest and demand to be remembered.

title: Dear Diary
description: DEAR Diary:

title: Energy Efficiency
description: To the Editor:

title: E. Stewart Williams, 95, 'Desert Modern' Architect, Dies
description: E. Stewart Williams, an architect whose many works in Palm Springs, Calif., including a home for Frank Sinatra, helped define what became known as the Desert Modern style, died on Sept. 10. He was 95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NELSON, STANLEY
description: NELSON--Stanley. Suddenly on November 4, 2005. Beloved husband of Eleanor. Devoted father of Richard and the late Diane and Marsha (Ray) Pesavento. Cherished grandfather of Leah and Mark, Juliana, Nina and Joey. Memorial service Monday, 3 pm, at "Gutterman's Inc," 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, LI. Family requests donations to Ronald McDonald House of Long Island and UJA Federation.

title: AMONG THE FINISHERS THE FREEDOM TEAM
description: The Achilles Track Club Freedom Team, a group of disabled runners who served in the armed forces, had 28 athletes competing in the New York City Marathon yesterday -- and all 28 finished, including Jonathan Holsey, who lost his left leg in a bombing in Iraq less than a year ago. After his handcycle broke down at Mile 13, Holsey ran and walked the rest of the way; he finished in 5 hours 42 minutes 56 seconds.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a study of new small schools in New York City referred imprecisely to the Web site where an earlier year's version of the study was posted. It was a research firm's site, not that of New Visions for Public Schools, which sponsors many of the schools and commissioned the study. The article also misstated the number of schools where community partners were replaced because of problems. It was four, not three.

title: Defense Holds Firm as Manning Struggles for Rhythm
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 6 - In beating the San Francisco 49ers, the Giants did all the things they had to do to win, and few of them needed to be remembered. It was a game far less memorable in victory than it would have been in defeat.

title: CRITICS' CHOICE: NEW CD'S
description: Neil Diamond "12 Songs" (Columbia)

title: Trade Officials to Hold Talks to Save a Global Agreement
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 6 - Trade ministers from around the world have agreed to hold meetings in London and Geneva through the coming week in an effort to rescue plans for a global trade pact that is at an impasse over agriculture issues.

title: How to Assess a School
description: To the Editor:

title: 50 Cent Creates a Group Portrait. Of Himself, Naturally
description: Various Artists

title: Saying Goodbye California Sun, Hello Midwest
description: LEE'S SUMMIT, Mo., Nov. 3 - A year ago, Melanie Fischer, a lifelong Californian, was not entirely sure where Missouri was. So when her husband proposed that they consider moving there, she raced to locate the state on a map printed on her children's placemats.

title: French to allow curfews to halt unrest
Edwards Has Momentum, but Time Is Running Out
description: FORT WORTH, Nov. 6 - Carl Edwards, slamming the accelerator through the floor as his first full season of Nascar Nextel Cup competition draws to a close, is having little trouble zipping past competitors or sticking the back flips that have become his celebratory trademark.

title: Ogilvy & Mather Reorganizes Units
description: Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of the WPP Group, is combining into one reporting structure its various North American agencies that specialize in tasks like advertising, direct marketing, public relations and sales promotion.

title: Terminator vs. Gerrymander
description: Sacramento - AS California prepares for the special election tomorrow called by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, his foes and backers would do well to recall the scene one year ago, when Californians rejected a proposal that would have substantially watered down the state's "three strikes and you're out" criminal sentencing law. Riding high in popularity, Governor Schwarzenegger joined forces with California district attorneys and prison guards to make mincemeat of a badly flawed initiative that the pollsters had pegged as an easy victory.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LEVIEN, DONNA
description: LEVIEN--Donna. 11/7/43--11/8/03. Happy Birthday. Your family and friends miss you very much

title: The Nation, Now Profitable, Has a New Commander
description: The torch is being passed today at The Nation, the political journal that has had a resurgence by being out of step with the mainstream political parties.

title: Dutch virtue of tolerance under strain
Court Choice Is Conservative by Nature, Not Ideology
description: In an office two doors away from Attorney General Edwin Meese III, Samuel A. Alito Jr. found himself at the heart of the Reagan revolution. He was a 35-year-old deputy assistant attorney general and it was 1985. He was working 12- to 14-hour days in the Office of Legal Counsel in a period of what colleagues describe as extraordinary intellectual ferment that marked them for life.

title: Chester Cooper, 88, a Player in Diplomacy for Two Decades, Is Dead
description: Chester L. Cooper, a retired United States diplomat who in the 1950's and 60's was a backstage player in many of the most critical negotiations of the cold war, died on Oct. 30 in Washington. He was 88.

title: In the Search for Themselves, the Knicks Are Clueless Again
description: A glimpse of the Knicks' future was on display yesterday at Madison Square Garden, or perhaps it was a glimpse of the present. Defining with any certainty who the Knicks are or what they will be five minutes from now is futile, and not even Coach Larry Brown seems to have the answers.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Yahoo to Add Online Services Using Set-Top Boxes by TiVo Yahoo and TiVo plan to announce a deal that will connect Yahoo's vast online service to TiVo's set-top boxes, which, in addition to recording television programs, have a largely unused capability to connect to the Internet. [Page C1.]

title: Exploring Repertory Where Three's Right Crowd
description: Chamber music sight reading often thrives at summer festivals, mostly for the sheer enjoyment of playing through great, indestructible repertory like, say, the Brahms String Sextets. These events are typically as ephemeral as they are spirited, but at the Aspen Music Festival two years ago, a trio of players got together and the combination seemed to stick. They were the violinist Robert McDuffie, the violist Lawrence Dutton and the cellist Ralph Kirshbaum. This year, they strung their last names together and took their music beyond the Rockies with a small tour that ended Saturday night in a performance at the 92nd Street Y.

title: Tornado Slams South Indiana; At Least 22 Die
description: EVANSVILLE, Ind., Nov. 6 - Well after most of his neighbors had gone to bed, Jerry Blackburn, a resident of the Eastbrook Mobile Home Park, was up late watching television when he saw the tornado warning.

title: Pride, Prejudice, Insurance
description: General Motors is reducing retirees' medical benefits. Delphi has declared bankruptcy, and will probably reduce workers' benefits as well as their wages. An internal Wal-Mart memo describes plans to cut health costs by hiring temporary workers, who aren't entitled to health insurance, and screening out employees likely to have high medical bills.

title: Women in Politics: Double Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: Climate Signals
description: President Bush has long argued that a nationwide program of mandatory controls on carbon dioxide and other global warming gases would saddle the country with crippling electricity costs. He may be surprised to learn that his own Environmental Protection Agency no longer believes that to be the case.

title: Bits, Bytes and Blisters: Tracking Runners From Start to Finish
description: The New York City Marathon began in the dark ages, technologically speaking. The inaugural race, four-plus laps around Central Park in 1970, was staged without computers because, well, they were not widely available.

title: Former Peruvian President Fujimori taken into police custody in Chile
From Blue-Collar Boys to Doo-Wop Sensation: A Band's Rise and Fall
description: A rush of vertigo, pleasurable but a little scary, descends around the middle of the second act of "Jersey Boys," the shrink-wrapped musical biography of the pop group the Four Seasons, which opened last night at the August Wilson Theater. This dizziness arrives during the kind of big showbiz moment (category: The Comeback) that anyone familiar with backstage back stories knows all too well.

title: A Place for Things Great, Small and Kosher
description: Rabbi Peter H. Schweitzer has lost count of how many neon kosher-sausage clocks he owns.

title: Bringing the Arcade Home on a Video Game Machine
description: Buyers of the Xbox 360, Microsoft's second-generation video game console, will, of course, expect to play big, expensive marquee games like Call of Duty 2 from Activision and Madden N.F.L. 06 by Electronic Arts.

title: Fighter Back in Queens, Nursing Concussion
description: For the second time in less than two months, the promoter Lou DiBella watched as one of his fighters was hit hard in the head. This time, the results were not as devastating.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAWL, BERNICE BARUCH
description: SHAWL--Bernice Baruch. November 4, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Alfred Shawl. 100 fabulous years of kindness, love and quick intelligence--'B' will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Graveside service Monday, November 7, 10:30 AM, at Mt. Carmel Cemetery, 718-366-5900.

title: 10 Officers Shot as Riots Worsen in French Cities
description: PARIS, Monday, Nov. 7 - Rioters fired shotguns at the police in a working-class suburb of Paris on Sunday, wounding 10 officers as the country's fast-spreading urban unrest escalated dangerously. Just hours earlier, President Jacques Chirac called an emergency meeting of top security officials and promised increased police pressure to confront the violence.

title: People
description: Bill Bruce, an executive creative director at the flagship New York office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, was promoted to creative director for BBDO New York, a new post, working with David Lubars, chairman and chief creative officer of BBDO North America. Mr. Bruce, who joined BBDO New York in 1986, has created campaigns for PepsiCo brands like Aquafina, Mountain Dew and Sierra Mist.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (Fox) ARRESTED DEVELOPMENT -- It wasn't enough that this show had Liza Minnelli as a recurring guest star during its first two seasons? This season, Charlize Theron (above), Oscar winner and general glamour girl, is playing the British love interest of Jason Bateman's character. Tonight's one-hour episode also involves activities for manly men and an inner-beauty pageant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEHRER, KATHERINE SHACK BROD
description: LEHRER--Katherine Shack Brod. October 31, 2005, in Manhattan. Beloved wife of Milton Lehrer and the late Melvin Brod, and beloved sister of the late Helen Adelman and the late Sylvia Wein. She is survived by her husband, nephews and their children. Her strength, energy and enthusiasm will continue to inspire us all.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HENDERSON, SKITCH
description: HENDERSON--Skitch. A consummate musician and entertainer recognized around the world, we knew you for your wonder-filled stories of a rich life, your ready friendship, and your caring soul. You were a musical genius with the uncommon ability to connect with and inspire not only musicians, but so many others to be our very best. We will miss your grace and smile, and the magic of your light touch on the piano through the Redwoods. Our heartfelt condolences are with Ruth and your family. Your Friends in Dragon Camp

title: Israeli Prisoners Dig Their Way to Early Christianity
description: MEGIDDO, Israel, Nov. 6 - When Israeli authorities wanted to expand the Megiddo Prison, they tapped their captive labor pool and put dozens of inmates to work digging inside the compound here that is ringed with coiled razor wire and guard towers.

title: CRITICS' CHOICE: NEW CD'S
description: Kate Bush "Aerial" (Columbia)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday profiling the theoretical physicist Lisa Randall of Harvard misspelled the surname of a New York University physicist who in 1998 proposed a relationship between the strength of gravity and the extra dimensions posited by string theory. He is Gia Dvali, not Divali.

title: Museums' Responsibility
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, BAILEY WARREN
description: BROWN--Bailey Warren. 92, died on November 5, in Bronxville. Born in St. Johnsbury, VT. Graduate of Andover and Yale, class of 1937. Served in the U.S. Navy 1940 to 1945, attaining the rank of Commander. President of Erkin Studios, garden ornament importers in New York, until retiring in 1982. Surviving are his wife Patricia Wright Charnley Brown, children: Bailey Jr., Hunting W., and Deborah B. Procino; a brother Raymond H., three grandchildren and five step grandchildren. His first wife, Barbara Worth Brown, died in 1970. Services private in Vermont. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to St. Johnsbury Academy, Box 906, St. Johnsbury, VT 05819.

title: Chrebet Has His Legacy. He Should Take It Home
description: East Rutherford, N.J. - NEARLY an hour after Wayne Chrebet walked slowly across the field to the Jets' sideline, the cobwebs of a concussion in his head, he was nowhere to be seen in the locker room, nowhere near the street clothes in his locker.

title: Society Rudely Sinks Into a Cesspool of Boorishness
description: Talk to the Hand The Utter Bloody Rudeness of the World Today, or Six Good Reasons to Stay Home and Bolt the Door By Lynne Truss 206 pages. Gotham Books. $20.

title: Azerbaijan Votes, Amid Accusations of Fraud and Abuse
description: Correction Appended

title: When a Vote for Governor May Have Added Meaning
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 - The off-year elections for governor in Virginia and New Jersey are often -- rightly or wrongly -- considered the miner's canary for national political trends. When the states vote Tuesday, after months of political upheaval on Capitol Hill and at the White House, both parties will be watching closely to discern the impact of President Bush's plummeting popularity.

title: Oil Producers Are Urged to Invest in More Capacity
description: Oil prices will keep rising over the next two decades unless the oil-rich nations of the Middle East and North Africa substantially increase investments in their energy sectors, warns a new report to be released today by the organization that represents energy-consuming nations.

title: Louisiana Lawmakers Begin Special Session on Rebuilding
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 6 - Gov. Kathleen Babineaux Blanco opened a special session of the State Legislature on Sunday, telling lawmakers that their actions in the coming days would serve as a catalyst for healing and as a guiding light for the rebuilding of New Orleans and other areas devastated by Hurricanes Katrina and Rita.

title: Grokster File-Sharing Service Shuts Down in Settlement
description: Grokster, one of the leading online networks for sharing music and videos, shut down abruptly today as part of a settlement with the recording industry, ending years of fighting over copyright infringement lawsuits that brought the company before the Supreme Court.

title: Bush, Replying to Chvez, Urges Latin Americans to Follow U.S.
description: BRASILIA, Nov. 6 - President Bush, in tough remarks aimed at Venezuela's leftist president, Hugo Chvez, called Sunday for Latin America to choose between competing futures -- an American-supported "vision of hope" and another that "seeks to roll back the democratic progress of the past two decades."

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: At Some Magazines, Men Appear to Rule the Word
description: Earlier this year, the feminist writer Susan Estrich said that women's bylines appeared far less frequently than men's on newspaper opinion pages like those of The Los Angeles Times. Now, a Cond Nast editor is making a similar case against several of publishing's top general-interest magazines -- including some owned by Cond Nast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ISAACS, PATRICIA M.
description: ISAACS--Patricia M. Sunrise August 6, 1960 Sunset October 2, 2005. Loving memory of Anthony and Nicole Isaacs.

title: More Commuters Are Going Against the Flow, and Out of the City
description: Manhattan grows on you, like no place else.

title: China Says Three Cases May Be Bird Flu
description: BEIJING, Nov. 6 - China announced Sunday that three people in which pneumonia was initially diagnosed, including a girl who died, are now suspected to have had bird flu. The government said it had asked the World Health Organization for help finding the cause of their illness.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Woman Killed In Head-On Crash
description: A woman was killed yesterday when the car she was riding in burst into flames after it was hit head-on by a vehicle driven by a woman who was drunk, the police said. The collision happened about 1:45 a.m. on Third Avenue in Bathgate, by the access ramp to the Cross-Bronx Expressway. The woman, whom the police did not identify pending notification of her family, was a passenger in a 1990 Acura Legend headed north on Third Avenue. It collided with a Toyota Highlander heading south when both vehicles turned to enter the expressway's eastbound ramp, the police said. The driver of the Toyota, Shaneeta Moore, 31, of the Bronx, was charged with driving while intoxicated, vehicular manslaughter and resisting arrest, the police said. Ms. Moore, a passenger in her car and the Acura's driver, who was not identified, were treated at St. Barnabas Hospital for minor injuries. Fernanda Santos (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A film review in Weekend on Oct. 28 about "Paradise Now" misidentified the nationality of the driver who gives a ride to Said, a member of a terrorist cell. He is Palestinian, not Israeli. It also misidentified the intended victims of a rumored plot to sterilize men with contaminated water. They are Palestinians, not Israeli settlers.

title: Iran Reports Making Bid to Resume Nuclear Talks
description: TEHRAN, Nov. 6 - Iran said Sunday that it had asked the three European countries involved in stalled negotiations over its nuclear program to resume the talks. The announcement came as the Iranian government said it had reversed a decision and allowed United Nations inspectors to visit a military site.

title: City Democrats Fell Asleep in Clubhouse
description: THE teeth-gnashing has begun among Democrats as they anticipate losing the fourth consecutive mayoral election to a Republican and fear that the city's entrenched party has lost its shine.

title: Bush Endorses Widening of Panama Canal in Speech
description: PANAMA CITY, Nov. 7 - President Bush today endorsed widening the Panama Canal and cited progress in reaching a free-trade agreement with Panama's president, MartAn Torrijos, whose friendly reception here was in contrast to some of the hostility that Mr. Bush has encountered on a four-day trip to Latin America.

title: Stock Offerings This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: New Islam in an old English town
Every State Left Behind
description: WHILE in office, Presidents George H. W. Bush and Bill Clinton both called for national academic standards and national tests in the public schools. In both cases, the proposals were rejected by a Congress dominated by the opposing party. The current President Bush, with a friendly Congress in hand, did not pursue that goal because it is contrary to the Republican Party philosophy of localism. Instead he adopted a strategy of "50 states, 50 standards, 50 tests" -- and the evidence is growing that this approach has not improved student achievement. Americans must recognize that we need national standards, national tests and a national curriculum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOFFER, ABIGAIL L.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ARNOLD, RUTH (NEE SCHWARTZ)
description: ARNOLD -- Ruth (nee Schwartz). Born December 26, 1921, in South Hampton, LI. Passed away at 84 years old on November 4, 2005, after a brief illness. Ruth is survived by her husband of 61 years, Joseph Arnold, of Manhattan, her son Richard of Los Angeles, CA, and daughter Deborah of Manhattan Beach, CA. Ruth grew up in what was then the tiny town of South Hampton, the daughter of Sarah and Alex with her sister Cele. She moved to Manhattan as a young woman joining her sister Helen, and she and Joe met at a USO dance in 1944 at Temple Emanu-El. They began married life in Brooklyn while Joe was serving in WW II. Upon return, they moved to Flushing, Queens, later moving to Brooklyn, where she and Joe raised their family. They moved to Manhattan in 1992, and Ruth loved the culture and museums that the Upper East Side afforded her, and the view of Central Park from her window. Ruth was a kind, gentle person who loved to paint, play tennis and bridge, and spend summers in East Hampton. She especially loved working with the Whitney Museum, travelling to schools in the NYC area helping young students develop an understanding and appreciation of fine art. Funeral services were held at Riverside Memorial Chapel on Sunday, November 6, 2005.

title: Monitors in Azerbaijan Say Election Did Not Meet Standards
description: BAKU, Azerbaijan, Nov. 7 - International election monitors said today that Azerbaijan's parliamentary election was tainted by range of government abuses and failed to meet democratic standards, expressing evident Western disappointment that the country had not lived up its president's pledges to hold a fair vote.

title: Congress's Sham Budget Savings
description: That rara avis, the moderate Republican lawmaker, is suddenly in sight, forcefully objecting to the House leadership's abominable package of budget cuts for the poor and environmental licentiousness for the energy industry. The five-year, $54 billion proposal is headed for a floor vote this week disguised as an overdue act of fiscal responsibility and government savings. In truth, it is so over-the-top in its inequities and giveaways that embarrassed moderates are actually rebelling, withholding support unless some of the more outrageous measures -- like despoiling the Alaska wildlife refuge with oil drilling -- are killed.

What do you think they can learn at this point in their development that will help them as international students living out here in the global village. Thank you for your suggestions and for all your work that we have benefited from as international teachers.

Lisa from San Diego, Calif., writes: Bushs policies of only abstinence has greatly harmed AIDS prevention in the world. Women cannot control how they have sex, or often with whom, so abstinence is irrelevant for those who do not have equal voice with their partner. The current policy has greatly harmed programs that the U.N. and others have had in place and were getting results, now it only helps after you are infected with a very complicated regimen and costly treatment. How dare you praise this administration for realistically dealing with a terrible epidemic?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Agreement To Fight Untaxed Cigarettes
description: One of New York's largest tobacco distributors has agreed to work with the state to block the illegal sale of untaxed cigarettes, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer announced yesterday. Harold Levinson Associates, of Farmingdale, buys state tax stamps and applies them to cigarette packs before distributing cigarettes to dealers. Some purchasers are permitted to buy tax-free cigarettes, but Mr. Spitzer is working to stop unauthorized dealers who buy packs without stamps and resell them on the Internet. The company has agreed to block sales of unstamped cigarettes to dealers identified by the attorney general or an independent compliance officer as ineligible to make the purchases.

description: After years of dispute between NBC Universal and Paxson Communications, the two sides ended a protracted and complicated negotiation yesterday that will result in the departure of Lowell W. Paxson as the chairman of Paxson Communications and an opportunity for NBC Universal to develop a partnership to control the company.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Ryanair Posts Record Profit, but Shares Fall
description: Ryanair Holdings, Europe's largest low-cost airline, reported record quarterly profit as sales soared 32 percent. Net income for the period ended Sept. 30 rose 17 percent, to 172.5 million euros ($203.8 million), or 0.22 euro a share. Second-quarter sales rose to 541 million euros ($639 million). But the stock fell as much as 5 percent after the airline said fares would decline in the fourth quarter. The chief executive, Michael O'Leary, said he would keep cutting fares to win market share and to double in size in five years, carrying 70 million passengers annually.

Bloomberg campaigned for 17 hours yesterday as he hit each borough twice in search of a historic victory -- and an overwhelming new mandate -- at the polls on Election Day. But would the concert's main sponsors -- the Edvard Grieg Society Inc. of New York, the Royal Norwegian Consulate General and the Third District Sons of Norway -- prove to be musically astute programmers?

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Investment Firm to Buy Software Maker
description: Golden Gate Capital, a private investment firm based in San Francisco, said yesterday that it would buy the software maker Geac Computer in a $1 billion cash transaction. Geac, once Canada's largest software company, accepted the offer after reviewing bids from 25 prospective buyers. Based in Markham, Ontario, Geac makes financial management software and was hard hit by the fall in software spending after upgrades leading to 2000. Golden Gate plans to transfer some of Geac's product lines to Infor, a company based in Waltham, Mass., that it already owns.

The difference is that Cookie, from Fairchild Publications, a unit of Cond Nast, is betting that mothers are eager to reclaim a sense of self and style as they face years of sleep deprivation and SpaghettiO-streaked outfits.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Woman Killed In Fire
description: An 83-year-old woman who had emphysema died yesterday in her East New York apartment in a fire that caused her oxygen tank to explode, fire officials said. The woman, Carrie Conway, left, was a longtime smoker, family members said. The fire, at 1212 Loring Avenue, was reported at 12:17 p.m. Damage was confined mainly to the bedroom, although there was heavy smoke throughout the one-bedroom apartment, fire officials said. Ms. Conway, a retired factory worker, had lived there for 31 years. A grandson, John Conway, lived with her but was at work at the time of the fire. A home health aide, who had served Ms. Conway breakfast, went grocery shopping and returned to find firefighters at the building. Ann Farmer (NYT)

title: A Performance Art Pioneer, With Friends
description: When Meredith Monk began performing 40 years ago, New York's so-called downtown scene had originality on its mind. New sounds and new ways of organizing them were the engines of exciting adventures, and Ms. Monk's extensions of the human voice became a part. Words faded to the background; wails, shrieks, burbles, tremolos, squeaks and screams, all carefully modulated and controlled, created nonverbal texts.

title: Arts, Briefly; Rivals' Gimmicks Don't Stop ABC
description: The first Sunday of November sweeps was full of attention-grabbing gimmicks. But a live presidential debate on NBC's "West Wing" (an estimated 9.6 million viewers) and the CBS television movie "Category 7: The End of the World" (about 14.7 million) couldn't reverse ABC's supremacy on Sundays. In Nielsen's estimates, the network won every hour between 8 p.m. and 11 p.m. in total viewers and among adults 18 to 49. ABC's "Extreme Makeover: Home Edition" (roughly 18.4 million) delivered its highest ratings of the season. CBS placed second among total viewers and NBC was third. The live "West Wing," drawing the show's best ratings of the season, finished third among viewers for the hour and fourth among 18-to-49-year-olds. A two-hour "Law & Order: Criminal Intent" followed, with an estimated audience of 14 million. Fox's annual Halloween "Simpsons" episode brought in 11.6 million, and ranked second from 8 to 8:30 p.m. in the 18-to-49 category. KATE AURTHUR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLAUSNER, ADELE
description: KLAUSNER--Adele. Devoted wife of the late Jack Klausner died at the age of 87, peacefully at home on November 6, after a long illness. Beloved mother, grandmother, greatgrandmother, sister and aunt, she will be remembered by her kindness, generosity, tenacity, intelligence and wit. She is survived by children Bernard, Alice, Joseph, Ellen, and Stanley, grandchildren Phillip, Jay, Julie, and Matthew, and great-grandchildren Gabrielle and Samantha. She will live forever in the hearts of those fortunate enough to have known her.

The suspect, Carl Leidig of Otego, sold pistols and ammunition to undercover officers and offered to sell a machine gun, Mr. Dillon said. He said Mr. Leidig paid an undercover officer to break his ex-companion's kneecaps and slice off her finger.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDELSON, MICHAEL
description: MENDELSON--Michael. On November 4, 2005. The staff and Board of Directors of The New Group Theatre Company are deeply saddened and moved by the passing of our friend, our supporter and the Chairman of our Board, a man who gave generously of himself, shared with us his wonderful family and friends and contributed so much in so many ways to our growth and development. We have all been touched personally and changed profoundly by his acquaintance. He has been our light and our spirit and his memory will be our guide to the future. We extend our heartfelt sympathy and love to his wonderful wife, Mimi, his three children, Shara, Gideon and Lauren, and all of his family and friends who, with us, share so many memories of this great man.

description: Since the emergence of Cindy Sheehan this past summer and her antiwar group Gold Star Families for Peace, women have provided the public face of politicized sorrow in protests against American involvement in Iraq. While mothers of slain soldiers have galvanized themselves into action, their husbands have been largely off the radar, or at odds with their ambitions. While Ms. Sheehan was voicing her dissent with the war that caused her son's death by taking up residence on a roadside by President Bush's ranch in Crawford, Tex., her husband stayed home in Vacaville, Calif., and filed for divorce.

World Briefing | Europe: New Attempts to Salvage a Global Trade Agreement
description: European and American officials called for improved access to developing markets yesterday, while countries like India and Brazil renewed pleas for deeper cuts in farm subsidies by rich nations. Representatives from Brazil, Europe, India, Japan and the United States sought to rescue negotiations for a new global agreement before the Dec. 13-18 meeting of all 148 World Trade Organization members in Hong Kong. The European trade commissioner, Peter Mandelson, left, sought to move the focus away from farm subsidies, saying that if agriculture "continues to keep everything else blocked at the gate, we cannot get to Hong Kong in the shape we need." The United States trade representative, Rob Portman, said Washington "will be standing" with Europe on opening up access to developing world markets in exchange for easing farm support.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ACTON, ANNIE M.
description: ACTON--Annie M., 88, November 5, 2005. Born in Castlebar, Co. Mayo IR, she was a resident of Norwood, Bx. for many years. Member of the League of the Sacred Heart at St. Margaret Mary Parish for 37 years. She worked at the United Nations as a Housekeeping Associate for 30 years. Daughter of the late John J. Kelly & Myria (nee Fadden). Beloved wife of 54 years to the late Patrick Acton. Dear sister of Winnie & Theresa. Loving mother of Joe, Michael, and the late Myria, Peter & John-Terrence. Visiting Tuesday 6-9 & Wed 2-5 & 7-9 P.M. at McKeon Funeral Home, 3129 Perry Avenue, Bronx. Funeral Mass on Thursday at 10 A.M. at St. Margaret Mary Church. Interment, Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Margaret Mary Church in memory of Mrs. Acton.

Who Are We? Where Are We? What Are We Doing? You Decide
description: Marguerite Duras is one of those rare writers (Sarah Kane and Gertrude Stein are others) whose blithe indifference to genre makes them ideal for use in multimedia performance, where effects become pregnant with meaning and language leans toward background music. "Destroy, She Said" (1969) belongs to a radical phase of Duras's career (after the 1968 student protests in France), when she began labeling her fascinatingly fractured texts more or less arbitrarily as novels, stories, plays or film scripts. It was perceptive of the adaptor and director Ivan Talijancic and his WaxFactory collaborators to recognize this coldly erotic, deeply ambiguous story as a potent foil for their technical wizardry.

title: World Briefing | Australia: 15 Arrested In Antiterror Raids
description: A week after the country's antiterrorism law was amended to expand the definition of a terrorist organization, the police carried out raids in Sydney and Melbourne, arresting at least 15 men. A senior police official in New South Wales, Ken Moroney, told ABC Radio that the raids had "disrupted what I would regard as the final stages of a large-scale terrorist attack." A lawyer for eight men arrested in Melbourne, Rob Stary, disputed that. He said his clients had not been arrested for planning an attack but for being members of a banned organization. Raymond Bonner (NYT)

He is so devoted that in July 2001, when he was interviewing for a job with Microsoft, he flew from Medford, Ore., to San Francisco one morning and hurried back to Ashland for that evening's performance of "The Merry Wives of Windsor."

title: John Fowles, 79, British Postmodernist Who Tested Novel's Conventions, Dies
description: John Fowles, the British writer whose teasing, multilayered fiction explored the tensions between free will and the constraints of society, even as it played with traditional novelistic conventions and challenged readers to find their own interpretations, died on Saturday at his home in Lyme Regis, England. He was 79.

title: Owner of Independence Air Files for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 7 - Independence Air, a low-fare airline that struggled with high fuel prices and stiff competition, filed for bankruptcy protection Monday and said that it would try to sell itself, in whole or in parts, within 60 days to avoid running out of cash.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Friday about a protest over New York City's plan to move the Shuang Wen Academy, a top-performing small school, into the Lower East Side building now occupied by Public School 137 misidentified a teacher and her class. She is Michelle Leung, not Grace Lin, and the pupils are kindergartners, not second graders.

title: Despite Minor Incidents, Chance of Large-Scale Riots Elsewhere in Europe Is Seen as Small
description: BERLIN, Nov. 7 - Cars were set ablaze late Sunday night in Berlin, in the German city of Bremen and in Brussels in what appeared to be copies of the riots in France. The incidents, though minor so far, served as a reminder to many Europeans that the violence that has swept France could spread to other countries in Europe that also have large, relatively poor and culturally alienated ethnic minorities, most of them predominantly Muslim.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Expressway Bus Lane Opens
description: A 1.9-mile, two-way dedicated bus lane, running from the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge toll plaza to Slosson Avenue on the Staten Island Expressway, opened with the evening rush yesterday. The $26 million project by the State Department of Transportation, begun in the summer of 2004, will allow buses to bypass regular traffic during peak hours. The rest of the project, including installation of nine noise barriers in five locations, will be completed by next spring. Several Metropolitan Transportation Authority express bus lines -- the X10, X11, X12/X42, X17 and X19 -- will use the lane, but not on trips taken via New Jersey. Off-peak X10 buses will not use the bus lane. All other stops and route designations were unchanged. Sewell Chan (NYT)

No financial terms were disclosed, but Lord Lloyd Webber said he would put about $17.5 million into refurbishing the theaters. JESSE McKINLEY

description: In 2000, voters in New York State narrowly rejected a $3.8 billion transportation bond act. But the result may have had more to do with a lack of interest or awareness: a slight majority of those who went to the polls that year did not vote at all on the measure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HORNBLOW, LEONORA
description: HORNBLOW - Leonora, novelist, 85, wife of the late movie producer Arthur Hornblow, Jr. Died in Fearrington Village, N.C. November 5, 2005. Mrs. Hornblow is survived by her son Michael and his wife Caroline.

title: Lack of Section 8 Vouchers for Storm Evacuees Highlights Rift Over Housing Program
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 - When the Northridge earthquake jolted Los Angeles in 1994, displacing tens of thousands of people, federal officials turned to one of the most venerable tools in their kit. Offering 11,300 housing vouchers under the Section 8 program, they quickly helped needy families rent private apartments.

title: UN scandal claims Indian diplomat
Currencies: Dollar keeps rising on rate advantage
DNA Expert Testifies Evidence Points to Suspect in 1973 Rape by Trillion-to-1 Odds
description: An expert in criminal DNA analysis testified yesterday that the odds were one in a trillion or longer that Fletcher A. Worrell, a defendant in a Manhattan rape trial, was not the man whose DNA was recovered from underwear the victim wore on the day of the June 1973 assault.

title: U.S. and China Agree on Import Quotas for Textiles
description: LONDON, Nov. 8 - Moving to control surging imports of clothes from Asia, the United States signed an agreement with China here today placing quotas on items including cheap shirts and trousers over the next three years.

title: India and China Take On the World and Each Other
description: SHANGHAI, Nov. 7 - For years, the rapid growth of China and India has been based on business with the developed world, and has often meant taking business away from Western industries. Now, companies in the two largest emerging economies in the world are beginning to hunt intensively for business in each other's markets.

title: Workers Are Pressing Gillette Over Conditions at Packaging Plants
description: LAWRENCE, Mass. - Marcelino Hiciano, a 56-year-old Dominican immigrant, complains that he packed Gillette razors for four and a half years as a temporary worker but was never hired as a permanent employee.

title: The Neediest Cases; Cancer Saps Queens Woman's Strength, but Not Her Endurance
description: Kymmie Smith reached up to put a can of Del Monte pineapples on the middle shelf of the kitchen cabinet, almost fully extending her left arm. She did it just to show that she could: it had been a long time since she was able perform such a simple kitchen task.

Dear daughter of the late Ellen and William O'Neill and sister of the late William O'Neill Jr. Also survived by her many cousins. Visiting Wednesday, November 9, 2005, 2-5 PM, and 7-9 pm, at the N.F. Walker Funeral Home, 2039 Merrick Ave, Merrick. Funeral Mass Thursday, 9:45 AM, at Cure of Ars R.C. Church. Interment St. John's Cemetery.

description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 8 - Shiite officials in the southern holy city of Najaf said today that two rival religious leaders had met there Monday night in a gesture of reconciliation ahead of the Dec. 15 parliamentary elections.

title: Arts, Briefly; Cuban Dancers Defect
description: Two more dancers from the Ballet Nacional de Cuba have defected. Octavio Martn, a principal dancer, and his wife, Yahima Franco, who ranked slightly above the corps de ballet, left after the company's final performance at a festival in Villahermosa, Mexico, on Oct. 30. "I want to begin a new chapter in my career," Mr. Martn said by telephone from Miami, where he and Ms. Franco, who uses the stage name Vanessa Franco, are staying with his brothers. Mr. Martn, 31, above, and Ms. Franco, 25, took a bus from Villahermosa to Matamoros, where they crossed the border to the United States, then took a 38-hour bus ride to Miami. He said he had asked Alicia Alonso, the company's general director, for permission to dance abroad permanently, but she said no. Both dancers have applied for asylum and plan to audition for ballet companies in the United States. ERIKA KINETZ

title: When firms' lawyers aren't workers' ones
While Paris Burns
description: As shocking as the riots that have swept through the depressed outskirts of Paris and other French cities over the past two weeks has been the flailing response of President Jacques Chirac and his ministers. They appear to have no idea what to do and to whom to talk. Their floundering illustrates the deeper problems that underlie the current unrest: a failed approach to absorbing immigrants into society, an out-of-touch political elite and ministers more interested in a presidential election that's still nearly two years away than in coming up with answers for today's literally burning problems.

Mark Warner, and sending a powerful message that President Bush's political standing has fallen in this reliably Republican state.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Munich Re Profit Rises 35% on Allianz Deal
description: Munich Re, the world's largest reinsurer, reported a 35 percent increase in third-quarter profit as proceeds from selling a stake in Allianz cushioned losses from the worst hurricane season in the United States. Net income rose to 492 million euros ($581 million), or 2.16 euros a share, from 365 million euros, or 1.60 euros a share, in the year-earlier period, the company reported yesterday. Munich Re said full-year profitability is within reach. Munich Re benefited from an after-tax gain of 552 million euros ($652 million) on the sale of a stake in Allianz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOODMAN, HARRISON D.
description: GOODMAN--Harrison D. On November 6, 2005. Beloved and devoted husband of Elaine, father of Douglas and John, brother of Rosemarie Tapfar. A University of Wisconsin graduate and a WWII veteran, he was a Professional Engineer, an ASHRAE Fellow, and a former Sr. Vice President of Joseph R. Loring and Associates. Longtime community activist in Bellmore, NY, where he resided for 47 years. Burial was private; a memorial service will be held at a later date. Donations in his memory may be made to the Southern Poverty Law Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KATZ, SONIA
description: KATZ--Sonia. On November 7, 2005. Daughter of the late Rachel and Max Katzman. Loving sister of Mattie Burger Livingston. Devoted aunt and "second mother" to Bonnie Cooperman, Dr. Howard Burger, Mark, Drew and Bruce Katzman & Mindi Katzman Dupille. Adoring aunt to many grand nieces and nephews. Sonia was a fine pianist, patron of the opera and philharmonic. Served for many years at the Social Science Research Council. She walked tall with pride and grace. Her warmth and caring touched many who will cherish her memory for all time. Graveside service Wednesday 11 AM Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to VNS-NY Hospice 107 East 70th Street, NYC 10021.

description: What do pedestrians, some species of fireflies and pendulum clocks have in common? Given half a chance, they act in unison, exhibiting what scientists call synchrony. And that is what lay behind the unexpected swaying of the Millennium Bridge in London five years ago, according to a new study.

Receiver Wayne Chrebet could ignore the potential for further head trauma and return for an 11th N.F.L. season because the pursuit of a Super Bowl ring was the one thing that seemed worth the risk.

title: A Writer's Curious Path to Success
description: BORDEAUX, France - Marie NDiaye is very French, which may seem surprising. Not because she was born of a Senegalese father and a French mother, but because she writes novels and plays with a freedom and daring -- some French critics even describe it as a sorcery -- more often associated with authors from Africa, India and Latin America.

title: 2nd Lawyer in Hussein's Trial Is Slain by Gunmen

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Elizabeth: Group Charged In Drug Sweep
description: Investigators arrested 33 people over the weekend, including a corrections officer, and charged them with involvement in a drug trafficking ring that made roughly $1 million per week, the Union County prosecutor, Theodore J. Romankow, said yesterday. He said the group had operated for the past year from a dollar store in Plainfield. The police seized $30,000, a large quantity of drugs and a cache of weapons and body armor, Mr. Romankow said. John Holl (NYT)

It is also a writer's -- flooded with books, pictures, paper and the autumn sunlight that catches a child's faded drawing taped to the door: "I HOWP YOU FEEL BETTR."

title: On Pride, Prejudice, Insurance: Health Care Crisis in the U.S.
description: Nell Farr, Elk Grove, Calif.: Your fine column contained this line: . . . Americans too young to receive Medicare and insufficiently destitute to receive Medicaid . . . This implies that those under 65 receive Medicaid if only they are poor enough. Many people believe this is true. It is not. Only if a person under 65 is on some Federal aid program such as AFDC or a disability program is he/she eligible for Medicaid. Others have an option of a free clinic, if available, or an E.R. for an emergency condition. However, E.R.s only stabilize a person if further care or diagnostic work is indicated, such as a mammogram or even chemo for cancer, usually such a person is totally out of luck. They die.

title: From Hunting and Gathering to Status-Seeking
description: Carl Schaefer, Lake Katrine, N.Y.: I have just finished reading Radical Evolution. Among one of Mr. Garreaus more irritating references, was the one in which he states that Steven Pinker has massively annoyed the left with his best-seller The Blank Slate: The Modern Denial of Human Nature. I am myself on the left and regard this book as the best I have read on the subject of human nature. I feel this statement distorts the true stance of Pinkers book. Pinker takes great pains to show that evolutionary psychology can be used to reframe political arguments of both the left and the right.

title: Alzheimers Patients and Privacy
description: An Oct. 30 article about Alzheimers patients and art therapy prompted Randy Alfred of San Francisco to raise some interesting questions about the intersection of journalism and privacy. Here is Mr. Alfreds e-mail message to the public editor and the response of the reporter, Randy Kennedy, which indicates to me that the article was approached with appropriate care and thoughtfulness.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: PEACOCK ALLEY -- After a $5.5 million renovation this restaurant deep within the Waldorf-Astoria reopened on Monday for lunch and cocktail snacks; dinner service begins next week. Despite striking changes, it looks as if it has always been part of the hotel. The original dining room has been turned into two private rooms, with the peacock murals inside. The chef, Cedric Tovar, and the pastry chef, Nancy Olson, both in photo, came from Django. Their seasonal dinner menu should satisfy those looking for inventive high-end fare: venison carpaccio with truffle vinaigrette, seared striped bass with a porcini and sunchoke ragout, and chocolate-peanut butter crunch cake with a glass of frozen milk. Waldorf, (212) 872-7335.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about Indian sweets that are eaten during the Hindu holiday of Diwali described the significance of the holiday and the relationship of two Hindu deities imprecisely. Diwali commemorates various events; it is not dedicated to the deities Ganesha and Lakshmi. The two are considered siblings by only a minority of Hindus.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Arrested In Fatal Shooting
description: A Brooklyn man was charged with murder and assault yesterday in connection with the shooting of two people in Kensington on Oct. 29, the police said. They said that Michael Colon, 33, of Avenue C, fatally shot Damian Menard, 23, of Beverly Road, in front of 200 East Eighth Street. Mr. Menard, who lived with his parents half a block from the shooting, was studying aeronautics in college, his relatives said. The police said he was carrying a .38-caliber gun. Mr. Colon was also charged with shooting a second, unidentified man, who survived.

title: The Yankees Are Seeking Bullpen Help
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif., Nov. 8 - Upon learning that Mariano Rivera had finished a distant second in the American League Cy Young award voting, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman had a simple response, "Ouch."

description: Correction Appended

title: UN is urged to stock up on flu drug
A 'Lost' Ship With Leaks
description: At the conclusion of the Oct. 19 episode of "Lost," a sonorous male voice narrated a preview of the next original installment of the popular ABC series. "Every season, there's one episode people will be talking about all year long," he intoned. "This is it." Over spliced images of various cast members in peril -- Sawyer collapsed, Shannon screamed, Ana-Lucia pointed a gun -- the narrator made a promise. "Three weeks from tonight, one of these survivors will be lost. Forever."

title: California Voters Reject Schwarzenegger's Plan
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8 - Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger was dealt a stinging rebuke on Tuesday by voters who rejected the centerpiece of his efforts to change the balance of power in Sacramento, an initiative to cap state spending and grant sweeping new budget powers to the governor.

title: Currencies: Higher U.S. rates give a lift to dollar
Appeals Court Upholds Ruling in Andrea Yates Case
description: Texas's highest criminal court today upheld a lower court ruling in January that tossed out the murder conviction of Andrea Yates, the Houston-area woman who was accused of drowning her children in a bathtub in 2001.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the "Arts, Briefly" column on Oct. 24 about the group Career Transition for Dancers gave an incorrect surname at one point for a former dancer it helped. He is Dan Grady (O'Grady was his stage name).

title: National Briefing | Washington: $20 Million In Grants For Aid To Ex-Prisoners
description: The Labor Department says it has awarded about $20 million in grants to religious and community groups to help people convicted of nonviolent crimes after they are released from prison. The money will go to about 30 organizations, officials said, and will help pay for programs in 20 states, including New York, Maryland and Texas. Elaine L. Chao, the labor secretary, said the programs would "provide job training, mentoring and other services to prepare returning ex-offenders for new lives as productive workers." The grants are being offered as part of an initiative that President Bush announced in his 2004 State of the Union address. John Files (NYT)

title: Meanwhile: Wherefore art thou, romance?
METS TO NAME NEW TV ANNOUNCER
description: Gary Cohen, who has called Mets games on WFAN for 17 years, is expected to be announced today as the primary play-by-play voice of the team on SportsNet New York, the Mets' TV network, which will start in the spring.

title: Saturday Night Peacocks in Squalid South Africa
description: Tailoring may not be destiny, but for the poor, black South African men known as Swenkas, donning a well-draped suit is a transformative experience. Every Saturday night, amid the squalor of downtown Johannesburg, the men engage in a ritualistic fashion show known as "swanking": dressed to the nines, they compete for cash prizes and, sometimes, livestock.

title: What if the Bleak Afterlife Were Overcrowded, Too?
description: It isn't the suicides, although they're shown with powerful bluntness. It isn't the strange, person-shaped, life-size smudge-stains that the vanished dead leave behind on floors and walls and the ground. It isn't the eerie images on computer screens or the ominous music. The most horrifying thing in Kiyoshi Kurosawa's fiercely original, thrillingly creepy "Pulse" (released as "Kairo," or "Circuit," in Japan) is the way the ghosts move.

title: Ambush of Defense Lawyers in Hussein Trial Kills One
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 8 - Gunmen ambushed two of the defense lawyers in the Saddam Hussein trial on a Baghdad street on Tuesday, killing one and seriously wounding the other. Coming after another defense lawyer was killed on Oct. 20, the latest attack brought immediate demands from other lawyers in the case for the trial to be halted and moved to a location outside Iraq.

title: When C.E.O.'s Are Entangled in Their Own Web of Words
description: On an investor conference call last month, James Dimon, the chief executive-designate at J. P. Morgan Chase, was asked about his plans for a potential merger.

Bloomberg was re-elected mayor of New York by a historic margin yesterday, beating back Fernando Ferrer's attempt to build a multiethnic coalition and giving Republicans a fourth straight victory over a Democratic Party that had controlled city politics for much of the last century.

title: Dr. Milton Elkin, 89, a Chief Radiologist, Dies

title: Provision of Blair's Antiterror Plan Is Rejected
description: LONDON, Nov. 9 - The House of Commons rejected a crucial provision of the government's anti-terrorism bill today by a vote of 322-291, handing the once-invincible Prime Minister Tony Blair his first Commons defeat since he came to power eight years ago.

Voters Approve Transit Bonds for $2.9 Billion
description: By a fair margin, a $2.9 billion bond act that will finance transportation projects statewide, including part of the Second Avenue subway and a link between the Long Island Rail Road and Grand Central Terminal, was approved by New York State voters yesterday.

title: World Business Briefing | Africa: South Africa: De Beers Stake Is Sold
description: De Beers, the largest diamond company, sold 26 percent of its South African business to help compensate black investors for centuries of white rule, loosening its grip on an industry that mines more than a tenth of the world's diamonds. De Beers, based in Johannesburg, said it sold the stake to a group including employees and former politicians for 3.8 billion rand ($562 million) to comply with new legislation on black ownership. "This deal recognizes the shoulders on which our company was built," said Jonathan Oppenheimer, managing director of the unit. South Africa's government last year passed a law forcing mining companies to sell at least 26 percent of their local assets to black investors by 2014.

title: Corrections
description: A Square Feet article in Business Day last Wednesday about development near public transit stations included an outdated reference to the management company for the Market Common, a retail and residential complex in Arlington, Va. It is the Trammell Crow Company, no longer McCaffery Interests.

Diwali commemorates various events; it is not dedicated to the deities Ganesha and Lakshmi. The two are considered siblings by only a minority of Hindus.

description: A Brooklyn man checking the oil in his car yesterday was fatally struck by a driver who had lost control of his Jeep, the police and witnesses said.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: West Bank: Israelis Kill Palestinian Youth
description: Israeli troops shot and killed a Palestinian teenager and wounded at least three other Palestinians in two confrontations outside the West Bank city of Nablus, the military and Palestinian medical workers said. Soldiers fired on four Palestinians who were believed to be planting a roadside bomb near Nablus, the military said. Three Palestinians were hit, and one, Muhammad Abu Salha, 15, died of his wounds, Agence France-Presse reported. Soldiers also shot and wounded a member of Islamic Jihad when the militant failed to stop his car at a checkpoint outside the city, the military said. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROKKEN, JAMES R.
description: BROKKEN--James R. May 24, 1941-November 3, 2005. Resident of New York City, NY, Fire Island Pines, NY and Palm Springs, CA died suddenly of a heart attack on Thursday, November 3, 2005 in Manhattan. Born May 24, 1941, the cherished third son of Edwin S. Sr. and Benita "Bonnie" Brokken, Jim's childhood was spent on the family cattle farm with five brothers and a sister west of Harmony, MN. In his early teens, occasional trips to visit relatives in the United States sparked an interest in travel that would continue throughout his life. Despite the untimely death of his father and resulting family obligations, he remained undeterred in pursuing his education. After receiving a B.S. in Business from the University of Minnesota, in 1963, he served his country as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy aboard the aircraft carrier USS Independence in the Vietnam and European Theatres. Returning stateside, he joined Northwestern Bank in Minneapolis, MN and continued his education receiving in 1969, a Master's in International Business from the American Graduate School of International Management (Thunderbird), Phoenix, AZ. After a year at Ford Motor Company in Detroit, MI, Jim accepted a position with Manufacturers Hanover Bank and moved to New York City. He remained with the bank from 1970 until his retirement in 1991, as Executive Vice President-Group Head of Europe. In retirement, he continued to provide advisory services through JR Brokken Investments to select clients and has pursued personal interests in history, travel and family, as well as philanthropic interests in education, human rights, and social services. Jim's passing leaves an unimaginable void for his family and friends. He had a loving generous spirit and lived life to the fullest measure. Preceded in death by his parents, partner of 22 years, Ed Schroer and brother Bingham Brokken. Survived by brothers Dr. Edwin (Pat) Brokken of NJ, Dr. William (Doris) Brokken of CA, Dr. Thomas (Sally) Brokken of FL, Frederick (Kay) Brokken of MN, and sister Bonnie (Jim) Bradt of CA and many loving nephews and nieces and devoted friends. A memorial service celebrating Jim's life will be held Thursday November 10, 2005, at the Waldorf - Astoria Starlight Roof, New York City. Details available from Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel 212-288-3500. Interment at Arlington National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in accordance with his wishes to: Thunderbird, the Garvin School of International Management, www.thunderbird.edu; God's Love We Deliver, www.godslovewedeliver.org; and Puppies Behind Bars, www.puppiesbehindbars.com $(6$)BROKKEN--James R. We are deeply saddened by the sudden death of our friend, mentor and a man of impeccable integrity, intelligence, style and our rock in an uncertain world. As previously agreed EDC will no longer exist and the brilliant memories of those times will have to carry us through the remainder of our lives. We'll miss you at the beach, on the dance floor, at all the wonderful restaurants and in all your travels. There will be a significant void in our lives. Our heartfelt condolences to the entire Brokken family. The Dining Club

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: Immigrant Sentenced To Life In Prison
description: Chai Soua Vang, left, who was convicted in September of shooting and killing six hunters and wounding two in northern Wisconsin last fall, was sentenced by Judge Norman Yackel to six consecutive life sentences without the possibility of parole. Mr. Vang, a Hmong immigrant, was in a tree stand in Sawyer County last November when the hunters confronted him for being on private property. Mr. Vang said that one hunter yelled racial slurs at him and that he acted in self-defense after a hunter fired a shot. The survivors said Mr. Vang ran after the victims and shot them methodically. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

Roberts Jr. stated his own views first. Then, in keeping with the court's tradition for the justices-only conference, the new chief called on the others, one by one.

Get French or Die Trying
description: PARIS - THE rioting in Paris and other French cities has led to a lot of interpretations and comments, most of them irrelevant. Many see the violence as religiously motivated, the inevitable result of unchecked immigration from Muslim countries; for others the rioters are simply acting out of vengeance at being denied their cultural heritage or a fair share in French society. But the reality is that there is nothing particularly Muslim, or even French, about the violence. Rather, we are witnessing the temporary rising up of one small part of a Western underclass culture that reaches from Paris to London to Los Angeles and beyond.

title: Arts, Briefly; Football Carries ABC to Victory
description: The rivalry between the Indianapolis Colts (Peyton Manning, far left, and Marvin Harrison, left) and the New England Patriots brought viewers to "Monday Night Football" and gave ABC a wide margin of victory for the night. In Nielsen's estimates for Monday, the Colts' win yielded an audience of approximately 19.89 million. On second-place CBS, the November sweeps tricks continued: "CSI: Miami" (17.72 million) began the first episode of a two-part crossover with Wednesday's "CSI: New York." And Martin Sheen, whose lame-duck status on "The West Wing" seems to have freed his schedule, was a guest star on "Two and a Half Men" (16.39 million), though he did not play the father of Charlie Sheen's character. On WB, "Related," which has taken the place of the canceled "Just Legal" in the 9 p.m. slot, continued to draw lackluster numbers (2.59 million). WB recently announced that it had picked up six more episodes of "Related," a sisterly drama-comedy, but Monday's episode lost more than half of the audience of its lead-in, "7th Heaven" (5.44 million). KATE AURTHUR
