Paid Notice: Deaths   HUBBY, FRANK WINFIELD III.
description: HUBBY--Frank Winfield III. Died on November 4, 2005, in his 99th year, a resident of Old Black Point, CT, and Princeton, NJ. He was the son of Frank Winfield Hubby Jr. and Alice Adams Hubby of Manhattan, great-grandson of L. M. Hubby, president and principal shareholder of the Cleveland, Cincinnati, Columbus and St. Louis Railroad-The Three C's--(Society of the Cincinnati), and Sarah French Hubby, grandson of Frank W. Hubby, founder of the Ojai Valley Improvement Company and a developer of Ojai Valley California, who with a partner built the Bear Valley Dam, San Bernardino County. His mother was a descendant of John Morgan of Salem, MA, clipper ship owner. He was a graduate of Hotchkiss School, Lakeville, CT, Yale University, Class of 1929, Harvard Law School, Class of 1932. His 50 year legal career was with Breed, Abbott & Morgan, Wall Street, Manhattan, an expert in estate, trust and corporate real estate law. His clubs included Pretty Brook Club, Springdale Golf, Beden's Brook, Nassau Club, all of Princeton, and Old Lyme Country Club, CT. He is survived by his wife of 72 years, Kingsley K. Hubby, his children, Nicholas M. Hubby of Boston and York, ME, Kingsley Gallup (Mrs. George III) of Princeton, NJ, Dr. Frank B. Hubby of Savannah, GA, Alison Hoversten of Vail, CO, and eight grandchildren. His charities include The Legal Defense Fund, Princeton Hospital, Lawrence & Memorial Hospital, New London, CT. Weir Farm Trust (The J. Alden Weir Homestead), Wilton, CT, The Florence Griswold Museum, Old Lyme, CT. Memorial services will be announced.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WHITE, JEFF
description: WHITE--Jeff. President of JWT Atlanta, died Saturday, November 5, while on a business trip to Washington to attend the Annual Marines Corps Birthday Ball. The U.S. Marines played a key role in Jeff's life. He served during the Viet Nam War, from 196871, rising to the rank of Captain. But his active service with the Marines continued, in effect, all his life. As the senior JWT executive supervising the Marine Corps advertising account, one of JWT's longest tenured, Jeff helped lead the creation of some of the most memorable and effective recruitment advertising programs in advertising history. "The Few,the Proud, the Marines" campaigns have won more awards for effectiveness than any other for military recruitment. Innovative use of public service announcements, internet advertising, and recruitment efforts aimed at women and minority officer candidates broke new ground under his direction. A native of Chicago and graduate of University of Illinois, Jeff White joined JWT in Chicago in 1968, and shortly went on leave for active duty in Viet Nam. Returning to JWT in 1971, he worked on the Gillette Safety Razor account, and later supervised the Northwestern Mutual Life insurance account. In the late 70's JWT recruited him to move to Washington, D.C. to lead the Marine Corps account, and he later ran that office. Subsequently, the Washington, D.C. office merged with the Atlanta office, and Jeff was selected to run that office. Other clients he served include Orkin, Norfolk Southern, FEMA, the U.S. Virgin Islands, and Bridgestone Golf. Friends observed that Jeff White broke a lot of "rules" about advertising people. But he lived the basic truths that mattered. He shied away from spot lights. He believed credit belonged to the team, not to him. Never a fashion plate, the only suit that mattered was the Marine's dress blues. Tough, quiet, thoughtful--Jeff believed actions spoke louder than boastful claims. Jeff's sanctuary was his home, which he shared with his wife, Sue, their son Brad, and three bull dogs. He planned to retire next year to a new home being completed in South Carolina. He would have turned 60 on December 4. He is survived by his twin brother, Randy. Jeff White made a difference to his country. He made a difference to his Company. He made a difference to his friends. And he made all the difference to his family. We will miss him enormously. Visitation for Mr. White will be 6:00-8:00 P.M. Thursday evening, November 11, at Patterson Funeral Home, Oglethorpe Hill, 4550 Peachtree Road, N.E., Atlanta, Georgia 30319, Phone: 404-261-3510. A Marine Corps Honor Guard will be in attendance. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested donations of toys or money to the Toys for Tots program sponsored by the Marine Corps Reserves. Bob Jeffrey, Lew Trencher, Rob Quish, and the JWT Worldwide Team

The Dutch bank ABN Amro encountered numerous difficulties when it tried to buy Banca Antonveneta of Italy this summer. Attempts by the Bank of Italy and a rival Italian bidder to block that acquisition are now being investigated. A yearlong study concluded that existing rules grant too much discretion to local authorities.

title: Photo (Photo by Chris Hondros/Getty Images); World Briefing | Africa: Liberia: The Economist Or The Soccer Star?
description: Liberians returned to the polls to choose their first post-war president from the two front runners in the first round last month, George Weah, the former international soccer star, and Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf, a former World Bank and United Nations official. Results are not expected for several days. Mr. Weah, 39, finished first in a field of 22 contenders last month with 28 percent of the vote, while Ms. Johnson-Sirleaf, 66, drew 20 percent. The lines of voters in the first round, for which nearly 75 percent of the country's registered voters turned out, were long, while those yesterday, including the one above on the outskirts of Monrovia, the capital, were much shorter, leading some to believe that turnout was lower. But workers at some stations said that was because the ballot this time was simpler. Lydia Polgreen (NYT)

title: Slutskaya and Kwan Taking Different Routes to Their Next Encounter

They have been competitors for so long -- Slutskaya is 26 and Kwan is 25 -- that they have become a two-person club.

title: Corrections

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Protesters And Pomp For Chinese Leader
description: President Hu Jintao of China arrived in London for a three-day visit, the first stop on a European tour that will also take him to Spain and Germany. The trip is meant to flex China's international muscles while giving the Europeans a chance to discuss common interests with an increasingly important trading partner. As hundreds of protesters waved signs denouncing Chinese policies, Mr. Hu and his wife, Liu Yongqing, were greeted by Queen Elizabeth and her husband, the Duke of Edinburgh, and driven in the royal carriage to Buckingham Palace. Today, Mr. Hu is to address the House of Commons and meet with Prime Minister Tony Blair. Before leaving, Mr. Hu and his wife will open an exhibition of Chinese art at the Royal Academy of Arts. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Alcan Profit Drops After Spinoff
description: Alcan, the Montreal-based aluminum producer, said third-quarter profit fell 52 percent as sales declined after the spinoff of the aluminum-sheet business in January. Net income declined to $81 million, or 21 cents a share. Sales dropped 21 percent, to $4.89 billion, and shipments of aluminum products declined 29 percent, to 1.11 million metric tons. Novelis, the spinoff, was created amid antitrust concerns after Alcan's acquisition of the French steel maker Pechiney in late 2004. Excluding Novelis, Alcan's pretax profit in the quarter rose by $4 million, to $725 million, from a year earlier because of higher shipments and selling prices for raw aluminum. Fourth-quarter profit in three of four business segments will probably fall from the third quarter because of lower demand and higher costs for chemicals and natural gas, according to Alcan said.

Paid Notice: Deaths   FALEK, DR. ARTHUR
description: FALEK--Dr. Arthur. 81, Professor Emeritus in the Department of Psychiatry and Behavorial Sciences, Emory University School of Medicine. Arthur Falek born March 23, 1924 in Brooklyn, NY died on November 7, 2005 from congestive heart failure. Dr. Falek was well loved for his humor and grace and will be missed by family and friends. He completed his Masters Degree in Education and a doctorate in Human Genetics in 1956 from Columbia University. In 1965 he became Director of the Human Genetics Laboratory in the Psychiatry Department of Emory University, which led to his interest in the developing field of behavior genetics. In 1967, Dr. Falek started working with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) to establish the Metropolitan Atlanta Congenital Defects Program (MACDP), which has made major contributions to understanding the incidence and causes of birth defects and is the foundation upon which the current National Center on Birth Defects and Developmental Disabilities at CDC was built. In 1979, he was awarded Georgia Mental Health Institute's Individual of the Year Award for his research into the causes of behavorial differences. At that time, he also became a national board member of the Committee on the Problems of Drug Dependency--a group devoted to understanding and combating drug abuse. Dr. Falek established the Georgia Huntington's Disease registry to track families in which HD occurred and to provide genetic counseling for those families. In the late 60's, Dr. Falek and Marjorie Guthrie, the wife of folksinger Woody Guthrie, co-founded the Committee to Combat Huntington's Disease--a support group for HD families and a lobbying agency for HD research. Dr. Falek served on the boards of both the Georgia HDSA chapter and of the national organization as science advisor. For this service he won the HDSA Mason Thompson Award. In the mid-70s, Dr. Falek received the first National Institute on Drug Abuse grant to study how drugs affect the health of AIDS addicts based on their ability to fight disease both from HIV and from other opportunistic infections. This field has expanded greatly over the last two decades and led directly to a dozen international conferences on drugs and AIDS, the formation of a scientific society (Society on NeuroImmune Pharmacology) and recently a Journal of NeuroImmune Pharmacology--all of which Dr. Falek was involved in starting. For his work on the effects of illicit drugs on AIDS progression, Arthur Falek received The Medal of the City of Paris, awarded in May 1990 by Mayor Jacques Chirac. In 1980, Dr. Falek initiated the Fetal Alcohol Surveillance project in Georgia. This project was one of the first to identify the effects of prenatal alcohol exposure and to describe the behavioral characteristics of Fetal Alcohol Syndrome and has contributed to the prevention of this common disorder. While at Emory, Arthur Falek taught several generations of medical students and was mentor to a large number of doctoral students and faculty members who went on to carve out their own distinguished careers in human genetic research, psychiatry and substance abuse. In addition to his academic excellence, Dr. Falek was well known for his community contributions including his service on numerous boards including the Jewish Family and Career Services in Atlanta; the Georgia Fetal Alcohol Task Force; Healthy Mothers, Healthy Babies; the Robischer Society, and a myriad of other community service organizations in Atlanta. Dr. Falek was active in many local, national and international Jewish organizations including the Jewish Educational Loan Fund, where he was President and Chairman of the Board; Jewish Family and Career Services of Atlanta; and at Hebrew University where he helped to establish The Sheinfeld Center for Behavior Genetics. Dr. Falek was also an advisor to Hillel on the Emory campus. Dr. Falek is survived by his wife Rhoda, his children Linda and husband Andrew Aymes; James Falek and wife Wendy Tanson; six grandchildren, three great-grandchildren, his sister Nina Epstein and his caregivers Juanita "Christy" Bowen and Rosa Parpolov. For information please call: Dressler's Jewish Funeral Care (770 - 451 - 4999). The funeral will be held at 11 A.M. Wednesday, November 9 at The Temple, 1589 Peachtree Street, Atlanta. Contributions may be made to the Jewish Educational Loan Fund (770396-3080) or Jewish Family & Career Services of Atlanta (770-677-9329) both at the following address: 4549 Chamblee Dunwoody Road, Atlanta, GA 30338.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Charged With Killing Half Brother
description: A 21-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested on Monday and charged with the fatal shooting of his half brother on Oct. 26, the authorities said. The man, Rannik Williams, was found after investigators received a tip, and he was charged with murder and possessing a weapon, the police said. Investigators said that Mr. Williams fired three shots at his half brother, Michael Williams, 17, after a dispute about money. Michael was taken to Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, where he was pronounced dead. Shamara Williams, their half sister, said that after the shooting, Michael lived long enough to tell detectives who had fired on him. He had two daughters, and Rannik Williams has a son, she said. Kareem Fahim (NYT)

World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Court Rules In Opposition Infighting
description: The leader of Zimbabwe's faltering political opposition, Morgan Tsvangirai, suffered another blow when a High Court judge overturned his suspension of a party member who had accused Mr. Tsvangirai of accepting $2.5 million in illegal contributions from foreign governments. Mr. Tsvangirai removed the accuser, Job Sikhala, from his party, Movement for Democratic Change, on the ground that he had brought it "into disrepute," but the court said the party's constitution did not allow such dismissals. Mr. Tsvangirai is embroiled in a power struggle with rival party members over whether to contest Senate elections this month. His summons of party leaders to a weekend meeting fell flat when four of the party's six top executives failed to show up. Michael Wines (NYT)

China looks very stable on the surface, but underneath it is actually boiling -- an overheated economy under a tightly sealed political lid.

title: Bloomberg Redux
description: Since this page endorsed Michael Bloomberg's re-election as mayor, we're obviously glad that New York City voters agreed. But to be honest, we'd have been even happier with a narrower margin of victory. Big wins do not always lead to better government, and Mr. Bloomberg -- who has never specialized in openness -- should not take this lopsided triumph as a mandate to insist on his way, no matter what. He need look no further than the White House for an object lesson on how quickly things can sour in a second term run from inside a bubble.

description: Shareholders of Parmalat, the huge Italian food and dairy company that went bankrupt two years ago, voted yesterday to appoint Enrico Bondi, left, as chief executive and cleared the way for him to seek settlements with the banks and auditors that Parmalat is suing. Mr. Bondi, who has run Parmalat as a government-appointed administrator since its bankruptcy in December 2003, is a corporate turnaround expert and has rarely stayed at a company once it has recovered. His decision to stay on at Parmalat will allow him to continue his pursuit of the banks and auditors that worked for it in the years before the bankruptcy. Under Mr. Bondi's direction, Parmalat has sued the banks that arranged bond sales in the year preceding its bankruptcy for 7.5 billion euros. Parmalat is also seeking 13.1 billion euros in damages from its former bankers and auditors.

Lewis Libby Jr., Vice President Dick Cheney's former chief of staff, is establishing a fund to help pay for his legal defense in the C.I.A. leak case, and associates of Mr. Libby have begun soliciting money from his friends and Republican donors, lawyers and people who have been contacted about the fund said on Tuesday.

title: Corzine Prevails in a Nasty Governor's Campaign in New Jersey
description: Jon S. Corzine, a liberal Democrat who parlayed his wealth and experience as a Wall Street executive into victory for the United States Senate five years ago, won election yesterday as New Jersey's 52nd governor. He defeated a moderate Republican and fellow multimillionaire, Douglas R. Forrester, in a nasty campaign that was the costliest in the state's history.

title: A Pilgrim's Progress
description: Xiaodong Li is Chinese. He is also a Christian, and that combination is dangerous. After he was arrested 10 years ago, Mr. Li said, he was tortured until he confessed to organizing an underground church. He was forced to clean public toilets 40 hours a week and given a date for a court hearing that was likely to end with two years in prison. With his hearing pending, Mr. Li fled to the United States.

title: No Covering Up the Patriots' Injury Problems This Time
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass., Nov. 8 - At the end, Tom Brady sat with his head against the bench, staring at the New England night sky. Unless a cornerback or two were dropping from the heavens, there were no answers to be found. The New England Patriots finally found something Monday night that even creative game plans and innovative personnel management could not disguise: an injury-depleted roster so bare that rookies and journeymen are finding regular work.

title: Big Builder Sees Slower Home Sales
description: The nation's largest maker of luxury homes, Toll Brothers, said yesterday that soaring home prices appeared to have ended. It was the latest sign that many real estate markets are slowing.

title: Deal sends Grokster down Napster path
Paid Notice: Deaths   KATZ, SONIA
description: KATZ--Sonia. On November 7, 2005. Daughter of the late Rachel and Max Katzman. Loving sister of Mattie Burger Livingston. Devoted aunt and "second mother" to Bonnie Cooperman, Dr. Howard Burger, Mark, Drew and Bruce Katzman & Mindi Katzman Dupille. Adoring aunt to many grand nieces and nephews. Sonia was a fine pianist, patron of the opera and philharmonic. Served for many years at the Social Science Research Council. She walked tall with pride and grace. Her warmth and caring touched many who will cherish her memory for all time. Graveside service Wednesday 11 AM Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to VNS-NY Hospice 107 East 70th Street, NYC 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PANZER, DAVID M.
description: PANZER--David M. After a short illness, he passed away from pneumonia on November 8 at the age of 58. Beloved partner and soul mate for 28 years of Charles Rosen, and son of the late Norma and Harry Panzer of Harrison, NY. He will be remembered for his sensitivity and kindness and mourned for his devotion to his many dear friends. President of Harrison Travel for the last decade and an Honored Virtuoso member. His personal involvement with clients worldwide created lasting and loyal bonds. He is survived by his brother Rick Panzer of Boca Raton, FL. Services Wednesday, 10 AM, November 9, Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and 55 Street to celebrate David's life. $(6$)PANZER--David. A friend, a mentor, a member of our family. The dignity of your presence will live on in our hearts forever. With our love, Lindsay, Marilyn and Stuart

title: Amtrak's President Is Fired by Its Board
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 - Amtrak's board of directors fired the company's president this morning after months of disagreement over a Bush administration plan to privatize parts of the national passenger rail system and spin off other parts to partial state ownership.

title: MANHATTAN C.C. ADVANCES
description: The Borough of Manhattan Community College men's team advanced to the semifinals of the Division III National Junior College Athletic Association tournament with a 4-1 victory over Manchester (Conn.) Community College on Pier 40 in Manhattan yesterday. B.M.C.C. (14-2-1) fell behind by 1-0 early, but took a 2-1 lead at halftime on goals by Jerry Bekoe. Bekoe, a striker from Ghana, has 23 goals this season. The Panthers will play Richland (Tex.) Community College on Saturday at Herkimer (N.Y.) Community College.

title: 'Innovative' Math, but Can You Count?
description: PENFIELD, N.Y. - LAST spring, when he was only a sophomore, Jim Munch received a plaque honoring him as top scorer on the high school math team here. He went on to earn the highest mark possible, a 5, on an Advanced Placement exam in calculus. His ambition is to become a theoretical mathematician.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about President Bush's stopover en route home from Latin America included an erroneous reference to his relationship with Panama. While Mr. Bush has typically preferred to stop in a friendly country as the last leg of a grueling foreign trip, Panama has not previously been an example of that choice: this was his first visit there. The first period between the Rangers and the Penguins wasn't 10 minutes old Monday night, but peering from on high in a Madison Square Garden luxury suite, Mark Messier had already seen why the 18-year-old Crosby is a marquee phenom.

description: Gonorrhea rates in the United States have fallen to their lowest level on record, but rates of two other sexually transmitted diseases, syphilis and chlamydia, are rising, federal health officials said yesterday.

After her retirement, she devoted herself to her paintings. A good friend to many. Services Wednesday 12PM at Weinstein Memorial Chapel, 1682 Central Park Avenue, Yonkers, NY.

description: DATAMONITOR, which tracks supermarket sales, has reported that "growth in organic milk is largely driven by continued use of hormones such as rbGH and antibiotics in the conventional dairy industry."

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 - After months of sagging poll ratings, scandal and general political unrest, the Republicans badly needed some good news in Tuesday's elections for governor. What they got instead was a clear-cut loss in a red state, and an expected but still painful defeat in a blue one.

title: Roundup: Klitschko retires
Paid Notice: Deaths   EISENSTEIN, JOAN BUEHLER
description: EISENSTEIN--Joan Buehler. An extraordinary woman of charm, grace and style died on November 8, 2005 after a long illness. For 50 years the treasured wife of Howard Eisenstein, the beloved mother of James and Susan, the cherished grandmother of Jenny, Katie and James Eisenstein and Nicole and Danielle Kerz. She is lovingly remembered by her daughter-in-law Beth Amaturo Eisenstein and son-in-law Jonathan Kerz. Born in Brooklyn in 1931, she graduated from Packer Collegiate Institute, Wells College and the Columbia School of Social Work. Her devotion to traditional family values was inspirational. Her contagious laughter and joyous optimism will not be forgotten-as she lived Thoreau's words: "to affect the quality of a day...that is the highest of the arts." She was an active and passionate member of the Alumni Board of Packer Collegiate Institute and the Board of Trustees of Daytop. Services will take place in Manhattan Thursday, November 10, 11:30 AM, Frank E. Campbell, Madison Avenue at 81st St. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to: Packer, 170 Joralemon St., Brooklyn, NY 11201 or Daytop, 54 West 40 St., NYC 10018. $(6$)EISENSTEIN--Joan B. She brought devotion and steadfastness to our ranks over this quarter-century and her footprints through this land of anguished youth shall remain engraved upon our lives. Our indomitable Trustee, Joan Eisenstein, has gone on to God and we acknowledge our great loss. Through the green and the dry, she was always at the Board table with her concern and guidance. Daytop's Board of Trustees offer prayerful support to her beloved Howard and the Family. (Msgr.) William B. O'Brien President Daytop Village, Inc. $(6$)EISENSTEIN--Joan B. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York expresses to the family of our longtime and devoted member, Joan B. Eisenstein, our deepest sympathies on the occasion of her passing. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to her life. May all who loved her be comforted. Dr. David M. Posner, Senior Rabbi Dr. Ronald B. Sobel, Senior Rabbi Emeritus Robert A. Bernhard, Pres. George Asch, Sec'y.

title: Coping with freedom at Kurkov's zoo
World Briefing | Americas: Cuba: Overwhelming U.N. Vote Against U.S. Blockade
description: For the 14th consecutive year, the United Nations General Assembly voted overwhelmingly against the United States commercial embargo of Cuba. The vote on the resolution, which is nonbinding, was 182 to 4 -- the United States, Israel, the Marshall Islands and Palau -- with one abstention, Micronesia. The Cuban foreign minister, Felipe Prez Roque said the 44-year-old embargo was being enforced with more "viciousness and brutality" than ever before because of "the helpless, imperial haughtiness of President Bush, which has taken him farther than anyone else in this madness." Ronald Godard, a deputy United States ambassador, told the General Assembly that "if the people of Cuba are jobless, hungry or lack medical care, as Fidel Castro admits, it is because of his economic mismanagement, not the embargo." Warren Hoge (NYT)

Last Night's Results
description: It's always dangerous to read national sentiments in local election results, especially when the balloting is as scattered and sparse as it was yesterday. But a few things seem obvious. Negative campaigning lost its punch. And George Bush's political capital turned into a deficit.

title: Ex-Envoy Accuses Blair on Iraq and Calls Cabinet Aides 'Pygmies'
description: LONDON, Nov. 8 - On Monday, the former British ambassador to the United States accused Prime Minister Tony Blair of squandering a golden opportunity to push the United States to delay the invasion of Iraq. On Tuesday, he characterized Mr. Blair's government as, mostly, "a crowd of pygmies."

title: Democrat Wins Race for Governor in Virginia
description: RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 8 - Lt. Gov. Timothy M. Kaine, a Democrat, won the race for governor on Tuesday night, scoring a major political victory for his mentor, Gov. Mark Warner, and sending a powerful message that President Bush's political standing has fallen in this reliably Republican state.

description: The sign outside St. Ann and the Holy Trinity Church takes a prominent place between notices for Sunday services and hours of quiet meditation. A promise of silence is no small thing on Montague Street in Downtown Brooklyn, but this middle sign offers tranquillity of another order.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Holocaust Denier Faces A Court
description: Ernst Zndel, the internationally known Holocaust denier who was deported to his native Germany from Canada in March, was put on trial in Mannheim. Mr. Zndel, 66, is accused of decades of anti-Semitic activities, including repeated denying of the Holocaust, a crime in Germany. He faces up to five years in prison. A verdict is expected at the end of the month. Victor Homola (NYT)

Bloomberg over the future of the World Trade Center site lie sharp disagreements -- over the Freedom Tower, the role of the developer Larry A. description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif., Nov. 8 - The Mets' pursuit of another bat for their modest lineup has taken them to familiar territory -- to a native of the Dominican Republic who has said he would not mind playing in New York again.

title: National Briefing | West: California: Santa Cruz Approves Medical Marijuana Ordinance
description: The Santa Cruz City Council gave final approval to an ordinance that would establish a city-run medical marijuana program. The measure, written with guidance from the American Civil Liberties Union, includes a clause that delays the start of the program until the federal courts rule on it. Sponsors of the ordinance said it would serve as a test for what city officials believe to be states' constitutional right to opt out of joining the federal government's recent efforts to close medical marijuana dispensaries. Mayor Mike Rotkin said, "We want to help medical marijuana patients obtain their medicine while also protecting them from the undesirable consequences of an unregulated black market." Carolyn Marshall (NYT)

Metro Briefing | New York: Sanitation Workers Approve Contract
description: City sanitation workers have overwhelmingly approved a new contract, with more than 98 percent of the ballots cast in favor of the agreement, union officials announced yesterday. "I am delighted that my membership approved this new contract so overwhelmingly," Harry Nespoli, left, the union president, said in a statement. Union officials said that members would receive graduated raises totaling 17.5 percent over the contract, which runs through March 2007. In exchange, the city has obtained productivity increases, including the operation of some garbage trucks by only one worker. Union officials said that two-thirds of the union's 6,200 members voted.

description: Rafael Gonzalez re-enacts the Crucifixion of Jesus in passion plays. He wrote a description of the experience in Spanish. Its translation: My experience personifying the King of Kings. It was and is impressive to reach and follow Calvary and live it. It is something divine, and I assure you that you will get closer to the Savior.

title: The Revolt of Ennui
description: A FRIEND called me a night ago from Paris. Paris? Not quite. My friend is of Indian origin and comes from a rundown "cit" in a suburb called Choisy-le-Roi, a housing project plopped down in an 18th-century royal park. The park retains a Louis XV elegance and grace. But as you walk by the project's windows, my friend says, on a good day only a trash bag will land on your head; on a bad day, it could be a washing machine.

title: Telekom plans huge spending for 2006
Down and In in Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES - In a downtown not known for its foot traffic, Santee Alley -- some 300 stores stretching over two blocks in the garment district -- is crowded even on weekdays, largely with Hispanic shoppers in search of flea-market-style bargains. Stacks of shoes, socks, underwear and jewelry spill out of the narrow stores.

title: Baby Drowned as Mother Listened to CD's, Prosecutor Says
description: A 16-month-old Brooklyn boy drowned in a filthy tub in a bathroom with no working light on Sunday while his mother spent 40 minutes in the next room playing CD's, prosecutors said yesterday as the city's Administration for Children's Services said it was starting its own full investigation of its handling of the troubled family.

Closing Grokster
description: The news on Monday of the shutdown of Grokster - the developer of software that lets individuals share files between their computers over the Internet - had an air of finality. Certainly its Web site read like an epitaph. But it was far from a conclusive moment in the illegal-downloading wars, the long struggle between the technical and social complexity of the Internet and the need to protect intellectual property. In fact, Grokster has largely been superseded by more recent file-sharing systems.

title: Bulgarian Nurses Face Death Penalty in Libya
description: The case has been running for years. Five Bulgarian nurses and a doctor stand accused of infecting Libyan children with AIDS in a children's hospital. They have already been sentenced to death. But will diplomacy -- and the Shariah -- be enough to save them?

Kaufman, Dean Emeritus of the College. We will always remember her decades of graciousness and devotion to our institution. We send our condolences to the entire Kaufman family. Michael C. Alfano, Dean New York University College of Dentistry

Her success over Tony Castro, the Democrat, ensured that the top posts in the county would remain split between the two parties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISBERG, FRED
description: WEISBERG--Fred. In his 66th year. Beloved husband of Janice. Devoted father of Lisa and Dale Rafferty, Julie and Cantor Cary Schwartz and Mindy Weisberg. Loving grandfather of Gabi, Luke, Ayla and Erica. Dear brother of Joan Dickson. Service 12 noon today at "Schwartz Brothers - Jeffer Memorial Chapels" Queens Blvd at 76 Road, Forest Hills, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Leukemia - Lymphoma Society, 475 Park Ave So, NYC, NY 10016 would be appreciated. Donating of blood and platelets in Fred's memory would be a fitting tribute. $(6$)WEISBERG--Fred. The world has lost a great man. My dear friend, Fred Weisberg, passed away on Monday. Freddy was the kind of guy who offered you unconditional support mentally, emotionally and intellectually everyday. He was the most reliable person in my life. Day or night, good times or bad, Freddy was always there for me. He was a fun-hearted person who never showed anyone that he had concerns of his own. He was bubbly and always had a smile on his face. He offered me the most sage advice. His optimism and love of life which helped get him through trying times rubbed off on me too. Fred always knew how to get me through a difficult time. He was truly one-of-a-kind. His friendship will be missed beyond words. His spirit and my love for him will be with me always. You should know, Fred, that there are so many people who will support your family as you supported your friends for so many years. Thank you, Fred. My heart goes out to Janice, Joanie, Lisa, Mindy, Julie and their families. Arthur Pergament $(6$)WEISBERG--Fred. All of us at Weisberg, Mole, Krantz & Goldfarb wish to express our deepest sympathies to the Weisberg family on the passing of our dear friend, Fred Weisberg. Throughout the years, Fred's friendships and relationships provided the bedrock that this firm has used as its foundation. Fred's compassion, guidance and wisdom were a beacon for all of us that were fortunate to have been touched by his life. His character and dignity earned him respect and loyalty on a level not often attained in life. His devotion to his family and friends was uncompromised and the love he displayed and shared was returned to him many times over by all of us who had the privilege of his friendship and companionship over the years. We perceive Fred's life to be summed up in one simple word--Love; Love for the Deal, Love for Life, Love for Friends and most importantly, Love for Family. He will be deeply missed and forever remembered. $(6$)WEISBERG--Fred. The Employees of Pergament Advisors are deeply saddened by the passing of our good friend and company mentor, Fred Weisberg. Fred was with us from the beginning to provide us with his sound advice, to guide us through our ups and downs, and set us on the path to success. Fred had a wonderful sense of humor and an infectious laugh. For those of us who knew him well, Fred knew how to make good come from any adverse situation: first, with good humor and then with exceptional business advice. We will miss him tremendously, but will carry on with all the valuable lessons about life and business that we learned from him. Arthur and the Pergs Team $(6$)WEISBERG--Fred. My deepest sympathies to Janice, Lisa, Julie, Mindy and the entire Weisberg family on the passing of Fred Weisberg. Fred's courage and wisdom was an inspiration and I will deeply miss his sense of humor and calming presence. My deepest regret is not having met Fred until somewhat late in life. I always admired his passion for living and the love he had for his family and friends. He enriched the lives of all those he touched and I'm forever grateful for the small portion of his life he graciously shared with me. Freddy, rest well and peaceful. Love, your Partner and Friend, Rich Mole $(6$)WEISBERG--Fred. My cherished friend of 30 years. Thank you for sharing all your guidance, wisdom, and patience. You defined friendship and trust. I always knew that I could count on you whenever I needed your help. Your love for your family was exemplary. Your constant optimism was refreshing. You were unselfish and giving in every way. I will miss your advice and friendship. My Deepest sympathies to Janice, Lisa, Julie and Mindy. Bruce Pergament $(6$)WEISBERG--Fred. Fred, thank you for being our friend. How we loved you. The wonderful advice you always gave. You had a genuine understanding of family values. We will miss your smile and laughter. Our hearts goes out to Janice, the girls and all of the immediate family. Lois and Bob Pergament and Family $(6$)WEISBERG--Fred. We will never forget your wisdom and kindness. Your strength and positive attitude were always inspiring. We have lost a really special friend! Our best to Janice and the entire Weisberg family. Love, Lori and Howard Dorman Debra and Andrew Levine $(6$)WEISBERG--Fred C. Treasured friend, colleague, and mentor. We will forever miss you. Heartfelt condolences to his wife Janice, daughters Julie, Lisa, Mindy, sister Joan and families. Marlene and Eric Woldenberg $(6$)WEISBERG--Fred. Our beloved friend, in our hearts forever. You were the best of the best. Love, the Welz & Bader Families

title: Of Rapes and Rubble
description: Arifa from Karachi writes: Your entire column on Mukhtar Mai did not mention that about 50,000 people in Pakistan are at risk for death as they brave the cold without shelter or as they filter into cities with amputated limbs and shattered lives. Many amputates will turn to begging because they will be unable to rebuild their lives. Rubble still lies in Muzaffarabad. The corpses remain buried under the rubble. No one knows what to do with the rubble. Yet your column focuses entirely on Mukhtar Mai. You seem be like Nero who fiddled while Rome burned. You mentioned Times readers donated 130,000 dollars to Mukhtar Mai. There are many trusted relief organizations on the ground who are doing tremendous work such as Sungi or Omar Asghar Khan Foundation. Please write about the victims of the Earthquake. They need help or more will be die. But then, the U.S. only cares about its own people.

description: What's the difference between Trey Anastasio's latest band, 70 Volt Parade, which performed on Tuesday night at Roseland, and Phish, the band he led for two decades and disbanded last year? In its lineup, his new band adds two backup singers and a fifth musician on guitar and keyboards. And in its music, it sets aside the layers of convolution and whimsy that were essential to Phish. But it's still jamming.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WEINSIER, JOAN TUBY

title: Beluga Caviar? Only Your Hairdresser Knows
description: BELUGA caviar is expected to soon all but disappear in the United States, now that the Fish and Wildlife Service has suspended imports in an attempt to help the endangered beluga sturgeon. In London, meanwhile, the delicacy is being applied not only to blinis but to hair. In a procedure that pushes the bounds of extravagance in hair care, Hari Salem, a salon owner in Knightsbridge, is moisturizing his customers' locks with oil from beluga sturgeon eggs.

World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Deutsche Telekom Posts Profit
description: Deutsche Telekom, Europe's largest telephone company, reported a third-quarter profit of 2.42 billion euros ($2.85 billion) as wireless customers increased in the United States. The stock had its biggest drop in six months after the company said additional spending would hurt earnings next year. The chief executive, Kai-Uwe Ricke, said the company would spend 1.2 billion more euros next year on new products and marketing to attract customers. Last week, he announced that 32,000 jobs would be cut. The net income included 952 million euros in gains from asset sales. A year earlier, the company had a net loss of 1.36 billion euros. Sales rose 4.8 percent, to 15 billion euros.

title: Mayor Crossed Ethnic Barriers for Big Victory
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg forged his historic re-election victory on Tuesday by drawing roughly half of New York's black voters and about 3 in 10 Latinos to the Republican line, even though he faced a Hispanic challenger who sought to capitalize on ethnic pride, an analysis of voting returns shows.

title: The Surviving Twin, Rearranging the Furniture
description: THOUGH it was the celebrity decorator Jed Johnson who died in the explosion of T.W.A. Flight 800 in 1996, it is his twin brother, Jay, who is in a sense the man who fell to earth.

title: When Children Act Out in Public Places
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing: Asia, Americas, Europe
description: ASIA

title: House of Commons Rebuffs Blair on Antiterror Provision
description: LONDON, Nov. 9 - The House of Commons rejected a crucial provision of the government's antiterrorism bill on Wednesday by a vote of 322 to 291, handing the once-invincible Prime Minister Tony Blair his first Commons defeat since he came to power eight years ago.

title: For Bloomberg, Victory Lap Leads Right Back to Work
description: Fresh off his landslide victory, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday fended off speculation that he would next run for governor or even president. And rather than basking in his victory on Tuesday night, he went right back to work at City Hall.

title: A Shift Among L.I. Voters
description: A string of Democratic victories across Long Island show it is no longer a Republican stronghold. Page B1.

title: An Army Ready to Snap
description: Have you heard what's been happening to the military?

title: Lobbyist Sought $9 Million to Set Bush Meeting
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 - The lobbyist Jack Abramoff asked for $9 million in 2003 from the president of a West African nation to arrange a meeting with President Bush and directed his fees to a Maryland company now under federal scrutiny, according to newly disclosed documents.

title: Bad Habits Linger at the Polls in Egypt
description: CAIRO, Nov. 9 - At many of Egypt's polling places, the government appeared to keep its promises as voters cast their ballots for members of Parliament on Wednesday: ballot boxes were transparent so there was no obvious stuffing, official monitors worked to make sure only registered people voted and the security services did not appear to stop people from casting ballots for or campaigning for opposition candidates.

title: New Jersey Man Pleads Guilty in Shining of Laser at Small Jet
description: NEWARK, Nov. 9 - A New Jersey man who ran afoul of the antiterrorism USA Patriot Act last year when he shined a laser pen at a private plane pleaded guilty on Wednesday to willfully interfering with a craft involved in mass transportation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MELAMED, LOUIS (LOU)
description: MELAMED--Louis (Lou), 91. on November 8, 2005 in New York. TV/radio producer, writer and director. Husband of Syma for 60 years. Father of Fred and Jill and father-inlaw of Leslee. Grandfather of Lee and Alec. Also survived by his brother David Jack and nieces and nephews. Services Friday 1:30 PM at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91 Street & Amsterdam Ave.

title: France to deport foreigners in riots
Paid Notice: Deaths   STERN, MARION HAAS
description: STERN--Marion Haas. Died peacefully at home on November 7, 2005 at age 102. She was greatly loved by and dedicated to her family and friends. She was the adored daughter of the late Addie and Benjamin Haas, the beloved wife of the late David I. Stern, the cherished sister of the late Richard Haas and the devoted mother of Richard B.H. Stern and Allan D.R. Stern and their wives Susan and Beth. She was deeply loved by her five grandchildren Douglas Stern, Gary Stern, Michael Stern, Susan Calenda and Trish Frohman and by her 11 great-grandchildren. She was a volunteer at the Lighthouse For The Blind and City Harvest. A family service in celebration of her life was held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home in NYC on November 9. Contributions may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Japan Broadening Its Wireless Phone Market
description: TOKYO, Nov. 9 - New competition is coming to Japan's mobile phone market, with the promise of cheaper services for its long-suffering callers. On Wednesday, the Japanese communications ministry said it would grant unused bandwidth to three new entrants -- Softbank, eAccess and a start-up, IP Mobile -- allowing them to offer wireless services as early as next year.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,049 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: N.Y.U. Teaching Assistants Strike
description: After a last-ditch effort by a group of professors on Tuesday failed to persuade officials at New York University to reopen labor negotiations with the union representing graduate teaching assistants, the union went on strike yesterday. Disruptions appeared to be modest. Some professors moved classes to churches and union halls, and two held classes in the empty fountain in Washington Square Park. Some discussion sections of large lecture classes, which are typically run by teaching assistants, were canceled, and some students apparently boycotted classes in sympathy with the graduate assistants. It was unclear how many teaching assistants failed to appear for their assignments. Alan Finder (NYT)

title: Roundup: Playoff dispute settled by FIFA
Got 2 Extra Hours for Your E-Mail?
description: Correction Appended

title: Curfew doesn't stop party
Blair on offensive with terror bill defeat
Arts, Briefly; Medal of Arts Winners
description: Robert Duvall, Wynton Marsalis, Dolly Parton, below, and Louis Auchincloss are among nine artists and writers who will receive the 2005 National Medal of Arts, President Bush announced. He also named 11 scholars and historians who will be honored with the National Humanities Medal, including Col. Matthew Bogdanos of the Marine Corps reserves, who has investigated the loss of antiquities in Iraq. The president plans to present the awards at an Oval Office ceremony this morning, with a formal dinner this evening. Others receiving the humanities award include the etiquette columnist Judith Martin; the art historians and appraisers Leigh and Leslie Keno, who appear on the PBS program "Antiques Roadshow"; and the political scientist Walter Berns, emeritus professor at Georgetown University. In addition to the individual recipients, the arts award will go to the 200-year-old Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, the oldest art academy and museum in the country, and the humanities medal will be given to the editorial team working to preserve the papers of George Washington at the University of Virginia. JOHN FILES

title: When Children Act Out in Public Places (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Disgraceful Signal at Amtrak
description: The sudden firing by the Amtrak board of David Gunn, the best president in years of the nation's only passenger railroad, was a body blow to anybody who cares about long-range passenger trains.

title: U.S. Reports Iraqi Civilian Casualties in Anti-Insurgent Sweep
description: HUSAYBA, Iraq, Nov. 9 - The American military command revealed Wednesday that civilians had been killed and wounded in heavy fighting here in the past few days, the first such acknowledgment of civilian casualties since the anti-insurgent sweep of this town in western Iraq began last Saturday.

title: Egypt's Christian-Muslim divide
On The Street: Then
description: IN the mid-1980's, New York style-setters traveled along divergent paths. The first was effusively romantic, an unlikely fusion of somber colors and crazily frivolous shapes. Turbans, knit stoles and multitiered skirts alluded, poetically, to the mid-19th-century exoticism being championed at the time by designers like Jean Paul Gaultier and Romeo Gigli. Mr. Gigli's cardigan wrap, at left, is worn over a taffeta skirt striped, Turkish style, at the hem.

title: Turnaround Leads Mayor to a Surprising Victory
description: DETROIT, Nov. 9 - Kwame M. Kilpatrick, the city's first-term mayor who has been dogged by scandal and budget deficits, pulled out a surprise re-election victory on Tuesday over the opponent he had trailed markedly in the primary.

title: Works of Crumb and Tower, With Stylized Mime, as Well
description: New-music groups periodically undertake theatrical collaborations, both as a way of reaching new listeners and to shake things up for the listeners they have. The Da Capo Chamber Players joined forces with the Yass Hakoshima Movement Theater -- which is to say with Mr. Hakoshima, a choreographer, dancer and mime -- on Tuesday evening for a program of George Crumb and Joan Tower works at Symphony Space.

title: On the Road, the One Called Cross Bay Boulevard
description: THE retirees who are regulars at Glen Patrick's Pub on Cross Bay Boulevard in Ozone Park are proud of two things. One, that Jack Kerouac used to drink there. And two, that they've never read a word of his fancy books. Or, for that matter, "Beat Generation," his newly published play, which was exhumed in a star-studded reading last month, 36 years after his death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREUMAN, HENRY, MD.
description: FREUMAN--Henry, MD. Adored, cherished and beloved husband of Carol, father of David and Daniel, brother of Reuven and grandfather of Jason. Strong, elegant and a man of immeasurable grace, Henry brought enormous love to his family, compassion to his patients, intellectual rigor to his academic interests, and a brave heart to all of his challenges in life. His life is his inspired legacy to us. Funeral services Friday, November 11, 9:30 am at "The Riverside" 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: The Races in New York City
description: KEY: +Winner * Incumbent **Winner and change in party

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Ground Zero Security Plan
description: Science Applications International Corporation of San Diego has been chosen to develop a security plan for the World Trade Center redevelopment project, Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday. James Kallstrom, a senior adviser to the governor, said the company would provide experts in counterterrorism, law enforcement, intelligence, military affairs, corporate security, emergency services, transportation, engineering and site development.

title: Now it's anywhere in the world, nonstop
A Tax Resister Is Convicted on 5 Counts
description: Tessa David, the wife of a leading promoter of a contention that most Americans are tricked into paying income taxes, was convicted yesterday by a federal jury in Philadelphia on five counts of willful failure to file tax returns, her lawyers said.

title: Rangers Save Best for Last in Sudden Victory
description: SUNRISE, Fla., Nov. 9 - The Rangers began a five-game trip in dramatic fashion against a Florida Panthers team that was playing its first home game in 19 days.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: MiniComputers For The Police
description: To get information to New York police officers in the streets more quickly, a batch of hand-held computers, like the one at left, have been distributed to some police commands around the city, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday. The new devices, specially made for the New York Police Department by Panasonic, can instantly check license plates and driver's license records and run warrant checks, mine departmental databases for information on pistol licenses and domestic violence cases and retrieve photographs of bank robbers that appear on wanted posters, among other things.

title: Times Editor's Oct. 21 Letter to Newsroom on Miller
description: Following is a memorandum from Bill Keller, the executive editor of The Times, sent to his staff on October 21.

title: Times Reporter Agrees to Leave the Paper
description: The New York Times and Judith Miller, a veteran reporter for the paper, reached an agreement yesterday that ended her 28-year career at the newspaper and capped more than two weeks of negotiations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUKEHART, SYBIL KANE WILLIAMS
description: DUKEHART--Sybil Kane Williams. Died Tuesday at her home in Maryland. She was 87. Born Sybil Kane Williams, she attended the Chapin School and St. Timothy's School, in Catonsville, MD. Later, she sang in the Junior League Chorus and Octet, studied at the Diller Quaile School of Music and studied piano with Carl Ulrich Schnabel. After her marriage to Dr. James Patton Miller, in 1942, she moved to Maryland. Dr. Miller died in 1959. In 1965, she married Edward Comegys Dukehart, a realtor and travel agent. Mr. Dukehart died in 1989. Mrs. Dukehart is survived by four daughters: Sybil M. Hebb, Susan M. Knott, Victoria B. Miller, all of Baltimore; two step-children: Edward C. Dukehart, of Palm Beach, and Frances K. Dukehart, of Denver; 11 grandchildren and 14 great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, November 12, 2005, at St. James Episcopal Church, in Monkton, MD. Memorial donations to United States Driving for the Disabled or to Hurricane Disaster Relief.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Kosovo: Concern Over Reports Of Armed Groups
description: The police said they were investigating reports of groups of armed men in the south of this province of Serbia, now under United Nations supervision. A spokesman for the United Nations mission said drivers near the southern town of Kacanik had seen groups of armed men with weapons setting up checkpoints. Last month, there were reports that armed men in the west were blocking traffic and handing out leaflets calling for Kosovo's independence. The sightings come with the approach of United Nations-sponsored talks on whether Kosovo should gain independence or stay a part of Serbia. Nicholas Wood (NYT)

title: Senators Grill Oil Executives on Prices and Profits
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 - Five of the country's top oil executives walked into a large Congressional hearing room on Wednesday -- one filled with nearly a third of all senators and with hundreds of other people, a dozen of them wearing T-shirts reading "Expose Exxon."

title: When Experts Need Experts
description: MINNEAPOLIS - BETWEEN them, Robert and Rosalie Kane, he a physician and she a social worker, have devoted 60 years to the study of aging, written scores of books and hundreds of journal articles about long-term care and are widely considered among the world's leading experts.

title: Chinese hotel terror alert was false alarm, U.S. says
In the Sort-of Ethnic Home
description: ANYONE who has furnished an apartment, read a shelter magazine or received a Pottery Barn catalog knows what a throw is.

title: Voting Over, the Post-Mortems Begin (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: It's My Money and I'll Run if I Want To
description: THE grand total: $100 a vote, give or take. That's what Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg spent on his re-election campaign, a sum that does not even count likely staff bonuses or his personal contributions to charities and organizations, only some of which, one can assume, he would have donated anyway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISBERG, FRED
description: WEISBERG--Fred. You were the brother I never had, you advised me like the father I lost and were always the friend that was there for me. But mostly it's the good times I remember, shooting craps, drinking Absolut, kayaking, sailing, despairing over the Jets and Giants, watching the sunsets in Bayville, playing pinball and of course drinking Absolut. And oh the great parties at the Oyster Bay House, hundreds of people that we sometimes found days later. Our "cultural" excursions, Mohegan Sun, Atlantic City, Atlantis, Vegas. We've lived a good life, sometimes fast, sometimes slow, but always talking, always discussing a deal and always with your smile and wonderful laugh, that's what I'll miss the most. Goodbye, good buddy, I love you man! Bill Rella

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: State Rejects Contractor Accused Of Mob Ties
description: State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi rejected a $46 million construction contract recommended by the Thruway Authority, saying it should not be awarded to a Connecticut company involved in a continuing federal corruption investigation. Mr. Hevesi said the company, Worth Construction of Bethel, Conn., had misled the Thruway Authority during its review process and had numerous red flags. Worth did not return calls for comment.

title: Taking TiVo Shows on the Road
description: Taking TiVo Shows On the Road

title: Democrats Press Court Designee Over Mutual Fund Case
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 - Laying the groundwork for a possible strategy of attacking Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr., Senate Democrats are ratcheting up their questions about the judge's failure to disqualify himself from a case involving Vanguard, the mutual fund company that managed his investments.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in the "Arts, Briefly" column on Oct. 29 about work by the author Stephen King on a Marvel comic book misstated his role. According to a Marvel publicist, Mr. King and Robin Furth, an author, have provided the initial plot and "will provide creative direction and supervision." Mr. King is not writing the comic.

title: Correction
description: An article last Thursday about cosmetics for non-Caucasian women misstated the number of shades in Avon's Personal Match makeup line before the colors were reformulated. There were six colors for darker skin tones, not two.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Latest From Ex-Envoy, 'Vendetta'
description: In the latest installment of his memoirs, Sir Christopher Meyer, the former British ambassador to Washington, accused the government of Prime Minister Tony Blair of conducting a petty "vendetta" against him. At one point, he said, Mr. Blair's aides tried to get him disinvited from a dinner at the White House for the prime minister, a development that left him feeling as if he had been punched "in the solar plexus," Sir Christopher writes. "By the time I retired," he continues, "I had reached the unhappy conclusion that what I had achieved as ambassador had been as much in spite of Downing Street as because of it." Excerpts from Sir Christopher's book, "D.C. Confidential," are being published in several British newspapers this week. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Pop Charts: Hits Disc Is Tops Again
description: "Now That's What I Call Music!," a series of pop compilation albums released jointly by four major record companies, has long been a durable hit, and its 20th volume, with songs by Coldplay, Missy Elliott, Pussycat Dolls, Destiny's Child, Fall Out Boy and 15 others, is no exception. It reached No. 1 on the Billboard chart on 378,000 sales in its first week of release, according to Nielsen SoundScan, putting the series atop the chart for the eighth time. Santana's "All That I Am" (Arista), with guest appearances by Steven Tyler, Big Boi, Mary J. Blige and others, opened at No. 2, selling 142,000 copies. Nickelback's "All The Right Reasons" (Roadrunner) is at No. 3, the Black Eyed Peas' "Monkey Business" (A&M/Interscope) remains high at No. 4, and last week's top seller, Destiny's Child's "No. 1's" (Columbia), fell to No. 5. Farther down, at No. 13, John Fogerty reached his highest chart position in 20 years with "The Long Road Home," a career retrospective that is also a reunion with his long-estranged former record label, Fantasy. BEN SISARIO

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Court Hears Challenge To Law On Downing Hijacked Planes
description: The Constitutional Court, Germany's highest court, began hearing a challenge to a law that authorizes the defense minister to order the shooting down of a civilian airliner if it is believed it was hijacked for a 9/11-style terror attack. Several individuals, including a pilot, argue that the government has no right to kill passengers in order to save more lives. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Frank's Outburst Leads to a Fine
description: Nets Coach Lawrence Frank was fined $25,000 by the National Basketball Association yesterday for his actions after the Nets' 90-89 loss in Miami on Monday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROTHMAN, JERRY
description: ROTHMAN--Jerry. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of our esteemed member and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Yaakov Y. Kermaier, Rabbi Ira Leon Rennert, Chairman J. Ezra Merkin, President

title: 'Responsible Spam'
description: Two words: funny essay.

title: After Ferrer, Beaten Party Looks to 2009
description: For New York Democrats, the 2009 race for mayor was all but under way yesterday, as they reckoned with the errors and shortcomings that helped fuel the historic Republican victory of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEINSTEIN, FRANCES
description: WEINSTEIN--Frances. November 9, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Al Weinstein, devoted mother of Robert, loving sister of Annette and Ruth. Funeral service on Sunday, November 13, 3:30 PM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St.

title: Beland Honderich, Publisher Who Transformed Toronto Star, Dies at 86
description: Beland H. Honderich, the publisher and editor who transformed The Toronto Star from a publication focused on crime and sensationalism into an influential newspaper with Canada's largest circulation, died on Tuesday in Vancouver, British Columbia. He was 86.

title: Sanofi to provide France with bird flu vaccine
Jordan pays the price of moderation
Iran Looking, Once Again, for Nominee for Oil Post
description: TEHRAN, Nov. 9 - President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad's candidate for oil minister, facing increasing criticism over his inexperience, withdrew his candidacy for the job on Wednesday as the president faced a tough parliamentary session to seek approval for his latest round of cabinet nominees.

title: Jets' Season of Hope Moves Into Renewal
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 9 - And then there were three.

title: Curves and Frills For the Hot and Cold
description: A KITCHEN faucet used to be very straightforward: you turned it on and water came out. Now some come with bells and whistles attached -- as well as the kitchen sink. New, sleekly designed faucets offer features like light that shines through the water and hands-free mechanisms.

title: A Baritone Crosses a Teutonic Gender Gap
description: It will be unfortunate if the remarkable song recital by the elegant German baritone Matthias Goerne at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night is remembered mostly for the novelty element of his program. After singing songs by Mahler and Berg, Mr. Goerne ended with Wagner's "Wesendonck Lieder," five songs built around poems by Mathilde Wesendonck, a silk merchant's wife with whom Wagner had a short-lived but impassioned affair.

title: Briefs: Laser pen defendant strikes plea agreement
How to Treat Tigers, Elephants and Owls (Besides Carefully)
description: If you enjoy graphic close-ups of fish or bird surgery, "New Breed Vets With Steve Irwin" is the series for you. Mr. Irwin, best known as the host of "The Crocodile Hunter," lives up to the late-night-comedy parodies of his style, expressing perpetual amazement, predicting excitement that never develops and reacting to just about everything with straight-faced gravity.

title: Fund bid wins most of Refco
Paid Notice: Deaths   BILLIG, CLARA
description: BILLIG--Clara. Of Manhattan. Loving wife, mother, sister, grandmother and great grandmother.

title: Ephemeral Art, Eternal Maintenance
description: EVEN as the real estate market cools, the contemporary art market is at fever pitch, as evidenced by the record-breaking total of $157.4 million brought in by Christie's sale of post-war and contemporary works on Tuesday. But as collectors bid extravagantly for works created in the last two decades, some may be failing to consider the perils of living with such pieces.

title: County Chief Sets Sights on School Tax
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Nov. 9 - Barely pausing to celebrate his resounding re-election as Nassau county executive, Thomas R. Suozzi unveiled his next crusade -- tackling school taxes -- on Wednesday morning, while being coy about his plans to run for governor next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLACK, RICHARD (DICK)
description: BLACK--Richard (Dick). Beloved husband of Bernice (Bunny). Devoted father of Julie (Robert Shepard), Elise (Ed Kerwin), Amy (Scott Spiewak). Loving grandpa of Emily and Rene. Service 12 noon Friday at Temple Beth El, 221 Schraalenburgh Rd., Closter, NJ 201-768-5112.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAUFMAN, RUTH L.
description: KAUFMAN--Ruth L. Beloved wife of Edward G. Kaufman. Mother of Edwina Friedman, Diane Weiss and Matthew P. Kaufman. Grandmother of Edward Friedman, Megan Weiss and Scott Weiss.

title: Yankees Have Met the Enemy, and It Is Tellem
description: FROM the man who induced the Yankees to erase any mention of steroids from Jason Giambi's contract comes another contractual sleight of hand. Under a clause negotiated by Arn Tellem, the Yankees have to sign Hideki Matsui by Tuesday or release him.

title: Moving from pineapples to plush
Paid Notice: Memorials   BONHAM, WILLIAM R.
description: BONHAM -- William R. 1921-1987. You are forever my true love. Mo

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLITTI, INES
description: COLITTI--Ines, 96. On November 9, 2005. Longtime resident of Millburn, NJ and partner in Millburn family fashion boutique, Eleganza/ Colitti. Survived by her three children, Vera Colitti, Millburn; Carlo Colitti, Brick, New Jersey; and Aldo Colitti, NYC; three grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. For further information visit bradleyfuneralhomes.com.

title: Documenting the Architecture Of American Pleasure Domes
description: Hotel developers in the 1920's hired Schultze & Weaver, a Manhattan architecture firm, to design Art Deco skyscrapers with opulent Georgian, Moorish or Renaissance interiors. From Sunday through May 28, an exhibition at the Wolfsonian-Florida International University Museum in Miami, "In Pursuit of Pleasure: Schultze & Weaver and the American Hotel," documents the partnership, best known for the Waldorf-Astoria and the Pierre (right, in a 1928 drawing) in New York and the Breakers in Palm Beach (below, its Venetian-style lounge). Ornate furnishings will be displayed, including nickel-bronze filigree gates from the Waldorf, along with sketches, photos, brochures and menus. 1001 Washington Ave., Miami; wolfsonian.org.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Saturday about Terence Riley, who is stepping down as chief curator of architecture and design at the Museum of Modern Art, referred incorrectly to an architect whose work he has championed. The architect, Kazuyo Sejima, is a woman.

title: Minority youth see odds stacked against them
Setback in Court for BlackBerry Maker
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 9 - A federal judge in Virginia said Wednesday that it was "highly unlikely" he would delay a patent case against the maker of the BlackBerry wireless e-mail device that could result in a ban on its use in the United States.

title: Manhattan and Brooklyn
description: TWO well-established retailers are opening stores in Midtown, providing nearby workers with new places to indulge in lunch-hour shopping. Abercrombie & Fitch, the clothing chain for teenagers, opened a four-level store (its largest in the world, below) at 720 Fifth Avenue, at 56th Street, (212) 306-0936. (Last week, Ruehl, Abercrombie's line for people in their 20's and 30's, opened its first all-accessories store at 370 Bleecker Street, (212) 924-8506.) And Charles Tyrwhitt, the English clothier known for its dress shirts, is opening Monday at 745 Seventh Avenue, at 50th Street, (212) 764-4697.

title: Halliburton violated pension laws
Spanish Style in Bold Candy Stripes
description: Agatha Ruiz de la Prada, a flamboyant Spanish designer of clothing and home furnishings, will open her first American store in SoHo on Nov. 18. The store, which bears her name, was designed by Jordi Castel and Jordi Veciana, architects in Barcelona. It will sell her riotously colored wares, including clothing, furniture, kitchenware, rugs, lamps and pet and bath accessories, all adorned with her signature patterns of hearts, flowers and stripes. A heart-shape acrylic accent rug, left, is $70, table lamps with flexible stems and striped shades are $68 to $190 and hot pink and orange cotton bedding is $20 for two pillowcases to $120 for a king-size duvet cover; 135 Wooster Street (Prince Street); (347) 628-9335.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about distortions in the advertising campaigns of the major candidates for governor of New Jersey gave an erroneous figure in some copies for the property tax increase in West Windsor during the years when the Republican, Douglas R. Forrester, was a mayor and council member. (The error also appeared in two articles on Sept. 29 analyzing specific ads.) Taxes rose 200 percent; they did not double.(Go to Article )

title: Voting Over, the Post-Mortems Begin
description: To the Editor:

title: A $23.8 million record
Peres Loses Israeli Labor Party Post, Endangering Sharon Coalition
description: JERUSALEM, Thursday, Nov. 10 - A trade union leader won a surprise victory over Shimon Peres in an election for leader of the Labor Party, party officials announced early on Thursday. The development greatly increases the possibility that Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's coalition government could collapse.

title: The Mets' Cohen Moves to a Visible Medium
description: After listening to him on the radio for 17 years, Mets fans will finally get to see Gary Cohen, now that he will be the team's television play-by-play voice on SportsNet New York, which starts operations in the spring.

title: And Now, the Scrambling for the Speaker's Chair
description: The conclusion of the mayoral race has set the stage for a contest over the next most powerful job in city government, the speaker of the City Council, a role that takes on even more importance now as the Bloomberg administration claims an electoral mandate.

title: Roche Plans Big Increase in Tamiflu Production
description: BASEL, Switzerland, Nov. 9 - In a factory here on the banks of the Rhine, three floors of linked vats and pipes churn out a compound that until recently drew only scant attention. Across the street, workers in protective suits dry that compound to make a white powder, to be packaged and sold as Tamiflu.

title: King to Sell Abuse-Resistant Form of OxyContin
description: King Pharmaceuticals has obtained the rights to an abuse-resistant version of the widely used painkiller OxyContin from Pain Therapeutics, a biotechnology company, the two companies plan to announce today.

title: When Children Act Out in Public Places
description: To the Editor:

title: Gala, Yes, but Two Hours of Formidable Music: Beethoven and Wagner
description: Gala concerts are typically festive affairs offering fancy dinners for select ticket buyers and lighter musical fare for the main portion of the evening. Lincoln CenterAs Fall Gala concert on Wednesday night at Avery Fisher Hall was another story.

title: Ex-Police Chief Wins San Diego Mayor's Race
description: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 9 - Jerry Sanders, the former police chief, won election as mayor on Tuesday, and followed up by vowing on Wednesday to restore public trust in a city government that has been reeling from a fiscal crisis and corruption.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: One Tempting Remedy for the Alternative Minimum Tax Has Flaws of Its Own
description: THE recommendations of President Bush's advisory panel on federal tax reform, announced last week, were greeted by Congress and the administration with all the enthusiasm of a recommendation for root canal surgery. Although the panel proposed two sensible plans to reduce distortions in the tax code and improve fairness, its proposal to cut the popular mortgage interest deduction, included in both plans, almost assures that the plans will not reach Congress as written.

title: Movements to the Music of Time, Baez and Dylan
description: First seen in 2002, Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker's "Once" opened a six-night run at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday. It was a curious event, sicklied o'er with the pale cast of pretension.

title: 3 Hotels Bombed in Jordan; At Least 57 Die
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Thursday, Nov. 10 - Terrorist bombs ripped nearly simultaneously through three popular hotels here on Wednesday night, killing dozens and wounding more than 100.

title: Comments from readers on the unrest in France
Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a proposal by the Financial Accounting Standards Board to change pension accounting rules included an outdated reference to Joshua D. Rauh, who helped conduct a study of company pensions. He is at the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business; he left the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in July 2004.

title: K. R. Narayanan Dies at 85; 'Untouchable' India President
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 9 - Kocheril Raman Narayanan, India's first Dalit, or "untouchable," president, died in a military hospital here on Wednesday evening, a Defense Ministry spokesman said. He was 85, according to the Press Trust of India, and he had been suffering from pneumonia and kidney failure.

title: Gala, Yes, but Two Hours of Formidable Music: Beethoven and Wagner

title: INSIDE
description: House Drops a Plan For Drilling in Alaska House Republican leaders, in an effort to overcome party opposition to a budget-cutting bill, dropped a plan to open the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska to oil drilling. In removing the drilling plan and a second provision on coastal exploration, the leadership enhanced prospects for winning approval of more than $50 billion in spending cuts demanded by House conservatives. The decision was likely to meet objections from the Senate.

Memorial service Friday, November 11, 4 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Contributions in his memory may be made to the North Shore Animal League, Port Washington, New York.

Interpublic Loss Narrows, but Tops Estimates
description: LOST accounts and higher costs led to another quarterly loss at the troubled Interpublic Group of Companies. The loss for the third quarter, which Interpublic reported yesterday, narrowed considerably compared with the period a year ago, but was still larger than Wall Street had expected.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Netherlands: Mittal Steel Profit Skids 64%
description: Mittal Steel, the world's largest steel maker, said third-quarter profit declined 64 percent because of a jump in costs and a worldwide drop in prices. Net income fell to $478 million, or 68 cents a share, while sales rose to $7.05 billion, from $6.29 billion. The cost of goods sold was 24 percent higher than a year ago, while prices were on average 1 percent lower. Raw material costs have surged this year as mining companies fail to keep pace with an expansion in global steel production, which exceeded a billion metric tons for the first time last year. Mittal, based in Rotterdam, expects steel shipments to improve in the United States and Europe in the fourth quarter, the company's billionaire owner, Lakshmi N. Mittal, above, said in a conference call.

title: Corrections

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EISENSTEIN, JOAN B.
description: EISENSTEIN--Joan B. Beloved wife of Howard Eisenstein, past President of 62nd Street East, Inc. Joan was a wonderful lady and a good neighbor and will be missed. Our condolences to Howard and his family-the Board of Directors, tenants, staff and Lawrence Properties.

title: Roberts Court Hears Its First Case in Federalism Debate
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 - The latest constitutional clash between the federal government and the states took place on Wednesday in a Supreme Court argument on whether prison inmates can sue states for damages under the federal law that bars discrimination against people with disabilities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLASSEROW, JEFFREY L.
description: GLASSEROW--Jeffrey L. Age 55 years of Franklin Township, NJ, died Saturday, November 5, 2005, as the result of an airplane accident in Pohatcong Township, NJ. Born in the Bronx, NY, April 9, 1950, he had formerly resided in Port Washington, NY, before moving to Franklin Township, Hunterdon County, NJ, fourteen years ago. An advertising consultant, he owned Glasserow Management Advisory Group. A graduate of Emerson University, Boston, MA, he was a member of the Friar's Club, New York City; the American Motorcycle Association; the AHRMA (American Historic Racing Motorcycle Association); the Experimental Aircraft Association; and the American Model Airplane Association. He owned a GMA motorcycle team which held several land speed records, as well as victories at Daytona and other major American and European events. Mr. Glasserow won an Emmy for audio for a Bluegrass Festival he televised. He was an avid gardener. He was formerly a religious teacher at Or Chadash Temple, Stanton, NJ. Surviving are his daughter, Coby Glasserow, of Franklin Township, NJ; his parents, Norman and Marion Glasserow, of Manhasset, NY; a sister, Laura Kardos, of Honolulu, HI; his former wife, Deb Dawson, of Frenchtown, NJ; and his fiancee, Pam Saletan, of Franklin Township, NJ. Memorial contributions may be made to the New York Times Fresh Air Fund, 633 Third Avenue, 14th Floor, New York, New York 10017. Please visit www.holcombefisher.com for further information, or to send condolences.

title: Like Climbing Into Their Nests
description: EMBRACING technology, most birders say, is the key to the sport. "There was no birding before the binocular," said Pete Dunne, the author of books on bird-watching. "There was simply ornithology." Homing in on a rare find is an indelible experience for most, if not all, of the 18.5 million Americans who watch birds away from home, according to a 2001 Fish and Wildlife Service survey, the most recent data available.

description: A monumental steel sculpture by the American artist David Smith became the most expensive work of contemporary art ever sold at auction last night when Larry Gagosian, the Manhattan dealer, fought off five aggressive bidders and paid $23.8 million at Sotheby's.

title: For Choicest Apartments, Many More Choices
description: WHEN developers opened new buildings for sale in New York a year ago, brokers jostled for appointments, buyers camped out before open houses and people made decisions to part with thousands of dollars in a matter of minutes. One sales agent famously sold five luxury condos from the back seat of her BMW in a day.

title: Recapturing Her Moments
description: EVER since John Galliano arrived at Dior in 1996, he has been looking for ways to transcend the earthbound limits of fashion. He has made clothes that look as if they are falling apart or stuck on with sweat, and he has staged his shows in some fairly lofty places like Versailles and the Paris Opera. But not until this past summer, when Mr. Galliano transferred the techniques of fashion illustration to dressmaking, using black beads on nude chiffon to impart the brisk lines of the artist, did you feel that he had finally conquered the problem of gravity.
