Brother to Anthony Jr., Carmine and Stephen. Funeral Mass Saturday, 9:30AM, St. Vincent de Paul RC Church, Stirling. Interment St. Vincent de Paul Cemetery. Visitation Friday, 2-4, 6-9PM at Valley Memorial Funeral Home, 1012 Valley Rd., Gillette. Donations: Michael F. Fornaro Family Educational Fund, C/O Richard Diegnan, Esq., 261 Springfield Ave., Berkeley Heights., NJ.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PLOTKIN, LAWRENCE
description: PLOTKIN--Lawrence. Died suddenly at his home on November 7, 2005. Born in 1921 and raised in NYC, he was educated at Townsend Harris High School and City College. He received his Ph.D. in psychology from Columbia University and was a Professor Emeritus at City College of the City University of NY. Larry was a veteran who served in the US Army during W.W. II. A longtime member of the Society for Ethical Culture, he served as President of the Society and was an honorary Trustee. For many years Larry worked closely with Dr. Kenneth B. Clark at the Metropolitan Applied Research Center on issues of racial justice. A born teacher, he was still teaching at the City College Center for Worker Education. Larry was known for his quick wit, his love of history, and his exuberant spirit. He is survived by his beloved wife, Amy Selwyn of Manhattan and East Hampton; three children from his marriage to the late Nancy Torres Plotkin: Lt. Col. (ret) John Plotkin of Atlanta, GA; Sarah Plotkin of San Francisco, CA; and Thomas Plotkin of West Hartford, CT; (his son, James Plotkin died in 1994); his stepson, Dr. Peter Selywn, his daughter-in-law, Dr. Nancy Reuben, and his four cherished grandchildren: Kyra Selwyn, Casey Selwyn, Harris Plotkin, and Katie Plotkin. A memorial service will be in January, 2006 at the Society for Ethical Culture.

title: New Orleans Crime Swept Away, With Most of the People
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 9 - On a single day last June in Pigeon Town and Hollygrove, impoverished neighborhoods of worn frame houses at the city's western edge, four men were killed, adding to the eight already slain there this year. Young men brazenly sold drugs from street corners in broad daylight. The gunfire was constant. Residents were fearful.

The article also misstated the name of the court in which the boys' mother, Tracina Vaughn, pleaded guilty to reckless endangerment after her older son was scalded. It was State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, not Brooklyn Superior Court.

World Business Briefing | Australia: Biggest Bank Posts 30% Rise in Earnings
description: National Australia Bank said that its profits were recovering as it bounces back from a trading scandal early last year, but it warned that competition in Australia's cooling housing market could pose a challenge to efforts to overhaul the bank, the nation's largest. The bank, which is based in Melbourne, reported that net profit in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 rose 30.1 percent, to 4.13 billion Australian dollars ($3.4 billion). The results included 1 billion Australian dollars of one-time profits from the sale of two banks in Ireland. Excluding exceptional items, net profit rose 11.1 percent, to 4.37 billion dollars. "The full-year results show the turnaround is on track, but we still have much work to do," said John Stewart, the chief executive. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Netherlands: Interest in Delivery Company
description: Shares of TNT, the delivery company, gained the most in almost seven years after the German investor Cornelius Geber said that he was interested in making a bid. Mr. Geber, a former transport executive, said in a telephone interview that he had approached TNT, which has a market value of 10.6 billion euros ($12.5 billion) and that discussions with partners are at "a very early stage." He declined to identify the potential partners. TNT, which employs 162,000 people and is based in Hoofddorp, operates the Dutch postal system and organizes storage and delivery of goods for companies like BMW.

title: Balancing Act
description: Cambridge, Mass. - SOME Democratic members of the Senate Judiciary Committee have argued that Judge Samuel A. Alito's nomination to succeed Justice Sandra Day O'Connor merits more thorough scrutiny, if not outright rejection, because it would disturb the "balance of the court." Whether Judge Alito will in fact shift the Supreme Court to the right on any matter is unknowable. But whatever kind of justice he may turn out to be, the premise of some ideal and inviolate balance of the court cannot be grounded in principle or put into practice.

title: U.S. Envoy's Criticisms Prompt Meeting With Zimbabwe Official
description: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 9 - Zimbabwe's foreign minister summoned the United States ambassador, Christopher Dell, to a meeting on Wednesday in the wake of a recent speech in which Mr. Dell laid blame for Zimbabwe's spectacular economic decline squarely -- and pungently -- at the government's feet.

title: Blaming the Messenger
description: In the last couple of days, the Republican leaders of Congress have been piously demanding a full investigation into the sources of a Washington Post article about the Central Intelligence Agency's chain of secret prison camps. These same leaders have spent 18 months crushing any serious look at the actual abuse of prisoners at those camps, and at camps run by the American military. And for more than two years, they have expressed no interest in whether the White House leaked the name of a covert C.I.A. operative to punish a critic of the Iraq war.

title: Is Owens a Distraction or a Talent?
description: Hempstead, N.Y. - IN this gloomy season, the Jets have sustained a torn biceps, a broken ankle and assorted shoulder injuries to key players.

title: U.S. Trade Deficit Hits $66 Billion, Another Record
description: The trade deficit widened by 11 percent and set another record in September, the government reported today, as exports of airplanes plummeted because of a strike at Boeing and imports of natural gas and petroleum products surged in the weeks after Hurricane Katrina struck the Gulf Coast. The deficit with China also hit a record.

title: Guidant Issues Data on Faulty Heart Devices
description: The Guidant Corporation, under scrutiny for failing to alert doctors about critical failures of its heart devices, issued its first report yesterday that showed how many units had malfunctioned in ways that prevented them from working.

title: Forgoing Business Lunches for Meetings on the Treadmill
description: KEITH FERRAZZI loves golf. As a youngster, he caddied for Arnold Palmer, and he played on his high school golf team. He takes great pleasure in tooling around a course, especially when he is conducting business. He finds people often share camaraderie when they are talking shop outdoors.

title: France Prepares to Deport Foreigners Guilty of Rioting
description: PARIS, Nov. 9 - Struggling to restore order after nearly two weeks of nightly street battles and car burnings, the French government demanded Wednesday that foreigners found guilty of rioting be expelled from the country, regardless of whether they are in France legally or illegally.

title: Corzine Prepares to Assume New Title, and the Problems That Go With It
description: TRENTON, Nov. 9 - Jon S. Corzine began his transformation from United States senator to New Jersey governor with equal measures of excitement and exhaustion on Wednesday, as he appointed the head of his transition team, reaffirmed his pledge to ease the state's high property taxes, then took a nap.

title: First woman is appointed as head of EU civil service
Lottery Numbers
More Than a Billion Chinese but So Few Coffins
description: LIUZHOU, China - In China these days, just about every form of commerce is thriving, including decidedly illegal ones like prostitution and counterfeiting. But not coffin making.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAGIN, FLORENCE
description: LAGIN--Florence. November 8, 2005. Devoted wife of Herbert. Loving mother of Arlene, Fred, Sheri and Robin. Beloved by her husband, children, grandchildren, brother, sons-in-law and great-grandchild. She made each feel special and loved. She was a woman of great strength and dignity, even in death. She will be missed by all whose lives she touched. Memorial service Friday, 10:30AM, Riverside Chapel, Great Neck. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Florence Lagin, C/O NYU Medical School.

title: TechEarnings: Net drops as BT loses customers
An Enduring Ribbon of Stars
description: Celebrities can be fickle, drifting from trend to trend, adopting charity causes as though they were tiny dogs, a new religion or a fad diet, abandoning interest in New York City's firefighters, starvation in Africa or colon cancer once the news media attention wanes. Nonetheless, a smorgasbord of health causes continue to jostle for star attention, hoping to score the backing of a celebrity like the actor Michael J. Fox, who helped lift the disease from which he suffers, Parkinson's, above obscurity.

title: Shocked and Defiant, Jordanians Mourn and Protest Bombings
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 10 - The dead were buried, the city mourned and a nation grew defiant Thursday after the worst act of terrorism in Jordan's history rattled the country's delicate sense of stability and set off an outpouring of emotion in condemnation of the attacks.

title: Flight of Boeings 777 Breaks Distance Record
description: International Herald Tribune

title: Talk Is Cheap, Improving the Mets Won't Be
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif., Nov. 9 - There are a few teams that Mets General Manager Omar Minaya knows so well that he may have their phone numbers on speed dial. He could chat with their general managers with the intimacy of a lifelong friend, trying to persuade them to trade him a particular player.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROTHENBERG, MOLLIE
description: ROTHENBERG--Mollie. Beloved mother of Marsha and Jeff Kaplan, Rona and Charlie Sampayo, Teri and Hank Weatherby, cherished grandmother of Ross, Scott, Aaron, Hank and Nyra. Adored wife of the late Ralph Rothenberg. Friend to the Southbridge "Brunch Bunch". A class act until the final curtain call. Contributions to Jacob Perlow Hospice, Beth Israel Hospital, NY, NY 10003.

title: The Last Chance For Bargains From Donghia
description: This will be the last year for Donghia's annual New York warehouse sale, eagerly awaited among bargain hunters. It will be held Saturday through Tuesday. Furniture, lighting fixtures and fabrics will be priced 50 to 80 percent below retail. Fabrics in limited quantities, like Juniper, by Bergamo, above, formerly $139 a yard, will be $20 a yard. Upholstered pieces, $500 to $3,000 (formerly $2,000 to $10,000) will include the Serpentine tub chair, inset, will be $1,260 (formerly $3,780). Tables will be $650 to $1,900 (formerly $2,000 to $5,500). Lamps will be $375 to $1,000 (formerly $1,000 to $2,000). The sale will be in the Puck Building, 295 Lafayette Street (Houston Street). Information: (718) 747-1656. MARIANNE ROHRLICH CURRENTS: WHO KNEW?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REGAN, WILLIAM J.
description: REGAN--William J., 78. Died November 8, 2005 in Naples, FL. A memorial mass will be held Wednesday, November 16 at 10 AM at St. Williams Catholic Church in Naples. Memorials may be made to Xavier High School, 30 West 16th Street, NY, NY for scholarships in his name. Fuller Funeral Home Pine Ridge Rd. (239) 592-1611

title: The Return of Ahmad Chalabi
description: It might have been awkward for President Bush to have told Ahmad Chalabi, a deputy prime minister in Iraq, that he would receive no official welcome in Washington this week. Mr. Chalabi does not easily take no for an answer, and he seems to have no inhibitions about embarrassing his former friends with impolitic remarks, especially if they help him in next month's Iraqi elections. But it is disgraceful to hand this multiply discredited schemer the prestige he will surely milk from his meetings with Vice President Dick Cheney, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and the national security adviser, Stephen Hadley.

title: The Jolt of Spray Paint on Snow
description: MUCH of the artwork created by Mark Paul Deren, a graphic designer based in Costa Mesa, Calif., is the kind that could land him in jail.

title: Amtrak Fires Its President in Dispute Over Future
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 - Amtrak's board fired the company's president on Wednesday morning, widening a divide between the Bush administration and Congress over the future of the railroad.

title: At This Sample Sale, No Flying Elbows
description: LAST Friday, in the very gray Vogue conference room at 4 Times Square, Anna Wintour met with a group of fashion industry executives for what would be the last of a series of weekly meetings to coordinate the construction of a store that will be open for less than 24 hours. Ms. Wintour had assembled the group to discuss outstanding details for 7th on Sale, the designer sample sale to benefit AIDS charities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUBIN, RUTH
description: DUBIN--Ruth. Beloved wife, mother and grandmother, passed away on November 7, 2005 at the age of 93 after a long illness. Her husband David died 14 years ago. She is survived by two children, Francine Lieberman, her husband Shelly, who in many ways was a real son to her, and a source of great comfort. Also her son Lawrence and his wife Susan and daughter-in-law Felice Dubin. Her first son, Paul Dubin died in 1999. She is also survived by nine grandchildren and two great grandchildren. The family requests that in lieu of flowers all donations be made to the Habitat For Humanity. Funeral November 9, Lakeside Memorial Cemetery, Miami, FL, 12:45 PM.

description: The Rose in Winter

title: A quiet writer's taste for tales with teeth
Hard Choices Seen in Efforts to Help Louisiana Wetlands
description: Restoring Louisiana's vanished wetlands, or even maintaining those that remain, will be impossible, according to an expert panel convened in 2004 by the National Academy of Sciences to consider a major proposal for wetlands restoration in the state.

title: In the Arena: Pirate joins the sailing fleet
Evolution and the Electorate
description: Voters in Dover, Pa., came to their senses this week and tossed out almost the entire school board, which had tried to discredit the theory of evolution and steer students toward the theory of "intelligent design" -- the idea that life forms are so complex that a higher being must have made them. Let's hope the voters in Kansas follow suit next year by ejecting several benighted members of the State Board of Education, which has just approved new science standards that open the way for supernatural explanations of natural phenomena.

title: The shopping wars heat up in Asia
Klitschko Pulls Punches and Retires From Ring
description: After sustaining a knee injury and postponing the most lucrative bout in his career, Vitali Klitschko, the World Boxing Council's heavyweight champion, announced his retirement from boxing and said he planned to support charitable and political causes.

title: For Those Who Love Brooklyn So Much They Can Taste It
description: Fishs Eddy, the china and glassware company, has introduced a 12-inch-square serving platter for New Yorkers who think Brooklyn is the new Manhattan. The company, with stores in both boroughs, already sold Manhattan-theme dinnerware, and last spring it sponsored a competition at Pratt Institute inviting proposals with a Brooklyn motif. The winning design, by Jordan Awan, a 21-year-old junior, has a Brooklyn landscape, including its best known bridge. The platter, the first piece in a line of heavy restaurant-style china that will be made with Mr. Awan's design, is $28. Information: (877) 347-4733.

title: Signs of Crocodile From Dinosaur Era Are Found
description: Scientists have nicknamed it Godzilla, but it really belongs in another movie, this one not yet made: "Jaws Meets Jurassic Park."

title: WINNER AT POOLS AND POLLS
description: Tom Wilkens, a bronze-medal winner in the 200-meter individual medley at the 2000 Sydney Olympic Games, has emerged a winner in his first venture into politics. Wilkens, a 29-year-old Republican, earned a three-year term on the Middletown, N.J., township council Tuesday, leading all candidates with 10,846 votes.

title: Gangsta, in French
description: After 9/11, everyone knew there was going to be a debate about the future of Islam. We just didn't know the debate would be between Osama bin Laden and Tupac Shakur.

title: Arab Royals Buy 2 Pieces of the Skyline
description: They are two trophy buildings in Manhattan, familiar if not instantly nameable by anyone who knows the city: 230 Park Avenue, the gold-crowned, 34-story tower that sits astride the avenue between 45th and 46th Streets, and the Essex House, one of the grand Art Deco hotels on Central Park South.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Writer Sought In Sexual Assault Case
description: The police officially released the name yesterday of a Queens man they are seeking for questioning in connection with a sexual assault on a woman in her Chelsea apartment last week. The man, Peter Braunstein, is wanted for violating the terms of his probation in an unrelated case, the authorities said. Investigators have been looking for Mr. Braunstein, 41, a writer, since the Oct. 31 attack, in which a man dressed as a firefighter started small fires outside the apartment of a 34-year-old woman, forced his way inside, drugged her, then sexually assaulted her. In a separate case this year, Mr. Braunstein was accused of menacing, stalking, aggravated harassment and unlawful imprisonment, and pleaded guilty to menacing, a misdemeanor.

title: Is There a Hit Film in the Battle for Ohio?
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 9 - With "Jarhead" revisiting the gulf war and "Good Night, and Good Luck" taking moviegoers all the way back to McCarthyism for a history lesson, it must not have seemed like such a stretch to make a documentary about a divisive event that at least everyone remembers.

title: A Prosecutor Comes Home a Conqueror
description: MINEOLA, N.Y. - Kathleen Rice was in third grade in 1974 when Denis Dillon was first elected Nassau County's district attorney.

title: Chirac admits failure on social problems
Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Friday, about the acquisition of CSTV Networks by CBS, referred imprecisely to the Web traffic for the sports sites of the two companies. According to Nielsen//NetRatings, the combined, unduplicated number of unique visitors for the sites in September was 10.8 million, not 12.1 million. ComScore Media Metrix, which also measures Web site traffic, put the number at 13.3 million, not 14.4 million.

title: Storm Victims Suing FEMA for More Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 - When the government check arrived 38 days after Hurricane Katrina destroyed their trailer in Long Beach, Miss., Russell and Tammy Hayward bought some towels, sheets and dishes. They paid for emergency dental care and kept receipts for everything linked to the $2,358 assistance check, which came without explanation.

title: G.O.P. Dissension Delays Vote on Budget-Cutting Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 - Facing defeat, House Republican leaders on Thursday abruptly called off a vote on a contentious budget-cutting bill in a striking display of the discord and political anxiety running through the party's ranks.

title: British Firm Wins Auction to Acquire Refco Assets
description: Refco, the bankrupt commodities broker, said today that Man Group, a large British hedge fund firm, had agreed to pay $282 million in cash to acquire a substantial portion of the company's assets.

title: One size doesn't fit all
Liberty gives Oracle executive chance to run the show
Fujimori's Detention in Chile Was Just Part of His Plan, Allies Say
description: LIMA, Peru, Nov. 9 - Former President Alberto K. Fujimori, detained in neighboring Chile after his jarring reappearance in the region after a five-year exile, is now confined in a 10-by-10-foot room outfitted with a single bed, a small television and a simple desk, his supporters here say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WETZSTEIN, MARTIN
description: WETZSTEIN--Martin. On November 7, 2005. Beloved husband of Sara. Devoted father of David and Mark and father-in-law of Melissa and Sarah. Cherished grandfather of Samuel Scott. He will be missed by all who knew him. Services Thursday, 11:30 AM at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: A Decisive Election in a Town Roiled Over Intelligent Design
description: DOVER, Pa., Nov. 9 - In the end, voters here said they were tired of being portrayed as a northern version of Dayton, Tenn., a Bible Belt hamlet where 80 years ago a biology teacher named John Scopes was tried for illegally teaching evolution.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMON, RHODA H.
description: SIMON--Rhoda H.. 84. Of Park Ridge, NJ, formerly of Tenafly, NJ. Cherished wife of the late Alfred. Beloved mother of Barry and Hinda, Clifford and Leslie, Proud grandmother and great-grandmother of Alan, John and Laura, Eric and Chris, Scott and Madeline, Robert and Elizabeth, Will, Leo, Maya, Benjamin, Sasha, and Danielle. Sister of Bruce. Services are today, 1:30 PM at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel W-150 Rt. 4, Paramus, NJ.

title: Sometimes, a Trick Lost Early Can Pay Dividends in the End
description: The International Bridge Press Association's personality of the year is Fred Gitelman. A Canadian by birth, he has lived in Las Vegas for five years and was a member of the U.S.A. 2 team at the recent world championships in Portugal, winning a bronze medal. But he is best known for being the person behind Bridge Base Online. This is a free service for people worldwide who wish to play bridge online, and it also runs live broadcasts of leading national and international events. At the moment Bridge Base Online can handle only 10,000 people, and that was a problem during the concluding session of the Bermuda Bowl final last Saturday. There were more than 8,000 watching the live feed from Estoril and nearly 2,000 playing bridge. If you were not logged in early, you waited quite some time to get into the system.

title: Labor Leader's Pullout Creates Crisis for Sharon Coalition
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 10 - The new leader of the Labor Party of Israel said today he would pull his center-left party out of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's coalition government, a move almost certain to force the government's dissolution and prompt new elections within months.

title: Police Say Man Robbing Store Is Killed in Struggle With Clerk
description: A man trying to rob a convenience store in Brooklyn last night was shot in the head during a struggle with a store clerk and died, the police said. The clerk was shot in the elbow and slashed in the arm, but survived the attack, they said.

title: At-Home Enterprises Seek Elbow Room
description: Eric Poses wanted to hire an assistant for the game-board company that he was running out of his two-bedroom condominium in Santa Monica, but realized it was too cramped to accommodate another desk.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Hope for a Global Trade Pact Evaporates Amid Impasse Over Agricultural Subsidies

title: U.S. and Europe to Give Iranians New Atom Offer
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 - The Bush administration and three European allies have approved a new offer to be made to Iran in a last-ditch effort to head off a confrontation over its suspected nuclear weapons program.

title: Al Qaeda claims responsibility for Amman blasts
Iraqi Deputy, Back in U.S., Strives to Rebuild Reputation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 - Ahmad Chalabi, once an Iraqi exile leader and now a deputy prime minister, began his campaign for American rehabilitation here on Wednesday by dismissing the claim that he lured the Bush administration into war with inaccurate intelligence on Iraqi weapons.

title: Azerbaijani Victory Rally Appears Orchestrated
description: BAKU, Azerbaijan, Nov. 10 - The ruling party of Azerbaijan rallied today to celebrate victory in parliamentary elections last Sunday, which international observers have said were tainted with extensive fraud, while the opposition called for all election results to be overturned.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MELITA, ROBERT N.
description: MELITA--Robert N. On November 9, 2005, of New York City, New York. Beloved husband of Anna-Marie. Devoted father of Isabella. Loving son of Anthony and Libby Melita. Also survived by his brother A.J. Family will receive friends on Thursday and Friday, 2-4 and 7-9PM at the Donohue Cecere Funeral Home, 290 Post Avenue, Westbury, L.I. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, 9:45AM, at St. Brigid's R.C. Church, Westbury, L.I. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury. In lieu of flowers, donations requested to Lance Armstrong Foundation, PO Box 131768 Houston, Texas 77219-1768 or www.livestrong.org

title: Company to Start Offering Free Use of Patents It Holds
description: A new patent-holding company, the Open Invention Network, is expected to begin operations today with the unusual business plan of buying certain patents and licensing them without charge.

title: A Leaping Man in Red, Propelled by Classic Brubeck
description: Breezy, fluid and engaging, Lar Lubovitch's "Elemental Brubeck" received its American premiere Tuesday night at the Skirball Center at New York University. It was also the dance's first performance by the choreographer's own company. Mr. Lubovitch made the work -- set to extracts from Dave Brubeck's 1963 jazz suite "Time Changes" -- for the San Francisco Ballet's visit to Paris in July, and its clean, lucid lines are clearly tailored to classically trained dancers.

title: Crowd Protests Fraud in Azerbaijan Vote
description: BAKU, Azerbaijan, Nov. 9 - Thousands of opposition members rallied peacefully here on Wednesday to protest fraudulent parliamentary elections, as the Azeri government, under intensive diplomatic pressure, moved to undo some of the most obviously falsified results.

title: Democrats Gain on Long Island, a Onetime G.O.P. Bastion
description: For decades, Republican candidates in New York have turned to Long Island as a reliable source of votes. Thousands of Long Islanders came to rallies for presidential candidates. Just 11 years ago, the Long Island vote, and the help of the Island's kingmaker, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, were instrumental in electing a little-known state senator, George E. Pataki, the governor of New York.

title: Palmeiro Ends Silence on Eve of Report
description: With a Congressional committee set to release a report today on whether Rafael Palmeiro committed perjury in March when he denied using steroids, Palmeiro offered his first public comments about his situation in more than three months yesterday in a statement released by his lawyers.

title: An Unclear Role for an Oversight Agency at Ground Zero
description: IN creating the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, Gov. George E. Pataki promised it would be "the entity that drives the train of Lower Manhattan development." The question on its fourth anniversary is where the track ends.

title: Move Expected by Nissan
description: DETROIT, Nov. 9 - Nissan plans to announce on Thursday that it is moving its North American headquarters out of California, most likely to Tennessee, people briefed on the company's plans said Wednesday.

title: A Digital Assistant Also Knows Its Way Around the Block
description: As portable navigation devices become more popular, manufacturers are starting to load them with features. What sets the Nvi from Garmin apart, however, is that it isn't easy to tell if it is a navigation device for cars that has a few extra tricks or a personal digital assistant with satellite navigation abilities.

title: Graduate Teaching Assistants Go on Strike Against N.Y.U.
description: After a last-ditch effort by a group of professors on Tuesday failed to convince officials at New York University to re-open labor negotiations with the union representing graduate teaching assistants, the union went on strike yesterday.

title: North Korea pressed to shut down reactor
Arts, Briefly; What's New in News
description: NBC squeaked out a win in Tuesday's competition for 18-to-49-year-olds, beating CBS by one-tenth of a ratings point. Its weight-loss reality show, "The Biggest Loser," delivered its highest ratings of the season with an estimated 10.11 million viewers. "My Name Is Earl" (11.65 million), with Jason Lee, below, and "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit" (15.52 million) both continued to draw well. But "The Office," which NBC has picked up for the season, still lagged, with an audience of 7.66 million. CBS was No. 1 among total viewers on this sweeps Tuesday, lifted by "NCIS" (17.58 million) For the week that ended on Sunday, "NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams" brought in an average of 9.77 million viewers, its best since the week of Hurricane Katrina. ABC's "World News Tonight" placed second (8.47 million) and CBS's "Evening News" (7.41 million) was third. Compared with October 2004, when coverage of the presidential election was at its height, both NBC and ABC were down for the month in total viewers, but CBS improved in that measurement. In the 25-to-54 demographic, advertisers covet during the nightly news, only ABC grew versus its share last year. KATE AURTHUR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YOLTON, JOHN WILLIAM
description: YOLTON--John William. Piscataway, New Jersey, has died in New Brunswick, New Jersey, at the Robert Wood Johnson Hospital. He was in his 83rd year. He and his wife, Jean (nee Sebastian) were married in 1945. His heirs are his wife and two daughters, Karin (Mrs. Bryant Griffith) and Pamela H. Smith. Burial service was private.

description: Politically, "Jarhead" tilts left, while "Over There" slants right, though the people who make and market them would never admit it.

One $2,300 Hub That Promises to Tame Multimedia in the Home
description: Keeping track of and organizing the hundreds of CD's, DVD's and downloaded music files found in the average household can be daunting. The Sony Vaio XL1 Digital Living System, a multimedia hub for the living room, may offer a solution.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KNAPP, HARRIET, PH.D.
description: KNAPP--Harriet, Ph.D. on November 9, 2005. Loved and loving wife of Philip. Devoted mother of John, Joshua and Josiah, mother-in-law of Elisabeth and Grace, grandmother of Katherine and David, sister of Shirley Corey. Respected Professor of clinical psychology; accom plished researcher, noted family and adolescent psychologist who devoted over fifty years of her life to helping her patients and students. She will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held 11AM Friday at I.J. Morris, Inc. 21 East Deer Park Road, Dix Hills, New York. Interment to follow at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: Germany to readjust its foreign policies
Treating the Scalp With Respect and Products
description: IT seems that the scalp, which has been sitting quietly under the hair forever, is suddenly being called into the limelight. Dehydrated, oily, stressed and overburdened scalps are receiving the kind of treatment normally reserved for the face. The hair, too, is coming in for pampering that takes the amount of time and trouble women once lavished only on their complexions.

title: What does 'assimilation' mean?
Where Brazilian Wood Meets Venetian Glass
description: Fernando and Humberto Campana, the Brazilian designers, have created 175 crystal hanging bells in collaboration with a glass artist at the Venetian company Venini. The bells, about one to three feet high ($1,600 to $8,950), are at Moss Gallery, through Dec. 18. The ones with wood handles, left, "were for us a way to bring a sense of our own Brazilian heritage to the project," said Fernando Campana, while those with cartoon characters, right, were inspired by Venetian souvenirs. The gallery is at 146 Greene Street (Houston Street); (212) 204-7104 or mossonline.com. TIM McKEOUGH CURRENTS: BELLS

title: A Democrat of Faith Turns Tables
description: RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 9 - One of the first things Lt. Gov. Timothy M. Kaine did after entering the race for Virginia governor last spring was to go on evangelical Christian radio to talk about faith in politics. And one of his early advertisements spotlighted his work as a Christian missionary in Honduras during a break from law school two decades ago.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (NBC) JOEY -- The network is not wasting Ellen DeGeneres during this sweeps period. She turned up during the live debates on "The West Wing" on Sunday night. Now she pops up in the life of Joey Tribbiani (Matt LeBlanc, above, with Ms. DeGeneres), who promises to apologize to an old girlfriend on Ms. DeGeneres's talk show. Otherwise the girlfriend will release an embarrassing sextape. Which might also be a good thing for sweeps.

title: After 3 Decades, Guilty Verdict in Rape Case, With Help From DNA
description: Thirty-two years after a young woman was raped at knifepoint in a Manhattan apartment, the man accused at the time was convicted yesterday for the assault, in a case that displayed the power of DNA testing to identify elusive criminals.

title: An Expert at the One-Night Stand Explores Long-Term Commitment
description: Antony Todd, the Manhattan event and floral designer who opened a store with Nina Griscom in Southampton, N.Y., last year, is expanding into furniture and interiors. The Brodsky Organization, developer of 4W, an apartment building by the architect Hugh Hardy at 4 West 21st St., hired Mr. Todd, above, to consult on the look of the lobby, the hallways and the kitchens and baths. Mr. Todd's design for a sample apartment at the 4W sales office includes 10 pieces of furniture that are now available through his company, Antony Todd Inc.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Shrewsbury: Former State Senator's Office Raided
description: Federal agents yesterday raided the law offices of John A. Lynch, a former state senator from Middlesex County who is one of the state's most powerful Democratic party leaders. It was unclear what they were looking for. The United States attorney's office and the F.B.I. have been investigating real estate development deals in central New Jersey involving several of Mr. Lynch's political allies and business associates. Mr. Lynch charged that the inquiry had been spurred by unfair and unfounded characterizations of his business and political dealings in the local news media.

title: Briefs: Oil-demand forecast is lowered
Corrections

Post, a management professor who said the concept might open opportunities for some job seekers. It is Boston University, not Boston College.

title: Peres Loses Israeli Labor Party Post, Endangering Sharon Coalition
description: JERUSALEM, Thursday, Nov. 10 - A trade union leader won a surprise victory over Shimon Peres in an election for leader of the Labor Party, party officials announced early on Thursday. The development greatly increases the possibility that Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's coalition government could collapse.

title: Intensely Hunted Terrorist Killed in Fight With Indonesian Police
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Thursday, Nov. 10 - After 24 hours of some uncertainty, President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono said Thursday afternoon that one of the most hunted terrorist suspects in Southeast Asia, Azhari Husin, a skilled bomb maker, was killed in a raid on Wednesday.

title: Democrats Get New Edge Over G.O.P. in Assembly
description: TRENTON, Nov. 9 - Buoyed by Jon S. Corzine's election as governor on Tuesday, New Jersey Democrats expanded their majority in the state's 80-member Assembly, giving their party its biggest majority in three decades.

title: Gear Test: Binoculars
description: Many makers of binoculars have added features that appeal to birders, including image stabilizers and built-in digital cameras.

title: Responses to One Step Closer to the Big Enchilada
description: Carlos, Turriago, Jyvaskyla , Finland: Your article brings up a point that often appears in press commentaries: The Bush White Houses infractions are nowhere near those of the Nixon administration. Can this be legitimately said? Please, refresh my memory: did a single innocent bystander die as a direct consequence of the Watergate mess? Can dirty political plots, however criminal, be compared with the devastation and suffering that an unjustified war of aggression has brought to innocent Iraqis? We quickly forgot that Paul Wolfowitz said clearly on at least one occasion, publicly, that the reason for the Iraq war was OIL and every other rationale was only meant to help sell the war. Your columns offer something badly needed at the moment: courageous challenge to fallacious notions fed to the gullible and ignorant American electorate. Please, more.

title: Raps and Riots: On Gangsta, in French
description: Greg Diamond, Denver: Sadly, you are right about Gangsta raps influence on the disaffected poor in France. But, the wretched of the earth are not the rioters. Much worse  they are the one billion humans on the planet who subsist on less than one dollar a day but who cannot rap and cannot riot. They are tired, sick and hungry. They have no voice. Who will be their voice? You and me, perhaps?

title: Repsonses to The Mysterious Death of Pat Tillman
description: April Portillo, Phoenix: I have never met Pat Tillman. I rarely watched football to any great extent. One day, however, maybe in 1993, I was watching an A.S.U. game and saw a player that left an indeliable mark in my mind. His name was Pat Tillman. I remember remarking to my boyfriend that this boy had heart and that he was destined for greatness. He said back to me that he would never make it in the pros because he was just too small. I made a bet with him that he would be in the pros after graduation. I won. But thats not the point. Pat Tillman was my hero, then as well as today. He never gave up. I saw him repeatedly defy all odds. He was a singular person. I am so upset as to what the military did upon his death. Nothing but lies and cover ups. I pray for Pats parents and wife. Thank you for writing about a man I will never forget as long as I live. He was betrayed as well as our country. I pray that other journalists will not give up finding out the truth of what happened to a great short life. War is hell. A fake war is beyond my comprehension or expression. Please do not forget this mans life. Bring closure and the truth to his family and to so many persons who were touched by his life. Someone must know.

title: Sprint Launches a Pricey Music Store

title: Readers Respond
description: Reader responses to Marjane Satrapis first two posts, Bird Flu and A War in Paris:Alicia Abel, New York: I am enjoying your excellent, illustrated series. I have spoken to friends in Paris where I once lived, who express the same sentiment  that there is no firebombing in Paris central, despite what CNN wants to show you, which I think reflects their control by white male Republicans, and their disdain for everything French, but that is another conversation.

It was a rural child survival project run by a small, nonreligious NGO in Minnesota. There were two Westerners on the project me and my bossneither of us religious in any way and everyone else was Ugandan. Which brings up several points:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SALMANOWITZ, BETTY (NEE POLLACK)
description: SALMANOWITZ--Betty (nee Pollack), 80, but young at heart, on November 9, 2005 in Naples, Florida. Beloved and patient wife of nearly 60 years of Harold; loving and devoted mother of Barbara, Richard, John and David; doting and proud grandmother of Rebecca, Josh, Michael, Jenny, Rachel and Natalie; and great-grandmother of Gad and Odelia. She loved winning at tennis and bridge, her daily crossword puzzle, dressing up and being out and about. We will fondly remember her for the loving, active, vivacious, generous, stubborn and feisty lady that she was. A remembrance gathering will be held at 1 P.M. on Monday, November 14 at Fuller Funeral Home in Naples. No flowers please. Contributions to Hospice of Naples, EMS of Collier County, or Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, Brookline, MA., would be appreciated.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Health Agency Says Polio Is Halted In 10 Countries
description: After spreading from Nigeria three years ago, polio has again been eliminated from 10 western and central African countries, the World Health Organization said. But it said the disease -- and rejection of vaccination -- persists in northern Nigeria. After northern Nigeria banned vaccinations for nearly a year in 2002, the disease spread rapidly. It has not yet been eliminated from several other countries that worry health officials, including Somalia and Indonesia, the world's fourth most populous country. New infections were eliminated from Benin, Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Chad, Ghana, Guinea, Ivory Coast, Mali and Togo. The disease remains endemic in Nigeria, Niger, India, Pakistan, Afghanistan and Egypt. Donald G. McNeil Jr. (NYT)

title: U.S. Inquiry Found Halliburton Mishandled Some Pension Funds
description: A federal investigation of Halliburton's pension plans has uncovered three violations of the law, including charging some costs of Halliburton's executive pension and bonus plans to the workers' pension fund, correspondence from the Labor Department shows.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TAYLOR, BEATRIX (''TRIXIE'') BENJAMIN
description: TAYLOR--Beatrix ("Trixie") Benjamin, of Oyster Bay, NY on November 10, 2005. Born Beatrix Chase Hoyt on July 9, 1920 in New York to Franklin Chase Hoyt, Presiding Justice of The Children's Court of New York, and Maud Rives Borland. Great granddaughter of Salmon P. Chase, Chief Justice of the U.S. Supreme Court, and sister of the late Constance Hoyt Moore. Survived by her husband Stephen H. Taylor of Oyster Bay. Previously married to Park Benjamin, Jr. deceased in 1986 and survived by their four sons Park Benjamin III of Bayville, NY, Hoyt D. Benjamin of Ithaca, NY, William C. Benjamin of Weston, MA and Stephen D. Benjamin of Norwalk, CT, seven grandchildren and one great grandchild. Devoted wife and mother, accomplished marine artist, avid sailor, and active member of Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club. Trixie was a wonderful person loved by all who knew her. A funeral service will be held at 1:30 pm Saturday at Zion Episcopal Church, 12 Satterlee Place, Wappingers Falls, NY and a memorial service at 1:00 pm Sunday at Christ Church, 61 East Main Street, Oyster Bay, NY. In lieu of flowers, please consider memorial donations to Christ Church or Save the Children, P.O. Box 38, Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724.

description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif., Nov. 10 - When the Philadelphia Phillies were pursuing the free-agent slugger Jim Thome in 2002, General Manager Ed Wade sent an e-mail message to Thome's agent with the club's initial offer at 12:01 a.m. on the first day they could discuss contract terms. It was a prudent move, because the Phillies' immediate interest ultimately persuaded Thome to leave Cleveland and sign with them.

title: City's 311 Help Line Plans to Add Data on Social Services
description: The city's 311 government help line will be expanded in a year through a partnership with United Way of New York City to give out information on social services provided by thousands of nonprofit agencies, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday.

title: Home Alone
description: Providence, R.I. - MY father's Army uniform came in three pieces: a jacket, slacks and a button-up shirt. It was made of 50 percent wool and 50 percent polyester and felt strangely resistant to the touch, scratchy, without give. In November 1992, Dad went to his bedroom to put it on, his first time in uniform in 23 years. Ten minutes later, he stood before me in full attire: government-issue ankle-high lace-up black shoes, a black tie and a tight-creased sandwich cap. Two hash marks slashed on the right sleeve of his jacket -- one for each six months of overseas duty -- and a blue braided ribbon looped his shoulder and chest, signifying infantry. There was a combat infantry badge, a rifleman's badge and patches for rank, unit and division: 25th Infantry "Tropic Lightning" Division.

title: 36 Hours in Indianapolis
description: FOR years, Indianapolis bore the stigma of nicknames like Nap Town and Indiana No Place. But in the 1990's, construction and development downtown seemed to wake the city up, and today, a thriving cultural scene mixes with Hoosier hospitality and charm. And there are still the old Indianapolis standbys, like the hearty Midwestern food; the many classical monuments and fountains, laid out using elements of L'Enfant's plan for Washington and built partly by freemasons; and of course, the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, home of the Indy 500. And all those smiling faces? Colts fans.

title: An Agile Hero in Reputation, Not Action
description: George MacDonald Fraser is now 80, or almost as old as his great creation Sir Harry Flashman was when Flashman -- self-proclaimed cad, poltroon, card cheat and serial fornicator -- began writing the multivolume autobiography that we know as "The Flashman Papers." Mr. Fraser has just published the 12th installment, "Flashman on the March," which, like its author, and like Flashman himself, for that matter, shows no signs of flagging.

title: Blood Lines That Blend Old Performance Arts With the New
description: Nowhere in the program for "Bright Abyss" does it say that James Thirre, the writer, director and star, is the grandson of Charles Chaplin. But look closely enough and you can discern his distinguished family history in every tumble. Those rubber-band legs, expressive eyes and herky-jerky movements -- all that's missing is the bowler hat.

title: Off the Charts: A tale of two deficits

Thou Shalt Not Destroy the Center
description: Dear God in Heaven: Forgive me my sins, for I have been to China and I have had bad thoughts. Forgive me, Heavenly Father, for I have cast an envious eye on the authoritarian Chinese political system, where leaders can, and do, just order that problems be solved. For instance, Shanghai's deputy mayor told me that as his city became more polluted, the government simply moved thousands of small manufacturers out of Shanghai to clean up the air.

title: Report Finds No Evidence of Perjury by Palmeiro
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 - The House Government Reform Committee concluded in a 44-page report released Thursday that it did not have enough evidence to determine whether Rafael Palmeiro had lied under oath in March when he defiantly testified that he had never taken steroids, even though he tested positive a few weeks later. The committee initiated a perjury investigation of Palmeiro after he was suspended for 10 days in August for testing positive for stanozolol.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Threat To Bar Campaigning On Charter
description: With a hotly contested referendum looming, the Electoral Commission blamed both supporters and opponents of the government's draft constitution for instigating recent rioting that has left 4 people dead and more than 30 injured. Gabriel Mukele, the vice chairman of the commission, which is overseeing the Nov. 21 polling, said both sides would be forbidden to campaign if there were any more violent clashes. President Mwai Kibaki is pushing to revise the country's colonial-era Constitution, but opponents, including some of his own ministers, say his proposal does not go far enough in weakening the powers of the presidency. Marc Lacey (NYT)

His humor and personable nature made him legendary and much loved beyond the west Brooklyn community where he served innumerable charities and organizations. Memorial service Sunday, November 13, 3PM, at Weinstein, 1153 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn (718-377-4848).

title: Children Persevering in the Face of Tourette's
description: If your understanding of Tourette's syndrome has shamefully come (like mine) from plotlines of network legal dramas ("Ally McBeal," "L.A. Law"), then you know that the condition is a disruptive and serious one, but you can't help feeling intrigued by the idea of a life spent medically exempt from the mandates of social decorum. Tourette's is a neurological disorder that popular culture has treated as a comedic form, an affliction that seems to leave sufferers unable to suppress the urge to tell the host of a dinner party that his lamb shanks taste like a dictionary.

title: God Spells? School Champion Puts Cabala Theory to the Test
description: The search for transcendence is one of the very greatest of all human endeavors, but it isn't the sort of thing that makes for good multiplex fodder. Neither does transcendence, at least at first glance, figure into those charming public rituals in which stuttering and steely-eyed children struggle to spell exotically difficult words. Yet in "Bee Season," a serious film filled with both great and awkward ideas and made as much from the heart as the head, an 11-year-old girl summons up perfectly strung-together words with an ineffable gift that the filmmakers boldly suggest may be divine.

title: Waiter Is Found Guilty of Killing Wife's Lover
description: A hotel-room-service waiter was convicted yesterday of shooting and killing his wife's lover in a Chelsea subway station, after an unusual episode in which a juror was dismissed after complaining that she had been "appalled" by the waiter's lawyer.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Indictments In School Stabbings
description: Four Manhattan teenagers have been charged with stabbing four people, one fatally, near Physical City High School on East 25th Street on Sept. 30, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau announced yesterday. The four -- Jason Chavis, 17; Robert Jack, 16; David McKay, 19; and Jason Procope, 17 -- were indicted on manslaughter, gang assault and other charges, prosecutors said. They pleaded not guilty. The dead victim was Shareef Lesane, 15, a student. Mr. Morgenthau said the defendants believed students had teased Mr. Procope's cousin.

title: For Election Reform, a Heartening Defeat
description: Washington - ON Tuesday, voters in California and Ohio defeated ballot initiatives to "reform" the way in which Congressional and state legislative districts are drawn. The California proposal, sponsored by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger and his Republican allies, lost 41 percent to 59 percent, while the Ohio initiative, sponsored by a coalition of groups generally aligned with the Democrats, was defeated by an even larger margin. While some commentators have portrayed the results as the death knell for districting reform, we believe that this conclusion is entirely unwarranted.

title: The Listings: Nov. 11 -- Nov. 18; 'WYNTON WITH STRINGS: 25TH-YEAR CELEBRATION'
description: At first glance, a concert featuring Wynton Marsalis with a string orchestra might seem like a step in the wrong direction. Mr. Marsalis, above, whose high-culture bona fides were established well before he became the artistic director of Jazz at Lincoln Center, has recently done his strongest work in casual settings. His most recent album, "Live at the House of Tribes" (Blue Note), documents a small-group performance in vibrant close quarters; it's clear, from Mr. Marsalis's high-stakes trumpet soloing, that the crowd's whoops and hollers provide more than background noise. As a programmatic concept, "Wynton With Strings" offers more muted pleasures. But Mr. Marsalis set romantic jazz standards against lush orchestral settings as early as 1984, on the album "Hot House Flowers" (Columbia); he offered a sequel in 1998, "Standard Time, Vol. 5: The Midnight Blues" (Columbia). During his three consecutive nights at the Rose Theater, he'll revisit this material with his quartet and an orchestra led by the jazz-literate conductor Robert Sadin. The music will shimmer and swell, and Mr. Marsalis will favor a tender sort of effulgence. What makes the project especially enticing is the potential for small surprises: the string arrangements have been updated, and Mr. Marsalis is a more thoughtful improviser than he was a decade or even five years ago. For those familiar with the scope of his 25-year solo career, these concerts could serve as a benchmark. For most everyone else, the romance of the evening will be more than enough. (Thursday through Nov. 19 at 8 p.m., Frederick P. Rose Hall, 60th Street and Broadway, (212) 721-6500; $30 to $130.)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Father Admits Fatally Shaking Son
description: A Queens man pleaded guilty to manslaughter yesterday for shaking his 3-month-old son to death, District Attorney Richard A. Brown announced. In a statement, he said that Victor Fuentes, 20, of Onderdonk Avenue in Ridgewood, admitted that he shook his son, Victor Fuentes Jr., on March 16, 2004, to stop him from crying. Mr. Fuentes's sentence will be 14 years in prison.

title: On a slow boatfrom Ambon to Banda
Two Strangers on a Train, en Route to Big Trouble
description: "Derailed," a glossy and often risible bit of trash about an adulterous affair gone bad, bad, bad, belongs to that reliable category of films that could be labeled "the wages of sin" or "the cheater's lament." In noirs like "The Postman Always Rings Twice" and the glorious "Double Indemnity," and in modern flicks like "Unfaithful" and that crazy mama of all feel-good, feel-really-bad cheating movies, "Fatal Attraction," the adulterer doesn't just experience a twinge or tidal wave of guilt, risk losing the spouse, the house and maybe even the bunny; he (sometimes she) hops aboard the River Styx ferry and rides that baby all the way to the bitter end.

description: Chamber orchestras obviously cannot solve deeply rooted ethnic or religious conflicts, but they offer a decent metaphor for coexistence. The troubles between north and south are referred to only obliquely in the group's program notes, but they presumably influenced the Belfast-born pianist Barry Douglas, who founded the group in 1999.

title: A Comic in Search of the Discomfort Zone
description: In "The Aristocrats," Penn Jillette and Paul Provenza's brilliant essay-film on the world's dirtiest joke, Sarah Silverman provides one of the few genuinely unsettling and provocative moments. Stripping away the frame ("A guy walks into a talent agent's office "), she tells the joke from inside, from the perspective of someone for whom it is not funny at all. Which makes it funnier than ever, as well as decidedly squirm-inducing.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Halts House Extension
description: The city issued an order on Wednesday telling Julian Schnabel, left, the painter and film director, to halt construction of a nine-story extension to his 19th-century house in the West Village, a project that has faced strong opposition from a local historic preservation group. The order will be in place until the city decides whether the project, at 360 West 11th Street, violates zoning regulations that went into effect on Oct. 11, limiting the height of area buildings to 80 feet. The decision hinges on whether enough work was done to strengthen the foundation under the old zoning rules, which would have allowed the project, according to a Buildings Department spokeswoman, Jennifer Givner. title: The Listings: Nov. 11 -- Nov. 17; THE BARNARD PROJECT
description: Two Augusts ago, Mary Cochran, chairwoman of Barnard College's dance department, stopped into the Dance Theater Workshop building, where she met its artistic director, Cathy Edwards. "We were just simpatico right away," Ms. Cochran said. "I said to her, 'A lot of people ask, what can D.T.W. do for me?' I was thinking, what can we do for D.T.W., to really support the artists?" On Thursday, audiences can sample the fruits of this conversation at "The Barnard Project." The first-time collaboration between D.T.W. and Barnard features dance majors from the college performing works by three choreographers, all of whom are in residence at Barnard. In "Flowers and Snow," David Parker reworks "Nut/Cracked," last year's naughty take on "The Nutcracker." Donna Uchizono revisits "Butterflies From My Hand" (above, with August Pozgay, left, Julie Bakshi, Betsy Coker and Rachel Krol), expanding it from a quartet to a dance for seven, and Ori Flomin completes the program with "Walking City, Standing Square," a new dance inspired by the sculptor Alberto Giacometti. Going mainly on instinct, Ms. Cochran said, she and Ms. Edwards chose these three from a pool of applicants. Then, after trying to ease as many of the production stresses as they could, they stepped away to let choreographers and dancers figure things out for themselves. Process "is not really given a chance to bloom" these days, Ms. Cochran said, adding that she sees the project as being "about the future -- of the choreographers, the students and my relationship with D.T.W." Stay tuned; plans for next year are already in the works. (Thursday through Nov. 19 at 7:30 p.m., with an additional 2 p.m. show on Nov. 19. Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 924-0077.)

description: An 18-year-old woman in a car driven by a friend was killed early yesterday when a car crash threw her onto the Grand Central Parkway, where she was struck by another car, the authorities said. The woman, Betina Madrid, was pronounced dead at the scene, the police said. The driver, Jennifer Grabowski, 19, who was taking her friends home from a cafe in Jamaica, was charged with driving with ability impaired, the police said. Shortly before 2 a.m., the Ford Explorer Ms. Grabowski was driving struck a guardrail, flipped over and ejected Ms. Madrid and Gabriel Diaz, 21, investigators said. Mr. Diaz, 21, said he was not badly hurt. Kareem Fahim (NYT)

The announcement fulfills Gov. George Pataki's pledge in his State of the State address in 2003 to make all cars sold in New York State adhere to the California standards. It also puts him on a direct collision course with the Bush administration, which has joined with the major automobile manufacturers in opposing the California program.

With darkness closing in, the hikers, most in their 40's and wearing sturdy boots, forged ahead, some not even bothering to turn on flashlights. As the sun's last light faded, a bright full moon was growing ever more clearly defined against the darkening sky.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Thailand Zoo Deal Draws Fire
description: Despite an outcry from conservationists, President Mwai Kibaki of Kenya and Prime Minister Thaksin Shanawatra of Thailand struck a deal to transfer 175 wild animals to a new zoo in the prime minister's hometown in northern Thailand. Among the animals to be relocated are zebras, hippos, flamingos, giraffes, African buffaloes and gazelles. "To export wildlife to a zoo is a completely deplorable action," said Richard Leakey, the former head of the Kenya Wildlife Service. Kenyan officials said the country would receive compensation for the cost of transporting the animals but would not be paid directly for them. The deal, however, is part of a wider effort to increase trade between the countries. The animals will be sent in small groups to determine how they adapt to the new location, officials said. "It is not harmful," said Chirau Ali Mwakwere, Kenya's foreign minister, who signed the deal Wednesday. Protesters were on hand at an appearance by Mr. Shanawatra yesterday, prompting him to say, "We did not come to take advantage of Kenya." Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Driving Around Manhattan, You Pay, Under One Traffic Idea
description: It is an idea that has been successful in London, and is now being whispered in the ears of City Hall officials after months of behind-the-scenes work by the Partnership for New York City, the city's major business association: congestion pricing.

title: Arts Guide
Paid Notice: Deaths   FREUMAN, HENRY, MD
description: FREUMAN--Henry, MD. Adored, cherished and beloved husband of Carol, father of David and Daniel, brother of Reuven and grandfather of Jason. Strong, elegant and a man of immeasurable grace, Henry brought enormous love to his family, intellectual rigor to his academic interests, and a brave heart to all of the challenges he met in life. After surviving the Holocaust, Henry immigrated to Israel and received his medical degree from Hadassah Medical School in Jerusalem. Affiliated with Lenox Hill and Beth Israel Kings Highway Hospitals, he provided compassionate care to his gynecological patients for over 40 years. His life is his inspired legacy to us. Funeral services Friday, November 11, 9:30 am at "The Riverside" 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in his memory may be made to The Lymphoma Research Foundation, 111 Broadway, 19th Floor, NYC 10006. His delightful presence will remain with us forever.

Arts, Briefly; Death Lifts 'Lost'
description: An estimated audience of 20.01 million tuned in for Wednesday's "Lost" to see Shannon (Maggie Grace, below) bite the dust. She was mistakenly shot and killed by Ana-Lucia (Michelle Rodriguez), who thought she was one of the island's dreaded "others." The program was the night's most-watched in Nielsen's estimates, and helped ABC win the 18-to-49 demographic for the night. But "Lost" alone couldn't lift the network to a No. 1 slot among total viewers; that victory went to CBS. Its lineup increased in audience size each hour from 8 to 11 p.m.: "Still Standing" (8.2 million), "Yes, Dear" (9.3 million), "Criminal Minds" (15.05 million) and "CSI: New York" (18.71 million). The second part of the "CSI" crossover with "CSI: Miami" helped the crime show squash its 10 p.m. competition, NBC's "Law & Order" (10.84 million) and ABC's "Invasion" (9.82 million). But one bright spot for NBC was the Pentagon drama "E-Ring," whose ratings have improved since it swapped slots with "The Apprentice: Martha Stewart" on Wednesdays. This week's episode delivered an audience of 9.78 million, winning the hour in total viewers.

description: Ninety-nine cents was an important figure in consumer pricing -- think Woolworth's -- before the iTunes Music Store came along, but it has become utterly canonical since then. Ninety-nine cents is the price of each of those downloadable songs, and now it is also the price of a few prime-time reruns from CBS and NBC. Beginning in 2006, viewers with the right equipment and the right cable service -- and, in the case of CBS, the right local affiliate -- will be able to download replays of currently popular television shows. ABC already plans to sell episodes of "Desperate Housewives" and "Lost" for the new video iPod at $1.99 apiece.

On Judy Garland's Stage, a Tribute to an Idol
description: Linda Eder was an 8-year-old girl sprawled on the green shag carpet of her parents' living room in Brainerd, Minn., watching black-and-white television when lightning struck and the heavens opened. That is more or less how she described her epiphanic first exposure to Judy Garland in "The Wizard of Oz" during her concert on Wednesday evening at Carnegie Hall. Suddenly, she knew who she was and what she wanted to do. Ms. Eder pointed out more than once that she was standing on the same stage where Garland made her legendary comeback in 1961. Another similarity: Both singers were born in Minnesota.

title: The Listings: Nov. 11 -- Nov. 17; 'CHRISTIAN SCHUMANN: VARIATIONS AND SUPPOSITIONS'
description: Known until now for his densely worked paintings of goofy cartoon imagery, Christian Schumann has taken a surprising turn to abstraction. He is now making atmospheric color fields, hard-edged stripe paintings ("Low Tide," above) and glowing, hourglass-shaped images. What remains from his earlier style is his propensity for finely grained graphic articulation: each painting is overlaid by a neatly brushed, see-through basket-weave grid, a kind of sheer netting that gives it a pixilated appearance. Up close you see that the colors of the weave pattern change subtly in response to the more broadly painted underlying areas. The paintings are absorbing and meditative, but something feels not fully realized about them. They seem tentative compared with the earlier, brashly comical works, and it looks as if Mr. Schumann is searching for something that so far has eluded his grasp. Three paintings are in Mr. Schumann's more familiar style: finely outlined cartoon landscapes with sprawling developments of rubbery architecture, roadways, cars and trucks. They are like collaborations between Yves Tanguy and R. Crumb, and though they appear more resolved than the abstractions, in the context of the show they look more like the end than the beginning of something. (Leo Koenig, 545 West 23rd Street, Chelsea, (212) 334-9255, through tomorrow.)

title: World Briefing | Africa: South Africa: Angry Commuters Burn Trains
description: Infuriated by a breakdown that halted local trains for 20 minutes, Johannesburg commuters set fire to 19 train cars and 9 engines at three Soweto-area stations on Wednesday, reducing some $6 million in equipment to cinders. A day earlier, commuters fed up with delays set fire to four commuter cars, and last month, 18 coaches and other railway carriages were destroyed. South Africa's commuter trains are riddled with breakdowns, partly because of poor maintenance and partly because of rampant thefts of critical electric cables by scavengers. No trains ran on the affected commuter line yesterday. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: A Conductor at the Keyboard
description: In their public lives, conductors make music at one remove, getting other musicians to play the notes, ideally in ways that reflect the conductor's ideas about tempo, tone, phrasing and balance. Most conductors are also instrumentalists, though, and it makes sense for them to put their hands on the note-making apparatus now and then. Dennis Russell Davies, who is between New York concerts with his Bruckner Orchestra Linz, is a superb pianist, and in recent years he has been performing in a duo with the pianist Maki Namekawa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HELLMAN, HENRY MARTIN
description: HELLMAN--Henry Martin. 85, of Lowell, IN. Professor Emeritus of Chemistry at New York University, died November 3, 2005. Beloved husband of the late Isabel (nee Paul) Hellman. He was born on July 4, 1920 in Gamla Nordsjo, Sweden, and immigrated to Gary, IN in 1927 with his family. He received a B.S. from Indiana University in 1943 and a Ph.D. in Chemistry from Purdue University in 1947. He joined the Dept. of Chemistry at NYU as an instructor the same year. He was promoted to Asst. Prof. in 1950, Assoc. Prof. in 1961 and Full Prof. in 1969. He served as Chairman of the Department from 1966 to 1970 and is remembered as a dedicated teacher by generations of NYU students. Hellman is survived by sister Maria Hellman Naslund of Umea, Sweden and brother Bertil Hellman of Saskatoon, Saskatchewan. He was the adored uncle and great-uncle of many nieces and nephews.

He graduated Harvard in 1960, has a Master's in mathematics from Yale, PhD in mathematics from UCLA, post graduate work in mathematics from Cambridge in England, law degree from UCLA. He was a man of many interest, ballet, theater, scuba diving, squash, bridge, marathon runner, animal lover, and world traveler. Survived by his companion of 22 years, Lillian Meyer, step daughters, Jenny Meyer of Brooklyn, Margot Hughes-Lopez of San Francisco, granddaughters, Maya and Nicole Lopez, and many relatives and friends. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Sentencing In 1994 Rape
description: A Ridgewood man convicted in September of raping a young woman in front of her 2-year-old daughter has been sentenced to 12 to 25 years in prison, District Attorney Richard A. Brown said yesterday. Hector Torres, 34, of Troutman Street, was convicted of rape and other charges after his DNA from a 1995 burglary conviction was matched to evidence collected at the scene of a 1994 rape. Mr. Torres was convicted of raping the woman after holding a knife at her daughter's throat and threatening to harm her. Prosecutors avoided the 10-year statute of limitations by originally charging Mr. Torres in 2003 under a "John Doe indictment," which cites the defendant's DNA profile when his identity is unknown.

description: If you are interested in starring in a one-person show, here's some advice: don't do it. This genre is already far too crowded and you would be better off working with dialogue instead. But if you must, here's some more advice: call Larry Moss. Over the last few years, Mr. Moss, above, the director and distinguished acting coach, has shaped and staged some of the best solo work in the city. His latest effort is directing "RFK," a biographical play about the Kennedy who might have been president, starring Jack Holmes as the title character. It is running at the Culture Project. When watching an actor directed by Mr. Moss, one gets the sense that each choice has been mulled over and decided with considerable intelligence, and each moment fits snugly into the whole. "The Syringa Tree," Pamela Gien's piece about the final years of apartheid South Africa, may be one of the most successful solo shows in recent years, and it grew out of an acting class conducted by Mr. Moss. "Who Is Floyd Stearn?" was one of the better confessional plays about family that I've seen. But Mr. Moss really impressed with the underrated "Runt of the Litter," an account of life in the N.F.L. starring a former jock and theater novice, Bo Eason, who made the most of his limited acting skills. To use a sports clich, the great coaches get the best out of their players. (Culture Project, 45 Bleecker Street, at Lafayette Street, East Village, (212) 253-9983.)

title: United hiring flight attendants

description: 8 P.M. (Nickelodeon) SPONGEBOB SQUAREPANTS -- Every pet owner who has ever unintentionally neglected his or her dog, cat, parrot or gekko and suffered from guilt later will feel SpongeBob's pain in tonight's "Where's Gary?" episode. Gary, SpongeBob's pet snail, is fed up with not being fed, much less cuddled and adored, and runs away from home. SpongeBob (above, with Gary) goes wild looking for him.

title: A Cyrano Story, but in the Land of Ranches and Rodeos
description: From London to Texarkana, Tex., theater companies are still mounting Edmond Rostand's 1897 verse swashbuckler "Cyrano de Bergerac." They can't resist the tale of the dazzling poet and swordsman who loved a beautiful and brilliant lady but feared that his outsize nose -- an object of insult and mockery -- would keep her from loving him. So, in a frenzy of self-sacrifice, he writes love letters to her in the name of his handsome but prosaic rival. And he suffers terribly.

title: On the Use of the Word Fratricide
description: Dan Langdale, Newton, Mass.: In your piece about Pat Tillman, you note in passing that his brother was in his platoon; you use the phrase friendly fire to note a possible cause of Pat Tillmans death; you refer to a possible cover-up of something darker and I find the word fratricide appearing twice, once in a quote from his mother. Would I correctly infer that you perceive the possibility that Pats brother is implicated in some dark way in Pats death? Or are you merely using fratricide as synonymous with death by friendly fire, considering those who accidentally killed him possibly included his brother?

title: The Fulton Fish Market Moves
description: The market is moving to a new $85 million refrigerated box in the Bronx.

title: New Question From Frank Rich:        Could Edward R. Murrow Exist Today?
description: George Clooneys movie Good Night, and Good Luck portrays a golden era in broadcast news when one crusading newsman, Edward R. Murrow, plays a crucial role in bringing down a demagogic politician, Joe McCarthy. Murrow functioned in the pre-cable, pre-Internet media world in which there were but three network news divisions and far less news available (as measured by air time or, for that matter, newspaper inches) to American consumers than the bounty available now. The movie expresses a certain nostalgia for that world, but were we in fact better off in that era? Could a Murrow exist in our current news culture? Would we want him to?

title: Women in the Work Force
description: Twenty years ago, womens work was secondary to mens work. Men were the primary breadwinners in most families and women worked if they had to. If a husbands wages dropped, his wife was likely to enter the labor force. If a husbands wages rose, his wife was likely to drop out of the labor force. Womens labor force participation was, as the economists say, elastic.

Baber, Chula Vista, Calif.: Gangsta culture  machismo, misogyny, brutality and gang warfare over women and turf  isnt a U.S. import even if the packaging comes from American ghettos. Its the ethos of the heroic age: check out The Illiad and the norm for pre-modern societies generally, including traditional societies in the developing world and the underclass in affluent countries.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'CSI' Waxes While 'The O.C.' Wanes
description: Not only did CBS win Thursday night, as it does nearly every week, but its "CSI" also delivered the largest audience of any program so far in the fall season. "CSI," the forensics crime series that is the No. 1 show on television, drew 29.48 million viewers. That nearly tripled the number of total viewers of "The Apprentice" (11.16 million), which was second place in the 9 p.m. hour for NBC. CBS's "Survivor" (19.1 million) also brought in its best ratings of the season, as one contestant, the former N.F.L. quarterback Gary Hogeboom, saved himself from being axed by finding a hidden immunity idol. CBS's "Without a Trace" also won its hour among total viewers, with 20.72 million, but NBC's "ER" (15.4 million) won 10 p.m. among 18-to-49-year-olds. On Fox, "The OC" (5.73 million) appears to be waning. It finished third among adults 18 to 49, but it was barely ahead of WB's "Smallville" and ABC's "Alias" for that age group. KATE AURTHUR

title: The History of Trade, Part 2
description: During the 1980's, the United States government, egged on by a Detroit auto industry terrified of Japan's low-cost, fuel-efficient cars, imposed quotas on imports of many Hondas and Toyotas. So Honda and Toyota -- and Mitsubishi and Mazda and Nissan -- started making luxury cars that could challenge Detroit in a far more profitable market. The results can be seen on the highways and byways of America: Acuras, Lexuses and boatloads of other high-end Japanese cars, which have steadily put the squeeze on a market niche previously dominated by the Americans and the Europeans.

title: Arts, Briefly; Record-Setting Buyer Identified
description: The mystery surrounding the buyer of David Smith's monumental sculpture at Sotheby's on Wednesday night is over. Joanne Heyler, director and chief curator of the Broad Art Foundation in Los Angeles, confirmed yesterday that Eli Broad, the Los Angeles financier, had purchased "Cubi XXVIII," right. Mr. Broad paid $23.8 million for the elegantly composed steel sculpture, the last work in Smith's most desirable series. It was the highest price paid for any artwork during the last two weeks of Impressionist, modern and contemporary art auctions, and the highest ever paid for a work of contemporary art sold at auction. "He bought the sculpture for his own personal collection," Ms. Heyler said of Mr. Broad in a telephone interview. "But he realizes that it is a museum-quality piece, and so he intends to lend it to museums." Besides gracing his home in Los Angeles, Ms. Heyler said, the sculpture will be displayed at the Broad Contemporary Art Museum, a new building that will be part of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. This week Mr. Broad also bought a 1961 painting by Cy Twombly, "Untitled (Rome)," for $7.9 million, also at Sotheby's. "That was also for his personal collection," Ms. Heyler said. "But it, too, will go on museum walls." CAROL VOGEL

title: Such an Unhappy Sex Life? But Such a Glorious Reign
description: Of all the legendary women who've proven themselves poorly skilled in the area of romantic management, few have had greater cause to lay blame on inheritance than the first Queen Elizabeth. She was, of course, a daughter of Henry VIII and only 3 when her mother, Anne Boleyn, received her beheading. The king had presumably grown tired of Anne's impertinence, tired of her commoner's habit of breastfeeding. He had charged her with adultery and moved to have the marriage annulled and his daughter declared a bastard. Stepmothers followed, and one knows how that goes.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Protest Over Tent Camp Move
description: The police in Muzaffarabad, the flattened capital of Pakistani-controlled Kashmir, wielded batons against a crowd of 200 earthquake survivors protesting an order to leave their makeshift camp because it lacked drinking water and adequate sanitation, Pakistani officials said. Several people were injured, and 10 were arrested. The police say they want to move the residents of the crowded 350-tent camp into two new and bigger ones in the city with better conditions. "We will use force, if we have to, to shift these people tomorrow," a police official said. Salman Masood (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KILKENNY, ALICE

title: BUSINESS BRIEFS
description: Sony Suspends CD Piracy Protection Software That Could Hide Harmful Code in PC's Sony BMG Music Entertainment said yesterday that it would suspend production of CD's with copy-protection technology that could be exploited by virus writers to try to hide malicious code on PC's. The decision came after 10 days of controversy around the technology, which is designed to limit the number of copies that can be made and to prevent a computer user from making unprotected MP3s of the music. Security experts blasted the technology because it uses techniques to hide itself on hard drives and could be used by virus writers to make malicious code invisible. (CNET News.com)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: U.S. Opens Southern Consulate
description: The United States opened a consulate in Juba, the primitive, hardscrabble town that is the capital of Southern Sudan. Robert B. Zoellick, the deputy secretary of state, officiated. The United States helped broker the peace agreement this year that ended a 21-year civil war between the mainly Muslim north and the Christian and animist south. It calls for power sharing, and Mr. Zoellick has been pushing the Sudanese government to implement its terms. Officials said the new consulate was intended to demonstrate that the United States will remain engaged. A senior official said two diplomats had so far applied to be consul general in Juba, where there is no indoor plumbing. Joel Brinkley (NYT)

There was no finer colleague, friend, father, husband. His devotion to his family and our firm and his constant counsel, in law and life, will be reminders to us all to enrich and savor every moment. Our heartfelt condolences to Diane and their children, Aaron, Rachel and Brian, Jay's parents and the rest of his family. Jay made us feel like family, and we will always be proud to have known and worked with him.
