description: GREENWALD--Carrie Weisberg, died peacefully in the Bronx, NY at 95 years. A social worker and for more than 50 years, a teacher in New York City schools, she remained independent through her final days. She was a loving wife to Herbert Greenwald, loving mother to John and Mark, loving grandmother to Joshua & Rachel. A great lover of the arts, poetry, ideas and nature, she was an engaging and strong willed spirit to the end. A private service will be held.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Serbia: U.N. Court Demands Suspects
description: The United Nations war crimes tribunal stepped up its pressure on Serbia to deliver its top fugitives to the court by the end of this year. Failing to do so could jeopardize Serbia's ongoing talks for membership with NATO and the European Union, said Zoran Stankovic, the Serbian defense minister. He said the warning came from the tribunal's president, Judge Theodor Meron, who met with Serbian officials in Belgrade, the capital, including Mr. Stankovic. In a statement, Judge Meron said the fugitives, who include Ratko Mladic and Radovan Karadzic, "are within the reach" of the Serbian authorities. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILBERLING, DIANE
description: SILBERLING--Diane. On November 10, 2005. Cherished aunt, great aunt and great great aunt to so many in the Silberling family, who mourn her passing. A masterful wordsmith, Aunt Dina had a brilliant mind and intense passion for the arts, travel and New York City. Her impeccable taste and sophistication made her the quintessential New Yorker. She had a long and distinguished career as administrator for the Department of Dermatology at the NYU School f Medicine. She had a deep appreciation for Brotherhood Synagogue where she found community and caring. Just short of her 90th birthday, Aunt Dina was preceded in death by sisters Anne, Lillian, Sau, Suche, Fannie and Belle, and brothers Lou, Shim and Meyer. The family extends its deepest gratitude to Drs. Hector and George Castro and the medical staff at Cabrini Medical Center and to Cirila, Marcela and Latchmin who provided her with such loving care for so many years. Yet film directors have often fared better when they have applied their screen experience to staging an opera in a traditional theater.

title: Fish Market's Salty Souls Bid South St. a Misty Adieu
description: Anthony Bencivenga, better known as Good Looking Anthony, was not about to get all mushy about a bunch of fish moving uptown.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, PHYLLIS
description: COHEN--Phyllis, 93. Formerly of Brooklyn died on Friday morning. She is survived by two sons, Peter C. Cohen of New York City and Dr. Laurence D. Cohen of Richmond, MA, sister Hannah Gornick of New York City, and four grandchildren. A graveside funeral service will be on Sunday at 12:00 Noon at the Mt. Pleasant Cemetery in Hawthorne, NY. For information Devanny-Condron Funeral Home, 40 Maplewood Avenue, Pittsfield, MA. 01201.

title: Desperate Search for Justice: One Man vs. China
description: CHAOHU, China - At his most desperate, when he had no more borrowed money for his son's legal defense, Xie Yujun went to a hospital. He knew of China's black market in body parts. He wanted to sell his eyes. He was refused.

title: Leonard Block, 93, Chief of Drug Company, Is Dead
description: Leonard N. Block, the retired chairman and chief executive of the Block Drug Company, a philanthropist and a former treasurer of Lincoln Center, died on Wednesday at his home on the Upper East Side. He was 93.

title: Empowered Sisterhood's Take on Vulnerable Lady Day
description: Billie Holiday has been many things to many people over the years: matchless jazz singer, poignant symbol, cautionary tale. In "Billie & Me," a touring concert production, she's a patron saint of female empowerment. Her projected image overlooked the stage at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night, where five diverse singers gathered in her name.

title: When Terrorism Strikes Jordan

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GARSON, EUGENE
description: GARSON--Eugene. May 8, 1926--November 12, 1998. An everlasting bond of love and devotion can never be broken. Gloria

title: Staying Vigilant, When Troubles Run in the Family
description: It was about a year ago that Sally Kilkenny really connected with her son, Rennick. He had lost his job, and was having problems with his wife and run-ins with the law. But he was spending a lot of time calling his mother in New York from Missouri, and she was helping him emotionally and financially.

title: Mayor Says Traffic Fees Are Not on City's Agenda
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he was not considering any plan for congestion pricing, which would charge drivers for entering the most heavily traveled areas of Manhattan at the busiest times of day.

title: Little Artist Versus Big Dealer in Sidewalk Showdown
description: Eric Doeringer is an artist who makes paintings. But he does not exactly obsess over them, wrestling Pollock-like with his muse. In fact, as he explained the other day, "I make them in batches -- so I can usually do somewhere from 6 to 15 in a day."

description: Correction Appended

title: Injury Takes Breath Away From Giants Linebacker
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 11 - Nick Greisen may be tough enough to play an N.F.L. game, but just do not tell him a joke or put pepper under his nose.

title: Power Failure Disrupts Queens Subways
description: Subway service on the E, F, R and V lines in Queens was interrupted for more than two hours yesterday, trapping some passengers on trains in tunnels for more than an hour, after an unexplained power failure occurred at a signal room near the Woodhaven Boulevard station.

title: Which Way For Amtrak?
description: To the Editor:

title: Atlanta Museum's New Pitch: Come for the Architecture, Stay for the Art
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 11 - More than steel or concrete or any other kind of durable material, the Italian architect Renzo Piano works with light. He is fussy about the kind he wants, too. The 1,000 conical skylights sailing across the roof of one of the new buildings he has designed for the High Museum of Art here, for example, are angled to catch only northern light, prized by artists for its softness. The controlled brightness in the galleries below recreates the tawny moment when a moth-eaten cloud will pass in front of the sun. It is the kind of light that makes colors pop and wood glow. It is the kind of light that makes paint look magical.

title: Hofstra Panels on Clinton Attempt to Outguess History
description: Hundreds of political scientists and former members of the Clinton administration met at Hofstra University yesterday to debate the legacy of President Bill Clinton, part of a three-day gathering that was part college reunion, part policy powwow and part dogfight.

title: For Two Players, Sometimes a Matter of Predominance, Sometimes of Equality
description: The fine young violinist Leila Josefowicz and her pianist, John Novacek, were the right musicians in the right place at the medium-size Zankel Hall on Thursday night. Music professionals, colleagues, sophisticated listeners and friends made the hall look comfortably full though not completely so. A good part of Ms. Josefowicz's program found her alone onstage. Esa-Pekka Salonen's "Lachen verlernt" begins as a lingering Gypsy lament. Tremolos make the music more nervous and lead at last to a point of high anxiety. A calming little coda, like a sedative, brings this brief piece to an end. The other solo work was Mark Grey's "San Andreas Suite," an elegant showpiece calculated to make the instrument and a strong performer playing it appear at their best. In the outer movements, Ms. Josefowicz roamed around a large repertory of traditional virtuoso effects. The slow movement is simple melody with left-hand pizzicato accompaniment.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "These baseless attacks send the wrong signal to our troops and to an enemy that is questioning America's will."

title: Vazquez Asks to Be Traded Someplace Closer to Home
description: Javier Vazquez figured that his future was secure when he signed a four-year, $45 million contract extension with the Yankees in 2004. The Yankees expected Vazquez to evolve into their ace, but he sputtered and was part of the trade that brought Randy Johnson from the Diamondbacks before the 2005 season.

title: Such an Unhappy Sex Life? But Such a Glorious Reign
description: Of all the legendary women who've proven themselves poorly skilled in the area of romantic management, few have had greater cause to lay blame on inheritance than the first Queen Elizabeth. She was, of course, a daughter of Henry VIII and only 3 when her mother, Anne Boleyn, received her beheading. The king had presumably grown tired of Anne's impertinence, tired of her commoner's habit of breastfeeding. He had charged her with adultery and moved to have the marriage annulled and his daughter declared a bastard. Stepmothers followed, and one knows how that goes.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: North Korea and U.S. Spar, Causing Talks to Stall
description: BEIJING, Nov. 11 - The United States and North Korea sparred over financial penalties and whether to negotiate a nuclear freeze or focus on full disarmament, as six-nation nuclear talks ended Friday on the same inconclusive and irresolute note they began with three days earlier.

title: Six Flags Asks Shareholders to Reject Offer From Investor
description: Six Flags, the theme-park operator, said yesterday that shareholders should reject an offer by the owner of the Washington Redskins, Daniel Snyder, to raise his stake in the company. It also said it had received other takeover offers.

title: Licensed to Rebrand
description: EVERY up brings a down. Every big brings a small. And as fans of James Bond say, every "Moonraker" brings a "For Your Eyes Only." Which is to say, Bond movies have a tendency to get bigger, more explosive, more outrageous, until someone on the inside says, "Hey, this isn't 007!" and the next movie is tougher, leaner.

description: To the Editor:

title: Low-Cost Credit for Low-Cost Items
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 11 - Mrcia Regina da Cruz, a 40-year-old janitor and mother of three, decided to splurge.

title: When It Has Its Swagger, Miami Is Tough to Beat
description: CORAL GABLES, Fla., Nov. 9 - Kenny Phillips came here knowing about the swagger. Growing up in Miami, he had heard about it for years. He had heard about Warren Sapp and Ray Lewis, the midfield rumble at the Cotton Bowl, the camouflage fatigues.

title: Today's Top Games
description: No. 12 Florida (7-2) at South Carolina (6-3)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Annan's Son Wins Libel Case
description: The Sunday Times of London agreed to pay a substantial sum of money to the son of the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, over an article in the newspaper in January that claimed he was involved in a plan to sell millions of dollars worth of Iraqi oil. Earlier, officials examining the United Nations oil-for-food program in Iraq investigated the allegations against Mr. Annan's son, Kojo, but found no evidence to support The Times's claim. The paper also accepted that its charges were untrue, apologized to Kojo Annan and agreed to pay his legal costs. Sarah Lyall (NYT)

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some copies yesterday about Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice's visit to Iraq misstated the location of Hilla, one of three cities where provincial reconstruction teams have been created. It is in southern Iraq, not in the north. (Go to Article)

title: Terms of the deal
Arts, Briefly
description: Not only did CBS win Thursday night, as it does nearly every week, but its "CSI" also delivered the largest audience of any program so far in the fall season. "CSI," the forensics crime series that is the No. 1 show on television, drew 29.48 million viewers. That nearly tripled the number of total viewers of "The Apprentice" (11.16 million), which was second place in the 9 p.m. hour for NBC. CBS's "Survivor" (19.1 million) also brought in its best ratings of the season, as one contestant, the former N.F.L. quarterback Gary Hogeboom, saved himself from being axed by finding a hidden immunity idol. CBS's "Without a Trace" also won its hour among total viewers, with 20.72 million, but NBC's "ER" (15.4 million) won 10 p.m. among 18-to-49-year-olds. On Fox, "The OC" (5.73 million) appears to be waning. It finished third among adults 18 to 49, but it was barely ahead of WB's "Smallville" and ABC's "Alias" for that age group. KATE AURTHUR

title: Getting People to Pay for Radio
description: XM Satellite Radio plays music that ranges "from Yo-Yo Ma to Snoop Dogg" and talk that extends "from Bill O'Reilly to Al Franken," the company's president and chief executive, Hugh Panero, is fond of saying.

title: Bridge; When It Was Best Not to Play the Normal Heart
description: Most top bridge players have one particular type of deal that appeals to them more than any other. A friend from Cardiff, the capital city of Wales, lives for complex squeeze endings. I particularly enjoy deals in which the "normal" play is wrong. One of the trademarks of an expert is spotting the correct line in these abnormal settings. The diagramed deal, which occurred during the Round 13 Bermuda Bowl match between Egypt and Italy at the recent world championships in Portugal, is an excellent example. At the time, these two teams were leading the event. (Egypt lost to Sweden in the quarterfinals; Italy won the gold medals.) The match was shown live to more than 3,000 people on Bridge Base Online and a few hundred spectators in the auditorium at the playing site.

title: When Terrorism Strikes Jordan (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Battle Is Drawn in G.O.P. Over How Conservative to Be
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 - If there was a message to be drawn from this week's Republican meltdown over tax and spending cuts, it was this: Conservative hopes for an economic agenda of big ideas and sweeping change are in tatters for the moment.

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: '93 Bombing Suspect In Custody
description: One of India's most wanted suspects, implicated in bombings in Mumbai in 1993 that killed more than 250 people, was extradited from Portugal and ordered into custody, paving the way for what is to be one of the most closely watched trials in the country. The suspect, Abu Salem, is accused of being a ringleader in the explosions in Mumbai, formerly Bombay, believed to be retaliation for the killing of Muslims in riots that followed the destruction of a 16th-century mosque four months earlier. His extradition from Portugal, where he was serving a sentence for possession of forged documents, came after a three-year legal battle in which India, which has the death penalty, assured Portugal that Mr. Salem would not be executed if convicted. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: National Briefs
description: WEST

title: Two Views From the Top
description: PIERCEFIELD, N.Y. - Across the Adirondacks, steel fire towers still jut from rocky summits with fanciful names: Mount Arab, Poke-O-Moonshine, Loon Lake Mountain and others. They are relics of an age of fire protection when observers scanned the wilderness from dawn to dusk, April to October, looking for smoke.

title: Report Clears Westchester in Death at Amusement Park
description: HAWTHORNE, N.Y., Nov. 11 - A Westchester County report on an amusement park fatality said three girls on a water ride saw the victim standing in the water wet from the waist down, an indication that he probably climbed out of his boat rather than fell.

title: Pacers Easily Handle Shorthanded Nets
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 11 - For the Nets, trailing by 27 points and eventually losing, 102-90, to the Indiana Pacers on Friday night may not be a cause for alarm. Sound defeats happen in the N.B.A. But a couple of things that are not happening may be worrisome.

description: Socking away that first million used to be so simple.

title: Art Promoted Heavily (Even in Your Mailbox)

It is one more sign that some New York art galleries of the contemporary kind have more money than they know what to do with, and that the competition for attention-getting frivolities in the overpopulated art scene is on the rise.

title: Trip to Police Lot Ends in Arrests
description: A 19-year-old Queens woman who was the driver in a fatal S.U.V. accident was arrested yesterday with two of her friends and her 51-year-old mother after they tried to retrieve belongings from the impounded vehicle, the police said. They were charged with criminal trespassing.

title: Our Faith in Science
description: WASHINGTON - SCIENCE has always fascinated me. As a child in Tibet, I was keenly curious about how things worked. When I got a toy I would play with it a bit, then take it apart to see how it was put together. As I became older, I applied the same scrutiny to a movie projector and an antique automobile.

description: The co-founders of Amerindo Investment Advisors, Alberto W. Vilar and Gary Tanaka, defrauded at least seven investors in addition to Lily Cates, the mother of the actress Phoebe Cates, the Securities and Exchange Commission said in court documents.

title: Admission Test's Scoring Quirk Throws Balance Into Question
description: For weeks, Joshua N. Feinman had graded practice tests to help his daughter prepare for New York City's specialized high school exam. Then one day, he took a hard look at the scoring chart from her private test-prep class and was stunned by how the verbal and math scores added up.

"The Green Table" (1932) is four years younger than "Apollo" (1928), not five.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KNOWLES, BARBARA RUTHERFURD
description: KNOWLES--Barbara Rutherfurd, 83. Died Sunday November 6, 2005 in Aiken, SC. Mrs. Knowles was born June 14, 1922 in New York, NY, the daughter of Winthrop C. and Lucy M. Rutherfurd. Mrs. Knowles was the widow of well-known amateur golfer Robert Winthrop "Bobby" Knowles, Jr. Surviving are two daughters, Lucy and Alice; two grandchildren, Kit and Martin; and two brothers, Hugo and Guy Rutherfurd. Memorials to the Green Boundary Foundation, Memorial Garden Fund, 780 Whiskey Rd., Aiken, SC 29801. www.shellhouseriversfuneral home.com

description: SELBST--Ronnie. (nee Appel), 52. Of West Orange, New Jersey, native of Brooklyn. Graduate of MIT and Rutgers Law School with highest honors from both. Funeral services November 13, 10:30 AM at Bnai Keshet, 99 South Fullerton Ave., Montclair, NJ. Interment at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI. Beloved mother and friend. Survived by children Andrew and Vanessa, parents Sylvia and Hy Appel, sister Sheila and brother Ken.

title: Conservative Episcopalians Warn Church That It Must Change Course or Face Split
description: PITTSBURGH, Nov. 11 - Conservative leaders of the Episcopal Church U.S.A. and their Anglican counterparts from overseas intensified their warnings Friday about the possibility of a schism in the Anglican Communion if the Episcopal Church did not renounce the consecration of gay bishops and the blessing of same-sex unions.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article and a picture caption on Nov. 3 about an exhibition of futuristic taxicab designs misstated the name of the institution where it is on view. And the Streetscapes column on Oct. 16, about efforts to preserve Madison Square Garden, used an outdated name. The institution, which was the Parsons School of Design, changed its name in August to Parsons the New School for Design; it is a division of the New School.

title: Supersize Comeback for Fast Food
description: TWO years ago, KFC was trying to market its fried chicken parts as a healthy alternative to pizza and burgers. Bob Garfield, writing in Advertising Age, ranted that the company had been misleading in its effort to sell America on the health benefits of its "chicken-flavored doughnuts."

title: Microsoft Settles Antitrust Suit Over Windows in South Korea
description: SEOUL, Nov. 11 - Microsoft will pay the South Korean Internet portal operator Daum Communications $30 million to settle an antitrust suit over the bundling of an instant-messaging program into its Windows software, Microsoft said Friday.

title: Heres to You, Cerebral Warriors of the Green Felt
description: In his column in this newspaper on Nov. 4, Harvey Araton seconded the Yankees' warning to Alex Rodriguez to stay out of illegal (though widely tolerated) New York poker clubs.

title: A Baby's Death, Grim as the Life of His Mother
description: Her parents were once homeless. A family member says that her mother and her only sister died of AIDS. Her childhood passed in a dismal drift: housing projects, group homes where others stole her clothes. She lived in drug-infested city shelters; she worked in a fast-food place, a relative said, where bosses found her "slow." She cut school. She cleaned bathrooms. And even in her 20's wet the bed.

title: For 'CSI,' Press A1
description: Don't touch that dial. A video-on-demand venture that CBS announced this week was just one part of an urgent plan by the nation's most watched television network to prove to investors that a media company built around broadcast television has legs in the digital world.

title: Jury Finds That Former Analyst Misled Investors
description: A federal jury found yesterday that a former analyst at Robertson Stephens, Paul Johnson, violated federal securities laws by omitting from his research reports important facts about his holdings.

title: BUSINESS BRIEFS
description: Canada has negotiated an airline trade liberalization agreement with the United States, Canada's transportation minister, Jean Lapierre, left, said yesterday. The deal stops short of allowing American airlines to move passengers between Canadian destinations. But it will make it easier for carriers based in the United States to transport passengers and cargo from Canadian cities to third countries. Canadian airlines will gain a similar right in the United States. "It is my hope that this agreement will encourage the development of new markets, new services, lower prices and greater competition," Mr. Lapierre said in a statement. The agreement is scheduled to become effective on Sept. 1, 2006. Ian Austen (NYT)

description: THIS was a week for major course corrections, in mergers, in markets, in media and in the financial statements of the granddaddy of industrial companies, General Motors.

title: Bush Contends Partisan Critics Hurt War Effort
description: TOBYHANNA, Pa., Nov. 11 - President Bush on Friday sharply criticized Democrats who have accused him of misleading the nation about the threat from Iraq's weapons programs, calling their criticism "deeply irresponsible" and suggesting that they are undermining the war effort.

description: HAAS--Rhoda Willner. You are remembered with love. Jane, Jay, Stella and Abbie Willner

title: German Coalition Is Declared After Delicate Talks
description: FRANKFURT, Nov. 11 - Germany's two major political parties on Friday sealed an agreement to govern the country together under Angela Merkel, who would become the country's first female chancellor.

title: What-If Decisions That Need to Be Made
description: WANT a quick way to cast a pall over a conversation? Ask those present if they've appointed a guardian for their children in the event that, God forbid, both parents should die.

title: Trying to Wean Internet Users From Free
description: PEOPLE hate, hate, hate to subscribe to things on the Internet," Microsoft's chairman, Bill Gates, said a few weeks ago.

title: Rice, in Stops in Iraq, Urges Sunnis to Reject Insurgency
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 11 - Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice visited a troubled Sunni stronghold in northern Iraq on Friday and then met with Iraqi leaders here in the capital, urging disaffected Sunnis in both places to reject the insurgency and address their grievances by voting in the parliamentary elections five weeks from now.

title: Playing With Fire
description: It certainly is a relief that the Senate is finally getting around to doing the job it so shamefully refused to do four years ago, after the 9/11 attacks: requiring the administration to follow the law and the Geneva Conventions in dealing with prisoners taken by the military and intelligence operatives.

title: Greetings, Newspaper Style
description: YouAve probably seen those Web sites that let you send free greeting cards by e-mail. But you probably havenAt seen one as clever as this one (http://www.atbcards.com).

title: With the Future in Flux, Anxiety About Keeping Life on Hold
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 5 - As a child, when Shantel Reddick dribbled her basketball up and down Delery Street in New Orleans, she drew comfort from the idea that the neighbors knew the very rhythm of her bounce. By college age, though, she longed to liberate herself from the vigilance of a community where everybody knew everybody else's business. She escaped to Atlanta on an athletic scholarship and started an independent life there.

title: Corrections

description: To the Editor:

title: Postcards From a Tax Holiday
description: PepsiCo recently followed in the footsteps of Hewlett-Packard, Pfizer and other big American corporations by initiating layoffs -- even as it takes advantage of a huge tax break that was supposed to generate cash for hiring.

title: A Year After Arafat's Death, Quiet Homage
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, Nov. 11 - On the first anniversary of Yasir Arafat's death, a small and subdued crowd of Palestinians paid tribute on Friday at his grave site, where he was buried after a tumultuous funeral.

title: Politics and the French Riots
description: A political contest has been taking place over who among France's politicians will gain and who will lose from the rioting.

title: The East Village, Then and Now
description: Nothing better bookends the changes that have swept through the East Village over the past decade than the original version of "Rent" and the musical's new incarnation on film.

title: Soft, Cuddly and Lashed to the Front of a Truck
description: Grille-mounted stuffed animals form a compelling yet little-studied aspect of the urban streetscape.

title: Homeless in Zimbabwe
description: The urban-demolition campaign aimed at slum dwellers has rendered thousands of impoverished citizens homeless.

title: Colleen Fitzgerald, William Shanahan
description: Colleen Catherine Fitzgerald and William Patrick Shanahan were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier in Manhattan. The Rev. John F. Garvey, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated, and Sister Kathryn E. King, a Roman Catholic nun and an aunt of the bride, participated in the ceremony.

title: Their Highbrow Hatred of Us
description: I applaud Traub's insights regarding the awarding of this year's Nobel Prize in Literature to Harold Pinter. I wonder if the value of an author's work, according to the Swedish Academy, has come to lie more in his or her politics than in actual literary merit. Whether we happen to agree with the current presidential administration's policy in Iraq or not, there is a great danger in equating literary merit or vision with an ideological position -- either of the left or of the right.

title: From Beethoven, a Bit of the Strange
description: IN the early 1960's, the cellist Mstislav Rostropovich and the pianist Sviatoslav Richter, old friends from their conservatory days in Moscow, met several times in Austria to record Beethoven's five sonatas for cello and piano. Back then, these works were concert rarities. Only the A major Sonata (No. 3) turned up now and then. The two early sonatas were generally considered quirky, hypercharged and a little strange; the two late sonatas struck many as mystifying, abrupt and downright strange.

title: Now Playing at Fidelity: Magellan, Unplugged
description: WHAT to do when blue-chip stocks are going nowhere? For a growing number of investors, the answer seems simple: go anywhere in search of higher returns. Fidelity Investments, the mutual fund giant, is embracing this approach in hopes of moving its flagship stock fund, the $51 billion Magellan fund, out of the doldrums.

title: Putting on the Blintz
description: JERSEY CITY - THIS is Tania's second appearance in the New Jersey section. Nine years ago, a brief review in the Quick Bite column spoke in awestruck tones about the restaurant's cold borscht: "fluorescent refreshingly tangy criminally cheap."

title: ON THE MARKET
description: Condo in a Castle $1,495,000 CONNECTICUT: 705 Weed Street, New Canaan A three-floor condo in a mansion built in the 1920's. The 1,948-square-foot unit has three bedrooms and two full- and two half-baths. Mary Jane Swanson, William Raveis Real Estate (203) 975-2205, www.raveis.com TAXES: $7,938 a year; common charges $988 a month PROS: The mansion's cavernous front foyer and expansive back lawns lend grandeur to this condo. CONS: There is no dining room.

title: Above the Arctic Circle, Answering the Call of the Wild
description: WE were skiing along the edge of a frozen lake, deep in the snowy mountains of northern Sweden, fueled by coffee and swaddled in high-tech fabrics, when we saw our first reindeer. A stampeding herd came over a ridge and rushed down toward us. Behind them a herdsman chased on a snowmobile, his battered machine kicking up a glittering cloud of Arctic snow.

title: Letters
description: The End of Pensions

title: And Ask to Rebury Ancient Remains
description: The Shinnecock nation is asking Suffolk County to allow the reburial of what appear to be charred bone fragments of two ancient Indians near where they were exposed by recent storm erosion in Indian Island County Park.

title: 'In Command of History'
description: Had Churchill won the election of 1945, he would probably not have written his memoirs-certainly not in the form they did take. A further spell in office for such an exhausted man, assuming he survived, would have sapped his energy and dulled his appetite for any major writing project. But while electoral defeat made possible literary triumphs, Churchill did not retire from politics and statecraft. Such was the scale of his defeat in 1945 that he burned for political vindication, and the story of The Second World War is inextricably bound up with his zeal to keep on making history. Nor, despite expectations, did he embark straightaway on the war memoirs. He was to take the plunge only when the conditions were right, and they took time to establish. It was not until the spring of 1946 that Churchill resolved the conundrum: to write or not to write.

title: Who Are You? Why Are You Here?
description: THE 60th edition of Who's Who in America, that venerable guide to American achievement, was published last week. The familiar two-volume "big red book," a librarian's Vanity Fair, recognizes 109,000 people and, by their inclusion, recommends them to posterity and to America's collective memory. Kind of like a magazine cover that stays on the stands forever.

title: 'The Norton Anthology of Children's Literature': Gingerbread and Giant Peaches

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   READ, GARDNER
description: READ--Gardner. Died on November 10 at the age of 92 at his home in Manchester-bythe-Sea, MA. Composer of more than 150 orchestral, choral and chamber works and pieces for the piano, organ and solo voice; author of 10 books on musical composition and notation; conductor; international lecturer on contemporary American music; and Professor Emeritus of Composition at Boston University School of Fine & Applied Arts, he will live on in his music and in the hearts of all who loved him. He was born January 2, 1913 in Evanston, Illinois. His wife Vail Payne Read died January 28, 2003. He is survived by his daughter Cynthia of Ossining, NY. A memorial concert will be announced later. Contributions in his memory should be sent to The MacDowell Colony, 100 High Street, Peterborough, NH 03458.

title: American Foreign Policy, in a Word
description: To the Editor:

title: Creatures From the Blueish Lagoon
description: ON a recent Saturday afternoon, Bonnie Ralston and her husband, Mark Yarm, settled into a sofa at HomeCourt, a furniture store in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. Atop a nearby table, in a 30-gallon aquarium, a little school of silvery killifish swayed and shimmered. A transparent shrimp danced across a bed of colorful pebbles. A blue crab batted at a golf ball with a fiery claw.

title: The Need for Speed
description: THE closest we come to free flight in our lives is not when we take off in an airplane. It is when we drive our cars. The speed, altitude, centrifugal forces and sensations of flying that we experience behind the wheel of an S.U.V., a sports car or, in my case, an economy box, let us feel what it is like to be a bird. This partly explains why we love our cars, preferring this mode of locomotion to any other, even walking and running, for which we are supremely adapted.

title: EU voting this weekon blacklist of airlines
What's a Modern Girl to Do?
description: Torn between "the Art Deco glamour of the 30's movies" and "the brazen new world of hard-charging feminists," Maureen Dowd explores the choices. I was intrigued by the photograph of Dowd wearing red shoes. They reminded me of the ones Dorothy wore in "The Wizard of Oz." Will Dowd click those heels as Dorothy did, saying, "There's no place like home"? A home where she will be "out of the work force" and without sarcasm? I hope not, because the Op-Ed page wouldn't be the same without her.

title: The Last Scone
description: ON Jackson Avenue in Long Island City, Queens, the Ten63 cafe chronicles the news of the day on a colorful, always-changing sidewalk chalkboard. The chalkboard has featured announcements of every sort and importance, from the demolition of smokestacks on a local-factory-turned-condos to the engagement (and subsequent breakup) of Paris Hilton.

title: Mammograms: Weighing the Risks
description: To the Editor:

title: On Location in the Homeland
description: Do you remember that restaurant scene in "Quiz Show," where John Turturro is told to take the dive? It took me weeks to find that place. And it wasn't even a restaurant. It was the old Grolier Club, between Madison and Park -- you've got to think creatively. That's my job. That's what a location scout does. The director gives me a script or a storyboard, and I search for the settings that will make his vision happen. I've been in the business for 25 years, done production work, been a location scout since 1991. The job's still the same as it was, but since 9/11, the game has changed a bit.

description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 13 - A suspected ringleader in the synchronized bomb blasts that struck the Indian capital late last month has been arrested, the police said today, asserting that the suspect has links to a Pakistan-based militant group called Lashkar-e-Taiba.

They were a distinct minority in the country, but they did have a certain cohesion and a more or less consistent view of the world, built on a faith in limited government.

title: Following the Union Money
description: New York City's system of public campaign financing has become indispensable to democracy on the local level. It has been good for candidates, good for government, and good for the city. It has gone a long way toward regulating money from special interests, while generously matching funds for candidates who can raise a fair amount from smaller, individual contributors. That has brought more everyday people into the political process.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENBERG, SAMUEL L.
description: ROSENBERG -- Samuel L. Born on June 21, 1909 in Odessa, Ukraine. Emigrated to the United States in 1911 with his parents and three sisters, Ann Weitzenberg (died 1998), Eva Blackman and Marcia Hoffman. Preceded in death by wife of 67 years, Natalie "Netty" Rosenberg (nee Baer). Survived by three children Morton (Linda), Harvey (Naomi), and Joel. Five grandchildren and twenty great-grandchildren also survive. Previously employed by Astoria Federal Bank in Forest Hills. Service to be held Sunday November 13, 2005 at 1:00 PM at Schwartz Brothers - Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills. Grandson Rabbi Jonathan Rosenberg officiating.

title: What's a Modern Girl to Do?
description: Dowd seems to accept, albeit with frustration and anger, that men aren't attracted to smart women andprefer to marry their maids. She buttresses her thesis with a smattering ofquotes and a few studies, her voice that of a bitterly resigned narrator-journalist.

title: What's a Modern Girl to Do?
description: Once "till death do us part" meant only until about age 50. Now it means until 80 or 90. So there's little surprise that men -- who have generally never been as eager to marry as women -- may be even more reluctant to make that lengthy commitment today. And for those men who do, there isn't much assurance that they will stay married. A man can marry his maid, his secretary, his assistant, etc., but the reality is that a year or two down the road, she is his wife and not his secretary anymore. She has no guarantee that he won't dump her when she turns 40.

The corner rarely attracts people, except when crowds congregate during the New York Film Festival.

title: An Affront to the Scoundrels
description: WANAQUE - LAST Wednesday morning, Warren Hagstrom took one final ride down Ringwood Avenue: past Borough Hall, where he had presided for the last 14 years as mayor, past the construction site of a development for the elderly that he had championed, and past the firehouse adorned with black-and-purple bunting, where old men gathered, sipped coffee, and declared that their mayor had been "like a brother."

The Vanishing Boy
description: If Paul Collins's son had leukemia or diabetes instead of autism, no one would question a father's decision to medicate his child according to a doctor's recommendation (Lives, Oct. 30). But his son has a brain disease, a "mental" illness, so he has to face the incredulous, suspicious questions of friends and strangers. That's stigma. And every parent of every child with a mental illness faces it every time he makes a decision: to medicate, to hospitalize, to tell teachers, to make it part of the child's public record.

description: IF you think life is moving too fast -- hyped up with BlackBerries, blogs, podcasts and instant messages -- imagine what it is like to run a movie studio these days.

title: The End of Pensions?
description: Congress should stop trying to salvage private pension plans. Instead, it should work on a painful but necessary phaseout of the wholesystem, a system that gives too much control to companies whose interests are antithetical to those of their employees. Private pension plans as we now know them will be obsolete 25 years from now anyway, but the sooner we replace them with something less reliant on corporate solvency and good faith, the less damage that will be done in the meantime.

title: Dale Dye Will Make a Man Out of You
description: On a late September afternoon in Los Angeles, Dale Adam Dye, captain, United States Marine Corps, retired, sits behind a desk in his modest North Hills bungalow and describes the rigorous process by which he takes a bunch "of weenie actors who think the sun rises and sets on their asinine selves" and turns them into fair facsimiles of grossly underappreciated fighting men.

title: Young Romance: The Past Is Never Past
description: HACKETTSTOWN - CENTENARY COLLEGE here has no archaeology major, but there is a first-rate excavation in progress at the theater on campus, where the Centenary Stage Company is offering "Sight Unseen," Donald Margulies's heady play about digging up and clinging to the past.

title: Thread Counts, Yo
description: WHEN we say, "I'm a New Yorker," we sometimes say it with a little sneer. Rats? Mafiosi? Terrorists? We can take it. Bars here close at dawn. Subway doors are ripped open with bare hands. New York's edginess is so endemic, so untamed, that a crack cocaine den was found this year in the otherwise relentlessly genteel Upper East Side. That's how we roll.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about a couple who decided against an apartment purchase on Irving Place in Manhattan because their broker had discovered that a proposed new building would block their view misspelled the surname of the broker. She is Karen Kelley, not Kelly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WARREN, WILLIAM ''BILL''
description: WARREN--William "Bill". November 6. Loving husband of Vivian for over 50 years and devoted father to Robert. Adored and esteemed by Wendy and Gary Seiden, Lora and Irving Shepard. The voice and mind of radio station WMCR, Oneida, NY. Bill will be remembered for his gregarious nature, keen intelligence, love and loyalty to friends and family.

title: Riots? What Riots? A Nostalgic Look at the City of Light
description: PARIS - IT was of course coincidental that a photographic exhibition celebrating the mystique of the Paris of yore should find itself competing with newspaper and television images of riots in some immigrant neighborhoods of Paris and other French cities. The exhibition honors Willy Ronis, the last of the great Paris photographers. At 95, he has outlived all of his peers, and his photographs now play a central role in keeping alive this city's rich visual memory. But this memory also encompasses the fierce left-right confrontations of the 1930's, Germany's wartime occupation and the 1968 anti-government student movement. Paris may at times resemble a theater set, but it is also one where high drama has often been enacted.

title: North Castle Sees End of an Era
description: NORTH CASTLE - JOHN A. LOMBARDI, a Republican who has served as town supervisor here for the past 44 years, keeps some impressive photographs on his office wall.

title: Duck! It's Andrew Lloyd Webber in 3-D
description: WHEN the Lumire brothers first showed the film "Arrival of a Train at La Ciotat" in Paris more than a century ago, the shot of a locomotive pulling into a station was supposedly so startling that much of the audience jumped back from the screen in fright. Simon Lee probably has a good idea of how they felt. He was conducting the orchestra in London for "The Woman in White" -- the new $8.5 million Andrew Lloyd Webber musical -- when he first saw the show's computer-animated train barreling toward him from a dark tunnel, its wheels rumbling and whistle screaming. He ducked.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LENZINGER, ROBERT
description: LENZINGER - Robert. 66, Ardsley, NY. Beloved husband of Anne (nee Cotter). Loving father of Jeanne and devoted brother to Charles and family. Mass of the Resurrection Monday, 10 am, Sacred Heart Church, Hartsdale. Visiting Sunday (today), 2-4 and 7-9 pm, Edwards - Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave, (Exit 17 Saw Mill), Dobbs Ferry. Memorials to Hospice of Westchester.

title: Police tighten security at Eiffel Tower, Champs-Elysees
'The Other Side' and 'Imagine': Look Again
description: THE OTHER SIDE

title: The Empathist
description: Perhaps it's because he is an only child or maybe it's because he is Catholic or it could just be that he allows the complications of his mind to flourish, but Peter Sarsgaard always looks as if he has a secret. There's something in his almond-shaped eyes -- a mix of withheld information, curiosity and latent volatility. When he first appears on-screen in "Jarhead," the new movie about the 1991 gulf war, he seems, as he usually does in his films, more complex and intriguing than his surroundings. In the movie, he portrays a Marine sharpshooter with a shadowy past, and though the audience is not told up front about his character's history, you immediately sense something dark and conflicted about him. There's a charged stillness about Sarsgaard's presence; even before he speaks, he communicates a kind of subterranean emotional range that commands interest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WENGRAF, GERTRUDE
description: WENGRAF--Gertrude. Born in Vienna, Austria on September 1, 1910, died at her home in New York City on November 10, 2005. Predeceased by her husband Dr. Fritz Wengraf. Beloved friend, your optimism and your love of art and nature greatly inspired us. You will be sadly missed. Madeline Buchsbaum and Fritzi Zeitlhofer

title: Swagger
description: In the closing speech at the Republican National Convention in 2004, the candidate for renomination, President George W. Bush, convulsed the partisan crowd with a not-quite-self-deprecating line: "Some folks look at me and see a certain swagger. In Texas, we call it walkin'." He credited his mother, Barbara Bush, with instilling that down-home habit of cowboy bluntness.

title: From Grit to Gloss
description: The other day, as I stood on the corner of Astor Place and Lafayette Street, two adorable young Japanese tourists stopped to ask me a question: "Can you tell us where is the East Village?"

title: Comings and Goings
description: Is airport food getting better? Yes, says the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine, in a press release e-mailed to travel editors earlier this month, citing an increase in "healthy entrees" available at 14 major airports. The group, identified as a nonprofit health organization, reported a 12 percent increase in airport restaurants providing at least one vegetarian entree that was "low in fat, high in fiber and cholesterol-free." Not so fast, charged the Center for Consumer Freedom in a press release e-mailed to those same editors about two hours later, calling the Physicians Committee an "animal-rights front group" with a hidden agenda. The Center for Consumer Freedom, identified as a nonprofit coalition of restaurants and food companies, said that the word "healthy" was "just another term for PETA-approved," referring to the People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals. The Center said it wanted to stop travelers from being misled into thinking "that all nonvegetarian food is unhealthy." Sounds like a dispute that needs to be settled over a cup of Starbucks coffee at La Guardia. Speaking of airports, the days of having your cuticle scissors confiscated might soon be over. The Transportation Safety Administration is reportedly considering relaxing the rules on what carry-on items are allowed passengers. Right now, the list of banned items includes scissors, knives, lights and golf clubs. The Los Angeles County Museum of Art is extending its King Tut exhibition to Nov. 20 because of record-breaking crowds. The show's next stop is the Museum of Art in Fort Lauderdale, where it will open Dec. 15 for a four-month run.

title: Movies on TV
description: OCEAN'S TWELVE (2004) Monday at 8 a.m. and 8 p.m., Monday/Early Tuesday at 4:30 a.m. and Wednesday at 2:20 and 10 p.m. on Cinemax The boys from Steven Soderbergh's "Ocean's Eleven" are planning another heist, but that's almost beside the point. What's important is that everybody looks gorgeous (George Clooney, Brad Pitt, Catherine Zeta-Jones, Julia Roberts, Matt Damon, Andy Garcia et al.). The European scenery is also lovely (Paris, Rome, Monaco, Amsterdam, Lake Como), and George Nolfi's screenplay is packed with self-referential humor. Mr. Clooney (above), as Danny Ocean, has a running gag about whether people think he looks 50. (He was 43 when the film was released last December.) Ms. Roberts has some real fun when her character, Tess Ocean, reluctantly agrees to pose as a movie star: Julia Roberts.

title: The $353 Million Cleanup
description: AS celebrations go, one of the more unusual has been under way in recent weeks at Brookhaven National Laboratory, a world-class center of advanced scientific research with a history of discharging contaminants.

title: Our faith in science
Secret Garden
description: A CIGAR is just a cigar, except when it's smoked in a bar in Manhattan. Then it is a very rare treat -- especially if it's Cuban.

title: 2 Health Departments Suspend Flu Shots
description: Two local health departments recently stopped scheduling flu shots because they had not received their entire supply from the state.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Nov. 13 -- Nov. 19; FILM
description: One of the criminally underrated films of the 1990's, "BABE: PIG IN THE CITY" is GEORGE MILLER's follow-up to his much-beloved "Babe." Released in 1995, the first film, directed by Chris Noonan, who also wrote the screenplay with Mr. Miller, spins an enchantingly sunny tale about a young orphaned pig who becomes a prize-winning sheep herder, thereby earning the affections of the farmer (James Cromwell) who might otherwise have made bacon and chops of him. Three years later, Mr. Miller took up the directing reins for the dark and rather more grown-up sequel, which tracks Babe (voiced by E. G. DAILY) as he and the farmer's wife (MAGDA SZUBANSKI) travel to a Dickensian city following a calamity at the farm. A grim metropolis roiling with peril, the city introduces Babe to a world of exotic excitement and a new menagerie whose numbers include chimps and a rampaging pit bull. Babe's nearly fateful meeting with the pit bull conveys more terror and tenderness than similar encounters in most human-centered films, and suggests that the film's bold message -- "a kind and steady heart can mend a sorry world" -- may not be so unattainable after all. Thursday at 8 p.m., Anthology Film Archives, 32 Second Avenue, at Second Street, East Village, (212) 505-5181.

title: Beatlemania for Beginners
description: JOHN LENNON

title: Where Not Only Agents Do the Selling
description: BUYER beware. If you purchase a home in South Orange or Maplewood, it may come with strings attached - or more aptly perhaps, ties that bind.

title: That Unsettled Feeling
description: Janet DiFiore came out ahead of Tony Castro in the Westchester district attorney's race last week by four percentage points and about 6,700 votes. It was a daunting lead for Ms. DiFiore, a Republican, given that there were only about 6,000 absentee and provisional ballots left to count. But Mr. Castro, a Democrat, said he would not concede until every last voting machine was checked and every ballot counted. Everybody else was eager to wrap up the game and go home, but there was Mr. Castro, alone in the end zone, looking up for his Hail Mary pass.

description: KONYA, TURKEY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TUFT, LEONARD W.
description: TUFT--Leonard W., 83, retired Executive Vice President of RCA, died Friday, November 11, of heart failure. Beloved husband of Irene Yuss and father of Sarah and David. At RCA, he negotiated commerical satellite agreements, retiring after 37 years to practice law. Born in Philadelphia, PA, he graduated first in his class from Temple University and received his juris doctorate from Harvard Law School. As a navigator in WWII he earned two Purple Hearts and the Distinguished Flying Cross. He was an ardent Democrat and a delegate to the 1960 Democratic National Convention. Funeral services will be held at 1 pm, Monday, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, NYC.

title: A Comeback Kid for a Dead-End Town
description: Detroit - ON Tuesday, in perhaps the one election with no national implications -- two black Democrats faced off, and President Bush didn't drop by -- Kwame Kilpatrick was re-elected mayor of Detroit. No real surprise there, as no incumbent has lost in Detroit since 1961. Then again, Mayor Kilpatrick had been well behind in the polls; early that night one of the local television channels projected that the challenger, Freman Hendrix, who was ahead by 19 points in its exit polling, would be Detroit's new mayor. I went to bed, feeling informed, and woke up, like much of Detroit, feeling flummoxed.

It confuses me that young women choose to diminish themselves so they can have a man. If they chose their self-respect instead, they could have the world at their feet.

title: Inside the List
description: FRANKENOMICS: Five new books surface on this week's hardcover nonfiction list, further scattering the familiar titles -- "Blink," "1776," "Freakonomics" and "The World Is Flat" -- that have dominated the list's top third for months. The new title at No. 1 is "The Truth (With Jokes)," by Al Franken, a gloomier, more astringent book than his "Lies (and the Lying Liars Who Tell Them)," which came out in 2003. Franken's new one has dark circles under its eyes. "The Truth (With Jokes)" went to press before Katrina and the indictment of Lewis Libby, so it already feels mildly dated; and regular readers of political blogs, which have multiplied exponentially since Franken's last book, may feel a lot of the material here (on John Kerry and his "Swift Boat" attackers, Abu Ghraib, Fox News) has already been hashed to death. But Franken is more wicked than your average blogger. In his new book he recalls how Paul Wolfowitz, then the deputy secretary of defense, told Congress in April 2004 that "approximately 500" Americans had been killed in Iraq up to that point, when the actual number was 722. "The next Saturday," Franken writes, "I happened to run into Wolfowitz at the White House Correspondents Dinner. 'You want to hear the joke I've been using about your not knowing how many of our troops had died in Iraq?' I asked. The small group that had gathered around us made it impossible for him to say no. 'O.K. Here it is. Paul Wolfowitz was off by a third when he was asked how many Americans have died in Iraq. The good news, however, is that he won the office pool.' "

description: One hard and fast rule about New York's state government -- about any government at all, really -- is that you have to watch 'em every minute. Here is a troubling example: While we were all busy with elections, the State Board of Elections issued a draft proposal for buying $220 million worth of new voting machines. Apparently, the manufacturers will be allowed -- perhaps even encouraged -- to push for one type of machine, while many civic groups and concerned voters are pushing for something else.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Nov. 13 -- Nov. 19; THEATER
description: History takes on aspects comic and tragic on New York stages this week, in a particularly intriguing slate of new plays. In "BACH AT LEIPZIG," ITAMAR MOSES's comedy set in 18th-century Germany, a swarm of organists scheme and connive to secure a prestigious musical position at the leading church in Leipzig. PAM MacKINNON directs a celestial-sounding cast that includes RICHARD EASTON, JEFFREY CARLSON, MICHAEL EMERSON, BOYD GAINES, REG ROGERS and ANDREW WEEMS. Opens Monday at New York Theater Workshop, 79 East Fourth Street, East Village, (212) 239-6200.

title: Bush-Era Engag
description: What are movie stars for? Yes, I know, it's an odd, possibly irrelevant question. The whole point of movie stars is that they just are. It might be more appropriate to wonder whether, in a world of generalized, instantly manufactured celebrity, movie stars are still necessary. The alloy of glamour and artistry that great screen actors embody may not survive the currency crisis precipitated by reality television and the Internet. At least for the moment, however, movie stars still serve as the gold standard of modern fame. Indeed, the rise of cheap, interchangeable, mass-produced celebrity may have endowed those whose primary medium is the big screen with a bit of added gravity, renewing their license to be taken (or to take themselves) seriously. Their fame remains a unique form of cultural capital, a resource that can sometimes be converted into influence or power.

A descendant of Johannes de Peyster who came to New Amsterdam in 1645, he was of the 12th generation to be born on Manhattan Island. Survived by his wife of 67 years, Dorothy Shelby Siems de Peyster; three children: James A. de Peyster Jr., Shelby de Peyster Wyckoff and F. Ashton de Peyster III; four grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Memorial service at the Episcopal Church of Bethesda-by-theSea, Palm Beach, Saturday, November 26 at 10:30 AM.

title: Beverly Hills Coup?
description: Last August, in Beverly Hills, I stopped in to see the actor, director and producer Rob Reiner, who has emerged in recent years as a highly articulate spokesman for Democratic causes and an acid critic of the president and his war in Iraq. There was a time, decades ago, when studio executives were the main political players in Hollywood, and like the heads of other profitable American industries, they spent their capital on their own parochial interests, things like intellectual property rights and access to foreign markets. Hollywood was as political as any other company town, but it was the bosses, and not the movie stars, who did the lobbying. Ronald Reagan helped change that tradition when he entered politics in the 1960's, opening the forbidden portal between two disconnected worlds, and by the time Bill Clinton occupied the White House in the 1990's, it was not unusual for Michael Douglas or Warren Beatty to turn up at a formal Washington dinner, or for Barbra Streisand to send a policy memo to a Congressional leader. The edict that Sam Goldwyn is said to have issued to filmmakers -- "If you want to send a message, try Western Union" -- has never seemed more pass. Both on-screen and off, famous and wealthy activists like Reiner now regard themselves not just as messengers but also as their own kind of opposition party, an essential bulwark against a president who would transform America into a ruthless global aggressor.

Paid Notice: Deaths   SILBERLING, DIANE
description: SILBERLING--Diane. On November 10, 2005. Cherished aunt, great aunt and great great aunt to so many in the Silberling family, who mourn her passing. A masterful wordsmith, Aunt Dina had a brilliant mind and intense passion for the arts, travel and New York City. Her impeccable taste and sophistication made her the quintessential New Yorker. She had a long and distinguished career as administrator for the Department of Dermatology at the NYU School f Medicine. title: Behind Foreign Lines
description: Where would Hollywood be without its snarling bad guys, jackboots and Sieg Heils, its cornfed G.I.'s, cigar-chomping corporals, its submarines, tanks and popping guns, its spectacles of war? Where would the movies be without the rockets' red glare? War has been good for American movies, and no war seems more important to our national cinema than World War II, the war that gives us permission to watch good guys kill bad guys without evident ambivalence, anguish and guilt, the war that makes violence not only patriotic but also pleasurable and profitable.

title: Dear Mayor Mike: I Have an Idea ...
description: Not every idea to improve New York requires megabucks. For example: Why not put MetroCard machines on subway platforms so people can buy while they wait? Some cities have installed plastic-glove dispensers for picking up dog waste; would they make New York cleaner? Why don't new "Walk" signs include timers on them, so pedestrians don't get caught halfway across?

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A T-Shirt-and-Dagger Operation
description: WASHINGTON - A DOCUMENTARY on Italian television on Tuesday accuses American forces of using white phosphorus shells in the assault on Falluja last year not just for nighttime illumination, their usual purpose, but to burn to death Iraqi insurgents and civilians. The mainstream American news media, whose reporters had witnessed the fighting and apparently seen no evidence of this, largely ignored the claim.

title: Tony Blair in Decline
description: Tony Blair has seen better weeks. While he is still highly popular among Americans, his political standing at home is much diminished, despite having led his Labor Party to a third consecutive electoral victory last spring.

title: Colors of Fall

For some women, a bit of fur trimming -- collars, cuffs, scarves or vests -- is the fashion message capturing the functional taste in dress in this new century. And accessories are the place to see a dash of color. ON THE STREET

title: Zapatero answers religious protest

title: What's a Modern Girl to Do?
description: I sadly concur with Dowd's observations about today's young women and their feminist predecessors. I would add one point: Dating strategies that do not include honestly revealing yourself and your values, and trying to ascertain the same of prospective partners, may result in more marriages, but they are bait and switch. Such tactics are illegal in commerce, and the high divorce rate speaks volumes about how effective they are in achieving successful matrimony.

title: Paris Police Are on Guard as Fear Rises Over Threats
description: PARIS, Nov. 12 - Unrest continued to percolate through poor, predominantly minority neighborhoods across France on Saturday, though by the afternoon there were no signs that the arson attacks would again reach into the heart of the capital as had been feared.

title: Hit Parade
description: In late 2002, the radio host Garrison Keillor committed an act of inadvertent but undeniable depravity: he published a poetry anthology for average readers that sold pretty well. Anthologies are often troubling for poets (who likes being left out?), and many serious writers are ambivalent about popular success, but the combination of these concerns -- a popular anthology -- can create a near perfect storm of psychic distress.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Page 9 of Arts & Leisure today about the actor Taye Diggs, who is appearing in "A Soldier's Play," misstates the name of the theater. It is the Second Stage, not Second Street.

title: They're Soft and Cuddly, So Why Lash Them to the Front of a Truck?
description: A bear with a prominent grease spot on his little beige nose spends his days wedged behind the bumper guard of an ironworker's pickup in the Gowanus section of Brooklyn. A fuzzy rabbit and a clown, garroted by a bungee cord, slump from the front of a Dodge van in Park Slope. Stewie, the evil baby from "Family Guy," scowls from the grille of a Pepperidge Farm delivery truck in Brooklyn Heights, mold occasionally sprouting from his forehead.

title: Diane Burstein, John Kosner

Judge Matthew F. Cooper of Civil Court in Manhattan is to officiate at Loft Eleven, an events space in Manhattan, with Rabbi Marcia Rappaport taking part.

description: The cruise industry is calling the violent attack on a cruise ship off the coast of Somalia on Nov. 5 an aberration. Pirates on two boats reportedly fired rocket-propelled grenades at the Seabourn Spirit, a luxury liner carrying 151 passengers, as it rounded the Horn of Africa last Saturday on its way from Alexandria, Egypt, to Mombasa in Kenya.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BEIMFOHR, JOELLA J. (WHITE)
description: BEIMFOHR -- Joella J. (White). Of Bonita Springs, FL, and Pine Valley, NJ (formerly of Short Hills, NJ), passed away on November 10, 2005. She leaves her husband Edward G. Beimfohr, her daughter Catherine Beimfohr Wilson of Bloomington, IL, two sons, Laurence Beimfohr of Mendham, NJ, and Douglas Beimfohr of Short Hills, NJ. She is also survived by ten grandchildren, Rob, Beth, Meg, Lauren, Emily, Katie, Catherine, Lucy, Devin and Justin. She was preceded in death by two brothers, J. Brown White, John White, and a sister, Anita Sherrick. A memorial service will be held at Wyoming Presbyterian Church, 432 Wyoming Ave, Milburn NJ, on Saturday, November 19, at 10:30 am. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Marissa Historical and Genealogical Society, PO Box 47, Marissa, IL 62257-0047, or to a charity of the donor's choice. For more information, contact The Jacob A. Holle Funeral Home, Maplewood, or to send conolences, please visit www. jacobhollefuneralhome.com

title: When a Church Is Not a Home
description: Six years ago, Philipp Angermeyer bought an apartment in the Carroll Gardens Landmark Condominiums, a 19th-century Romanesque church turned residential building on Court Street in Brooklyn. In part, the appeal of living in the landmark church is architectural: stained-glass windows, high ceilings and a certain monastic quietude.

title: Karmine Alers and Jimmy Greco
description: FOR Karmine Alers, 1999 was as worrisome as a tax audit. Miss Alers, an aspiring singer and actress, had been performing in all-girl pop bands and wearing miniskirts and boots since high school. She constantly auditioned for roles in the theater, mostly musicals, but kept being told she didn't have the right look.

title: Singing the Blues in a Blue City
description: WITH post-election analysis raising questions about what the Democrats can do to recapture City Hall in 2009, it's time for a good hard look in the mirror, and a new approach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HURWIN, ELLSWORTH B.
description: HURWIN--Ellsworth B., 86, of Boca Raton, FL and Massapequa Park, NY, on Monday, October 24. Beloved husband of 60 years to Mollye L. Loving father of Ralph and Jeannine and Gene and Davida. Honored grandfather of Frazier. Son of the late Louis and Rose and devoted brother of the late Miriam S. An extraordinary man of great warmth, generosity, understanding, patience, humor and wisdom. He was a graduate of New York University and the University of Southern California. During WWII he served in the Air Force, participating in a number of bombing missions and attaining the rank of Captain. After the war he joined Allied Purchasing. He went on to a career in the toy and sporting goods industry in New York as an executive with a number of leading companies. He was instrumental in fostering the careers of many newcomers. In his leisure time, he enjoyed working on the grounds of his home, boating and rooting for the Yankees. "His life was gentle and the elements so mixed in him that nature might stand up and say to all the world 'this was a man!"'. 561-272-8983

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUCE, HENRY III.
description: LUCE--Henry III. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Asia Foundation extend our condolences to the Luce family and the Henry Luce Foundation on the loss of Henry Luce III. The Foundation is grateful for Mr. Luce's long-term friendship and support and is proud of its association with the Luce Scholars Program since its inception by Mr. Luce in 1974. The Asia Foundation, 465 California St, 9th Fl San Francisco, CA 94104

description: David Letterman

title: Lessons From Dad
description: WHERE I grew up in Chicago, I could stand in a parking lot near my house and see my grade school, my high school and my college. My father was a minister with the Swedish Covenant Church. He had to preach Sunday morning, Sunday night and Wednesday night. I remember him being in the basement and my sister and me upstairs. There was a laundry chute between us. On a Saturday night, we could hear him practicing his sermon; it would just be a kind of rumble where he would try out different sentences. I realized you just don't stand up and speak; it takes preparation.

description: Correction Appended

title: It's a Blue Island
description: The beefy bagpipers in the back of the catering hall in Patchogue on election night were paying no attention -- they were trying hard to pour Champagne without letting go of their Coors Lights -- but not 20 feet away, in the happy glow of a huge video screen, the final pieces of a revolution were falling into place. Long Island, land of Republicans practically since glacier days, was turning blue.

title: The Narnia Skirmishes
description: Disney's new feature film, "The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe," spends a good deal more time than C.S. Lewis's beloved children's book on the climactic battle between the forces of the sinister White Witch and the army of Aslan, the supernatural lion. The movie of course has the benefit of studio bean counters and recognizes that this could be the mother of all screen battles -- not just your basic struggle of good and evil but a $200 million smackdown between the religious right and godless Hollywood, between C.S. Lewis and J.R.R. Tolkien and, for that matter, between Aslan and King Kong, a resurrected version of whom opens in a movie of his own a few days after "Narnia" does next month. The great philosophical debate of my childhood was: Who is stronger, King Kong or Mighty Joe Young? In the Kong-Aslan matchup, Aslan, a Christ figure, would seem to have the advantage of omnipotence, but that's not to say he will prevail at the box office.

description: HASSMAN--Geoffrey, 60. Devoted son of the late Bobbe and Sid Hassman and loving brother to Ellen Hassman, passed away on November 7 in Hawaii where he has been living for the past three years. He was President and CEO of Geoffrey Hassman Design in Oahu. Known in New York as a playwright/architect, Geoffrey has had several plays mounted OffOff Broadway. A memorial will be announced at a later date. $(6$)HASSMAN--Geoffrey. Dearest Friend, Thanks for the wonderful times. You graced us all with your immense talents and wit. I'll miss laughing with you the most. You will never be forgotten. My love forever, Beverly Perry $(6$)HONIG--Emil. Temple Avodah, Oceanside, NY, notes with sadness the passing of Past President, Emil Honig, in West Palm Beach, FL. description: Only two restaurants outside Manhattan won stars in the new Michelin Guide for New York, Peter Luger and Saul, and both are in Brooklyn. In all, 25 Brooklyn restaurants were listed, with places on Smith and Court Streets dominating. Here are some high points (star ratings are by New York Times).

title: Paperback Row
description: THE INNER VOICES: Selected Poems, 1963-2003, by Richard Howard. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16.) Many of the poems in this exacting collection share a concern with art or artists and reveal Howard's fondness for dramatic monologues. One, "Nikolaus Mardruz to Ferdinand, Count of Tyrol, 1565," elaborates on Robert Browning's "My Last Duchess," squeezing new implications from classic lines. PAPER TRAIL: Selected Prose, 1965-2003 (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16) gathers Howard's criticism, much of it enthusiastic, including substantial pieces on Marianne Moore and Emily Dickinson.

title: Rice Calls on Israel and Palestinians to Resolve Differences
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 13 - Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, making her fourth visit to the Middle East this year, again implored Israel and Palestinians today to resolve their differences, amid mounting signs of frustration in Washington over the lack of progress since Israel withdrew from Gaza in the summer.

title: Medal Fatigue
description: I AM proud -- but also deeply humbled -- to deliver this unofficial and unsolicited reminder that next Wednesday, Nov. 16, the National Book Awards will be distributed in New York City. (I know! I can hardly wait, either.) These awards will, as always, add incomparable and well-deserved luster to the reputations of the lucky -- that is to say, the absolutely worthy and painstakingly chosen -- winners, and also reveal the vibrancy and diversity of American literary endeavor in all its forms. (All four of its forms, that is, since that is how many categories the N.B.A. has these days. Sometimes there have been as many as 27, sometimes as few as two. But now there are four: fiction, nonfiction, "young people's literature" and poetry.)

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Nov. 13 -- Nov. 19; POP/JAZZ
description: The musicians of KONONO NO. 1 come from Kinshasa, Congo, and for 25 years they have been super-amplifying that most acoustic of instruments, the African thumb piano. On the recent album "Congotronics: Konono No. 1" (Crammed Discs), you can hear the band's incredible sound: trance music made with rudimentary percussion and three thumb pianos, each in a different register, pumped through homemade microphones. In the group's first New York club appearances, one expects something to be lost in translation -- unless they bring their own sound system -- but the dense groove should be portable. Wednesday at Joe's Pub, at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 539-8770; Thursday at S.O.B.'s, 204 Varick Street, at Houston Street, South Village, (212) 243-4940.

How does an actor prepare to play a soldier? What is the relationship that the industry has with the troops? ith the president? What do documentaries about the current conflict show us that feature films cannot, and vice versa? And what do these films say about us?

description: Dowd writes that successful women wish to marry successful men but that these men "marry down" instead. An alternative to blaming male egos for this is to look at the practicalities. A workaholic who wants a family needs a spouse who is willing to spend time at home. Successful women are reinforcing sexist stereotypes if they dismiss suitors who would forgo work for family.

title: Now on your own station
'The Lost Painting'
description: The Englishman moves in a slow but deliberate shuffle, knees slightly bent and feet splayed, as he crosses the piazza, heading in the direction of a restaurant named Da Fortunato. The year is 2001. The Englishman is ninety-one years old. He carries a cane, the old-fashioned kind, wooden with a hooked handle, although he does not always use it. The dome of his head, smooth as an eggshell, gleams pale in the bright midday Roman sun. He is dressed in his customary manner-a dark blue double-breasted suit, hand tailored on Savile Row more than thirty years ago, and a freshly starched white shirt with gold cuff links and a gold collar pin. His hearing is still sharp, his eyes clear and unclouded. He wears glasses, but then he has worn glasses ever since he was a child. The current pair are tortoiseshell and sit cockeyed on his face, the left earpiece broken at the joint. He has fashioned a temporary repair with tape. The lenses are smudged with his fingerprints.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Nov. 13 -- Nov. 19; TELEVISION
description: Portraying Queen Elizabeth I means following in the footsteps of actresses of both sexes -- think Bette Davis, Cate Blanchett, Quentin Crisp. ANNE-MARIE DUFF, who played one of the brutalized teenage girls in the 2002 film "The Magdalene Sisters," shows she's up for it in this week's "MASTERPIECE THEATER" (PBS, Sunday at 9 p.m.). In "THE VIRGIN QUEEN," a two-part co-production with the BBC, Ms. Duff's Elizabeth is a crafty schemer: she goes from the prison tower to the maze of court politics with a hint of a smirk.

title: Q & A With Chris Davenport
description: Named one of North America's top 25 skiers by Skiing Magazine, Chris Davenport is a two-time extreme skiing world champion and former University of Colorado ski racer. Davenport, 34, does television commentary for ABC and ESPN, has a flourishing global business as a private heli-skiing guide and appears in the new adventure ski film, "The Hit List," from Matchstick Productions. Raised in New England and now living and working in Aspen, Davenport has skied all over the world, from the Himalayas to the Andes, making films and producing magazine covers.

title: In New Orleans, Look for the Hidden Crimes
description: To the Editor:

title: Are Trams Going the Way of Wooden Skis?
description: LIKE rope tows, wooden skis and cable bindings, the aerial tram may soon be obsolete in American ski resorts -- if the news coming out of Jackson Hole is any indication.

title: The Empathist
description: Perhaps it's because he is an only child or maybe it's because he is Catholic or it could just be that he allows the complications of his mind to flourish, but Peter Sarsgaard always looks as if he has a secret. There's something in his almond-shaped eyes - a mix of withheld information, curiosity and latent volatility. When he first appears on-screen in "Jarhead," the new movie about the 1991 gulf war, he seems, as he usually does in his films, more complex and intriguing than his surroundings. In the movie, he portrays a Marine sharpshooter with a shadowy past, and though the audience is not told up front about his character's history, you immediately sense something dark and conflicted about him. There's a charged stillness about Sarsgaard's presence; even before he speaks, he communicates a kind of subterranean emotional range that commands interest.

title: Seventh on Sale Makes a Comeback
description: DESIGNERS are such a competitive lot that it took a decade and the coaxing of Anna Wintour, the editor in chief of Vogue, to unite the fashion industry behind a campaign to heighten AIDS awareness by offering steep discounts on their clothes.
