description: This week offers a particularly rich steam table of the unusual and new in opera, or at least in art forms that include music, text and theatrics of various types.

title: In Zimbabwe, Homeless Belie Leader's Claim
description: BULAWAYO, Zimbabwe - President Robert G. Mugabe has one word for reports that Operation Drive Out Trash, the urban-demolition campaign aimed at slum dwellers that his government describes as a civic beautification program, has rendered thousands of his impoverished citizens homeless.

title: Country Comes to the City
description: A dozen blocks uptown, where Harvey Fierstein and Rosie O'Donnell are playing husband and wife in "Fiddler on the Roof," Broadway is boasting that it has the oddest couple in New York, but on Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden, the Country Music Association may top that. The group's annual awards show, to be broadcast live beginning at 8 on CBS, will feature a musical pairing that Ed Benson, the association's executive director, says is a first: Elton John and Dolly Parton.

title: Correction
description: An article on Oct. 30 about pensions and companies that are phasing them out or unable to pay them referred imprecisely to the credit status of General Motors and its potential effect on the company's pension plan. Earlier this year, the company's bonds, not its stocks, were downgraded to a junk rating.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLOCK, LEONARD N.
description: BLOCK--Leonard N. (December 21, 1911-November 9, 2005). Survived by Adele Block, wife of 69 years, children, Peggy Danziger (Dick) and Thomas Block (Marilyn Friedman); grandchildren, Michael Danzinger (Betsy), Katie Danziger (Steve Horowitz) and Jonathan and Alison Block; great-grandchildren, James, Robby, Charlie and Teddy Danziger and Jake and Jilly Horowitz. Services Sunday, November 13, 11 am, at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue at 65th St, NYC. $(6$)BLOCK--Leonard. The Board and staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened by the death of Leonard Block, who passed away peacefully on November 9. Beloved husband of founding Board member Adele Block, Leonard was a staunch and generous advocate of the theater, passionate in his determination to see the theater reestablished, artistically distinguished and organizationally sound. We extend our condolences and love to Peggy, Tom and the entire Block family. John B. Beinecke, Chairman John Chalsty, President Andre Bishop Artistic Director Bernard Gersten Executive Producer $(6$)BLOCK -- Leonard. Light house International mourns the death of Leonard Block, husband of Adele, a devoted Board Member and generous supporter of the Lighthouse mission to help people of all ages overcome the challenges of vision impairment. On behalf of Lighthouse Board of Directors, our staff and our consumers, we offer deepest sympathy to the family. Tara Cortes, President and CEO William B. Follett, Chairman, Board of Directors Lighthouse International

title: Tracking the Artists' Journey on the Hudson
description: NEAR the base of Kaaterskill Falls, a waterfall deep in the woods near Catskill, N.Y., is a place once frequented by Thomas Cole, the self-styled founder of the Hudson River School and one of the fathers of American landscape painting. An outdoorsman, Cole (1801-48) lived year round with his wife and extended family in a Federal-style house at an orchard in Catskill. From there, he would hike up to 30 miles into the wildly beautiful Catskills to find vantage points for sketching.

title: Hamilton Is League's Running Man
description: Off the court, Pistons shooting guard Richard Hamilton is an avid runner. On the court, he logs miles in and around opponents, then dashes out the back door. If he was running on a treadmill last year in Larry Brown's system, Hamilton has turned into Forrest Gump under Flip Saunders, finding the freedom of running the full 94 feet.

title: Jon Had a Party. Guess Who Came?
description: Among the Democrats at the Hilton on election night was one celebrant who on the one hand had every reason to be there -- but on the other had every reason not to be.

title: Rules of Engagement
description: In the middle of Peter Davis's Vietnam war documentary, "Hearts and Minds," a large, pale, scarily eyebrowless face suddenly takes over the screen. It's the face of Col. George S. Patton III, son of the famous general, as he describes his attendance at a memorial service in Vietnam for some fallen American soldiers. When he gazed upon the faces of the memorial's attendees, Patton says: "I was just proud. My feeling for America just soared.. . .They looked determined and reverent at the same time. But still" -- and here Colonel Patton's abrupt, savage smile reveals a mouth packed with draft-horse-size choppers -- "they're a bloody good bunch of killers."

title: What's a Modern Girl to Do?
description: So powerful men want to marry only their secretaries, assistants or nannies? Let them! Even the most cursory survey of powerful men in this country over the past decade reveals a brigands's list of greedy, philandering, manipulative predators who put their self-interests above any responsibility to their employees, constituents, parishioners or family. What hard-working woman, feminist or no, wants to come home to that every night? Yech.

title: Sifting and Sorting Until the Sun Sets
description: Weeks after shuttering their windows, they have returned to their houses.

title: Other Voices: Judith Miller Responds to the Public Editor; News and Advertising
description: Surely you jest with your feigned concern that advertising in The Times may be tainting the purity of its news content. The example cited is ludicrous. A "watermark" shadow of the Prudential Financial logo faintly visible behind stock-price quotations does nothing at all to change the accuracy or completeness of the trading results presented.

title: Iraqi Insurgent Blamed for Bombings in Jordan
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 12 - The leader of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, dispatched three men, and possibly a woman as well, from Iraq to carry out the suicide bombing attacks here on Wednesday night, Jordanian security officials said Saturday.

title: Meeting of Muslim Nations Ends in Discord
description: Correction Appended

title: Up Front
description: This week we feature the last pages to bear the imprint of Eden Ross Lipson, who has been our children's books editor since 1984. The 32 pages Eden assembled for this annual special section exhibit the hallmark strengths that readers have come to expect over the years. There is, as always, the diverse and stimulating collection of books and the equally diverse and stimulating roster of reviewers, including Daniel Handler, David Leavitt, Gail Collins, Paul O. Zelinsky and Meg Wolitzer. There is the mix of seriousness and fun, of bold adventure and quiet exploration. And there is the announcement of the year's best illustrated books, chosen as always by three distinguished panelists.

title: ATOP THE CONTINENTAL DIVIDE, AT 12,000 FEET, OCT. 23, 2005
description: LOVELAND PASS, COLO. - Playing in the snow for the first time are Leonardo Fuquen, 28, an account manager for a telecommunications company, with his girlfriend, Jenny Zarabanda, both of Bogot, Colombia: "We just wanted to know the snow, because we are from Colombia and there's no snow," Mr. Fuquen said. "And just to feel the cold and view the wonderful view and stay there for a moment, in calm and peace with friends. So we drove from where we were staying in Summit County up to the mountain. The snow was very nice, very cold. It was very different to real ice, like soft ice." Soft enough, in fact, for Ms. Zarabanda to make a "snow boy." Mr. Fuquen was throwing a snowball at two friends who were off camera. "I think I was trying to throw it at anyone I could hit."

title: Not Bob Hope's U.S.O.
description: "Where are you from?" It was the first question that the punk legend and occasional film actor Henry Rollins asked a soldier named Andy who was standing in line to meet him one afternoon last August. Rollins and Andy were in a small, half-empty cafeteria on a military base in Izmir, Turkey. The two men made for an interesting contrast: the lanky 20-something soldier who looked downright shy despite his camouflage uniform and black boots, and the 44-year-old, heavily tattooed, obviously muscled Rollins, who appeared the more menacing, despite his boyish shorts and gray tucked-in T-shirt. Rollins was at the base as an entertainer with the U.S.O., making a stop on what the organization calls a handshake tour, a chance for soldiers to meet a celebrity one on one. Fliers taped around the cafeteria promoted the event, showing a picture of Rollins with his two forefingers pointing out, like a version of Uncle Sam with a graying buzz cut: he wants you! The American soldiers who provide security at the Turkish base were mostly off that day, but several made a point of coming by to meet Rollins, and the line slowly grew, as men finished plates of spaghetti and made their way over to where Rollins was standing.

description: BLATT--Lillian. December 22, 1910--October 31, 2005. Daughter of the late Marx Stein and Clara Kushner, Bridgeport, Connecticut. Mother of Benjamin Jim Blatt. Grandmother of Claire Blatt. Resident buyer, "Lillian Blatt", better women's clothing. 301-942-0748

title: Defining Me, Myself and Madonna

My parents' response was to buy me a Star of David only slightly smaller than the hood ornament on our Buick.

Despite soaring prices, China expects 6% rise in its oil imports
What's a Modern Girl to Do?
description: Bravo to Maureen Dowd for her critique of "modern" women (Oct. 30). I find it painful to watch intelligentclose friends and colleagues dumb themselves down in front of men, believing this behavior to be "attractive." I'm not afraid to admit that if wit, intellect and a wicked sense of sarcasm are still a recipe for Old Maid, I'd better start stockpiling cat food now.

title: This TV Soap Opera May Outlive Its Star
description: How eager was NBC Universal to resolve its feud with Lowell W. Paxson, the founder of Paxson Communications? If Mr. Paxson, who is 70, dies in the next few years, NBC may be paying him not to compete with it from beyond the grave.

title: Shinnecocks Gain Judge's Recognition
description: Judge Thomas C. Platt of the Federal District Court in Central Islip issued an opinion last Monday describing the Shinnecock nation as a sovereign Indian tribe. The ruling opened the way for a trial in a lawsuit over the 800-member tribe's plan for a casino in Hampton Bays.

title: A Park Ranger's Delicate Mission
description: SANDY HOOK - RICHARD WELLS picked up stray soda cans as he led visitors through the abandoned Army gun batteries here at Fort Hancock, part of the Sandy Hook Unit of the Gateway National Recreation Area. "Hi, how are you doing?" he greeted park guests, his native Florida instantly clear in his voice. In his standard-issue straw hat, Mr. Wells could have passed for an ordinary park ranger. In fact, he is the head man here, Sandy Hook's superintendent and the only person who still lives on Officers' Row.

title: Suiting Your Fancy
description: No longer mannish corporate armor, women's suits have taken center stage with flair. This year's suits come in styles that move beyond classic skirts or pants with jackets to gauchos and knickers, knits and trim. More than mere office apparel they project images like schoolgirl, dominatrix, princess and president. Here are eight of the season's best-suited roles. PULSE

description: THE restaurants I love are the hardest to write about. What can I say about Roy Ip, the chef, host and co-owner, with his wife, Winnie, of Le Petit Caf in Branford?

description: THE actor John Lithgow has been spending more time in New York lately, appearing in four stage productions over the last three years.

title: Deconstructing L'Office
description: When is a show that includes movement, songs, speech, objects and film not a dance, not a piece of theater, not a musical comedy, not a movie and not performance art? When it's Grand Magasin's "Fifth International Forum of Corporate Cinema," opening at St. Ann's Warehouse on Thursday night, as part of the citywide Act French Festival through Dec. 15. Two former dancers, Franois Hiffler and Pascale Murtin -- fed up, as Ms. Murtin put it, "with this constant business of virtuosity, of sweat, of daily training" -- have tried their best to forget everything they know about choreographed movement and create unidentified theatrical objects. For their first piece, in 1982, they discovered that using speech "offered a wealth of possibilities since we were able to express tons of things without having to budge," Ms. Murtin said.

title: Sometimes With Flowers
description: IF any statement can be made that applies equally to the realms of psychology and design, it is that human beings have a strange habit of confusing the past with the future. This is not merely a modern mix-up, limited to the 1930's-style wares at Restoration Hardware or the 70's style of Marc Jacobs. Some 250 years ago, the excavation of Pompeii sparked a Neoclassical craze that lasted well into the 19th century.

title: The Hard Sell
description: Q: There will be a number of war movies out in the next few months. The conventional wisdom is that they do not attract a female audience. Do you agree? Women go to movies about characters. When you think about war movies and women, you have to think about the reason why there is fighting: if it's emotional or just fighting for fighting's sake. With "Saving Private Ryan," the point was to rescue someone's remaining son. For women, that story is emotional. It's not, Can you capture that hill over there. To market a war movie successfully, the film needs to have something at stake: honor or pride or personal dignity. That's why audiences like films about W.W.II. There's no gray to it.

title: Juliette Has Fun (Before She Dies, of Course)
description: IN late October, several levels below the stage at the Metropolitan Opera House, chorus and dancers in Renaissance masks and motley rehearsal clothes were getting up to speed for the ball in Guy Joosten's new production of Charles Gounod's "Romo et Juliette," which opens Monday. Off to one side, barely noticed, a tiny creature knelt on the floor clutching a dagger in both hands. Suddenly, she plunged it into the pit of her stomach -- then again and again and again, with fierce concentration, stifling a gasp each time.

description: GILES--Patrick, 48, On October 13, after a thirteen month battle with Lymphoma. Patrick was a consummate sibling, friend, writer, critic, teacher, and New Yorker--a champion for the transforming power of culture, ideas and ideals. There will be a memorial mass said on November 18th at 7 P.M. at the Church of St. Paul The Apostle (9th Avenue between 59th & 60th St). Those of his many friends who would like to contribute or read others' recollections of this wonderful man should go to auracentral.com In lieu of flowers, please make donations in Patrick's name to Cancer Care Inc.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEBSTER, DOROTHY
description: WEBSTER--Dorothy, 92. Died peacefully on Thursday, November 10, 2005, at Victoria Home in Ossining, New York. Dorothy was born in Little Neston, England, and came to America in 1967 with her youngest daughter JUne Webster Walden to join her son Barrie Webster (deceased 1992) and her oldest daughter Norma Hill. Dorothy lived in Hartsdale, NY, for many years and worked in White Plains as a medical assistant to Dr. Tennyson D. Phillips. A loving and gentle soul she will be missed by everyone who loved and knew her. Memorial service on Tuesday, November 15th, at 11 AM, at the Larchmont Avenue Church, 60 Forest Park Ave., Larchmont, N.Y. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Victoria Home, 25 North Malcolm Street, Ossining, NY.

title: A Game Evokes the Contests Between Lasker and Chigorin
description: Mikhail Chigorin was the first Russian to become a luminary of the game. He did not win the world championship in his two tries against Wilhelm Steinitz, in 1889 and 1892, although in the second he would almost surely have done so had he not made an incredible blunder and fallen into a sorry checkmate in the 23d encounter of the series.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Mother Trying to Put Some Joy in What Remains of Her 2 Children's Lives
description: Santa Artiles says that her most fervent wish is that a cure will be found in time to save her 5-year-old son and 3-year-old daughter from the rare blistering disease that is torturing them as it is killing them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CLARK, DONALD G.C., M.D.
description: CLARK--Donald G.C., M.D. The Members of the Society of Memorial Gynecologic Oncologists and the Division of Gynecology at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center record with profound regret the recent death of their colleague and friend Donald G.C. Clark, M.D. Dr. Clark was a member of the Gynecology Service at Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center from July 1, 1956 until July 1, 1987. He was appointed to the Emeritus Staff in 1987. He was regarded as an excellent surgeon and teacher who devoted his career to caring for women with cancer. He will be missed by all.

title: Talk Movie Talk, And Hang Out With 'Money'
description: HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON - GROUPS of professionals tend to invent their own private languages, because shortcuts save time, and also perhaps to endow their fields with allure and mystery.

title: Beyond Lift Lines, Online
description: Go heli-skiing in Alaska, rollick in luxury on 5,300 skiable acres at Vail (above) in Colorado, or enroll your kids in the Little Rascals on Snow program at Smugglers' Notch in Vermont. An online guide to some of the best places for extreme skiing, luxury resorts, family resorts and more is at nytimes.com/travel.

title: Turin, Italy: Grand Hotel Sitea
description: THE BASICS -- The Grand Hotel Sitea, part of the Turin Hotels International chain, exemplifies measured Piedmontese refinement. Detractors might call it prudish; others would describe it as dignified. The city is gussying up for the Winter Olympics in February, and the 80-year-old, four-star Sitea is doing the same. By the time the Olympic flame is ablaze in this northern Italian city, the hotel will have a completely refurbished facade, six more rooms and high-speed Internet connections in all 120 rooms. Aside from the scaffolding outside, you'd never know renovations are under way; there is no extra noise.

title: Officer Wounded In Deadly Shootout
description: A shootout erupted last night after two Hamilton Township, N.J., police officers pulled over an S.U.V. at the Trenton border and the driver shot one of them while trying to flee. The other officer returned the fire, and the driver, a 36-year-old Trenton man, was killed, the Mercer County prosecutor's office said.

title: Burress Proving to Be Quite a Catch
description: Plaxico Burress sat with his back to his locker two Fridays ago, idly chatting while packing for the Giants' trip to San Francisco. He stopped. Something was missing.

title: AVAILABLE FOR HIRE
description: Two months after resigning under fire for his handling of aid efforts after Hurricane Katrina, Michael D. Brown, the ex-chief of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, actually left the agency's payroll last week.

title: Food Pantries Feel a Post-Hurricane Pinch
description: HUNGRY people who go to the Christian Community Action food pantry in New Haven these days can no longer get cereal. At the East End Community Center in Bridgeport, those seeking a meal no longer have hotdogs and frozen dinners as options.

title: The Dish on the Bushes
description: Deborah Solomon's interview with Ariel De Guzman, the longtime personal chef to George and Barbara Bush, affirms that President Bush the elder presented a poor example in nutrition (Oct. 30). Apparently, George W. Bush was raised on a diet of frozen vegetables, mayonnaise and heavy cream. If that doesn't sound an alarm for parents to make sure that their children eat healthfully, I don't know what will.

title: The End of Pensions?
description: Roger Lowenstein's article was excellent (Oct. 30). My father's work buddy was an avid and responsible saver. He contributed the maximum allowed to his 401(k) and chose good investments for his age. After 20 years he had a nest egg in addition to the company's pension plan. In 1998, after watching his buddies' 401(k)'s soar beyond his own, he transferred all his assets into the tech funds that were making them rich. Three years later half his savings was gone. One year later the underfunded steel company went bankrupt. He and my father will receive a fraction of what they expected because of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporations's benefit cap.

The new TheaterWorks production of William Nicholson's weighty three-character play "The Retreat From Moscow" lives by that law.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARCUS, DR. JULES A.
description: MARCUS--Dr. Jules A., 86, retired physics professor, died at home in CT. on November 5, 2005. Son of Julia Parks and Alexander Marcus, attended Ethical Culture and Walden Schools; graduated Yale, '40; married Ruth Barcan, '42; worked for the Navy in WW II; received PhD, Yale, '47; taught at Northwestern U., '49-'89; survived by his sister, his former wife, four children and three grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BECK, DR. ARTHUR
description: BECK--Dr. Arthur. Age 90, on November 11, 2005 in Trumbull, CT. Born in Brooklyn. Devoted husband of the late Ruth Beck; beloved father of Dr. Lawrence & Alice Beck, Dr. Michael & Marcia Beck; adored grandfather of Sara, Andrew, Marissa, Morgen, and brother of Mildred Jonas. Dr. Beck was a graduate of Columbia University in 1936 and the Medical College of Glasgow and Edinborough in 1940. He served in the military as a troop ship physician until 1945, and practiced 37 years in Brooklyn until his retirement to Florida in 1984. He will be deeply missed by his family, friends and patients. Services Sunday Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. Shiva Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday at the home of Dr. Michael & Marcia Beck. Memorial contributions to Bridgeport Hospital Foundation, 267 Grant St., Bridgeport, CT. 06610.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZIERING, HERMAN
description: ZIERING--Herman. The AntiDefamation League mourns the passing of Herman Ziering, a longtime ADL activist and supporter. A survivor of the Riga ghetto, Herman's leadership on ADL's Task Force on Nazi War Criminals was invaluable in the effort to bring to justice those responsible for the Holocaust. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Lea and the entire family. Barbara B. Balser National Chair Abraham H. Foxman National Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BUCHIN, JOHN D.
description: BUCHIN--John D. Age 50, on November 11, 2005, in Los Angeles, CA, after a long, courageous battle against lymphoma. Beloved son of Jean and the late Irving, dear brother of Peter and brotherin-law of Marilyn, cherished uncle of Benjamin. Graduate of the Horace Mann School; B.A. University of Pennsylvania; M.A. Northwestern University. He was a television reporter and journalist in NYC, and later a marketing director for corporations. A talented and creative individual who was well-loved by many people. His courage in the face of illness was an inspiration to us all. He will be missed dearly. Contributions may be made to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society.

title: Timed Deposits: Small Banks Finding a Niche, One Branch at a Time
description: OPENING a one-branch bank bucks the industry trend: big banks are in. But that is what Community National Bank has done in Great Neck.

title: Harry Who?
description: Boys love action heroes. Entertainers from Homer on have known how to enthrall the barely bearded with tales of derring-do, whether their chase scenes are powered by wind, oats or rocket fuel. Two new adventure stories cleverly draw on great examples of this tradition: the Greek myths, which gave us the word "hero," and the Arthurian legends, which celebrated honor equally with courage. Both follow a more recent model - Harry Potter - in taking as the hero an ordinary boy who at first seems set apart from his peers, not by any special talent but by his painful home life and his difficulties fitting in.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Nov. 13 -- Nov. 19; ART/ARCHITECTURE
description: Travel photography usually shows us beautiful and exotic locales we wish we could visit ourselves. But many photographers travel in pursuit of something more than just another pretty place. STEPHEN SHORE, for example, traveled all over the United States in 1972 and '73, and the almost 250 small, jewel-bright color pictures that resulted suggest a wry, downbeat search for the American soul in the most ordinary of people and situations. "American Surfaces" continues at the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Street, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084, through Jan. 23.

title: Psst! 'Human Capital'
description: Help! I'm turning into the "plastics" guy from "The Graduate." I'm pulling people aside at parties and whispering that if they want to understand the future, it's just two words: "Human Capital."

title: A Very French Message From the Disaffected
description: PARIS, Nov. 11 - The last time France was convulsed by rioting as serious as the current bout -- the student revolts of 1968 -- the symbol of the insurrection was a paving stone, which the protesters dug out of the streets by the hundreds to hurl at the truncheon-wielding police officers.

title: Ski Lures: Halfpipes and Wine Bars
description: THIS ski season, resorts are going more extreme: Their lifts are getting bigger and faster, the slopes they access are steeper and narrower, and their terrain parks are getting larger in number and size. With the expansion of lodges and time-share developments, and major overhauls of entire towns, resorts hope to lure more skiiers -- and some nonskiers -- to their properties. No matter whether the improvements are on- or off-mountain though, the key ingredient is a healthy dose of snow. Few businesses rely on snowfall as much as the ski industry, and some early-season storms and last year's hefty tallies (except in the Pacific Northwest) bode well for this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EFRON, LILLIAN WESTERMAN
description: EFRON--Lillian Westerman. Age 95, of Rockville, MD, died peacefully on November 7, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin Efron, loving mother of Sheila (Steven) Efron, Taube and Richard (Kay), grandmother of Michelle and David (Somer) Taube, Amanda and Elenia Efron. Great grandmother of Rebecca. Beloved sister of the late Abe Westerman and Pearl Mizrachi, survived by sister, Ann Steindler. She worked tirelessly to insure that all people had equal opportunities. title: The Army That Isnt
Steps to Take Before the Collective Well Runs Dry

Carl Edwards is not expected to stretch his winning streak to three races in a row, but you never know. Edwards has been performing the unexpected all season.

title: The Funny Pages
description: My husband and I look forward to every installment of Elmore Leonard's "Comfort to the Enemy." We even make special arrangements to get a copy of the magazine when we are out of town to make sure we don't miss one. Thank you for the Funny Pages.

title: Their Highbrow Hatred of Us
description: As an American who lives in Europe, I can tell you that it's not only the "highbrows" here who dislike many United States foreign policies (James Traub, Oct. 30). Lowbrows, ordinary working stiffs, average people on the street -- many of them admire the United States for its expressed ideals yet despise it for its real international behavior. Is that hatred? No. Only an American who craves adoration from everyone would think it is.

title: Corzine Seems Headed For a Short Honeymoon
description: FOR a moment, while Jon S. Corzine was pounding and railing about corruption to the victory-party crowd Tuesday night, he brought to mind an evangelist who had recently discovered exorcism.

title: Real Energy Savers Don't Wear Cardigans. Or Do They?
description: WHEN oil and gas prices surged after Hurricanes Katrina and Rita, President Bush appealed to Americans to conserve energy. He asked people to cut back on nonessential travel, for example, and to carpool to work. Then, in October, the White House started a campaign for energy conservation in American homes, dusting off some old ideas like switching to fluorescent light bulbs and installing better insulation in attics.

title: Corrections
description: An article about "Memoirs of a Geisha" last Sunday in the Holiday Movies issue of this section misstated the director Rob Marshall's Oscar record. He was nominated for directing "Chicago"; he did not win, but the movie itself won as best picture.

Paid Notice: Deaths   BRUCK, MILTON
description: BRUCK--Milton. Age 95, on November 7, 2005. Devoted husband of the late Ruth. Beloved father to Joseph and Linda. Adoring grandfather to Darren, Craig and Jonathan. Businessman, member of the Musician's Union and the Knights of Pythias, Mason, member of the Forest Hills Jewish Center. A very special person loved by all. Services Monday, November 14, at Parkside Memorial Chapel, Forest Hills, at 12:45 PM.

title: FORMER STATE SENATOR'S OFFICE RAIDED
description: Federal agents last Wednesday raided the law offices of John A. Lynch, a former state senator from Middlesex County who is one of the state's most powerful Democratic Party leaders. It was unclear what they were looking for. The United States attorney's office and the F.B.I. have been investigating real estate development deals in central New Jersey involving several of Mr. Lynch's political allies and business associates. He charged that the inquiry had been spurred by unfair and unfounded characterizations of his business and political dealings in the local news media.

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: CONDUCT UNDER FIRE: Four American Doctors and Their Fight for Life as Prisoners of the Japanese 1941-1945. By John A. Glusman. (Viking, $29.95.) "Conduct Under Fire" is a chaotic, undisciplined, seriously flawed, and wonderful book. Glusman's father, a Navy doctor, was captured by the Japanese on Corregidor in 1942 and imprisoned, along with three of his colleagues, for nearly three and a half years. This is supposed to be their story, but the author wanders so haphazardly that we never really get to know the men, not even Glusman's father, Murray. Instead, Glusman has amassed a truly astounding amount of information about P.O.W.'s in the Pacific, down to what seems to be every last illness, ration and death. At one point, describing a sinking ship, he writes: "Her position was 20.00N 118.44E, southeast of the Pratas Reefs." (Yes, I can picture it now.) Still, the details have a cumulative power. Lucille Ferguson continued to receive postcards from her husband, one of the four doctors, listing his health as excellent, for nearly a year after his death. One American nightclub owner, known as "High Pockets" because she stuffed her bra with valuables, smuggled 10,000 quinine tablets into a camp. And there's the story of Second Lt. Robert Overbeck, a P.O.W. on a Japanese ship hit by the Americans. Overbeck swam out the torpedo hole, found a lifeboat, discovered a sail in a crate that was floating by, and made it 250 miles to the only strip of China's coast not occupied by the Japanese. If Glusman had exerted more control over these riches, "Conduct" might have been a home run. As it is, the details get him to third base.

title: In Jordan, Methodical Madness
description: ALL is chaos under heaven," a revolutionary once wrote, "and the situation is excellent." The writer was not Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the terrorist whose group has claimed responsibility for the triple bombing last week in Amman, Jordan, but Chairman Mao.

title: Despite Loss, Knicks See Improvement
description: SACRAMENTO, Nov. 12 - The list of things that went right for the Knicks on Friday night, as articulated by Coach Larry Brown, was lengthy and detailed. Their turnovers were down, their defense was sturdy and their poise was noteworthy. The list of what went wrong was more limited: They lost again, despite their best effort of the season.

description: In mid-July, senior American intelligence officials called the leaders of the international atomic inspection agency to the top of a skyscraper overlooking the Danube in Vienna and unveiled the contents of what they said was a stolen Iranian laptop computer.

description: STUPELL--Leah. Our Mudgie died peacefully on November 11th at age 101 at home in NYC after a wonderful life of living and loving. Beloved wife of the late Edward, cherised mother of Ruth (and Bernie) Weinflash, adored and idolized grandmother of Jody (and Steve Konstadt), Jeff (and Elahna) and Carol (and Michael) Kopelman, loved great-grandmother of Michelle, Debbie, Sarah, Eden, Noah, Emily and Naomi. She touched so many lives with her unmatched warmth and generosity. She was a true fairy Godmother to her family and friends. Services 1:30 P.M. Sunday at GuttermanMusicant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, NJ.

description: JUSTIN LI is not due to graduate from Manhasset High School until next June. But he has already mailed his application to the Wharton School, the prestigious business college at the University of Pennsylvania. Weeks ago, in fact.

title: Now Playing the Artist
description: Re "Self-Mutilation Is the Sincerest Form of Flattery" by Randy Kennedy [Nov. 6] and Marina Abramovic's failure to get permission from Chris Burden to perform his work: In the 1970's I was in performance festivals in Europe with both artists, and they are both great artists. But I don't blame Mr. Burden for refusing to even discuss with Ms. Abramovic having his work recreated. The performance art of the early 1970's was concrete. We made one-time sculpture actions. If Mr. Burden's work were recreated by another artist, it would be turned into theater, one artist playing the role of another.

title: What's a Modern Girl to Do?
description: I'm as happy as the next woman to sit around with my friends, trashing some man for whatever insensitive, sexist or duplicitous behavior in which he has lately engaged. Still, I think that with her blanket condemnation of men for their tendencies to date or marry down, Maureen Dowd isn't looking at the whole picture. She seems to be focused an awful lot on the needs and desires of famous and powerful men, a pretty small fraction of the population.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Nov. 13 -- Nov. 19; DANCE
description: The BATSHEVA DANCE COMPANY is based in Tel Aviv and is 41 years old. Since 1990 its artistic director has been Ohad Naharin, who counts as about the most consistently interesting choreographer to have emerged from Israel. The good news is that the company is returning under the auspices of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival for a 13-performance run of a Naharin piece called "Mamootot." The good and bad news is that the performances will be in a small space in Mark Morris's gleaming Dance Center, cater-corner from the main academy building. That should make Mr. Naharin's choreography look intimate and intense, but it will severely limit the number of people who can see it. Tuesday through Friday and Nov. 22, 23 and 25 at 7:30 p.m., Saturday and Nov. 26 at 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., next Sunday and Nov. 27 at 3 p.m., James and Martha Duffy Performance Space, Mark Morris Dance Center, 3 Lafayette Avenue, Fort Greene, Brooklyn; (718) 636-4100 or www.bam.org; $40 (sold out).

title: Resisting 'Affordable' Homes in Darien
description: DARIEN - A HUSBAND-AND-WIFE development team is invoking Connecticut's controversial affordable housing law to circumvent restrictions on multifamily housing in an exclusive neighborhood here. Their proposal for 20 units of senior housing on one acre in a section more acclimated toward Wall Street moguls and yachting enthusiasts has riled residents and resurrected calls for repeal of the statute.

I've also noticed that there are a lot of women who find themselves unhappily single after years of routinely rejecting sincere guys who weren't rich, handsome or successful enough. Yet these same women are often indignant about similar male shallowness.

A bartender served pitchers full of nonalcoholic strawberry daiquiris and pia coladas.

title: Singing an Urgent Song of Attica
description: COMPOSERS, no matter how evident their stylistic allegiances may be, almost invariably prefer to regard themselves as unclassifiable. Frederic Rzewski is harder to classify than most. His overtly political pieces receive a lot of attention, but he writes plenty of works free of extramusical agendas, and they are no less striking. Stylistically, he is everywhere, from Minimalism to 12-tone and densely pounded clusters that sidestep debates about tonality entirely.

My car was seen in the neighbor's driveway overnight, easily recognizable because of my kid's college decals plastered on it. A few people have inquired about my car's being there overnight. How do I explain without ratting out my friend?

title: Consuming Spirit
What's a Modern Girl to Do?
description: Dowd cites a report indicating that high I.Q. is inversely correlated to marriage rate for women, seemingly to suggest that intelligent women are less attractive to men. This might be true to some extent. However, the reverse might also be true: that intelligent women find fewer men attractive as suitable life partners. Women who make thoughtful decisions and expect excellence in their professional lives tend to apply this same standard to their personal lives and are unwilling to settle for less.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BORN, HENRY
description: BORN--Henry. The entire St. Luke's - Roosevelt Hospital Center family joins with the leadership of its parent company, Continuum Health Partners, in acknowledging with sadness the passing of our beloved friend and benefactor, Henry Born. Together with his late sister Mildred, they established the Born Critical Care Unit at Roosevelt Hospital in memory of their parents. In addition, they endowed a major fund to support cardiac research, and Henry generously supported the Hospital's clinical and research efforts in hepatobiliary and pancreatic medicine. Henry will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved him. To his family and friends, we extend heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Boards of Trustees, Continuum and St. Luke'sRoosevelt Stanley Brezenoff, President and CEO, Continuum Richard F. Daines, M.D., President and CEO, St. Luke's-Roosevelt

Finkelstein of River Edge, N.J. Rabbi Neal Borovitz is to officiate at Pleasantdale Chateau, a caterer in West Orange, N.J. After the couple have said their vows they will hold a traditional Chinese tea ceremony.

title: 'The Lost Painting': The Caravaggio Trail
description: Historians take windows where they can find them, and in certain circles this entry from a 17th-century ledger bears particularly vivid witness: On Jan. 2, 1603, a Roman nobleman named Ciriaco Mattei paid 125 scudi - the liras of the day - for what his bookkeeper described as "a painting with its frame of Christ taken in the garden." The artist in question, Michelangelo Merisi, known to most of us as Caravaggio (after his hometown outside Milan), was then among the most famous, innovative and copied painters in Rome - the Picasso of his day, more or less. But tastes change, and the realism that was bracing and revelatory to his contemporaries left a bad odor in the 18th and 19th centuries. By the turn of the last one Caravaggio had become but a footnote in art history. And so, another window: on April 16, 1921, according to the notation on a catalog from a now defunct auction house, "The Taking of Christ," misattributed at the time to a minor Dutch painter, was sold at auction in Edinburgh, for a mere eight guineas, a silk purse pawned off as a pig's ear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRUEN, SYLVIA
description: GRUEN - Sylvia. Passed away November 11, age 97. She is survived by daughter Suzanne, son Arthur, daughter-in-law Mary Anne, granddaughters Dana and Gillian and great - granddaughter Lexi. Graveside service Monday, 11 am, Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ.

title: Best Illustrated Books
description: The illustrations on these pages have been taken from the Book Review's choices of the 10 best illustrated children's books of 2005. Every year since 1952, the Book Review has asked a panel of judges to make a selection from among the several thousand children's books published that year. The judges this year were Roger Sutton, the editor of The Horn Book magazine; Starr LaTronica, from the Four County Library System in Vestal, N.Y.; and Jules Feiffer, a writer and illustrator whose most recent book is "A Room With a Zoo." As a matter of note, Chris Raschka has been a winner three times before, and Alexis Deacon and Robert Sabuda once each.

title: 5,000 Tickets Issued To Aggressive Drivers
description: The first six months of a state-wide crackdown on aggressive driving resulted in more than 5,000 tickets and more than $1 million in fines, Gov. M. Jodi Rell's office said on Nov. 3.

title: The Need for Speed
description: THE closest we come to free flight in our lives is not when we take off in an airplane. It is when we drive our cars. The speed, altitude, centrifugal forces and sensations of flying that we experience behind the wheel of an S.U.V., a sports car or, in my case, an economy box, let us feel what it is like to be a bird. This partly explains why we love our cars, preferring this mode of locomotion to any other, even walking and running, for which we are supremely adapted.

title: So Changed, So Decidedly Grown-Up
description: KATONAH - THE young family looked bewildered. "Where's my favorite salad?" the mother asked the waiter, as she turned the menu over again and again. "Don't you have a children's menu?"

title: Frances Evans, Lisa Faccadio
description: Frances M. Evans and Lisa A. Faccadio affirmed their partnership in a civil union ceremony on Friday at their home in Middletown, Conn. Helen F. Ryan, a Middletown justice of the peace, officiated.

description: Cornelia Barnwell Spruill, an editor, and Todd Douglas Dykshorn, an architect, were married on Friday at the courthouse in Charlotte Court House, Va. Stuart B. Fallen, the circuit court clerk there, officiated.

description: Must women and men hurl stereotypes at one another? We've heard it over and over: Men want only bimbos; women like their men rich and arrogant. Let's talk about people, and their diverse needs, for a change.

title: The End of Pensions?
description: As more and more pensions are at risk, it becomes ever more important for us to keep Social Security strong and not cut benefits. If a pension fund fails, Social Security may be what makes the difference between basic survival and destitution for the fund's recipients.

"I have to tell you about this story, or it will possess me for the rest of my natural-born life," Ms. Maddow mentioned one very early morning last month.

description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 12 - Former officials of the Baath Party confirmed Saturday on their Web site the death of Izzat Ibrahim al-Douri, the last of Saddam Hussein's inner circle still at large in Iraq and a man long sought by the American military command as the effective leader of the Baathist insurgent underground here.

title: Are U.S. Innovators Losing Their Competitive Edge?
description: Baltimore - WHEN James E. West was 8 years old, he propped himself on his bed's brass footboard one afternoon and stretched to plug the cord of a radio he had repaired into a ceiling outlet. It was one of his first experiments. Mr. West's hand sealed to the light socket as 120 volts of electricity shimmied through his body, freezing him in place until his brother knocked him from the footboard and onto the floor.

title: How to Make Employees Take Their 401(k) Medicine
description: WITH more than $2 trillion invested in 401(k) retirement plans, it is hard to argue with their popularity. But a check under the hood of the 401(k), the primary retirement savings vehicle for Americans, shows a rash of problems that can send many plans back to the shop for overhauls.

title: Turin, Italy: Grand Hotel Sitea
description: THE BASICS  The Grand Hotel Sitea, part of the Turin Hotels International chain, exemplifies measured Piedmontese refinement. Detractors might call it prudish; others would describe it as dignified. The city is gussying up for the Winter Olympics in February, and the 80-year-old, four-star Sitea is doing the same. By the time the Olympic flame is ablaze in this northern Italian city, the hotel will have a completely refurbished facade, six more rooms and high-speed Internet connections in all 120 rooms. Aside from the scaffolding outside, you'd never know renovations are under way; there is no extra noise.

The editors who permitted this affront should be dressed down for an unpardonable lapse of taste.

title: Watch This, It's for Your Own Good
description: DISCOVERY HEALTH, though enjoyable, is misnamed. The language probably scares away some viewers, who expect to find the usual waiting-room magazine filler -- diet tips, exercise regimens and hymns to the power of antioxidants. Far from it! Instead one finds a wonderworld of gruesome diseases, burn victims and breech births, a little Mtter Museum in your own home. And as bad as it gets, it's hard to stop watching.

description: Last spring, when the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission voted to protect a triangular glass building in Elmhurst, Queens, that was once home to a branch of the Jamaica Savings Bank, the commission's report called the modernist structure "bold," "eye-catching," "unique" and "memorable."

The History of a Loft Reflects the His-and-Her Story of a Couple
description: THE evolution of David Scott's Red Hook loft from party pad to stylishly designed apartment tracked the 38-year-old's personal growth. Once a stay-up-all-night bachelor, he is now a married entrepreneur who goes to bed around 9 p.m. so he can get an early start on his work -- making modern furniture for his own Brooklyn-based design firm.

title: It's Showtime, and McGrady Dazzles the Nets
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 12 - The question that faced the Nets after their 99-91 loss to the Houston Rockets on Saturday night was a tricky one.

title: A Kaleidoscope From Argentina
description: Argentina's love affair with torronts, a grape and white wine, translates into 20,000 planted acres. The wine, reminiscent of viognier and muscat, is alluring. Susana Balbo makes exceptional torronts. Her dry, refreshing 2005 Crios has a flower-shop bouquet and a honey and fruit-compote flavor. Its kaleidoscopic effects are best appreciated if the wine is drunk young and lightly chilled. Harlem Vintage, 2235 Frederick Douglass Boulevard (121st Street), asks $17. (VOS Selections is the New York distributor.) HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: While We Weren't Looking
description: One hard and fast rule about New York's state government -- about any government at all, really -- is that you have to watch 'em every minute. Here is a troubling example: While we were all busy with elections, the State Board of Elections issued a draft proposal for buying $220 million worth of new voting machines. Apparently, the manufacturers will be allowed -- perhaps even encouraged -- to push for one type of machine, while many civic groups and concerned voters are pushing for something else.

title: Do Jokes Told in Vegas Stay in Vegas?
description: What's so funny about Las Vegas? Starting Thursday, there may be more comedians on the Las Vegas Strip than showgirls: Jerry Seinfeld, Jerry Lewis, George Carlin, Chris Rock, Garry Shandling, Jon Stewart (right), Larry David and others -- at last count, the list included more than 110 comics -- will be taking over Caesars Palace and the Flamingo Las Vegas for a three-day event called, simply enough, the Comedy Festival.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TETZELI, FREDERICK EDWARD
description: TETZELI--Frederick Edward, 75. Of Boca Grande, FL, died in peace November 8, 2005 in Charlottesville, VA surrounded by his family. Fred was born September 12, 1930, in Chomutov, Czechoslovakia, the son of Baron Louis Tetzeli von Rosador and Countess Sophinka Deym. Fred lived in Czechoslovakia; Havana, Cuba; Milan, Italy; Princeton, NJ and Boca Grande, FL. He was married to Margaret Lee Weld with whom he raised three sons. Fred was an international banker for J.P. Morgan. Following the untimely passing of his wife, Lee, Fred retired to Boca Grande, FL in 2002, Fred married Diane Duys of Miami, FL. Fred is survived by his children, Rick, Bill and Chris; his wife, Diane; his brother, John; and his grandchildren, Jonah, Tal and Maude. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Our Lady of Mercy Catholic Church, 240 Park Ave., Boca Grande, FL 33921.

description: JESUS LAND

title: This TV Soap Opera May Outlive Its Star
description: How eager was NBC Universal to resolve its feud with Lowell W. Paxson, the founder of Paxson Communications? If Mr. Paxson, who is 70, dies in the next few years, NBC may be paying him not to compete with it from beyond the grave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRANDT, IDA (NEE JACOBSON)
description: BRANDT--Ida (nee Jacobson). Died Friday, November 11, 2005, in Hampshire Care in Leeds, MA. She was 90. A longtime resident of Riverdale, NY, she along with her husband, Stanley M. Brandt, an insurance executive, who predeceased her in 1995, later lived in Somers, NY. Funeral service Sunday, November 13, at 3:30 pm, at the Jewish Community of Amherst, MA. Burial Monday, November 14, at 1:30 pm, at Westchester Hills Cemetery in Hastingson-Hudson, NY.

title: Delta faces threat of a pilots' strike

The French Riots: A Political Scorecard
description: PARIS - A LONGSIDE the urban unrest that has swept France in the last two weeks, another battle has been taking place. It is the political contest over who among France's politicians will gain and who will lose from the rioting. Thus far, one observation seems inescapable: tough talk seems to be working with the public, as opposed to a discussion of the general condition of the alienated children and grandchildren of immigrants, whose frustration has fueled the violence.

title: What's a Modern Girl to Do?
description: In recent years we've heard from writers like Dowd talking to their elite peers about this supposed trend toward ditching diplomas and heading for home. There is always a sentence or two of lip service given to those who have to work, whose families are threatened, as factories close, farms go under and day care doesn't happen. Where do those women stand in this feminist evolution? I frankly don't know but would like to see someone outside the Ivy League and the Beltway reporting on this subject. Paging Barbara Ehrenreich!

title: Confusion Is Rife About Drug Plan as Sign-Up Nears
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 - Enrollment in the new Medicare drug benefit begins in three days, but even with President Bush hailing the plan on Saturday as "the greatest advance in health care for seniors" in 40 years, large numbers of older Americans appear to be overwhelmed and confused by the choices they will have to make.

title: Smile and Say 'Bone'
description: ON a recent Sunday morning, Amanda Jones arranged lights, set out snacks and erected a stark white backdrop in a rented a photography studio in Chelsea as she awaited her clients. Briscoe, her 11 o'clock, bounded in with so much excitement that his companion looked worried.

title: The City Giveth, and the City Taketh Away
description: WHEN the East River Drive was built in the 1930's, the loss to some riverfront owners was considerable: River House, at 52nd Street, lost its riverside terrace; 10 Gracie Square, at 84th Street, lost its pier. But several buildings came out ahead -- among them the 1926 co-op at 1 Sutton Place South, one of New York's great apartment houses.

description: WAYNE - IN the late 1980's when Andrew Hopper moved into the low-lying, wooded, working-class Hoffman Grove neighborhood here on the banks of the Pompton River, he took full advantage of the floods that would regularly maroon him in his house.

title: Ireland shaken by sex abuse report
Corrections
description: A map on Page 4 of the Travel section today with the Surfacing column, about Bulgaria, carries an outdated label in some copies for an adjacent country to the west. It is Serbia and Montenegro, not Yugoslavia.

title: Drug Arrest on Bridge
description: Officers arrested a Hillburn, N.Y., man, identified as Shawn Chance, 23, after he was stopped yesterday on the George Washington Bridge with 600 pounds of marijuana worth $1 million, the Port Authority police said. They said they pulled over Mr. Chance because he was driving on the bridge's lower level, where trucks are not permitted. He was charged with possession of and intent to distribute marijuana.

title: An Invisible Director Gets Physical
description: WHEN Johannes Wieland gave his dance company no name but his own -- just that, Johannes Wieland -- it may have been the only ego-driven act of his career. More typically, this postmodern choreographer, whose austere dances suggest both physical and psychic violence, operates like a disappearing act.

title: The World's Most Unlikely Movie Star
description: If the conventional image of a philosopher is a rumpled, retiring fellow scribbling away in obscurity, a coming documentary on the Slovenian whirlwind Slavoj Zizek will radically change that notion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RHODES, WILLIAM D.
description: RHODES--William D. An investor whose successful career on Wall Street spanned over 60 years died October 31, 2005. Mr. Rhodes headed the Economics, Research and Investment Departments at the firm of Lionel D. Edie & Co. He was born in West Virginia and educated at Indiana University. He served in the Intelligence Corp during WWII. He is survived by his wife Sally and three sons Ross, Andrew and Mitchell Bartlett.

title: What's a Modern Girl to Do?
description: In Dowd's discussion about who should pick up the check on dates, I was shocked to find that nowhere did she suggest that men and women, rather than being weighted down by either feminist or traditional expectations and assumptions, should simply discuss the issue between themselves as individuals. If even Dowd misses the point that men and women need to communicate with one another more openly and honestly, how are we going to make progress?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TRIPPE, JOHN TERRY
description: TRIPPE--John Terry. Died peacefully on October 29 in Mechanicsville, PA after a long illness. He was 67. Husband of Jane Reis and proud father of Juan T. Trippe II. Beloved son of the late Betty and Juan Trippe. His sister Betsy T. DeVecchi and brothers Charles W. Trippe and Edward S. Trippe survive as well as 11 nieces and nephews. Private funeral services will be held at Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY on November 17. Contributions in John's memory may be sent to the National Alliance for Research on Schizophrenia and Depression, 60 Cutter Mill Road, Great Neck, NY 11021.

title: Want to Make Millions? First, Get the Loan
description: NELL MERLINO winced when the last census showed that women owned nearly half of the nation's privately held businesses -- but that four times as many men as women owned companies that raked in more than $1 million a year.

title: Darfur Crisis Defies Even Redoubled U.S. Peace Efforts
description: JUBA, Sudan, Nov. 11 - As three white helicopters carrying Robert B. Zoellick and his traveling party began descending over the Kalma refugee camp in the Darfur region of Sudan on Thursday afternoon, crowds of refugees -- thousands of them -- stopped what they were doing, then ran to the camp's central square.

title: Post-Its for Passers-By
description: During the Republican National Convention last year, Robert Pietri, a 37-year-old filmmaker from Park Slope, was arrested on 16th Street between Irving Place and Park Avenue South. You'd know that if you went to that block -- well, if you went to that location, and if you had a Motorola i860 cellphone, and if that phone were connected to a program called Socialight.

title: The N.B.A.'s New Age Rule Will Get Old in a Hurry
description: THEY are certainly a breed of wildlife fitted in custom suits for their harrowing journey to March Madness in search of a perfect end, but this isn't the methodical "March of the Penguins."

title: Mysteries of the Amazon
description: My search through the wish lists on Amazon.com yielded five results. I could immediately rule out the Jeff of Athens, Ohio. "Jeff r" seemed too capricious with the shift key to be the right person, and his taste in DVD's ("The Cannonball Run"? "Aces: Iron Eagle III"?) seemed all wrong. But the third Jeff had filled out his "Unique Facts" section: "New to the city," he'd written -- just as he'd mentioned at the party where I met him. "Likes: baseball, indie films, radio comedy." This definitely was the Jeff that I knew. Well, knew a little. And liked. Maybe like liked: he did, after all, want the "Freaks and Geeks" boxed set.

title: Not Going Softly, But Still Headlining And Swinging to the Beat
description: Correction Appended

title: It's Like Selling Meals by the Bite. And It May Work.
description: HOW much is this sentence -- the very one you are reading right now -- worth? Is it potentially more valuable than this entire column, this section, or the entire newspaper itself? This is not a play for a raise or a plug for the genius of my prose, but a riff on the latest mania in media-land: finding new ways to be paid for old material. Nearly every day, it seems, a new business strategy emerges that on its face may sound not only counterintuitive but also absurd. Then consumers start to buy it, and you can only say, "Who knew?"

title: The Democrats and Judge Alito
description: Judge Samuel Alito has been working hard to win over moderate Democratic senators. But just as it would be irresponsible to reject his nomination to the Supreme Court without giving him a full hearing, it is unwise to embrace it -- or rule out the possibility of a filibuster -- until more is known.

Beloved wife of Stanley Poll. Memorial service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St., Tuesday, November 15 at 5:30 P.M. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Scleroderma Foundation, 59 Front Street, Binghampton, New York 13905.

description: You present convincing evidence of the blameworthiness of Bill Keller, the executive editor, in the Judith Miller episodes. You articulate the errors he committed in his handling of Ms. Miller's stories, particularly his failure to thoroughly question her research and the validity of her conclusions.

title: NEW OPERATOR TO TAKE OVER FERRY ROUTE
description: The high cost of fuel has thrown the New Jersey high-speed commuter ferry business into flux. New York Water Taxi, an operation whose principal owner is the developer Douglas Durst, is scrambling to take over service between South Amboy and Manhattan. The current operator, SeaStreak America Inc., is moving to quit the business, citing losses caused by the spike in the price of fuel. South Amboy's mayor, John T. O'Leary, said last Monday that city officials had struck a deal with New York Water Taxi that would prevent a disruption in ferry service. But he added that commuters would have to pay more for the service. Starting Monday, the price of 20 round trips on the new service will be $440, about 20 percent more than SeaStreak has been charging.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of DVD gift sets last Sunday in the Holiday Movies issue of this section misstated the number of films in the collection "The Matt Helm Lounge." It is four, not three.

description: The superstar treatment is not what it seems. For four marquee players experiencing inauspicious beginnings, it has less to do with pampering and more to do with rehabilitation.

description: This year's selections, chosen by a panel of judges assembled by the Book Review, include "Encyclopedia Prehistorica," "Jitterbug Jam" and "Traction Man Is Here!"

title: College Leaders' Earnings Top $1 Million
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 - Donald E. Ross turned Lynn University, once a nearly bankrupt two-year Catholic school for women in Boca Raton, Fla., into a thriving four-year liberal arts college. Now, as Mr. Ross nears retirement after 34 years as president, it is apparent how much the board of trustees appreciates his work.

title: Ernest Crichlow, 91, Lyrical Painter, Dies
description: Ernest Crichlow, an influential Harlem Renaissance painter whose depictions of African-Americans reflected social injustices and shifting social realities through much of the 20th century, died on Thursday at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 91 and lived in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

title: Retired Doctors, Retired Nurses, Very Busy Clinics
description: GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass. - AFTER working for years as a pediatric nurse practitioner here, Lynne Shiels was hardly nave about the costs of health care but nonetheless thought that everyone in this picturesque area had access to medical help.

title: Catherine M. Pessino, Naturalist and Educator, Dies at 80
description: Catherine M. Pessino, a naturalist and educator who spent more than three decades introducing young people to wildlife in the most inhospitable of places -- the sidewalks, sewers and catchment basins of New York City -- died on Nov. 5 in Mount Vernon, N.Y. She was 80.

title: When 14 Hours of Help Equals Some Heavy Lifting
description: LEA CUTTER, a 33-year-old single mother, part-time artist and full-time student in Portland, Me., lives frugally, subsisting mainly on student loans and child support. She had been staying with friends while waiting to get her own two-bedroom apartment, and found a way to finance the move without spending a dime.

title: From One Disaster Response, Lessons for Another
description: MOVED by some awkward syncopation of grief, shock and patriotic fury after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, Americans -- individuals and corporations -- opened wallets, clicked on Internet donation sites, met with advisory boards and cut checks.

Like millions of Americans, Ms. Hunt, the president of an African-American philanthropy called the 21st Century Foundation, was stunned by the pictures of the damage caused by Hurricane Katrina, the wretched conditions its victims confronted, the aid that never seemed to arrive.

title: Parents Carry Burden of Proof in School Cases, Court Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 - The Supreme Court ruled today, in a case of intense interest to educators and millions of parents, that people who demand changes to their children's special-education programs have the burden of proving those programs inadequate.

title: He Made His Money on a Whim, but Now He's Got a Serious Idea
description: WHEN the Web site that he started on a whim, HOTorNOT.com, a meeting site popular with 20-year-olds, unexpectedly made James Hong a millionaire, he wanted to donate some of his newfound wealth toward good causes. But he wasn't sure how much he should give: 5 percent of his income? $5,000? $50,000?

description: To the Editor:

title: Balance on the Court: The Alito Factor (4 Letters)
