title: Paper Maker Georgia-Pacific to Be Sold to Koch
description: Georgia-Pacific, the paper giant that makes Dixie cups and Brawny paper towels, agreed to be sold yesterday for $13.2 billion to Koch Industries, a family-controlled conglomerate that will become the nation's largest privately held company.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   DIMSTON, BLANCHE
description: DIMSTON - Blanche. Her birthday is remembered by those who miss her daily, deeply, and truly.

title: Candidate Cites Bad News for Bush as Key to Loss
description: The race for New Jersey governor between the multimillionaires was supposed to be a tight one, or so the final polls said before Tuesday's election. But Douglas R. Forrester, a Republican, lost by a wide margin to Senator Jon S. Corzine, a Democrat, and the chief reason, Mr. Forrester now says, is President Bush's unpopularity.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the political economist and management consultant Peter F. Drucker on Saturday included erroneous names or hometowns listed by Claremont Graduate University for his surviving children. The children are Kathleen Spivack of Watertown, Mass.; Cecily Drucker of Mill Valley, Calif.; Joan Winstein of Oak Park, Ill.; and Vincent Drucker of Dallas.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about a restatement of 2001 earnings by General Motors misstated the company's net income for that year. It was $601 million. (The $1.2 billion figure represented income from continuing operations after G.M. recalculated 2001 results to reflect the sale of Hughes Electronics in 2003.)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NUSSBAUM, ALLAN IRWIN
description: NUSSBAUM -- Allan Irwin. Passed on November 12, at the age of 72, after a long battle with cancer. He is survived by his wife Vivian, his son David and Steven (Lauren), grandchildren Joshua, Samantha, Alanna and Eli. Funeral services will be held on Monday, November 14, at 12:45 pm, at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: French Unrest Subsides, but Violence Persists in Lyon
description: PARIS, Nov. 13 - The recent unrest roiling France continued to subside Sunday without having touched the capital's tourist districts, as had been feared.

title: When One Tragedy Gets More Sympathy Than Another
description: CRUNCHING the numbers on human despair is an undignified exercise. But here it is.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BUCHIN, JOHN D.
description: BUCHIN--John D. Age 50, on November 11, 2005, in Los Angeles, CA, after a long, courageous battle against lymphoma. Beloved son of Jean and the late Irving, dear brother of Peter and brotherin-law of Marilyn, cherished uncle of Benjamin. Graduate of the Horace Mann School; B.A. University of Pennsylvania; M.A. Northwestern University. He was a television reporter and journalist in NYC, and later a marketing director for corporations. A talented and creative individual who was well-loved by many people. His courage in the face of illness was an inspiration to us all. He will be missed dearly. Contributions may be made to the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society.

title: Zuckerman Juiced
description: Santa Monica, Calif. - NOT to cast aspersions but, with all the furor over performance-enhancing drugs, it's remarkable that Philip Roth's name hasn't surfaced. Just last week Rafael Palmeiro avoided perjury charges, but his career achievements have been irreparably tarnished. Not so Roth. In fact, since turning 60, an age when most renowned writers start having trouble making stuff up, Roth has written, arguably, four of his finest novels. Is he juiced or merely the beneficiary of superior genes? No one can -- or will -- say for sure.

title: Suicide car bomb in Kabul kills a NATO peacekeeper
One Well-Read Home Has Some New Pets: 1,082 Penguins
description: LOS ALAMOS, N.M., Nov. 11 - Rushing to evacuate her home as a forest fire lapped at the edges of this high-desert town in May 2000, Kathryn Gursky took with her just one book, a British edition of "The World of Pooh," by A. A. Milne, bought when she and her husband were vacationing in Dorset some 11 years earlier.

title: U.S. presses offensive on border with Syria
Earth's Future Peacemakers Just Need a Little T.M.
description: DAVID LYNCH, the filmmaker known for his distorted, labyrinthine worlds, wants America's young people to clear their minds.

title: Hu presses Spain on EU arms embargo
U.S. fears it's losing ground to Asia in science and innovation
Control the Internet? A Futile Pursuit, Some Say
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13 - Working with Pentagon funds in the 1960's and 1970's, a small group of designers created a pioneering research network called the Arpanet and a software framework that could let an unlimited number of computers exchange data.

title: Those Who Served
description: To the Editor:

title: Allure fades for Link REIT
Clintons Visit a Hotel Struck by Terrorists in Jordan
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 13 - As former President Bill Clinton and his wife, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, walked into the bombed-out ballroom of the Radisson SAS Hotel here Sunday night, the sound of broken water glasses and chandelier shards could be heard crunching beneath their feet. The walls were pockmarked with holes from the nails and ball bearings that had been packed into the bomb to make it deadlier.

title: A Software Strategy Helps the Little Guy Buy Smarter
description: IT'S not tough to see why small companies have avoided the chorus of Internet cheerleaders. The Web has been where they get dragged through so-called reverse auctions -- where big customers watch them duke it out with 10 other suppliers for the right to sell goods at the lowest possible price.

title: What We Really Want in a Cell Phone
description: Last week in the Times, I reviewed Sprint's new $2.50-a-song online direct-to-phone music store. I wanted to pass along this note from a reader:

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "The Radisson Hotel was a Jordanian wedding with Jordanians and Palestinians, where innocent people were killed. So this was nothing to do with the West."

title: New fund sees underperformers as top picks
French state of emergency may be extendedby 3 months
F.D.A.'s Rejection of Contraceptive Is Questioned
description: Correction Appended

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Accenture, New York, is expanding its marketing sciences practice through the acquisition of Media Audits, London, which helps marketers in measuring return on investment for advertising spending. Terms were not disclosed. Julian Spooner, chief executive at Media Audits, will become chief operating officer at Accenture Marketing Sciences, a new post. Jeffrey Merrihue, who is based in London and leads Accenture Marketing Sciences, also gets a new post, chief executive.

title: Failed Jordan Bomber's Brothers Were Killed in Iraq, Officials Say
description: AMMAN, Jordan Nov. 14 - A day after Jordanian officials presented an Iraqi woman who they said had taken part in the bombings of three hotels, investigators here said today that she had volunteered to become a suicide bomber because three of her brothers were killed during "operations" in Iraq.

title: Review Under Way For Discover Card
description: Review Under Way For Discover Card

title: In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Back at Work After Battle, Prepping the Next in Line
description: WASHINGTON - The night before President Bush announced that Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. was his choice for the Supreme Court, Judge Alito met at the White House with someone who knew better than most the tsunami that was about to crash down on his life: Harriet E. Miers, the White House counsel, who had withdrawn as the president's Supreme Court nominee under furious assault from conservatives only three days before.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bay Shore: Handicapped Man Found Shot To Death
description: A paraplegic man was found fatally shot yesterday, and the Suffolk County Police Department said it was investigating the death. The man, Alan F. Felicetti, 46, was found by his sister about 11:30 a.m. at his home on Brooklyn Boulevard, where he lived alone, the police said. The police are asking anyone with information to call the homicide squad at (631) 852-6392.

title: O2's new customers lift profit
Corrections
description: A picture caption on the sports highlights page of the Television section yesterday about the Coaches vs. Cancer Classic basketball championship game misidentified the player shown last year wearing No. 33 for Syracuse. He was Terrence Roberts, not Gerry McNamara.

title: Diva in a Verismo Rarity, Chewing Imaginary Scenery
description: "Zaz" is a lesser known but not a lesser Leoncavallo opera. Toscanini conducted the premiere in 1900, but the piece did not arrive in New York until 1920. The soprano Geraldine Farrar quickly commandeered the title role. The Metropolitan Opera gave it some 20 performances in the next three seasons; and when Farrar said goodbye to the part in 1922, "Zaz" left New York with her.

title: Good cheer for Wal-Mart
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Bloomberg Visits Religious Supporters
description: Reaching out to religious leaders who endorsed his re-election, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg returned yesterday to several black churches whose pastors were among his most important supporters. At the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, the Rev. Calvin O. Butts III, right, extended a warm welcome to Mr. Bloomberg, but also remarked that his decision to support the mayor's re-election did not sit well with all of his congregants. Mr. Butts initially backed a parishioner, C. Virginia Fields, the Manhattan borough president, but came out for Mr. Bloomberg after Ms. Fields lost the Democratic primary. "I caught some flak for that," he said. "But in my heart I believe that he is the best man for the job." Mr. Bloomberg told Mr. Butts he was sorry "for putting you in a difficult position," adding, "When I needed you most, you were always there." Mr. Bloomberg said his visit was part of a broader expression of gratitude for support he received from religious leaders and their congregations. "I'm also this weekend visiting a Muslim mosque, a Jewish temple and a number of Christian churches of various denominations to offer my thanks to all of you for your support that you have given me," the mayor said.

title: Stonewalling the Katrina Victims
description: Public outrage is clearly growing over the federal government's woefully inadequate program for housing the hundreds of thousands of people displaced by Hurricane Katrina. Last week a group of survivors filed the first of what are likely to be several lawsuits alleging that the Federal Emergency Management Agency has failed to live up to its responsibilities. The recovery effort has been subject to blistering criticism from conservative, nonpartisan and liberal groups alike.

title: Balance on the Court: The Alito Factor
description: To the Editor:

title: Amman attack: Is America to blame?
Shall We Fado? On a Cloud of Fatalism, Shall We Fly?
description: Attempting to translate a nation through dance is a strange thing. Companhia Portuguesa de Bailado Contemporneo came to the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College on Friday as part of the World of Dance series and promised, in program notes, to deliver the "innate Portuguese sentiment" expressed in the country's emotive folksongs, called fado.

title: Busy Times for Groups Offering Tangible Support to the Troops
description: WITH Motown tunes blasting in the background, about 900 volunteers for Operation Gratitude spent Veterans Day and this past weekend getting blisters on their hands and sore backs on an assembly line in the California Army National Guard Armory in Van Nuys, Calif. They were there packing 15,000 boxes for soldiers in Iraq with items like energy bars, coffee, DVD's, CD's, phone cards and T-shirts for shipment this morning.

title: Briefs: Rice remains in region in push for Gaza accord
State G.O.P. Divided by Ideology and Rivalry, Officials Say
description: While the Republicans celebrate their victory in the New York City mayoral race, the state Republican Party is beset by ideological divisions, personal rivalries and individual agendas that are undermining any semblance of party unity as the 2006 elections approach, many party officials say.

title: People
description: Gary Goldsmith was named chief creative officer for the New York office of Young & Rubicam, succeeding Matt Eastwood, who left in September. Mr. Goldsmith, who will also work on regional and worldwide creative projects, had most recently been chairman and chief creative officer at the Lowe USA unit of Lowe Worldwide, New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Young & Rubicam is part of the Young & Rubicam Brands unit of the WPP Group.

title: Battered Patriots Rebound With a Comeback Victory
description: MIAMI, Nov. 13 - PATRIOTS 23, DOLPHINS 16

title: Graham Payn, 87, Debonair Actor, Dies
description: Graham Payn, a handsome, debonair actor and singer who for 30 years was the companion of the playwright Nol Coward, died on Nov. 4 at the home the two had shared, Les Avants, in the Swiss Alps above Montreux. He was 87.

title: Evolution in Kansas, and America
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FUSS, RUTH KEMPNER
description: FUSS--Ruth Kempner. On November 12, 2005, at age 98. Beloved wife of the late Albert, devoted mother of Carolyn, adoring grandmother of Alicia. Ruth was a loving sister, sister-in-law, aunt, friend and a dedicated teacher. A woman of valor, she will be deeply missed. Services Tuesday, November 15, at 1 pm, at I. J. Morris, 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead, NY; 516-486-2500.

title: TechBrief: Canada deal seeks peace on Net rule
Sun Microsystems Will Offer New Generation of Processors
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13 - Sun Microsystems is set to announce the first of a new generation of processors for computer servers on Monday that the company says offers faster performance with far less energy use.

title: U.S. Official Defends Pace of Iraqi Reconstruction
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 13 - The American official in charge of reconstruction in Iraq went on the offensive Sunday in response to skeptical questions from Iraqi journalists, saying that American-financed projects here are moving forward but that officials have not publicized them to avoid putting Iraqi workers at risk.

title: Europe's jungle of drug regulators
Daniel Gribbon, Commercial Lawyer, Is Dead at 88
description: Daniel McNamara Gribbon, former managing partner of the prominent Washington law firm Covington & Burling, died on Nov. 3 at his home in Washington. He was 88.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Koch Industries Agrees to Buy Georgia-Pacific for $13.2 Billion Georgia-Pacific, the paper giant that makes everything from Brawny paper towels to Dixie disposable plates and cups, agreed to be sold for $13.2 billion to Koch Industries, a family-controlled conglomerate that will become the nation's largest privately held company. [Page C1.]

title: Currencies: Yen slips as Koizumi tries to delay rate rise
CBS's Fill-in Anchor Has Extended His Stay
description: When Bob Schieffer took up residence last March in the broadcast studio long occupied by Dan Rather, he assumed he would serve as interim anchor of the "CBS Evening News" for about two months.

title: Mercifully, the Knicks and Brown Win One
description: SACRAMENTO, Nov. 13 - The Knicks were teetering on the edge of their first victory of the season, but still perilously close to their sixth straight loss, when their coach's passion spilled over a bit. Another call had gone against them, and Coach Larry Brown, sensing the worst could happen again, bellowed at the referee Luis Grillo.

title: Germany: The coalition may do some good
Beacon Wins Title, Ending Martin Luther King's Run
description: Martin Luther King Jr. High's reign as the top soccer team in the city ended yesterday when a freshman for Beacon High scored in overtime to give the Blue Demons a 1-0 victory in the Public School Athletic League boys A championship at Campus Magnet High School in Queens.

title: Mr. Grassley Goes Begging
description: In advance of the Senate hearing last Wednesday on oil companies' windfall profits, Senator Charles Grassley, Republican of Iowa and chairman of the Finance Committee, passed the hat to the world's major oil companies, asking for charitable donations to help poor people pay their heating bills this winter. "You have a responsibility to help less fortunate Americans cope with the high cost of heating fuels," Mr. Grassley wrote in a letter to oil and gas industry lobbying groups. He called on their member companies to contribute a "mere 10 percent" of their third-quarter profits.

title: French Cabinet to Ask for Extension to Emergency Powers
description: PARIS, Nov. 14 - In his first formal address to the nation since riots erupted in France almost three weeks ago, President Jacques Chirac said tonight that restoring security remained his first priority, but he also spelled out proposals to combat unemployment and discrimination among the country's disaffected minorities.

title: She Helps Disabled Children Get Into the Game
description: NAME -- Youth Challenge. FOUNDED -- In 1976 by Mary Sue Tanis in Fairview Park, Ohio (outside Cleveland). MISSION -- To promote interaction between children with physical disabilities and teenage volunteers through one-on-one sports and other recreational activities. CONSTITUENCY -- About 100 disabled children ages 4 to 18; about 400 teenage volunteers. FINANCING -- The $450,000 annual budget comes from private donations, grants, foundations and fund-raisers. THE STORY -- As a student at the University of Colorado in the 70's, Ms. Tanis worked with disabled Vietnam veterans through sports rehab. She felt a kinship with the men because her brother had served in Vietnam. After graduation, she came home on a mission. "My brother came back in one piece," she said. " So I thought, I'm going to work with disabled children in Ohio."

title: Bridge; Who's Hiding That Queen? The Answer's in the Discards
description: When words are used unnecessarily, it is called redundancy. Examples are "famous celebrities" and "two twins." There were twins playing in partnership on England's Bermuda Bowl team at the recent world bridge championships in Portugal: Jason and Justin Hackett. They adopt an aggressive, fearless style at the table. They also know no fear when it comes to backing their own judgment. The diagramed deal from England's match against Japan featured a great piece of card reading by Justin. He was being watched by a few thousand people online and a couple of hundred in the auditorium at the playing site.

title: Evolution in Kansas, and America (8 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Ancient Ritual Springs Seamlessly Into Profane Life
description: There is nothing quite like the blend of raucousness and delicacy to be found in traditional Korean dance and music. On Friday night at Symphony Space, a program presented by the Seoul Performing Arts Company under the aegis of the World Music Institute and the Korea Society perfectly captured that odd mix of the sacred and near-profane.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 10 P.M. (Food) SECRET LIFE OF... THANKSGIVING -- The holiday isn't necessarily the same all over the country. So Jim O'Connor, the host, focuses on regional Thanksgiving dishes. That means deep-fried turkey with Paul Prudhomme (above) in New Orleans (filmed about a month before Hurricane Katrina), sweet potato casserole in Atlanta, apple pie in Upstate New York and a re-creation of the original Thanksgiving feast in Plymouth, Mass. But the best part may be, as it often is in real life, the post-Thanksgiving turkey sandwich in Philadelphia.

title: How Marseille escaped France's urban unrest
The Neediest Cases; Keeping Son in Mind in Quest for 2nd Job
description: Daniel Gousse, a 29-year-old Brooklyn resident, says he has two important desires in his life: to help support his 3-year-old son, David, who lives in Haiti, and to go to school to learn to repair electronics.

title: On the frontier of China's real estate market
Dear Diary
description: DEAR Diary:

title: At Tsunami's Epicenter, a Town Is Reborn but Housing Is Scarce
description: Banda Aceh, Indonesia - THE center of town here is lively these days. Businesses are open and crowded. Markets are fully stocked and residents block the streets sifting through fruits, vegetables and meat. Hundreds of cars and motorbikes sit in traffic.

description: The Kansas Board of Education adopted new science standards last week that include required criticism of evolution. Some of the additions are below, paired with the mainstream understanding of evolutionary biology. (Words bolded for emphasis)

title: Knight Ridder hires an adviser as it considers calls for its sale
Paid Notice: Deaths   BRANDT, IDA (NEE JACOBSON)
description: BRANDT--Ida (nee Jacobson). Died Friday, November 11, 2005, in Hampshire Care in Leeds, MA. She was 90. A longtime resident of Riverdale, NY, she along with her husband, Stanley M. Brandt, an insurance executive, who predeceased her in 1995, later lived in Somers, NY. Burial Monday, November 14, at 1:30 pm, at Westchester Hills Cemetery in Hastings-onHudson, NY.

title: After the Storm, One Town Finds 1,000 Ways to Give
description: ST. FRANCISVILLE, La. - THAT Saturday, Aug. 27, Rose Parsee, or Mother Rose to her church and her three younger generations, got a call from a daughter, Kathlyn Locke. Ms. Locke, Ms. Parsee and most of the clan lived in two houses and an apartment in Harvey, just south of New Orleans on the city's west bank. A hardy brick of a woman, intense and passionate, Ms. Parsee had never been out of the area in her 65 years.

title: Sydney nuclear reactor may have been terrorist target
China to redeem Hu Yaobang
The Battle for the Exurbs
description: Washington - FOR some time now, conservatives have tended to see America's exurbs -- those fast-growing counties at the fringes of metropolitan areas populated by legions of young families -- as a source of Republican strength that will, over time, turn the Democrats into a permanent minority party. George W. Bush's strong showing in the exurbs in 2004 seemed to validate the thesis. When it comes to understanding exurban voters, Republicans just seemed to "get it."

title: French police see violence waning
Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHULTE, DAVID A. JR.
description: SCHULTE--David A. Jr. On Sunday, November 13th, 2005, at age 88. Beloved husband of Sandra Schulte, loving father of Holly Schulte Ellison, Christina Fleur and William Thatcher Dowell, and adored grandfather. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday, November 15th, 1:30 pm. Interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEEHAN, MIRIAM FITZSIMMONS
description: MEEHAN--Miriam Fitzsimmons. Died peacefully, surrounded by her family, November 14th. Born in Brooklyn September 23, 1912, she graduated from Convent of the Sacred Heart, NY. She was a New Yorker and had homes in New York City and East Hampton. Muzzy was loved by her children, their families, her many relatives and friends. Devoted wife of the late William M. Meehan, sister of Helen F. Cahill, Eileen F. Murray and the late Charles Fitzsimmons. Loving mother of Joanne Berghold, Maureen O'Leary, Bill Meehan and Terence S. Meehan; mother-in-law of Billy Berghold, Jack O'Leary, Laura Roebuck and Emily Souvaine Meehan. Beloved grandmother of Mark and David Berghold, Kara Berghold Passaro, Tad Sennott and their spouses Betta, Amy, Rob and Jennifer Kellogg and of Luke and Matthew Meehan. Delighted great-grandmother of Michael and Nicholas Berghold, Connor Devine and Brenna Berghold, Bruno Passaro, Ronan and Huxley Sennott. Her activities and interests included: her 45 year service as a member of the Board of Directors of Catholic Big Sisters, Big Brothers; The Convent of the Sacred Heart; Patrons of the Vatican Museum; Voice of the Faithful and Bread for the World Institute. The family will greet friends at the Colony Club, 564 Park Avenue, on Monday, November 14th, from 4 to 8 pm. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue at 84th Street, on Tuesday, at 11 am. A reception will follow in Wallace Hall of St. Ignatius Loyola. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to the Convent of the Sacred Heart Financial Aid Program, 1 East 91st Street, New York, NY 10128.

title: In Vermont, Eating Well Is the Best Revenge
description: NAME -- Food Works' Two Rivers Center for Sustainability. FOUNDED -- In 1987 by Martin Kemple and Joseph Kiefer in Montpelier, Vt. MISSION -- To encourage sustainable agriculture and consumption of local produce. CONSTITUENCY -- Working families and schoolchildren. FINANCING -- The $400,000 annual budget comes from foundations and income generated from classes, books and educational videos on sustainable farming. THE STORY -- When Food Works was started by Mr. Kemple and Mr. Kiefer in 1987, it intended to fight childhood hunger in Vermont. But its focus soon shifted to teaching schools and communities how to grow nutritious food and feed themselves.

title: Germans agree on coalition
Hollywood Unions Object to Product Placement on TV
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 13 - A group of show business unions are denouncing the creeping practice of "stealth advertising," the integration of commercial products into the story lines of television shows, which they say deceives audiences and forces writers and actors to do jobs they were not hired for.

title: Is microlending all it's cracked up to be?
From Grown-Ups, a 'Little Prince' for Children
description: It is interesting that Antoine de Saint-Exupry's classic novella "The Little Prince" is widely viewed as a children's book. It is also, evidently, viewed as the perfect subject for a work of musical theater.

title: Starting a Newspaper War (of Sorts) in a University Town
description: Journalism students at Ohio State University expected to get a real-world lesson in competition this school year, courtesy of two media entrepreneurs who see national business potential in taking on student-run campus newspapers. But with the rollout of the new paper called U Weekly, they are getting a lesson in campus politics as well.

title: Numico to buy Asian food maker
Ethiopia's Capital, Once Promising, Finds Itself in Crisis
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia - This city fancies itself the capital of Africa, the crossroads of the continent, a refined refuge where African leaders gather to address the crises in unruly places like Sudan, Ivory Coast and Congo.

title: 'Butterfly' on wings of a filmmaker
Groups Propose Alternative to E.P.A. Rules on Mercury
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 - Concerned that new federal standards on mercury emissions will not produce more immediate health benefits, two national groups of state and local air quality regulators have developed a plan to yield fewer emissions in less time.

title: Internet Service to Put Classic TV on Home Computer
description: Looking for "The Fugitive?" Didn't get enough "Eight Is Enough?" Would you like to "Welcome Back, Kotter" one more time?

title: Officials Laud New Ethics Code in Yonkers
description: YONKERS, Nov. 10 - The question before voters on Tuesday was simple: Should this city, the state's fourth largest, approve a stronger code of ethics for city government employees, one that would set clear standards and enforce them?

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Nov. 1 about a finding that ginseng extract had a small but significant effect in reducing the number and severity of colds misstated the name of the journal in which it appeared. It is The Canadian Medical Association Journal, not The Canadian Journal of Medicine.

title: 2 Marines Die in Assault on Small Iraqi Town
description: CAMP AL QAIM, Iraq, Nov. 14 - Two Marines were reported killed and at least nine were wounded today in fierce street fighting as they and a contingent of Iraqi troops stormed Ubaydi, a town near the Syrian border that American commanders said had become a haven for foreign fighters.

title: U.S. mixes demands with pleas to China
The Ghost in the CD
description: The latest album from Johnny and Donnie Van Zant, "Get Right With the Man," delivers "anthems with the sort of conviction that will inevitably inspire raised fists and chorus sing-a-longs," says Amazon.com's official music reviewer.

title: Wal-Mart's Profit Growth Is Lowest in More Than 4 Years
description: Wal-Mart Stores said today that its third-quarter profit rose 3.8 percent and predicted that an aggressive marketing campaign would result in a "good holiday season" despite higher gasoline and home heating costs.

title: Court Pick Described View on Abortion in '85 Document
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 - As a young lawyer seeking to move up in the Reagan administration in 1985, Samuel A. Alito Jr. declared that the Constitution does not protect a right to abortion.

title: A Basketball Team That's in a League of Its Own
description: THERE are no grizzly bears in Memphis, but there are Grizzlies, a National Basketball Association team that moved from Vancouver four years ago in search of a hoops-crazy city. Besides a more devoted fan base, the city of ribs and Elvis appealed to the team's owners because it offered prime opportunities to indulge one of their off-court passions -- major charitable contributions.

title: Habeas Corpus
Paid Notice: Deaths   FINEMAN, GERTRUDE
description: FINEMAN--Gertrude. Age 97, on November 12, 2005. Devoted wife of the late Lester, beloved mother of Ellen Rosand (David) and the late William, proud grandmother of Jonathan Rosand (Judy Polacheck) and Eric Rosand (Sarah), Deborah Bleisnick, and Jessica Howie (Mark), and loving great-grandmother of Benjamin and Oliver Rosand.

title: The Can't-Miss Dinner for the Black Elite
description: THE throngs that descended upon the Studio Museum in Harlem Gala, held one cold and dreary evening late last month, were not going to let a little thing like a downpour get in the way of their good time. "Nothing could keep me away from this," said one woman, who held an umbrella in one hand and her gown's train in the other. "I've been waiting for this party all year."

title: To Ask and How to Ask: Those Are the Questions
description: IN its 25 years of existence, the Pregones Theater, a Latino performance group in the South Bronx, had never asked its audience for donations. Instead, its survived on profits from ticket sales and grants from foundations and corporations.

title: Tug of warover Net takes center stage
In Ord, Neb., the Latest Success Is 20 New Residents
description: ORD, a town in Nebraska that is smack in the middle of the country, set on the edge of the state's vast sand hills, has been losing residents since its heyday in the 1930's, including 10 percent during the 90's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRUEL, PAUL J., D.D.S.
description: BRUEL--Paul J., D.D.S. Of Eastchester, on November 12, 2005. Beloved husband of the late Una Bruel, loving father of Margaret Bruel, Madeline Bruel, Mary Curto and the late Robert, grandfather of three. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 pm, Monday. Mass of Christian Burial Annunciation Church, Crestwood, on Tuesday, November 15, at 9:30 am. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Rd, Bronx, NY 10461.

title: A Community Mourns a Favorite Son Who Defied the Odds and Convention
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 12 - Almost from the day they were abandoned as newborns in a hospital nursery here, everyone in Palm Beach County knew John and Greg Rice.

title: Raymond Hains, 78, French Artist, Dies
description: Raymond Hains, one of the last surviving members of the influential French Nouveaux Ralistes group of artists, died on Oct. 28 at his home in Paris. He was 78.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HEYMAN, CLAUDIA SUSAN
description: HEYMAN -- Claudia Susan. Dearest Claudia, It has been one year that you passed away from such a short illness. We miss your wonderful smile, kind heart, beautiful blue eyes and great mind. A day does not go by that we do not think of you. We miss you so much and love you with all of our hearts. Mom, Dad and Alexandra

title: Acts of Kindness Give a Warm Feeling That Lasts All Winter
description: SANFORD, Me. - VICKY PHOTINOS spent much of the summer in this southeastern Maine town fretting about how cold it would be this winter in her trailer, with its drafty windows and poor insulation.

title: EBay Expected to End Fees for Third-Party Developers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13 - EBay is expected to announce Monday that it is ending the fees it charges software developers who build Web sites and software programs that channel buyers and sellers its way.

title: The Poor Endure With the City
description: One of the earliest records of the generosity of New Yorkers was in 1691 when the Common Council allocated four shillings a week to "two objects of charity" listed as "Topknot Betty" and "Stillwell's wife with the children." Since then, both the poor and the openhearted attitude of New Yorkers continue to be a part of this city.

title: Did the New Deal Kill Old Giving?
description: LONG after the water has receded in New Orleans, students of philanthropy will be pondering a question posed by the surge in contributions that followed Hurricane Katrina: were Americans digging deeper into their pockets because they concluded the government wasn't up to the job?

title: Michael Mendelson, 63, Asset Manager, Dies
description: Michael Mendelson, former president of the investment firm Oppenheimer & Company, died on Nov. 4 at his home in Manhattan. He was 63.

title: Turning Up the Heat on a Landmarks Agency
description: Someone has stolen one of my buildings! That was the panicked reaction of Beverly Moss Spatt, then the chairwoman of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, after the cast-iron facades of a building by James Bogardus were spirited away from a downtown lot in 1974. The 1849 facades, supposedly protected by official landmark status, had been disassembled and stored for eventual relocation at another site. But thieves broke into the lot and sold most of them off as scrap metal.

title: Trenton Man Killed by Police Was Wanted on Parole Violation
description: A man killed in a Trenton gun battle on Saturday night that also left a police officer wounded was a recently released convict wanted on a parole violation, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Israeli troops kill senior Hamas militant
India Arrests Suspected Ringleader in New Delhi Bombings
description: NEW DELHI, Nov. 13 - A suspected ringleader in the synchronized bomb blasts that struck the Indian capital late last month has been arrested, the police said Sunday, asserting that the suspect has links to a Pakistan-based militant group, Lashkar-e-Taiba.

title: Britain Considers a Timetable for Exiting Iraq
description: LONDON, Nov. 14 - British officials have begun to talk, however gingerly, about withdrawing their troops from Iraq.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TRIPPE, JOHN TERRY
description: TRIPPE--John Terry. Died peacefully on October 29 in Mechanicsville, PA after a long illness. He was 67. Husband of Jane Reis and proud father of Juan T. Trippe II. Beloved son of the late Betty and Juan Trippe. His sister Betsy T. DeVecchi and brothers Charles W. Trippe and Edward S. Trippe survive as well as 11 nieces and nephews. Private funeral services will be held at Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY on November 17. Contributions in John's memory may be sent to the National Alliance for Research on Schizophrenia and Depression, 60 Cutter Mill Road, Great Neck, NY 11021.

title: Honoring Pop and His Palace of Latin Soul in the Bronx
description: One December night in 1948, a boy in the Bronx fell in love with a song. He was 14 and new to New York, and as he walked by a music store on Prospect Avenue, the strains of a Los Romanceros holiday tune, "Aires de Navidad," drew him inside. It reminded him of home, in Bayamn, Puerto Rico. So he took the 78 r.p.m. record for a test spin in a listening booth in the corner.

title: AUTOS ON MONDAY/Design; Imagining the Taxi's Future, With a Nod to Checkers Past
description: ONE day, flagging down a taxicab may take nothing more than pushing a button on your cellphone. That enticing solution to an everyday challenge of city life is among the many proposals offered in "Designing the Taxi: Rethinking New York City's Movable Public Space," an exhibit that opened on Nov. 3 at the Manhattan gallery of Parsons the New School for Design.

Now, a boutique agency is hoping to rectify that by actually going into business with a client.

title: Their Mission: Spreading the Word Through Business
description: TOM SUDYK is not most people's idea of a missionary.

title: Youth Says Father Admitted to '88 Long Island Murders
description: It was supposed to be a special time, a teenager's long-awaited reunion with his estranged father. But their visit last year took a chilling turn, the youth said, when his father admitted that he played a central role in a notorious double murder on Long Island 17 years ago.

title: At Storm Victim's Funeral, a Celebration of a Life and a City
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 12 - Almost 11 weeks after she drowned in her attic during Hurricane Katrina, Helen J. White, 54, lay inside a polished coffin beneath a resplendent carpet of flowers, no longer an "unidentified black female" languishing in a morgue.

title: Looking for the Burmese Junta? Sorry, It's Gone Into Hiding
description: BANGKOK, Nov. 13 - At precisely 6:37 a.m. last Sunday, according to one account -- with a shout of "Let's go!" -- a convoy of trucks began a huge, expensive and baffling transfer of the government of Myanmar from the capital to a secret mountain compound 200 miles to the north.

title: Learn Chords, Form Band, Inspire Cult Following
description: On Saturday, an absurd and irresistible British punk band named Art Brut finished its four-night tour of Greater New York. The band's leader, Eddie Argos, had already ranted to paying crowds at Maxwell's (in Hoboken, N.J.), the Mercury Lounge (in the Lower East Side) and Northsix (in Williamsburg, Brooklyn). Now it was time for a free gig in the basement of the TriBeCa Grand Hotel. True to form -- and to their credit -- Mr. Argos and his bandmates made it feel less like a hotel and more like a basement.

title: U.S. Officials Ask China for Trade Help on 2 Fronts
description: BEIJING, Nov. 14 - Senior American officials called on China today to open its markets further but also asked for Chinese help in breaking an impasse in global trade talks, a combination of tough demands and pleas for Chinese assistance that increasingly characterizes the broader Sino-American relationship.

title: Broncos Pull Away From Rivals With an Easy Victory in Oakland
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 13 - The Oakland Raiders, mindful of every opportunity to expand their audience, broadcast Sunday's game against the Denver Broncos in Navajo.

title: Mixing Business With Philanthropy in the Classroom
description: ONE Tuesday night in September, Steven B. Klinsky, a prominent Wall Street financier, organized a casual Texas Hold 'Em poker tournament at the New York Racquet Club. The invitations drew mostly friends and friends of friends, but they included those already captured in the distinctive stippled portraits of The Wall Street Journal: chief investment officers, managing directors and founders of financial companies large and small. The minimum buy-in was $5,000, all of which would go to Brooklyn after-school centers named after Mr. Klinsky's brother, Gary, who had died of Niemann-Pick disease at age 29.

title: Esquire Gets a Temporary Bachelor Pad
description: Many magazines have branding ventures, among them Time's Person of the Year, the Vanity Fair party at the Oscars and Glamour's Women of the Year. Now Esquire is trying to brand real estate.

title: Spain Looks Into C.I.A.'s Handling of Detainees
description: LONDON, Nov. 11 - On the Spanish island of Majorca, the police quietly opened a criminal investigation in March after a local newspaper reported a series of visits to the island's international airport by planes known to regularly operate for the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Evolution in Kansas, and America
description: To the Editor:

title: Oprah Effect Lifts New Books, and Old
description: There's a belief in publishing circles that if Oprah Winfrey selected a lawn-mower manual for her book club, she could sell a million copies. But it seems that her marketing magic works for authors who base their stories on their real lives even when those lives were not what they first thought.

title: Evolution in Kansas, and America
description: To the Editor:

title: LOOKING AHEAD
description: SIGN UP NOW! -- Enrollment for the new Medicare prescription-drug benefit starts tomorrow. Coverage begins Jan. 1. The deadline for signing up is May 15; those who miss it must pay a penalty, though not if they already have coverage of their own and decide to switch over at some point. Private companies are selling the plans. Premiums average about $32 a month, but range from $2 to $50 and up, depending on how comprehensive the coverage is. Details can be found on www.medicare.gov.

title: APEC's relevance is under scrutiny
Blair cautious on Iraq pullout
Behind Each Donation, a Tangle of Reasons
description: IF you wanted to test the charitable limits of humanity, you probably could not devise a greater challenge than the disasters of the last four years. Americans have responded with billions of dollars in donations and untold hours of volunteer work.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: More Find Online Encyclopedia Is Handy
description: By several measures, the user-written online encyclopedia Wikipedia (www.wikipedia.com) has exploded in popularity over the last year. The Internet traffic-measurement firm Nielsen//NetRatings found that Wikipedia had more than tripled its monthly readership in September from the same month in 2004. September may have been a month of especially heavy usage for Wikipedia: the site does better during major news events, and September saw both the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina and the confirmation of John G. Roberts Jr. as chief justice of the United States Supreme Court.

title: Earth's Future Peacemakers Just Need a Little T.M.
description: DAVID LYNCH, the filmmaker known for his distorted, labyrinthine worlds, wants America's young people to clear their minds.

title: Turning a Collection Into a Foundation, Without a Big Tax Bill
description: ONE truism of a strong art market is that it lures material to auction that may not normally be offered for sale. Even the most reluctant collector may be persuaded to part with a beloved artwork by the promise of a previously undreamed-of profit.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BLINKEN, ROBERT
description: BLINKEN--Robert. A gathering to celebrate the life of Robert Blinken will be held on Thursday, November 17, at 9:45 AM at The Harvard Club, 27 West 44th Street, NYC.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Chicken Little' Still No. 1 at Box Office
description: Despite competition from Jennifer Aniston and 50 Cent, "Chicken Little" (Buena Vista), right, easily retained the No. 1 spot at the box office this weekend. The first fully computer-animated movie produced by Walt Disney, it grossed $32 million, a second-weekend slip of just 20 percent; its cumulative take so far is $80.7 million, according to studio estimates. "This is what we would consider a very minimal drop," said Paul Dergarabedian, president of Exhibitor Relations, a box-office tracking company in Los Angeles. "It says that word of mouth is great, and that obviously families are enjoying the movie. Disney's foray into their own homegrown computer-animated film is obviously highly successful. There's no question now that they can do this." Three new films in wide release trailed far behind. "Zathura" (Sony), a space adventure directed by Jon Favreau, opened at No. 2 with $14 million. "Derailed" (Weinstein Company), starring Ms. Aniston and Clive Owen, was third with $12.8 million. And "Get Rich or Die Tryin' " (Paramount), the semifictional 50 Cent biopic directed by Jim Sheridan, took in $12.5 million over the weekend; in the five days since it opened on Wednesday, it has grossed $18.2 million. The Desert Storm war drama "Jarhead" (Universal) rounded out the Top 5 with $12.3 million in its second week of release. But the most successful film of the weekend, by one measure, was "Pride & Prejudice" (Focus Features), the new adaptation of the Jane Austen novel starring Keira Knightley and Donald Sutherland. It made $2.8 million in a limited release at 215 theaters, but its per-screen average of $13,000 was the highest of this week's Top 12 movies. CATHERINE BILLEY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TUFT, LEONARD W.
description: TUFT--Leonard W., 83, retired Executive Vice President of RCA, died Friday, November 11, of heart failure. Beloved husband of Irene Yuss and father of Sarah and David. At RCA, he negotiated commerical satellite agreements, retiring after 37 years to practice law. Born in Philadelphia, PA, he graduated first in his class from Temple University and received his juris doctorate from Harvard Law School. As a navigator in WWII he earned two Purple Hearts and the Distinguished Flying Cross. He was an ardent Democrat and a delegate to the 1960 Democratic National Convention. Funeral services will be held at 1 pm, Monday, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, NYC.

title: Hit-Run Kills One Pedestrian; Separate Crash Hurts Another
description: Two pedestrians were struck, one fatally, in separate accidents in Brooklyn and on Staten Island yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Heavy Hand of the Secret Police Impeding Reform in Arab World
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 13 - At a cultural festival last year, Sameer al-Qudah recited a poem of his depicting Arab rulers as a notch below pirates and highwaymen on the scale of honorable professions. Within days, Jordan's intelligence police summoned him.

title: The President's Trip to Asia
description: Fresh from his disastrous Latin American tour last week, President Bush is off again -- this time to Japan, South Korea, China and even Mongolia, presumably to thank the latter for the 131 soldiers it is contributing to America's Iraq efforts. "My visit should send a signal to the people of Mongolia that you've got a friend in the United States and a friend in George W. Bush," the president recently told an American Christian and Mongolian TV station.

title: Startling End to Unlikely Friendship
description: When they met the first time in a grimy gym off Times Square, the boxer and the wordsmith were the most unlikely of friends. They were teenagers with bright futures from opposite corners of New York City.

title: Foreign Student Enrollment Drops
description: The number of foreign students enrolled in American universities declined slightly in the 2004-5 academic year, according to a survey to be released today, suggesting that a more significant drop that took place in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks in 2001 might be abating.

title: Along With 'I Do' Comes a Chance to Say 'We Care'
description: JENNIFER VAN ZANDT'S wedding in Key Largo, Fla., had all the trimmings: Friday night party, Saturday celebration, drinks, dancing and merriment. And something else: rather than taking home a commemorative box of chocolates or a trinket, the guests helped save a few manatees.

title: Big Drug Makers See Sales Decline With Their Image
description: The drug industry's image problems are beginning to hurt pharmaceutical companies where it matters most -- at the bottom line.

title: Popular Demand
description: Madonna's last album, "American Life" (2003), sold less than 1 million copies. Her most successful title from the past 10 years is "Ray of Light" in 1998. But, lately it seems that things have been looking up for the 47-year-old performer.

title: Liberal Coalition Is Making Plansto Take Fight Beyond Abortion
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 - A coalition of liberal groups is preparing a national television advertising campaign against the Supreme Court nomination of Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. that seeks to move the debate over his selection beyond abortion rights and focus instead on subjects like police searches and employment discrimination, several leaders of the coalition said.

title: From the Trash, a Treasure Chest for the Creative

Even through lean years and under various city administrations, the program, run by the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs, has survived and grown.

title: RESTLESS GIANT The United States From Watergate to Bush v. Gore

Jordan Arrests Iraqi Woman in Hotel Blasts
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 13 - Jordanian security officials on Sunday announced the arrest of an Iraqi woman they said was closely linked to the terrorist leader Abu Musab al-Zarqawi as a fourth bomber in the Amman hotel attacks. They also broadcast a taped confession showing her wearing a translucent explosive belt packed with ball bearings, in which she described how she had tried unsuccessfully to blow herself up.

I, together with you, have the opportunity to give my students their first impressions of books and reading. I want these early experiences to be filled with high quality literature in a variety of genres from ABC and counting books to compelling storybooks." (A $453 proposal from Chicago.)

That was it for the Velvets, his early band, and the viola, his signature instrument. This show was stridently about rocking, not rumination.

title: In Classic Battle of the Sexes, Women Take the Upper Hand
description: What could be more apt than the Queen's Company, an all-female acting troupe, tackling Shakespeare's "Taming of the Shrew," perhaps the most famous war-of-the-sexes comedy of all time -- a play that has over the years caused manifold arguments about whether it is sexist and misogynistic, or cleverly, quite the opposite. But don't be mistaken; just because Petruchio (and every other character) is played by a woman doesn't mean this is a feminist diatribe.

title: The Prankster as Omnivore
description: Gyorgy Ligeti's output is so vast and varied that it is impossible to characterize his style concisely. There are undoubtedly fans of certain Ligeti scores who don't know what to make of others, and given the pranksterish humor that drives many of Mr. Ligeti's works, this may please him. But if nothing else, an evening of his music is bound to include surprises, and that clearly appeals to much of the new-music audience: for the final installment of its Ligeti mini-festival, on Saturday evening, the Miller Theater was packed.

title: Corrections

title: Arts, Briefly; A Slow Beginning For Anderson Cooper
description: In Nielsen's estimates, CNN's "Anderson Cooper 360" had a pale first week in its new 10 p.m. to midnight slot. The show drew an average of 601,000 viewers from Monday to Thursday. By comparison, on the same nights from 10 p.m. to 11 p.m., Fox News's "On the Record With Greta Van Susteren" delivered an average of 1.79 million viewers, whereas the first hour of "360" attracted 745,000. In October, when Mr. Cooper, above, and Aaron Brown were co-anchors of "NewsNight," that show's average audience was 698,000. On Friday, CBS's "Close to Home," from executive producer Jerry Bruckheimer, drew 11.87 million viewers, performing much better in its new slot than it had on Tuesdays at 10 p.m. CBS won the night, as usual. ABC delivered its highest Friday ratings of the season, and placed second among adults 18 to 49. KATE AURTHUR

title: Heavy Hand of the Secret Police Impeding Reform in Arab World
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 13 - At a cultural festival last year, Sameer al-Qudah recited a poem of his depicting Arab rulers as a notch below pirates and highwaymen on the scale of honorable professions. Within days, Jordan's intelligence police summoned him.

title: The Bond Passed. Now Comes the Hard Part: Actually Building a 2nd Avenue Subway.
description: As the November election approached, the mayor and other officials urged citizens to support a transportation bond issue that would allow a Second Avenue subway to be built. Planners said the project would work wonders for congestion. New York State voters went to the polls and approved the measure.

title: Review Under Way For Discover Card
description: Discover Financial Services in Chicago, part of Morgan Stanley, is seeking an agency to create campaigns for its Discover credit card after the resignation of the incumbent of almost seven years, Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco. Discover spends about $80 million a year on advertising.

title: Doing Unto Others as They Did Unto Us
description: Washington - HOW did American interrogation tactics after 9/11 come to include abuse rising to the level of torture? Much has been said about the illegality of these tactics, but the strategic error that led to their adoption has been overlooked.

title: Rhinestones and Cowboy Hats as the Opry Turns 80
description: "Boy, Carnegie Hall can be very quiet," Alison Krauss observed between songs on Monday night. For the first time since 1961, the Grand Ole Opry, a Nashville institution founded 80 years ago, brought an all-star revue to Carnegie Hall. The occasion was the night before the Country Music Awards at Madison Square Garden. Everyone - musicians and audience - was on good behavior, not always a good thing for country. It was a night for ballads, not hoedowns.

title: Theodore Puck, 89, Leader in Growing Cells for Research, Dies
description: Theodore T. Puck, a geneticist who devised an efficient method for growing colonies of human cells that he used in developing early and important tests for cell damage from radiation, and later for studying the genetic causes of cancers, died Nov. 6 at a hospital in Denver. He was 89.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HENDLER, HAROLD
description: HENDLER--Harold. "King of the Ribbon Trade," age 92, past proprietor of Hyman Hendler & Sons, resided in Lawrence, NY, passed away on November 12, 2005. Beloved husband of Betty and the late Janet Hendler, adored father of Gail Hendler and Michael, Maida and Michael Weisman, and step father of Sharon Douglas, Aimee Rothenberg and Helaine, Michael and Gary Trock; cherished brother of Gert Wellington and Norman Hendler, predeceased by Aaron Hendler and Sadie and Hyman Hendler, and loving grandfather and great-grandfather of Steven, Ann Marie, Amanda and Emily Weisman, David, Mari, Max and Benjamin Weisman, Lindsey, Blair and Harrison Douglas, Craig and Henry Rothenberg and Harris, Jonathan and Emily Trock. Harold loved his family, living life, cruises, people watching, Ribbons, apple pie and chocolate ice cream. It was a privilege to call him "Dad." His brilliance, kindness, insightful honesty and abounding generosity enriched every life he touched. Harold was admired and respected worldwide and will be missed by all who knew him. May his memory be a blessing. Services today, at 11 am, at Temple Beth Shalom, 390 Broadway, Lawrence, NY.

How can we develop human/social/moral/etc. capital when our lives revolve around consumption, non-participatory non-social recreation, TV, video games, movies, web-surfing, and commuting long distances in single occupancy vehicles. The key to human capital is interpersonal relationships.

Some of them have been remarkably successful at a local level. But nationally, Americas educational system is about as mediocre as it was then.

title: Its Question Time!
description: I just landed in Khartoum with my multimedia partner, Naka Nathaniel, and will be heading to Darfur at the crack of dawn tomorrow, Tuesday. I should have on-and-off email access there, so send in your written questions  about Darfur only  and Ill reply to some of them by video on the Times site. The questions should go to a new email address weve just set up:kristofontheground@yahoo.com.

title: Helena Christensen | Photographer
description: Back in her supermodel era, Helena Christensen flew every other day. She expected her schedule to lighten up when she switched to photography. No such luck. Next week I go to five countries in six days, she says. While abroad, she scouts for her West Village shop, Butik, which features antiques, Danish clothing and flea-market and yard-sale finds. She has been collecting the furniture that fills her store for years, especially in her native Denmark and in France. I love the antiques market in Nice every Monday. Its so beautiful, in the old flower market. Christensens destinations have become less exotic since the birth of her son, Mingus, now 6, though the desire remains. I do want to go to Vietnam, and I promised my son Id take him to the Galpagos Islands. They have all of those animals he is so interested in.

title: Marcus Samuelsson | Chef
description: Born in Ethiopia and raised in Sweden, Marcus Samuelsson, Aquavits chef and co-owner, understands disparity. We always stuck out, he says of himself and his sister, because we looked different with our big Afros in cold Sweden. Today he travels with ease as an ambassador for Unicef and as a world-class chef, visiting places like New Zealand and Brazil every month. He staves off in-flight boredom with books, a journal and an iPod stocked with Wu-Tang Clan and Nina Simone. It doesnt matter if its a 1-hour flight or a 12-hour flight, Im good.

title: Readers Respond
description: Kelly Picard, Bernardsville, N.J.: I have really enjoyed your commentary and approach. I think your feelings and attitudes truly reflect our humanity and our mutual struggle to comprehend the BIG picture of the world around us and the little pictures of our day to day. Very much looking forward to more of your thoughts and art.

As a kid, I would collect systems timetables from as many airlines as possible, creating fantasy trips, stringing connections from one destination to another in as short a time as possible. My goal was to also create an imaginary trip around the world through exotic places like Istanbul and Calcutta.

In Suffolk County Court, the commissioner, Robert Chartuk, pleaded not guilty of official misconduct in the second degree, and was released on his own recognizance, according to a spokesman for the Suffolk district attorney, Thomas J. Spota. Prosecutors said that Mr. Chartuk, 44, sought about $700 in campaign contributions from the contractor, and gave him permission to remove 40,000 cubic yards of sand from the park site. A senior Iraqi official who visited the detainees said two appeared paralyzed and others had had the skin peeled off their bodies by their abusers.

title: Icann. Can you?
Arts, Briefly; Martha Stewart's 'Apprentice' Days Are Numbered
description: NBC executives acknowledged yesterday that the network would not produce any further editions of the Martha Stewart version of "The Apprentice," below, but said it had never intended to do so, so that did not mean the show was canceled. The show, which has five episodes left to run, has posted mainly meager ratings for NBC in two different time periods on Wednesday nights. Still, NBC is not cutting the show off in midrun as it would for a cancellation but will allow it to continue to its finale on Dec. 21. Network executives insisted yesterday that they were not changing any plan in not carrying Ms. Stewart's "Apprentice" forward. Mark Burnett, the executive producer of Ms. Stewart's "Apprentice" show and her daily show, said that he and NBC had agreed before the "The Apprentice" show started that Ms. Stewart "could not possibly do another prime-time show" because of her other television commitments and her other businesses. "The 'Apprentice' deal was made to reintroduce Martha to the television landscape," he said. Most reality shows start out with open-ended futures and receive orders for additional runs only after they post good ratings. That was the case with the original "Apprentice," starring Donald Trump, which was a breakout hit within its first few episodes and thus won quick approval from NBC for more editions. Mr. Trump's show, while its ratings have declined, remains among the top 20 shows in the weekly ratings in the category of viewers ages of 18 and 49 -- the group NBC cares most about -- and posted its best ratings of the year in the last two weeks. BILL CARTER

title: In Personal Move, Rice Pushes Mideast Talks Into a 2nd Day
description: JERUSALEM, Tuesday, Nov. 15 - Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice struggled into the early morning hours on Tuesday to conclude what the administration hoped would be a broad agreement between Israel and the Palestinians to move people and goods in and out of Gaza and to take other steps to enhance Gaza's economic viability.

title: Canadian Winery Matures Enough to Draw Suitors
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 14 - Normally at this time of year, Donald L. Triggs's thoughts would be on the grape harvest: the quality and abundance of the grapes, the fluctuations of the temperature, and the timing of the harvest. But this season, Mr. Triggs, president and chief executive of Vincor International, is focusing on something very different -- a hostile takeover bid from Constellation Brands valued at 1.4 billion Canadian dollars ($1.18 billion).

title: World Business Briefing | Australia: Telstra Announces Job Cuts
description: Telstra, Australia's biggest telephone company, will lay off up to 10,000 workers, or 19 percent of its work force, as the government prepares to sell its controlling $20 billion stake in the company. "Costs have been going in the wrong direction," Solomon Trujillo, the chief executive, told analysts and reporters in Sydney. The cuts will be over five years, the company said in a statement. Telstra also said today that it would merge its CSL mobile phone unit with a rival, New World Mobile Holdings.

title: Wholesale Inflation Slowed in October

title: Pentagon's Fuel Deal Is Lesson in Risks of Graft-Prone Regions
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 - Soon after the American invasion of Afghanistan in late 2001, the Pentagon opened an air base in neighboring Kyrgyzstan and made a deal to get jet fuel from the only two suppliers in the country. The companies just happened to be linked to relatives of the country's president.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: Opposition Leader Is Arrested
description: The police arrested the country's main opposition politician, Kizza Besigye, left, on charges of treason, prompting thousands of supporters to riot in Kampala, the capital. Mr. Besigye, who unsuccessfully challenged President Yoweri Museveni in 2001 and went into exile in South Africa immediately afterward, returned to Uganda amid much fanfare last month. A fierce critic of Mr. Museveni, whom he condemns as a dictator, Mr. Besigye is accused by prosecutors of having links to two rebels groups seeking the violent overthrow of the government. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Parties Back Coalition Deal
description: Angela Merkel's Christian Democratic Union, its Bavarian sister party, the Christian Social Union, and the Social Democrats of Gerhard Schrder, the departing chancellor, overwhelmingly approved a deal for a coalition government to be led by Mrs. Merkel, above. The votes clear the way for Parliament to elect her to a four-year term as chancellor on Nov. 22. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Improvements Set For Atlantic Avenue
description: The city plans to spend $17.6 million on traffic safety improvements along Atlantic Avenue, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday. The improvements are scheduled for a 2.2-mile section from Euclid Avenue in Brooklyn to Rockaway Boulevard in Queens. Construction is scheduled to start in 2007. The plan calls for wider medians, which will reduce the number of travel lanes from three to two outside the commuter rush. In the high-traffic area between Euclid Avenue and Logan Street, parking will be restricted during the commuter rush to provide a third lane in the high-traffic direction, officials said.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: 3 Accused Of Passing Secrets To China
description: The Federal Security Service announced that it had arrested three officials from a research institute associated with Russia's space agency and charged them with spying and passing restricted technology to China, official Russian news agencies reported. The institute's director, Igor Reshetin, and two subordinates face criminal charges apparently related to a 1996 contract to provide expertise on manned space flight, Itar-Tass reported. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Demand for Natural Gas Exceeds the Supply, Threatening Winter Shortages and High Prices Demand for natural gas is exceeding production for a variety of reasons, among them a shutdown of some production capacity after recent Gulf of Mexico hurricanes. The result could be a squeeze in the energy market this winter, particularly if the weather is cold. Homeowners and businesses that use natural gas are expected to pay sharply higher utility bills. [Page C1.]

title: National Briefing | Washington: The Price Of A Stamp Is Going Up
description: The United States Postal Service approved a 2-cent increase in the price of a first-class stamp, to 39 cents, effective Jan. 8, the first increase since 2002. The rate for sending a two-ounce first-class letter will rise to 63 cents from 60 cents, and a postcard will climb to 24 cents from 23 cents. The priority mail rate will rise to $4.05 a pound from $3.85. Express mail rates will increase to $14.40 from $13.65 for a half-pound and to $18.80 from $17.85 for two pounds.

title: A Storyteller Who Honed His Stories
description: Before writing "Angela's Ashes" (1996), his best-selling memoir about his impoverished childhood in Ireland, Frank McCourt spent three decades teaching in New York City, conducting, by his count, at least 33,000 classes and instructing some 12,000 students. He taught days and nights and summers. He taught basic English to immigrants and creative writing to the college-bound. He taught in vocational schools, where he was reprimanded for "giving kids ideas they shouldn't have," and he taught at the elite Stuyvesant High School, where he encouraged his writing students to study restaurant reviews, cookbooks and folk tales, as well as poems and novels.

title: Those Wacky Medieval Tunes, So Reverent, Yet So Bawdy

The major exhibition at the Frick now is a collection of portraits by the 15th-century painter Hans Memling, and on Sunday afternoon the Newberry Consort offered a musical counterpart in the Frick's concert room.

title: Prisoners of the Senate
description: BOSTON - AFTER the Northern victory in the Civil War, laws passed by Congress during the era of Reconstruction imposed military governments on the former Confederate states. A Mississippi editor, William H. McCardle, was arrested by the military and charged with publishing incendiary and libelous articles. He was held for trial before a military commission. But he went to a federal court and sought his release on a writ of habeas corpus, arguing that military rule of civilians was unconstitutional.

Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday, November 15th, 1:30 pm. Interment private.

title: Parents Carry Burden of Proof in School Cases, Court Rules

description: KYOTO, Wednesday, Nov. 16 - President Bush opened his tour of Asia on Wednesday with a carefully couched warning to China's leaders, telling them that they are finding "that once the door to freedom is opened even a crack, it cannot be closed."

description: The video imagery was luscious and professional, and the concept was intriguing: pale-painted performers clad in fantasy costumes moved slowly in dim light, serving as shifting screens for projected patterns in dances embedded in a program-long score performed live on the stage. But the effect was of closely watching the slow upheavals of a Lava lamp for an hour or so. Why was "Tearing of the Night Sky," presented by the Anemone Dance Theater on Saturday night at the Joyce SoHo, so disappointing?

Outpourings of Excitement Could Not Tame an Audience
description: Big orchestras can coast on their reputations. The Chicago Symphony, for example, can offer pretty much anything in New York and people will stick around to hear it. The Bruckner Orchestra Linz, by contrast, banks less on its own reputation than on its namesake's. And on Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall, even Bruckner's music failed to hold the audience in thrall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEEHAN, MIRIAM FITZSIMMONS
description: MEEHAN--Miriam Fitzsimmons. Died peacefully, surrounded by her family, November 11th. Born in Brooklyn September 23, 1912, she graduated from Convent of the Sacred Heart, NY. She was a New Yorker and had homes in New York City and East Hampton. Muzzy was loved by her children, their families, her many relatives and friends. Devoted wife of the late William M. Meehan, sister of Helen F. Cahill, Eileen F. Murray and the late Charles Fitzsimmons. Loving mother of Joanne Berghold, Maureen O'Leary, Bill Meehan and Terence S. Meehan; mother-in-law of Billy Berghold, Jack O'Leary, Laura Roebuck and Emily Souvaine Meehan. Beloved grandmother of Mark and David Berghold, Kara Berghold Passaro, Tad Sennott and their spouses Betta, Amy, Rob and Jennifer Kellogg and of Luke and Matthew Meehan. Delighted great-grandmother of Michael and Nicholas Berghold, Connor Devine and Brenna Berghold, Bruno Passaro, Ronan and Huxley Sennott. Her activities and interests included: her 45 year service as a member of the Board of Directors of Catholic Big Sisters, Big Brothers; The Convent of the Sacred Heart; Patrons of the Vatican Museum; Voice of the Faithful and Bread for the World Institute. The family will greet friends at the Colony Club, 564 Park Avenue, on Monday, November 14th, from 4 to 8 pm. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue at 84th Street, on Tuesday, at 11 am. A reception will follow in Wallace Hall of St. Ignatius Loyola. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to the Convent of the Sacred Heart Financial Aid Program, 1 East 91st Street, New York, NY 10128.

title: Boeing Takes On Airbus With New 747 Wide-Body Jets

title: Thomas H. Lee Partners Files Suit Against Former Refco Executives
description: Thomas H. Lee Partners, the private equity firm that owns more than half of Refco, the collapsed futures and commodities brokerage firm, sued former Refco executives yesterday, seeking to recover at least $245 million.

title: Strange Behavior at the F.D.A.
description: Congressional investigators have documented some highly suspect maneuvering behind the Food and Drug Administration's decision last year to reject over-the-counter sales of the controversial morning-after contraceptive known as Plan B. The investigation, by the Government Accountability Office, stopped short of asserting that political considerations had led agency officials to overrule their own experts and outside advisers. But the most plausible inference one can draw is that politics or ideology was allowed to trump science as higher-ups at the agency searched for rationales to keep access to the contraceptive restricted.

title: Mahler as a Perfect Meeting Place
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra has never quite outlived its reputation as a peacock among orchestras. Luxurious sound, emanating in particular from its string sections, was celebrated and tenderly cared for during the days of Leopold Stokowski and Eugene Ormandy, and it was in good part made possible by an orchestra struggling to be heard at its best in the dead acoustics of the old Academy of Music.

title: Corrections

(A correction on Sept. 27 about a related article on Sept. 24 also referred imprecisely to the donation.) While the total pledged was $100,000, Ms. Mai has received only a check for $10,000, as a first installment.

He has improved relations with the city's black and Latino populations. And, a decade after his first, abbreviated term as New York City police commissioner, he did it all with a shrinking number of officers.

title: U.S.-Iraqi Assault Meets Resistance Near Syrian Border

title: Berlin admits Uzbek minister despite EU ban
World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Potential Putin Successors Advance
description: President Vladimir V. Putin promoted two of his closest aides in a cabinet reshuffling that could prove significant in the search for his successor. He appointed Dmitri A. Medvedev, his chief of staff and the chairman of the gas monopoly Gazprom, to be the first deputy prime minister, a newly recreated position under Prime Minister Mikhail Y. Fradkov, whose government has widely been criticized as ineffective. Mr. Putin also appointed Sergei B. Ivanov, the defense minister, as a deputy prime minister. Mr. Ivanov will continue to serve as defense minister. Both men have been mentioned as possible candidates to succeed Mr. Putin when his second -- and, by law, last -- term ends in 2008. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Vodafone warns of declining profit and slowing growth
China to Give Memorial Rite to Hu Yaobang, Purged Reformer
description: BEIJING, Nov. 14 - Despite strong internal opposition, the Chinese Communist Party later this week will officially restore the reputation of a liberal-leaning party leader whose death helped inspire pro-democracy protests, people informed about the plans said.

title: M.T.A. Enlists Santa to Promote Fare Discounts

title: Scientists' Rift on Stem Cells Surrounded by Mystery
description: American stem cell experts are baffled by a break between an American researcher and the South Korean research team that has reported producing the first, and so far the only, stem cells derived from cloned human embryos.

title: Fighting for Seats
description: FIGHTING FOR SEATS -- It's better-plan-ahead time again for business travelers. Airlines based in the United States will carry a record 21.7 million passengers on domestic and international flights during the Thanksgiving holiday travel period (which begins Saturday and ends Nov. 29), the Air Transport Association estimates. Last year, the airline trade group said, 16.3 million passengers traveled by air during the period, the busiest of the year.

title: When Childlike Wonder Meets Eroticism
description: Ohad Naharin is 53 now, and long since established as Israel's leading choreographer. But he's been through a lot lately, and his new piece, "Mamootot," in its spare, reserved, sexual and literally touching way, reflects all that.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: M.T.A. Begins Fare Discount Ad Campaign
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority began a $2 million advertising campaign yesterday to promote holiday fare discounts, and transit officials said that the 40-day unlimited-ride holiday MetroCard would go on sale on Thursday at a price of $76, usually the price of a 30-day card. The holiday cards will be sold until Nov. 29 "while supplies last," the authority said. The ad campaign will be seen on 6,000 buses and at least two cars of every subway train, the authority said. An explanation of the discounts can also be found at www.mta.info/mta/bonuses.htm. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: His turf: Stage, film, the dance studio

title: Seeing Mountains in Starry Clouds of Creation
description: In 1995, astronomers using the Hubble Space Telescope produced "The Pillars of Creation," an image of stars emerging from biblical-looking clouds of dust that has become an icon of the space age.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about expressions of caution on the new cancer drug Herceptin misstated the location of McMaster University, where a researcher urged "skepticism" in viewing data about it. The university is in Hamilton, Ontario, not Toronto.

title: Arts, Briefly; For ABC, Sunday Love
description: The romantic losses of young surgeons are ABC's gain. As the November sweeps continue, "Grey's Anatomy" is hitting its ratings stride. On Sunday, the hospital soap opera delivered its highest ratings of the season in both total estimated viewers (20.68 million) and the 18-to-49 demographic. The episode was the second-highest-rated of the series, which made its debut in March. Those numbers, combined with those of "Desperate Housewives" (26.53 million) and "Extreme Makeover: Home Edition" (17.11 million), helped ABC easily win the night in Nielsen's estimates for the eighth Sunday in a row. CBS's lineup -- "60 Minutes" (14.23 million), "Cold Case" (17.35 million) and Part 2 of "Category 7: The End of the World" (13.85 million) -- placed second among total viewers and third among adults 18 to 49. Fox was No. 2 in that age group, helped by a football spillover into prime time. At 9 p.m., its "Family Guy" (9.2 million) drew its best ratings of the season. KATE AURTHUR

title: Vine Deloria Jr., Champion of Indian Rights, Dies at 72
description: DENVER, Nov. 14 - Vine Deloria Jr., a Standing Rock Sioux who burst into the American consciousness in 1969 with his book "Custer Died for Your Sins" and later amplified his message through 20 more books about the Native American experience, died on Sunday, a family friend said.

title: In Asia, Bush Hopes to Advance Trade, but Soft-Pedal Iraq and North Korea
description: KYOTO, Japan, Tuesday, Nov. 15 - The first time President Bush visited Asia as president, just two months after the Sept. 11 attacks, he had little time or patience for a summit meeting that traditionally focused on trade and globalization. He talked only about terrorism, and insisted that everyone else follow his lead.

title: Karachi blast kills 2 outside fast-food outlet
World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Numico Buys Nutrition Unit
description: Royal Numico, Europe's largest maker of baby food, agreed to buy the East Asiatic Company's nutrition unit for 1.2 billion euros ($1.4 billion) to catch up with Nestl in markets like China and India. Numico shares fell 5.7 percent in Amsterdam after the company said it would sell new shares to raise 550 million euros. The purchase is Numico's third baby-food acquisition, as it has shifted its focus to infant and clinical nutrition from vitamins. Numico is seeking growth in Asia, where 50 million children were born last year compared with 4.1 million in Western Europe, its chief executive, Jan Bennink, said yesterday.

title: Germany Accepts Ailing Uzbek Official Despite Travel Ban
description: BERLIN, Nov. 15 - European officials confirmed today that a government minister from Uzbekistan who has been formally banned from travel to the 25 countries of the European Union is in Germany, where he has received medical treatment.

Sweatman looked as if he had not gotten any sleep. Given how poorly the Giants played on special teams in their 24-21 loss to the Minnesota Vikings on Sunday, this was entirely possible.
