He's tried to share the blame, claiming that Congress had the same intelligence he had, as well as President Bill Clinton. He's tried to pass the buck and blame the C.I.A. Lately, he's gone on the attack, accusing Democrats in Congress of aiding the terrorists.

It could have been his last chance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEMING, MACDONALD, ESQ.
description: DEMING--MacDonald, Esq., 90, of Tampa passed away on November 13, 2005. He is preceded in death by his wife of 53 years, Judith and his sister, Barbara. He is survived by his two daughters, A. Meredith and Laura; a son, Michael and his wife Pamela; two grandchildren Jeneva and Madison; and two brothers, Quentin and Angus. He was a WWII US Naval Officer serving on the USS Nevada, as well as in the Aleutian Islands. He was a graduate of Harvard and Yale Law School. He practiced law at Sullivan and Cromwell as well as Haight, Gardner, Poor and Havens in N.Y.C. He was a longtime resident of South Mountain Road in New City, Rockland County, New York. For information Blount & Curry Funeral Home, 813968-2231, Tampa, FL.

title: That Rossini Could Swash Buckles With the Best of Them
description: At 11:25 on Sunday night, there was still one scene to go in Eve Queler's concert performance of Rossini's seldom-heard "William Tell" with her Opera Orchestra of New York at Carnegie Hall. You might have expected the audience to be restless, as the performance approached the four-hour mark. But after the Italian tenor Marcello Giordani, singing the treacherous role of the tormented Swiss patriot Arnold, gave a fearless account of the cabaletta "Amis, amis, secondez ma vengeance," his rallying cry to vanquish the Austrian occupiers of 13th-century Switzerland, soaring over the orchestra with clarion top notes and thrilling high C's, the audience threatened to stop the show with a frenzied ovation. So with a nod from Ms. Queler, Mr. Giordani sang the aria again.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: State Subpoenas 5 Oil Companies
description: Executives from five oil companies were subpoenaed to appear at a state hearing next month and provide information about refinery capacity, pricing and profits earned after Hurricanes Katrina and Rita. "The big oil companies have made an unprecedented fortune from recent high gas prices," said Gov. James E. Doyle, a Democrat, who ordered the subpoenas. Mark Boudreaux, a spokesman for ExxonMobil, one of the companies subpoenaed, said that company officials had not seen the subpoena and that Mr. Doyle was requesting information already provided in a Senate hearing last week. Erin Roth, executive director of the Wisconsin Petroleum Council, which represents the oil companies, said he thought Mr. Doyle should wait for a federal investigation to be completed before holding any hearings. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

description: After five years of budget hypocrisy, Republican leaders in Congress are floundering in their current attempt to portray themselves as fiscally responsible. Their plan to cut basic safety-net programs for the poor and use the money for a new round of ridiculous tax reductions for the wealthy is meeting resistance from the party's newly emboldened moderates. When the House returns for business today, we hope those late-arriving champions of financial and moral sanity hold firm.

The girl, Dilane Sandrakumar, is an eighth grader at Intermediate School 72, her father, Sandrakumar Sabaratnam, said. She was listed in guarded condition yesterday at St. Vincent Catholic Medical Centers, said James McMahon, the hospital's director of development. William J. Smith, a spokesman for the Richmond County district attorney's office, said that no criminal charges had been filed against the driver, Anil John, 41, but that an investigation was in progress. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MURPHY, MICHAEL J.
description: MURPHY--Michael J., 65. Of Vero Beach, died November 13, 2005 at VNA Hospice House after a long and valiant battle with cancer. He was born April 4, 1940 in New York City to James and Mary Murphy, both of whom were born in Co. Roscommon, Ireland. He has been a resident of Vero Beach, FL. for three years. Until recently, he also had homes in New Jersey and South Carolina. Mr. Murphy was a 1961 graduate of Manhattan College. In 1968, he received his J.D. from Fordham University Law School, where he was a member of the Board of the Fordham Law Review. His law career began as a Law Clerk for the Hon. Thomas F. Murphy in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York. In 1969, Mr. Murphy became associated with the New York law firm of Lord, Day & Lord. In 1976, he became a partner. After the dissolution of Lord, Day & Lord, he briefly joined Morgan, Lewis & Bockius as a partner. He then joined Healy & Baillie, LLP, as partner in 1995. He was admitted to practice before the following Bars: State of New York, United States District Courts for the Southern and Eastern Districts of New York, District of Connecticut, United States Court of Appeal for the Second, Fifth and Ninth Circuits, as well as the United States Supreme Court. Some of the many clients represented in his distinguished career as a commercial litigator include both foreign and domestic companies and the Government of Bermuda. Surviving are his wife of 42 years, Patricia Murphy of Vero Beach, FL; son, Michael P. Murphy of Hilton Head, SC; daughter and son-in-law, Patti and Mark Schuette, and their children, Cormac and Meaghan of Suwanee, GA; daughter, Kathleen Murphy of Hoboken, NJ; sisters, Anne Bogart of Belle Harbor, NY, Eileen Doyle of Morris Township, NJ, Margaret Murphy of Neponsit, NY, Theresa Sanders of Huntsville, AL and brother, Lt. Col., Ret. Patrick Murphy of Overland Park, KS. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Michael and Patricia Murphy Commemorative Scholarship Fund, St. Thomas Aquinas College, Rt.340, Sparkill, NY 10976. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, "The Funeral Chapel", 1076 Madison Avenue, Thursday, 2-5 P.M. and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial will be at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Friday, 10 A.M. Interment will be in Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fire Forces Evacuation At Penn Station
description: A one-alarm fire at the tail end of last evening's commute forced the evacuation of Penn Station and halted Long Island Rail Road service into and out of the station, a spokesman for the railroad, Brian Dolan, said. The fire, which was reported at 7:05 p.m., burned the ceiling in the main gate area, Mr. Dolan said, filling the concourse level with smoke and delaying 25 trains until service resumed at 8:31 p.m. About 12,000 riders were affected, but no injuries were reported, Mr. Dolan said. New York City Transit honored L.I.R.R. tickets, and many riders took the subway to Jamaica and Flatbush Avenue where they boarded trains for Long Island destinations, he said. A spokesman for the Fire Department said that the blaze appeared to have been started by workers using a torch at 2 Penn Plaza, which is situated above the station. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 10 Charged With Immigration Fraud
description: Ten people, including six sailors from the U.S.S. Eisenhower, have been charged with conspiring to fake marriages to help people they believed were illegal immigrants enter the United States, Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan, said yesterday. Prosecutors said the immigrants were actually undercover F.B.I. operatives conducting a sting operation. The prosecutors said that Kenneth Adam Howard, of Baltimore, recruited the sailors, who were based in Norfolk, Va., and others to participate in sham marriages, and that he provided identification documents for $3,000 to $4,000 each.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Uzbekistan: 15 Convicted In Uprising
description: A court in Tashkent, the capital, sentenced 15 men to prison terms of 14 to 20 years for their supposed roles in the antigovernment uprising in Andijon in May, closing a legal proceeding widely regarded as a show trial. All had previously said that they were "fully guilty," and several said they deserved to be executed. Rights groups said the confessions were coerced. In Brussels, the European Union blocked 12 senior Uzbek officials and security officers, including the defense and interior ministers, from traveling to the 25 member countries, citing their roles in the bloody crackdown after the uprising. Survivors say hundreds of people, many unarmed, were killed. The ban did not include President Islam A. Karimov, which a spokeswoman for the bloc said was in the interest of a maintaining "dialogue and cooperation" with Uzbekistan. In Moscow, Mr. Karimov and President Vladimir V. Putin signed a mutual defense treaty, binding their countries more closely than they have been since the collapse of the Soviet Union. The pact could allow Russia to post troops on Uzbek soil. C. J. Chivers (NYT)

title: Vine Deloria Jr., 72, Writer Who Pursued Indian Causes, Dies

title: Old Methods, Newly Found
description: The early-music business, and the bands that ride its waves, have two principal agendas. One is the rehabilitation of composers who were considered great in their day but have since been forgotten. The other is to find fresh ways to present the music of the most familiar early composers -- fresh ways that ideally can be presented as closer to the source, which is to say as newly discovered old ways.

title: In search of the smart orangutan
Inflation Eased in October; Car and Energy Sales Drop
description: Inflation at the wholesale level tapered off in October after surging in the immediate aftermath of the hurricanes, the government reported yesterday, as energy and auto prices fell.

title: Helping Students Cope With a Katrina-Tossed World
description: Students keep coming in to see Cassandra Henry, the school nurse at Three Rivers Elementary School in Gulfport, Miss., with vague complaints: headaches or stomach pains that are rarely accompanied by fevers or other symptoms. Other pupils are quiet and withdrawn.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: When the National Brand Loses Its Local Appeal
description: HAUPPAUGE, N.Y. - EVER since dinosaurs walked you could count on one thing: Republicans would control Long Island politics, and particularly the 12-story tower poking out of the Long Island landscape that's the seat of Suffolk County government.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MONSERRAT, JOSEPH
description: MONSERRAT--Joseph. On November 13, 2005. Survived by wife Judith Reiss, daughter Dr. Laura Monserrat, granddaughter Andrea Monserrat Colon, sister Olga Bello. Visitation Wednesday, 5-9 PM, at Frank E. CampbellThe Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Services Thursday, 11:30 AM, at the funeral home. Interment Calverton National Cemetery.

title: 5 marines die in Iraq in assault near border
Google Aims for the Classified Ads Business
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15 - Google is poised to enter the highly competitive classified advertisement business, posing a threat to online and traditional businesses in that field.

title: Ex-spy chiefs arrested in South Korea
Briefly: Deutsche Bahn to buy BAX
Sarkozy ratchets up his challenge to Chirac
Seeing Opportunities, Not Headaches, in the New Laws
description: WANT to plump up the bottom line? Business owners who stay abreast of the nation's ever-changing tax laws can almost certainly find opportunities to do so.

title: This Could Be the True Test for Chocophiles
description: At ABC Carpet & Home, let the aroma of chocolate be your guide to the back of the store and down a few steps. There you will find a giant oval cacao pod and the chocolates of Michel Cluizel, which has opened its first shop outside Paris. Plush banquettes and tables line two sides of the area.

title: Free Flow: Railroading Amtrak's president
Drug Plan Maze: Directions Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: In 'smart' hotel rooms, everything is just right
William Bryant, Top Lawyer and Trailblazing Judge, 94, Dies
description: William B. Bryant, who in four decades on the Federal District Court in Washington presided over scores of leading cases and became the court's first black chief judge, died on Sunday at his home in the capital. He was 94.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARSO, BLANCHE
description: MARSO--Blanche. 100 years old. Beloved wife of the late Ernest. Devoted mother, loving grandmother and great grandmother. Services 1 PM Thursday at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC.

title: Wild Demand, and Competition, for New Pet Products
description: HOW hot is the pet market these days? Think dog purses, cat strollers, "Cab-bone-net" wine-flavored dog treats and sitters hired to watch television with Fido, and some sense of the lunatic growth becomes clear.

title: Serving Essence of Pumpkin, Instead of the Annual Pie
description: IT may be Thanksgiving, but to make pumpkin pie is a relatively thankless task. Always invited but often ignored, most pumpkin pies are too heavy to enjoy after a large dinner. Yet the meal is somehow incomplete without it.

title: Arts, Briefly; Dance Magazine Awards
description: "He was the last hoofer standing, the last action hero." Thus spake Savion Glover on Monday night about the veteran tap dancer Jimmy Slyde, left. Mr. Slyde was on hand at Florence Gould Hall to receive a 2005 Dance Magazine Award, and accepted it on behalf of all the other "doctors," fellow tap dancers with whom he had received an honorary doctorate. Others honored were the choreographer Christopher Wheeldon, the critic Clive Barnes, the choreographer Donald McKayle and the ballerina Alessandra Ferri. In addition to the awards and speeches, Wendy Whelan and Sbastien Marcovici from City Ballet danced a pas de deux from Mr. Wheeldon's "Polyphonia"; Roxane D'Orleans Juste did a hot solo from Mr. McKayle's "Angelitos Negros"; there was a short film by Fabrizio Ferri of Ms. Ferri dancing in an abandoned Milan factory to music by Bach played on acoustic guitar by Sting; and Mr. Glover and Mr. Slyde did a little soft-shoe shuffling. Mr. Barnes did not perform.

title: When Childlike Wonder Meets Eroticism
description: Ohad Naharin is 53 now, and long since established as Israel's leading choreographer. But he's been through a lot lately, and his new piece, "Mamootot," in its spare, reserved, sexual and literally touching way, reflects all that.

title: A War Against Time for the Painted Soldiers of Gettysburg
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa. - Just two decades removed from the horrors of the Civil War, throngs of sightseers stepped into the center of a gigantic painting-in-the-round to imagine what it might have felt like to be in the scrum of battle on the hallowed ground of Gettysburg.

title: Giving a Woman a Job While Stealing Her Soul
description: "Hilda," by the French novelist and playwright Marie Ndiaye, is a psychodrama from which most of the psychology seems to have mysteriously evaporated, taking a lot of the drama with it. Part of the citywide Act French festival devoted to new theater from France, it opened last night at the 59E59 Theaters.

title: A Curious Strategy for Dealing With the Other Woman
description: Set in one of those sleepy hamlets burbling with underground rivers of molten feeling, the French drama "Gilles's Wife" opens with a man returning home and rousing his sleeping wife first to consciousness, then to passion. The man is Gilles (Clovis Cornillac), a provider with the fleshy round face of a baby, who dutifully trudges with antlike constancy between his home and the mine in which he works. Not until this pacific world comes undone by those molten passions do we hear the name of Gilles's wife, a woman whose steady smile speaks to a well-ordered life organized around her beautiful children, her tidy home and, most important, the husband who serves as her sun.

title: Recipe: Simple Roast Turkey
Child Agency Is Subject of Charges Against 6
description: The Westchester County district attorney, Jeanine F. Pirro, said late yesterday afternoon that she had filed a criminal complaint charging six former supervisors of what was once the fifth-largest contract foster care provider in New York City with forgery and conspiracy.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Mining Company Suit Dropped
description: A court in Jakarta dismissed a civil suit filed by the government against the world's largest gold producer, the Newmont Mining Corporation, saying charges of pollution at Buyat Bay near one of the company's mines should instead be heard by an international arbitrator. A criminal trial against the company and its senior executive in Indonesia, Richard B. Ness, on similar charges of pollution, will continue. The government was seeking $133.6 million in damages in the civil suit.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Morris Plains: Construction On New Hospital
description: Construction began yesterday on the new Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital, an important project for the acting governor, Richard J. Codey. The new 510-bed hospital will replace a facility that was opened in 1876 and partly demolished last spring. The $190 million project, scheduled for completion in 2008, was part of Mr. Codey's efforts to improve the state's mental health system. It will allow for more staff members per patient and better security, state officials said.

title: New Jersey Sets Bear Hunt for Six Days in December
description: New Jersey will hold a six-day hunt next month to reduce the state's bear population after an increase this year in complaints about problem bears.

title: Exxon at odds with Jakarta on reserve
At home in Italy, but still apart
Drug Plan Maze: Directions Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Sharon's Son Takes Plea Deal
description: Omri Sharon, the 41-year-old son of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon and a member of Parliament, pleaded guilty to illegal fund-raising linked to his father's campaign for the leadership of the Likud Party in 1999. He accepted the plea agreement at the start of his trial. He faces several years in prison, but the sentence is expected to be lighter, according to news media reports.

title: Country Music Awards Nod to Future While Gazing at Days Past
description: In country music, it was a good year for cheating, drinking and looking back. The 39th annual Country Music Association Awards, country's top prizes, went to old-fashioned songs about those perennial topics when they were presented last night at Madison Square Garden during a live telecast on CBS.

title: Waking to a New Flu Threat
description: EVERYONE is wondering whether the bird-flu virus will mutate and cause an outbreak of influenza comparable to the 1918 pandemic, which killed more than 25 million people. But there is an additional possibility -- that the bird flu, if it comes, may bring more than influenza.

title: Senate Panel Approves Special Tax on Oil Profits
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 - In a telling sign of the political impact of soaring energy prices, the Republican-controlled Senate Finance Committee voted on Tuesday to impose a $5 billion tax next year on the nation's biggest oil companies.

title: Invisible New Yorkers
description: Marjorie Eliot holds Sunday afternoon jazz concerts in her apartment in the Sugar Hill neighborhood of Harlem. They are meant to honor her son Philip Eliot, who died of a kidney infection in 1992 at age 32. She said he shared her love of music. LENS

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about violence in Iraq misstated the given name of a prominent politician's relative who disappeared after Iraqi police officers and American troops said he had ties to insurgents. He is Hatem Mahdi Saleh, the brother of Hajim al-Hassani, speaker of the National Assembly -- not Nashat Mahdi Saleh, another brother of Mr. Hassani's.

title: In New Orleans, the Wait for Federal Loans Drags On
description: WASHINGTON - AT a Senate hearing last week, Walter Isaacson, the former CNN chief who is vice chairman of the agency leading Louisiana's recovery from Hurricane Katrina, identified the state's two highest priorities: stronger levees and loans to help the 80,000 or so small businesses in the hardest-hit areas stay afloat.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Supreme Court Bans Fringe Party
description: The Supreme Court banned the National Bolshevik Party, a small radical organization that has organized repeated antigovernment protests. The party's roots include radical elements and ideas, like annexing parts of Kazakhstan, but under its leader, the writer Eduard Limonov, its members have sought to establish themselves as a legitimate, if fiercely antigovernment, political party. Mr. Limonov said in a telephone interview that the ban -- the first of any political party in Russia's modern history -- was a Kremlin effort to silence its opponents.

title: Earnings Soar at J. C. Penney; Saks Drops Plan to Sell Chain
description: The J. C. Penney Company said yesterday that quarterly profit surged 57 percent on sales of private-label apparel. Saks Inc. reported profit from insurance and credit card settlements and said that it had abandoned plans to sell its Club Libby Lu chain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRUNSWICK, JOHN
description: BRUNSWICK--John. Round Dune mourns the passing of longtime resident John Brunswick. Deepest sympathy goes out to his wife Hilda and family.

title: A War Against Time for the Painted Soldiers of Gettysburg
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa. - Just two decades removed from the horrors of the Civil War, throngs of sightseers stepped into the center of a gigantic painting-in-the-round to imagine what it might have felt like to be in the scrum of battle on the hallowed ground of Gettysburg.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROTH, GLORIA
description: ROTH--Gloria. The Board of Directors of The Nathaniel Wharton Fund wishes to extend its sympathy to the family of our esteemed Board Member Gloria Roth. She has been an extraordinary help in our research for many years. Her loss is felt by everyone both at The Wharton Fund and at Columbia University. Ralph N. Wharton, M.D. Executive Director

title: News Analysis:Indonesia hailed for efforts on terrorism
Cook in Zero Minutes: Make a Reservation
description: THERE are various ways to avoid roasting a turkey, preparing the trimmings and baking a pie. Hire a caterer, order the meal to take out or, as New Yorkers are more than ready to do, make a reservation. Increasingly, restaurants are staying open on Thanksgiving Day.

title: Revisiting the History Of the War in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Funds in brief: Media fund in Australia falls short of its goal
Stocks: Shares fall on oil price and American Express
Ground Zero Cooling Plant Shrinks From XL to S
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey intends to drastically shrink its plans for an underground chiller plant at the World Trade Center site, cutting off the new commercial office towers from the central air-conditioning and water cooling system.

title: INSIDE
description: Reporters and the Leak Case Lawyers for I. Lewis Libby Jr. plan to seek testimony from journalists beyond those cited in his indictment, people involved in the case said.

title: China confirms first human bird flu cases
Paid Notice: Deaths   AIKMAN, ROBERT E.
description: AIKMAN--Robert E., 73, and Rachel S., 74. Of Amarillo, TX, died Friday, November 4, 2005 of injuries sustained in an automobile accident. Mr. and Mrs. Aikman met and married while students at the University of Oklahoma. A leader in the oil and gas industry for more than fifty years, Mr. Aikman began his career in 1952 with Cities Service Oil Company. In 1960 Mr. Aikman and other family members formed Aikman Brothers Corporation. Mr. Aikman actively participated in the management of PanCanadian Petroleum, Dorchester Gas Corporation, Dorchester Exploration Inc., Energy Resources Corporation, OGP Energy Companies, Inc., Provident Trade Co., Lazy G Ranch Inc., and WhamTech Inc. From 1990 until his death he served as a Director of Range Resources Corporation. Mr. Aikman cherished his personal relationships and found great delight in meeting with "oil cronies" and other friends. Mrs. Aikman, a woman of boundless energy, found time to dedicate her considerable talents to her church and many charitable and civic organizations. In 1981 Mrs. Aikman founded Caledonia Market Inc., an interior design firm. Her designs were influenced by her vibrance, warmth and charm. Bob and Rachel never learned the meaning of the word "stranger". They believed in the inclusiveness of the extended family and their welcome knew no bounds. They found greatest pride and fulfillment in their four children, their daughters - and - sons - in - law, fifteen grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A memorial service was held on November 12 at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church, Amarillo. The family suggest memorials be made to the Matthew Aikman Gray Rehabilitation Fund, Happy State Bank, Sconcy, Amarillo, TX. 79119 or a favorite charity.

title: Nokia set to purchase Intellisync
A Rancorous Primary Leaves 3-Way Race to Lead Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 15 - It was a bitter primary campaign, full of mudslinging, scandals and party schisms, the sort of political donnybrook seldom seen in Mexico. But as the last returns came in Monday from Sunday's final primary, voters were left with three candidates standing for president.

title: Test Prep Help for Students Who Can't Afford Kaplan
description: MINNEAPOLIS - MIDDLE- and upper-class teenagers get lots of extra help in the college application process. They get personal SAT tutors and SAT prep courses, they get assistance on their rsums and college essays from writing coaches and parents. They have guidance counselors and teachers with time to help.

title: America's Future Is Stuck Overseas
description: Arlington, Va. - ACCORDING to a recent survey, more foreign graduate students enrolled in American universities this year than last, but their numbers remain far lower than they were in 2002. That international graduate student enrollment is no longer declining is welcome news. But it should not distract us from the obstacles the United States still faces in attracting top talent to its shores.

title: Revisiting the History of the War in Iraq (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Can I Get a Little Privacy?
description: WILL Estelle Griswold ever be able to rest in peace? Although she died in 1981, the poor woman gets kicked up and down the block whenever someone is nominated to a seat on the United States Supreme Court. But few people remember who Griswold was or what she did.

title: Members of the Giants Remember Tisch
description: The death of the Giants co-owner Preston Robert Tisch yesterday came only three weeks after the death of the team's patriarch, Wellington Mara.

title: For a Family Winery, Marketing Proves as Crucial as the Grapes
description: SONOMA, CALIF. - IF the dusty driveway in this flat, inelegant swath of wine country was a deterrent, you couldn't tell from the man in the Maybach. As cicadas buzzed and a pile driver in a neighbor's yard pounded in the heat, the gentleman backed his sparkling Mercedes-Benz up to a barn door at the Robledo Family Winery, filled the trunk with cases of wine and said simply, "I buy it every year because it's so good."

title: Remapping the Cultural Territories of America
description: The Believer is a monthly magazine as smartly designed as the comics we call graphic novels. It is filled with what was once labeled new journalism and is now called experimental or creative nonfiction.

title: Torture Alleged at Ministry Site Outside Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 15 - Iraq's government said Tuesday that it had ordered an urgent investigation of allegations that many of the 173 detainees American troops discovered over the weekend in the basement of an Interior Ministry building in a Baghdad suburb had been tortured by their Iraqi captors. A senior Iraqi official who visited the detainees said two appeared paralyzed and others had some of the skin peeled off their bodies by their abusers.

title: Dreamy Galaxies for Star-Cross'd Lovers
description: The Metropolitan Opera's much-anticipated new production of Gounod's "Romo et Juliette" opened on Monday night without the star for whom it was conceived, the brilliant French coloratura soprano Natalie Dessay. Ms. Dessay, a petite beauty and charismatic actress, was to sing the role of Juliette but had to withdraw because of a bad cold. Her replacement was Maureen O'Flynn, a gifted American soprano and an experienced Juliette. This was the role of her 1998 Met debut in the company's previous production, which dates from 1967. But since Ms. O'Flynn performed without having had a stage rehearsal, it would be premature to assess the production of the Belgian director Guy Joosten and his creative team, all in their Met debuts.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Sex Offender Sentenced
description: A convicted sex offender who is already imprisoned for sexually abusing a dozen teenage boys was sentenced yesterday to 50 years to life in prison for the murder of a 12-year-old Yonkers boy in 1998. The man, Robert D. DeRosario, 42, was a suspect from the beginning, but because investigators had trouble coming up with enough evidence he was charged with the crime only in 2004. By then, at least four inmates had come forward to testify that Mr. DeRosario, in conversations, had admitted to abducting and then strangling the boy, Orlandito Rosario-Maldonado. Mr. DeRosario was convicted on Sept. 28. "We never ever gave up on Orlandito," the Westchester County district attorney, Jeanine F. Pirro, said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article by The Associated Press on Monday about the Los Angeles Galaxy's 1-0 soccer victory over the New England Revolution for the Major League Soccer championship misstated the Galaxy's regular-season record. It was 13-13-6, not 13-13-7.

title: Rangers' Winning Streak Ends in Toronto
description: TORONTO, Nov. 15 - A former New York-area star bedeviled the Rangers on Tuesday night against the Toronto Maple Leafs. It was not the star many fans might have expected.

title: 4 Tenet Doctors Settle U.S. Case
description: Four doctors who worked at a former Tenet Healthcare Corporation hospital in California have agreed to pay $32.5 million to settle a federal inquiry into claims that they performed unnecessary procedures.

title: CALENDAR
description: Food for Mind and Tummy A party to kick off the Goddard Riverside Community Center's New York Book Fair will be held on Friday from 6:30 to 9:30 p.m. at the center, 593 Columbus Avenue (88th Street). New books will be sold at 50 percent off cover price, and food, wine and cheese will be served. Tickets are $125 in advance, $150 at the door: (212) 873-4448.

title: Rules and Advice for Turning You Inc. From Idea to Reality
description: YOU'RE slaving away at your job, and you can tell you're going to finish yet another tedious task on time. Your boss is nice enough. The pay is decent, but you need something more. So amid the buzz of the office environment, you temporarily turn your attention to the Web to order supplies for You Inc., the small business you have quietly started on the side.

title: Preston Robert Tisch, Owner of Loews Hotels and Giants, Dies
description: Correction Appended

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Cell Tower Review Proposed
description: The City Council held its first hearing yesterday on legislation that would allow communities to have more say in the placement of cellular antennas in residential neighborhoods. The legislation, sponsored by Councilman Peter F. Vallone Jr. of Queens, would require the installation of the antennas to be approved by the City Planning Commission and the Council. The antennas now need approval only from the Buildings Department, which primarily considers technical criteria like size. The Bloomberg administration and telecommunications companies have opposed the legislation, saying that it would pose an undue burden on the companies and impede the industry's growth. "We're not looking to prevent progress, but we do think that future placement of these antennas must be done responsibly," Mr. Vallone said.

title: Fuel Costs Factor in More Heavily
description: With oil about $60 a barrel, compared with $40 a barrel a year ago, and natural gas prices double those of last year, real estate managers are scrambling to contain their costs for electricity and other forms of energy and to find ways to reduce energy consumption.

title: Soccer: Australia squeezes into World Cup
Keepers of the Flame Pay Tribute to an Original
description: If any cabaret entertainer could be named the artistic heir to the irreplaceable Bobby Short, the most likely candidate is probably Michael Feinstein, the singer, pianist and musical archivist, who is so busy he sometimes seems to be performing on several New York stages at once.

title: Stand by Your Publicist
description: Stand by Your Publicist

title: Panel approves Bernanke as Fed nominee
Before Memoirs, He Wrote A's, B's, C's, D's and F's
description: When Susan Jane Gilman's parents picked up a hitchhiker years ago because he was wearing a Stuyvesant High School T-shirt, they were rewarded with this advice for their Stuyvesant-bound daughter: "Tell her to take Frank McCourt's creative writing class."

title: Tiptoeing Through the Tulips Straight to the Bank
description: JIM BELOFF found his muse at a flea market in Pasadena, Calif., 14 years ago. It was a Martin tenor ukulele that cost $250, and it changed his life.

title: Rhinestones and Cowboy Hats as the Opry Turns 80
description: "Boy, Carnegie Hall can be very quiet," Alison Krauss observed between songs on Monday night. For the first time since 1961, the Grand Ole Opry, a Nashville institution founded 80 years ago, had brought an all-star revue to the hall. The occasion was the night before the Country Music Association Awards at Madison Square Garden. Everyone -- musicians and audience -- was on good behavior, not always a good thing for country. It was a night for ballads, not hoedowns.

title: Drug Plan Maze: Directions Needed (8 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Post reporter Bob Woodward testifies in CIA leak investigation
Paid Notice: Deaths   SARACHEK, BERNARD
description: SARACHEK--Bernard. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of Bernard "Red" Sarachek, a legendary coach and proud Jew. He led and inspired generations of YU athletes as head basketball coach and athletic director from 1940 to 1969. A revered basketball strategist, he willingly lent his unparalleled expertise to coaches and players throughout the United States and Israel. Red Sarachek has been immortalized at YU through its annual national Jewish high school basketball tournament that proudly carries the "Coach's" name. Our heartfelt condolences to his children, Arlene (and Joseph) Weissmann, Esther (and Bert) Blitner, Jules, and Michael (and Jane), his eight grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: An attack on all Arabs
The Naked Truth About Thanksgiving; The Pilgrims Didn't Brine
description: I HAVE done foolish things in pursuit of a delicious Thanksgiving turkey.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BLINKEN, ROBERT
description: BLINKEN--Robert. A gathering to celebrate the life of Robert Blinken will be held on Thursday, November 17, at 9:45 AM at The Harvard Club, 27 West 44th Street, NYC.

title: China to Vaccinate All Its Poultry, With 5.2 Billion Flu Shots
description: BEIJING, Nov. 15 - China's Agriculture Ministry said Tuesday that it would inject all of the nation's 5.2 billion chickens, geese and ducks with a vaccine against bird flu.

title: I Have the Idea, You Have the Factory
description: Correction Appended

title: A.I.G.'s View on Suits
description: The American International Group Inc. employees facing possible lawsuits from the Securities and Exchange Commission are not "senior corporate officers," the chief executive, Martin Sullivan, said.

title: Sex Offenders Held Illegally, Judge Rules
description: A judge ruled yesterday that New York State was illegally holding 12 convicted sex offenders in a mental hospital after they had served their prison sentences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ANTMAN, SIDNEY D.
description: ANTMAN--Sidney D. Died in Florida, November 14. Devoted husband of Claire. Dearly loved by three generations: daughters Susan and Hope; grandchildren Melissa, Stephanie and Henry; greatgranddaughters Alexa and Lindsay. Perfect father-inlaw to Ted and Gregg.

title: World Briefing: Africa, Middle East, Asia, Europe, United Nations
description: AFRICA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCCOWN, R. GAYNOR
description: McCOWN--R. Gaynor. Educator, beloved wife and sister, friend, inspiration. "Make the world a better place." Services Friday, November 18 at 2 p.m., Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue at 84th St., NYC. A Celebration Toast to Gaynor follows immediately (approximately 3:15 p.m.) at the Council on Foreign Relations, 58 E. 68th St. Bring your favorite stories. Donations to NYC Outward Bound and Signature Theater.

title: Baseball Backs Stiffer Penalties for Steroid Use
description: Reacting to Congressional pressure, Major League Baseball announced yesterday that it would again toughen the penalties for steroid use and for the first time establish testing and penalties for the use of amphetamines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   QUIGLEY, LEONARD V.
description: QUIGLEY--Leonard V., 72. Died peacefully at home in Forest Hills Gardens on November 15, surrounded by his family. Born in Kansas City, Missouri, Len graduated from Holy Cross and Harvard Law School, and served in the Navy in the Korean War. A partner for over 35 years at the law firm of Paul, Weiss, where he founded the Canadian practice group, Len served for over 25 years as the General Counsel of the Archaeological Institute of America (AIA), and was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations and the Board of Directors of the Covenant House. Survived by Lynn, his wife of 41 years; four children, Matthew, Cannon, Daniel and Megan; 8 grandchildren; a sister, Rosemary McPhillips, and an extraordinarily close extended family. Predeceased by his brothers, Bernard and James, and four faithful German Shepherds, Major, Alberta, Petra and Sparta. Visiting hours Wednesday and Thursday evenings from 6:30-9 PM at Fox Funeral Home in Forest Hills and Mass of Christian Burial at Our Lady of Mercy Church in Forest Hills Friday at 10:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the AIA or the Covenant House of New York.

title: Dancing the obsessive, but in monk's clothing
11 Top Jordanian Advisers Resign in Wake of Attacks
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 15 - King Abdullah II of Jordan, concerned with a threat to his country that he described as Iraqis "who believe they're resistance fighters," accepted the resignations of 11 of his advisers on Tuesday night, including the national security adviser.

title: Taking a Side? Have It Ready at 'Hello'
description: YOU'VE got to figure that at least three-quarters of us travel to the homes of others for Thanksgiving. So why does turkey get so much attention when it's only the hosts who have to prepare it?

title: Nassau Prosecutor Calls Roslyn Plea Bargain Too Lenient
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Nov. 15 - Nassau County's district attorney has attacked as too lenient a judge's plan to impose a six-month jail sentence on the outside auditor who has pleaded guilty to helping cover up the theft of millions of dollars from the Roslyn school district.

title: Prosecutors Bet Big on Antiquities Trial in Italy
description: ROME, Nov. 15 - It is not every day that an American museum curator goes on trial, accused of a crime. But for Italian prosecutors, the spectacle is part of the point. In a high-stakes gamble, they are betting that a trial that opens here on Wednesday will strongly deter illicit trading in Italian antiquities -- and even persuade some American museums to give lost treasures back.

title: Pension Board Says Deficit Is Steady for Now
description: The federal agency that insures pensions reported yesterday that its financial position stayed roughly constant over the last fiscal year, after three years of record losses. But its executive director warned that the pension system's troubles, and the risk to the agency, were not over.

title: Morgan Stanley Bankers Brace for Cuts
description: JOHN J. MACK, under pressure to lift Morgan Stanley's profits and its flagging stock price, will take his eponymous knife to the firm's highly regarded investment banking division and dismiss as many as 22 managing directors in the coming days, said a person briefed on the plan.

title: Drug Plan Maze: Directions Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Ralph Edwards, Who Made Lives Into Shows, Dies at 92
description: Ralph Edwards, the broadcast pioneer who was the creator and master of ceremonies of two of the most popular programs in entertainment history, "Truth or Consequences" and "This Is Your Life," died today at 92.

title: People: Salman Rushdie, Sharon Stone, Oprah Winfrey
Learning to take risks
Swiss seize Russian-owned art to settle a debt
Paid Notice: Memorials   PARADNY, ROBERT, M.D.
description: PARADNY -- Robert, M.D. Dear Bob/Dad/Papa, you are loved as much today as ever. You were the best! Forever, Your Family

title: Hip-Hop Producer Begins Trial on Money Laundering Trials
description: In the insinuating world of hip-hop - where innuendo rules and, according to the old rap song, even means bad means good - Irv Gotti always knew how to play an edge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SALMON, TOM W.
description: SALMON--Tom W. Of Fort Lee, NJ and Palm Beach, FL. on November 14, 2005 at age 85. Born Kassel, Germany. Beloved husband of Faye for 59 yrs. Cherished father of Jane and husband Jerry Gliklich and Debra and husband Barry Seidel. Adored grandfather of David and Benjamin Gliklich and Erica and Julie Seidel. He was esteemed by his entire family and many friends. Services Wednesday 11:30 AM at "Wien & Wien", 402 Park St. Hackensack, NJ.

title: The Successor
Latin America, Classico and Nuevo
description: LIVING in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, for more than a decade, Vivian Torres felt she had no choice but to open a restaurant.

title: Focus on Myanmar
Paid Notice: Deaths   AMOS, REV. JAMES G.
description: AMOS -- Rev. James G. passed away on Saturday, November 12, 2005 at The Aultman Woodlawn Nursing Home in Canton, OH. He was 82. He was the beloved Pastor of The Gustavus Adolphus Lutheran Church for the last 421/2 years in Gramercy Park, in New York City. He also served as Pastor for The Our Savior Lutheran Church in Toledo, OH, and The Frederick Lutheran Church in St. Thomas. Pastor Amos was born in Massillon, OH on July 23, 1923. He was the son of the late Philip and Lily Graham Amos. In addition to his parents, he was preceded by his wife, the former Joan Demetral and two brothers, Wilson and Maurice Amos. He was the loving godfather of Mindy and Bradford Chin. Surviving are one sister and brother-in-law, Gloria and Richard Buxser, of Canton, OH, two sisters-in-law, Elaine Amos, of Brewster, OH, and Delores Amos, of Mississippi, ten nieces and nephews, and numerous great nieces and nephews. Viewing will be at Gustavus Adolphus Lutheran Church, 155 East 22nd Street, at Third Avenue in Manhattan on Friday, November 18th, 2005 between the hours of 2 to 4 P.M. and 6 to 9 P.M. Viewing on Saturday, November 19, 2005 from 5-7 P.M. with Memorial Services following at 7 P.M. On Tuesday November 22, 2005, there will be a Memorial Service at The First Evangelical Lutheran Church, in Beach City, OH at 11 A.M. Interment will be at South Lawn Cemetery in Beach City, OH following the service. Contributions in his memory may be made to: The Pastor James and Joan Amos Scholarship Fund at Gustavus Adolphus Lutheran Church, 155 East 22nd Street, New York, New York 10010, 212-674-0739.

title: A Matchup That's Just Not the Same
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 15 - Two of the greatest coaches in N.B.A. history will share a sideline again here Wednesday night, but the superlatives and the intrigue will more or less end there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OSCARD, FIFI
description: OSCARD--Fifi. The Mercantile Library of NY mourns the death of Fifi Oscard, esteemed member of its Board of Directors. Her concern for writers, her deep love of literature, her humor, intelligence and spirited embrace of life in this city will be much missed. She was an extraordinary human being, a wonderful Board member, and a cherished friend. Our deepest sympathy to her family and to all who loved her. The Board of Directors, staff, and members of the Mercantile Library of NY

title: Britain approves Muslim's extradition
For the Coffee Palate Too Refined for a Certain Large Chain
description: YOU may think these entrepreneurs are crazy when they talk about selling coffee beans for 40 bucks a pound. When they tell you that properly prepared single-origin coffee varietals have as much depth and complexity and nuance as the finest pinot noirs. When they talk "latte art," handing you a three-shot latte topped by an artistic memento -- a rosetta -- formed when perfectly textured black-brown espresso foam intermingles with the stiff froth of steam-blasted milk.

title: Apollo plans to step up its takeovers in Europe
Sports of The Times; Tisch Had 15 Years of Fun With the Giants
description: WHEN Bob Tisch, then a month shy of his 65th birthday, purchased 50 percent of the Giants for a reported $75 million in 1991, he told the team's co-owner Wellington Mara, "I just want to have 10 years of fun." "To have 10 years of fun in pro football," Mara replied with a smile, "you'll need to be in it for 30 years."

title: A Record Turnaround
description: Why does this page look this way?

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Commerzbank Acquisition
description: Commerzbank, Germany's fourth-biggest bank by assets, will take over the mortgage lender Eurohypo for as much as 4.65 billion euros ($5.4 billion). The company, which already owns 31.8 percent of Eurohypo, plans to buy Deutsche Bank's 37.7 percent holding and the 28.5 percent owned by Dresdner Bank, a unit of Allianz, Commerzbank said in a statement. Commerzbank, which returned to profit last year after 2.6 billion euros of losses in 2002 and 2003, has just 6 percent of the German bank market, where almost half of lending is controlled by state-owned banks that cannot be bought by publicly traded rivals.

title: Judge Halts Guantnamo Trial
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 - A federal judge has halted for at least several months the military's plan to resume the war crimes trial in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, of David Hicks, an Australian charged with fighting for the Taliban in Afghanistan.

title: Briefly: Deal struck on changes to expiring Patriot Act
Nets Show They Have More Than Three Stars
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 15 - The Nets made progress on two fronts Tuesday night: they projected a defensive presence that had been absent in their last two games and went deep into their lineup for production.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Johnson & Johnson and Guidant Revise Merger Deal, Cutting Price by $4 Billion Johnson & Johnson, the medical products giant, announced a revised merger deal under which it will pay $21.5 billion, or $4 billion less than it had originally agreed, for the Guidant Corporation, the troubled maker of implantable heart devices. [C1.]

title: A Tiny Theater in San Diego and Its Director Supply a Steady Flow to Broadway
description: Correction Appended

title: Catholic Bishops Approve Proposals on Lay Workers
description: Correction Appended

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: China will vaccinate its poultry population
For Rice, a Risky Dive Into the Mideast Storm
description: PUSAN, South Korea, Wednesday, Nov. 16 - Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice spent all day and night successfully brokering an accord on Tuesday on security controls at a Gaza border crossing, suddenly elevating the Bush administration's involvement in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict to a new level.

title: In Germany, leaders arising from the East
The Links of Influence Peddling
description: Little did Representative Tom DeLay and other lawmakers dream that in frolicking on the golf junkets of Jack Abramoff, the indicted Republican superlobbyist, the influential politicians might, in effect, be caddying for his avaricious lobbying reach.

title: Deal made by bird flu drug firms
Spaniard Calls C.I.A. Plane Case 'Very Serious'
description: MADRID, Nov. 15 - Spain's interior minister expressed concern on Tuesday about accusations that planes used by the C.I.A. to transport terrorism suspects had made stopovers at a Spanish airport, saying the charges were "very serious" and would not be tolerated if proved.

title: The Naked Truth About Thanksgiving; What to Make First? A Plan
description: THERE will be 11 of us at the Thanksgiving table this year, and if the table were larger there would be more. For me Thanksgiving isn't Thanksgiving unless there are a lot of people at my table.

title: Escaping, With Flair, From a World of Ugliness
description: The adage that history repeats itself first as tragedy, then as farce is charmingly illustrated by Neil Jordan's picaresque fairy tale, "Breakfast on Pluto." Superficially, the movie might be described as "The Crying Game" redux, in which the director revisits his 1992 political thriller with its gender-bending twist. This time, he reimagines its themes as a sprawling comic epic: "Candide" meets "Tom Jones" in drag heaven.

title: Literature,one screen at a time
Arts, Briefly; Cowboys and Snail Score
description: A come-from-behind victory by the Dallas Cowboys against the Philadelphia Eagles put ABC in first place in Monday's Nielsen ratings. ABC's lineup -- "Wife Swap" and "Monday Night Football," -- finished ahead of CBS in both total viewers and in the 18-to-49 demographic. CBS had the most-watched program of the night in "CSI: Miami" (18.85 million). Those viewers saw Wolfe (Jonathan Togo) shot in the face with a nail gun. Through the November ratings sweep so far, CBS is No. 1 both in total viewers and among adults 18 to 49. Friday's "SpongeBob SquarePants" special on Nickelodeon was the highest-rated entertainment show on cable last week. The episode, in which Gary, the meowing snail, ran away from home, delivered an audience of 7.93 million. The special was second in popularity only to the Super Bowl among children 2 to 11 and 6 to 11 in 2005.

title: Dozens Hurt in Bombing in Indian Kashmir
description: NEW DELHI, Wednesday, Nov. 16 - In the latest in a surge of violence over three days, a large car bomb exploded Wednesday morning in restive Indian-controlled Kashmir province, severely wounding dozens of people and leaving an uncertain death toll.

title: Broadcast Chief Violated Laws, Inquiry Finds
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 - Investigators at the Corporation for Public Broadcasting said on Tuesday that they had uncovered evidence that its former chairman had repeatedly broken federal law and the organization's own regulations in a campaign to combat what he saw as liberal bias.

title: France Is Trying, Discreetly, to Integrate Television a Bit
description: PARIS, Nov. 15 - Audrey Pulvar's posture straightens incrementally as a television producer counts down from five in a broadcast studio here, and at 7:30 p.m. sharp, her image flashes onto screens across the country.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Burberry Profit Slips
description: Profits at the Burberry Group dropped for the first time since the company, the luxury goods retailer, went public in 2002. The company also said that Brian Blake, group president and chief operating officer, resigned. Net income for the six months ended Sept. 30 fell 2.7 percent, to 53.1 million ($92 million). Suzy Menkes (IHT)

title: Tennis: Davydenko beats Gaudio
Judges Rebuked for Abusing Contempt Power
description: The State Commission on Judicial Conduct announced yesterday that it had disciplined two judges for abusing their power to hold litigants in contempt of court.

title: Washington Post's Woodward Apologizes for Lapse on Leak
description: Bob Woodward, assistant managing editor of The Washington Post, today apologized to his newspaper's executive editor for waiting two years to tell him that a senior Bush administration official had told him about the C.I.A. operative Valerie Wilson.

title: Death Penalty Case Gives a Clue to Alito's Methods
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 - As partisans work feverishly to dissect the judicial record of President Bush's latest choice for the Supreme Court, one point may easily be lost: judges do not actually spend much of their time on high-profile issues like religion or abortion.

title: Israeli Cleared in Death of Arab Girl
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 15 - An Israeli military court on Tuesday cleared an Army captain of accusations that he shot repeatedly, and from close range, at a 13-year-old Palestinian girl who already had been shot, apparently fatally, by soldiers under his command.

title: N.F.L. Seeks Partner in Possible Second Network
description: Jerry Jones's wide smile added wattage to the bright lights at Lincoln Financial Field when he talked about the TV rights still left to be sold by the National Football League.

title: BMW North America Signs With GSD&M
description: BMW North America in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., part of BMW, has named GSD&M in Austin, Tex., as its national creative agency, replacing Fallon Worldwide in Minneapolis, part of the Publicis Groupe. After a decade, Fallon parted ways with BMW in June, when the account was placed in review. BMW North America plans to spend $70 million to $80 million next year on advertising.

title: Pujols's Excellence Finally Earns Him an M.V.P.
description: For four years, a sizable obstacle stood between Albert Pujols, the St. Louis Cardinals' talented young slugger, and his first National League Most Valuable Player award.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Father Striving to Provide a Home for Two Daughters
description: Daric Davis wanted a son. And 15 years ago, the momentary placement of an umbilical cord convinced him that he had one.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Correction Officer Admits Theft
description: Correction Appended

title: Other Views: Daily Star, The Guardian, Business Times
Golf: Woods feels good about his game
Like a Rose, a Woman Withers
description: Watching Repertorio Espaol's "Doa Rosita la Soltera" is a bit like finding a dried flower pressed in a book: charming, archaic and just a bit musty, starting with its name, which translates as "Doa Rosita the Spinster." (Not a title the "Sex and the City" generation is likely to relate to, even though Doa Rosita is played by Denise Quiones -- Miss Universe, 2001 -- who is, by any period's standards, a babe.)

title: Arts, Briefly; Cash Family Histories
description: After fans of the Cash country-music dynasty see the new film "Walk the Line," about Johnny and June Carter Cash, they will get another view of the family story in a new album by Rosanne Cash, below, the acclaimed songwriter who is a daughter of Johnny Cash. On "Black Cadillac," to be released on Jan. 24 by Capitol, Ms. Cash confronts the losses of her father; her mother, Vivian Liberto Distin; and her stepmother, June Carter Cash. The three died within two years of one another. Another Cash daughter, Kathy Cash, has criticized "Walk the Line" for its portrayal of her mother, Ms. Liberto Distin, Johnny Cash's first wife, who divorced him in 1966. "My mom was basically a nonentity in the entire film," she said, "except for the mad little psycho who hated his career."

title: School Coach, Now Dead, Is Subject of Abuse Charges
description: For generations of boys coming of age at Poly Prep Country Day School in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, Phil Foglietta was more than a football coach. Over 25 years, as he built the school into a powerhouse, Mr. Foglietta, who died in 1998, also served as a tough father figure and inspiring confidant, pushing his charges to high levels of achievement.

title: Believe It or Not, a Ms. Runs the Shop
description: WASHINGTON - WHEN Marsha Serlin began picking up scrap metal off the street and selling it in 1978, she was the rare -- if not the only -- woman in Chicago's scrap metal recycling business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KEENAN, ALICE M.
description: KEENAN--Alice M. Of Punta Gorda, FL, formerly of Centerport, LI, NY. Wife of the late Thomas J., mother of Thomas J., Harry J., John T., Christopher R. and the late Peggy Keenan. Grandmother of four. Reposing Nolan & Taylor-Howe Funeral Home, Northport, LI, Thursday and Friday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass Saturday 9:45AM, Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Centerport. Burial Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn.

title: Report urges curbs on insurance sales to GIs
Stamford Man Charged in '71 Bronx Murder
description: A Connecticut man was arrested on Monday and charged with the murder of a tailor during a robbery in the Bronx nearly 34 years ago, the New York police said yesterday.

title: He Figured That Business Is So Good, Who Needs a Store?
description: RANDOLPH, Vt. - AFTER three years of riding the Internet to steadily climbing sales, Eric Truran decided to use the Web to move his small manufacturing business, CourierWare, in another direction. He wanted it to shrink.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEEHAN, MIRIAM
description: MEEHAN--Miriam. We at Brown Harris Stevens Residential Management, LLC extend our heartfelt sympathy to the Meehan family on the passing of Mrs. Meehan who served so well on the Board of Directors for her Cooperative Corporation. She was a woman of infinite grace and she will be greatly missed.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Church Says Lenin Should Be Buried
description: The Russian Orthodox Church waded into the renewed debate over whether to remove Lenin's corpse from its tomb on Red Square. Metropolitan Kirill, who serves as the church's chief of foreign relations, called for Lenin's burial, saying "the idea of mummification is beyond the realm of Russian cultural and religious traditions," Interfax reported.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PUGH, JAMES
description: PUGH--James. Of Bronxville, New York. December 27, 1943--November 14, 2005. Beloved husband of Carole, loving father of Mary Elizabeth and John Joseph, adored son of Mary and Joseph Pugh, dear brother of Joseph, Stephen and Peggy. Graduate of USC, Vietnam veteran, FX Professional, loyal friend. Wake: McGrath & Son, Bronxville, NY, Thursday, November 17th, 2-4 and 7-9. Mass: St. Josephs, Bronxville, 10AM, November 18.

title: Big Board Settles With Dissidents Opposed to Planned Merger
description: The New York Stock Exchange reached a settlement yesterday with 10 dissident seat holders, or exchange owners, who had sued to halt the exchange's merger with the electronic trading operator Archipelago Holdings.

title: Some Caution Helps When Selling Fantasies
description: FOR comic-book readers, Christmas comes every Wednesday. That is the day new issues arrive in stores. Whether you are a fan of superhero titles starring the Teen Titans or the Young Avengers, or independent books like "The Walking Dead," this day is when aficionados line up to get their latest comics fix.

title: Tokyo in Midtown (English Optional)
description: AT Aburiya Kinnosuke, a new restaurant in Midtown, you probably won't spot any celebrities, the way you might at a more lavish, trendy Japanese pleasure palace like Megu or Nobu.

title: China phones may get Skype
World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Bomb Kills G.I.
description: A bomb killed an American soldier on patrol in southeastern Paktika Province, near Pakistan, military officials said. Eighty-seven American soldiers have died this year in Afghanistan. David Rohde (NYT)

title: In an old Celtic revival, spelling is a test of wills
Transit Agency Authorizes Funds for 2nd Avenue Line
description: After months of uncertainty about the pace and progress of the Second Avenue subway, a project that seems to be forever on the drawing board, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority intends today to authorize spending $150.4 million for the final design of a first segment, from East 96th to East 63rd Streets.

title: Allergan Makes a Bid for Implant Maker
description: Allergan, a company best known for eye-care products and its Botox antiwrinkle therapy, said yesterday that it had offered a $3.2 billion combination of cash and stock to acquire Inamed, a leader in breast implants and the fast-growing market for antiobesity devices.

title: Car bomb in Kashmir kills 3
Free Countertop Parking For a New Baster in Town
description: Silicone basting and pastry brushes have been around for a year or so, but this new one from Cuisipro ramps up the convenience with a self-contained stand, to avoid a mess when you park it on the counter. The handle unscrews so that fats, glazes or other ingredients (about three tablespoons' worth) can be poured in and released with slight pressure. The business end is flattish and perfectly angled. The brush, in red or frosted white, is $11.95 at the Art of Cooking in Greenwich Village; the Peppermill in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn; and at cooking.com for $10.95. FOOD STUFF

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: New Leader For Schrder's Party
description: The Social Democrats, the party of Gerhard Schrder, elected a 51-year-old East German, Matthias Platzeck, as their new chairman. He succeeds Franz Mntefering, 65, who stepped down last month after losing an internal power struggle.

title: Mystery of Gossipy Blog on the Judiciary Is Solved
description: Alex Kozinski, a federal appeals court judge in California, was a little miffed last year when a blog called Underneath Their Robes, a dishy hybrid of People magazine and The Harvard Law Review, failed to list him as a candidate for "male superhottie of the federal judiciary."

title: Jackhammers Shake a Refuge for the Weary
description: AT the very bottom of Manhattan island, where black skyscrapers blunt the sunlight and most people leave by dusk, there sits a small building of brick at 7 State Street. It seems out of place, out of context -- a corner of the sepia-tinted past, pasted onto the Technicolor present.

title: Adrian P. Rogers, 74, Leader of Conservative Baptist Group, Dies
description: The Rev. Adrian P. Rogers, the three-time president of the Southern Baptist Convention who led a conservative takeover of the powerful denomination that helped usher in a resurgence of conservative Christians on pulpits and in politics, died on Tuesday in Memphis. He was 74.

title: G.O.P. Ends Push for'Bridges to Nowhere'
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 - Congressional Republicans decided today to legislatively raze two Alaskan bridge projects that had demolished the party's reputation for fiscal austerity.

title: Drug Plan Maze: Directions Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Currencies: Dollar strengthens on U.S. asset buying
Gifted Classes Will Soon Use Uniform Test, Klein Decides
description: Despite weeks of angry resistance from parents on the Upper West Side, Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein has decided to move forward with plans to apply a single standardized application process for the school system's coveted talented and gifted programs.

title: What Made Pistachio Nuts? Some Historical Answers
description: No Applause -- Just Throw Money The Book That Made Vaudeville Famous By Trav S.D.Illustrated. 328 pages. Faber & Faber. $25.

title: 5 Marines Killed as U.S. Pushes Sweep in Western Iraq
description: UBAYDI, Iraq, Nov 16 - Five marines were killed and 11 were wounded in an ambush at a farmhouse on the outskirts of this rural town while they were hunting for insurgents, Marine officials said. It was the deadliest day for the Marines since beginning an aggressive sweep on Nov. 5 for guerrillas near the Syrian border.

title: Corrections
Tunisia chided over Web censorship
Revisiting the History Of the War in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article and a picture caption on Oct. 26 about American service members who were killed in Iraq misstated the date of the death of Marine Cpl. Jeffrey B. Starr. It was May 30, not April 30.

title: Study Identifies Heart Patient's Best Friend
description: DALLAS, Nov. 15 - For people hospitalized with advanced heart disease, it is better to have visitors than to lie quietly alone. But one type of visitor seems to be especially beneficial, researchers reported on Tuesday.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Literary Laurels

title: Nominee Plays Down Remarks on Quotas and Abortion
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 - Seeking to tamp down a political uproar over a 1985 document in which he denounced racial quotas and said the Constitution did not protect the right to abortion, Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. told senators on Tuesday that the sentiments were simply the views of "an advocate seeking a job."

title: News Analysis: A sense that 'now was the time'
World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Softwood Lumber Appeal
description: Jim Peterson, Canada's trade minister, said Canada would appeal a World Trade Organization ruling that upholds the method used by the United States to impose duties on softwood lumber from Canada. If the appeal succeeds, Canada would impose trade retaliation of $3.57 billion against the United States. The W.T.O. found that the United States altered the methods used to calculate the tariffs on Canadian softwood to make them comply with international trade rules. An earlier decision found that the United States had not acted in an "objective and unbiased" manner. Mr. Peterson repeated Canada's contention that any W.T.O. rulings were trumped by a Nafta ruling ordering that the tariffs be dropped. Rob Portman, the United States trade representative, said he hoped the decision would prompt a negotiated settlement. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Vietnam Archive Offers Parallel to War in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 - White House advisers convene secret sessions on the political dangers of revelations that American troops committed atrocities in the war zone, and whether the president can delicately intervene in the investigation. In the face of an increasingly unpopular war, they wonder at the impact on support at home. The best way out of the war, they agree, is propping up a new government that can attract feuding elements across a fractured foreign land.

title: Congress Nudges Union in Selig's New Lineup
description: COMMISSIONER BUD SELIG and the owners should enjoy what is left of the era of labor peace because it won't last much longer. Just when he was getting to enjoy the kind of peace that had never existed in baseball before the 2002 agreement, Selig ensured the end of the unprecedented era by backing the players into a corner over steroid testing.

title: Consumer Inflation Rate Dropped Significantly in October
description: The consumer inflation rate dropped significantly in October and touched its lowest level since June as surging gasoline prices fell from their peak in September, the government reported today.

title: Health problems delay hearings on Milosevic
Matsui Signs With Yankees Just Before Deadline
description: Arn Tellem said Monday that he and his client Hideki Matsui were "exploring the great restaurants of New York." They dined again yesterday for the third night in a row, and the meal was a celebration.

title: Britain to Extradite Terrorism Suspect to U.S.
description: LONDON, Nov. 16 - Britain today approved the extradition to the United States of a 31-year-old British computer technician on terrorism charges, provoking anger and complaints from Islamic leaders that the decision was unjust and would alienate young Muslims.

title: They Know From Beauty, But Business Is Another Matter
description: RANDY CURRIE was 22 and riding high as a Vidal Sassoon-trained hair stylist when he decided to open his first beauty shop. Confident he could run his own business, he rented a 1,500-square-foot storefront in a Delaware shopping mall for $687 a month, installed 10 swivel chairs and named it Razzle Dazzle. Many customers were women who happened to pass his salon on their way to the butcher shop nearby.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEWIS, MYRNA IRENE
description: LEWIS--Myrna Irene, 67. Died November 15, born in Fountain, Minnesota, she was an undergraduate at the University of Minnesota and received her Master's and Doctorate at the Columbia University School of Social Work. She was co-author of "Aging and Mental Health," the first comprehensive textbook on the subject, as well as the popular "Love and Sex After 60." She devoted her life to confrontations with injustice and to understanding both the adverse events and possibilities in the lives of women, especially in their middle and later years. She taught at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine and was an active alumna of the Columbia University School of Social Work. She is survived by her husband, Robert N. Butler, M.D., daughter Alexandra, stepdaughters Christine Butler, Carole Hall and Cynthia Butler, her sister Diane Barnhart, two brothers Donald and Virgil Eickhoff and six loving grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Unitarian Church of All Souls at 80th St. and Lexington Ave. at 12 PM on Monday November 21st. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that contributions be sent to the Myrna I. Lewis Minority Students Scholarship Fund, Columbia University School of Social Work, 1255 Amsterdam Ave., Room 629, NY NY 10027. Checks are payable to "The Trustees of Columbia University."

title: China Confirms 3 Cases of Bird Flu in Humans
description: GUANGZHOU, China, Nov. 16 - The Chinese government announced late today that it had confirmed the country's first three cases of bird flu in people, an admission that marked a potentially far-reaching change in how China handles the emergence of new diseases.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BEHRENS, DR. ALFRED F.
description: BEHRENS--Dr. Alfred F. Of Madison, on November 12, 2005. Beloved husband of Valerie Behrens. Loving father of Thomas F. of Los Angeles, CA; Mark H. of Los Angeles, CA and Erik B. of San Diego, CA. Also survived by his mother, Lydia Behrens, and sister, Sylvia Bieri, both of Switzerland. A Memorial Service will be held at Grace Episcopal Church, Madison Ave., Madison, on Wednesday, November 23, 2005 at 11:00 am. All in attendance are invited to join the family for a reception following the service. Those who wish may contribute in his memory to either the "Orthopaedic Residents Fund" Foundation of UMDNJ, Attn: Chris Sickels, 65 Bergen St., Suite 1551, Newark, NJ, 07107 or Habitat for Humanity Newark, Inc., PO Box 3246, Newark, NJ, 07103. For additional information or to leave the family a message of condolence, go to www.bradleyfuneralhomes .com

title: Deal Is Reached on Easing Gaza Crossings
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 15 - Israel and the Palestinian Authority clinched a rare agreement and settled a bitter dispute on Tuesday when they decided to allow Palestinians to travel in and out of the Gaza Strip with relative freedom.

title: Metro Briefs
description: NEW YORK

title: Kerik Is Accused of Abusing Post as City Official
description: New Jersey officials said yesterday that Bernard B. Kerik abused his position as New York City correction commissioner in the late 1990's by accepting tens of thousands of dollars from a construction company that he was helping to pursue business with the city. They say the company has long had ties to organized crime.

title: Techbrief: Chip sales seen rising in 2006
National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Killer Whales Placed On Endangered List
description: Killer whales, which were proposed for threatened status last year, have instead been listed as endangered by the National Marine Fisheries Service. Either listing indicates a risk of extinction and requires that actions by federal agencies not harm the population of the species. The Fisheries Service expects that efforts to increase local salmon stocks will benefit the 89 remaining whales, whose number is up from 79 in 2001 but still lower than the 97 counted in the 1990's. The whales' small population makes them more vulnerable to disease, oil spills, toxic chemicals and declining salmon upon which to feed. Known officially as southern resident killer whales, and often called orcas, they communicate by emitting high-frequency sonar, which is increasingly disrupted by vessel traffic. The whales visit Puget Sound every summer. They can live up to 90 years.

title: Drug Plan Maze: Directions Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Hoot, Man, My Oatcakes Shrank, But There's Something Tasty Inside Them
description: Holiday hosts have lots of canap shortcuts to choose from, like little cups of pastry or phyllo ready to fill and serve. New this year are tiny Scottish oatcakes shaped to hold a filling. They beg for a spiral of smoked salmon or a dollop of smoked trout mousse and have crunch to boot. They are made by Macleans Hebridean Bakery and are $14 for 24 (5.2 ounces). They are available from scottishgourmetusa.com or (877) 814-3663.

title: Lawmakers Berate Amtrak Board Over Firing
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 - Days after Amtrak's board of directors fired the railroad's president, the chairman of the House subcommittee that oversees Amtrak said Tuesday that the board might have acted illegally because it lacked a quorum.

title: Testing the Proposition That Children Know Best
description: The death of the management theorist Peter Drucker last week, at 95, called to mind that at least one subgenre of reality television owes a great deal to his particular brand of organizational thinking.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice's visit to the Middle East misstated the location of her meeting with Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian leader. It was in the West Bank city of Ramallah, not in Israel.

title: Literary Laurels
description: Salman Rushdie, Nick Hornby, AliSmith and Christopher Wilson havebeen named to the shortlist for the2005 Whitbread Novel Award. TheWhitbread awards, for novel, firstnovel, biography, poetry and children'sbook, honor "well-written, enjoyable"books by writers based inBritain and Ireland. Winners will beannounced on Jan. 4; each receives$8,700, and the winner of the book ofthe year, announced on Jan. 24, receives$43,500. Mr. Rushdie was chosenfor "Shalimar the Clown"; Mr.Hornby for "A Long Way Down"; Ms.Smith for "The Accidental" and Mr.Wilson for "The Ballad of Lee Cotton.". . . Jon Stewart, the host of "TheDaily Show With Jon Stewart" onComedy Central, is a winner of the2005 Thurber Prize for American Humor,The Associated Press reported.He was chosen with David Javerbaumand Ben Karlin for their book,"America (The Book): A Citizen'sGuide to Democracy Inaction." TheThurber award, established in 1996,is named for the author, humoristand New Yorker magazine cartoonistJames Thurber, who died in 1961.

title: SNCF to meet unionsbefore threatened strike
China No. 1? Don't hold your breath
As Background Checks Get Big, the Little Guys Get Bigger
description: AS long as employers have wanted to check up on job applicants, an industry of tiny background-checking companies has existed, prowling courthouses to check criminal records and working the phones to verify employment and education.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PARISI, MAYOR JOSEPH C., SR.
description: PARISI--Mayor Joseph C., Sr. (age 79), of Englewood Cliffs, formerly of Guttenberg, died on November 15, 2005. Beloved wife of Lucille (nee Ahrens) and children, Joseph Jr. and his wife Gina, Deborah Ryan and husband Terry, and Laura Bigica and husband Joseph. Beloved grandfather of Carrie Ann and Kristin Ann Ryan, Joseph III and Thomas Parisi, and Sophia Lauren and Biagio Joseph Bigica. Devoted son of the late Dominick and Anna (nee DiPrima) Parisi. Beloved brother of Catherine Benanti and Lucy Hollum and the late Sara Oddo, Josephine Cantelmo and Salvatore. Dear uncle, great uncle and great grand uncle to more than 40 nephews and nieces. Funeral from the A.K. Macagna Funeral Home, 495 Anderson Ave., Cliffside Park, New Jersey, Saturday, November 19, 2005 at 9am, thence to St. Cecilia RC Church, Englewood, where a Funeral Mass will be offered at 10am. Interment at Madonna Cemetery, Ft. Lee. Visiting hours Thursday and Friday, 2-4 and 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Joseph C. Parisi Sr. Charitable Foundation, 540 Sylvan Ave., Englewood Cliffs, NJ 07632.

title: CD's Recalled for Posing Risk to PC's
description: The global music giant Sony BMG yesterday announced plans to recall millions of CD's by at least 20 artists -- from the crooners Celine Dion and Neil Diamond to the country-rock act Van Zant -- because they contain copy restriction software that poses risks to the computers of consumers.

title: 50 Cent and Posse: The Books
description: The MTV/Pocket Books division of Simon & Schuster and the rap star 50 Cent will produce a new line of rap-related fiction called G-Unit Books, which will feature 50 Cent, right, and members of his G-Unit posse. Louise Burke, the publisher of Pocket Books, said the stories would be written by authors recruited by the publisher in collaboration with 50 Cent. They will include fictionalized versions of the experiences of members of the G-Unit, including Lloyd Banks, Tony Yayo, Young Buck and Olivia, as well as the types of stories that 50 Cent told in his recent autobiography, "From Pieces to Weight," which was on the New York Times best-seller list for five weeks. The first G-Unit book, to be written by Nikki Turner, is scheduled to be in stores in 2007.

title: Celebrities Taking a Gamble
description: Correction Appended

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Nov. 5 about Mary Wittenberg, the president and chief executive of the New York Road Runners and the first woman to be director of the New York City Marathon, included erroneous information about Val Ackerman, the former president of the Women's National Basketball Association and current president of USA Basketball. She neither applied for a legal position with the National Hockey League in 1994, nor was approached about it, and she was not rejected for the job.

title: Countdown to the Main Event
description: Today If you want a heritage, organic or fresh turkey and have not ordered one, do so today. Make two shopping lists: List 1: Nonperishable and perishable items that will be used in cooking by Sunday. List 2 : Perishable items to be purchased on Monday.

title: Ignore the Man Behind That Memo
description: Judge Samuel Alito Jr.'s insistence that the Constitution does not protect abortion rights is not the only alarming aspect of a newly released memo he wrote in 1985. That statement strongly suggests that Judge Alito is far outside the legal mainstream and that senators should question him closely about it.
