They should be prepared to reject his nomination to the Supreme Court if he cannot put to rest the serious concerns that the memo, part of a job application, raises about his worthiness to join the court.

title: Finding Information Online From Peers and Professionals
description: Web sites and mental health support groups, many doctors agree, can provide patients with valuable information about treatments for depression, anxiety, attention deficit disorder and other problems. And learning about psychiatric medications from peers, they say, can destigmatize mental illness in a way that no medical authority ever could.

title: A drug critic becomes psychiatry's pariah
Illinois Law Offers Coverage for Uninsured Children
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 15 - Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich signed a measure on Tuesday intended to allow all children in Illinois, including those in working-class and middle-class families, to obtain health insurance.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Oil-For-Food Firing Reversed
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan rescinded the June 1 dismissal of Joseph J. Stephanides, the only United Nations official fired in the oil-for-food scandal, and restored his pay up to his scheduled retirement in September. Mr. Annan acted after a review panel said Mr. Stephanides, a 60-year-old Cypriot, had done nothing wrong. Mr. Annan said that while he now considered dismissal to have been too harsh, he still felt that Mr. Stephanides had violated staff rules by disclosing bidding information related to an oil-for-food contract.

title: New Rules Make It a New Game
description: THE neo-general managers of the iPod generation must be furiously tapping on their computers in an effort to discover a new sabermetric formula to reflect the fangs that baseball placed on its steroid policy yesterday.

title: Soros gets run for his money on donations
Buyback Urged at McDonald's
description: McDonald's should sell two-thirds of the restaurants it owns and borrow almost $15 billion to finance a stock buyback, the managing partner of a hedge fund that owns almost 5 percent of the company said yesterday.

title: Ex-Chad dictator held on killing charges
Germany Accepts Uzbek Official for Care
description: BERLIN, Nov. 15 - European officials confirmed Tuesday that an official from Uzbekistan who had been banned from travel to the 25 countries of the European Union was now in Germany, where he received medical treatment for cancer.

title: Briefs: Bomber kills 3 civilians in a new suicide attack
Lawyer in Judge-Bribing Case Is Charged With a Theft
description: Gary Berenholtz, a Manhattan lawyer whose secret recording of a conversation led to the conviction of a Brooklyn judge for bribery, was arrested yesterday on charges of stealing $63,000 from a former law partner's escrow account.

title: Tyco plans plant closings to bolster its shares
Square Feet; TRANSACTIONS
description: Recent Sales $24 million 447-449 Fulton Street (at Jay Street) and 497-501 Fulton Street (at Bridge Street) Downtown Brooklyn The Laboz family bought these two corner retailing buildings for $12 million each in the Fulton Street Mall. Buyers: Albert, Jason and Jody Laboz (doing business as United American Land L.L.C.) Seller: Emmes Asset Management Broker: Eastern Consolidated

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Nov. 5 about hunting for pheasant on a 17,000-acre ranch in Montana owned by the brothers David and Vergis Aageson misstated the name of the ranch. It is Aageson Grain and Cattle, not the Double AA Ranch.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZUPPARDI, CORA A.
description: ZUPPARDI--Cora A. 89. Born October 1, 1916, Kingston, Jamaica, died November 12, 2005, Canoga Park, CA. Beloved wife of the late Frank Zuppardi. Cora was a generous, caring, self-sacrificing Christian woman. Cora grew up in Jamaica, raised a family in NY, enjoyed senior years in CA. A wonderful sense of humor, she enjoyed cooking, gardening, the beach, cheering the Mets. Loving and devoted mother of Dorothy, Franklin, and Thomas and grandmother of Andrew. Loving sister of Herbert Johnston and aunt of Francy and Sharon. Contact Crawford Mortuary for Services, 8717 Tampa Ave, Northridge, CA. 91324, (818)349-9701.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a television highlight entry yesterday for the Fox series "House" misidentified the actor who portrayed an ailing cyclist. He is Kristoffer Polaha, not Currie Graham.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MENACK, MARTIN I.
description: MENACK--Martin I. Died November 15. Mourners welcome at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Graveside Thursday Nov., 17 1:15 P.M.

title: 'Why Us?' Sunni Arabs Should Ask, 'Why Anyone?'
description: JERUSALEM - We've been so bombarded with news of terrorism lately that we don't even notice anymore when a fundamental line has been crossed. The period of the last few weeks has been one of those times. At the start of the Muslim holy month, Ramadan, a Sunni Muslim suicide bomber walked into a mosque in Hilla, Iraq, and blew himself up in the middle of a funeral. Just after the close of Ramadan, a Sunni Muslim suicide bomber walked into the Radisson SAS Hotel in Amman, Jordan, and blew himself up in the middle of a wedding reception.

title: Kerik Is Accused of Abusing Post as City Official
description: New Jersey officials said yesterday that Bernard B. Kerik abused his position as New York City correction commissioner in the late 1990's by accepting tens of thousands of dollars from a construction company that he was helping to pursue business with the city. They say the company has long had ties to organized crime.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: U.N.'s Rwanda Commander Sees Darfur
description: The Canadian general who headed the United Nations' failed peacekeeping mission in Rwanda in 1994, Romo Dallaire, said the 6,000-member African Union force in Darfur needed to be strengthened to quell the killing there. "They need a stronger mandate with enough resources to implement it," he told Reuters during a visit to Nyala in South Darfur. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the genetics of heart disease in African-Americans referred imprecisely to the drug BiDil. It has been found to increase survival among black patients with advanced heart disease, not to reduce heart attacks.

title: Eternal Question, Not Really Answered
description: IT was a lively and provocative Thanksgiving gathering chez wine panel, where we recently sat down to an early feast and spirited debate over which were the best wines to serve with the bird and its table mates.

title: The Thing She Carried: A Bride's Passport to No Man's Land
description: The small, arid no man's land in which the last third of Eran Riklis's tightly wound film, "The Syrian Bride," unfolds is between checkpoints at the Israeli and Syrian borders. This bleak area is tiny enough to allow people on either side to converse by bullhorn.

title: Drug Plan Maze: Directions Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 1 about families displaced by Hurricane Katrina who had found shelter in New York misstated the name of one of the Louisiana cities to which Sheila Clifton, a refugee from New Orleans, fled before arriving in Queens. It is Donaldsonville, not Donaldsville. An e-mail message from a reader pointing out the error was misdirected at The Times.

title: Small-Town Shops Bulk Up on the Web
description: MANITOWOC, Wis. - ALMOST every significant American economic era is apparent in this neat-as-a-pin city on the western shore of Lake Michigan. Its agrarian heritage is reflected in the farms lying at the city's edge, and a beer-malting plant at the center of town. The maritime and industrial eras are represented by a coal-fired ferry that crosses Lake Michigan, and the steel cranes built here by the 103-year-old Manitowoc Company. The rust belt period, with its manufacturing-job losses and downtown decline, is still felt in slow population growth, modest housing prices and shuttered plants.

title: Low Inflation and Rising Wages Can Coexist, Fed Nominee Says
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 - Ben S. Bernanke, the nominee to succeed Alan Greenspan as chairman of the Federal Reserve, told lawmakers on Tuesday that it was a "false dichotomy" to assume that low inflation was at odds with rising wages and greater income equality.

title: Washington Post's Woodward Talks to Leak Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Bob Woodward, assistant managing editor of The Washington Post, has told Patrick Fitzgerald that he learned the identity of Valerie Wilson from a senior administration official nearly a month before her identity was disclosed, the paper reported.

title: Not Quite Ready for the Big Time?
description: A couple of weeks ago, I reviewed the Olive Symphony, a stereo component that combined a hard drive (to store all the music from your CD collection, wireless and wired networking, iPod compatibility, and more). To sweeten the deal, the company is offering to load all your CD's onto the hard drive ahead of time, for free.

title: U.S. indicts 3 linked to China in spy case
Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: New Historical Society President
description: After an eight-month search, the Brooklyn Historical Society announced yesterday that it had named as its next president Deborah Schwartz, an educator who built her career at the Brooklyn Museum of Art. Ms. Schwartz, the deputy director for education at the Museum of Modern Art, will be the first person in the 142-year history of the Brooklyn group to leave a major cultural institution in Manhattan to assume its presidency. The appointment comes at a financial crossroads for the society, which laid off employees after a renovation of its Brooklyn Heights building exceeded the budget by $9 million and the schedule by nearly three years. In an interview, Ms. Schwartz said she hoped to use oral history projects, documentary techniques and technology to expand the society's range and forge connections with a broad swath of Brooklyn.

title: Tax Increase Is Sought to Bolster Westchester Medical Center
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 15 - The Westchester County executive, Andrew J. Spano, proposed a $1.54 billion budget Tuesday calling for a 4.5 percent property-tax increase that will be used largely to pay for operating costs at the financially troubled Westchester Medical Center.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Water Inspector Sentenced
description: A former employee of the city's Department of Environmental Protection was sentenced to two years of probation for making false entries into a logbook about the cloudiness of city water, Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney, said yesterday. The former employee, Dieter Greenfeld, 64, of the Bronx, pleaded guilty to making the false entries in August, prosecutors said. In a statement, Mr. Garcia said Mr. Greenfeld filed log entries indicating he had tested water samples when he had not performed the tests.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WERNER, FREDERIC P.
description: WERNER--Frederic P., 73. Of Washington, DC; Palm Beach, FL; and West Stockbridge, MA, died November 1. Born in Brooklyn, NY April 17, 1932, son of Eleanor Blatteis Werner and Edward A. Werner. Raised in Great Neck, NY, graduated The Hotchkiss School, Amherst College and Columbia University School of Law. After graduating Columbia Law School, he practiced law in NYC. Moving to West Hartford, CT in 1965, he joined the labor law firm of Segal and Werner as partner. In 1967, he joined Connecticut Bank & Trust Company, where he served as, among other things, Senior Vice President and Senior Counsel of the Legal Department and Private Banking Division until retirement in 1991. He leaves his wife Jacqueline Rosenfeld Werner; three sons Kenneth E. Werner and his wife Rhea, Robert W. Werner and wife Suzanne, and James S. Werner and partner Suzanne Kho; five grandchildren Allison, Katherine (Kit), Emma, James and Nathaniel, and sister, Alice Charwat.

title: Revisiting the History Of the War in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report by The Associated Press in the Sports Briefing column on Friday about an increase in ticket prices at Saratoga Race Course misstated the financial condition of the New York Racing Association. NYRA told the A.P. that if several options to ward off insolvency failed, it would be insolvent by the end of this month, not next fall.

title: Mets Decline Options On Ishii and Heredia
description: The Mets' bullpen next season is not expected to include the left-handers Felix Heredia or Kazuhisa Ishii, whose options were declined yesterday.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,061 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Vodafone Issues a Profit Warning, and Shares Drop
description: LONDON, Nov. 15 - Facing fierce competition in Europe and poor results in Japan, the Vodafone Group warned Tuesday that its profit margins would narrow through early 2007.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ENGELSTEIN, HAROLD
description: ENGELSTEIN--Harold. Age 95, on November 15, 2005 of Surfside, FL., formerly of Far Rockaway, N.Y. Devoted husband of the late Dora Seidman, loving father of Miriam (Rabbi Jeremiah) Wohlberg of Merrick, N.Y., Sandra (Reuben) Maron of Woodmere, N.Y., Marcy (Martin) Hoffman of Hollywood, FL.; proud grandfather of Simeon (Sharon) Wohlberg, Yael (Ephraim) Sobol, Evan (Royce) Maron, Richard (Naomi) Maron, Avery Maron, Dr. James (Heather) Hoffman, Daniel Hoffman, Michael (Lara) Hoffman, Jessica Hoffman. Adoring great grandfather of 16. Also survived by his brother Stanley of NYC. Mr. E. was Founder and President of the Enbee Transparent Co. and NB Jackets which became a division of the Bell and Howell Corp. At his death he was the oldest surviving alumnus of the Yeshiva University High School and a Master Builder of YU. He was a learned, honorable, loyal, loving and remarkable individual. Services 11AM, Wednesday, November 16th, Boulevard Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, N.Y.

title: Euro Disney restructuring shrinks loss
Raising Stakes, Boeing Plans a Larger 747
description: LONDON, Nov. 15 - After a long period of indecision, Boeing announced plans Tuesday for a new, larger generation of its 747 jetliner to do battle with the Airbus A380, the largest passenger jet ever built.

title: Mahler as a Perfect Meeting Place
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra has never quite outlived its reputation as a peacock among orchestras. Luxurious sound, emanating in particular from its string sections, was celebrated and tenderly cared for during the days of Leopold Stokowski and Eugene Ormandy, and it was in good part made possible by an orchestra struggling to be heard at its best in the dead acoustics of the old Academy of Music.

title: FEMA Is Set to Stop Paying Hotel Cost for Storm Victims
description: JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 15 - The Federal Emergency Management Agency moved Tuesday to nudge victims of Hurricane Katrina toward self-sufficiency, announcing that it would cut off financing for most of the 60,000 families in government-paid hotel and motel rooms by the end of this month.

title: N.F.L. Committee Meets to Discuss Saints' Future
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 15 - The last time Tom Benson, the New Orleans Saints' owner, was seen in public, he was shoving a television cameraman after fans heaped verbal abuse on him at a Saints game at Louisiana State.

title: Injured McNabb Likely Out Against the Giants
description: The Philadelphia Eagles, who have struggled lately with quarterback Donovan McNabb in the lineup, will most likely play without him Sunday against the Giants.

title: Young, Assured and Playing Pharmacist to Friends
description: Correction Appended

title: China confirms bird flu in humans
Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice's visit to the Middle East misstated the location of her meeting with Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian leader. It was in the West Bank city of Ramallah, not in Israel. (Go to Article)

title: Noah and His Whole Family, With the Audience, 2 by 2
description: As family entertainment with a religious flavor, "The Ark" may win fans. But as musical theater, it largely fails. This story of Noah and his family's adventures as they wait for the floodwaters to recede is a kind of extended sitcom, with the confined quarters of the ship setting up the familiar suburban scenarios of a meddling mother-in-law and neglected wives.

title: Trekking through Europe's Arctic
Rugby Union:Japan bids hard for World Cup
Waiting for Their Moment in the Worst Place on Earth to Be a Woman
description: You can't get to Bukavu, Congo, from Monrovia, Liberia. Like just about everywhere else in Africa, the two places are separated by dense rain forests, interminable wars and impassable dirt roads that don't go anywhere.

title: Armed Robbers Strike at Brooklyn Post Office
description: Three armed men burst into a post office in Brooklyn early yesterday and surprised the five workers who were sorting the usual piles of mail before the doors opened to the public. The men forced the workers to lie face down on the floor, and one of them escorted the workers' manager to a safe in the back of the building.

title: A Lovely Starter With a Hidden Surprise
description: IN October, when summer's persistence made it seem as though we would never want to wear tweed or eat butternut squash, I had lunch at Perry St., Jean-Georges Vongerichten's new restaurant in the West Village.

title: Technology Lets High-End Hotels Anticipate Guests' Whims
description: When regulars like Dr. Laurence Wiener check into the Mandarin Oriental in Manhattan, they get more than a smile from the concierge and a mint on their pillow. Dr. Wiener's hotel room knows how warm he likes it -- 68 degrees. It welcomes him with a personal message on his television set. It even loads his most frequently dialed numbers onto the phone.

title: The Streetcars Don't Run Here Anymore
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 15 - Bourbon Street, with its show-must-go-on swagger, is back, but another venerable symbol of this city has fallen on harder times. Herded into a terminal a couple of miles from the tourist territories are row after row of streetcars, their metal undercarriages diseased with rust.

title: Busch Was Reckless but Not Intoxicated
description: A preliminary breath test showed the Nascar driver Kurt Busch registered an alcohol level of .017 and was not legally under the influence when he was issued a citation for reckless driving last Friday, two days before a Nextel Cup race at Phoenix International Raceway.

title: Lots of Brass and Sound, and, Sometimes, Silence
description: Shelter is something impermanent: a skin holding the outside, barely, out; an illusion of security. That's the message of "Shelter," an allegorical piece of music theater that opened at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Harvey Theater on Wednesday night. It deals with the manmade and the ephemeral in seven vignettes made poetic by their fusion of image, sound and word.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "We want to know how this was allowed to happen, and how things reached this point."

title: Drug Plan Enrollment Opens Amid Confusion
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 - Medicare beneficiaries around the country began enrolling in prescription drug plans on Tuesday, wading through the complexity of the new program to secure protection against high drug costs.

title: A Compromise of Sorts on Internet Control
description: TUNIS, Wednesday, Nov. 16 - Representatives from the United States and nations that had sought to break up some of its control over the Internet reached an accord on Tuesday night that leaves the supervision of domain names and other technical resources unchanged. They agreed instead to an evolutionary approach to Internet management.

title: Roundup: South Africa wins opener in India
Yellowstone Grizzly May Lose Endangered Status
description: HELENA, Mont., Nov. 15 - The Yellowstone grizzly bear, one of the first and most controversial animals to be protected by the Endangered Species Act, is fully recovered, and it is time to remove the stringent safeguards it has had for three decades, federal officials said Tuesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FUCHSMAN, ERIC
description: FUCHSMAN--Eric, 51. Of Barrington, IL., formerly of New York City, died on November 13, 2005 after a valiant battle against brain cancer. He was a creative force in the world of music, promoting concerts and encouraging performers. He is survived by his wife Laura of Barrington, his mother Vera of Ossining, N.Y., his daughter Alexandra of San Diego, his brother Paul of Newburgh, N.Y. and his inlaw parents Jack and Annette Westheimer of Long Grove, IL. We mourn deeply that a life so excitingly creative and so loving should be cut off so young.

title: Swiss Oil Broker Tries to Seize Russian Art to Collect Debt
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 16 - A Swiss businessman's dogged, 14-year campaign to collect a debt from Russia ensnared, briefly, another unlikely government asset: 54 French paintings from the State Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts in Moscow that had been on display in Switzerland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FASSLER, FRIEDA
description: FASSLER--Frieda. On November 15, 2005, age 101. Beloved wife of the late Max. Devoted mother of Leonard (Bunny), Norman (Rebekah), and mother-inlaw of the late Joan. Loving grandmother of David, Ellen (Paul), Matthew (Mandy), and Rachel. Adoring great grandmother of Joanne and Marc. Dear sister of Rabbi Isaac Teicher. Services today 10 A.M. at "Schwartz BrosJeffer Memorial Chapels", 114-03 Queens Blvd (cor 76th Road), Forest Hills, NY.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Music Producer's Trial To Begin
description: The hip-hop producer and record executive known as Irv Gotti, left, is scheduled to go on trial today in Federal District Court in Brooklyn on charges of money laundering. Mr. Gotti, whose real name is Irving Lorenzo, surrendered in January after federal authorities accused him of concealing more than $1 million in illicit drug profits. His brother, Chris Lorenzo, is also charged in the case. Prosecutors say that Irving Lorenzo, who helped launched the careers of rap stars like Ja Rule, used his record label, Murder Inc., to hide bags of cash given to him by a childhood friend, Kenneth McGriff, who led a Queens drug gang in the 1980's. Alan Feuer (NYT)

title: Drug Plan Maze: Directions Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Denmark: Offer for TDC Is Expected
description: A consortium of five private equity funds will present the Danish telecommunications company TDC with a buyout offer worth about $12 billion today, two executives involved in the negotiations said. TDC's stock has risen 40 percent in the last six months after equity groups expressed interest. The Blackstone Group, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Permira, Apax Partners and Providence Equity Partners have banded together to make the new offer. A second group of private equity funds has also expressed interest in the company. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: A Lobotomy That He Says Didn't Touch His Soul
description: Correction Appended

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Janitor Charged In Identity Theft
description: A janitor who worked at Fort Totten has been charged with stealing the identities of more than 150 Army reservists, some of whom are deployed to the Middle East, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. In a statement, Mr. Brown said the janitor, Edwin Gomez, 35, of Jamaica, had been charged with identity theft, grand larceny and other offenses. Mr. Gomez was scheduled to be arraigned yesterday evening. Mr. Brown said the investigation began after a reservist returned from a tour of duty in Kuwait and reported unauthorized credit card charges to the authorities.

title: Ms. Rice and the Mideast Shuttle
description: Condoleezza Rice has now had her first taste of the Middle Eastern shuttle diplomacy that has drawn in almost every secretary of state since Henry Kissinger. She did a good job, staying up most of the night to extract a sorely needed agreement on moving people and goods in and out of Gaza.

title: Just Say Yes: U.S.O.C. Hires a Maker of Nutritional Supplements and Requires Testing
description: Departing from its traditional just-say-no stance toward nutritional supplement use by athletes, the United States Olympic Committee has taken a new approach: signing up a supplement manufacturer as an official supporter and requiring every batch of its product to be tested for banned performance-enhancing substances.

title: Bush, in Japan, Suggests That China Expand Freedoms
description: KYOTO, Japan, Wednesday, Nov. 16 - President Bush planned to open his tour of Asia on Wednesday with a carefully couched warning to China's leaders, telling them they are finding "that once the door to freedom is opened even a crack, it cannot be closed."

title: Problem: Good Jobs Are Scarce. Solution: Become Your Own Boss.
description: IF there is one place where the idea of the ownership society is taking hold, it is America's colleges and universities. More than 1,600 colleges offer courses in entrepreneurship, up from 1,050 in the early 1990's and a mere 300 schools in the 80's.

title: Drug Plan Maze: Directions Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (Fox) THAT 70'S SHOW -- Yes, that's Bruce Willis above (left) with Ashton Kutcher, and guest-star casting doesn't get any better than this. Kelso (Mr. Kutcher) applies for a job at the Playboy Club in Chicago, and Mr. Willis plays the security chief who decides whether he's up to the job. Viewers who don't know why this is funny may require remedial tabloid-awareness training.

title: Adding Commercial Pizazz to a Chicago Suburb
description: EVANSTON, Ill. - A new mixed-use development rising in the heart of the downtown here -- a close-in suburb of Chicago that is also home to Northwestern University -- is the latest step in this city's decade-long transformation from sleepy college town to major commercial center.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Revisiting the History Of the War in Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Presses Administration for Iraq Plans
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 - The Senate voted on Tuesday to press the Bush administration to provide more public information about the course of the war in Iraq as lawmakers of both parties made it clear they wanted chief responsibility for securing the country shifted to the Iraqi government within the next year.

title: In Germany, a Puzzling Prescription for Economic Health
description: FRANKFURT, Nov. 15 - Germany, saddled with some of the highest taxes and lowest-spending consumers in Europe, has put an improbable measure at the heart of its economic agenda: an increase in the tax on consumption.

title: Dutch activist fatally shot
Paid Notice: Deaths   STEPHENSON, JOHN L.
description: STEPHENSON--John L. The Department of Physiology and Biophysics of WeillCornell Medical College deeply regrets the passing of Dr. John L. Stephenson, Professor Emeritus. John came to Cornell in 1982 following a distinguished career at the National Institutes of Health as Chief of the Section on Theoretical Biophysics within the Heart, Lung and Blood Institute. John pioneered the application of mathematical and computational methods to the study of kidney function and was an internationally recognized authority on renal transport and water excretion. John's theoretical models of kidney function had a profound impact on experimental investigation. We have lost an important scientist and a great friend. The Department and the Cornell community extend their condolences to the Stephenson family.

title: Dodgers Hire G.M.
description: The new general manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers comes from their most hated rivals.

title: Earnings: Home demand lifts profit
Paid Notice: Deaths   REYNOLDS, CONDIE ALLER
description: REYNOLDS -- Condie Aller. On November 13, 2005 in Greenwich, CT. at age 58. Indomitable spirit, unlimited willingness to help out, quick smile, world traveller, adventuresome cook, knowledgeable gardener, exquisite dresser, enthusiastic dancer, tough love mother, insatiable wife. Survived by husband Wallace Reynolds, daughter Victoria, son Andrew, sister Sally Marti, brother Howard Aller, and mother Juliet Aller. Memorial services 11:30 A.M. Saturday November 19, 2005 at Round Hill Community Church, 395 Round Hill Road, Greenwich, CT. Contributions may be made to The Kent School, Kent, CT or Memorial Sloan-Kettering.

title: Soviet Leftovers, Where Statecraft Is Stagecraft
description: BAKU, Azerbaijan, Nov. 12 - Two years ago, when the government of Georgia collapsed during street protests against a tainted election, its fall energized pockets of revolutionary sentiment against the autocratic rulers who dominate the former Soviet Union. Then Ukraine fell amid similar outrage. And then Kyrgyzstan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JORDAN, JOSEPHINE C.
description: JORDAN--Josephine C. On November 13, 2005. We mourn the loss of an energetic, independent and life-affirming woman. Daughter of the late Hortense and Joseph Straus. Talented long-time executive with Clothiers Corporation. Devoted member of Temple Emanu-El, member of Opera Index. She is and will be deeply missed by her friends. Memorial Services Wednesday 2PM at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Ave. at 65th Street. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Congregation Temple Emanu-El of New York.

title: The Turkey That Stopped in Haiti on Its Way to Dinner
description: RAFAEL MATEO is a man of many flavors. By day he is a teacher, with a flock of seventh and eighth graders in East Harlem, and by night a devoted cook and wine lover who is planning to open his own cafe and wine bar. He is also a writer, working on a book of recipes and lore inspired by his Haitian and Dominican heritage. That is, when he's not on the mat: he is a serious martial artist with black belts in judo, Kokushi-ryu jujitsu, Tomiki aikido and karate.

title: Celebrating California Cheese And 65 Years
description: As part of its 65th anniversary celebration, Murray's Cheese in Greenwich Village and at Grand Central is selling a package of eight California cheeses in half-pound portions for $26.99. The box includes Cowgirl Creamery's triple-cream, soft-ripened Mt. Tam; Original Blue from the Point Reyes Farmstead Cheese Company; Bellwether Farms's raw-milk Carmody Reserve; Vella Cheese Company's Dry Monterey Jack; Fiscalini Farm's bandage-wrapped Cheddar; Marin French Cheese Company's washed-rind Schlosskranz; Bravo Farms's Cheddary Silver Mountain; and Three Sisters Farmstead Cheese's mildly tangy Serenita. Through Nov. 30. Also at murrayscheese.com. FOOD STUFF

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAWN, GILBERT S.
description: SHAWN--Gilbert S. On November 12, 2005 at the age of 84. Beloved husband of the late Melba Rae, loving father to Eric and Lisa, adoring grandfather to Oliver. A man of courage, valor and deep family commitment, he will be sorely missed. Services to be announced.

description: Top prizes went to Lee Ann Womack, Keith Urban, Gretchen Wilson and Brooks & Dunn at Tuesday's Country Music Awards at Madison Square Garden.

description: Old-fashioned custom shirt making is catching on with a small but growing fraternity of men who want it their way.

description: Style Reporter Eric Wilson visits this year's Country Music Awards at Madison Square Garden to see just how 'New York' country can dress.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Landlord Charged With Endangerment
description: An Astoria landlord has been charged with illegally subdividing a six-family house and renting it to as many as 17 families, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said yesterday. The landlord, Cesar Robles, 37, of 48th Street, was charged with first-degree reckless endangerment, Mr. Brown said in a statement. Marla A. Grossman, Mr. Robles's lawyer, said that his client maintained his innocence.

title: EU Parliament toughens laws on chemicals
Celebrity:A novel way to reach beyond fame
Good Care (Rich Version)
description: To the Editor:

title: Former Curator in Courtroom as Her Trial Begins in Rome
description: ROME, Nov. 16 - Ending a bit of suspense, Marion True, the former antiquities curator at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles, showed up Wednesday for the opening of her trial here on charges of conspiring to import illegally excavated antiquities for the museum.

title: A 1,200-Year-Old Murder Mystery in Guatemala
description: Archaeologists and forensic experts in Guatemala have made a grisly discovery among the ruins of an ancient Maya city, Cancun.

title: No One Ever Saw a Germ Floss, So Why Give It a Toothbrush?
description: For the microbe-phobic, VIOlight offers a toothbrush sanitizer that slams bacteria with ultraviolet light. "Food gets caught in toothbrushes, and particles break down," said Joel Pinsky, the founder and chief executive of VIOlight, in Elmsford, N.Y., which makes a four-brush plug-in sanitizer and a new travel version, below.

title: Sri Lankans vote in election
A Conscripted Soldier's Tale From the Heart of Darkness
description: Beasts of No Nation By Uzodinma Iweala 142 pages. HarperCollins Publishers. $16.95.

title: A Straight-Up Approach to Better Fitness
description: WHEN Jacqueline Thousand saw the photographs that her trainer had taken, something clicked. "I saw this little old lady slouched over, looking 70," she said. "I'm 55, a very young 55." But Dr. Thousand, a professor of education at California State University, San Marcos, said: "I had molded myself through the way I stand and move into a person who slouches."

title: New Dispute in Technology for Next Generation of DVD's
description: The battle for who will control the standards for the next generation of DVD's became more tangled yesterday when the Blu-ray Disc group said that it would not adopt technology requested by one of its leading members, the Hewlett-Packard Company.

title: From Flatbush, Chants of 'Ger-ma-ny, Ger-ma-ny'
description: "ONCE in a lifetime," Damian Snagg said. "You only see this once."

title: It Happened Here First
description: Inverness, Calif. - HE is the Albus Dumbledore of green architecture. Long before the Prius hit the road and sustainability became the buzzword du jour, there was Sim Van der Ryn, now 70, the intrepid pioneer of the eco-frontier.

title: In Germany, Instant Dorm Rooms That Double As Billboards
description: One of the latest prefab houses to hit the European market is a nine-foot aluminum cube, small enough to fit on a trailer. Seven were installed on Nov. 3 as student housing, top, in the Schwabing neighborhood of Munich. The prefabs look like 21st-century Japanese teahouses with overlapping areas for showering, cooking, dining and television watching, and elements that flip down and slide out. After the table, above, disappears under drawers, cushioned seats, right, can be used for sleeping. A second bed drops down from a compartment on an upper wall.

title: INSIDE
description: Congress Tumbles 2 Alaskan 'Bridges to Nowhere' Congressional Republicans decided to kill two projects in remote areas of Alaska that had become known as "bridges to nowhere" and threatened their party's reputation for fiscal austerity.

title: From SongBook to iSongBook With a Docking Station (iPod Not Included)
description: Tivoli Audio's SongBook portable radio, released earlier this year, echoed the iPod's styling. Now it has added a model that's a working partner, not just a visual match. A flip-down panel at the side of the new iSongBook holds a docking station that connects with any iPod but the Shuffle.

title: At the Mideast Table, Making a Difference
description: To the Editor:

title: Consumer Prices Slowed in October, but Energy Costs Stir Inflation Fears
description: The consumer inflation rate dropped significantly in October and touched its lowest level since June as surging gasoline prices fell from their peak in September, the government reported yesterday.

title: Judge Alito and the Abortion Memo
description: To the Editor:

title: Bid for Retrial Cites Claim That Judge Had Affair
description: A Queens man in prison for murder has filed a motion for a new trial, based on accusations that the judge unfairly helped Queens prosecutors and had an affair with one of them, which tainted his judgment.

title: Sex Ed for the Stroller Set
description: THIS September 3-year-old Halley Vollmar of Bellmore, N.Y., was having her annual checkup when her pediatrician paused. "I'm going to check your peepee now," he warned, and tugged down her underwear. But Halley protested. "Mommy, why he call my vagina a peepee?" she scolded, telling the startled physician he was a "silly doctor" before allowing him to proceed.

title: Bloomberg Puts More Muscle Into Rebuilding
description: Putting power and influence where his campaign pronouncements had been, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday named four top members of his administration and two executives to the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation board, ensuring a larger role for City Hall in rebuilding the World Trade Center site.

title: 'Goodnight Moon,' Smokeless Version
description: In the great green room, there is a telephone, and a red balloon, but no ashtray. "Goodnight Moon," the children's classic by Margaret Wise Brown, has gone smoke free.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 10 P.M. (Sundance) ICONOCLASTS -- Samuel L. Jackson wants to know more about the basketball great Bill Russell (above left, with Mr. Jackson). So they go out to dinner, play a little golf and talk about sports careers ("Winning is necessary to get to play"), race and the joys of being a "genuine, certified old person," as Mr. Russell, 71, describes himself. This is the first of six shows in which celebrities interview celebrities they particularly admire. The big finish, on Dec. 22, will be Robert Redford talking with Paul Newman.

title: Accord on Sharing Flu Vaccine Production
description: Correction Appended

title: EU to set up blacklist of airlines
Bridge; Never Trump a Partner's Ace? Never Say Never
description: The Fall North American Bridge Championships begin this afternoon in the Adam's Mark hotel in Denver and run through Nov. 27. The premier event is the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams, the defending champions being Nick Nickell, Dick Freeman, Bob Hamman, Paul Soloway, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell. Full details can be found at www.acbl.org.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: 3 Hurt In Blaze At Vacant House
description: A fire in a vacant two-story house in Jamaica injured three men yesterday afternoon before firefighters could pull them to safety, fire officials said. The odor of smoke drifted into the quarters of Engine Company 298 about 4 p.m., and firefighters on the second floor saw the house at 153-14 88th Avenue ablaze. When firefighters arrived there, they found two men unconscious in the house, and lowered a third man down a ladder from the second floor. The three were taken to Mary Immaculate Hospital, where the two unconscious men, both in their 40's, were listed in serious condition and the third, whose condition was not known, was treated, said Seth Andrews, a department spokesman. The cause of the fire was under investigation last night, Mr. Andrews said. The owner of the house, who gave his name as Munir, said that it was unoccupied, and that the men inside were squatters. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Home Audit Can Pinpoint Energy Lapses
description: Pelham, N.Y. - MY house, a 1922 colonial with plaster walls, a gas boiler and 34 windows, looks from the outside like a solid citizen with thrifty ways. But step a little closer and you will find unexplained drafts, a chilly kitchen and winter heating bills that have gone as high as $450 a month. With a household budget so tight it squeaks and the cost of gas expected to climb 40 percent, I decided it was time to bring in an expert.

title: Murtha Calls for a 'Change in Direction'
description: REP. MURTHA: I just spoke to the Democratic Caucus and told them my feelings about the war. And I started out by saying the war in Iraq is not going as advertised. It's a flawed policy wrapped in illusion. The American public is way ahead of the members of Congress.

title: The Gift of Books, a Bounty to Be Savored
description: To the Editor:

title: Back in Town, a Singer Picks Up Right Where She Left Off
description: In the mid-90's, Dominique Eade was near the top of the list of the new jazz singers. Her voice was rich and clear and strong in all ranges; she had musicianship and cool intelligence and didn't seem to be ahistorical, or to have arrived at jazz by accident.

title: Kansas City Will Stage Super Bowl, With One If
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 16 - In a move that surprised even the Chiefs, the National Football League awarded a Super Bowl to Kansas City on Wednesday. The decision was contingent on significant improvements being made to Arrowhead Stadium, including the addition of a rolling roof.

title: India lures more upmarket outsourcing
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Harsher Penalties For Unruly Fans
description: Sports fans who throw things or spit at athletes or otherwise attempt to disrupt a sporting event could face up to a year in jail and be fined as much as $25,000 under legislation that was passed yesterday by the City Council. The law, which was approved in a 48-to-0 vote, has been supported by the New York Mets and other representatives of Major League Baseball and professional tennis. "If you throw stuff at a player, we are going to throw you in jail," said Councilman Peter F. Vallone Jr. of Queens, who proposed the legislation. Aides to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said that he was expected to sign the bill into law. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DREYFUS, FERNANDE
description: DREYFUS - Fernande. Of Teaneck, NJ on November 16, 2005. Beloved wife of Jack. Devoted mother of Karen Borghard and Steven Dreyfus. Dear sister of Norbert Richter. Loving grandmother of Erica, Alexander, Rachel, David Borghard and Ashley and Nina Dreyfus. Service 9:30 AM, Gutterman-Musicant, Hackensack, NJ. For information call 800-522-0588.

title: Israel Moving Toward Early Elections
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 17 - Israel appeared headed for early parliamentary elections in late February or March after two leading politicians discussed the issue today with Prime Minister Ariel Sharon.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Michigan: Rosa Parks's Will Is Contested
description: A nephew of Rosa Parks filed a petition in Wayne County Probate Court last week requesting that he be appointed personal representative for Mrs. Parks's estate over two people appointed in her will. William McCauley, 47, of Detroit, one of Mrs. Parks's 13 nephews and nieces, plans to argue that Mrs. Parks was not mentally competent and was "under undue influence" from her caretaker when she signed the will in 2003, said Keith Findling, Mr. McCauley's lawyer. In her will, Mrs. Parks appointed two longtime friends, Elaine Steele and Adam Shakoor, to manage her estate. Jon Gandelot, a lawyer representing the estate, said Mrs. Parks had indicated she wanted Ms. Steele as a personal representative since at least 1998 and had not changed her will since 2000 or 2001 when she added Mr. Shakoor.

title: Atlanta Looks to Sum Itself Up in Just Six Words
description: WHEN slogans for cities work, they really work. There's the world-famous "I Love New York," which dates back to 1977, and Las Vegas's more recent: "What Happens Here, Stays Here."

title: Italy arrests three Algerians suspected of terror links
World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Quebec's Separatist Party Picks New Leader
description: Andr Boisclair easily won the leadership race to head the separatist Parti Qubcois and immediately declared his hopes to push for an independent Quebec as quickly as possible. He became the first openly gay man to lead a major political party in Canada. Mr. Boisclair, 39, who had faced revelations of cocaine use, is expected to lead the party in the next election, probably in 2007 or 2008, against the current Liberal premier, Jean Charest, who has a 70 percent disapproval rating. If he becomes premier, Mr. Boisclair has promised to hold a third referendum for independence soon after. Federalist forces won the last such referendum, in 1995, by a slim margin.

title: Strike by Graduate Students at N.Y.U. Enters Its Second Week
description: As a strike by graduate student teaching and research assistants at New York University entered its second week yesterday, the frustrations of students, strikers, professors and parents were rising. But many on campus seemed to be settling in for a prolonged strike.

title: Customers Get a Lift At a Store With Wheels
description: Wired magazine will open a temporary "pop up" store tomorrow in SoHo, specializing in what its publisher, Drew Schutte, calls geek chic. Items include a remote-control toy called Jumpin' Banana Shocking Tanks ($50), above left, and the Tassimo TA 1400 hot-beverage maker ($169.99), above right. Half the products are made by companies that advertise in the magazine, Mr. Schutte said.

title: Arts, Briefly; CBS Thrives On Country Airs
description: Though its ratings were down compared with previous years, the "39th Annual C.M.A. Awards," in which Lee Ann Womack was the big winner, gave CBS an easy victory in Tuesday night's Nielsen estimates. CBS is usually No. 1 in total viewers on Tuesdays with its regular schedule, and just as often, NBC comes first among adults 18 to 49. But the Country Music Association awards ceremony, which drew 17.64 million viewers from 8 to 11 p.m., delivered that age group for CBS. NBC's "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit" (15.6 million) did manage to win the 10 p.m. hour among 18-to-49-year-olds, but the rest of the night belonged to CBS. Also notable on this Tuesday of sweeps was that ABC's "Commander in Chief" (12.46 million) drew its lowest ratings of the season. And on "The Gilmore Girls" on WB, Rory (Alexis Bledel) finally re-enrolled at Yale, moved out of her grandparents' house and made up with Lorelai (Lauren Graham). An audience of 6.06 million wept with relief.

title: China Approves a Selective Cancer Drug
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GIBSON, JOSHUA, M.D.
description: GIBSON--Joshua, M.D. Members of the Division of Infectious Diseases and the Samuel Bronfman Department of Medicine at The Mount Sinai School of Medicine mourn the sudden death of their beloved colleague and friend, Joshua Gibson. He was also a son, a brother, a husband and a member of the Mount Sinai family. Prior to entering the Infectious Diseases Fellowship, Joshua completed his internal medicine training at Mount Sinai Hospital, obtained his medical degree from Yale University School of Medicine and his undergraduate degree from Bowdoin College. Joshua was a wonderful and compassionate physician and a tireless patient advocate. In addition to his numerous local as well as international efforts on behalf of those in need, he cofounded the Advancing Idealism in Medicine Curriculum at Mount Sinai to facilitate medical resident involvement in programs worldwide focussed on improving the plight of others. Although he will be sorely missed his legacy will continue through the continued good works of the Mount Sinai trainees. Mary E. Klotman, M.D. Chief, Division of Infectious Diseases, Mount Sinai School of Medicine

title: Flickr Zen
description: And now, your moment of visual Zen: a visually fascinating poster generated from "squared circle" images harvested from the Flickr photo-sharing Web site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MENACK, MARTIN I.
description: MENACK--Martin I. Died November 15. Mourners welcome at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Graveside Thursday Nov., 17 1:15 P.M.

title: Immigrants in Italy: At home, but still apart
Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 7 about Afghan criticisms of the American reconstruction effort in Afghanistan misspelled the name of one firm and incorrectly described its former status. The firm is BearingPoint, not Bearing Point, and it was the former consulting unit of KPMG LLP, and was not formerly KPMG Peat Marwick.

title: Swiss Businessman Tries to Seize Art in a Dispute With Russia
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 16 - A Swiss businessman's dogged, 14-year campaign to collect a debt from Russia has ensnared, briefly, 54 paintings from the Pushkin State Museum of Fine Arts of Moscow that had been on display in Switzerland.

title: Corrections
description: A Calendar listing on Sunday in the Connecticut Weekly referred incorrectly to an event this Saturday at the Pequot Library in Southport. The performance by the pianist Vassilis Varvaresos is a benefit for the Free Young Persons' Concerts and outreach programs for Music for Youth, and tickets cost $10 and $20 for students and $25 and $50 for adults. It is not a free concert for children.

title: High Drama via Beethoven and Bartok
description: Superb string quartets are plentiful at the moment. But even so, the performance that the Parker String Quartet gave on Tuesday evening at Weill Recital Hall set the group apart as something extraordinary.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Web Sites Give Away Shopping Secrets As the Internet Flexes Its Retailing Muscle Highlighting the way the Internet is shifting power in the retail sales industry to consumers from companies, several Web sites are disclosing what, in years past, were closely guarded secrets: Promotional strategies that the nation's major retailers were planning for the day after Thanksgiving, one of the biggest shopping days of the year. [Page A1]

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Terror Suspect To Be Extradited To U.S.
description: Home Secretary Charles Clarke, Britain's top law enforcement official, ordered the extradition of Babar Ahmad, a British citizen, to the United States, where he is accused of running Web sites to raise money for terrorism in Afghanistan and Chechnya. He would be sent under new laws that remove the requirement that some countries, including the United States, provide evidence. Relatives said they would appeal to the High Court.

title: Ralph Edwards, TV Pioneer, Dies at 92
description: Ralph Edwards, the broadcast pioneer who was the creator and M.C. of two of the most popular shows in entertainment history, "Truth or Consequences" and "This Is Your Life," died yesterday at his home in West Hollywood, Calif. He was 92.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about the ballet star Fernando Bujones misstated the precedent for an American's winning the gold medal at the International Ballet Competition in Varna, Bulgaria. Eva Evdokimova, an American citizen born in Geneva, was the first, in 1970. Mr. Bujones, in 1974, became the first American male dancer to win the gold medal, not the first American.

title: An Accidental Living in Luggage and Other Wares
description: SUNDAYS are still flea market days for the Fennick brothers, even after two decades in the antiques business. With their tousled Beatles haircuts and gleaming stacks of vintage luggage -- Vuitton and Goyard are specialties -- the twins and their wares make a spiffy landmark in the roiling sea of vendors at the Hell's Kitchen Flea Market, on West 39th Street between 9th and 10th Avenues.

title: Prosecutors Seek More of DeLay's Records
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 - Texas prosecutors in the criminal case against Representative Tom DeLay issued a subpoena on Wednesday for records of transactions between his national political action committee and a political committee run by his successor as House majority leader, Roy Blunt of Missouri.

title: House Leaders Are Dealt a Rare Defeat on Spending Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 - House Republican leaders were dealt a rare defeat today as Democrats and about two dozen Republicans teamed up to kill a $142 billion health and education spending bill.

description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Alito and the Abortion Memo (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Timetable for Mr. Bush
description: No matter how the White House chooses to spin it, the United States Senate cast a vote of no confidence this week on the war in Iraq. And about time.

title: News Analysis:Many claim victory over global Web pact
QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "If you have an election right now, it is going to be some of the people voting on behalf of all the people."
