description: Page Numbers In Microsoft Word

title: New York and Dallas
description: HOLIDAY shopping is not yet in full swing but Greene Street in SoHo is bustling with activity following last week's opening of two stores and the expansion of another.

title: Mexican Court Says Sex Attack by a Husband Is Still a Rape
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 16 - The Supreme Court of Mexico ruled Wednesday that rape within marriage is a crime, bringing Mexico's laws into line with much of the world and removing one of the many obstacles women here face in reporting rape.

title: Kazaa head to face grilling on assets
What Iris Wore: A Style Original
description: HERV PIERRE BRAILLARD is no fashion evangelist, but the other day Mr. Braillard, the self-effacing designer behind the Carolina Herrera label, was uncustomarily effusive. "Everyone is going to be talking about this," he predicted, this being "Rara Avis: Selections from the Iris Barrel Apfel Collection," the exhibition at the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: World Briefing: Americas, United Nations, Europe
description: AMERICAS

title: Mahler as a Perfect Meeting Place for the Somber and the Lavish
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra has never quite outlived its reputation as a peacock among orchestras. Luxurious sound, emanating in particular from its string sections, was celebrated and tenderly cared for during the days of Leopold Stokowski and Eugene Ormandy, and it was in good part made possible by an orchestra struggling to be heard at its best in the dead acoustics of the old Academy of Music.

title: Recipe for a Camcorder: One Part Toy, One Part Technology
description: Consider the recipe for a successful children's camcorder.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: In the Middle of a Mess
description: They were the league's overachieving band of slick shooters last season, and despite their impending future as free agents, they bonded to reach the Western Conference semifinals. But after an off-season of thrift and departures, the Seattle SuperSonics have become a cautionary tale of how everything can go from breaking just right to breaking apart.

title: Ex-Chief of Hollinger Is Indicted on Fraud Charges
description: A federal grand jury indicted Conrad M. Black, the prominent and flashy media entrepreneur, on eight counts of mail and wire fraud today along with three of his deputies, the United States Attorney for Chicago, Patrick Fitzgerald, said.

title: Arts, Briefly; Shortlist's Cloudy Future
description: The Shortlist Music Prize may be short-lived. The future of the prize, created in 2001 to honor left-of-center acts that had not yet achieved mainstream commercial success, is in doubt amid squabbling between its two creators. Tom Sarig, below, a talent manager who is one co-founders, says there will be no Shortlist contest or award program this year. Instead, he is creating the New Pantheon, which, like the Shorty, will be given to the best album of the year that has sold fewer than 500,000 copies, as decided by a diverse panel of musicians, actors and journalists. Mr. Sarig said he and the Shortlist's other founder, Greg Spotts, had a parting of ways that arose from being "people at different places in their lives." Mr. Spotts declined to comment yesterday, but said previously that he had planned to stage the Shortlist this year before the dispute. He added that he considered the New Pantheon to be competition to the Shortlist, and may take legal action. Winners of the Shortlist have included TV on the Radio, Damien Rice, N.E.R.D. and Sigur Ros.

title: The Set-Top Sage Knows All, Sees All
description: Most people don't give the set-top boxes on their televisions a second thought. After all, for years, the boxes did little more than decode the encrypted TV programs the cable provider sends.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BAKER, JACK
description: BAKER--Jack, Nov. 17, 1994 Remembering you with love and affection. Miss you. Paula, Beau and Bobby

title: Preston Robert Tisch, Co-Owner of the Giants, Dies at 79
description: Correction Appended

title: Seating Alternatives
description: Q. I have a small dining room but I like to have lots of guests. How should I handle the crowd?

title: On The Street: Then
description: IN the late 1980's dedicated fashion followers took the notion of uniform dressing to heart, turning themselves out, almost identically, in a high-end variation on an officer's jacket from Chanel. Polished up with brass buttons that marched in twin rows down its front, this snappy Karl Lagerfeld design sometimes came with a collar and bellows pockets and could be personalized, as the wearer saw fit, with a strand of pearls, a bow-shaped brooch, a turtleneck sweater or, most reliably, a pair of shades.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column yesterday about a guilty plea by a New York City correction officer in the theft of a drawing from Rikers Island was published in error. The plea by the officer, Timothy Pina, was actually entered last year, not recently (and was reported in The Times on Aug. 31, 2004). Because of an editing error, the article also misspelled the given name of the artist. He is Salvador Dal, not Salvatore.

title: Builder's Lawyer Says Kerik Had to Know Cost
description: A day after New Jersey officials said that Bernard B. Kerik had tried to help a mob-connected company while it paid for renovations to his apartment, a lawyer for the builder who did the work said Mr. Kerik should have known the labor and materials he received were worth tens of thousands of dollars more than he paid.

title: Suicide Bomber Kills Two Afghans
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Nov. 16 - A suicide bomber rammed a taxi filled with explosives into an American military convoy near the southern city of Kandahar on Wednesday, killing two Afghan bystanders and wounding four others in the blast, Afghan officials said.

title: Skin Deep; Dentists Frown At Overuse Of Whiteners
description: KEVIN ROSS, a psychologist in Queens, is a serial tooth whitener. He started out seven years ago with custom-fitted bleaching trays, the kind dentists sell. When his teeth became sensitive, he switched to over-the-counter whitening strips, which use less bleach. These were gentler, but not as effective. So earlier this year Mr. Ross upgraded to professional-strength whitening strips dispensed by his dentist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOLOMON, HORACE H.
description: SOLOMON--Horace H. On November 16, 2005, after a long struggle with cancer. Thank you L.S./M.F.T. Born on February 11, 1929 in New York, he was the son of Lillian (Rubin) and Nat L. Solomon of New York, Englewood, NJ and Palm Beach, FL. Loving husband of Anita Grossman Solomon, author and quilter; father of devoted children John of Glendale, CA and Thomas of Los Angeles; brother of the late Muriel Ribner; loving cousin of many Taplinger and Solomon family members. Horace was educated at the Englewood School for Boys, graduating in 1946 and Yale College, Class of 1950. He joined Solo Products Corporation where he remained for 25 years, eventually serving as President and Director of various associated companies, including the family charitable foundation. Known throughout his life for his superb taste and keen sensibilities, he cofounded the Holly Solomon Gallery in Soho in 1975. In 1985, Horace joined The Brooklyn Museum as the Vice Director in charge of development. In 1988, he founded the Arts Video News Service, a subscription-based monthly video service featuring critical reviews, interviews, and up-to-date information on work featured in galleries and museums primarily in the New York area. He retired in 1992. He was a member of the Harmonie Club, the Metropolis Country Club and the City Athletic Club. Services will take place at Congregation Emanu-El, 5th Ave. at 65th St. on Friday at 10 a.m. Internment follows at Temple Israel Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY.

title: Private livesin public
www.thewebisours.usa
description: The Internet conference starting Wednesday in Tunisia was preceded by bitter conflict. Countries across the globe wanted the US to give up control over the Internet. That didn't happen, but the issue is not likely to disappear.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Russia: Happy Birthday, Maya

title: Bob Mackie Is Selling a Share of His Excess
description: CAROL BURNETT made her Broadway debut as Princess Winnifred in "Once Upon a Mattress" in 1959 and starred in a television version in 1972, wearing the fanciful ball gowns of Bob Mackie. In December she will star in a new version of the fairy tale on ABC, this time as the princess's mother, Queen Aggravain, in costumes Mr. Mackie describes as a cross between Joan Collins and the drag artist Lypsinka.

title: How to Make a Disc New When It's Already Old
description: How do you follow a hit album? A number of stars (and, presumably, their record companies) have discovered a surprisingly simple answer: tweak it, and release it again.

title: Rail Link to Benefit From Unused 9/11 Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 - The Senate is set to approve a measure that would allow New York officials to use $2 billion in unused Sept. 11 aid to build a rail link connecting the World Trade Center site to the Long Island Rail Road and Kennedy International Airport, Congressional officials said on Wednesday.

title: Two Women Are Attacked in Carjacking Attempts
description: In a brief but destructive spree in Jamaica yesterday morning, a man stabbed a teacher in the leg and stole her car, then crashed it and began pummeling a second woman, the police said. He was subdued by a security officer and arrested, they said.

title: Battered by Decades of War, Sri Lankans Vote for President
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Nov. 17 - Battered by more than two decades of war, Sri Lankans went to the polls today to vote for president. The two front-runners could not have offered them two more starkly different roadmaps for peace and prosperity.

title: Send In Theaters, Not Clowns, West Side Planners Are Told
description: Correction Appended

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Parliament Extends State Of Emergency
description: The Senate extended a national state of emergency by three months to give the police the means to keep a lid on the violence that swept the country this month. The lower house of Parliament had earlier approved the extension, which goes into effect on Monday. It allows local governments to call curfews and give the police additional investigative powers. Meanwhile, the number of cars burned and other incidents of unrest continued to subside.

title: FEMA Broke Its Promise on Housing, Houston Mayor Says
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 16 - Mayor Bill White of Houston accused the Federal Emergency Management Agency on Wednesday of breaking its promise to Hurricane Katrina evacuees by imposing strict limits on a housing relocation program as it stops thousands of hotel subsidies.

title: Cheney Says Senate War Critics Make 'Reprehensible Charges'
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 - Vice President Dick Cheney joined the White House attack on critics of the Iraq war Wednesday night when he told a conservative group that senators who had suggested that the Bush administration manipulated prewar intelligence were making "one of the most dishonest and reprehensible charges ever aired in this city."

title: $100 laptops unveiled at UN summit
Saving Cornish: But Stop. Isn't That Spelled With a K?
description: CAMBORNE, England - No one knows for sure who the last native speaker of Cornish was, although some point to Dolly Pentreath, a resident of the village of Mousehole who died in 1777, apocryphally uttering the Cornish phrase for "I don't want to speak English."

title: Iran Has Resumed Reprocessing Uranium, Diplomat Says
description: BERLIN, November 17 - Iran has resumed reprocessing uranium at a nuclear station it maintains in Isfahan despite European requests that it abstain from such activities pending a new round of negotiations, according to a diplomat close to the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna.

title: Google Stock Hits $400
description: Google became a verb before it became a public company. Now it has also become a $400 stock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TISCH, PRESTON ROBERT
description: TISCH--Preston Robert. 79. Died peacefully at his home in NYC on November 15th. Survived by Joan Tisch, wife of 57 years, son Steven and his wife Jamie, daughter Laurie, and son Jonathan; grandchildren, Emily, Hilary, Carolyn, William, Charles, Henry, Elizabeth, Holden, and Zachary. Brother of the late Laurence Tisch and his wife, Billie, and uncle, relative, friend and colleague to many. Cofounder and Chairman of the Board of Loews Corporation and Chairman & Co-CEO of the New York Football Giants. Dedicated to his country, state and city, Bob generously gave both his time and resources, serving in countless leadership positions, including: Postmaster General of the United States, founding Director of Citymeals-onWheels, founder and Chairman of Take the Field, Chairman of the New York City Convention & Visitors Bureau, founding Chairman of the New York City Convention and Exhibition Center Corporation, Chairman of the NYC Partnership, Inc. and the NY Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Chairman of NYC Public Private Initiatives, Inc., and trustee of New York University. Funeral services will be private for family. The family will be receiving condolences on Thursday, November 17, and Sunday, November 20, from 5 to 9 PM. A memorial service will be held on Friday, December 9, 2005, at 11 AM, at Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Preston Robert Tisch Brain Tumor Research Center at Duke University, Citymeals - on Wheels, or the Preston Robert Tisch Center for Hospitality, Tourism, and Sports Management at New York University.

title: At the Mideast Table, Making a Difference
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOSSARD, SANDER ''SAM''
description: GOSSARD -- Sander "Sam". The Jazz at Lincoln Center family mourns the loss of Sander "Sam" Gossard, project director from 2000-2004 for the creation of Frederick P. Rose Hall. At a crucial time in the facilities development, Sam dedicated his extraordinary energy and talent to building this new home for jazz. We extend our condolences to Pamela, his children and the entire Gossard family.

title: Council Bill Eases Restriction on Union Political Donations
description: The City Council pushed through a bill yesterday that would allow labor unions to greatly increase their donations to political candidates, the most significant loosening of contribution limits since the city's campaign finance program was established in 1988.

title: 2 Editors, Successful at Penguin, to Start a Book Division at Doubleday
description: The founding editors and co-publishers of Riverhead Books, the Penguin Group imprint that in recent years brought to bookstores hugely successful works like "The Kite Runner" and the journals of Kurt Cobain, announced yesterday they would leave Penguin later this month to start a new division of the Doubleday Broadway Publishing Group of Random House Inc.

title: Iraqi Rift Grows AfterDiscovery of Prison
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 16 - As Iraqi investigators began searching through a secret underground prison run by the police in the capital, Sunni Arab leaders furiously denounced the Shiite-led government on Wednesday, saying it supported the torture of Sunni detainees there and calling for an international inquiry.

title: Regulators Approve 2 Exchanges' Deals
description: Antitrust regulators said yesterday that they had approved two separate acquisitions, one by the New York Stock Exchange and the other by Nasdaq.

title: Shy Also Pulls Your Ears
description: Shy Also Pulls Your Ears

title: For Sake's Sweet Sake
description: OVER the years my husband has tinkered with many exotic drinks. We survived his zombie phase, the summer of mangrove smashes and what I now think of as a dark period he devoted entirely to mixing the ingredients of a Manhattan in unnatural proportions.

title: Los Angeles Times to Cut 85 Jobs in Newsroom
description: The Los Angeles Times said yesterday that it planned to cut jobs throughout the newspaper, including about 85 of its 1,032 newsroom jobs.

title: What Palestinians?
description: The swallows fly to Capistrano; I go to the Middle East.

title: Despite Slow Start to Season, Thomas Likes What He Sees
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 16 - Unbowed by an 0-5 start, by trade rumors surrounding his star player and by daily speculation about imminent turmoil, Isiah Thomas stopped by to survey his team Wednesday and declared he was "very proud and very pleased at the ways the guys are playing."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DI MAGGIO, CHARLES J.
description: Di MAGGIO--Charles J. On November 16, 2005 of Port Washington, NY. Beloved husband of Maryann. Cherished father of Dean and Barbara Di Maggio and Celeste and Gregg Schneider. Loving grandfather of Sydney, Caroline, Cole and Ryan. In repose at the Fairfield Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Boulavard, Manhasset, Thursday 7-9PM and Friday 2-4 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass 9:30AM, Saturday at St. Peter of Alcantara RC Church Pt. Washington. Interment Private.

title: Special Education Ruling's Effects Unclear
description: It may take years to assess fully the impact of the Supreme Court ruling on Monday on disputes between school districts and the parents of special education students, experts across the country have said.

title: Group Seeks Further Inquiry in Frist's Stock Sales
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 - A consumer advocacy group called Wednesday for the Securities and Exchange Commission to expand its inquiry into the stock trades of Senator Bill Frist, the Republican leader, saying it had uncovered "questionable transactions lucrative to Frist family members."

title: Inelegant, Ineffective and in the Way
description: DING-DONG, the fortress of Broadway is gone!

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Tuesday, about the effect of the reckless driving citation against the racecar driver Kurt Busch on liquor advertising within Nascar, misstated the result of his field sobriety breath test in Arizona. His alcohol level was below the state limit for legal intoxication; he did not fail the test.

title:
Curbs on Insurance for 
Military Are Urged
description: In a report to be released today, the Government Accountability Office strongly urges Congress to act to protect military personnel from the deceptive sales practices and unsuitable investments and insurance policies that the report says have been a disturbing fact of military life.

title: Tennis:Gonzlez makes his trip pay off
Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Tuesday about the making of a movie at the Metropolitan Opera House misspelled part of the title of an opera by Offenbach that was played, on a recording, during filming. It is "Tales of Hoffmann," not Hoffman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REYNOLDS, CONDIE ALLER
description: REYNOLDS -- Condie Aller. On November 13, 2005 in Greenwich, CT. at age 58. Indomitable spirit, unlimited willingness to help out, quick smile, world traveller, adventuresome cook, knowledgeable gardener, exquisite dresser, enthusiastic dancer, tough love mother, insatiable wife. Survived by husband Wallace Reynolds, daughter Victoria, son Andrew, sister Sally Marti, brother Howard Aller, and mother Juliet Aller. Memorial services 11:30 A.M. Saturday November 19, 2005 at Round Hill Community Church, 395 Round Hill Road, Greenwich, CT. Contributions may be made to The Kent School, Kent, CT or Memorial Sloan-Kettering.

title: One-Stop Furniture Shopping
description: BY no accident, most of the furniture Jan Blythe has bought over the past three years has come from one store, Bassett Furniture Direct, near her home in Charlotte, N.C. Unlike the old-fashioned, often family-owned stores that sell many brands of sofas and tables, the Bassett store sells just one brand: Bassett's own.

title: Judge Alito and the Abortion Memo
description: To the Editor:

title: Ferry Business Is Suffering Even as New Terminals Open
description: A visitor to any of the grand new ferry terminals in and around Manhattan might conclude that the region has a thriving commuter-ferry business. That assumption would be mostly false.

title: The Pen Gets a Whole Lot Mightier
description: THE holiday season may be a time for love, hope and all that jazz. But let's face it: for millions of Americans, a big part of it is getting new toys.

title: A Blend of Childlike Wonder, Formality and Eroticism
description: Ohad Naharin is 53 now, and long since established as Israel's leading choreographer. But he's been through a lot lately, and his new piece, "Mamootot," in its spare, reserved, sexual and literally touching way, reflects all that.

title: Illuminating twist in the politics of art
Assad of Syria: No more Mr. Nice Guy
VNU Expected to Drop Deal For $6.4 Billion Acquisition
description: VNU, the Dutch publishing and market research company, is expected today to abandon its $6.4 billion deal to acquire IMS Health after a shareholder revolt, according to executives involved in the talks.

title: A Recording Studio That You Can Easily Hold in Your Hand
description: These days, practically any audio device with a button -- from cellphones to MP3 players -- seems to record sound. But miniaturization often takes its toll on quality.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Beaten After Car Accident
description: A man was beaten and critically injured yesterday after his vehicle struck another man's car at the corner of 65th Street and Third Avenue in Bay Ridge. The accident occurred shortly before 1 a.m., the police said. After the collision, both men got out of their vehicles and began arguing, and one of them, Jonathan Goody, 25, struck the other man in the head with a blunt object, the police said. The victim, whose name was not released, was taken to Lutheran Medical Center in critical condition, and Mr. Goody was arrested and charged with assault, the police said. Michael Wilson (NYT)

title: The Perpetual Student
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   QUIGLEY, LEONARD V.
description: QUIGLEY--Leonard V., 72. Died peacefully at home in Forest Hills Gardens on November 15, surrounded by his family. Born in Kansas City, Missouri, Len graduated from Holy Cross and Harvard Law School, and served in the Navy in the Korean War. A partner for over 35 years at the law firm of Paul, Weiss, where he founded the Canadian practice group, Len served for over 25 years as the General Counsel of the Archaeological Institute of America (AIA), and was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations and the Board of Directors of the Covenant House. Survived by Lynn, his wife of 41 years; four children, Matthew, Cannon, Daniel and Megan; 8 grandchildren; a sister, Rosemary McPhillips, and an extraordinarily close extended family. Predeceased by his brothers, Bernard and James, and four faithful German Shepherds, Major, Alberta, Petra and Sparta. Visiting hours Wednesday and Thursday evenings from 6:30-9 PM at Fox Funeral Home in Forest Hills and Mass of Christian Burial at Our Lady of Mercy Church in Forest Hills Friday at 10:30 AM. In lieu of flowers, donations to the AIA or the Covenant House of New York.

title: Banned Egyptian Group Gains Parliament Seats in Runoff Vote
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, Nov. 16 - Egypt's largest Islamic opposition group, the Muslim Brotherhood, has doubled the number of seats its members will hold in Parliament, the state-run Middle East News Agency and members of the group said Wednesday, based on preliminary reports of vote totals from a runoff election on Tuesday.

title: HBO Takes the ABC Sunday Challenge
description: Chris Albrecht, the chairman of HBO, does not buy the widely heard argument that something has undermined his channel's former hold on viewers on Sunday nights at 9, something in the form of an ABC show called "Desperate Housewives."

title: Amman Bombs Churned Local Emotions
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 16 - By every measure, it would seem that Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia and its leader, Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, should be roundly vilified in Jordan after having taken responsibility for sending suicide bombers into three hotels here last week, killing 58 people and injuring many others.

title: Survey Shows a Revival of Isolationism in U.S.
description: Shaken by the Iraq war and the rise of anti-American sentiment around the world, Americans are turning inward, according to a Pew survey of United States opinion leaders and the general public.

title: Shopping on Internet spurned by Chinese
A Star With Multiple Roles Now Faces Questions of Conflict Among Them
description: For 30 years, Bob Woodward has reigned as a one-man investigative reporting franchise from his base at The Washington Post. With the blessing of Post management, he has juggled his roles as star reporter, assistant managing editor and best-selling author, managing to keep those roles from colliding.

title: Longtime Manager Plans to Leave Wenner
description: The general manager of Wenner Media, Kent Brownridge, is retiring after 31 years.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 1 about the many victims of the Oct. 8 Kashmir earthquake who remained untreated misspelled the surname of an Egyptian-American emergency room doctor who was in the region helping victims. He is Ali Shehata, not Shehada.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDMAN, STEVEN M.
description: FRIEDMAN--Steven M. on November 15, 2005. Survived by his loving wife Jennifer Simpson, his mother Edith Friedman, sisters Janice and Laura, niece Shana and a nephew Matthew, mother-inlaw Arlene, sister-in-law Jill and brother-in-law Michael. Grew up in Scarsdale, NY, attended Edgemont High School and Northwestern University. Vikings fan, avid golfer, Senior Vice President of Production, Atlas Media Corp. Began his career at Michael Krauss Productions. Service Friday, 11:45 AM at The Riverside, 76 St & Amsterdam Ave.

title: Turning Back the Clock to the Days of Crotchless Pants and a Deceased Rabbit
description: For seven hours, on seven consecutive nights ending Tuesday, the grand, malleable space of the Guggenheim Museum felt like a church, a penitent's cell, an armed camp, a sanctuary, a lecture theater, a downtown performance studio, a tiered opera house or a carnival. It all depended on what the Yugoslav-born performance artist Marina Abramovic was up to.

title: Ice Dancer Is Closer to Citizenship and Turin
description: Virtually every time Tanith Belbin and Ben Agosto compete in ice dancing, the question arises: Will Belbin become a United States citizen in time for the Olympics in Turin, Italy, in February?

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Boeing Labor Contract
description: The Boeing Company, the aircraft maker, reached a tentative agreement yesterday on a contract with engineers, keeping its 787 program on schedule and avoiding a strike.

title: Switzerland and Spain also in
Metro Briefs
description: NEW YORK

title: Series of War Stories Wins Book Award
description: "Europe Central," a sprawling series of 37 intertwined stories by William T. Vollmann that examine the moral decisions of characters, some real and some fictional, in Germany and the Soviet Union during World War II, won the National Book Award for fiction on Wednesday night.

title: Sharing Name but Little Else
description: Sharing Name but Little Else

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a Canadian government proposal to cut taxes in preparation for an election campaign misidentified one of the opposition parties that are demanding an early federal election. It was the Bloc Qubcois, and not its provincial ally, the Parti Qubcois.

title: Too Few Good Men
description: THIS month, the Iraqi Ministry of Defense encouraged former officers in Saddam Hussein's army to apply for commissions in the country's new army. Much has been made of this initiative, which is sensible and welcome at a time when Sunni cooperation is crucial to Iraq's stability. But contrary to news reports, the announcement does not mark a policy change.

title: M.T.A. Expands Its Surplus Estimate for the Third Time This Year, to $1.04 Billion
description: In February, it was $76 million. In July, it ballooned to $833 million. Yesterday, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced its third -- and, it hopes, final -- estimate for the size of its surplus this year: $1.044 billion.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: U.S. Arrests Top Drug Officer On Drug Charges
description: The country's chief drug enforcement investigator, Adn Castillo, and two of his aides were arrested in Virginia on charges of conspiring to smuggle tens of thousands of pounds of United States-bound cocaine through Guatemala, officials of the United States Drug Enforcement Administration said. The three had been indicted by a federal grand jury in Washington a day earlier. The drug agency has been warning that Guatemala has become the transit point for at least 75 percent of the drugs that reach the United States and that high-level members of the military and national police were linked to the trade. In Guatemala City, Interior Minister Carlos Vielmann said that the government had cooperated fully with the arrests and had even helped organize the trip that sent the drug agents to Washington. The agents, he said, were told they were going to attend a law enforcement seminar.

title: American Faces Charge of Graft for Work in Iraq
description: In what is expected to be the first of a series of criminal charges against officials and contractors overseeing the rebuilding of Iraq, an American has been charged with paying hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes and kickbacks to American occupation authorities and their spouses to obtain construction contracts, according to a complaint unsealed late yesterday.

title: New Orleans VoteNear, but Who Will Go?
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 15 - Were things different, Mayor C. Ray Nagin would be barnstorming for another term these days through Gentilly and Lakeview and the Lower Ninth Ward, neighborhoods that instead form an archipelago of desolation.

title: Torre Goes Headhunting, With Giles in Mind
description: If a free agent gets a phone call from Joe Torre, he knows the Yankees are serious. Torre, the Yankees' manager, has made successful recruiting pitches to Mike Mussina, Jason Giambi and Carl Pavano in recent years, and now he is calling Brian Giles.

title: Dreams, Compromise and a Talking Box
description: "Who could bear to see war right in your own living room?" asks the pioneering young heroine of "The Ruby Sunrise" as she argues in an Indiana barn in 1927 for the social benefits of television. The question lingers in the air during the course of Rinne Groff's period drama about the country's growing pains during the early years of television, promising a payoff that doesn't quite arrive.

title: Blinding Justice
description: In recent years, DNA testing has shown that innocent people can be convicted of serious crimes, and even end up on death row. The main legal mechanism for saving wrongly convicted prisoners from execution, and for challenging other wrongful convictions, is the writ of habeas corpus. Although habeas traces to Magna Carta and is enshrined in the Constitution, Congress may be about to scale it back drastically. The proposed changes would make the criminal justice system less fair and far more likely to convict the innocent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBINSON, BARCLAY, JR.
description: ROBINSON--Barclay, Jr. of Stonington, CT and Castine, ME, on November 14, 2005. Survived by wife Katharine, sister Betsy Taylor, son Timothy and daughter-in-law Merritt, daughters Elizabeth and Anne, son-in-law Michael, grandchildren Harrison, Maxwell, Luke, and numerous nieces and nephews. Born November 28, 1934 in Hartford, CT, grew up in Avon, CT. Graduated from Pomfret School, Yale College, and Yale Law School. Served in the Navy, and spent entire professional career at Robinson & Cole in Hartford. Member of Pomfret School Board of Trustees, also a Trustee of Ethel Walker School in Simsbury, Stonington Free Library, McManus Trust of Hartford, and Southeastern Connecticut Council on Foreign Relations. He was an avid railroader, photographer, marathoner, bicycler, kayaker, sailor, and joketeller. Funeral services 1PM, Sunday, November 20th at United Church, Main St., Stonington. Information: Dinoto Funeral Home, Mystic, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations to Stonington Free Library, PO Box 232, Stonington, CT 06378.

title: Arts, Briefly; Cultural Grants For the Gulf Coast
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities has awarded the first set of emergency grants in a program to provide about $1 million to recover and preserve Gulf Coast-region cultural resources that suffered hurricane damage. The grants, totaling $565,000, will go to 19 institutions, including the New Orleans Museum of Art, below, for packing supplies and conservation for about 30,000 items being relocated from the museum's flooded storage building; the Ohr-O'Keefe Museum of Art in Biloxi, Miss., to recover, clean and conserve ceramic art and other items; and the Old Capitol Museum of Mississippi History in Jackson, Miss., to conserve paintings and other items damaged after Hurricane Katrina tore away part of the museum's roof.

title: China's Hu recommits to efforts on NKorea
Arts, Briefly; Pop Charts: Chesney Bookends the Year at No. 1
description: After weeks of slow record sales, the country star Kenny Chesney's new album, "The Road and the Radio" (BNA), charged to the top of the Billboard chart this week with 470,000 copies sold, according to Nielsen SoundScan. The album is Mr. Chesney's fourth to reach No. 1, and his second in 2005, after "Be as You Are: Songs From an Old Blue Chair" in February. The soundtrack to the new 50 Cent biopic, "Get Rich or Die Tryin' " (G-Unit/Interscope), opened at No. 2 with 317,000 sales, and the 20th installment of the evergreen pop compilation series "Now That's What I Call Music!" dropped to No. 3 in its second week. Neil Diamond's "12 Songs" (Columbia) opened with 93,000 sales at No. 4, Mr. Diamond's highest chart position since "The Jazz Singer" in 1980.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Nov. 7 about Afghan criticisms of the American reconstruction effort in Afghanistan misspelled the name of one firm and incorrectly described its former status. The firm is BearingPoint, not Bearing Point, and it was the former consulting unit of KPMG LLP, and was not formerly KPMG Peat Marwick. (Go to Article)

title: At the Mideast Table, Making a Difference
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran to Reopen Case in Death Of Journalist
description: TEHRAN, Nov. 16 - An Iranian appeals court ordered Wednesday that the case of an Iranian-Canadian journalist who was killed while she was in custody in 2003 be reopened, after pressure from Canada and her family's lawyers.

title: Indonesia television airs terror warning
A Virtual Environment for Shedding Pounds
description: As the holidays approach, many brace for leaner wallets. Jacqueline Wicks, president of a Web site called PEERtrainer, offers advice about another holiday aftermath: fuller waistlines.

title: Cameron for Nady Looks Like Done Deal
description: It was just another sun-splashed August afternoon in San Diego, when the Mets' Mike Cameron ambled into the visitor's clubhouse at Petco Park and, to no one in particular, said jokingly, "What was I thinking?"

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENBERG, HAROLD JAY
description: GREENBERG--Harold Jay. Beloved husband of the late Jeannette. Devoted father of Arlene and Andrew Linder, Joel and Leslie Greenberg, and Phyllis Greenberg. Loving grandfather of Jonathan, David, Dana, and Adam. Dear brother of Florence and Leon Tempkin. Adored patriarch; respected industrialist; honored humanitarian and community leader. His zest for life, keen sense of humor, and cheerful disposition touched so many. Services today at 1pm at Boulevard Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett. Contributions may be made to United Cerebral Palsy of Nassau, 380 Washington Avenue, Roosevelt, NY 11575.

title: The Trackball Returns. Is Rubik's Cube Next?
description: Video game veterans have long pined for the return of an 80's classic: the spinning trackball. This heavy cue ball embedded into arcade machines controlled classics like Centipede and Marble Madness. Solid and not prone to the skips and jumps of computer mice, arcade trackballs offered a different kind of tactile control.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Dominican Arraigned In Drug Case
description: A former lieutenant colonel in the national police of the Dominican Republic, who was arrested last year in possession of a 3,000-pound shipment of cocaine destined for the United States, was extradited yesterday and arraigned in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Prosecutors said that the former officer, Lidio Arturo Nin Terrero, was wearing his police uniform when he was arrested on Dec. 18, 2004, in the Dominican Republic, driving a pickup truck with the cocaine in cardboard boxes in the rear. Another accused trafficker, Tirso Cuevas Nin, was also extradited and arraigned. The two men were indicted with 15 others as part of a Dominican ring that shipped South American cocaine to the United States through Haiti and Puerto Rico. Both men pleaded not guilty. Julia Preston (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Parliament Approves New Constitution
description: The Senate gave final legislative approval to bitterly contested changes in the Constitution that would cede more power over policing, health care and education to Italy's 20 regions. They would also alter the structure of Parliament and grant far more powers to the prime minister. But the measure must still pass a national referendum next year -- a hurdle many political experts say will be difficult for such sweeping and contentious changes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARROLL, HELEN S.
description: CARROLL--Helen S., 76. Of Jackson Heights, NY died on November 12, 2005. An Artist and Teacher, she was born Helen Catherine Schrader in Huron, S.D. She attended Augustana College in Sioux Falls, S.D. and received her MA at NYU in New York City. She taught Art for 26 years at the Newtown High School in Queens. She was the widow of Robert E. Carroll of Providence, RI. Mrs. Carroll is survived by her sister, Mrs. Cecil Ane Borri of Metuchen, N.J. and by nieces, nephews. A memorial service is planned for a later date.

title: Sunnis Tell of Abuses in Iraqi-Run Detention Sites
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 16 - In the wake of the discovery of a secret detention center in a former bomb shelter here, where prisoners were alleged to have been starved and tortured, four Sunni Arabs have given accounts of abuse in several other detention centers run by Iraqi commandos.

title: Hevesi to Open More Books of State's Public Authorities
description: ALBANY, Nov. 16 - Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi announced new draft regulations on Wednesday that would crack open the books of the state's sprawling public authorities.

title: 5 Marines Dead and 11 Hurt in an Ambush by Insurgents
description: UBAYDI, Iraq, Nov. 16 - Five marines were killed and 11 wounded Wednesday in an ambush at a farmhouse while hunting for insurgents on the outskirts of this rural town, Marine officials said. It was the deadliest day for the Marines since beginning an aggressive sweep along the Euphrates River near the Syrian border early this month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, MURRAY
description: SHAPIRO--Murray, 80. Died November 14 in New York. Structural engineer, designer of over 150 major high rise office buildings in NY. Beloved husband of Florence Morrison Shapiro. Father of Alan and Fred. Grandfather of Andy and Jamie. Services 11:30 Friday, Riverside Memorial, Amsterdam & 76th.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GARATE, JORGE
description: GARATE--Jorge. On November 15, after a long illness. Beloved brother of Silvia, and cherished life partner of Paul Stumpf. An exceptional man who will be missed by all who knew him. Also survived by mother, Gregoria of Peru; brother Oscar and sister Lucia of Peru; sisters Marta and Betty of Canada. Viewing on Friday, November 18, from 69PM, at Joseph V. McGrath Funeral Home, 91-20 37th Avenue, Jackson Heights.

title: U.S. and Seoul Share a Goal but Not a Strategy on North Korea
description: KYONGJU, South Korea, Thursday, Nov. 17 - President Bush and President Roh Moo Hyun of South Korea tried Thursday to reconcile their differing approaches to dealing with North Korea, with Mr. Roh repeating his vow that a nuclear armed North would "not be tolerated," even while defending his efforts to take a softer approach toward the country.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Tuesday about Alex Rodriguez of the Yankees being named the most valuable player in the American League referred incorrectly to his home run total in some copies. His 48 home runs led the American League, not the major leagues.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City Takes Title To High Line
description: CSX, the railroad that held the title to the High Line, the elevated rail viaduct that stretches through Chelsea, transferred it to the city this month, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said in a statement yesterday. The transfer allows the city to continue its plan to transform the abandoned line into a public recreation space. Work is to begin in 2006 and is expected to be completed in 2008. The High Line, which was built between 1929 and 1934, stretches 22 blocks, from 34th Street to Gansevoort Street, and offers 6.7 acres of space atop an elevated rail deck. The site has been abandoned since 1980. In 1999, some neighborhood residents formed Friends of the High Line to save it from demolition and to transform it into a public space. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Series of War Stories Wins Book Award
description: "Europe Central," a sprawling series of 37 intertwined stories by William T. Vollmann that examine the moral decisions of characters, some real and some fictional, in Germany and the Soviet Union during World War II, won the National Book Award for fiction on Wednesday night.

title: Vietnam Archive Casts a Shadow Across Decades
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 - White House advisers convene secret sessions about the political dangers of revelations that American troops committed atrocities in the war zone, and about whether the president can delicately intervene in the investigation. In the face of an increasingly unpopular war, they wonder at the impact on support at home. The best way out of the war, they agree, is to prop up a new government that they hope can unite the fractured foreign land.

title: An irresistible but dark 'Harry Potter'
Folding Tables so Artful, They Can Hang on the Wall
description: Leonhard Pfeifer, an Australian designer currently working in London, is known for coming up with big ideas for small spaces, and his latest piece, a low table that folds flat so that it can hang like a picture, turns the concept into an art form. "The dynamic curves of stainless steel contrast with the warmth of the timber to create a work with strong sculptural elements that could hang in any gallery," Mr. Pfeifer said. He makes the table, 14 inches high and 18 inches wide, in oak or walnut, and in two lengths: 36 inches and 59 inches. The smaller one can double as a tray for breakfast in bed. The tables are $800 and $1,075 from 2JANE Co. in Tampa, Fla., (813) 832-5263.

title: The New Wearing of the Green
description: GOING green is not a new phenomenon in the outdoor-apparel industry. But until recently exercisers who wanted environmentally friendly clothes found only a handful of companies selling organic cotton and fleece made of recycled soda bottles.

title: Japan gets a 2nd chance at global phone market
With Loss of Tisch, a Sad Year Gets Sadder
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 16 - At 10:25 on Wednesday morning, two stadium workers lowered the American flags in front of the Giants' offices to half-staff in memory of Preston Robert Tisch, the team's co-owner who died a day earlier of an inoperable brain tumor at age 79. It was a solemn moment witnessed by only a handful of people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAHLER, HILDA R.
description: MAHLER--Hilda R. Beloved and cherished wife of Bernard. Mother of Edith, Howard and Susan. Grandmother of Zachary. Funeral service today at 12:00 noon, Schwartz Brothers - Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Blvd. at 76th Road, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Shop-Till-You-Drop Specials, Revealed Here First
description: For retailers, the day after Thanksgiving is a painstakingly orchestrated affair.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AMOS, REV. JAMES G
description: AMOS -- Rev. James G. passed away on Saturday, November 12, 2005 at The Aultman Woodlawn Nursing Home in Canton, OH. He was 82. He was the beloved Pastor of The Gustavus Adolphus Lutheran Church for the last 421/2 years in Gramercy Park, in New York City. He also served as Pastor for The Our Savior Lutheran Church in Toledo, OH, and The Frederick Lutheran Church in St. Thomas. Pastor Amos was born in Massillon, OH on July 23, 1923. He was the son of the late Philip and Lily Graham Amos. In addition to his parents, he was preceded by his wife, the former Joan Demetral and two brothers, Wilson and Maurice Amos. He was the loving godfather of Mindy and Bradford Chin. Surviving are one sister and brother-in-law, Gloria and Richard Buxser, of Canton, OH, two sisters-in-law, Elaine Amos, of Brewster, OH, and Delores Amos, of Mississippi, ten nieces and nephews, and numerous great nieces and nephews. Viewing will be at Gustavus Adolphus Lutheran Church, 155 East 22nd Street, at Third Avenue in Manhattan on Friday, November 18th, 2005 between the hours of 2 to 4 P.M. and 6 to 9 P.M. Viewing on Saturday, November 19, 2005 from 5-7 P.M. with Memorial Services following at 7 P.M. On Tuesday November 22, 2005, there will be a Memorial Service at The First Evangelical Lutheran Church, in Beach City, OH at 11 A.M. Interment will be at South Lawn Cemetery in Beach City, OH following the service. Contributions in his memory may be made to: The Pastor James and Joan Amos Scholarship Fund at Gustavus Adolphus Lutheran Church, 155 East 22nd Street, New York, New York 10010, 212-674-0739.

title: In Brown vs. Jackson, Bryant Rules Again
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 16 - Larry Brown paced at one end of the court, frenetically moving in rhythm with his emotions. Phil Jackson sat at the other end, arms at his side, stoic at times to the point of disinterest.

title: Woven of Wool That Reaches Like a Lifeline to Afghanistan
description: Organizers of the Connoisseur's Antiques Fair, running today through Sunday at the Gramercy Park Armory (Lexington Avenue at 26th Street), are donating space there for a sale of rugs woven by women in rural Afghanistan. The weavers are represented by Arzu, a nonprofit organization in Chicago; in addition to their wages, they and their families benefit from the profits, which Arzu says help with education and health care. The rugs are made in traditional patterns and in many colors and sizes, from 3 feet by 5 to 10 by 14 ($900 to $20,000). They can also be ordered from arzurugs.org or (312) 280-0354.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Citing of Polygamy as a Cause of French Riots Causes Uproar
description: PARIS, Nov. 17 - In the search for explanations for the riots that have rocked France, some politicians and intellectuals are pointing to a novel one: polygamy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROTHWAX, VIVIAN
description: ROTHWAX--Vivian. On November 14. Graveside services will be held at Lakeside Memorial Park, Miami, FL. on November 18 at 11:15 A.M. For information contact her cousin Albert Binder.

title: Arts, Briefly; $40.6 Million Gift to Music School
description: Indiana University said yesterday that its 1,600-student school of music had received a $40.6 million gift from the family of David H. Jacobs, left, a shopping-mall magnate and onetime co-owner of the Cleveland Indians, and called it the largest gift to a public university conservatory and the largest ever to the university itself. The institution, considered a leading conservatory in the United States, will be renamed the Jacobs School of Music. The donation will help finance graduate-school fellowships, undergraduate scholarships and endowed faculty chairs, the university said. Mr. Jacobs, who died in 1992, and his wife, Barbara, attended the university; their son, David Jacobs Jr., attended the music school. The smaller Yale School of Music earlier this month announced an anonymous $100 million pledge that it said would be used, partly, to eliminate tuition.

title: American Ingenuity, Irish Residence
description: The newest expatriates aren't people. They're ideas, and we can't afford to watch them go. The Wall Street Journal reported last week that Microsoft had trimmed more than $500 million from its annual tax bill by putting a small subsidiary in Dublin in charge of $16 billion in assets. The game is simple: a company sends intellectual property to a tax-haven country like Ireland and keeps the tax difference on the money it earns.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Maneuver on Exchange Bid
description: Macquarie Bank, the Australian company pondering a bid for the London Stock Exchange, is tapping an unexpected source for information to help make that decision. The bank, based in Sydney, has recently spoken with Werner G. Seifert, former chief of Deutsche Brse, to get his views on the London Stock Exchange, say several executives involved in the deliberations. Mr. Seifert was ousted from his job in May after a failed bid for the London exchange that shareholders said was too expensive. He would not be actively involved in any bid, nor would he take any management position if Macquarie does secure a deal, said one executive briefed on the Macquarie management's thinking. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: China not a threat, Hu tells Koreans
Paid Notice: Deaths   SILBERLING, DIANE
description: SILBERLING--Diane. The faculty and staff of the Charles C. Harris Skin and Cancer Unit, Department of Dermatology, NYU School of Medicine record with sadness the death of Diane Silberling. Diane served our department loyally for over 30 years working with our past three Chairmen. Her caring and enthusiasm are missed. We extend our sympathy to her entire family. Nicholas A. Soter, MD Interim-Chair NYU Department of Dermatology

title: Letters: The Mideast shuttle
Paid Notice: Deaths   RENERT, SIDNEY
description: RENERT--Sidney. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the father of our member, Deborah Renert. May her entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Ari Berman, Rabbi Joseph S. Kaplan, President Paulette Papilsky, Sisterhood

title: Judge Grants Northwest Airlines $446 Million a Year in Pay Cuts
description: Northwest Airlines won permission from a bankruptcy judge yesterday to cut temporarily the pay of some of its union workers by $446 million a year as part of a plan to reduce annual costs by $1.4 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAZARUS, MARGARET
description: LAZARUS--Margaret. It is with profound sorrow that the Officers, Board of Governors, members and staff of Fresh Meadow Country Club record the passing of our longtime member, Margaret Lazarus, wife of our late President, J. Louis Lazarus. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her entire family. Attilio Petrocelli, Pres. Robert D. Lang, Sec'y

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RITZ, NORTON, M.D.
description: RITZ--Norton, M.D. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center was saddened to learn of the death of Dr. Norton Ritz in early November. Dr. Ritz was a physician in the Division of Hematology in the Department of Medicine for over 40 years. He was involved with the Hematology Residency Program and was an outstanding teacher. He was well-respected by his peers and will be sorely missed by all. We extend sincere condolences to his entire family. Ira Mayer, M.D., President Warren Wexelman, M.D. President-Elect Steven Farber, M.D. Secretary/Treasurer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERLMAN, IRVING B.
description: PERLMAN--Irving B., 87. Passed away November 16, 2005 at his home in Floral Park, N.Y. Beloved husband of Ruth, father and father-inlaw of Marjorie and Stephen Shoenholz, grandfather of Jeffrey and Ellyn Guttman and Amy Guttman. Former owner of M. Perlman, Inc. Office Supplies of New York City. Services 10AM, Friday, November 18 at "RiversideNassau North Chapels", 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York. Interment at Union Fields Cemetery, Queens, N.Y.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Copper Sales Planned
description: China will sell $80 million of copper from inventories next week amid speculation the government is seeking to drive down prices and limit losses from an investment by one of its traders. The State Reserve Bureau in Beijing will auction 20,000 tons of copper on Nov. 24, the country's top economic planning agency said yesterday. The bureau sold 20,000 tons yesterday. Copper rose to a record $4,174 a metric ton in London on Tuesday, taking its gain this year to about 32 percent, and the price fell to $4,140 yesterday. "The inference must be that they face huge losses" as a result of the trades, said Angus MacMillan, an analyst at Bache Financial in London. China has sold more than $240 million of copper this month to ease a domestic shortage. China is the world's largest copper consumer.

title: Queens Man Is Chased Into Coffee Shop and Shot to Death
description: A 47-year-old Queens man was shot to death inside a coffee shop in front of several people early yesterday after being chased for at least a block by the gunman, the police and several witnesses said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEEHAN, MIRIAM F.
description: MEEHAN--Miriam F. The Trustees of Freedom Institute are deeply saddened by the death of Miriam F. Meehan. We are profoundly grateful to her and her entire family for their loyal and generous support since the Institute's inception. She was a friend in every way. She will be sorely missed. Nancy I. Stahl, Board Chair Connie B. Murray, Executive Director

title: China Confirms Its First 3 Cases Of Bird Flu Infecting People
description: GUANGZHOU, China, Nov. 16 - The Chinese government announced late Wednesday that it had confirmed the country's first three cases of bird flu in people, an admission that marked a potentially farreaching change in how China handles the emergence of new diseases.

title: A spark for Mideast peace
New Jersey Child Caseworker Charged in $25,000 Fraud
description: A caseworker with the embattled New Jersey Division of Youth and Family Services was indicted yesterday on charges of cheating the agency out of about $25,000 by charging for day care services and furniture that were never provided to the children they were meant for.

description: For retailers, the day after Thanksgiving is a painstakingly orchestrated affair.

title: General Rejects Any Call for Timetable for Withdrawal of Troops
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 16 - A day after the Senate voted down a Democratic proposal to require the Bush administration to project dates for a phased withdrawal of American troops, the general commanding 30,000 troops in Baghdad spoke out forcefully on Wednesday against a withdrawal schedule.

title: Judge Alito and the Abortion Memo
description: To the Editor:

title: Collar From Column A, Cuffs From Column B
description: IF ever a grown man wants to feel like a kid in a candy store, he need only head over to the nearest dress shirt department. In the last few years, courtesy of fashion houses like Etro, Paul Smith, Richard James and Thomas Pink, the blah blue or white shirt was born anew in sherbet-colored sport stripes, gingham checks, subtle florals and pastel shades of pink and lavender. With French cuffs, two- or three-button collars and prices upward of $275, the modern dress shirt has done as much to kindle men's interest in style as the entire run of "Queer Eye for the Straight Guy."

title: Benefits of the bacterium in breast milk
Ex-Student Says Prep School Hid Years of Abuse by Coach
description: Officials at a Brooklyn prep school covered up decades of sexual abuse of students by a coach, a man suing the school charged in court papers made public yesterday after arguments before a judge.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the approval of proposals dealing with lay workers by the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops misstated the percentage of lay ministers who are women. It is 80 percent, not 64 percent.

title: Fan Support of Eagles Is Fading Like a Late Lead
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16 - Paul Weckerly went to sleep late in the fourth quarter on Monday, comfortably assured that his Philadelphia Eagles would protect a 20-7 lead against the Dallas Cowboys.

title: Veto Threat as Senators Approve Pension Bill
description: The Senate passed a bill yesterday aimed at strengthening the nation's troubled system of company pension plans. But the White House called the measure inadequate and warned that President Bush was likely to veto it if it remained in its current form.

title: Turmoil in Haiti, Seen Close Up
description: "Aristide and the Endless Revolution" is a probing look into the 2004 overthrow of the twice democratically elected Haitian president Jean-Bertrand Aristide, who had previously been ousted in a 1991 coup. Mr. Aristide was cherished by his country's poor (in 2001 he won with an astounding 91 percent of the vote) and deemed ineffectual by the wealthy powers of the United States, France and Canada, among others.

title: New Snags in Oil Talks by Indonesia And Exxon
description: The Exxon Mobil Corporation has run into a new impasse with Indonesia's state-owned oil company over plans to develop the country's largest known oil reserve, prompting the government to warn that it will take over the project if an agreement is not reached by the end of the year.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Growth Outlook Trimmed
description: The Bank of England lowered forecasts yesterday for economic growth and inflation, raising speculation that interest rates will remain at current levels for at least a year. Economic growth will accelerate to about 3 percent before easing in the first quarter of 2007, the bank said in its quarterly inflation report. "There are substantial risks to the outlook in both directions," the bank's governor, Mervyn A. King, left, said. "It is perfectly reasonable to leave rates on hold," given the projection for inflation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBERTS, ALFRED B.
description: ROBERTS--Alfred B., 83. Of Livingston passed away suddenly Sunday, November 13. A resident of Livingston for over 50 years he was instrumental in the creation of The Living Sections for The New York Times where he retired in 1991 after thirty-one years as an assistant editor. Al was a World War II veteran, serving the US Army as a Lt. in the South Pacific. Born in Staten Island, NY, he attended Wagner College and was a lifetime newspaperman; beginning his career at the Staten Island Advance as a sports reporter and later as a Copy Desk Chief and editor at The Star Ledger. He also worked as a copy editor for the New York Journal American, World Telegraph and the Daily News. An avid baseball fan, especially of the NY Mets he was a Livingston Intermediate Little League baseball coach in the 1970's, a daily visitor of Seymour's Luncheonette and a patron of many charities and the arts. Widow of his beloved Rosemary, he is survived by his loving daughter Nita, sister Sylvia Surpin of Staten Island, brother Lionel Roberts of Sugarland Texas, niece Jo Surpin of Philadelphia and Rick Surpin of Brooklyn, along with many loyal friends. In lieu of flowers please make donations of the Livingston National Little League.

title: Curbs on Insurance forMilitary Are Urged
description: In a report to be released today, the Government Accountability Office strongly urges Congress to act to protect military personnel from the deceptive sales practices and unsuitable investments and insurance policies that the report says have been a disturbing fact of military life.

title: Oil costs lead EU to cut growth outlook
In Choosing Experience, Dodgers Forgo a Chance at History
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 16 - As the Los Angeles Dodgers introduced their new general manager Tuesday, the most intriguing candidate sat in the audience.

title: Arts, Briefly; Russia: Happy Birthday, Maya
description: The 80th birthday of the Russian ballerina Maya Plisetskaya, right, is being observed all across Moscow this week. Posters and banners at every turn in the city center announce the Bolshoi Theater festival in her honor that was to open last night with "Swan Lake," her signature ballet. A film festival in her honor opened on Monday. A telecommunications company set up a free hot line for fans from across the country to call in their congratulations. Ms. Plisetskaya, who performed regularly well into her 60's, was not scheduled to dance last night; but at a standing-room-only news conference last week she announced that she would perform "Ave Maria" at a gala performance on Sunday (her birthday), when guests from the Paris Opera and Covent Garden are to perform, as well as break dancers, whom Ms. Plisetskaya loves.

title: Europa:Ukrainian city wants to reclaim its past
Sharon agrees to early elections
Two 'Bridges to Nowhere' Tumble Down in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 - Congressional Republicans decided Wednesday to take a legislative wrecking ball to two Alaskan bridge projects that had demolished the party's reputation for fiscal austerity.

title: The Big City Writ Small, in Twigs and Fungus
description: LAST week, two elegantly dressed women pressed their noses against the window of a large greenhouse at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx and peered inside with the secret glee of children spying on Santa's workshop.

title: Closing of College Shadows Candidate for Governor
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 16 - In the days since William F. Weld left Decker College here to focus on a race for governor of New York, the commercial trade school has been raided by federal agents, declared bankruptcy and left hundreds of students marooned without classes.

title: On Ohio Flatland, a Megachurch's Eye-Catcher Dominates
description: MONROE, Ohio - Jesus first appears in a flash, a white statue rising from the flat cornfields 40 miles north of Cincinnati. Then he is gone, hidden behind a gas station.

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Term Of Volcker Committee Extended By A Month
description: The inquiry led by Paul A. Volcker into the United Nations oil-for-food program in Iraq has been extended another month, to the end of December, to give prosecutors time to pursue leads turned up in the committee's five lengthy reports and to settle the question of what to do with all its documentation.

Testimony by Oil Executives Is Challenged
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 - Senators from both parties demanded Wednesday that several oil executives explain statements they made to Congress last week about their ties to the energy task force led by Vice President Dick Cheney.

title: Fellow Republicans, Open Your Doors
description: Purcellville, Va. - REPUBLICAN candidates hoping to make illegal immigration a central issue in next year's Congressional elections and the 2008 presidential race should consider the results of the Virginia governor's contest.

title: A Second Chance for Japanese Cellphone Makers
description: TOKYO, Nov. 16 - Cellphones here have cash chips that let shoppers swipe them at the register like debit cards. They have crisp color screens for watching television shows and music videos. They have full-fledged Web browsers, and they even have fingerprint readers and cameras with face-recognition software that lock up a phone if a stranger tries to use it.

title: Kendall at Center of Sacrificial Jets
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 16 - Playing poorly is something that Jets offensive lineman Pete Kendall has no qualms addressing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORGENTHAU, JANE, WERTHEIMER
description: MORGENTHAU -- Jane, Wertheimer. Age 94 died November 14, 2005. Wife of Charles S. (deceased) and mother Kate (deceased). Jane, a graduate of Connecticut College was a lifetime avid reader of books, though born with greatly impaired eyesight. She worked at The Book Store in her hometown of Saint Louis, MO and in New York City at the Cokesbury Bookstore and the McBurney School Library. Friend, confidant and frequent hostess to her many cousins and dear friends, Jane always shared her interest and love in the lives of these individuals. A memorial gathering in her honor will be held on December 4, 2005 at 2PM at her home, 40 East 88th Street. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Kate Morgenthau Library Fund of Connecticut College.

title: Corrections
description: A Calendar listing on Sunday in the Long Island Weekly for a performance this Saturday at the Star Playhouse in Commack misidentified the musical and its author. It is "Phantom," by Maury Yeston, not "The Phantom of the Opera," by Andrew Lloyd Webber and Charles Hart.

title: Fifth Floor: Evening Wear and a Cozy Lunch
description: WRITERS of bodice-rippers might disagree, but no two consumer hobbies go together better than shopping and eating. The French even use gustatory metaphors to describe the ritual of prepurchase flirtation: their phrase for window shopping is lche-vitrines, which literally means "lick the windows."

title: The Neediest Cases; Raising 3 Grandchildren With a Giant Work Ethic
description: If there were a contest, Beverly Farrar would be a serious contender for World's Most Dynamic Grandmother.

description: THE President's Advisory Panel on Federal Tax Reform struggled long and hard to come up with some economically sensible and politically feasible ways to reform the tax code.

description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,065 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: School Building Officials Charged
description: Three current and three former officials of the School Construction Authority were charged yesterday in Federal District Court with soliciting and accepting bribes from contractors, the commissioner of investigation, Rose Gill Hearn, left, said yesterday. The six were responsible for monitoring construction and renovation projects for New York City schools, the commissioner said in a statement. The charges included demanding bribes in cash or equipment before approving payments to the contractors for work performed, or in exchange for inside information about bids. Bronx, Manhattan and Brooklyn schools were involved.

title: Museums Under Fire on Ancient Artifacts
description: Three years ago, directors of some of the world's top museums, meeting in Munich, commiserated over a major annoyance: the growing demands from countries like Greece and Italy that they return ancient artifacts.

title: The Perpetual Student
description: To the Editor:

title: National Briefing | Washington: College To Study Sexual Abuse In Church
description: An advisory group to the United States Conference of Catholic Bishops announced the selection of the John Jay College of Criminal Justice of the City University of New York to study the causes behind the sexual abuse scandals that have plagued the Roman Catholic Church. The study was commissioned by the Bishops' National Review Board, which advises the bishops on handling sexual abuse cases involving priests. It is to explore aspects of the abuse, including the psychological problems of the abusers and the "circumstances which enhanced the vulnerability of the victims," according to a statement from the conference. The Survivors Network of those Abused by Priests, a victims' advocacy group, criticized the study as too narrow because of its focus on cases in the 1970's and 80's, asserting that it was too early to tell if number of cases had fallen.

title: Northrop Grumman Seeks $2 Billion to Repair Hurricane Damage
description: PASCAGOULA, Miss. - The destruction is everywhere at the Northrop Grumman shipyards here. Buildings look forlorn, with walls missing and soggy insulation dangling from rafters. Even the destroyer Kidd has a hole in its side.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCCOY, ANN WYETH
description: McCOY--Ann Wyeth, 90, composer, painter died November 10, 2005. Survivors are three children John, Anna, and M. Robin; one brother, Andrew, and four grandchildren. Services are today in Wilmington, DE. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Brandywine River Museum, PO Box 141, Chadds Ford, PA 19317. www.chandlerfuneral home.com

A daughter Jane Hersch survives. A graduate of Columbia University School of Social Work and practiced for 40 years as a clinical social worker.

description: New home construction dropped to its slowest pace in five months and permits for building had their biggest monthly drop in almost six years in October, the government reported today, providing more evidence of a housing slowdown.

description: DURANDO--Olga. A kind and gentle person, November 15, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Natale Durando, devoted mother of Rita and John, mother-in-law of Kathleen and Robert, loving grandmother of David, Germaine, Peter and Natalie, greatgrandmother of Nicholas and the late Isabella. Visitation at Macken Mortuary, Island Park, NY.

title: Debate in Senate on Alito Heats Up Over '85 Memo
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 - The debate over the Supreme Court nomination of Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. escalated into a full-fledged fight in the Senate Wednesday as top Democrats sounded new alarms about his approach to the law and Republicans warned that any effort to block a vote on him would be "outrageous."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VELISKAKIS, KONSTANTIN P. (AKA KOSTAS P. VELIS, M.D.)
description: VELISKAKIS--Konstantin P. (aka Kostas P. Velis, M.D.) left us on November 14, 2005 at his home in New York City, of Hellenic ethnic descent, father Dr. Protesilaos Veliskakis, mother Athina of Athens, Greece. He graduated from the American University of Beirut Medical School in 1948, completed surgical and orthopaedic residencies at the Royal College of Surgeons, London, England, Lambeth Hospital, Southend General Hospital, Derbyshire Royal Infirmary, Derbyshire and Hospital for Crippled Children. Gibney Scoliosis Fellowship at the Hospital for Special Surgery working with John R. Cobb, M.D. for seven years. Joined the staff of the Hospital for Special Surgery, The New York Presbyterian Hospital, Cornell Medical Center in 1957. Started the Scoliosis Service at Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center in 1971. Certified by the American Board of Orthopaedic Surgery and American Board of Spine Surgeons. He was a Fellow of the American College of Surgeons, Scoliosis Research Society, North Americana Spine Society, International Hippocratic Foundation of Kos, Semmelweiss Society, Hellenic Medical Society, Medical Society of the State and County of NY, American Orthopaedic Foot and Ankle Society. Published only in peer-reviewed journals, presented several scientific exhibits at the Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons, helped thousands of suffering patients and mentored large numbers of medical students, residents and Fellows. He was skilled and innovative as a surgeon, a person with high intellect, free uninhibited thinking, superior wit, total dedication to spinal sciences, and having great concern and compassion for his patients. He left us with great memories for which we feel fortunate to have been with him and for which we have all loved him profoundly. He shall be remembered forever in the hearts of the only woman he loved, his wife, Barbara, his loving children Danae, Neobe and Kosta, his grieving sisters Tina and Mary the late Ellie and Demetrious, grandchildren James, Natahaniel, Breck and Nadja. He will be greatly missed by his colleagues, other health care persons and multiple friends. He wants us to know that he completed a wonderful biological se quence in this planet and is content now to exit. Kostas was also a painter and sculptor. He left all his work to his wife, Barbara. Funeral services will be held on November 18th, 2005 at John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Avenue @ 70th Street between 2:00 PM and 5:00 PM. Flowers will be appreciated or donations to the American University of Beirut Medical School or the Central Park Conservancy.

title: TIAA-CREF Resignation

A Lifetime of Personal Memories Captured in a Coffee Table Book
description: "In 2000 my grandmother went in for a hip operation, and when she got out, it was as if a delete button had been pushed," said Samantha Reynolds. "She came out with a new hip and no long-term memory," recalled Ms. Reynolds, who went on to create a company called Echo Memoirs. Ms. Reynolds works with interviewers in 25 cities to glean the intimate memories, photographs and favorite quotations of an older person. She then creates a narrative illustrated with photos, drawings, and documents like marriage certificates and letters, and publishes it as a hardcover book. One copy is $6,000, and additional ones are $200 to $250 each. Information: echomemoirs.com or (877) 777-3246. CURRENTS: BOOKS

World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Milosevic's Trial Adjourned Over Illness
description: The war crimes trial of Slobodan Milosevic, the former Yugoslav president, was abruptly adjourned when he said he was too ill to continue. "I cannot sit here any longer," he told the United Nations tribunal. "The pressure in my head and in my ears is unbearable." Mr. Milosevic, 64, has long suffered from hypertension and recently complained of new ailments. He underwent a medical examination, but no details were released. Meanwhile, tribunal judges acquitted and released Sefer Halilovic, a former Bosnian Muslim army commander, saying prosecutors had failed to prove that he was in charge of the troops who killed 62 Croat civilians in the villages of Grabovica and Uzdol in 1993. Marlise Simons (NYT)

title: Lean Cuisine: Can I Put My Oven on a Diet?
description: AS a hard-core New Englander, I was raised to view the local oil company as the enemy and heating as something one resorts to only after donning thermal underwear and a wool vest. It was so cold in our house it took an extra day to defrost the Thanksgiving turkey; one uncle used to show up for the big meal in his shirt sleeves and make an elaborate ritual of putting on his down vest before joining the table.

title: Wrestling With Tradition: Keep Your Shirt On

In the 1980's, the glory days of WrestleMania, Hulk Hogan accessorized his banana-colored bikini with matching wristlets when challenging Andre the Giant, he of the chronic wedgie.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Bush Approval Drops Among Students
description: A nationwide poll has found that President Bush's approval rating among students has declined precipitously. Forty-one percent of college students say they approve of the job Mr. Bush is doing, down from 61 percent in 2003. Recent polls show Mr. Bush's approval rating has dipped in general. A poll by the Pew Research Center, released last week, showed Mr. Bush with an approval rating of 36 percent. The student poll of 1,204 undergraduates was commissioned by the Institute of Politics at Harvard and conducted by the Washington firm Prime Group LLC from Oct. 10-18, has a margin of error of plus or minus three percentage points. John Files (NYT)
