description: It is a war on rising hospital costs, being fought one tiny balloon at a time. And as with most wars, some of the tactics are controversial.

title: Enough to Make an Iguana Turn Green: Darwin's Ideas
description: DURING the years in which Charles Darwin was working on his revolutionary book, "On the Origin of Species," and later, with more intensity, in the 1860's, when controversy raged over his ideas, the naturalist was plagued with bouts of gastric trauma, sometimes accompanied by severe eczema. The illness was never diagnosed, and various hypotheses about a tropical parasite, picked up during Darwin's five years traversing the world aboard the HMS Beagle, have not been widely accepted.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Saint-Gobain to Buy BPB
description: Compagnie de Saint-Gobain agreed yesterday to buy BPB of Britain, the world's largest maker of plasterboard for walls and ceilings, for 3.89 billion ($6.7 billion). BPB's chief executive, Richard Cousins, who opposed the deal, quit. The transaction values BPB at 775 pence a share ($13.31), or 7.6 percent higher than the French company's initial offer on Aug. 31. Saint-Gobain, Europe's biggest distributor of building materials, gains leadership in board and gypsum, an industry with sales growth twice that of construction as a whole. BPB is based in Slough, England and Saint-Gobain is based in Paris.

title: Hewlett Profit Falls
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17 - Hewlett-Packard reported Thursday that its quarterly net income declined sharply because of expenses related to cost-cutting, but it said that the cutbacks resulted in a strong increase in operating income.

title: String-Quartet Fugue Gets The Four-Handed Treatment
description: Musicological heads were turned last month when news broke of an exciting Beethoven discovery: a working manuscript score for the piano transcription of the "Grosse Fuge," a towering string-quartet landmark of the composer's final years.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Lego Loses Trademark Bid
description: Canada's Supreme Court unanimously rejected an attempt by the Lego Group to use the design of its plastic toy bricks as a trademark. The decision yesterday was the latest development in several countries between Lego, based in Billund, Denmark, and Mega Bloks, a maker of interlocking bricks based in Montreal. Lego's fundamental patents on the toy expired in 1978. But nine years ago, it sued Mega Bloks for trademark infringement and asked for an injunction blocking sales of that company's toy blocks. The distinctive knobs on the top of the interlocking bricks, Lego argued, were so closely associated with the company that they had become an unregistered trademark. In upholding a lower court ruling against Lego, the Supreme Court dismissed that idea." A purely functional design cannot be the basis of a trademark and trademark law should not be used to perpetuate monopoly rights enjoyed under now-expired patents," the court wrote in its decision. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Born to Run
description: On a steaming August afternoon in Washington, D.C., a few years ago, two friends and I busted out of class -- oops, work -- early, and headed for Maryland's Eastern Shore for blue crabs and cold beer. We were baking as we sat in traffic on the black leather seats of my convertible. Finally, we got to the Chesapeake Bay Bridge and paid the toll, and Neil slipped a disc into my CD player. The first familiar piano chords sounded: "The screen door slams./Mary's dress waves."

title: The Neediest Cases; Still Time, Despite Infirmities, to Pursue That Law Degree
description: O'Dena Nelson's friends say she should be a lawyer, and she has entertained the thought. Her work as an advocate for those who, like her, have weathered New York's foster care system resonates deeply within her. And at 34, a survivor of childhood abuse and severe health problems, Ms. Nelson feels that she has time to achieve her goal.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Kashmir: Quake Survivors Cross Border
description: Pakistan and India allowed two dozen Kashmiris to walk across the Line of Control, the militarized line that divides the disputed territory, at the Chakothi-Uri crossing. It is one of five points on the line that the countries had agreed would be opened after last month's earthquake to help move relief supplies and reunite divided families. This was the first civilian crossing. The 24 Kashmiris were from the Indian zone and had arrived in the Pakistani zone before the Oct. 8 quake on the new cross-Kashmir bus service and became stranded there when a bridge on the bus line collapsed in the quake. Salman Masood (NYT)

title: On His Own, Letting His Lyrics Speak for Themselves
description: Jeff Tweedy can seem like a guy who's been reading Bob Dylan's biography backward. Once he was associated with a stolid American roots classicism, an august, honest kind of rock that just hums along and doesn't need to be explained. Then, with a changed band, he took that idea apart, challenging and amping up the music, causing a stir. Now he appears to be blowing minds alone, with voice and guitar.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Jordan: Bride's Mother Dies Of Bombing Wounds
description: The mother of the bride whose wedding was under way when three hotels in Amman were attacked by suicide bombers last week died of her wounds. Her death brought the number of people killed by the bombers to 59, including the fathers of both the bride and the groom. Hassan M. Fattah (NYT)

title: Failed acquisition bid forces out VNU head
Two Thieves Bound by Honor Ricochet Through the Underworld
description: Claude Sautet's "Classe Tous Risques" is the kind of French movie that makes you want to throw on your trench coat, light up a cigarette and shoot somebody. Originally released in 1960, it was lost in the frenzy of the Nouvelle Vague, which made its straightforward use of genre look a bit old-fashioned. Back then, a dubbed version (titled "The Big Risk" and distributed by United Artists) played briefly in American theaters, but now, thanks to Rialto Pictures, English speakers can see a handsome restored print with newly translated subtitles. It is worth seeking out, not only because "Classe Tous Risques" represents a missing piece of film history -- a link between the great postwar policiers and the brooding 1960's gangster dramas of Jean-Pierre Melville -- but because it is a tough and touching exploration of honor and friendship among thieves.

title: Disability Law, Moving Backward
description: The federal Individuals With Disabilities Education Act, known as the I.D.E.A., has greatly improved the lives of disabled schoolchildren across the United States. Before the original legislation was passed in 1975, children who were institutionalized with serious emotional problems could sometimes be found strapped to their desks and screaming at the top of their lungs. In the public schools, otherwise bright and capable children with undiagnosed learning disabilities were regularly shunted into corners and ignored.

title: Russian City's Sacred and Secular Visions
description: BALTIMORE, Nov. 11 - St. Andrew the Fool was, at first, nonplussed. Keeping vigil one night in a church where the robes of the Mother of God were preserved, he saw the Virgin unfurl her veil over the congregation. He turned to a companion. "Do you see what I see?" His friend was young; the hour was late. Maybe he saw; maybe he didn't. But to Andrew, all was now clear. The wardrobe was in use; the Virgin was in residence.

title: A Tutor, a Triangle and Hearts That Sing
description: Bravely flouting centuries of accepted scientific theory, the creators of "The Woman in White" have set out to prove that the world is flat after all. Inspired by the spine-tingling Wilkie Collins novel of 1860, this latest work from the poperetta king Andrew Lloyd Webber, which opened last night at the Marquis Theater, seems to exist willfully and unconditionally in two dimensions.

title: TEACHER MAN: A Memoir
An Artist Who Inspires New Ways of Seeing
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 17 - Like much of the work gathered under the rubric of avant-garde cinema, the films of Phil Solomon deserve a larger audience than even the enthusiastic crowd that welcomed them at Redcat (the Roy and Edna Disney/CalArts Theater) on Nov. 14 in downtown Los Angeles. Etched in black and vivid color and infused with melancholy, Mr. Solomon's stunningly beautiful films have an emotional power that might well attract more viewers, if not for the maddening divisions that find a few rarefied films classified (read: ghettoized) as art, while the vast majority are relegated to the commercial trough.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City University To Increase Faculty
description: The City University of New York is planning to hire 800 additional full-time faculty members over the next four years, Matthew Goldstein, the university's chancellor, said yesterday. In a speech for the Center for Educational Innovation he said the long-term goal was to have 70 percent of the teaching performed by full-time personnel, up from about 50 percent now. CUNY, which has 200,000 students, hired 300 full-time faculty members at its community colleges in the past three years, which helped raise the number of full-time faculty members to 6,260 in the last academic year, 11 percent above the level three years earlier. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: Boy Is Killed While Playing
description: A 13-year-old Long Island boy who was playing with friends died yesterday after his head became tangled in a rope the boys had tied to a tree, the Nassau County police said. The death of Julio Sanchez, of Floral Park, appeared accidental, homicide detectives said last night, but the circumstances were still being investigated. About 3 p.m., as the boys were playing in a yard on Hendrickson Avenue in Elmont, Julio became entangled. When his friends could not free him, they sought help. Rescuers took Julio to Franklin Hospital Medical Center in Valley Stream, where he later died. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: 36 Hours in Huntington Beach, Calif.
description: HUNTINGTON BEACH was not specifically on Dean Torrence's mind when he and the late Jan Berry recorded their 1963 hit "Surf City." But Mr. Torrence, the Dean of the pop music duo Jan & Dean, is among those who help promote the city as "Surf City USA." Huntington's wide, white beaches, with a series of shallow sandbars that gradually drop off into the blue Pacific, help shape ocean swells into some of the most consistently surfable sets of waves anywhere in the world. Combine that with a practically ideal year-round climate, eight and a half miles of uninterrupted public coastline and 67 parks, all in a city of just under 200,000, and you've got a recipe for endless summer. title: The Listings: Nov. 18 -- Nov. 24; MARIA SCHNEIDER ORCHESTRA
description: When the Maria Schneider Orchestra won a Grammy Award last year for "Concert in the Garden," it signaled a mainstream arrival for ArtistShare, the startup engine behind the album's Internet-only distribution. It also marked the rightful acknowledgment of what has become one of the most expressive large groups in jazz. The playing on "Concert in the Garden" captivates both in solo and ensemble terms; Ms. Schneider's billowing compositions, laced with Latin American harmony and rhythm, breathe in such a manner as to mask their scrupulous precision. This deceptively airy quality multiplies in concert, as the orchestra has proved on countless New York engagements. One, in January 2000, yielded "Live at the Jazz Standard -- Days of Wine and Roses," a recording originally issued only to buyers of a Maria Schneider Riesling. Now available through ArtistShare (at www.mariaschneider.com), the album offers a glimpse at Ms. Schneider's history as a composer and arranger; several pieces date as far back as her student years at the Eastman School of Music. Most of the arrangements were staples of a mid-1990's residency at the now-defunct Greenwich Village club Visiones; Ms. Schneider, above, led the orchestra there every Monday night for five years. It was during that time that she began to reshape the harmonically astute big-band syntax of her mentors, the composers Gil Evans and Bob Brookmeyer, into a dialect of her own. Returning to the Jazz Standard this week, Ms. Schneider and her colleagues will speak it fluently. (Tuesday through Nov. 27 (except Thursday) at 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232; cover, $25 to $30.)

title: Return of the Patriot Act
description: With key parts of the Patriot Act due to expire shortly, Congress has an opportunity to improve the law. Instead, it seems poised to renew many of the provisions that infringe most directly on civil liberties -- and to add some new ones. There is nothing "patriotic" about letting the F.B.I. seize the records of ordinary Americans without a judge's approval, or taking away the federal judiciary's historical role in ensuring that the death penalty is imposed fairly. Some senators are threatening a filibuster as they negotiate to block some of the act's more egregious provisions. We hope a filibuster isn't necessary.

Loquacity breeds laryngitis, as do multiple victory orations in celebration of his $135,000-a-year post. Slumped in a saggy chair at the conference table that dominates his shabby, soon-to-be-vacated district office at 230 West 72nd Street, he seems in the throes of campaign hangover: a little dazed, a tad tired.

title: Review: The fine points of a high-performing pen
The Listings: Nov. 18 -- Nov. 24; 'THE WOMEN OF GIACOMETTI'
description: Unlike the female subjects of Picasso and Matisse, women in the paintings and sculptures of Alberto Giacometti are rarely if ever objects of purely erotic desire -- not judging by this impressive, museum-quality exhibition of works depicting women from all phases of his career. In painted, mostly gray portraits, women described by innumerable fine lines appear inapproachably isolated in large rooms. (A recurrent sitter is the artist's mother, a formidable Swiss woman to whom he was deeply devoted.) Whether they are clothed or nude, Giacometti's painted women have a sad, disembodied remoteness, as if they were fading memories of an abandoned child. Nondescript, studentlike efforts from the 1920's provide few clues to Giacometti's feelings about his female subjects, but one of his best-known sculptures from the 30's, the Surrealistic semi-abstraction called "Woman With Her Throat Cut," naturally invites suspicions of misogyny. However, murderous rage is not the animating spirit of the elongated, skinny, big-footed and heavily textured figures from the 50's for which he is most famous. Barely differentiated as female (see "Women of Venice," above) they are like idols made by a tribe of prehistoric cave dwellers. These figures have been so widely reproduced that they start to look like a species of kitsch -- especially the ones riding on big chariots -- but in the gallery they still have a mysteriously urgent presence. Whether male or female, they are a valiant attempt to honor primordial gods who have continued to haunt the margins of rational consciousness ever since they were banished by the Enlightenment. (PaceWildenstein, 32 East 57th Street, Manhattan, (212) 421-3292, through Dec. 17.)

title: Arts, Briefly; A Film Producer Exhales
description: Fox Searchlight Pictures has bought the distribution rights to the film "Phat Girlz," a comedy starring Mo'Nique Imes-Jackson, below, said its producer, Bobby Newmyer. The film, about a plus-size fashion designer who finds unexpected love during a free trip to Palm Springs, was financed by Mr. Newmyer himself with his personal savings and several home mortgages. "I'm incredibly relieved," Mr. Newmyer said. "I'll sleep through the night for the first time in 18 months." The film, written and directed by Nnegest Likk, cost $3 million to make. Mr. Newmyer said that Fox Searchlight had paid "mid-seven figures" for it and that the filmmakers would also get a percentage of profits, though he declined to give specific figures. Through his Outlaw Productions company, Mr. Newmyer has produced the films "Training Day," "The Santa Clause" and "Mindhunters." "Phat Girlz" is expected to be released in April.

description: ROSENBERG--Sylvia S. The Faculty, Advisory Council and Alumni Association of the Columbia University School of Social Work note with great sadness the passing of Sylvia Rosenberg, class of 1958. A psychiatric social worker, member of the School's faculty, field work instructor and private practitioner, she served also as a chief social worker at Presbyterian Hospital and taught at the College of Physicians and Surgeons. A devoted alumna, she was an Alumni Board and Advisory Council member who initiated and chaired many important programs for the alumni and the School, and her commitment and generous support will help ensure Columbia's future. She was an esteemed colleague and beloved friend who will be greatly missed by all who knew her. Jeanette C. Takamura, Dean

description: GOLDEN--Balfour Henry. Acclaimed New York City restaurateur and amateur violinist, died suddenly on November 11 at the age of 83. Son of Samuel and Helen, he was born in Bangor, ME. and was graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Bowdoin College in 1944. After a stint in the army and post graduate work at Columbia University business school, he went to work for his father's food services business, and in 1954 started his own company, Golden Food Services Corp, through which he owned and operated The Dubonnet Restaurant and The Marlburo, among others. He married the late Emma Jane in 1956. In the 70's, with Gerald Ossip, he owned and operated more than a dozen restaurant cafes and other eateries at Rockefeller Center, most famously The Assembly Steakhouse. He retired in the late 1980's and devoted his later years to The Hobbyists, Activities Unlimited and other organizations. He is survived by his sons Peter and Bob, his daughter Betsy, his grandchildren Casey, Danika and Mandy, and an enormous network of family, friends, and colleagues. The family will receive visitors at home from 2-6 on Saturday, November 19. Contributions can be made to the Emma Jane and Bal Golden Scholarship Fund, Bowdoin College, 400 College Station, Brunswick, ME. 04011-8432.

title: Amphetamines Step Up to Be Counted Out

title: Building a Better Boom
description: Kentfield, Calif. - IT sure feels like a bubble, doesn't it? Let's tick off the signs: a red-hot market for Internet stocks (Google, for example, has more than quadrupled since it went public in 2004); fawning articles celebrating entrepreneurs; a glut of venture capitalists elbowing one another to invest in companies with no plans on how to make money past some hand waving about "advertising" and plenty of vague claims about how their technology will "change the world."

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Lost' Delivers Again
description: There was no mystery to Wednesday's television ratings: "Lost" on ABC was once again the most-watched show of the night. The latest episode, which focused on the recently introduced survivors from the tail end of the plane, delivered 21.58 million viewers and helped ABC win the night among adults 18 to 49, according to Nielsen's overnight estimates. CBS was No. 1 in the total viewer category, as its lineup -- "I Walk the Line: A Night for Johnny Cash" (12.6 million), "Criminal Minds" (14.31 million) and "CSI: New York" (15.39 million) -- climbed in each hour in both total viewers and 18- to 49-year-olds. On Fox, "That 70's Show" continued to win its 8 p.m. time slot in the 18-to-49 demographic, but "Stacked," the Pamela Anderson bookstore comedy that follows it, was not so hot, falling to fifth place in that measurement. Though the show is only in its second week since its season premiere, such attrition can spell doom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARRISON, JEAN (NEE SINSHEIMER)
description: HARRISON--Jean (nee Sinsheimer), 86. Died at home on Wednesday after a long illness. Jean was born in Brooklyn to Walter & Myrtle Sinsheimer and was raised by Myrtle & Samuel Sinsheimer after the premature death of Walter. She graduated from Adelphi College (1940) and Queens College (M.S. Ed. 1960). Jean was a longtime resident of Malverne, NY, and Cranbury, New Jersey, before moving to Hanover, NH, in 1993. She is survived by her loving husband of 64 years, Leonard; two devoted sons and daughters-in-law, Dr. Walter and Jackie, and Andrew and Dr. Adrienne Weiss-Harrison; grandchildren, Lisa Austin, Michael and Peggy, Daniel, Mark, and Rachel Harrison; great grandchildren, Molly and Jacob, and step-grandchildren, Nick and Shana Kaplan. A brother, Walter (Buddy) Sinsheimer, predeceased her. Jean was a highly literate woman who taught college-level English, high school English and French, and wrote wonderful poetry and fiction. She and Len enjoyed extensive travel and pursued lifelong learning in many subjects. Memorial service November 27, 2 PM @ Kendal/Hanover, NH. For details, contact Rand-Wilson Funeral Home 603-643-2552. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Cadbury Fund, Kendal @ Hanover, 80 Lyme Rd, Hanover, NH 03755 or Dartmouth Hillel c/o Roth Center for Jewish Living, Dartmouth College, Hanover, NH will be welcome. Family will observe Shiva at the Peabody, MA home of Dr. Walter and Jackie Harrison, evening of November 28, and at the Larchmont, New York home of Andrew and Dr. Adrienne Harrison, evenings of November 28-29.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about a radio documentary, "My Lobotomy," reversed the description of two types of lobotomies performed by a central figure, Dr. Walter J. Freeman. The procedure in which holes are drilled into the patient's head is a prefrontal lobotomy, not transorbital. A transorbital lobotomy is the one in which a spike is driven beneath the lids of the eyes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VELISKAKIS, KONSTANTIN P. (AKA KOSTAS P. VELIS, M.D.)
description: VELISKAKIS--Konstantin P. (aka Kostas P. Velis, M.D.) left us on November 14, 2005 at his home in New York City, of Hellenic ethnic descent, father Dr. Protesilaos Veliskakis, mother Athina of Athens, Greece. He graduated from the American University of Beirut Medical School in 1948, completed surgical and orthopaedic residencies at the Royal College of Surgeons, London, England, Lambeth Hospital, Southend General Hospital, Derbyshire Royal Infirmary, Derbyshire and Hospital for Crippled Children. Gibney Scoliosis Fellowship at the Hospital for Special Surgery working with John R. Cobb, M.D. for seven years. Joined the staff of the Hospital for Special Surgery, The New York Presbyterian Hospital, Cornell Medical Center in 1957. Started the Scoliosis Service at Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center in 1971. Certified by the American Board of Orthopaedic Surgery and American Board of Spine Surgeons. He was a Fellow of the American College of Surgeons, Scoliosis Research Society, North Americana Spine Society, International Hippocratic Foundation of Kos, Semmelweiss Society, Hellenic Medical Society, Medical Society of the State and County of NY, American Orthopaedic Foot and Ankle Society. Published only in peer-reviewed journals, presented several scientific exhibits at the Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons, helped thousands of suffering patients and mentored large numbers of medical students, residents and Fellows. He was skilled and innovative as a surgeon, a person with high intellect, free uninhibited thinking, superior wit, total dedication to spinal sciences, and having great concern and compassion for his patients. He left us with great memories for which we feel fortunate to have been with him and for which we have all loved him profoundly. He shall be remembered forever in the hearts of the only woman he loved, his wife, Barbara, his loving children Danae, Neobe and Kosta, his grieving sisters Tina and Mary the late Ellie and Demetrious, grandchildren James, Natahaniel, Breck and Nadja. He will be greatly missed by his colleagues, other health care persons and multiple friends. He wants us to know that he completed a wonderful biological se quence in this planet and is content now to exit. Kostas was also a painter and sculptor. He left all his work to his wife, Barbara. Funeral services will be held on November 18th, 2005 at John Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Avenue @ 70th Street between 2:00 PM and 5:00 PM. Flowers will be appreciated or donations to the American University of Beirut Medical School or the Central Park Conservancy.

title: National Briefing | Charity: Red Kettles On The Internet
description: The Salvation Army's red kettles, long a holiday staple, will become even more ubiquitous through a new program that encourages individuals, corporations and organizations to put them on their Web sites and invite visitors to fill them with donations over the Internet. Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer, has put its weight behind the initiative and will have a kettle on its Web site and on the Sam's Club Web site today. A spokesman for the Salvation Army said several individuals had inquired about adding the kettle to their personal Web sites. The Salvation Army tested the program last year in the West and found that it produced an average gift of $95 and increased online donations by 36 percent. Stephanie Strom (NYT)

title: An Image of Darwin, Carrying on His Work
description: Less than a week before the Darwin show opened, the most thrilling live display was neither the big, sleepy iguana nor the pair of Galpagos tortoises, but rather an Englishman, a living descendant of Darwin himself. He is Randal Keynes, a conservationist and writer now living in London. He is Darwin's great-great-grandson. That is, his grandmother was Darwin's granddaughter. He is also the great-nephew of the economist John Maynard Keynes. He is no longer on display.

title: Arts, Briefly; Former Curator Received Loan From Collector
description: Marion True, who resigned last month as the antiquities curator at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles, amid accusations that she failed to disclose details about the purchase of a vacation home in Greece, received a loan for that home from a wealthy art patron whose collection the Getty had just bought, according to a report in The Los Angeles Times. Ms. True, who is on trial in Rome on charges of conspiring to import illegally excavated antiquities for the Getty's collection, received the $400,000 loan from Lawrence Fleischman in 1996, three days after the Getty paid $20 million to acquire part of a renowned collection of Greek, Roman and Etruscan antiquities owned by Mr. Fleischman and his wife, Barbara, the newspaper reported, citing loan documents and interviews. The couple gave the rest of the collection, valued at much more than $20 million, to the museum. The loan from Mr. Fleischman was used to repay money Ms. True had borrowed in 1995 in an original loan for the house, according to the article. When Ms. True stepped down in October, the Getty said only that she "failed to report certain aspects of her Greek house purchase transaction in violation of Getty policy." Ms. True's lawyer, Harry Stang, said yesterday that any implication that the loan from the collectors had any bearing on the sale and gift of their collection was false, adding that Ms. True's involvement in negotiations for the collection ended long before the loan offer was made. Ms. Fleischman, whose husband died in 1997 and who joined the Getty's board in 2000, said in an interview yesterday that she was aware of the loan but did not report it to the board because she did not believe it presented an ethical conflict. "Looking back is very easy," she said. "At the time, I was, well, call it nave or inexperienced." She added, "I do stand corrected, but I don't stand condemned."

And don't forget the lock of hair, neatly braided or twirled just so, supplying the illusion that the great man (or woman) is somehow just out of sight.

Rodney Alston, 18, who was indicted on charges of second-degree murder and criminal possession of a weapon, is still at large. title: Not Content to Entertain, a Star Aims to Conquer
description: From zero to 100 miles an hour in 30 seconds: that's the kind of accelerated drive Michele Lee exhibits in her cabaret show "Catch the Light," which roared onto the stage of Feinstein's at the Regency on Tuesday evening. A tightly constructed autobiography with songs, the show belongs to the old school of knock-'em-dead entertainment embodied by Liza Minnelli, Sam Harris and Patti LaBelle. Once you're on the stage, it isn't enough to seduce or enlighten; the only goal worth pursuing is total conquest.

title: Cadaver Exhibition Raises Questions Beyond Taste
description: The jaunty fellow with the conductor's baton waving in one hand stands on a pedestal seemingly lost in the music. But there are a few startlingly odd things about this tall, lithe gentleman: He is dead, his skin has been methodically ripped away and there is a pinkish void where his viscera are supposed to be. Besides a few supporting segments of muscle, bone and ligament, the man has been rendered into a web of white spindly nerves.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Monaco: Albert Is Crowned Sovereign
description: Prince Albert II of Monaco completed his enthronement with a solemn ceremony in his medieval palace and officially became ruler of this tiny Mediterranean principality. His investiture has been done in several steps, beginning in July, four months after the death of his father, Prince Rainier III. While his father was known for sparring with France, the tiny state's protector, and expanding Monaco into a thriving tax haven, Prince Albert has expressed greater interest in international cooperation and transparency in order to clean up the principality's lingering reputation as a money-laundering hub. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: A Pianist Cruises, Then Thunders in Her Interpretations

Chu-Fang Huang, the 23-year-old Chinese pianist who played at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday evening, has developed that faculty so strikingly that as she thundered through the climactic pages of Liszt's B minor Sonata at the end of her program, it was difficult to think of her as the same pianist who, 90 minutes earlier, was cruising briskly through crisp, light-toned and thoroughly transparent accounts of two Haydn sonatas.

title: China balancing act

description: A play called "RFK" assumes an awful load of expectations, because no thinking person is neutral on the Kennedys. Some -- of a certain age -- will come, eager to see the dead walk again, hoping to salve old wounds and relive momentous emotions by drinking in the details of a spot-on impersonation. Others will come, curious about history and heroism from a bygone time, wary of nostalgia and skeptical of hagiography but hungry for some wisdom that might illuminate current politics.

title: From Sinatra to Astaire to the Bergmans
description: The song lyrics of Alan and Marilyn Bergman are a world unto themselves. The me's, you's and we's in their ballads attach to well-heeled Hollywood dreamers with romantic expectations loftier than Everest. The dreaded word "forever," rarely heard in popular music nowadays, is unashamedly dropped into love songs in which the changes of season are fraught with heavy emotional baggage: Gucci, of course.

title: Russia Plans to Use Turkey as Hub for Gas
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 17 - Russia will extend the reach of its natural gas exports by using Turkey as a hub for shipments to southern Europe and possibly Israel, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said Thursday at the formal opening of a pipeline project on the Black Sea.

title: Mayor Plans New Education Measures, Including Reshaping 8 Troubled High Schools
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced an array of initiatives yesterday to improve the city's public high schools, including 15 new "transfer" schools for students in danger of dropping out and a project to reshape eight large, struggling schools into "small learning communities."

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: European Commission Pares Forecasts
description: The European Commission cut its forecasts for economic growth in the union and in the 12 countries that use the euro, and warned that continued high oil prices and tepid consumer confidence could undermine any recovery. Economic growth for the euro zone this year was estimated at 1.3 percent, down from the 1.6 percent forecast in the spring, the commission said. The euro zone economy grew 2.1 percent last year. The commission's outlook for 2005 growth was pared to 1.5 percent from the 2 percent forecast earlier this year. High oil prices will keep euro zone inflation above the target rate of 2 percent this year and next, declining to 1.9 percent in 2007, according to the forecasts. Paul Meller (NYT)

description: DENVER, Nov. 17 - Stephon Marbury does not have a championship ring, an N.B.A. finals appearance or, for that matter, a simple playoff series victory. For 10 pro seasons, Marbury's greatness has instead been defined by the box scores.

title: Hurricanes Rip Rangers on Hat Trick by Adams
description: RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 17 - The Carolina Hurricanes' marketing slogan this season is "Here to Play, Here to Stay" -- a not-so-subtle reminder that the franchise was in considerable trouble entering the National Hockey League's salary-cap era.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TISCH, PRESTON ROBERT
description: TISCH--Preston Robert. 79. Died peacefully at his home in NYC on November 15th. Survived by Joan Tisch, wife of 57 years, son Steven and his wife Jamie, daughter Laurie, and son Jonathan; grandchildren, Emily, Hilary, Carolyn, William, Charles, Henry, Elizabeth, Holden, and Zachary. Brother of the late Laurence Tisch and his wife, Billie, and uncle, relative, friend and colleague to many. Cofounder and Chairman of the Board of Loews Corporation and Chairman & Co-CEO of the New York Football Giants. Dedicated to his country, state and city, Bob generously gave both his time and resources, serving in countless leadership positions, including: Postmaster General of the United States, founding Director of Citymeals-onWheels, founder and Chairman of Take the Field, Chairman of the New York City Convention & Visitors Bureau, founding Chairman of the New York City Convention and Exhibition Center Corporation, Chairman of the NYC Partnership, Inc. and the NY Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Chairman of NYC Public Private Initiatives, Inc., and trustee of New York University. Funeral services will be private for family. The family will be receiving condolences on Thursday, November 17, and Sunday, November 20, from 5 to 9 PM. A memorial service will be held on Friday, December 9, 2005, at 11 AM, at Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Preston Robert Tisch Brain Tumor Research Center at Duke University, Citymeals - on Wheels, or the Preston Robert Tisch Center for Hospitality, Tourism, and Sports Management at New York University.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Riverhead: Man Re-Sentenced For 5 Murders
description: A Hicksville man whose death sentence for murdering five women was vacated by the State Court of Appeals was re-sentenced yesterday to life in prison without parole. A Suffolk County jury sentenced Robert Shulman, 51, to death in 1999 when they found him guilty of killing three women. He was later convicted in Westchester County of killing two others. Peter C. Beller (NYT)

title: Slow Pace of Contract Talks Has Owners Pondering Lockout for 2008 Season
description: The National Football League has made so little movement toward a new collective bargaining agreement that during a two-day meeting this week in Kansas City, Mo., the owners discussed the possibility of playing the 2007 season without a salary cap and having a lockout in 2008. They also talked about creating a contingency fund in the event of a lockout.

title: Threats of Terror Attacks Run on Indonesian TV
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 17 - A masked man who officials here say is a leading militant threatened Western nations with more terrorist attacks in a video broadcast Thursday on Indonesian television.

title: Timid Mice Made Daringby Removing One Gene
description: Scientists working with mice have found that by removing a single gene they can turn normally cautious animals into daring ones, mice that are more willing to explore unknown territory and less intimidated by sights and sounds that they have learned can be dangerous.

title: Iraq war of words heats up
Russell Crowe Pleads Guilty in Hotel Phone Case
description: The movie star Russell Crowe pleaded guilty today to third-degree assault and admitted to a judge that he threw a phone that hit a Manhattan hotel concierge in June.

title: Torture Charges Deepen Rift Between U.S. and Iraqi Leader
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Friday, Nov. 18 - A split between American officials here and one of Iraq's most powerful ministers widened Thursday as the minister played down reports that Iraqi police officers tortured prisoners while the American Embassy bluntly warned that such abuse would not be tolerated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FIRESTONE, ABRAHAM
description: FIRESTONE--Abraham. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of Abraham Firestone, beloved father of our devoted members Robert and Laurie Firestone, grandfather of Day School student Arielle. Deepest sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier

title: The Listings: Nov. 18 -- Nov. 24; 'IN THE CONTINUUM'
description: An H.I.V. diagnosis collapses the wide distance between the distinct worlds brought to life in this affecting new play written and performed by a pair of enterprising young actresses. The subject is journalistic, the approach intimately personal. Danai Gurira plays Abigail, a pregnant, proudly middle-class professional in Zimbabwe who learns that her husband has infected her with the AIDS virus. Nikkole Salter (above left, with Ms. Gurira) is Nia, a troubled 19-year-old in Los Angeles who contracted it from the hotshot basketball star about to leave her behind for a college scholarship. Ms. Gurira and Ms. Salter also play the various men and women Abigail and Nia look to for guidance or support, widening the play's focus to establish how both women's lives are circumscribed by dismayingly similar economic and cultural forces. Both are desperate not to alienate the men who have infected them. The buoyant performances and sharply detailed writing ensure that the play never moves to a drumbeat of doom. Warm and often disarmingly funny, it pulses with life from start to finish. Produced by Primary Stages and directed by Robert O'Hara, the production has moved to the Perry Street Theater in the West Village for a limited run after playing two performances a week uptown. (Tonight at 8 and tomorrow at 3 and 8 p.m., 31 Perry Street, (212) 868-4444.)

title: Publisher Sued Over Book Critical of Turkish State
description: ISTANBUL, Nov. 18 - A Turkish book publisher said today that the government was suing it for distributing a translated book critical of the Turkish identity, army, state and the founder of the republic, Mustafa Kemal Ataturk.

title: Red Update Alert: Poseidon Goes Belly Up Again
description: Re-creations of 70's schlock, from "Starsky & Hutch" to "The Dukes of Hazzard," all seem to obey the second law of movie dynamics: remakes drift to a state of inert uniformity known as entropy.

title: The Listings: Nov. 18 -- Nov. 24; SALLY SILVERS
description: Ms. Silvers has been moving to her own drumbeat for 25 years now. Her dances are often dense and gnomic. But they repay the close attention they demand with continual small, surprising revelations: some slyly funny, some tender, and all springing from the unruliest of imaginations. Ms. Silvers, above, hasn't changed much from the keen-eyed political science major at Antioch College -- born in eastern Tennessee, too, for a little extra edge of exoticism -- who was turned on to performing partly by the avant-garde musicianship of the pianist Cecil Taylor. In New York, she was too odd to be chosen at auditions, and dance teachers suggested gently that what she was doing was nice enough, but not what everyone else was doing. She found herself in classes with Sara Rudner, who got the point of her. And she presented a first dance program that included a 30-minute piece in which she gave herself 30 problems to solve, like how to assume a sleeping position while standing up. Her anniversary program, at Performance Space 122 through Sunday, will feature a sextet called "Puppy-Skills" that will be performed by some of the favorite stars of the downtown dance and performance worlds, among them Vicky Shick, Paige Martin, Julie Atlas Muz and Jamie Di Mare. Two other starry types -- Pooh Kaye and Cydney Wilkes -- will perform an improvisation, dressed in inflatable-art costumes, with a different musician at each performance. And a different guest will create a dance on the spot at every performance in "Live Choreography." Ms. Silvers's longtime collaborator Bruce Andrews will provide the music, with Michael Schumacher. (Tonight at 8, tomorrow at 5 and 8 p.m., Sunday at 5 p.m. and Nov. 25 and 26 at 8 p.m.; Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street, East Village, (212) 352-3101 or www.ps122.org.)

title: Austria Arrests David Irving, Writer Known as a Holocaust Denier
description: LONDON, Nov. 17 - The writer David Irving was arrested in Austria last week, according to a statement on his Web site. Although he has not yet been charged, he is suspected of the crime of Holocaust denial.

title: Punk, Funk and Singalongs, Dwelling on Life in Clubland
description: The Arctic Monkeys' first single, "I Bet That You Look Good on the Dancefloor," zoomed to No. 1 on the British pop charts when it was released in October. A month later, the group was already braced for a backlash when it performed at the Bowery Ballroom. As the band played barreling punk chords in its Wednesday night show, the first words Alex Turner sang were, "Anticipation has a habit to set you up for disappointment."

title: India Concern to Design I.B.M. Chips
description: BANGALORE, India, Nov. 17 - I.B.M. announced an agreement Thursday establishing an Indian outsourcing company, HCL Technologies, as the first design center outside I.B.M.'s own walls for its Power Architecture chips.

title: Arts, Briefly; 2 Top Chess Players Won't Match Up
description: An attempt to organize a match between two claimants to the title of world chess champion has collapsed. Veselin Topalov, a 30-year-old Bulgarian grandmaster who is ranked No. 1 in the world, and who won the championship tournament organized by the World Chess Federation last month in Argentina, has rejected an offer to play Vladimir Kramnik, a Russian grandmaster who is also 30, said Mr. Topalov's manager, Silvio Danailov. Mr. Kramnik, who is ranked No. 7 and did not play in last month's tournament, bases his claim to the title on his defeat of Garry Kasparov in a 2000 match. The proposal for the match -- with a promise of a $1.4 million prize fund -- came from a German company, Universal Event Promotion, which was created to stage it. Mr. Danailov said Mr. Topalov, above, was willing to play the match on three conditions: that Mr. Kramnik be the challenger, that the prize be at least $2.4 million, and that it take place under the auspices of the World Chess Federation.

title: University of Texas at Darfur
description: Im traveling with Naka Nathaniel, who shoots pictures and puts together multimedia shows on these trips. Hes a regular travel companion, and weve managed to be detained together in a growing number of countries.Naka is a proud graduate of University of Texas at Austin, and so a couple of days ago on our first visit to Kalma Camp in Darfur, he used a spare moment to teach some children the hand sign of UT  index finger and pinkie sticking up, to resemble longhorns. Were always surrounded by kids in places like Kalma, and they always want to chat and touch us.Well, Naka seemed to have started a fad. Because today we returned to Kalma, and everywhere we went we were again surrounded by kids  waving the UT longhorn gesture!The next Texan to show up in Kalma will get quite a surprise.

description: Johannes Wieland's cool, spare dances are intermittently full of highly charged movement, but the affectless, pictorial quality of "artificial," a program of four works that opened on Thursday night at the Citigroup Theater, gives this work a flavor of performance art that is both alienating and compelling.

description: FELDMAN--Beatrice, 88. Of NYC. Loving sister of Eleanor Tepfer. Graveside service is Sunday 11AM, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont NY.

title: Halliburton Case Is Referred to Justice Dept., Senator Says
description: Pentagon investigators have referred allegations of abuse in how the Halliburton Company was awarded a contract for work in Iraq to the Justice Department for possible criminal investigation, a Democratic senator who has been holding unofficial hearings on contract abuses in Iraq said yesterday in Washington.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Preston Robert Tisch, the real estate investor and half-owner of the New York Giants, misstated the way he became postmaster general of the United States. He was appointed by the Postal Service Board of Governors, not named by President Ronald Reagan.

title: Life's Twists and Turns, Complete With Yapping Dog
description: Sally Silvers, who is celebrating her 25th anniversary as a choreographer with a program from Thursday to tomorrow at her longtime base of operations, Performance Space 122, has never had her own company. As a result, her anniversary program is wildly diverse, with new dancers -- all of them women -- for every piece. It's also wildly variable, from inconsequential experiments to intermittently exciting stuff.

title: National Briefings | Midwest: Illinois: Pact On Great Lakes Basin
description: A final draft of an agreement that will protect and conserve water in the Great Lakes Basin and give states in the region the power to regulate water use has been sent to eight governors for approval. Prompted by concerns that other states could draw off the waters and affect the region's environment and economy, the Great Lakes Basin Water Resources Compact would also prohibit most water diversions outside the basin and require states in the region to create conservation programs. The governors of Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Minnesota, New York, Ohio, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania are expected to sign the compact next month. State legislatures and Congress must approve the compact for it to become binding. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

title: Schools Data Subpoenaed in Suffolk
description: The 70 school districts in Suffolk County have been ordered to produce voluminous financial records by the end of the month as part of a fraud investigation by a county grand jury, according to a representative of their school superintendents association.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: West Bank: Israel Plans New Construction
description: Israel has invited bids for the building of 13 homes in Maale Adumim, the largest Jewish settlement in the occupied West Bank, despite an obligation to freeze such construction under the "road map" peace plan with the Palestinians and a promise to President Bush not to expand settlements. Israel also issued tenders for building in Ariel and Adam, two other "settlement blocs" that Israel says it intends to keep in any peace agreement. Tenders have been issued for 315 housing units in the territories since the beginning of the year. Steven Erlanger (NYT)

title: Chase Leads to Arrest in String of Robberies
description: After a chase on the Upper East Side, two detectives arrested a Bronx man yesterday as a suspect in as many as 16 bank robberies over the past three months, mostly in Manhattan, the police said.

description: ISTANBUL, Nov. 18 - A Turkish book publisher said Friday that the government was suing it for distributing a translated book that the government charges is critical of the Turkish identity, army and state and the founder of the republic, Mustafa Kemal Ataturk.
