Former President of Young Israel of the Grand Concourse; Administrator Charity Fund, Fifth Avenue Synagogue, President Dylan Carpet, begun as United Carpet. Remembered for his infectious smile, dapper attire, and magnetic personality. Survived by sons, Drs. Stephen, Howard and Nathan, their wives, eight grandchildren and 11 great-grandchildren.

title: Coughlin Tries to Keep Grief in Perspective for the Giants
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 18 - Tom Coughlin is the man in the middle. His role as head coach of the Giants makes him the link between management and the players, between the people who perform off the field and those who perform on it.

title: All-Male, All-Human Troupe Explores Physical Universe
description: Men in the dance world enjoy princely status. Good male dancers can pretty much choose whom they want to dance for, and Terry Creach's continuing ability to attract such talent to his all-male company is testament either to the satisfactions of his choreographic process, which is collaborative, or the quality of his work, or both.

title: Googling Literature: The Debate Goes Public
description: If there was any point of agreement between publishers, authors and Google in a debate Thursday night over the giant Web company's program to digitize the collections of major libraries and allow users to search them online, it seemed to be this: Information does not necessarily want to be free.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: One Killed In Blast Near Istanbul
description: A bomb hidden in a garbage container on the outskirts of Istanbul killed one person and wounded 10 others, the Anatolian News Agency reported. No one claimed responsibility for the blast, near a popular amusement park in the Beylikduzu district. The Istanbul governor, Muammer Guler, said security forces suspected a remote-control device caused the blast. Sebnem Arsu (NYT)

title: Acquisition Offers Hint of Cisco's Strategy
description: Cisco Systems sees its future sitting on top of a television.

title: Agency Plans Updated Fuel Economy Standards
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 18 - New standards for calculating fuel economy ratings on cars and trucks will be proposed by the end of the year, the Environmental Protection Agency said on Friday, but the agency is still not saying exactly how the standards may change.

title: Man Dead in Queens Fire
description: A 25-year-old man was killed when a fire broke out on the second floor of a two-story private house in Jackson Heights, Queens, yesterday morning, the Fire Department said.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Nov. 1 about Paul Reynard, a painter and teacher, misstated his title at the Gurdjieff Foundation of New York, which is dedicated to the teachings of the Armenian-born mystic G. I. Gurdjieff. Mr. Reynard was a co-president of the foundation, not a co-chairman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TISCH, PRESTON ROBERT
description: TISCH--Preston Robert. 79. Died peacefully at his home in NYC on November 15th. Survived by Joan Tisch, wife of 57 years, son Steven and his wife Jamie, daughter Laurie, and son Jonathan; grandchildren, Emily, Hilary, Carolyn, William, Charles, Henry, Elizabeth, Holden, and Zachary. Brother of the late Laurence Tisch and his wife, Billie, and uncle, relative, friend and colleague to many. Cofounder and Chairman of the Board of Loews Corporation and Chairman & Co-CEO of the New York Football Giants. Dedicated to his country, state and city, Bob generously gave both his time and resources, serving in countless leadership positions, including: Postmaster General of the United States, founding Director of Citymeals-onWheels, founder and Chairman of Take the Field, Chairman of the New York City Convention & Visitors Bureau, founding Chairman of the New York City Convention and Exhibition Center Corporation, Chairman of the NYC Partnership, Inc. and the NY Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Chairman of NYC Public Private Initiatives, Inc., and trustee of New York University. Funeral services will be private for family. The family will be receiving condolences on Thursday, November 17, and Sunday, November 20, from 5 to 9 PM. A memorial service will be held on Friday, December 9, 2005, at 11 AM, at Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Preston Robert Tisch Brain Tumor Research Center at Duke University, Citymeals - on Wheels, or the Preston Robert Tisch Center for Hospitality, Tourism, and Sports Management at New York University. $(6$)TISCH--Preston Robert. Benenson Capital Partners mourns the loss of our distinguished colleague, partner and friend, Bob Tisch. We will miss his insight, wisdom and personal perspective. We were lucky to have over 50 years of business and friendship together to remember and cherish. We will always remember a man who was greatly dedicated to his family, business, philanthropy and the New York Giants. All the citizens of New York and beyond will miss his generosity and support. Those of us who know how special he was share the sense of loss with his family, friends and associates. Our deepest sympathy to Joan, Steven, Jon, Laurie and the entire Tisch family. Lawrence Benenson Bill Benenson Fred Benenson Richard Kessler Jim Stifel $(6$)TISCH--Preston Robert. For 40 years, Bob's passion, optimism and generosity of spirit has brightened our lives and enriched all of us in his vast, extended New York Family. He leaves such a strong presence, even as we miss him dearly. Our thoughts are with Joan, Steve, Laurie and Jon. Jay Kriegel & Kathryn McAuliffe $(6$)TISCH--Preston Robert. I will always cherish and remember your leadership for the benefit of the City of New York. I will remember your philanthropic work and your friendship. You were always a true gentleman and a friend. My heart is with all the members of your family. You will be missed! George S. Kaufman $(6$)TISCH--Preston Robert. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our friend, Bob Tisch, and would like to express our deepest sympathy and heartfelt condolences to Joan, Steven, Jon and Laurie and the entire Tisch family. Richard & Stephanie Kessler $(6$)TISCH--Preston Robert. Nico Salon extends deepest sympathy to the Tisch family. Nick Mossa

title: Doctor of Girl, 7, Who Died Says He Made Abuse Report
description: A Brooklyn pediatrician recalled yesterday how a 7-year-old girl who died last month of severe internal injuries was brought to him two years ago with a broken leg -- and how he accused the father of beating her and notified child welfare authorities.

title: DeLay Ex-Aide to Plead Guilty in Lobby Case
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 - Michael Scanlon, a former top official for Representative Tom DeLay and onetime partner of the lobbyist Jack Abramoff, has agreed to plead guilty in a deal with federal prosecutors, according to his lawyer. The deal reveals a broadening corruption investigation involving top members of Congress.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the C.I.A. leak investigation gave outdated information about Paul D. Wolfowitz's response to queries about any role he might have had. When asked if Mr. Wolfowitz, the president of the World Bank, had told Bob Woodward the identity of the C.I.A. officer in the case, his spokesman initially did not reply to requests for comment, but later said that Mr. Wolfowitz was not the source.

title: National Briefings | New England: Massachusetts: Disclosure About Priests
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston agreed to provide information to federal officials about priests working with government agencies. The accord was part of the settlement of a case involving a chaplain with the Department of Veterans Affairs. Federal prosecutors in Boston said the agreement, the first of its kind in the United States, resolved accusations that archdiocese officials had failed to disclose the priest's history of sexual misconduct to Veterans Affairs investigators doing a background check. The church will be required to turn over information about candidates for agency chaplain positions and to immediately report all suspected violations of federal laws governing child abuse and exploitation, the United States attorney Michael J. Sullivan reported.

title: Police Car Kills a Pedestrian in Harlem
description: Police officers driving to investigate a report of a man on a corner with a gun early yesterday struck and killed a pedestrian in Harlem as he stepped out into the street, the police said.

title: Marbury and Brown Can Agree on the Point
description: DENVER, Nov. 18 - They walked in together, not quite side by side, but just close enough that, at a distance, Larry Brown and Stephon Marbury appeared to be on the same plane.

title: Dutch Hiller, 90, Speedy Ranger on 1940 Stanley Cup Team
description: Dutch Hiller, one of the three surviving players from the Rangers' 1940 Stanley Cup hockey champions, died Saturday at a hospital in Glendale, Calif. He was 90 and lived in Montrose, Calif.

title: Endless Winter: A Surfing Paradise Not for the Faint of Heart
description: BUFFALO - It is November and the gales have arrived on the Great Lakes, with gusts up to 60 miles an hour, the very conditions that 30 years ago this month sank the lake freighter Edmund Fitzgerald. At this time of year, as the temperature drops and the wind wails dirges for another lost summer, swells of 10 feet or more can build. And when they do, a handful of hardy surfers in cities and rural communities from Lake Superior to Lake Ontario will ride them.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: The Edge's Plan for New Orleans Musicians

title: Two Musicians, 2,800 Seats: A Big Leap Into the Big Time
description: Hillary Hahn is among the more accomplished and interesting violinists circulating in the professional world these days. Her program with the pianist Natalie Zhu on Thursday night was thoughtful, free of clich and strongly played. At 25, Ms. Hahn is beyond the point of promising; she is there.

title: U.S. Aide Accused of Graft in Iraq Had a Shadowy Past
description: One of them dressed all in black, Johnny Cash style, even in the summer in Iraq, where the temperature often rose above 120 degrees. The other put up huge blue-and-white signs advertising one of his companies -- GBG Logistics -- that remain standing even now along the dangerous road to the Baghdad airport, after car bombs and firefights have destroyed nearly everything else around them.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Migrants Drown Off Sicily
description: At least nine men died after high waves and bad weather rocked a clandestine boat of some 200 illegal immigrants off the shore of Sicily, the Italian authorities said. Italian television showed the bodies of several victims under blankets, and officials said they worried that more had died. Every year, thousands of migrants travel across the Mediterranean from North Africa, especially from Libya, seeking to find work or claim asylum in Italy. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Julius Edelstein, 93, Who Devised CUNY's Open Admissions, Dies
description: Julius C. C. Edelstein, a primary architect of open admissions at the City University of New York in the late 1960's, died on Friday morning at New York Hospital. He was 93.

title: Juggling Stances in the Sports Circus
description: PHILADELPHIA - HEAVY security was in force yesterday afternoon as the national news-media obsession with Terrell Owens and the Philadelphia Eagles focused on the latest installment of the drama at a hotel here: the arbitration hearing.

title: Rivera Isn't Worried About Setup Man
description: Mariano Rivera was the last celebrity to meet reporters before Joe Torre's charity dinner in Manhattan last night, closing things out again. As the Yankees try to surround him with a deeper relief corps, Rivera is not paying attention.

title: Southern Exposure
description: Athens, Ga. - IN 1964, when the blood and terror of Freedom Summer prompted many Americans to condemn the South as backward and bigoted, the historian Howard Zinn struck a nerve with his suggestion that "the nation reacts emotionally to the South precisely because it sees itself there." Now, as Americans rebuild from the wreckage and aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, they see another portrait in time, one that tells us much about what has and hasn't changed in the South in recent years, as well as about what the South can still tell the rest of the nation about itself.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Jail Sentence For Judge In Crucifix Dispute
description: A judge was sentenced to seven months in jail for refusing to hear cases in protest of the presence of crucifixes in the nation's courtrooms. The judge, Luigi Tosti of Camerino, in central Italy, was convicted for failing to carry out his official duties. "I was convicted because I am a minor-league citizen compared to Catholics," the judge said, declining to give his religion. He is appealing the verdict and is not required to begin his sentence unless those appeals fail. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Are the Birds and the Bees Right for the 3's?
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Saturday about the political economist and management consultant Peter F. Drucker misstated the source of a quotation about him -- "He is remarkable for his social imagination, not his futurism" -- and misstated the authorship of a book, "The World According to Peter Drucker." The book was written by Jack Beatty, not by Mr. Drucker, and the quotation was from the book, not from a review of the book.

title: Ex-Salvadoran Colonel Is Ordered to Pay for Crimes Against Humanity
description: A federal jury in Memphis yesterday found a former military colonel from El Salvador responsible for crimes against humanity during that country's civil war in the 1980's and ordered him to pay $6 million in damages.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENTHAL, ANN EDITH, (NEE PRINCE)
description: ROSENTHAL -- Ann Edith, (nee Prince). Of Boca Raton, FL, died on November 15, 2005. She remained vital and beautiful until her passing at the age of 95. Beloved wife of the late Edward H. Rosenthal, M.D. and mother of the late Nelson I. Rosenthal. She is survived by her children Alan David Rosenthal, M.D. and Enid Feldman Rosenthal; granddaughters Nina Michelle Fusillo and Amy Ilyse Rosenthal, grandson-in-law, Michael Fusillo, Ph.D., and great grandson Nathaniel James Fusillo. Her commitment to the community included membership on the board of the March of Dimes of Greater New York and a former president of the Brooklyn chapter of the National Council of Jewish Women. Her journey was long and varied but always traveled with elegance and a graceful expansion of her horizons. She will be deeply missed. Service on Sunday, November 20, at 11:30AM, at the "Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave, New York City. Contributions may be made to the March of Dimes of Greater New York.

title: New Orleans Utility Struggles to Relight a City of Darkness
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 18 - From his temporary headquarters on the top floor of the Hyatt Regency here, Daniel F. Packer, the chief executive of Entergy New Orleans, has a perfect vantage point for viewing the problem confronting his beleaguered utility company: lights twinkling in dozens of neighborhoods, but darkness spread across 40 percent of the city.

title: Examination of Sex and Violence in Four Distinct Ways
description: There are not three, but four sides to every human triangle, especially one involving sex and violence, and Glyn Maxwell examines each of them in minute detail in "Broken Journey," a modern-day rendering of "Rashomon" that is being given a gripping production by the Phoenix Theater Ensemble.

title: Movies on TV
description: THE LIFE AQUATIC WITH STEVE ZISSOU (2004)Saturday at 9 p.m. on StarzSteve (Bill Murray) is a world-weary ocean explorer who never lets an opportunity for pop-culture branding pass him by. But now he's angry: His sidekick has been eaten by a shark, and he vows revenge. The comedy that follows, however, bears absolutely no resemblance to "Moby-Dick." Anjelica Huston plays Steve's wife, Jeff Goldblum his rival and Owen Wilson a young man who may be his illegitimate son. Wes Anderson, who gave the world "The Royal Tenenbaums," directed and wrote, with Noah Baumbach ("The Squid and the Whale"), the screenplay.

title: Making Sure the Cleanup Is Clean
description: DISASTERS bring about the best, and sometimes the worst, in human behavior. So do disaster cleanups. With tens of billions of dollars at stake, and a sense of emergency overriding normal checks and balances, the potential for fraud, waste and abuse rides like a poisonous tide in the wakes of Hurricanes Katrina and Rita. While hurricanes can't be stopped, however, fraud and abuse can.

title: The Neediest Cases; The Hardship and Fleeting Joys of a Mother With Dyslexia
description: Growing up in the South Bronx, Joselyn Lopez hid the fact that she could not read by using a good ear and a good memory.

title: Trip Ends Same Way It Began for Knicks
description: DENVER, Nov. 18 - The journey spanned six cities and 10 days and at the end of it all, the Knicks found themselves worse than weary. They were disjointed and dispirited, with their star player baffled about his role and everyone else just generally out of sorts.

title: Life After Near-Death: A Normalcy in Football
description: EASTON, Pa. - Lafayette fullback David Nelson walked into his off-campus apartment in early August, two months behind schedule.

title: Cautiously, China Honors Leader Linked to Tiananmen Unrest
description: BEIJING, Nov. 18 - With security heavy and a veil of secrecy, China on Friday officially rehabilitated a former Communist Party leader whose death in 1989 set off huge student demonstrations.

title: As Italian Vote Nears, It's Hard to Tell Hawks From Doves
description: ROME, Nov. 18 - Outsiders might be forgiven for being puzzled.

title: G.E. to Sell Insurance Business to Swiss Re
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it was selling its troubled reinsurance business for $6.8 billion to Swiss Re, which will become the largest company in the world selling insurance to insurance companies.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   RICH, GORDON A.
description: RICH--Gordon A. Nov. 8, 1957--Nov. 19, 2000. Five years gone. Your spirit lives. Loving you, missing you, now and forever. Mom and Dad

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NEWBERRY, ELSA KINGMAN
description: NEWBERRY--Elsa Kingman. Of Pomperaug Woods, Southbury, CT. Widow of F. Stark Newberry died November 17 in her 96th year. Daughter of Dr. Russell B. and Ethel (Spencer) Kingman, she is survived by three children, Anne Newberry Pineda, Andrew Todd Newberry and Barbara Newberry Lindsley, numerous grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be on Tuesday, November 22 at 9:30 A.M. at the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany, Southbury. Interment private.

title: Children, Apples of Parents' Eyes, Face Arrows on TV
description: In last week's episode of "Criminal Minds," the new CBS series in which Mandy Patinkin plays a profiler for the F.B.I., a young family, readying for a vacation, are shown tucking themselves into bed. The wife is blond and beautiful, the father strapping; the children are dear.

title: A Foreign Correspondent Who Does More Than Report
description: The Great War for Civilisation The Conquest of the Middle East By Robert Fisk 1,107 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $40.

title: Ugly Images of Asian Rivals Become Best Sellers in Japan
description: Correction Appended

title: Both Sides Share Goal in Trial of Former Democratic Leader
description: Correction Appended

title: Money Takes Up a Lot of Time
description: I CAN'T believe what it takes to manage my finances these days. I'm not talking about anything complicated, like weighing the merits of exchange-traded funds -- just the endless pile-up of money chores.

title: East Has a Fistful of Diamonds and Knows When to Play Them
description: The Fall North American Bridge Championships are under way in the Adam's Mark hotel, Denver. The Nationals were last held in Denver in the fall of 1978. Then, the winners of the prestigious Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams were an early Aces quartet of Bob Hamman, Bobby Wolff, Fred Hamilton and Ira Rubin, with Ira Corn Jr., the Aces' founder, as the nonplaying captain. Hamman is one of the defending champions this year; he has had a phenomenal career.

title: A Doctor Faces the Odds (All Kinds) at Foxwoods
description: In 1980 the tiny Mashantucket Pequot Tribal Nation successfully sued to regain land it had lost in the 17th century.

title: Hispanic Peers Back Menendez for the Senate
description: Prominent Hispanic elected officials are putting pressure on Democratic leaders for New Jersey's governor-elect, Jon S. Corzine, to appoint Representative Robert Menendez to fill his seat in the Senate.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a schedule note in Weekend yesterday with an opera review about the Juilliard Opera Center's production of "A Midsummer Night's Dream" misstated the location. It is tomorrow at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater at Juilliard, 165 West 65th Street, not the Peter Jay Sharp Theater at Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street.

title: The Star It Was Made for Returns to Opera at the Met
description: The Metropolitan Opera's new production of Gounod's "Romo et Juliette" opened on Monday without the star for whom it was created: the French coloratura soprano Natalie Dessay, who was to sing Juliette but was sidelined with a bad cold.

title: Cameron Passes Test, and the Trade Is Official
description: Mike Cameron passed his eye test yesterday in San Diego, completing the deal that sends him to the Padres for Xavier Nady, whom Mets General Manager Omar Minaya touted as a potential member of the team's core.

title: Foreign Investors Pour Money Into Bonds Every Minute, Every Day
description: CALL it the trillion-dollar investment.

title: Computing the Cost of 'Acting White'
description: Roland Fryer, a Harvard economist, has done a couple of very clever things. First he devised a mathematical technique for identifying the coolest kids in school. Then he came up with a surprising answer to a tougher question: If a black student does well in school, will his black friends shun him and accuse him of "acting white"?

title: In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
Dixie Cups and Paper Towels Sell Well
description: JUST as some retailers seem to think it is never too early to start shopping for Christmas, they also think it is never too early to start worrying about how much Christmas shoppers will spend. So when big retail chains like Wal-Mart turned on the holiday hype earlier than usual this year, it only accelerated the holiday hand-wringing.

title: Yale Alumni Strike Back atTailgating Limits
description: When Yale University distributed new rules last month to curb binge drinking and public drunkenness at football games, the reaction was swift. But the loudest outcry came not from students but from alumni who have returned here for decades to watch the Yale Bulldogs and to fraternize at often-elegant tailgate parties.

title: Are the Birds and the Bees Right for the 3's?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Policy of Deceit
description: Jackson, Miss. - RESIDENTS of the Mississippi Gulf Coast withstood a devastating blow from Hurricane Katrina. Now, as they face the enormous task of rebuilding, they are threatened with yet another crippling misfortune -- this time at the hands of insurance companies, which are trying to deny coverage. That's why the State of Mississippi has filed suit to get the courts to clarify that insurance companies must cover the water damage that policyholders sustained from the hurricane.

title: Mayor Takes a Long Weekend (Maybe)
description: For the first time in recent memory, it appears that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is taking a long weekend off. He had no scheduled events yesterday or today, and he was nowhere to be seen around City Hall.

title: Preserving the Earth, One Joke at a Time
description: LAS VEGAS, Nov. 18 - Ice caps are melting. Oceans are rising. Villages are disappearing. Wild animals are not quite sure what is going on.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANKLIN, MARTIN
description: FRANKLIN--Martin of Little Neck, NY on November 17, 2005. Beloved husband of Isabel (nee Elman). Devoted father of Teri and Peter Herzog, Ticker and John Bashen, and "adopted" daughter Judi. Loving brother of Larry. Dear friend of Carole. Loving brother-in-law of Beverly. Adored grandfather of Jordan, Michy and Josh. Cherished great-grandfather of Caleb. Services Sunday 2:15pm at "Gutterman's", 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, LI.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Advertising column in Business Day on Wednesday about online casinos that pay celebrities to promote Internet gambling misstated the type of commercials that the ESPN network accepts. It runs ads for horse racing, not ads for sports betting over the Internet.

title: The Rose That Is a Thorn in Chvez's Side
description: CARACAS, Venezuela - SHE'S the Venezuelan government's most detested adversary, a young woman with a quick wit and machine-gun-fast delivery who often appears in Washington or Madrid to denounce what she calls the erosion of democracy under President Hugo Chvez.

title: Burglaries Are Causing Jitters in a Quiet Enclave of the Bronx
description: In one burglary, a $10,000 silver Tiffany vase from the late 19th century was stolen from a big Georgian-style house overlooking the Hudson River. In others, laptop computers, jewelry, silverware and ceremonial silver cups were taken from residences in the same wealthy neighborhood of Riverdale in the Bronx.

title: Ziff Davis Plans to Close Sync Magazine
description: Sync magazine, a men's magazine devoted to electronic gear and gadgetry, will close after 18 months of publication, a spokesman for its parent company, Ziff Davis Media, said yesterday. The final issue will be on newsstands Dec. 6.

title: In Skeleton, a Broken Leg Hurts Hopes of U.S. Women
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Nov. 18 - As they competed here on Friday in the second World Cup event of the season , the members of the United States women's skeleton squad still had Noelle Pikus-Pace in mind as they focused on trying to make the 2006 Olympic team.

title: INSIDE
description: New Grand Jury to Hear About C.I.A. Leak Case The special prosecutor in the C.I.A. leak case, Patrick J. Fitzgerald, said he would use a new grand jury, a development that seems certain to extend the political cloud hanging over the Bush administration and could draw new players into the investigation. The previous grand jury's term expired last month. PAGE A10

title: Corrections
description: An article and a headline in Business Day on Thursday about China's regulatory approval of a new cancer therapy referred imprecisely to how unusual it was. The approval was the first anywhere for a cancer therapy using a virus that attacks tumor cells; it was not the first for a gene therapy, which China granted in 2003 to a different company, SiBono GeneTech, for a cancer treatment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SERLIN, FRED
description: SERLIN--Fred of Boca Raton, Fl. Beloved husband of Gert, devoted father of Leslie Weiskopf (Alan), dear grandfather of Alyssa Zeff and Jo Ann, brother of Ed. Graveside services at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY Sunday 11 A.M. (Call 1-888351-4414 for information)

title: The Shape of Taxes to Come
description: There are important differences in the two tax bills now moving through the Senate and the House. Depending on how the bills are melded into one, the American people could end up with a train wreck of a tax law, or a reasonable compromise.

title: As Befits Royalty, Organist Offers an Elegant Baroque Selection
description: Many performers come from musical families, but Marie-Claire Alain hails from something more: French organ royalty. Her father, Albert Alain, was born in 1880 and became a noted performer, composer and even builder of his own instruments. Her brother, Jehan Alain, became a major 20th-century organ composer, even though he was killed tragically young while fighting in World War II.

title: In Mount Vernon, Fights Close a High School Early
description: A series of fights broke out at Mount Vernon High School in southern Westchester County on Friday, prompting school officials to lock down the school shortly after lunch and send students home early.

title: National Briefs
description: SOUTHWEST

title: Luge Champ Is Favored, but Feels Heat of Hometown Expectations
description: CESANA, Italy, Nov. 18 - The day before the World Cup luge races on the Olympic track were to start here, Armin Zoeggeler was trying desperately to fend off the popular story line that he is the home-country hero who will turn loose an Italian celebration with a gold medal in February.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Nov. 9 about a planned renovation of the New Yorker Hotel in Manhattan misattributed the design of the Empire State Building, and a correction in this space on Monday misstated the architectural firm's name. It is Shreve, Lamb & Harmon, not Sugarman & Berger.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Nov. 9 about a planned renovation of the New Yorker Hotel in Manhattan misattributed the design of the Empire State Building, and a correction in this space on Monday misstated the architectural firm's name. It is Shreve, Lamb & Harmon, not Sugarman & Berger.

title: Prosecutor in Leak Case Calls for New Grand Jury
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 - The special prosecutor in the C.I.A. leak case said on Friday that he would use a new grand jury in his continuing investigation, a development that seemed certain to extend the political cloud hanging over the Bush administration and could draw new players into the investigation.

title: Ex-HealthSouth Executive Convicted at Trial
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. Nov. 18 - A federal jury convicted a former executive of the HealthSouth Corporation on Friday of conspiracy and lying to auditors in connection with the $2.7 billion fraud at the company.

title: $100 Billion in the Hands of a Computer
description: PEOPLE ask me all the time: What's your secret?" James Simons said.

title: AIDS Testing at Home
description: Rapid AIDS tests that yield results in 20 minutes have revolutionized outreach counseling and greatly improved efforts aimed at slowing the spread of infection. With the older test, which required two weeks, about a third of the people tested at AIDS clinics never returned to pick up their results. Those who never learned that they had tested positive most likely went on to infect others through unprotected sex or by sharing needles during intravenous drug use.

title: A Hawk Narrowly Wins Sri Lanka Presidential Election
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, Nov. 18 - Mahinda Rajapakse, the Sri Lankan prime minister who spent his campaign for president honing a hawk's reputation, narrowly won the race on Friday, raising new questions about how this island nation, which has suffered more than 20 years of civil war, would achieve peace.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the C.I.A. leak investigation gave outdated information about Paul D. Wolfowitz's response to queries about any role he might have had. When asked if Mr. Wolfowitz, the president of the World Bank, had told Bob Woodward the identity of the C.I.A. officer in the case, his spokesman initially did not reply to requests for comment, but later said that Mr. Wolfowitz was not the source. (Go to Article)

title: Senate Bill Would Renew Insurers' Aid on Terrorism
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 - The Senate on Friday passed legislation that would extend a program that required the federal government to cover insurance losses in cases involving catastrophic terrorist attacks.

title: National Briefings | Religion: Call For Troop Withdrawal
description: More than 2,000 delegates at a national convention in Houston of the Union for Reform Judaism voted overwhelmingly to call on the Bush administration to produce an exit strategy for American forces in Iraq and to begin withdrawing troops after the Dec. 15 elections there. The union, with 1.5 million members, represents the largest branch of Judaism in the United States. The resolution also condemns the torture and abuse of detainees in American custody and calls for a bipartisan, independent commission to investigate the lessons learned from what it calls the war's failures. Laurie Goodstein (NYT)

title: U.S. and Europe Reach Tentative Airline Accord
description: PARIS, Nov. 18 - The European Union and the United States struck a preliminary accord on Friday to increase trans-Atlantic airline access.

title: For a G.M. Family, the American Dream Vanishes
description: Correction Appended

title: At the Edge of Respectability, a Celebration
description: "If it wasn't for one thing, I'd call your brother a bald-faced liar," one character says.

title: G.O.P. Operative Mixed Charm and Ruthlessness
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 - Even among the ambitious Republican aides driving the Clinton impeachment case in 1998, Michael Scanlon stood out.

title: Road to a Big Ten Crown Is Lined With Attractions
description: The road through Pennsylvania, Ohio and Michigan travels through mountains and past farms and automobile factories. As snow flurries swirl, voices on the car radio chatter about the conclusion of a memorable Big Ten football season.

title: CONE INTERESTED IN BROADCASTING
description: David Cone, the former Mets and Yankees pitcher, said he had some interest in a part-time broadcasting job with the Mets' new TV network. "We're still figuring it out," Cone said. "I tried to be honest with them and let them know I'm not really ready to travel full time."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAMASHEK, GEORGE
description: DAMASHEK - George. A rare, principled man and compassionate attorney, he was loved and respected by all who knew him. Tirelessly devoted to his family, his friends and his work, he extended himself on behalf of those whose lives he touched. He will forever be remembered by his wife Zelda, his daughter Sandy, his sons Robert and Ron and their spouses, his sisters Nancy and Bea, his brother Dave, and grandchildren, Elliot, Aaron, Samuel, and Ruth. Services Sunday November 20, 1:30PM Westchester Reform Temple, Scarsdale, NY.

title: Arts, Briefly; New Museum Director Is Named in San Francisco
description: After an eight-month search for a new director, the board of the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco announced the appointment of John E. Buchanan Jr., effective Feb. 1. Mr. Buchanan, who was executive director of the Portland Art Museum in Oregon for 11 years, replaces Harry S. Parker III, who for 18 years has run the Fine Art Museums, which include the de Young Museum in Golden Gate Park and the Legion of Honor in Lincoln Park. Mr. Parker, 65, is retiring next month, two months after opening the de Young's new $135 million building, designed by the Swiss architects Herzog and de Meuron. CAROL VOGEL

title: A Congressman's Plea on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a Bush administration report on the price of cocaine misstated the name of an independent group whose director was quoted assessing the report. It is the Drug Policy Alliance and is no longer called the Lindesmith Center-Drug Policy Foundation.

title: Lincoln Center's Man With the Trumpet, With Orchestra
description: Just before the lights dimmed in the Rose Theater on Thursday night, a voice announced that while the use of cellphones was prohibited, hand-clapping, foot-stomping and cries of "Aw, yeah!" were all welcome forms of audience participation. It was a hokier introduction than one might have expected from a concert called "Wynton With Strings." But in a way, it suited both subject and setting.

title: Gators, in Taking Title, Play Beyond Their Years
description: With Florida having lost its top three scorers from last season, it was believed this was going to be a rebuilding year for the Gators men's basketball team. It may be time to rethink that assumption.

title: A Birthday Party Not All Fun and Games
description: Whoever said that little girls are made of sugar and spice and everything nice never spent time at one of the little monsters' birthday parties. One might point such naA fs to Heather Harrington's "Devil's Playground," which opened Thursday night at Danspace Project in St. Mark's Church.

title: Lottery Numbers
Panel Advises New Orleans to Relinquish Purse Strings
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 18 - The city should turn over its finances to a municipal oversight board similar to the one that helped New York through its fiscal crisis in the 1970's, a prominent planning group recommended on Friday.

title: Bush and Putin Want Iran to Treat Uranium in Russia
description: PUSAN, South Korea, Nov. 18 - Presenting a united front against Iran, President Bush and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said Friday that they would press Iran to reverse itself and accept a compromise allowing it to enrich uranium, but only in Russia and under strict controls.

title: BUSINESS BRIEFS
description: Former Refco Executive Pleads Not Guilty To Eight Charges in Accounting Scandal The former chief executive of Refco, Phillip R. Bennett, pleaded not guilty yesterday to eight counts of conspiracy, fraud and other charges related to an accounting scandal that drove the futures brokerage company into bankruptcy. Mr. Bennett, 57, left, is accused of hiding hundreds of millions of dollars in bad debts from Refco investors as the company went public in August. Refco, based in New York, was the largest independent futures and commodities brokerage in the nation before the scandal prompted customers to abandon the firm, forcing it to file for bankruptcy last month. No trial date was set but Judge Naomi Reice Buchwald of United States District Court in Manhattan set another hearing for Jan. 18. Mr. Bennett, a British citizen, was indicted on Nov. 10 on eight charges related to the accounting scandal. He was released on a $50 million bond but confined to his penthouse on Park Avenue and monitored electronically. (Reuters)

title: A Congressman's Plea on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Uptown College Program Takes On Downtown Style
description: A move south for the Barnard College dance department to Dance Theater Workshop on Thursday night represents more than just geographical displacement from the campus theaters where the students performed for decades. Under its former director, Janet Soares, the department presented programs that included classics and works by established choreographers like Mark Morris.

title: The Grandeur of Evolution in a New Exhibition Called 'Darwin'
description: In the summer of 1868, Charles Darwin and his family visited the poet Alfred Tennyson and his family on the Isle of Wight. The visit -- and the visitor's ideas -- troubled Tennyson. "What I want," he later told a friend, "is an assurance of immortality."

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Blast Kills Portuguese Peacekeeper
description: One member of a patrol of Portuguese peacekeepers was killed and two were wounded by an explosion 10 miles southeast of Kabul. A spokeswoman for the NATO-led peacekeeping force said investigators were trying to determine whether the explosion was a land mine or an improvised explosive device. An Afghan Interior Ministry spokesman said the bomb appeared to have been hidden in a street drain. On Monday, a double suicide bombing in Kabul killed a German peacekeeper and nine Afghan bystanders. Abdul Waheed Wafa (NYT)

title: A Congressman's Plea on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Hearing Is Latest Twist in Owens-Eagles Saga
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 - After a hearing that lasted more than 14 hours Friday, receiver Terrell Owens's grievance against the Philadelphia Eagles was expected to be ruled upon by early next week.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,076 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: RIVALRIES -- LUNCH TO DINNER
Uproar in House as Parties Clash on Iraq Pullout
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 - Republicans and Democrats shouted, howled and slung insults on the House floor on Friday as a debate over whether to withdraw American troops from Iraq descended into a fury over President Bush's handling of the war and a leading Democrat's call to bring the troops home.

title: Top Names Aid Fund for Libby
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 - Several dozen prominent political and business leaders have pledged to help organize a drive to raise millions of dollars for the legal defense of I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney who was indicted last month on perjury and obstruction charges, an aide to Mr. Libby said on Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCNULTY, JOHN P.
description: McNULTY--John P., 52. Of Short Hills, N.J., Naples, FL, and Aspen, CO, a senior director at Goldman Sachs, passed away suddenly on Wednesday, November 16 in Naples. The son of Nora Sweeney McNulty and Charles McNulty, John was born on October 31, 1952, in Philadelphia, PA. After earning his B.S. from St. Joseph's University in 1974 and his M.B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania Wharton School of Business in 1979, John went on to a distinguished 22-year career at Goldman Sachs. Under his leadership, the firm built a global investment management business that became a significant and integral part of the firm. John became a partner in 1990 and a managing director in 1996. He retired in June of 2001, but continued to serve as a Senior Director at the firm. At the time of his retirement, John was the head of the Investment Management Division and a member of the firm's Management Committee. Outside of Goldman Sachs, John was a strong advocate for education and the arts. He served on the Board of Trustees at the University of Pennsylvania Wharton School of Business, chaired St. Joseph's University's Finance Committee and was an advisory director at the Metropolitan Opera. He also was a patron of St. Joseph's School in Chinatown. In addition, John served as a trustee of The Aspen Institute and on the board of the Carnival Corporation & PLC. John is survived by his wife, Anne, and their three children, John, Brynne and Kevin, his mother and his siblings, Noreen Tully, Charles McNulty, Kevin McNulty and Mary Grady. There will be a viewing Monday, November 21, 2005, from 9-11AM at the Cathedral of Sts. Peter and Paul, 18th Street and The Benjamin Franklin Parkway, Philadelphia. A funeral mass will follow at 11:00AM at the same location. Those interested in making memorial contributions may forward them to: The John P. McNulty Scholarship Fund for Excellence in Science and Math, 1300 3rd Street South, Naples, FL 34102. $(6$)McNULTY--John. The Patrons Program is deeply saddened by the untimely death of John McNulty, the Patron of St. Joseph School in Manhattan. Because of his and Anne's generosity, St. Joseph's inner-city elementary school children enjoyed academic learning and outstanding enhancement programs. He profoundly cared about the well-being and success of the students and the school's future. John kept all of us on our toes with his astute observations and graciously opened up his personal rolodex to propel any initiative forward. His presence will be sorely missed at St. Joseph School. We extend our sincerest sympathy to Anne and his children. Jill Kafka, Executive Director The Patrons Program Sister Deborah Lopez Principal, St. Joseph School $(6$)McNULTY--John. The Board of Directors, the faculty and the staff of the NYU Child Study Center mourn the death of our board member and friend John McNulty. John was a brilliant and creative businessman and philanthropist, a devoted and proud father to John, Brynne and Kevin, and a loving and dedicated partner to his wife Anne. We share the sorrow of his wonderful family. Brooke Garber Neidich Chair Harold S. Koplewicz, M.D. Director $(6$)McNULTY--John. We will miss your friendship, loyalty and the laughter we have shared over the years. You have been an inspiration to us; we will never forget the things you have taught us or the memories we have created. Our nights will never be the same without your evening calls. All our love to Anne, Johnny, Brynne and Kevin. We love you. Eric Lane and Sarah Dillon $(6$)McNULTY--John. There are partners and then there was John. There are philanthropists and then there was John. There are mentors and then there was John. There are good friends and then there is especially John. Lyn and George Barbara and Eric

title: How to Tame an InflatedEntertainment Budget
description: Correction Appended

title: Soaring Copper Prices Feed Talk of a Bluff by China and Its Mystery Trader
description: LONDON, Nov. 18 - This much is true in the copper market: Prices are at record highs, and there is a Chinese trader named Liu Qibing.

title: A Congressman's Plea on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Big Houses, Big Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOLKER, LEON (LEE)
description: KOLKER--Leon (Lee), 95. Survived by loving wife of 37 years, Betty Lee March Kolker; previously married to the late Myrtle Picker Kolker. Father of Anne and Thomas, grandfather of Joanne and Amy, stepfather to Ward, Tom and Bill Blum, and children. 1931 graduate of MIT. Owner of Kolker Chemical of Newark, NJ and Houston, TX. Trustee of Elmira College. Honorary Consul General of The Gambia, 1973-1986. Services private. In lieu of flowers please send donations in his name to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave, NY, NY 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FLOCH, ERNA
description: FLOCH--Erna. Of Palm City and Tequesta, Florida died on October 16, 2005 at the age of 96 following a stroke. She was preceded in death by her husband, Alex Floch, and her brother, Ernst Vesely. She is survived by her sister, Ursula Globig of Carvoveiro, Portugal, and her cousin, Cecille Davis of New York and many loving nieces and nephews and their families. Erna was widely admired for her strength and positive outlook and will be missed by her extended family and many friends. Services will be held in Rosedale Cemetery in New Jersey. Memorial gifts in Erna's honor may be made to Archie Carr National Wildlife Refuge, 4424 NW 13th St., Suite A-1, Gainesville, FL 32609 or Treasure Coast Wildlife Hospital and Center, 8434 SW 48th Avenue, Palm City, FL. 34990, or to a charity of your choice.

title: Are the Birds and the Bees Right for the 3's?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ready, Aim, Shop
description: As contact sports go, there is nothing quite like the four weeks before Christmas. For consumers, every door-busting trip to the neighborhood strip mall is an adventure, if not a near-death experience. For retailers, which generate as much as a third of their annual sales during this manic month, it's a question of survival. And every holiday season has its subplots. Here are five to keep an eye on:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EDELSTEIN, JULIUS C.C.
description: EDELSTEIN--Julius C.C. Educator and public servant, died peacefully in his sleep on November 18, 2005. He will be remembered with much love, awe and pride. Contributions may be made to the Julius C.C. Edelstein Scholarship Fund at Hunter College. A memorial service will be held at a date to be announced. $(6$)EDELSTEIN--Julius C.C. The City University of New York community deeply mourns the passing of Senior Vice Chancellor Emeritus, Julius C.C. Edelstein, who contributed enormously over the many decades to the development and growth of our University system. As a prominent advisor to U.S. presidents and senators, governors and mayors, international leaders, and CUNY chancellors, he is best remembered at CUNY for his lifelong commitment to, and compassion for, economically and educationally disadvantaged students. His brilliant writing and wry sense of humor, combined with a twinkle in his eye and a delightful laugh, will always be remembered by his CUNY family. We express our deepest sympathy to his beloved daughter, Suzy, and his extended family. Benno C. Schmidt, Jr. Chairperson, Board of Trustees Matthew Goldstein Chancellor $(6$)EDELSTEIN--Julius C.C. The Board, staff and members of United Neighborhood Houses of New York, Inc. mourn the death of our Emeritus Board Member, and father of our colleague Suzy Edelstein. For decades, Julius was a leading civic figure in New York City and a great friend and supporter of the settlement house system. He dedicated his life to the cause of social justice and to reforming public policies that would benefit the less privileged of the City he loved. Sidney Lapidus, President Nancy Wackstein, Executive Director $(6$)EDELSTEIN -- Julius C.C. Brooklyn College mourns the passing of Sr. Vice Chancellor Emeritus, Julius C.C. Edelstein, a close friend and steadfast supporter of the College. Throughout a long and distinguished career as influential policymaker, educator and administrator, Julius Edelstein was an unrelenting advocate of public higher education and of the City University of New York. Christoph M. Kimmich, President $(6$)EDELSTEIN -- Julius. We mourn the loss of our dear friend and send condolences to his family. A seminal figure with a significant impact on CUNY and its Graduate Center, he was deeply dedicated to this City and the cause of higher education for all. He served as a remarkable, influential, and positive force for many, many years. William P. Kelly, President, CUNY Graduate Center

title: A Man's Spiritual Journey From Kierkegaard to General Motors
description: When Peter F. Drucker died eight days ago, the only specifically religious reference that appeared in most obituaries was "guru" -- as in "management guru." It was, incidentally, a term he despised.

title: Russell Crowe Pleads Guilty to Assaulting Hotel Clerk
description: After a wild scrum of full-contact paparazzi and reporters nearly stopped him from entering a Manhattan courthouse, Russell Crowe, the film actor, walked, astonished, into a hushed courtroom, bowed his head and pleaded guilty yesterday to assaulting a hotel desk clerk.

title: A Congressman's Plea on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption from The Associated Press on Thursday about the opening of the money laundering trial of the record producers Irv and Christopher Gotti misidentified the defendant shown arriving in Federal District Court in Brooklyn. He was Irv Gotti, not Christopher.

title: Another Dreadful Season for Columbia Draws to a Close
description: It was early in the season, but an Oct. 1 game against a quality Princeton team promised to be a defining moment in the Columbia football season.

title: Emerging From Geekdom, but at What Cost?
description: Gamers love to grouse about how the outside world doesn't get it. But even as they moan about how American culture often demonizes video games, many gamers deep down actually revel in their outsider status. That sense of camaraderie in a hidden world that most of the mainstream just doesn't understand has become a major part of the gamer psyche.

title: The Torture Of Prisoners
description: To the Editor:

title: City's Private Sector Shows Biggest Job Loss for October
description: New York City lost 11,000 jobs in October -- an 11 percent decrease from September. It is the greatest month-to-month loss since late 2003.

title: Shopper Alert: Grocery Stores Have a Future
description: As more consumers make their way to the "natural" and "organic" aisles of their local food stores, the supermarket business has found itself in a bit of a fix.

title: Iraqi Qaeda Leader Is Said to Vow Attacks on Jordan
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 18 - The top leader of Al Qaeda in Iraq has threatened to chop off the head of King Abdullah II and to attack tourist sites throughout Jordan, according to an audio recording posted Friday on a Web site. He also insisted that he never intended to attack a Muslim wedding in the triple suicide blasts that killed more than 60 people here last week.

title: Port Authority Says It Can Build 9/11 Memorial
description: Reasserting its own importance in the rebuilding of ground zero as the governor and the mayor push and pull over the site, the Port Authority said yesterday that it would be prepared to construct the World Trade Center memorial itself. It also unveiled its own vision of a big shopping complex along the Church Street side of the site.

title: South Korean Tells Japan's Leader to Stop Visiting Shrine
description: PUSAN, South Korea, Nov. 18 - President Roh Moo Hyun of South Korea urged Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan to stop visiting a nationalistic Japanese war memorial in a meeting here between the leaders on Friday, saying the visits raised fears of a revival of Japanese militarism.

title: Saturday's Top Games
description: No. 5 Penn State (9-1) at Michigan State (5-5) 4 p.m., ESPN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RICH, DANIEL E.
description: RICH--Daniel E., 31. Of New York, NY on November 16, 2005 after a long and courageous fight against all odds. Beloved son of Bruce and Judy Rich. Adored brother of Stacey, loving nephew and cousin, and devoted friend. Honors graduate of Cornell University and graduate of Emory University School of Law. Donations in his memory may be made to the Daniel E. Rich Fund, C/O Dr. Lisa De Angelis, Chair, Dept. of Neurology, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, West 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave. on Sunday, November 20 at 11:45 AM. $(6$)RICH--Daniel. We wish to express our deepest sympathies and condolences to our colleague Bruce Rich, and his family, on the loss of their son Daniel Rich. The Partners, Associates and Staff at Thelen Reid & Priest LLP

title: Stalking the Ferocious Clay Pigeon
description: MY wife pointed the business end of a 20-gauge Browning over-and-under at the pupil of my left eye. The twin muzzles of the shotgun were so close I could smell the cleaning oil. I squinted at the tiny silver sighting bead mounted on the rib above the top barrel. Then I sucked a long hard breath, all of a sudden feeling weak-kneed and squirmy.

title: Bush, in Beijing, Faces a Partner Now on the Rise
description: BEIJING, Nov. 19 - Fresh from another impassioned defense of his war leadership, President Bush arrived here on Saturday evening to defuse a host of tensions with China, even as many in Beijing argue that he will be able to apply little true pressure on the world's fastest-rising power.

title: A Congressman's Plea on Iraq (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: When a Village Fails a Child
description: There were opportunities to save Sierra Roberts, a bright-eyed 7-year-old from Queens who died while in the care of her father, but perhaps none more critical than two years ago, when she suffered a broken leg just months after her spine was fractured. Children's Services accepted the father's account that the injuries had been accidents.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Debate Pits Public Safety Against Sex Felons' Rights
description: ALBANY, Nov. 18 - For Vincent Scala, the debate over the civil confinement of sexual predators pits his personal beliefs as "a card-carrying member of the A.C.L.U." against his family ties.

title: A Hesitant Puerto Rico Tries Commuting by Train
description: SAN JUAN, P.R. - Carlos Medina rides the subway only when he visits New York. Here, where he lives, he spends untold hours in his car.

title: Red Sarachek, Innovator as Yeshiva Basketball Coach, Dies at 93
description: Correction Appended

title: The Cube, Restored, Is Back and Turning at Astor Place
description: Last March, when the familiar cube at Astor Place vanished abruptly, residents and visitors alike were bewildered. Some offered dark speculation about the disappearance. Those who crossed to the traffic island where the cube had stood for decades found three metal barricades and a notice from the Parks Department assuring viewers that the artwork formally known as "Alamo" had not gone missing, but had merely been taken away for repair.

title: The Rootkit of All Evil
description: SONY BMG can take two lessons from its recent wayward attempt to fend off digital piracy: One, in a world of technology-astute bloggers, it's not easy to get away with secretly infecting your customers' computers with potentially malicious code. And two, as many a politician has learned, explaining your own screw-up badly is often worse than the screw-up itself.

title: Coming Soon to Europe: Higher Rates
description: FRANKFURT, Nov. 18 - The European Central Bank said Friday that it was poised to raise interest rates, ending weeks of speculation about when Europe would join the United States in tightening credit.

title: Photos That Don't Capture Reality, but Change It
description: PARIS, Nov. 18 - If photography began escaping the shadow of painting a century ago, decades passed before it was widely recognized as an art unto itself. Today proof of its star status can be found in a four-day international fair called Paris Photo, which closes on Sunday. Clearly, the market for art photography is booming.

title: Nissan's Mr. Fix-It Is the Talk of Detroit
description: TOKYO, Nov. 18 - Carlos Ghosn, one of the world's smoothest car pitchmen, skipped a beat.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the killing of a 7-year-old girl, Sierra Roberts of Queens, whose father has been charged in the case, misstated the name of the church where her memorial service was held. It is the Humble Way Church of God in Christ Worldwide Ministries, not the Humbleway Church for God and Christ.

title: A Lapse in Judgment, Capitalized
description: BERNARD B. KERIK, who once led the police force of this city, uses such convoluted language on the Web site for his consulting company -- "an internationally respected global provider of Homeland Security and industrial security services" -- that he all but challenges us to crack the code. Having been trained in the Ovaltine school of decoding, we accept.

title: A Cold War China Policy
description: President Bush probably won't mention the word "containment" when he visits China this weekend. But his hosts can surely be excused for wondering whether his administration is now trying to revive that cold war anti-Soviet strategy and apply it to the very different circumstances of today's complex relationship between Washington and Beijing.

title: Arts, Briefly; All Too Easy for 'CSI'
description: The second half of a two-part episode of "CSI" (with Paul Guilfoyle, below), in which the forensics team meticulously retraced a complicated shootout between the police and some bad guys, was Thursday's most popular show, with an audience of 28.82 million. That led CBS to another easy Thursday victory among both total viewers and adults 18 to 49, according to Nielsen's estimates. The only chink in CBS's Thursday armor was "Without a Trace," which reached second place in the 18-to-49 demographic: once again, it lost to NBC's "ER," despite drawing nearly 6 million more viewers in total (21.33 million versus 15.34 million). CBS's "Survivor," however, dominated the 8 p.m. hour in the 18-to-49 age group, as well as in the wider audience, with 18.98 million viewers. But WB's "Smallville," also at 8, continued to be one of the season's biggest surprises, beating all the other networks among men 18 to 34, its target audience. In that demographic, the Clark Kent series's move to Thursday nights has allowed WB to increase its audience by 163 percent from last year in the 8 p.m. slot. KATE AURTHUR

title: Mosque Attacks Kill 70 in Iraq; Hotel Is Hit, Too
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 18 - As worshipers gathered for Friday Prayer, a pair of suicide bombers wearing explosive belts demolished two Shiite mosques in the northern Kurdish town of Khanaqin, killing at least 70 people and wounding more than 100.

title: Joseph Monserrat, 84, Leader in Efforts to Unify Latinos, Dies
description: Joseph Monserrat, a leader among Puerto Ricans in New York and the continental United States beginning in the days of their mass migration in the 1950's, died last Sunday at a nursing home in Greenwich Village. He was 84 and lived in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan.

title: The Four-Figure Cocktail
description: THERE is no reason the conversation should lag around the dinner table on Thursday, not when you're armed with these facts, anyway. GOBBLE GOBBLE -- In its first year of operation -- 1981 -- the Butterball Turkey help line got 11,000 calls from people who had questions about how to prepare the traditional Thanksgiving meal, Health magazine reports in its November issue.

title: On Capitol Hill, Ney Is the Mayor
description: Representative Bob Ney has represented a vast swath of southern and eastern Ohio for more than a decade. But in Washington, he is referred to as the mayor of Capitol Hill.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (NBC) LAW & ORDER: CRIMINAL INTENT -- Natalee Holloway's disappearance in Aruba is clearly the inspiration for this special two-hour episode. A teenage girl from Iowa disappears during her class trip to New York, and a judge's son (Matt O'Leary) is the prime suspect. Colm Meaney guest-stars as the judge. Four star detectives (Vincent D'Onofrio, above left, Chris Noth, right, Kathryn Erbe and Annabella Sciorra) get involved with the case.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "You guys are pathetic."

title: The Harlem Preacher
description: When the time came to replace a legendary Harlem pastor, the people of Canaan Baptist Church of Christ began a long and arduous journey.

title: On the Market: $2.5 million Loft
description: Reporter Anna Bahney leads a tour of a $2.5 million downtown loft apartment that is chic in style and unique in its contemporary renovation.

title: Newest Latte Flavor? Try a Library
description: MOST afternoons Marie Rendina, a retired office worker, heads for Caf Livre in the New Rochelle Public Library to enjoy a cup of coffee and a book. The book is no surprise; it's what you would expect to find in a library. But the latte and hazelnut muffins are signs of something new.

title: CHARITY FOR THE HOLIDAYS
description: To the Editor: Regarding "At the Holidays, Few Gifts for Travelers" (Oct. 30): If prospective vacationers decide against traveling during the holidays, because of rising costs, they could contribute part (or all) of the money they would have spent on traveling to a legitimate charity that is helping the victims of Hurricane Katrina or Wilma or another favorite cause. Thus, they would be dealing with their disappointment in a very constructive way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LYNAM, JULIA
description: LYNAM--Julia. On November 18, 2005. Beloved wife of the late William, loving daughter of Frances Connors, devoted mother of William X., Frances Gunnison and Mary - Jane McEneaney. Cherished grandmother of nine. Friends may call Monday 9am-10:45am at the Thomas F. Dalton Funeral Home, 412 Willis Ave, Williston Park, NY. Mass of Christian burial Monday, 11:15am, St. Aidan's RC Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Allison Goldstein and Drew Gutstein
description: Allison Goldstein, the daughter of Ronnie Goldstein and Dr. Lance Goldstein of Boynton Beach, Fla., is to be married this evening to Drew Gutstein, a son of Blanche Gutstein and the late Dr. Alan Gutstein of New York. Rabbi Tom Weiner is to officiate at the Puck Building in New York.

title: Logic Usually Wins the Day, but Gambling Clearly Can, Too
description: Chess tends to favor logic machines like Bobby Fischer, Garry Kasparov, Jos Raul Capablanca, Anatoly Karpov, Tigran Petrosian and Emanuel Lasker. But it also offers prizes and awards to gamblers like Alexander Alekhine, Frank Marshall and Mikhail Tal. The gamblers bank on imagination and inspiration and opponents who can't find their way in weird complications. Sometimes when they have overreached themselves, the players who have trusted in logic have to clutch on to whatever the gypsy life will allow.

title: The New Culture of Self-Medication
description: To the Editor:

title: He's Moving Up (and Moving Out, Too)
description: IN his 22 years, Ryan Bingham has run for office four times. He was elected sergeant-at-arms of his college fraternity, and in Torrington High School he won a seat on the student council and was president of the Young Republicans.

title: Feeling Lost and Found
description: KAROO BOY

title: Biggest Surprise For the Sixers Also Goes by A. I.
description: Before every game at the University of Arizona, Andre Iguodala watched the 1998 movie "He Got Game," looking for inspiration. Iguodala would cut it off at the same scene: right after Ray Allen's character, Jesus Shuttlesworth, walked off the playground and went on to win his high school state championship.

title: Pathways of Manhattan, and Places in the Heart
description: THE CONFERENCE OF THE BIRDS By Jeffrey Lewis Other Press ($22.95, hardcover)

title: Hello, I'm Your Sister. Our Father Is Donor 150.
description: Like most anonymous sperm donors, Donor 150 of the California Cryobank will probably never meet any of the offspring he fathered through sperm bank donations. There are at least four, according to the bank's records, and perhaps many more, since the dozens of women who have bought Donor 150's sperm are not required to report when they have a baby.

title: Andrea Brothman and Michael Frezel
description: Andrea Rose Brothman and Michael Lawrence Frezel were married last evening by Rabbi Jay M. Stein at Har Zion Temple in Penn Valley, Pa.

title: The Family Ticket; The Sixth Floor Of The Ritz-Carlton Boston
description: With the Plaza Hotel closed for renovations until at least late 2006, the Eloise set is in a state of despair. What will they do for five-star fun and games? Check into the "children's suite" at the Ritz-Carlton Boston. This kiddie-proportioned paradise can be monitored by parents or by nannies from an adjoining room and offers a stuffed-animal kingdom, a Disney DVD library, Nintendo, a bubble-bath kit, optional butler service ("Jeeves, bring me a cookie, now!") and a specially stocked minibar. To appease the little literati, it even has its own storybook heritage. In E.B. White's "Trumpet of the Swan," Louis the little swan has his own room at the hotel.

title: Bloomington, Minn: Crowne Plaza Minneapolis West
description: The Basics -- The area around the Mall of America -- which says it is Minnesota's top tourist attraction -- is thick with lodgings. Virtually every national hotel chain is represented in a few square miles, sometimes more than once. But until three years ago, the local Holiday Inn was "a dump," says Jim Saccoman, the general manager. Then the owners, an investment group based in Chicago, hired the Minneapolis architect James Dayton, whose projects include the new McPhail Center for the Arts, to redo the building. Mr. Dayton added a sleek metal awning out front -- signaling that contemporary architecture had arrived -- and revamped the interiors, giving them the look of a boutique hotel. If it is surprising that the owners of a Holiday Inn near the mall would try to emulate a "W," it is even more surprising that, for the most part, they have succeeded.

title: Iran Approves Bill to Bar U.N. From Visiting Nuclear Sites
description: TEHRAN, Nov. 20 - Iran's conservative Parliament approved the outline of a bill today that would bar United Nations inspectors from visiting its nuclear sites if the agency referred Iran's case to the Security Council for possible punitive measures.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Arts & Leisure

title: Heard on the Streets (of the Axis of Evil)
description: YOU might expect an American CD surveying Cambodian music to be a dry affair: an ethnographic overview of the country's folk styles, with academic notes indicating who the players are and when and where they were recorded. Put on "Radio Phnom Penh," released this year on the Seattle label Sublime Frequencies, and you might be very surprised.

title: 2006 Jeep Grand Cherokee: Refining the Rugged
description: REMEMBER the 90's? Is it too soon to be nostalgic for the quaint era of Bill Clinton and Newt Gingrich, Whitewater and Y2K, impeachment hearings and Internet stock bubbles, George Costanza and the Jeep Grand Cherokee?

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed last Sunday about the Atlantic Yards project in Brooklyn misstated some of its details. Plans for the project call for 16 buildings surrounding a sports arena, not 17, and for nine million square feet of construction, not 14 million.

title: Oh, Mr. Darcy ... Yes, I Said Yes!
description: IT was perhaps a little embarrassing to learn that the British producers of the latest "Pride and Prejudice" released a different ending for American audiences: a swoony moonlit scene of Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy in dishabille, kissing and cooing in a post-coital clinch.

title: The Winner Is. . . Only Acting Gay
description: GROUPS that hand out awards can be suckers for acting stunts, from Nicole Kidman's fake nose in "The Hours" to Adrien Brody's near-starvation for "The Pianist." The tradition is so entrenched that Kate Winslet, playing an outrageous comic version of herself in the HBO series "Extras," listed a surefire way to get that elusive Academy Award. "Daniel Day-Lewis in 'My Left Foot?' Oscar. Dustin Hoffman, 'Rain Man?' Oscar," she says. "Seriously, you are guaranteed an Oscar if you play a mental." Irreverent, imprecise (the Day-Lewis character was not mentally troubled) yet essentially true.

title: Let's Do Something
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENTHAL, ANN EDITH, (NEE PRINCE)
description: ROSENTHAL -- Ann Edith, (nee Prince). Of Boca Raton, FL, died on November 15, 2005. She remained vital and beautiful until her passing at the age of 95. Beloved wife of the late Edward H. Rosenthal, M.D. and mother of the late Nelson I. Rosenthal. She is survived by her children Alan David Rosenthal, M.D. and Enid Feldman Rosenthal; granddaughters Nina Michelle Fusillo and Amy Ilyse Rosenthal, grandson-in-law, Michael Fusillo, Ph.D., and great grandson Nathaniel James Fusillo. Her commitment to the community included membership on the board of the March of Dimes of Greater New York and a former president of the Brooklyn chapter of the National Council of Jewish Women. Her journey was long and varied but always traveled with elegance and a graceful expansion of her horizons. She will be deeply missed. Service on Sunday, November 20, at 11:30AM, at the "Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave, New York City. Contributions may be made to the March of Dimes of Greater New York.

title: A Sophisticated Eye for Nave Art
description: THE artist Richard Tuttle seems to share little with his minimalist cousins -- Sol LeWitt, Carl Andre, Dan Flavin -- but it's a good little. That is, a longstanding exploration of what constitutes art, well chronicled in the Whitney Museum retrospective of his work, which opened this month. While his colleagues have exalted fluorescent tubes and lead, Mr. Tuttle has thought smaller and weirder: string, wire, cloth, cans. Or some combination thereof, recalling the uneasy catchall genre known as outsider art.

title: Japanese fad: Comics that degrade Chinese and Koreans
Grunt's-Eye View, From Basic to Baghdad to Home
description: ANGIE WILLIS didn't know too much about what her husband's life was like in Baghdad. To ease her mind, Sgt. Steve Willis warned her to avoid the news and disclosed few details of his operations.

title: Rice Says She Wasn't Woodward's Leak Source
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 - Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice is not the source who told Bob Woodward of The Washington Post in June 2003 that the wife of the former diplomat Joseph C. Wilson IV worked at the C.I.A., the State Department spokesman said on Saturday.

title: Correction
description: The Modern Love column last Sunday omitted the byline. It was by Mindy Hung.

title: Movie English as a Third Language
description: BEIJING - In America, strict grammarians may bemoan the effects of popular culture on the standards of spoken English. In China, however, the latest fad in the huge market for English instruction comes in the form of "Action English," a television show that uses clips from Hollywood movies to teach what it calls "American slang."

title: Lauren Snow and Gregory Royce
description: Dr. Lauren Ellis Snow, a daughter of Margaret Ellis Snow and Dr. Robert B. Snow of Manhattan, was married last evening to Gregory Todd Royce, a son of Barbara Royce and Stephen A. Royce of Rye, N.Y. Barbara Newman, an acting State Supreme Court justice in the Bronx, officiated at the River Club, a private social club in Manhattan.

title: A Winter's Table: Thick, Juicy, Abundant
description: AS fall hardens into winter, something happens to our bodies. It may not be pretty, but it is primordial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZEIDEL, JULIUS
description: ZEIDEL--Julius. Of Teaneck, NJ. On November 18, 2005. Beloved husband of Beatrice in a 64 year marriage, and father to Susan and Beth. A great role model, a man of ethics who loved a good laugh and a good book. Arrangements pending.

title: Dispute Over Division of Authority at the U.N. Grows
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 20 - A growing dispute over the future division of authority at the United Nations has prompted showdown talk among diplomats and a warning from John R. Bolton, the American ambassador, that the United States may look elsewhere to settle international problems.

title: In This Corner, the Sofa Cushion
description: THANKSGIVING dinner is often scheduled for the late afternoon or early evening, so there is plenty of post-turkey time for families to socialize. Unfortunately, living-room conversations occasionally degenerate into arguments, especially when far-flung relatives of varying political persuasions or football fan bases are thrown together. The urge to bop one's father-in-law or cousin on the head can be powerful.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SILBERT, GERALD
description: SILBERT--Gerald. 10/26/2211/22/04. Beloved husband, cherished father, love never dies, fovever remembered. Ramie and Terry

title: Vienna Woods, via Long Island
description: No Long Island white equals Macari's 2005 Early Wine as a match for Thanksgiving turkey. The French would call it a nouveau. This scrumptious off-dry chardonnay, made from North Fork grapes, offers piquant grapefruit and orange-zest flavors and a creamy texture. Helmut Gangl, Macari's Austrian winemaker, gave it the fizz customary in young wines poured in Vienna Woods wine taverns. Vintage New York, 482 Broome Street (Wooster Street), SoHo, and 2492 Broadway (93rd Street), charges $13. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: Fund-Raising Fatigue Syndrome
description: IT'S that time of year again: The time when I send e-mail messages to everyone I know to announce "It's that time of year again" and try to lure them into attending my favorite nonprofit's annual dinner-dance. Mercifully, the computer frees me from having to grovel by phone, just as caller ID makes it possible to screen out those individuals whom I suspect of trying to hit me up for their own causes.

title: Beating the Heating: Alternatives to Fuel

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Nov. 20 -- Nov. 26; CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Typically, the first weeks of November are among the busiest of the classical music season. Then comes Thanksgiving week and almost everything seems to stop. But concertgoers still have some enticing choices. The dynamic German cellist JAN VOGLER will be the soloist with the New York Philharmonic on Friday and Saturday nights in Schumann's underappreciated Cello Concerto. The program opens intriguingly with the American premiere of "Berceuse for Dresden" by the British composer Colin Matthews. If only LORIN MAAZEL, who will conduct, had chosen something other than a warhorse, Dvorak's "New World" Symphony, to end the program, which already has a rich Romantic work in the Schumann. 8, Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212) 721-6500; $31 to $99.

description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 19 - Ohio State quarterback Troy Smith had 4 minutes 17 seconds and a good idea of what he wanted to do with the time as he leaned into the huddle at the Buckeyes' 12-yard line Saturday.

Nor was he pleased that I had already borrowed one from another source. And besides, he added, I wouldn't be able to figure out how to use it anyway.

description: PORTER--David. The East End Hospice Board of Directors, staff and volunteers note with sadness the death of David Porter, founding member of Hospice Board of Directors, artist, patron and loyal friend. David was devoted to helping others and we are truly grateful to have had the benefit of many years of his good counsel and fidelity. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Marion, extended family and many friends. Priscilla Ruffin, President W. There are at least four, according to the bank's records, and perhaps many more, since the dozens of women who have bought Donor 150's sperm are not required to report when they have a baby.

title: The Prodigy Puzzle
description: 'So you're the geniuses," Senator Carl Levin said, looking pleased as he peered over his glasses. He was addressing the flaxen-haired Heidi Kaloustian, a 17-year-old freshman at the University of Michigan, and John Zhou, a superfriendly 17-year-old senior at Detroit Country Day School, unusual visitors to Room 269 of the Russell Office Building on Capitol Hill. Michigan had distinguished itself, Levin had been informed: the state boasted two Davidson Fellows, and he had clearly been told these teenagers came trailing brainy superlatives. "Genius loves company," announced the September press release about the students who had won scholarships awarded annually since 2001 by the Davidson Institute for Talent Development, a foundation that supports "profoundly intelligent" youths, a more recent term for off-the-charts children. "Seventeen prodigies," the press release went on, were "to be honored at the Library of Congress for contributions to society" in the fields of science, math, technology, music and literature.

But when he ran this year, the story was different: he had a huge number of endorsements from those groups.
