description: Princeton, N.J. - SOMETHING rare and important happened in Washington on Tuesday. But you might have missed it if you read your newspaper too quickly. The Senate held a hearing on the nomination of Ben Bernanke to be the new chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROEBLING, FERDINAND W. III
description: ROEBLING--Ferdinand W. III died November 15 at his home in Mantoloking, New Jersey at the age of 95. He was born in Trenton, New Jersey and resided there until moving to Lambertville, New Jersey in 1946. He was a graduate of the Pomfret School in Pomfret, Connecticut. He graduated in 1933 from Princton University with a degree in Engineering. He was a Senior Vice President and Chief of Engineering at John A. Roebling Sons where he worked until the company was sold in 1953. He worked at the successor company, Colorado Fuel and Iron, as a Senior Vice President in charge of Engineering until 1965. He was the great gradson of John A. Roebling, the designer of the Brooklyn Bridge and the founder of John A. Roebling Sons Company of Trenton, New Jersey. He was the great nephew of Washington Roebling who completed construction of the Brooklyn Bridge as Designer and Chief Engineer after his father died during construction of the bridge. He was the son of Ferdinand W. Roebling, Jr. who was President of the family company until his death in 1963. He was predeceased by his brother Joseph M. Roebling, who was Chairman of the Board of John A. Roebling Sons Company until 1953. During World War II he served in the Army Corp. of engineers for 4 years. He went to Europe and left in 1945 with a rank of Lieutenant Colonel. He was predeceased by his first wife Mary Van Campen Schley of New York City. He is survived by their two children, Mary Roebling Foster of Pennington, New Jersey and William Schley Roebling of Princeton, New Jersey. He is survived by his second wife, Kate Maddock Roebling and two stepdaughters, Lynn Prior Harrington and Kay Prior Everitt. M. William Murphy Funeral Home, Ewing, NJ.

title: Chasing the Cashmere Crocodile
description: This year shoppers don't seem to get enough of cashmere, and Lacoste's new pique-stitch sweaters for men and women are no exception. The pullovers ($275 to $350 at Lacoste stores) arrived in shops the first week of November and quickly sold out. Like the classic polo shirts that inspired them, the sweaters seem to satisfy both form and function requisites. In saturated pastels and rich neutrals, the collection comes in a V-neck style for women and a crew neck style for men. Relaxed but pulled together, the sweaters are equally appropriate for a Palm Beach holiday, a Snow Valley outing or thrown on over jeans anywhere. PULSE

So Good!" -- its Superdog as long as a garden hose.

title: Great Expectations Come in Threes

title: Movies on TV
description: THE LIFE AQUATIC WITH STEVE ZISSOU (2004) Saturday at 9 p.m. on Starz Steve (Bill Murray, right) is a world-weary ocean explorer who never lets an opportunity for pop-culture branding pass him by. But now he's angry: His sidekick has been eaten by a shark, and he vows revenge. The comedy that follows, however, bears absolutely no resemblance to "Moby-Dick." Anjelica Huston plays Steve's wife, Jeff Goldblum his rival and Owen Wilson a young man who may be his illegitimate son. Wes Anderson, who gave the world "The Royal Tenenbaums," directed and wrote, with Noah Baumbach ("The Squid and the Whale"), the screenplay.

title: The Basics; When Did They Know It?
description: Last week, Bob Woodward of The Washington Post revealed that he was among the first journalists to discuss the identity of Valerie Wilson, the covert C.I.A. operative, with Bush administration officials. The disclosure ensured that officials will be checking their 2003 datebooks very carefully. Further investigation of the leak will surely focus on the period from June to July 2003, when the first rumors and interviews began. BILL MARSH

title: Pride, Straight Up
description: If a visitor stops in at LeNell's on Van Brunt Street in Red Hook, Brooklyn, in the late afternoon or evening, he or she will probably find a few locals standing around chewing the fat. The two-year-old liquor store, which is decorated with an eclectic mix of antiques, bourbon memorabilia and kitsch, also features a fully functional replica of Manneken-Pis, the landmark Brussels statue of a little boy urinating in a pool. Whiskey, the resident calico cat, snoozes on the counter. Delta blues play in the background.

title: Oaxaca
description: WHY GO NOW -- Equally cosmopolitan, but far more tranquil than Mexico City, Oaxaca is fast becoming the artistic capital of Mexico, drawing artists from around the country while shepherding its own to acclaim. It's difficult to find a block in the Centro Histrico without an art gallery, many of them showcases for striking abstract and expressionist works, as well as indigenous folk art, including weavings, local black pottery and other handicrafts.

description: WARD--Paul L. Sarah Lawrence College mourns the death of its fifth president Paul Langdon Ward, who led the liberal arts college from 1960-1965 during a period of growth, while strengthening and preserving the College's commitment to rigorous, individualized education. We extend our sympathies to his wife, Catherine Wakefield Ward, his children and grandchildren. Michele Tolela Myers President Barbara Kaplan Dean of the College

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MERCER, CAROLYN R.
description: MERCER--Carolyn R. May 16, 1927-October 31, 2005. "Carrie" died peacefully in her sleep. She is survived by her children, Christie Mercer Platt of Washington, DC, Fielding L. Mercer of Honolulu, HI and Donald W. Mercer, Jr. of Godfrey, IL as well as three grandchildren, Benjamin and Hilary Platt and Adam Mercer. Born in St. Louis, MO, she graduated from Vassar College and married Donald W. Mercer. They lived in Lake Forest, IL where she was an avid athlete. In 1975 they moved to Santa Fe, NM where she was actively involved with both the Greer Garson Theater and the Santa Fe Opera. She moved to Ponte Vedra Beach, FL in 2000 and will long be remembered for her indomitable spirit and fierce intellect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KALM, FLORENCE, DR.
description: KALM--Florence, Dr. Died peacefully at home in Manhattan on October 18, 2005. Born in NYC, she graduated from Hunter College where she returned to complete an M.S. degree in Guidance and Counseling and a M.A. in Anthropology. In 1975, she received a Ph.D. in anthropology from CUNY Graduate School. A lifelong educator, she taught in Yorktown Heights, N.Y., Brooklyn College and Hunter College. She traveled extensively and conducted ethnographic research in Aruba, Norfolk Island, and Bristol, England. For the past 12 years, she worked for the NYC Dept. of Education as an analyst. She is survived by her sister Dorothy Hirsch of Graton, CA, her son Bob Goldhamer of Los Angeles, CA and her daughter Ellen Bollinger of Atlantic Highlands, N.J. as well as by her beloved grandchildren Samantha, Daniel and Wesley. Friends and family will honor her life in New York City on November 26. Donations may be made in her name to the Fund for Public Schools, 52 Chambers St., Room 305, NY NY 10007

So what's the big whoop about these men who toil assiduously in their eager-beaver professions, early-to-bed, teetotaling types who live in gelato-free suburbs, where they bag their own groceries at the local ShopRite (as Alito has evidently been spotted doing) and prefer the tried-and-true uniform of a shirt, tie and (sometimes unlaced) lace-up shoes?

We stayed in third-rate hotels and traveled in yellow school buses, sometimes spending as much as eight or nine hours on a bus. They gave us a per diem allowance of $1.25 for food. I stayed nine weeks and they cut me. I thought my life had ended.

title: 'The Bonfire of the Vanities,' 2005 Edition
description: PAUL E. JOHNSON, a former Wall Street analyst who never saw an overpriced technology stock he didn't like, is still reeling from a federal jury's finding 10 days ago that he violated securities laws by misleading investors with his research. But his shock is less than shocking. After all, this is a man whose favorite state seems to be denial. He continued to rate more than 20 bubble stocks a "buy" in 2002 even after they had lost most of their value. And he was so certain that it was O.K. to advise investors in 2001 to buy the shares of a company as he was selling that he chose to try his case rather than settle with regulators.

title: Bread and Chocolate
description: Puebla is the Lyon of Mexico, the city that the locals invariably bring up when a conversation turns to their country's cuisine. If you were to identify the quintessential Mexican plate, you would probably winnow the choice down to two finalists: mole poblano, a preparation of chicken or turkey in a rich, dark blend of chocolate, spices, nuts and chiles; and chiles en nogada, another festive recipe, in which large poblano chiles are stuffed with a picadillo of ground meat and diced fruit, then topped with a walnut-and-sour-cream sauce. But however much they applaud these complicated dishes, most foreign aficionados of Mexican food fail to register the fact that the word "poblano" in both dishes derives from the name of the country's fourth-largest city.

Last year, Mr. Frankfort, the chairman and chief executive of Coach, the leather goods company, bought a four-story apartment that extends into one of the three towers in the Emery Roth-designed landmark at Central Park West and 81st Street. The seller was Bob Weinstein, a co-founder and former co-chairman of Miramax Films.

Not surprisingly, the most fervent cultural revivalists are ethnic Hawaiians. Their culture remains very much alive, even in Waikiki, where tourists and triathletes congregate. Among native islanders, almost everyone surfs or plays the ukulele, or both. They may be living in paradise, but a surprising number cite the Alpine "Sound of Music" as their favorite movie.

title: A New National Malaise?
Paid Notice: Deaths   LEROY, MAXIMILIAN WARNER
description: LeROY--Maximilian Warner. During his all too short life Maximilian (universally known as Max) Warner LeRoy--beloved son of Kay LeRoy and precious brother to Bridget Warner LeRoy, Carolyn Plum LeRoy and Jennifer Oz LeRoy--embraced an extraordinary number of people with a singular charisma during his 30 years; a life ended by a motorcycle accident in Los Angeles on November 3rd. He was a literal, as well as figurative, embrace. Max was a hugger par excellence, a habit that started in early childhood when his parents tried to teach him how to shake hands in greeting; he preferred hugging. Visitors to the LeRoy household were routinely assaulted by a dark-haired, dark-eyed ball of energy who threw himself at them, hugging whatever body parts he could best reach. After what became his signature hug (just a little longer, just a little tighter and just a little more loving than anyone else's), Max would step back to ask the hug-ee's name. He embraced life just as ferociously and with as much abandon. And he had an enormous capacity for living, because he was so prodigiously talented. The word "best" always surfaced when Max was discussed by his family and friends. He was the best musician, the best writer, the best cook, the best at getting the party going, the best at getting the girls, the best son, the best brother and the best friend. Most of all, he was the best at loving those same family and friends, the latter an always increasing circle of people he embraced--literally! Without that special Max love, reinforced by that patented Max hug, the world is a colder, harsher and lonelier place for all who knew him. The solace is that Max will now always be so young, so handsome and so vital, while the rest of us will not be so lucky.

title: Everything To Fear, Especially Fear Itself
description: FLIP through any newspaper these days, and chances are there is an article or two revealing some shady terrorist threat or foiled mega-plot. These reports have the ancillary effect of feeding a culture of fear in which we become afraid of everything, convinced that someone is looking to do us harm. Perhaps that is the terrorist's goal.

title: That Sports Guy Thrives Online
description: IT was a curious sight in Greenwich Village one balmy night this fall: hundreds of men in their 20's and early 30's lined up around a city block for a book signing, many of them decked out in team jerseys and wearing the eager expressions of teenagers on the verge of meeting a real celebrity.

title: We Said Wireless, Not Clueless
description: WHEN Andrew J. Spano, the county executive, proposed the Public Internet Protection Act, it's safe to say he didn't expect scorn and vitriol in response.

title: Generation Rx
description: In the world of bureaucratic Washington, D.C., few if any possess the gravitas and smarts to get away with quoting Teddy Roosevelt. Lewis Engman, Richard Nixon's 1973 appointee as chairman of the powerful Federal Trade Commission (FTC), was one of the few. A Midwesterner with traditional Republican inclinations, Engman had "the gift," as one friend later put it - people simply wanted to be around him. He was a handsome man, with a broad brow and piercing dark eyes, and he was a social creature, stylishly dressed and coiffed and noticeable on the D.C. cocktail circuit, where he could be seen in the company of many of the president's closest advisers. Engman was a personable, if tightly wound, man as well, comfortable with business types and staff typists alike; when a young FTC appointee named Elizabeth Hanford (later Dole) had a minor accident and ended up in the emergency room on the day she was to be installed, Engman took his entire staff over to the hospital and swore her in while she was still in bed.

title: BRACE FOR COLLISION
description: The Senate has confirmed Donald C. Winter as the next secretary of the Navy, but he cannot take the job because the current secretary of the Navy, Gordon R. England, has to stay in the office until the Senate confirms him for his next assignment.

title: Vienna Weekend
description: Vienna packs as much culture as either London or Paris, but within a fraction of the space. And December is the perfect time to visit, with crisp weather and rib-sticking food. For the full Viennese experience, book yourself a seat at the opera for the latest production of "The Marriage of Figaro." ROBERT JOHNSTON

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OSCARD, FIFI
description: OSCARD--Fifi. The nationally-known, highly-respected Artists Representative, Fifi Oscard, a.k.a. Fifi Steinmetz, died suddenly on Nov. 12th at the age of 85. This vibrant, determined and thoughtful woman was esteemed by several generations of authors, playwrights, actors and directors whom she represented. The Fifi Oscard Agency, which has handled clients such as Orson Welles, Alexander Scourby, Jack Matlock, William Shatner, Art Buchwald, George Plimpton, Arthur Ashe, Joe Pistone(Donnie Brasco), Jack Palance and Margaret Edson's Pulitzer Prize winning play "Wit" has been in business for over 50 years. Legend has it that the movie "Fame" was created at Fifi's desk! Fifi was passionate about people, theatre, literature and politics and was a source of inspiration for many. Ms. Oscard sat on the Board of Directors of the Mercantile Library of New York, the New York Hall of Science and the Avignon/ New York Film Festival. She was also on the Council of the Temple of Understanding, a member of the Cosmopolitan Club, the Coffee House, and The Women's Forum. She received a Lifetime Achievement Award in 2002 from the League of Professional Theatre Women for her countless contributions to the American theatre. Fifi Oscard is survived by her son, Eric Steinmetz and his wife Sylvie, six grandchildren, Victoria Steinmetz, Alexandra Galantic and her husband John, Cyrele Steinmetz, Graham Murray and his wife Susan, Shepherd Murray and his wife Margo, Ian Murray, as well as five great-grandchildren, Alexi, Zachary, Cooper, Tucker and Saylor. The family kindly requests all donations be made to the Mercantile Library, 17 East 47th St, NY, NY 10017, (212) 755 6710. The memorial service will be held at the Cosmopolitan Club on Friday December 9th at 4:00 pm, 122 E 66th Street, New York, NY 10021 (212) 734-5950

title: The Director Who Could Have Been a Contender
description: LOS ANGELES - NICK GOOSSEN'S apprenticeship as a director began at the age of 3. He would watch his father train prizefighters in a gym here, a dark, cramped, oddly angled soundstage for polished pros and battered tomato cans. While the boxers worked the rope and hit the mitts, Hollywood Joe Goossen would orchestrate the action.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Nov. 20 -- Nov. 26; DANCE
description: OHAD NAHARIN designed "MAMOOTOT," now at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival, to be performed by his Batsheva Dance Company for a small audience seated near the performers dancing around a four-sided space. It is hard to imagine Mr. Naharin's propulsive dancers in that setting, given their habit of holding nothing back physically or emotionally. So expect to get up close and personal with nine members of this Tel Aviv-based modern-dance troupe, founded in 1964 with help from Martha Graham and directed by Mr. Naharin since 1990. Nov. 22, 23 and 25 at 7:30 p.m., Nov. 26 at 7:30 and 9:30 p.m., and Sunday and Nov. 27 at 3 p.m., the Mark Morris Dance Center, 3 Lafayette Avenue across from the Academy, Fort Greene, (718) 636-4100 or bam.org.

title: Remember: It's the Saw Mill RIVER Parkway
description: Pleasantville - IT doesn't take a hurricane, or even a tropical storm, to swamp the northern stretch of the Saw Mill River Parkway. A good cloudburst will do it. By now there's a feeling of fatalism about the flooding.

title: So Yesterday
description: 'Domino," the latest Tony Scott film, features cameo appearances by the actors Ian Ziering and Brian Austin Green, who in previous lives starred in the seminal 90's television show "Beverly Hills, 90210." The two, in fact, play themselves, outfitted to appear as if they were still living and dressing in their 90's heyday. To achieve their look, the film's costume designer, who goes by the initial B., paid close attention to their denim. "Jeans from the early 90's just don't fit well," she explains. "They're a little peg-legged. They're a little saggy in the rear end. Which was the key to pinpointing that era." Nicole Kidman in "Cold Mountain" this is not.

title: Dancing in the Aisles for a Liberia at Peace

Some are covered in zebra-print tablecloths, others in a design emblazoned with black-and-white cowry shells, and the walls are painted white and a dull sky blue. Yet it is not the dcor that provides the excitement; it is the food and the conversation.

Across Long Island, the candidates who tried to run as hard-liners on the immigration question were conspicuously absent from the victory lists. For all the talk of suburban outrage at the supposed onslaught of day laborers and Latino gangs, it wasn't the hyperventilating candidates who won.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Is Brickell Avenue the next South Beach? This boulevard in Miami's financial district, just a couple of blocks off Biscayne Bay, is already home to the Four Seasons, the Mandarin Oriental and the year-old Conrad Miami. Now, another luxury property -- the Viceroy -- is scheduled to open there early next year, as part of the Icon condominium complex being designed by Arquitectonica and Philippe Starck's YOO firm. The 129-room Viceroy, the latest hotel from the Kor Group (www.korhotelgroup.com), will feature a rooftop pool bar, as well as a spa. EasyCruise (www.easycruise.com) has started offering low-cost voyages in the Caribbean. The weeklong route will begin in Barbados and stop at St. Vincent, Martinique, the Grenadines, Grenada and St. Lucia. Passengers can sign up for as few as two nights on ship, and fares start at about $15 a person a night, based on double occupancy. . . . Fall snowstorms out West are allowing skiers to get an early start on the slopes. The Red Resort, www.redresort.com, in southeastern British Columbia, said that because of an alpine snow depth that has already hit 39 inches, its winter season will begin on Nov. 24 -- its earliest opening in more than two decades. The resort said that 83 runs should be available on opening day and that discounted lift tickets would be sold the first week of operations.

title: San Francisco's Mission District: Eclectic, Eccentric, Electric
description: FROM the rooftop patio of Medjool, a new restaurant in the Mission district of San Francisco, the entire neighborhood is laid out like a flamboyant mosaic. Ranks of painted ladies -- San Francisco's ornate wooden Victorians -- rise to Twin Peaks in the west, the hills that block the city's infamous fog and make the Mission one of the city's warmest and sunniest neighborhoods. This terrace is the perfect spot for watching the cottony wave of evening fog roll into downtown, for the sky in the Mission remains crystalline.

Cheapo Records, on Central Square in Cambridge, is among those few places that sell long-playing records and even 45's.

description: IF a day without orange juice is like a day without sunshine, as Anita Bryant once told America, what is a day without black currant juice? It's a day that makes Allyn Brown of Preston unhappy.

A British Sports Car, Made in Bridgeport
description: AC CARS, a British auto manufacturer that has been building sports cars since 1901, will open its first plant in the United States in Bridgeport next summer, state and city officials announced on Tuesday.

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: GRANT AND SHERMAN: The Friendship That Won the Civil War. By Charles Bracelen Flood. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.) The Civil War, like any long-established brand, requires periodic repackaging to induce its fans to buy the new and improved version. But fresh angles on this conflict are as scarce as Mini balls in Iraq. It's not news that Ulysses S. Grant and William Tecumseh Sherman were friends, and that together they led the Union to victory. Flood's inspiration is to devote an entire book to their friendship. Except that he doesn't, really: most of "Grant and Sherman" is given over to a battle-by-battle narrative of the war, from Fort Donelson to Appomattox. Flood, the author of books on Hitler and Robert E. Lee, pauses occasionally during the action to highlight the personal dynamics that allowed Grant and Sherman to forge an effective partnership, while other Union generals bickered and plotted. "He stood by me when I was crazy," Sherman said of Grant, "and I stood by him when he was drunk, and now, sir, we stand by each other always." Actually, they had a falling out after the war, when Grant was president and Sherman led the Army. Flood unfortunately glosses over that period, giving it only a few pages. Which means, inevitably, that some enterprising author soon will give us "Grant and Sherman: The Postwar Years." Aprs Flood, le dluge.

title: Rumsfeld Says Iraq Troop Levels Must Be Maintained
description: Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, addressing the renewed debate over American troops in Iraq, said today that any paring down of the forces there would depend on military and security conditions, and that current troop levels must be maintained at least until the December elections in Iraq.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: IF THE SKY FALLS: Stories. By Nicholas Montemarano. (Louisiana State University, paper, $16.95.) Montemarano's remarkable stories are united by their dyspeptic outlook and not much else: this collection, his first, includes straightforward narratives and metafictional experiments, a surreal fantasy about grief, an acerbic parable of torture and the commercialization of 9/11, and one audacious 11-page sentence that hilariously (but grimly) details the tyranny of an obsessive-compulsive mother who demands that her children clean house just so. If there's a theme, it might be that damaged people have no business taking care of others, or even interacting with them. On the other hand, it might be that everybody is damaged beyond repair. One narrator, a passive-aggressive home health aide, does a good job describing all of Montemarano's characters when he talks about "the usual human disabilities, like not knowing how to be nice or being a little too funny for your own good." As the book proceeds, the experimental detours start to feel less ambitious and more perfunctory, but Montemarano's deft storytelling and ruthless honesty ensure that this collection is as dark and dazzling as a mine shaft studded with diamonds.

title: You Might Say He's a Rebel
description: LINCROFT - IT is not often that Jersey girls distinguish themselves by being demure. But time-travel back to the heyday of the Shirelles, the 1960's girl group from Passaic that had hits like "Soldier Boy" and "Will You Still Love Me Tomorrow," and students of pop history, like John Grecco, detect a trend: When it came to recording, he says: "The less hopeful, milder stuff suited Jersey. The bolder stuff was Brooklyn, Queens, New York."

title: Help! They Need Someone
description: VOLUNTEERS often work at unglamorous tasks -- sorting clothes, selling cookies, giving rides -- for which they receive perhaps a handshake or a smile.

title: At Age 128, Looks Still Matter
description: The Jefferson Market Library, on the corner of 10th Street and the Avenue of the Americas, is a regal High Victorian Gothic building, formerly a courthouse, then a prison for women, and now an unofficial beacon of the West Village.

description: LONDON - AFTER months of unease, a humdrum incident in a hardscrabble part of town turns suddenly sour. Pretty soon, the police and the poor are locked in street fighting. Gasoline bombs fly. Cars burn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COREY, JOSEPHINE V.
description: COREY--Josephine V. 89, of Plandome Manor, L.I. on November 19, 2005. Loving wife for 55 years of the late William. Sister to Mary Caporaso. Beloved mother of Dr. Paul (and wife Kathy), Robin and Nancy Corey; grandmother to Justine Whitehead, Amy, Ryan and the late Jena Corey; great-grandmother to Corey and Kalen. Friend to hundreds. Intrepid world traveler, voracious reader, gardener, most popular co-ed of NYU '37; devoted thirty year volunteer at St. Francis Hospital. We will miss your love, spirit, energy, humor, thirst for knowledge, fairness, honesty and caring. (And your lasagne). Always.

title: Like Many of Its Wares, an Old Store in Brooklyn Passes Out of Style
description: To survey the history of Frank's Department Store, you need only look at the merchandise scattered and stacked about the place. A partial list, in no particular order, includes children's sailor suits, bone knitting needles, thermal underwear, truckers' caps featuring the 1980's sitcom puppet Alf, corduroy slacks with blue piping, newsboy hats, bicentennial American flags, gray plaid knickers and black nylon stockings preserved in tissue paper.

title: SAKHALIN'S HISTORY
description: To the Editor: I was astonished that James Brooke in "Change Comes to a Wild Island at Russia's Edge" (Explorer: Sakhalin, Oct. 30) did not explain an important aspect of the history of Sakhalin Island -- including why a mountain there is named for the writer Anton Chekhov.

title: Japan space probe nears asteroid
Way, Way Uptown
description: Favorite kitchen tool: Our La Cornue oven. It's the Rolls Royce of stoves. The Vikings are good, but this one has all the beauty you would associate with a 19th-century kitchen in Provence, and it's state of the art. It took us 10 years to get it, and it has our names on it. There's a little brass plaque that reads, "Bill and Bjorn 2003."

title: The Remix; Little Grass Shack
description: The fashion designer Betsey Johnson went to Zihuatanejo, Mexico, in 2000 and came back with the ultimate souvenir: beachfront property. "I decided that I just can't do hotels anymore," she said. "I go to these la-di-da perfect places and end up hanging out with plastic surgeons and dentists and their wives by the pool." To escape, she drove to the fishing village of Barra de Potos, felt at home and bought Betseyville -- five thatch-roofed bungalows with two pools. Decorating was "such a trip, I thought more people have to see it." Starting this Thanksgiving, more people can: Betseyville is available for $5,500 to $8,500 a week, staff included (go to www.lacurevillas.com). Vacationers -- it sleeps up to 10 -- will find interiors true to Johnson's funky style: patterned fabrics, glittery chandeliers and Popsicle-colored walls. GISELA WILLIAM

title: Out of the Cold, Into the Warmth
description: YOU don't have to be a martyr all winter long. Plenty of places offer respite from the season's chill for an hour, an afternoon or more. It can be as simple as a visit to a tropical greenhouse or as sybaritic as a weekend in a luxurious suite with a whirlpool and a fireplace. Whether you're looking for a quick escape or something longer and more lavish, following are some suggestions for getting in out of the cold.

title: SAKHALIN'S HISTORY

They will also be able to create home pages with links to databases, books, journals, Web sites and other resources.

But because of the rising number of them trying to do so, cultural shifts since Sept. 11 and a possible labor shortage in a few years, extended sabbaticals need not be the kiss of death they were a generation ago.

title: The Smell of Hope
description: MY father's father, Diamante Mazzucco, arrived in New York in April 1903, at the age of 12. Like millions of Italians before and after him, he had come to "look for America"; that expression has fallen into disuse, but it was tantamount to "look for a better life," or at least the hope of one. He knew nothing about New York. All he had was an address: Prince Street.

description: College and postgraduate guys, in their baggy-seat jeans, artfully torn and washed, loose sweaters and year-round flip-flops or leather sandals, are crowding into the new Abercrombie & Fitch store on Fifth Avenue. Among the shoppers was Stefano Gabbana, second from top right in leather-patch jeans, who with his partner Domenico Dolce set the look in motion a few years ago as a design statement. Having run its course with the hipsters, it is now a uniform for young antidesigner guys and divorced from the falling-down style of hip-hop and the tight fit of the 70's and 80's. ON THE STREET

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the actor Taye Diggs and his dance company, dre.dance, misstated its connection to the Dance Theater Workshop. The article also misstated the name of the Rochester high school he attended, and misspelled the surnames of a teacher and a choreographer. Dre.dance is a member of the workshop; the troupe is not financed by it. The institution was the School of the Arts, not the Performing Arts High School. Mr. Diggs's teacher was Timothy Draper, not Traper; the choreographer was Garth Fagan, not Fagen.

title: Lessons From Bosnia, 10 Years On: A U.S. Commitment Can Work
description: WASHINGTON - ARRIVING at Sarajevo airport last month, R. Nicholas Burns, the United States under secretary of state for political affairs, was escorted some way into the city by the Bosnian Serb police. But at an invisible line in the road his convoy stopped as the Serbs handed over to the police of the Muslim-Croat federation.

title: Briefly: Mugabe says uranium won't be used for arms
The Melting Pot
description: In the Swiss Alps, the tastiest aprA s-ski option is the standby fondue. And with good, gooey reason. You may think you have the etiquette down - dip cube of starch into molten mix of hard (GruyA re) and soft (Vacherin) cheeses, let cool, then devour - but there are rules. If a woman loses a morsel in the pot, she has to kiss someone at the table, while a man must buy a bottle of wine. He should choose a nice regional white like fendant or a cherry eau de vie like Etter kirschwasser. Best places to dip in?

title: Budget Lodgings, Minus the Austerity
description: HOSTELING used to be so easy. Choose a place at random. Make a side trip to the drugstore for sleep aids and earplugs. Brace yourself for the 4 a.m. hip check from the guy who drank his weight in Guinness, and shuffle to the refrigerator at first light to see whether someone stole your food.

title: This Deal Came Around Twice

When the National Gallery of Art in Washington recently decided to acquire a 17th-century marble statue of John the Baptist, it was the museum's second shot at a piece attributed to at least two different artists over half a century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUBERSTEIN, CONRAD B.
description: DUBERSTEIN -- Conrad B. Died peacefully at his home on November 18, 2005 at the age of 90. Beloved husband of Anne (nee Saggio), loving father of Elysa Belessakos and father-in-law of Elias; devoted grandfather of Nicole Chemtob (Mark), Josephine and Dimitri Belessakos and Angie Allison; adoring brother of Barbara Roberts and the late Kathryn Goldberg; United States Bankruptcy Judge for the Eastern District of New York; former Chief Bankruptcy Judge of the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Eastern District of New York, 1984-2005; Courtrooms and Chambers of the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Eastern dedicated in his honor; namesake and guiding spirit of the Judge Conrad B. Duberstein National Bankruptcy Moot Court Competition established by St. John's University School of Law and the American Bankruptcy Institute; served in the 91st Infantry Division of the 5th Army from 1943-1945, saw combat in Italy and was awarded the Bronze Star Medal, the Purple Heart and the Combat Infantry Badge; graduated from Brooklyn College and St. John's University School of Law (class of 1942), admitted to the practice of law in 1942; former partner in Otterbourg, Steindler, Houston & Rosen, P.C. and Schwartz, Rudin & Duberstein; former Judge Advocate General of the Military Order of the Purple Heart for the State of New York; recognized for his outstanding academic and professional achievements including an honorary Doctor of Laws from St. John's University School of Law; awarded Medal of Honor by St. John's University recipient of the Brooklyn Bar of Association's Annual Award for Outstanding Achievement in the Science of Jurisprudence and Public Service; recipient of the Emory University School of Law Lifetime Achievement Award; Fellow American Bar Association and the American College of Bankruptcy. Funeral services will be held at Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East 87th Street, New York, NY 10128, on November 21st at 1 PM. Those who wish to contribute in his memory to the Park Avenue Synagogue or Congregation Mount Sinai of Brooklyn Heights, New York. Further questions please call Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 212-769-4400.

title: Andrea Eisenstein and Joshua Sherman
description: Andrea Robin Eisenstein, the daughter of Evelyn Eisenstein of West Orange, N.J., and the late Joseph Eisenstein, was married last evening to Joshua Isaac Sherman, the son of Ruth Sherman and Michael Sherman of Manhattan. Rabbi Alan Sherman, an uncle of the bridegroom, officiated at the Crystal Plaza in Livingston, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: Correction Appended

title: Screening for Ethics: How One School Does It
description: BUSINESS schools concerned about training ethical corporate leaders need to start by admitting ethical students, says Gabriel Hawawini, dean of Insead, the international business school with campuses in France and Singapore. Here are excerpts from an interview:

title: The Ticket; Three Ways To Please Your Petulant Son
description: With the possible exception of certain terriers (and in-laws), no traveling companion is more impossible than an adolescent boy in the throes of hormone-induced alienation. Herewith, solutions for a headache-free trip.

title: All the World's a New Technology Incubator
description: WHEN is a play actually a film? It's a question one might ponder after seeing "Super Vision," the audacious multimedia production by the Builders Association, an experimental theater company based in New York. In one scene, a video-projected child talks to a live actor inside a virtual living room. The stage is lighted to look like a movie screen. Even the dialogue has been written by a screenwriter. Later, the lights go out and a flood of three-dimensional animated cubes swoops around the proscenium stage, organizing into a 40-foot-high map of the world.

title: DataBank; Another Fall in Oil Prices, Another Gain for Stocks
description: For the fourth consecutive week, the stock market rose, pushing the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index to its highest level since June 2001.

title: Political Puffery
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KAHN, SHIRLEY AND CHUCK
description: KAHN--Shirley and Chuck. We gather today to unveil your monument. Still grieving, we love you and miss you. Your Family

title: China Wages Classroom Struggle to Win Friends in Africa
description: BEIJING - As the teacher, a career Chinese diplomat, spoke, his class of African diplomats scribbled furiously.

title: The Ticket; Three
description: Last summer, Four Seasons Hotels and Resorts introduced "teen concierges" in cities like New York, London and Atlanta, where savvy natives give junior-varsity visitors the 411 on the best stores, restaurants and happenings. The program was so popular that Four Seasons Hotel New York is bringing Ilana Yamin, a Vassar freshman, back for hanksgiving and Christmas breaks. Three recommendations?

title: Nothing Sacred, or Secret, on the Web
description: FORGIVE the Miami student blogger named Kyle, as his eyelids are as heavy as a convertible's ragtop. Controversy creationism is exhausting.

title: Health Experts Fear Chinese Flu Vaccination Plan Could Backfire
description: China's plans to vaccinate billions of chickens against avian flu could backfire and end up spreading the disease, poultry and vaccine experts warned last week.

title: The Remix; Delhi or Bust
description: This month, Continental Airlines starts nonstop service to New Delhi from Newark, which makes a long shopping weekend in India doable. Leave Thursday night at 9:05 and be in New Delhi by 9:30 p.m. Friday. Shop until the Sunday-night flight at 11:30, and you're back in New York by 5 p.m. Monday. Go to www.continental.com.

title: Jay Leno, David Letterman and Conan O'Brien
description: Jay Leno

title: The Fall of the Warrior King
description: Dexter Filkins's article (Oct. 23) provides extraordinary insights into the complex challenges facing United States Army leaders in Iraq. The article was so rich in content and context that we plan to incorporate it into our leadership classes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TARANTAL, AL (ABRAHAM)
description: TARANTAL--Al (Abraham). 82. On November 6. Loved by all, especially daughter Naomi, son Joel (Linda), granddaughters Coppelia and Maya (Michael), great grands Max and Kelsey, and late partner Roz, with whom you traveled the city and world, collecting stories and friendships. An orphan at 14, a veteran of WW II, Einstein lookalike, union, civil rights, and peace activist, your legacy will sustain us. Donations to Holy Apostle Soup Kitchen or Drs. Without Borders. Memorial to be announced.

title: Dispute Over Division of Authority at the U.N. Grows
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 20 - A growing dispute over the future division of authority at the United Nations has prompted showdown talk among diplomats and a warning from John R. Bolton, the American ambassador, that the United States may look elsewhere to settle international problems.

title: Normal Life With More Pancakes
description: THE WOMAN AT THE WASHINGTON ZOO

title: He Sings, He Dances, but He Will Not Stop
description: As the man who founded the hedge fund Crescendo Partners, Eric S. Rosenfeld has made a name for himself as an activist investor willing to take on the managers of companies that he believes are undervalued. At a conference last week, he made a new name for himself by singing and dancing about it.

title: Why Vote?
description: I can't imagine a better paradigm of economics as "the dismal science" than Stephen J. Dubner and Steven D. Levitt's article (Freakonomics, Nov. 6). I imagine that such an expert knows the exact value of the rose he gives his wife. He appraises its life expectancy, the cost of sending his secretary out to buy it and the value of the sunshine it may bring into his marriage. He knows the price of everything and the worth of nothing.

title: Special Issue: Iraq
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMERSTEIN, CHRISTINA LIND
description: HAMMERSTEIN -- Christina Lind. Passed away peacefully November 19th at home in Durham, NC surrounded by her three beautiful girls, Pat (Patricia Hammerstein Benner), Marty (Martha Hammerstein) and Dinie (Diana Hammerstein). Born February 4, 1919, Ms. Hammerstein was an actress and singer who started her career in radio and the fashionable nightclubs of New York in the early 1940's. She appeared on Broadway and in summer stock productions of many Rogers & Hammerstein musicals including "The King & I," "Showboat" and "South Pacific," and remained active in the arts throughout her life. She will be greatly missed by her loving family including her daughters, son-in-law Tom Benner, six grandchildren and three great-grandchildren as well as the many friends and colleagues who remember her for her warmth, talent and beauty. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Actors Fund of America.

title: The Ticket; One Hundred
description: Dollars (excluding delivery) for a one-week rental of a crib and bed linens in the Los Angeles area. Strollers, toy packages, blow-up tubs and BabyBjrns also available. (www.babydelish.com; 310-200-7331.)

title: What Do You Expect for $99.23 a Night?
description: It was about 4 p.m. when something crawled on the carpet. A large insect of unidentified species made its way across the hotel lobby, and a group of European tourists tracked it with a cheerful curiosity until a gray-haired man in a baseball cap waiting to check in stomped on it.

title: Rumsfeld cites 'red herring' in Iraq war debate
WHY WE TRAVEL: IBIZA
description: PLAYA D'EN BOSSA, OCT. 28, 2005 - Three-year-old Zoe Mylne and her father, James Mylne, a veterinarian from Dunbar, Scotland: "We travel throughout the world, just doing artificial reproduction in sheep, so we're very strange people. We have a very, very busy breeding season and we'd finished, so we were looking for a last-minute holiday and we went off to Ibiza. It's just started to be really filthy in Scotland, the weather. I mean, we go to work and the curtains are closed and we get back and the curtains are still drawn -- you just don't see daylight. So you just want that last burst of sun before winter. We were building sandcastles and Zoe was giving instructions, and I was probably querying something. And as a consequence of that, she was giving me further instructions. That's the usual story. She's quite bossy like most little girls and I suppose we indulge that. I'm sure we'll pay eventually. But now, it seems worthwhile. As told to Austin Considine

title: The Ticket; 27 The Age Of The Suave Sailing Coach Who Will Make Your Tween Nuts
description: To a teenage girl, could there be anyone more crush-worthy than a Club Med chicken-dance leader? An Aspen ski-school sensei? Yes: Rob Hebert, the director of the Bitter End Yacht Club's sailing school in Virgin Gorda. Nickname: Buck-Oh-Five, because there isn't an ounce of fat on him. Skills: swimming, sailing, windsurfing, kinesiology. What your daughter won't learn to do because she's too busy daydreaming about her marriage: tie a half hitch. Private lesson: one-on-one sailing on a Hobie Cat, $50 an hour.

title: Climbing the Walls Beats Cabin Fever
description: LONG ISLAND may lack mountains, but it doesn't lack people with the imagination to create a mountaineering experience.

title: Don't Beat Up Big Oil. It's Just Doing Its Job.
description: "INSANITY," the old saying goes, "is doing the same thing and expecting different results."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISSMAN, MORRIS
description: WEISSMAN - Morris. With deep sadness our family announces the passing of this wise and gentle man. He is survived by his beloved wife of 71 years, Gertrude, and children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren, and others too numerous to name.

title: How to Vaccinate 14 Billion Birds
description: Fourteen billion. That's how many ducks and chickens are produced in China every year. To vaccinate all those birds against avian flu, as the government announced last week that it was planning to do, would require about 550 million injections a week.

title: In Iraqi Town, Marines' Work Is Routine and Terrifying
description: HUSAYBA, Iraq, Nov. 16 - The harsh staccato of an automatic rifle suddenly sounded inside the house, and marines spilled out the side and front doors. They were yelling and their message - simple, and made all the more chilling for that - crackled across the radios of I Company, Third Battalion, Sixth Marines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOWEY, REBECCA
description: LOWEY--Rebecca. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Rebecca Lowey, beloved mother of Stephen Lowey and mother-in-law of Hon. Nita Lowey, devoted friends of the New York Jewish community whose dedication and support make a profound impact on our ability to care for those in need. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to Stephen and Nita; their children, Douglas, Dana, Jacqueline; and the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Danielle Morgan and Kevin Koplin
description: Danielle Ann Morgan, was married last evening to Kevin Scott Koplin in New York. Rabbi Daniel Alder officiated at the Metropolitan Club.

title: Patient Vandalism
description: My husband is a psychoanalyst. A patient left a session (without indicating that she was upset) and smashed some glass in a public hallway. At a hearing, the building management ruled that we must replace the glass and that the patient can never return to the building. We also had to pay our attorney and change airline tickets originally scheduled for the day of the hearing. What costs should the patient cover? What about the new office space we must rent?

title: Lewis and Clark on the Edge
description: Sacramento, Calif. - SOME 200 years ago, on Nov. 15, 1805, the Lewis and Clark expedition reached its destination, the Pacific shore. Clark's often quoted words, "Ocean in view! O! the joy," had been mistakenly written a week earlier, in what is now Wahkiakum County, Wash. It is wild, breezy country there, and almost everything about it is wide, including the Columbia River itself. Every time I pass through that region, I feel grateful to have been born in the American West.

title: To Restore a Roman Piazza, the Unknowns Get the Boot
description: ROME, Nov. 19 - For nearly 400 years, the Piazza Navona has been an artistic jewel at the heart of this ancient city.

title: The Remix; The Melting Pot
description: In the Swiss Alps, the tastiest aprs-ski option is the standby fondue. And with good, gooey reason. You may think you have the etiquette down -- dip cube of starch into molten mix of hard (Gruyre) and soft (Vacherin) cheeses, let cool, then devour -- but there are rules. If a woman loses a morsel in the pot, she has to kiss someone at the table, while a man must buy a bottle of wine. He should choose a nice regional white like fendant or a cherry eau de vie like Etter kirschwasser. Best places to dip in?

title: The Family Ticket; 1/2 Ounce Of Grenadine Makes A Kiddie Cocktail
description: The Shirley Temple's reign as the queen of junior libations should have ended long ago. The Cosmo-Not is finally here to push the old dame aside. The Peninsula New York Hotel serves its saccharine concoction to Sarah Jessica juniors in a fluted pint glass (or a martini glass with Mom's or Dad's O.K.). Elsewhere, boys might opt for a "slowjito" -- a rum-free mojito.

title: Mary Peck and Gregory Kasper
description: Correction Appended

title: Gunman Wounds Off-Duty Policeman in Brooklyn and Steals His Badge
description: An off-duty police officer in Brooklyn was shot in the shoulder and robbed early yesterday as he was going home, the police said. The officer traded gunfire with the robber, who escaped, they said.

title: The Red Hair of the Dog
description: I HAVE a friend in Texas who keeps score of his most pounding, galloping, praying-for-death hangovers of the year. This guy doesn't just keep the list, he also distributes it, and around this time of year I start looking forward to the results, partly for an informative recounting of parties I've missed and partly because nothing in nature reinforces puritanical guilt cycles like the hangover.

title: So Many Books, So Many Ways to Snuggle Up With One
description: WHETHER it is with a novel, a memoir or a history tome, winter is a favorite time to curl up by the fireplace or snuggle under the covers with a good read. Some try to plow through a book in one sitting; others stretch the reading out for months. Here are the reading habits and current book lists of some notable Long Islanders.

title: The Incest Loophole
description: WHAT if I told you that a father who was regularly raping his 8-year-old daughter could reasonably expect to avoid prison if he were discovered? You'd be outraged, right? But this is a fact of life in New York, thanks to the "incest loophole." And nobody in the Legislature is even trying to change this reprehensible law.

title: Bread and Chocolate
description: Puebla is the Lyon of Mexico, the city that the locals invariably bring up when a conversation turns to their country's cuisine. If you were to identify the quintessential Mexican plate, you would probably winnow the choice down to two finalists: mole poblano, a preparation of chicken or turkey in a rich, dark blend of chocolate, spices, nuts and chiles; and chiles en nogada, another festive recipe, in which large poblano chiles are stuffed with a picadillo of ground meat and diced fruit, then topped with a walnut-and-sour-cream sauce. But however much they applaud these complicated dishes, most foreign aficionados of Mexican food fail to register the fact that the word "poblano" in both dishes derives from the name of the country's fourth-largest city.

title: The Future of Buyouts
description: To the Editor:

title: Sleeping With the Devil
description: WITCHFINDERS

title: Bringing the triple play to Europe
Far, Far Away From Cheez Whiz
description: SOME may favor chocolate, hot or not, for the holidays. Others may think of fruitcake, or cookies. But cheese is gaining -- fast. Retailers credit the growing sophistication of the American palate, an increase in the quality of American artisanal cheeses, and cheese plates at finer restaurants.

title: Real Women Have Curves
description: MUCH has been written about what draws an artist to a model, but how about the way sitting for the artist affects the person who poses? Paola Carla, who sat for Alberto Giacometti for several months in the late 1950's, says her experience prompted some curious sensations: "Sometimes while I was posing, I felt I was the immobile object and the sculpture was the lively presence."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOLKER, LEON (LEE)
description: KOLKER--Leon (Lee), 95. Survived by loving wife of 37 years, Betty Lee March Kolker; previously married to the late Myrtle Picker Kolker. Father of Anne and Thomas, grandfather of Joanne and Amy, stepfather to Ward, Tom and Bill Blum, and children. 1931 graduate of MIT. Owner of Kolker Chemical of Newark, NJ and Houston, TX. Trustee of Elmira College. Honorary Consul General of The Gambia, 1973-1986. Services private. In lieu of flowers please send donations in his name to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave, NY, NY 10021.

title: Essential Reading
description: I never go anywhere -- often not even from room to room in my home -- without taking something along to read. It's a lifelong habit, but it became something of a fixation about 15 years ago when I was sent by Granta magazine to the town of Hammerfest. Stuck above the Arctic Circle in Norway, in the dead of winter, I ran out of things to read. Hammerfest is the loneliest town in Europe -- 1,200 miles north of Oslo -- and it passes most of the winter in frigid darkness. I was there to write about the aurora borealis. (I believe the commissioning editor's hope was that I would just go amusingly insane.) I expected to be there for a week. Instead I got more thantwo weeks of cloud cover with no aurora. There is little to do in Hammerfest in winter but go for creeping walks in the pitch-blackness, watch the single channel of Norwegian television or read. I read. By the end of the second week, I had read everything in my possession, including the labels inside my suitcase and every word of the three English-language magazines sold in the local newspaper shop. I reached the point where I was calling in twice a day to find out if the new issue of Woman's Weekly had arrived. Since then I have never ventured abroad without packing more books than is strictly sensible and enough magazines that I can always have one rolled up in a back pocket. More often than not, it is a copy of The Economist, which I like very much except sometimes when it reviews my books. I'm pleased to report that on my 16th day in Hammerfest, the clouds parted and I saw an aurora. It was wonderful -- worth the trip. Just as good, the latest issue of The Lady arrived at the shop, so I had something to read -- and reread and read again -- on the 30-hour bus trip back to Oslo. TIMELESS

title: Heating the Home With a Bit of Ingenuity
description: MAYBE this is the year the big oil companies pay an excess-profits tax. Maybe this is the year world peace breaks out. Maybe not.

title: 'Movin' Out' Moves Out, and Just When It Was Really Getting Going
description: THREE years can be a long time in the life of a Broadway musical. Dialogue that once sparkled dims with routine. Performances grow soggy. Cast changes alter the chemistry that once made a show more than the sum of its parts. Even musicals forced into retirement well before a third anniversary can look prematurely aged by the time the last curtain falls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCNULTY, JOHN P.
description: McNULTY--John P., 52. Of Short Hills, N.J., Naples, FL, and Aspen, CO, a senior director at Goldman Sachs, passed away suddenly on Wednesday, November 16 in Naples. The son of Nora Sweeney McNulty and Charles McNulty, John was born on October 31, 1952, in Philadelphia, PA. After earning his B.S. from St. Joseph's University in 1974 and his M.B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania Wharton School of Business in 1979, John went on to a distinguished 22-year career at Goldman Sachs. Under his leadership, the firm built a global investment management business that became a significant and integral part of the firm. John became a partner in 1990 and a managing director in 1996. He retired in June of 2001, but continued to serve as a Senior Director at the firm. At the time of his retirement, John was the head of the Investment Management Division and a member of the firm's Management Committee. Outside of Goldman Sachs, John was a strong advocate for education and the arts. He served on the Board of Trustees at the University of Pennsylvania Wharton School of Business, chaired St. Joseph's University's Finance Committee and was an advisory director at the Metropolitan Opera. He also was a patron of St. Joseph's School in Chinatown. In addition, John served as a trustee of The Aspen Institute and on the board of the Carnival Corporation & PLC. John is survived by his wife, Anne, and their three children, John, Brynne and Kevin, his mother and his siblings, Noreen Tully, Charles McNulty, Kevin McNulty and Mary Grady. There will be a viewing Monday, November 21, 2005, from 9-11AM at the Cathedral of Sts. Peter and Paul, 18th Street and The Benjamin Franklin Parkway, Philadelphia. A funeral mass will follow at 11:00AM at the same location. Those interested in making memorial contributions may forward them to: The John P. McNulty Scholarship Fund for Excellence in Science and Math, 1300 3rd Street South, Naples, FL 34102.

title: Brown Detects Glimmer of Hope From Dreadful Trip
description: After a miserable trip, the best stab at optimism that Coach Larry Brown could muster was that he knew more about the Knicks now than he did when they left town 11 days earlier.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Nov. 20 -- Nov. 26; TELEVISION
description: BBC AMERICA sends us "TOM BROWN'S SCHOOLDAYS" (Thursday night at 9), at least the fifth screen version of THOMAS HUGHES's 1857 novel about coming of age, in constant fear, at a 19th-century British boarding school. STEPHEN FRY stars as the frightening (but secretly thoughtful and well-intentioned) headmaster, who makes strong boys cry. The beautiful blond ALEX PETTYFER plays Tom. JOE BEATTIE plays Flashman, the chief bully, whose father gives a lot of money to the school.

title: The New Culture of Self-Medication
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-23

title: Letters to the Editor
description: CANCAN'S RECOVERY

title: Sunset Revival
description: I am standing on the terrace of one of the two 15th-floor penthouse suites of the Sunset Tower Hotel in West Hollywood. At one time, Howard Hughes lived here. He had both penthouses, as well as the entire 14th floor. Jane Russell, who starred in his film "The Outlaw," may occasionally be seen at the bar to this day. From the building's opening in 1929 as the Sunset Tower residential hotel, a galaxy of stars, as well as the gangster Bugsy Siegel, have lived here. Of all the legends that surround them, my favorite concerns John Wayne, who is supposed to have kept a cow on his balcony.

title: Behind the Mask
description: ABSOLUTE WATCHMEN

title: Why Vote?
description: How can an American voter be compared to a child who impulsively picks a blossom off a tree and reasons that only she, not everybody, is doing it? In the case of the American voter, we know that nearly half of those eligible didn't vote in the last presidential election. The many eligible voters who opt out are perilously defoliating our tree of privilege.

title: Down-Home Barbecue in a Setting to Match
description: WE sniffed the smoky air appreciatively before entering Tennessee Jack's BBQ in East Islip. Long Island is not barbecue country, so any new barbecue outpost is cause for celebration, and here was real Southern barbecue: ribs and pulled pork that had been in the smoker for 12 hours and brisket that had been there for 22 hours.

title: Congress's Quiet Holiday Plans
description: For all the shambles Congress has made of this year's public agenda, the reigning politicians of Washington are diligently attending to their own private wish list, which emphasizes ever greater protections for incumbents like themselves.

title: Adobe Walls, but Fare Beyond the Southwest
description: WHEN I first went to New Mexico in the early 1990's, with my young English head full of D. H. Lawrence, imagining adobe cabins among pines with big vistas of blue desert opening up below, I didn't like chili peppers. In fact I was afraid of them. I'd once had an encounter with one on an Argentine train. I bought a plastic plate of food from a platform vendor, and blithely bit off half of what I took to be a small, wrinkled tomato. Big mistake.

title: Rome's Pantheon: A Grand Survivor in a Timeless City
description: Correction Appended

title: The Pros and Cons of a Living Trust
description: THE use of a revocable living trust is often touted as a way to avoid the time and expense of probate -- and, by some, as a way to lower taxes -- when leaving a house and other property to heirs. But does a living trust live up to its promise?

title: Contributors
description: RYAN McGINNESS

title: The Remix; Carry on | Heels in Tow
description: Your touring shoes tread marble, cobblestone, gravel, dirt, water. Surely they deserve to cool their heels in style. Fragonard, the French purveyor of perfumes, soaps and cosmetics since 1926, now also offers men's and women's shoe bags for about $22. Smart yet practical, the women's bags are white cotton, the men's black, and they are adorned with fanciful (and very French) hand-embroidered images -- a sexy lavender slingback or a serious tan oxford. (51 rue des Francs Bourgeois, Paris; 011 33 1 44 78 01 32; www.fragonard.com.) AGNES GREENHALL

title: Days of Turkey, Days of Thunder
description: WALL TOWNSHIP - THOMAS and Jennie Nicol, the founders of Wall Stadium, invited their extended family to their home every Thanksgiving for dinner. For several years in a row, the weather was unusually balmy. And that got Jennie Nicol to thinking.

title: Cry Wolf
description: AH, fall. This is the season when suburban males grab their rifles and don fluorescent-orange caps to pursue the whitetail deer in the sweet-smelling woods of the Adirondacks. What's odd about this -- besides the hats -- is that most of the deer are in the suburbs the hunters have left behind.

title: Dana Wallach and Michael Jones
description: Dana Alison Wallach was married last evening to Michael Tomo Molyvos Jones. Rabbi Tom Weiner officiated at the University Club in New York.

title: Reviving Their Revival (Again)
description: Let's say you're in a rock band from a distant but suddenly hot era, and you've gotten your original lineup together for the first time in over 20 years. You've toured the world to huzzahs, and played all your old songs. You've even heard them played by lots of hip new bands. What's left to do to extend the brand?

title: Gay Retirement Communities Are Growing in Popularity
description: PALMETTO, Fla. - THREE years ago, Philip Owens started thinking about retiring from a career in retailing in New York, and he considered what his next move might be. He wanted to get away from the snow and miserable winters. Florida's Gulf Coast beckoned, especially Sarasota with its rich cultural calendar.

title: Treasure boxes on your TV
'Andrew Jackson'
description: The struggle for North America began long before Andrew Jackson was born. Like similar struggles on all the inhabited continents, it ran back millennia, perhaps to the moment humans first found their way across the Arctic plain from Asia. Oral tradition and archaeological evidence indicate that conflict was a regular feature of life among the North Americans. They fought for forests where the game was most abundant, for rivers where the fish were thickest, for bottomlands where their corn and beans and squashes grew most readily. Great warriors were the heroes of their tribes, emulated by other men, sought by women, hallowed in memory. Strong tribes expanded their territories, driving the weak to less-favored regions and sometimes to extinction. Diplomacy complemented military force: the Iroquois confederation made that alliance a terror to its neighbors.

title: Kiss, Kiss, Bang, Bang
description: Descending into the skinny gulch that is Deadwood, S.D., you can easily mistake it for your average cow town, with a population of 1,830. It's hard to conjure up its past as a lawless frontier town, once home to thousands of gold miners, gunslingers, flimflam artists, gamblers and whores, not to mention Chinese opium dealers. In 1876, a million dollars' worth of gold was pulled from the hills in a matter of months. And the murder rate was about one a day.

title: Breathing room for Bernini
Are Three Towers Now Two? No. One's Just Hiding.
description: IS there suddenly a new twin-towered apartment house on Central Park West? Not really. It's just the 1929 Beresford, between 81st and 82nd Streets -- construction netting has temporarily shrouded one of its three distinctive towers.

title: Why Vote?
description: I was unmoved by the Freakonomists' case against voting. Their Swiss example seems to be especially counterillustrative. Undera universal vote-by-mail scheme,the almightyballot becomes just another piece of postal matter.With no exclusive date and place set aside for voting, it becomes immeasurably easier to forget to vote. While mail-in ballots are certainly a boon to house-bound citizens, it was unrealistic to imagine that depriving voters of thetime-honored incentive of a dedicated calendar date would have anything other than the mild turnout-depressing effect that it did.
