title: Venice, Calif., Is Turning Into Sunrise Boulevard
description: "ABBOT KINNEY BOULEVARD is the nucleus of Venice," said Hillary Greene Shugrue, manager of French 50's-60's, the vintage French furniture and art store that sits at the south end of this Los Angeles street.

title: Special Issue: Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: CALENDAR
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Cultural Calendar, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE DARLING, by Russell Banks. (Harper Perennial, $14.95.) Hannah Musgrave, the narrator of Banks's gripping novel, is a dreamer and privileged child of the 1960's who continually remakes herself: first as Dawn Carrington, a member of the Weather Underground who flees America to avoid arrest; then as Mrs. Woodrow Sundiata, the pampered wife of a Liberian cabinet minister. Years later, Hannah reflects on the brutal revolution that killed her husband, turned their three sons into crazed killers and brought Charles Taylor to power in the 1990's. Our reviewer, Mary Gordon, called "The Darling" "savage in its particulars but consistently elegant."

title: Crying Racism
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: China to buy 70 Boeing 737 airliners
Why Mr. Magliaro Carries a Metal Detector
description: ONCE winter arrives in earnest, when front lawns and backyards resemble glacial plains, Tom Magliaro doesn't leave his oil-delivery truck without a metal detector.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TISCH, PRESTON ROBERT
description: TISCH--Preston Robert. 79. Died peacefully at his home in NYC on November 15th. Survived by Joan Tisch, wife of 57 years, son Steven and his wife Jamie, daughter Laurie, and son Jonathan; grandchildren, Emily, Hilary, Carolyn, William, Charles, Henry, Elizabeth, Holden, and Zachary. Brother of the late Laurence Tisch and his wife, Billie, and uncle, relative, friend and colleague to many. Cofounder and Chairman of the Board of Loews Corporation and Chairman & Co-CEO of the New York Football Giants. Dedicated to his country, state and city, Bob generously gave both his time and resources, serving in countless leadership positions, including: Postmaster General of the United States, founding Director of Citymeals-onWheels, founder and Chairman of Take the Field, Chairman of the New York City Convention & Visitors Bureau, founding Chairman of the New York City Convention and Exhibition Center Corporation, Chairman of the NYC Partnership, Inc. and the NY Chamber of Commerce and Industry, Chairman of NYC Public Private Initiatives, Inc., and trustee of New York University. Funeral services will be private for family. The family will be receiving condolences on Thursday, November 17, and Sunday, November 20, from 5 to 9 PM. A memorial service will be held on Friday, December 9, 2005, at 11 AM, at Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Preston Robert Tisch Brain Tumor Research Center at Duke University, Citymeals - on Wheels, or the Preston Robert Tisch Center for Hospitality, Tourism, and Sports Management at New York University.

title: Special Issue: Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: November 20, 2005
description: Weeks

title: In the Line of Fire
description: CAMP NORMANDY, Iraq - IT was her first raid of an Iraqi home, and Pvt. Safiya Boothe, 21, had no idea what to expect. Tucking herself behind a group of men from her Army unit, her soft features and wispy body hidden by full battle gear, she walked through the front door, trying to be as anonymous as possible. When no shots were fired, she exhaled.

title: Italian Favorites With an Asian Touch
description: WHEN I first walked into Marisa's Ristorante in Trumbull, I thought, "Uh-oh, another oversize Italian restaurant with an oversize menu and ordinary food." Connecticut is full of places like that. But I Marisa's is a pleasant surprise.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about Westchester real estate misstated the price and the location of an eight-room co-op. The listed price is $949,000, not $900,000; the building is in Yonkers, not Bronxville.

title: A Bus Stop Named Trouble
description: West End Avenue in the 60's is a de facto retirement community. The elderly are everywhere: teetering up the steep, tilted sidewalks of the avenue; chatting over trays of soup and tuna fish in the Lincoln Square Neighborhood Center; and waiting for their lifeline, the M57 bus, which takes them up and down the avenue, and all the way crosstown along 57th Street, without the need to transfer.

title: Tennis: Nalbandian, a late entry, grabs rare victory from Federer's grasp
The Incest Loophole
description: WHAT if I told you that a father who was regularly raping his 8-year-old daughter could reasonably expect to avoid prison if he were discovered? You'd be outraged, right? But this is a fact of life in New York, thanks to the "incest loophole." And nobody in the Legislature is even trying to change this reprehensible law.

title: The Problem With an Almost-Perfect Genetic World
description: MIA PETERSON is not a fan of tests. Because she has Down syndrome, she says, she cannot always think as fast as she would like to and tests end up making her feel judged. A recent driving test, for instance, ended in frustration.

title: No Clear G.O.P. Successor in Line After Mayor's Win
description: Correction Appended

title: Union and Unity
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Matthew Leachman and Pablo Szneiberg
description: Matthew Steven Leachman and Pablo Sebastian Szneiberg celebrated their partnership last evening at their home in Miami. Brandon Macsata, a friend of theirs, led the commitment ceremony.

title: The Family Ticket
description: 26 ways to entertain your kids on the road, in the city, at sea, even on their own. They don't need a tv, just a mocktail.

title: University Is Accused of Bias Against Christian Schools
description: Cody Young is an evangelical Christian who attends a religious high school in Southern California. With stellar grades, competitive test scores and an impressive list of extracurricular activities, Mr. Young has mapped a future that includes studying engineering at the University of California and a career in the aerospace industry, his lawyers have said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YASS, ANNE
description: YASS--Anne. Loving wife of the late Edward. Wonderful mother of Helene Dubin, Janice Guterman and David. Caring mother - in - law of Scott, Ed and Kara. Dear sister of the late Eva Turk and Marion Levine. Adoring grandmother of Zachary, Rebecca, Julia, Emily, Alec and Eliza.

title: Buss Balm
description: As cold weather approaches, Aesop's new line of lip balms inspired by herb gardens have acquired a cult following among the chapped of lip. The balms come in three scents -- coriander, ginger and rose hip seed -- and are enriched with autumnal staples like carrot, almond and ginger root. Sheer and clear, the fragrant salves are neither sticky nor shiny and are a refreshingly sophisticated alternative to the recent boom of candy-colored, sugar-flavored lip glosses that have glutted the market. Each pot costs $15; all three varieties are available at Barneys New York. PULSE

title: Chancellor Angela Merkel
The Nets Keep Arenas in Check and Beat the Wizards
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 19 - Nets Coach Lawrence Frank said before Saturday's game against the Washington Wizards that the key to victory was stopping guard Gilbert Arenas. It was not exactly a novel approach. Arenas entered as the third-leading scorer in the N.B.A., at 27.8 points a game.

title: Other Views: Sddeutsche Zeitung, Miami Herald, Toronto Star
Dorothy Nolte, 81, Author of Parenting Poem, Dies
description: Dorothy Law Nolte, a writer and family counselor whose ubiquitous inspirational poem, "Children Learn What They Live," was photocopied, circulated, anthologized and affixed to refrigerator doors worldwide for nearly two decades before she claimed rightful authorship of it in the 1970's, died on Nov. 6 at her home in Rancho Santa Margarita, Calif. She was 81.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCKHANN, CHARLES F.
description: MCKHANN -- Charles F., Professor Emeritus of the Yale School of Medicine, died of prostate cancer on November 14, 2005, at the age of 75. He leaves his wife Rhona, sons Chas and Peter, daughter Lisa, grandchildren Emma and Alice, and brother Guy. A graduate of Harvard College and the University of Pennsylvania Medical School, his clinical work and extensive research were devoted to the study of cancer, first at Harvard, then at the University of Minnesota and later at Yale. His books include "The Facts About Cancer" and "A Time to Die, the Place for Physician Assistance." An avid outsdoorsman, he enjoyed sailing, canoeing, skiing, climbing and hiking with his family. A memorial service will be held at Yale in the spring.

title: Ultimate Soviet Henchman Returns to His Pedestal
description: Fourteen years ago, Moscow's summer was filled with sheer exuberance. The Soviet Union was suddenly gone, separated into 15 different states and a thousand pieces. People were afraid, but many believed Russia would turn democratic naturally, like a whole nation taking a sudden breath of fresh, free air after being too long underwater.

title: A Doctor For the Future
description: Dr. Morton was a source of significant education of these communities about the genetic aspect of the children's illnesses. But there was nothing in the article to indicate that he educated parents about the need for their children to begin marrying outside their immediate community, to increase the health of the gene pool. Without that change, many Amish and Mennonite children will continue to have these terrible illnesses.

title: The Literary Darwinists
description: Your article on the Literary Darwinists, who "study literature through biology" and say that literature "derives its truth from laws of nature," seems to view this approach as revolutionary. What it describes, however, are tenets of literary naturalism, a philosophy espoused by a number of canonical American and European writers of the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Zola, Hardy, Dreiser, Crane, Norris, Sinclair, London and others relied on the biological determinism of Charles Darwin (but more directly Herbert Spencer) to unite science with the humanities and add to the interpretation of human behavior what Edward O. Wilson referred to as "deep history, deep genetic history."

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   CONHEIM, SUE
description: CONHEIM--Sue. November 19, 1950. In ever loving memory. Marilyn

title: Widespread Violence Kills Dozens Across Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 20 - The Marine Corps said today that 15 Iraqi civilians and a United States marine were killed on Saturday when a roadside bomb exploded in the town of Haditha, 140 miles northwest of Baghdad. At least 11 other Iraqis were killed or discovered dead today in various incidents, and military officials reported the deaths of two more Americans and a British soldier.

title: Republican Mayors In a Democratic Town
description: To the Editor:

title: One House's Heart Transplant
description: JERSEY CITY - THOSE of us who live in the Northeast are already painfully aware of how expensive it's going to be to keep warm this winter. With heating-oil prices rising over the past couple of years, people gambled and converted to gas; now, with natural-gas prices expected to surge, it all seems to be about the same. Perhaps the only difference is the efficiency of the heating system itself -- and, in older homes, the boiler.

title: For Those Museum-Quantity Pieces
description: MUSEUMS are measured by the quality of their collections and so, too, are museum shops. Whether they are looking for a memento of a visit or searching for a special gift, shoppers at these stores will find merchandise as quirky and diverse as the museums themselves.

title: 'One Bullet Away'
Inside the List
description: JESUS, JUICED: Anne Rice's 27th novel, "Christ the Lord: Out of Egypt," is No. 4 on this week's hardcover fiction list. The book, like Norman Mailer's "Gospel According to the Son" (1997), is a first-person account of the life of Jesus, though Rice cannily breaks off a smaller piece of that life, writing about him at age 7. ("It's as if Rice is casting Christ as the new Harry Potter," Chris Ayres wrote in The Times of London.) The book has arrived to some of the best reviews of Rice's career. There's something about writing in the voice of Jesus that smooths out a writer's prose; Reynolds Price, reviewing Mailer's book in the Book Review, didn't like Mailer's "excess of self-effacement." Yet Rice has been praised for pretty much the same thing. As Laura Miller put it in Salon: "Gone are such Ricean devices as passages of florid description, conspicuous high-end consumption, endless assurances of the main characters' beauty and that odd, pseudo-archaic Germanic syntax that would later become a trademark of Yoda. (Pretentious it was.)" Rice, who was brought up in the Roman Catholic Church, was an atheist for 30 years -- and wrote "Interview With the Vampire" and a pile of other pop-gothic novels -- before returning to the church in 1998. On "Charlie Rose," she seemed grateful she's been welcomed back. "I thought maybe," she said, "I had been officially excommunicated."

title: The Manager Is in a Slump (or Maybe It's Just a Phase)
description: FEW mutual fund managers beat the stock market over the long term. That sad truth is widely understood, and it helps to account for the vast popularity of index funds, which aspire only to match the returns of a particular market.

title: In Sri Lanka vote, 2 views on separatists
Cheap Sleep
description: Too often, an inexpensive hotel resembles the hostels of our youth. Here are four affordable hotels that make you feel like a grown-up. (All rates are for double rooms.) Paul L. Underwood

title: A Storefront That Ink Built
description: WHITE PLAINS - WHEN Ray Imperato received a yellow coupon in the mail offering $2 off on an inkjet or toner cartridge refill at Cartridge World, he was flummoxed.

title: Locked Bikes, Taken by the Police
description: To the Editor:

title: American Luger Sees the Olympics and the Germans
description: CESANA, Italy, Nov. 19 - When Courtney Zablocki came to the luge track here every day last week for training runs, she blocked out thoughts of how it will look in February in full Olympic regalia -- with thousands of fans packed into seats not yet built, snow covering the surrounding mountains, Olympic banners draping now-bare fences.

title: Upper West Side: Appetite Evolution
description: Galpagos tortoises and horned frogs from South America are on display at the American Museum of Natural History in the Darwin exhibition that opens this weekend. Hungry museumgoers can find more traditional fare at these restaurants, only a short trek away.

title: Catalan Comida
description: Food-happy travelers in Barcelona usually wind up dining on two things: El Bulli-style over-the-top meals or straightforward tapas. They'll find neither at the first restaurant by the Australian chef Sarah Stothart. It has no name or menu, just an address (53, Carrer de Tapioles; 011 34 93 329 2238). Call for reservations and head to the green door of this former umbrella factory, tucked away in the gritty Poble Sec neighborhood. Dinner is whatever Stothart whips up that day, largely dictated by market visits and trips to her parents' gardens in nearby Alt PenedA s. Think handmade gnocchi followed by a dessert made with her mother's just-harvested almonds. "I serve food I want to eat, and I like to chat with my guests," she says. "It's like having a meal in my home." GISELA WILLIAMS

title: High Thai Design
description: The northern Thai city Chiang Mai, a former backpacking hub once known for elephant treks, ancient temples and carved wooden tchotchkes, has reinvented itself. Budget travelers and bohemian wanderers have made way for big-name modern designers and artists who come here to find inspiration, new talent and smart-looking bamboo coffee tables. Lured by the cheap cost of living, a long history of craftsmanship and the abundant natural resources, particularly the exotic local woods, Bangkok-based artists and designers have colonized Nimanhaemin and Charoen Raj Roads. La Luna gallery, for example, was established by a New Zealand photographer, a Danish journalist and a Thai store owner to showcase emerging artists from all over Southeast Asia. Nearby, Sop Moei Arts sells kitchen basketware and lacquerware based on the craft work of northern hill tribes. At Gerard Collection, two French brothers, Gerard and Jean Dauplay, rework bamboo and other native crops into mod-looking European pieces. Recent customers include Giorgio Armani, who likes his bamboo painted black.

title: Relatively Thankful
description: A week before my niece's bat mitzvah last weekend, my brother sat me down to screen a 13-minute video montage of family snapshots he had made for the event. I told him it was kind of repetitive and would be better a lot shorter.

title: State Panel to Rate Hospitals to Identify the Least Viable
description: The state commission on shrinking New York's hospital industry has adopted a rating system to start determining which hospitals should close, and it plans to assign scores to individual hospitals or groups of hospitals in January.

title: Corrections
description: The "Living In " article on Nov. 6, about Newburgh, N.Y., misstated the number of students in the Newburgh Enlarged City School District, which also encompasses New Windsor, N.Y. It is 12,650, not 2,700 (which is the number of high school students in the district).

title: A Legitimate Transaction
description: To the Editor:

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Nov. 20 -- Nov. 26; POP/JAZZ
description: It's funny how quickly -- and completely -- the roles have changed. It wasn't so long ago, after all, that R & B singers had a comfortable place in the entertainment industry and rappers could only watch them with envy. (Often well disguised as disgust.) Now R & B stars have to figure out a way to follow the trails blazed by hip-hop stars.

title: They Appraise Finer Points of the Diamond
description: GREENBURGH - IT was in Kansas more than 30 years ago that Bill James, a boiler-room attendant at a Stokely-Van Camp canning plant, took up the cause of debunking some of baseball's conventional wisdom. Taking documents and books to work every day -- as a profile in The New Yorker recalled a couple of years ago -- Mr. James pored over arcane statistics, eventually proving that starting pitching has no impact on attendance, among other things.

title: A Money-Laundering Case Turns to 50 Cent
description: The money-laundering trial of Irv Gotti, the hip-hop producer, and his brother has been relatively tame so far, centering on allegations of financial hanky-panky and the odd shoebox stuffed with cash dropped off at the offices of his record label, Murder Inc., in a glass tower on the West Side of Manhattan.

title: Music to Fit Your Mood
description: In the never-ending quest for those mythical beasts, the Young Audience Member and the First-Time Concertgoer, orchestras are dangling all manner of bait: musician blogs, preconcert cocktails, show-and-tell performances. The San Francisco Symphony's latest entry is the Concert Concierge, a Web site (www.sfsymphony.org/concierge) created to help users pick what concert to attend.

title: Local Museums Tapping Into Big-City Exhibitions
description: IT is always chancy to read trends into museum exhibitions, especially when examples are isolated and scattered. But at least one thing seems clear.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROOKER, BRUCE
description: BROOKER--Bruce, 78. Of Pelham Manor, died November 15. Survived by his loving wife Catherine and son Roger.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Nov. 20 -- Nov. 26; THEATER
description: It is the age-old challenge for playwrights: how do you dramatize human affairs with just, well, plain old humans? The answer for a couple of productions opening this week is to junk realism for something a little weirder.

title: Six Easy Pieces
description: Bikini-ready bodies not included. THE GET

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HIGGINS, GERRY
description: HIGGINS--Gerry. The President, faculty, staff and students of Borough of Manhattan Community College, and the Board of Directors and staff of the BMCC Foundation, mourn with heavy hearts the death of our colleague and friend, Gerry Higgins. Gerry was a member of the Board of the BMCC Foundation, and a tireless advocate for and supporter of the college and its students. More than that, Gerry was an inspiration to us all: a person who overcame obstacles in life, constantly strove for excellence in his professional and personal endeavors, and lived life to the full. He lived to help others, and the lives he touched and changed for the better are a testimony to the difference he made. Hundreds of disadvantaged young men and women have gone to college because of Gerry's work with the BMCC Foundation. He gave the gift of life itself to countless people by raising awareness of organ donation. We will miss his sound judgment, his good humor, and his great kindness. As a new road now rises to meet Gerry, may God continue to hold him in the hollow of His hand.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the front page of the Travel section today misstates the name of a building in Rome. It is the Pantheon, not the Parthenon.

title: SESSION EXPOSES POLITICAL RISKS INSIDE CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 - It was a bitter and fitting final note for a discordant Congress.

title: Yes, Virginia
description: VIRGINIA WOOLF

title: A Breathless and Savage 'La Mer' (Adieu Playful Waves)
description: Debussy: Orchestral Works Berlin Philharmonic, conducted by Simon Rattle. EMI Classics 5 58045 2; CD.

title: Can Nuclear Power Become Just Another Business?
description: LONDONDERRY, Pa. - STAND among the pumpkins and purple mums in the gravel parking lot of Anna's Garden and Gift Center and you can glimpse beyond the trees a ghost that haunts the nuclear power industry.

title: Last Exit to Los Angeles
description: MALIBU, Calif. - TUCKED into a narrow ravine above the Pacific Coast Highway, the Getty Villa, a faux-Roman retreat brimming with real Greco-Roman antiquities, has always drawn strong reactions. Built in the 1970's by an eccentric mogul, it was derided by aesthetes as a vulgar display of personal vanity. But the public was entranced by its splendor, and continued to flock there until the villa closed for renovations in 1997.

title: Nissan chief staying put
Stewart Poised to Head Onto Road Less Traveled
description: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Nov. 19 - The door to the most exclusive club in Nascar opens only about once or twice a decade, on the rare occasion when a driver earns the right to be measured against those who have won multiple season points titles. Of all the competitors who have raced in Nascar's premier division since the sport was organized in 1949, only 13 have managed to win more than one title in their careers.

title: The Holiday Crunch
description: Got that congested, tightly restricted feeling? It could be a chest cold, but we're guessing that you might also be feeling the effect of being stuck on one of the city's many impassable holiday streets. Gridlock, a common New York complaint, is especially severe from Thanksgiving week until January -- a powerful seasonal malady marked by a headache, rising blood pressure and an impending feeling of tardiness.

title: City Art, Suburban Art
description: IT is always chancy to read trends into museum exhibitions, especially when examples are isolated and scattered. But at least one thing seems clear.

title: 16 Years And Older Allows Your Teenager To Mush In Maine
description: If you long for a honeymoon-style holiday, here's where to ship the children off during winter break.

title: Meditations on the Commonplace
description: Correction Appended

title: Never Again, Again?
description: TAMA, Sudan - So who killed 2-year-old Zahra Abdullah for belonging to the Fur tribe?

title: With First Big Ten Title in 11 Years, Penn State Takes Revival to B.C.S.
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 19 - When it ended for Penn State on Saturday -- with a 31-22 victory over Michigan State, a share of the Big Ten championship and a major bowl berth -- the winners did not want to leave the field, even after most of the 75,005 spectators had vacated Spartan Stadium.

title: Storm Hit Little, but Aid Flowed to Inland City
description: JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 19 - When the federal government and the nation's largest disaster relief group reached out a helping hand after Hurricane Katrina blew through here, tens of thousands of people grabbed it.

title: Network Error
description: Truth and Duty

title: Why Vote?
description: I have to say that as a relatively dissociated person, with few ties to my community, the "civic duty" aspect is quite important to me. I appear at the polls (which are in a beautiful elementary school that I would not otherwise see) and make contact with the functionaries. We affirm that I am still alive and still a citizen. I disappear into a booth, push down the levers at the relevant places and vanish again. To the economist this may be nonproductive, irrational behavior, but for me, it shows that I am still here, still going and still an American. These are priceless facts.

title: The Great White Way
description: The last e-mail message I received from Wayne Hall contained two caveats. The first pertained to the local lingo: "Alaska residents can tell a newcomer by the terminology they use," he wrote. "'Snow machine' means snowmobile. 'Minus 30' is just 30 below." Though I sincerely hoped never to have occasion to use "30" and "below" in that order, being recognized as a lower-48er was the least of my worries. It was the second warning that had my long underwear in a knot: "I want you competent handling the team. A training run ahead of time is imperative or you will end up wrapped around a tree with a busted dog sled and a bloody nose. Don't want that to happen. Ha!"

title: Keeping Warm as Fuel Prices Rise (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: There Goes the Neighborhood
description: AT cocktail parties, family dinners, ballgames, even charity events, conversations across New York City invariably turn to two things: the staggering price of real estate and the latest new restaurant.

title: Elected Officials Can Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Gomes Wins Election For State Senate Seat
description: Edwin A. Gomes, a Democratic councilman from Bridgeport, won the special election on Monday to fill the vacant State Senate seat of Ernest Newton III in the 23rd District. Mr. Newton resigned in September before pleading guilty to corruption charges.

title: The Interior Designer
description: When David Netto decorates a home, his personal tastes take a back seat. "My sensibility is disciplined and largely molded on other people's taste," said this 36-year-old designer, whose clients include the actress Ione Skye and the fashion executive Eliza Bolen. "My projects don't look alike at all," he said. "I've done very dressed-up houses, but it's fun when someone wants some mischief too." When putting together an outfit, however, he relishes that "you don't have to please anyone else."

title: Deals and Consequences
description: DANIEL H. BAYLY, a gaunt, diminished man, sits alone in the visitor's room of the Petersburg federal prison in southern Virginia. The former head of investment banking at Merrill Lynch, Mr. Bayly wears his prison fatigues sharp and well-pressed. His grooming -- clean cheeks and silvery hair cut short -- is immaculate. Taut, he seems ready to shed his jailhouse garb for a suit of the darkest blue and catch his regular 6:58 a.m. commuter train out of Darien, Conn.

title: Iran's Parliament movesto block UN inspections
The Center No Longer Holds
description: The struggle for supremacy in American politics is usually seen as a closely fought battle for the middle ground. The two parties compete to win over the unassuming but pivotal figure that political scientists call the "median voter" -- the swing voter in the ideological center, who plays the decisive role come Election Day. The theory of the median voter is inspired by the analogy of two stores competing for customers: if consumers are evenly scattered in a region, the stores' best strategy is to locate right next to each other; otherwise, they take an unnecessary risk of losing potential customers. Political parties, too, should seek the center. Like a pendulum, politics swings back to the middle when governance strays too far to the extremes.

title: Iran Approves Bill to Bar U.N. From Nuclear Sites
description: TEHRAN, Nov. 20 - Iran's conservative Parliament approved the outline of a bill today that would bar United Nations inspectors from visiting its nuclear sites if the agency referred Iran's case to the Security Council for possible punitive measures.

title: Roundup: Playoff hole birdie lifts Woods to title
ON THE MARKET
description: Contemporary Village Loft $2,500,000 MANHATTAN: 56 East 11th Street (University Place and Broadway), #6 A one-bedroom, two-bath co-op loft. Jeffery Sholeen, the Corcoran Group (212) 875-2821; www.corcoran.com. MAINTENANCE: $1,900 a month PROS: This loft has had a smooth and sleek contemporary renovation. It uses materials like nickel tin ceiling tiles, glossy plywood floors, stainless steel appliances and Corian counters, and surfaces like white walls to pull and reflect light from the two natural sources in the front and back. Shops, restaurants and bars are located along the avenues at either end of this block, which is quiet because it is not a through street. CONS: The average sales price in this area of the Village is $988,000, and the median is $729,000, so a buyer is paying a premium for the aesthetics of the renovation.

title: Gadfly leader seeks Rio's reinvention
L'quipe looking beyond France
Awaiting God's Decision
description: "IN Case of Emergency" was the topic of a recent Sunday morning sermon at Canaan Baptist Church of Christ on West 116th Street in Harlem. The Rev. Dr. Welton Thomas Smith III, a compact man with a meaty handshake and an irrepressible smile, delivered the message, an inspired hodgepodge of passages from the Book of Mark, Seussian rhymes and news headlines. "Good God from Zion," he said, wiping his brow with a towel. "Even if FEMA don't know where to go and President Bush is still on vacation, the church is standing vigil and knows what to do when evening comes!"

title: Soccer: Awe overpowered the loyalty, and all else
Full Season Under Belt, Manning Surpasses the Learning Curve
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 17 - The Giants' offense begins at the sound of Eli Manning's voice, setting off collisions in front and on either side of him. It is a fast-moving, jumbled landscape where Manning has worked as a starting quarterback for 16 games, the line of demarcation that separates babe from veteran in the N.F.L.

title: Residential Sales From Around the Region
description: Manhattan

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a report on Nov. 6 about the marriage of Sheryl Joy Hillman and Michael Louis Press referred imprecisely to the occupation of the bridegroom's father, Robert Press. In addition to being a prosthetist, he is also an orthotist, not an orthodontist, with the Hanger Orthopedic Group in Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: A Victory for the Obvious
description: The recent opinion by Judge Thomas C. Platt of Federal District Court in Central Islip that the Shinnecocks of Southampton are really and truly an Indian tribe was received by some tribe members with sardonic gratitude.

title: Bush, in Beijing, Faces a Partner Now on the Rise
description: BEIJING, Sunday, Nov. 20 - President Bush began a one-day visit here on Sunday with a first set of meetings with President Hu Jintao of China to defuse a host of tensions, even as many in Beijing argue that he will be able to apply little true pressure on the world's fastest-rising power.

title: In a Mouthy Town, a Soft-Spoken Old-Timer
description: COME drink at McSorley's wonderful saloon in Manhattan, they say, and step into history. Sit where Abraham Lincoln tipped a few after his Cooper Union speech shortly before the Civil War, or so they like to say, where endless numbers of workingmen, schemers and honest New Yorkers have sat since the tavern opened in 1854.
Mother-Son

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEWIS, MYRNA
description: LEWIS--Myrna. We mourn the death of the beloved wife of our co-walker and dear friend, Bob Butler. Her significant contributions in so many areas have made, and will continue to make a difference. Our deepest sympathy to Bob, Alexandra and the many others who loved her. The Walking Group

title: Join a Revolution. Make Movies. Go Broke.
description: ARIN CRUMLEY, 24, and his girlfriend, Susan Buice, 27, sat in their cramped apartment in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, in front of the computers on which they edited their independent film. Post-Its on a nearby wall read, "Eat Less," "No More Banana Chips" and "Work Succeed." An oversized skateboard leaned precariously against a makeshift desk. Several women's wigs were scattered on the floor.

title: Why Vote?
description: The article is fun, but nonsense. It is the active human expression of will and determination to influence an outcome that drives democracy and voting. Take away that hope, and we no longer have a democracy. So looking at rational and irrational voting habits, trends or behavior in terms of statistics misses the point.

title: The Story of the Search, Applause Included
description: THOUGH "The Google Story," by David A. Vise and Mark Malseed (Delacorte Press, $26), is as adoring a business profile as I have read, there are occasional hints that the extraordinary success of this search-engine phenom has begun to go to its head -- and maybe even produced a touch of the arrogance for which past software kings have been famous.

title: MORE HIGHLIGHTS OF ST. JOHN
description: To the Editor: As a homeowner on St. John for 20 years, , I certainly endorse Bonnie DeSimone's rave reviews of the beaches and snorkeling in St. John in "America's Aquarium, Seen From the Inside," (Oct. 23). I keep looking for a better place for these activities in my travels. So far, no comparison anywhere.

title: Riversprawl
description: Gaze at length at the landscape paintings of the Hudson River School, and you may find in their luminous details the ineffable glory of the natural world. You will also find a near total absence of condominiums. Call us crazy, but we feel certain the two phenomena are connected somehow.

title: To Shoppers, This Thrift Store Includes Joy in the Bargain
description: LAURIE STERN placed the black velvet hat over her long, honey-colored hair and grinned like a smiley-face logo. "This is stunning," she said.

title: Israel's Labor Party to Pull Out of Ruling Coalition
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 20 - Israel's Labor Party, under its new leader, agreed today to pull its eight ministers out of the ruling coalition with Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, hastening the prospect of early elections.

title: At Least Toss the Runner-Up a Bone
description: "It's 'Sex and the City' meets 'Best in Show' meets 'Lassie,' " Gayle Kirschenbaum said, explaining the star vehicle she had created for Chelsea, her Shih Tzu. Shot in part with a specially rigged "doggie cam," the film is called "A Dog's Life: A Dogamentary," and it is one of 14 films featured in the International Dog Film Festival.

title: How Google Tamed Ads on the Wild, Wild Web
description: FIVE years ago, Web advertisers were engaged in an ever-escalating competition to grab our attention. Monkeys that asked to be punched, pop-ups that spawned still more pop-ups, strobe effects that imparted temporary blindness -- these were legal forms of assault. The most brazen advertiser of all, hands down, was X10, a little company hawking security cameras, whose ubiquitous "pop under" ads were the nasty surprise discovered only when you closed a browser window in preparation for doing something else.

title: Who Dares Challenge the Nerd King's Crown?
description: THERE he sits, the "Sultan of Stats," a schlumpy, paunchy middle-aged man with an unkempt goatee, so secure in his status as king of the sports nerds that he has the temerity to wear a Knicks jersey over a T-shirt, Patrick Ewing-style. He's so uncool that he's cool, the stand-in for every beer-bellied face painter who never got a prom date, the office manager-slash-fantasy football commissioner without the corner office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   QUINN, JOHN D.
description: QUINN--John D. Former New York State Lottery Director, John D. Quinn of Saratoga Springs, NY, died November 16, 2005 at the age of 77. Born in New York City to Irish immigrants, Mr. Quinn was a career Army officer who retired as a Colonel in 1970 with the Bronze Star and Legion of Merit awards. From 1976 to 1988, he served as Director of the New York State Lottery, introducing Lotto to the U.S. gaming industry, making New York highest in sales among U. S. state lotteries, and enlisting celebrities like Frank Sinatra, Dean Martin, and Bob Hope to participate in drawings. He was instrumental in the acquisition of the USS Intrepid for the floating Sea, Air, and Space Museum in New York City. He is survived by Dora, his wife of 55 years; his children Carol Loulis, John Quinn, Anthony Quinn, and Timothy Quinn; his siblings James Quinn, William Quinn, and Kathleen Viccora; eight grandchildren; and a large, close, extended family. Funeral services, including burial with full military honors in Arlington National Cemetery, will be conducted on January 19, 2006. Contact the Adams-Green Funeral Home in Herndon, VA for details. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions may be sent to Catholic Relief Services, 209 West Fayette St., Baltimore, MD 21201-3443; or the American Hospice Foundation, 2120 L Street NW, Suite 200, Washington, D.C. 20037.

title: Lynne Truss Has Another Gripe With You
description: 'To some people, the fact that I am not married, or don't have children, would be the reason I have written a book on punctuation,' Lynne Truss remarked on a recent afternoon in her gravelly British voice. She was sitting in her living room in Brighton, the seaside resort on the southern coast of England, where she inhabits a realm far removed from the vacationing families who stroll the Palace Pier, eating fried cod, lifting pinwheels into the breeze and gazing out toward the tip of France.

title: A Big Start for a Show Reveling in Smallness
description: MAMARONECK - IT'S a smart show that puts its big number at the top of Act I, and "The Fantasticks" is a smart show.

title: At Least 35 Iraqis and 5 G.I.'s Are Killed in Attacks, Including a Bombing at a Funeral
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 19 - A suicide bomber drove a car packed with explosives into a Shiite funeral tent on Saturday and blew it up among the mourners, killing at least 18 Iraqi civilians and wounding 18 others.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Nov. 20 -- Nov. 26; ART/ARCHITECTURE
description: During the 1970's EMILIO AMBASZ was a design curator at the Museum of Modern Art. Now Mr. Ambasz, an Argentine-born architect, is the subject of a small exhibition opening there on Wednesday. On view will be seven drawings, a pair of models and recent photographs of his HOUSE OF SPIRITUAL RETREAT, designed in 1979 for an imaginary site near Cordoba, Spain, and built only last year outside Seville. The design features two white walls at a 90-degree angle with a stairway descending into a sunken patio that features the living quarters surrounding it on two sides, recessed below ground, using the earth's covering to insulate them.

title: Insurgents raise stakes in Iraq

Turkey, Turkey, Everywhere (and Football, Too)
description: On a certain late-November Thursday, football talk and leftover turkey (Please, please, take some home!) are infinite -- or so it often seems at the time. But while researchers have yet to discover any limit to football talk, the number of turkeys across this great, gobbling land is most definitely finite.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 6 about a couple who decided against an apartment purchase on Irving Place in Manhattan because their agent had discovered that a building was planned on the site of an adjoining parking garage misstated the date for the start of construction. The developer says it has not set a date for construction; it is not expected to start by the end of this year.

title: The Remix; Welcome to WeBo
description: The Mayfair section of London west of Bond Street is getting a face-lift. Following in the footsteps of the fashion designer Rei Kawakubo and her avant-garde emporium, Dover Street Market (17-18 Dover Street; 011 44 207 518 0680), Paul Smith has opened 9 Albemarle Street (011 44 207 495 4708), filled with ceramic birds, globes, 1920's wallpaper borders and back issues of Domus magazine. A few doorsteps away is David Linley's furniture store (46 Albemarle Street; 011 44 207 290 1410). Tucked among the tiny tea shops is Automat (right), a jazzy-looking American brasserie (33 Dover Street; 011 44 207 499 3033). When you're ready to stow your purchases, check into Brown's Hotel (Albemarle Street; 011 44 207 493 6020), a group of Georgian town houses that has undergone a $36 million renovation and will reopen in December. DOROTHY GIORDIANO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBINSON, BARCLAY JR.
description: ROBINSON--Barclay Jr. A loyal and dedicated member of the Board of Trustees of The Ethel Walker School. His commitment, ethusiasm and deep caring for the School will be greatly missed by all who knew and worked with him. Our deepest sympathies go to his wife Katharine, and their entire family. C. title: How to Act Like a Poet in Black and White
description: Duane Michals's photographic sequences, often as poignant as they are witty, have been likened to visual poems. Constantin Cavafy's poems were of the more traditional variety -- words strung together on a page. But in Mr. Michals's new series, "The Adventures of Constantin Cavafy" (on exhibit at Pace MacGill Gallery in New York), the two come together in imagined scenes from the poet's life that reflect themes in his poetry. Cavafy was unable to participate, having died in 1933, so he is played by the actor Joel Grey.

title: A Doctor For the Future
description: Lisa Belkin's article (Nov. 6) on Holmes Morton and his work with severely ill Amish and Mennonite children is the perfect argument against intelligent design. There was a time when we had not yet "discovered" germs, and people said illness was God's punishment for our sins. Today,even the Amish are willing to accept that there is a scientific explanation for the diseases that strike them. Simply because we don't have all the answers for the complexity of human beings does not mean that there is not a logical explanation. It means only that we have not yet figured out the answers. God may exist, but we do not need to use him as an excuse for everything we do not comprehend.If we do, itputs us back in the Dark Ages. Is this the logic we want to teach in our schools?

title: Toasty Restaurants With Menus to Match
description: WHEN cold winds blow and the person who pays the bills at home keeps lowering the thermostat, it may be time to head to a cozy restaurant for some heartwarming food. Let someone else spend all day braising that lamb shank or cooking that pot roast. And if you plan ahead, you may even snag a table in front of a fireplace.

Put up by carpenter-builders as the country village of Yorkville was taking shape, the foursome have held their own through the successive waves of mansions, town houses and apartment buildings that have come to define Carnegie Hill.

title: As the McMansions Go, So Goes Job Growth
description: THERE'S a growing consensus that the housing market is cooling off. This month, Toll Brothers, the luxury home builder, warned that sales of McMansions were falling, and its highflying stock fell to earth. Last Thursday, the Commerce Department reported that housing starts, a reliable gauge of present activity, fell 5.6 percent in October from year-ago levels, while building permits, a reliable gauge of future activity, fell 6.7 percent.

description: On one level, Jack Murtha is right. The American presence in Iraq does incite violence. The American presence in Iraq does lend popular legitimacy to the terrorists that they would not otherwise have. All things being equal, it would be a good thing if we could reduce the American presence in Iraq.

title: Why Vote?

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Nov. 20 -- Nov. 26; FILM
description: Issues of history, national identity and the shadowy path to affluence seep through the work of the Italian filmmaker GIANNI AMELIO, the subject of a 12-movie retrospective, "POETRY AND RIGOR," being presented at the MUSEUM OF MODERN ART in partnership with the CINECITT HOLDING company In "LAMERICA," set in Albania just after the country converted from Communism to democracy, two Italian swindlers descend on it to set up a dummy corporation to steal redevelopment money. For its chairman they choose a mentally addled Albanian imprisoned by the Communists for 50 years, a man who turns out to have been an Italian war deserter. When the chairman escapes from the orphanage, where the swindlers have stashed him, the younger con man scours the country looking for him and along the way loses most of his material possessions and a sense of his own national identity.

title: The Remix; Catalan Comida
description: Food-happy travelers in Barcelona usually wind up dining on two things: El Bulli-style over-the-top meals or straightforward tapas. They'll find neither at the first restaurant by the Australian chef Sarah Stothart. It has no name or menu, just an address (53, Carrer de Tapioles; 011 34 93 329 2238). Call for reservations and head to the green door of this former umbrella factory, tucked away in the gritty Poble Sec neighborhood. Dinner is whatever Stothart whips up that day, largely dictated by market visits and trips to her parents' gardens in nearby Alt Peneds. Think handmade gnocchi followed by a dessert made with her mother's just-harvested almonds. "I serve food I want to eat, and I like to chat with my guests," she says. "It's like having a meal in my home." GISELA WILLIAMS

title: Continental Drift
description: Q: As one of France's most celebrated philosophers, can you give us any insight into the civil discontent that is pitting a generation of young people against the rest of the country? It will get worse and worse and worse. For a long time, it was a relatively friendly coexistence or cohabitation, but the French haven't done much to integrate the Muslims, and there is a split now. Our organic sense of identity as a country has been split.

title: Uprooted by Hurricane Katrina, Finding a Hand in New York
description: After Sept. 11, 2001, New York's social service organizations were confronted by an unprecedented swirl of need. In an effort to synchronize the streams of resources, the groups formed a citywide disaster response committee under the city's Human Services Council, and left the framework in place after the 9/11 demands died down.

title: One-of-a-Kind Gifts, All Made by Hand
description: CRAFTS fairs have come a long way since the days when potters and woodworkers simply gathered on Main Street to sell their wares. Today's events are sleek and sophisticated, with lavish displays of painted silks, watercolors and jewelry vying for attention with hand-framed prints and stained-glass creations.

title: Corruption Inquiry Threatens to Ensnare Lawmakers
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 - The Justice Department has signaled for the first time in recent weeks that prominent members of Congress could be swept up in the corruption investigation of Jack Abramoff, the former Republican superlobbyist who diverted some of his tens of millions of dollars in fees to provide lavish travel, meals and campaign contributions to the lawmakers whose help he needed most.

title: The Perplexing Pandemic Flu Plan
description: The Bush administration deserves credit for issuing a comprehensive plan to combat pandemic influenza and for seeking $7.1 billion to get it started. But the lengthy document recently issued by the Department of Health and Human Services looks like a prescription for failure should a highly lethal flu virus start rampaging through the population in the next few years. The plan sets lofty goals but largely passes the buck on practical problems. The real responsibilities wind up on the shoulders of state and local health agencies and individual hospitals, none of which are provided with adequate resources to handle the job.

title: Palestinian Finance Minister, Citing Election Plans, Quits

But the minister, Salam Fayyad, has also expressed enormous frustration at the inability of the Palestinian Authority to confront its financial problems, which are considerable, Palestinian and Western officials said.

title: Wedding Singers? Not!

He obliged, he told friends, but for only two numbers. Ja Rule, the platinum-selling rapper accustomed to Madison Square Garden, could not afford to strain his vocal cords. He had an important gig the next night. He was playing a Miami steakhouse. The occasion was a bat mitzvah.

title: Italo for Beginners
description: I took Italo Calvino's death -- 20 years and 5 days ago as I write this -- personally. Though he didn't know it, he'd broken a date. Calvino, one of the greatest European writers of the 20th century and among the only Italians (with Alberto Moravia, Luigi Pirandello and Umberto Eco) to have penetrated our shamefully translation-immune literary culture, had been about to visit the United States to deliver the Charles Eliot Norton lectures at Harvard, when at the age of 61, sitting in his backyard garden, he suffered a cerebral hemorrhage and, two weeks later, died. As well as the Harvard lectures, he'd agreed to a small American book tour, which was to have brought him as far as Cody's Books in Berkeley. I was to have been sitting in the front row, breathless. Instead, I learned of Calvino's death by reading a notice taped to Cody's doors, explaining the cancellation of the event, together with a clipping of the obituary I'd happened not to see.

title: Sending a Lost Boy to the Wilderness to Find Himself
description: IT'S dark. I lie in bed with my eyes open. The windows are closed, but I can still hear the gentle midnight roar of the New Jersey Turnpike, a mere quarter-mile from the front door of my safe suburban home.

title: Up Front
description: JONATHAN ALTER, who reviews Mary Mapes's account of the CBS-National Guard scandal on Page 12, remembers when the reputation of the news media was nearly as bad as it is today. "The period in 1984 when both CBS News (in the Westmoreland case) and Time magazine (in the Sharon case) were on trial in the same Manhattan courthouse was comparable," he said in an e-mail message. "But there was much less media criticism then, so the bad odor was not as strong." Having worked at Newsweek for more than 20 years and at NBC News for almost 10, Alter is used to the competitive environment that apparently had something to do with the decision to rush a story about George W. Bush's military record onto the air. "TV news is more influenced by ratings than newspapers and newsmagazines are by circulation, so the pressure is more intense," he said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KESTEN, SEYMOUR R.
description: KESTEN--Seymour R. A professor and author noted for his studies of utopian colonies, died last November in Palo Alto, California. He was 78. His death was announced by his sons, Philip and Randy. Mr. Kesten was born in Brooklyn and attended Richmond Hills High School. Upon returning from service in the Navy, he attended LIU, later receiving his BA in Fine Arts from SUNY New Paltz. In the intervening years, he owned and managed a wine and liquor store in Belrose, Queens and founded and operated a printing and publishing firm, Pastoral Press, in Grahamsville, NY. He received an MA in Musicology and a PhD in Humanities from Syracuse University. His research in that period focused on Beethoven's use of humor, Wagner's Ring Cycle, and American Studies of the early-to-mid 19th century, while serving as an instructor at Utica College, Cayuga County Community College and Syracuse University. He later was an assistant professor at Augusta College, Lake Superior State University and LaSalle College. He retired from teaching in 1991 to focus on research and writing. "Utopian Episodes: Daily Life in Experimental Colonies Dedicated to Changing the World," a work that grew out of research he had begun in the 1970's, was published in 1993 and is considered a seminal work on the subject. At the time of his death he was working on two further manuscripts relating to this time in history. Mr. Kesten's wife of 50 years, Rose Edith (Posner) Kesten, had died two months prior to his death, on their 50th wedding anniversary. He is survived by his sons, his daughters-in-law Kathy and Kirsten, and his grandchildren Sam, Chloe and Jamie. He is remembered by them and those who knew him as a humanist-concerned with people, how they live, what they do and what they believe.

title: Shoppers in the Malls, if Not on Wall Street
description: NO one can predict with certainty what the stock market will do on any given day, but forecasting a gain on the day after Thanksgiving is a safer bet than most. Investors are inclined to feel good after their day off, and they often express it by bidding up share prices upon their return.

title: From Nibbles to Big Portions, a Meal is Made
description: WHITE PLAINS - TIGHT schedules have made weekday dining out commonplace for singles and families, even those on a budget. Slow food is not always an option and fast food has little to recommend. The local Italian trattoria has often appealed to these customers, but now another choice is becoming popular: the Greek taverna.

title: Don't Celebrate Sexism
description: To the Editor:

title: Mastered Mozart, Preached Janacek, Schmoozed Shostakovich
description: LONDON - ASKED to imagine how we might spend our 80th birthday, most of us would say: taking it easy. But conductors tend to be of tougher mettle. Pierre Boulez turned 80 this year with scarcely a change in his working schedule. And on Thursday evening, if all went as planned at press time, Charles Mackerras did the same, marking the event by slipping quietly into the pit of the Royal Opera House as he has done countless times during the last half-century, to conduct a revival; in this case, Verdi's "Ballo in Maschera."

title: Maggie's Wonderful Saloon
description: JERSEY CITY - I USUALLY don't like to make blanket comparisons of cozy neighborhoods to Frank Capra's "It's a Wonderful Life" -- especially around the holidays. And my guess is that those who have never visited downtown Jersey City would conjure images that are far from a typical idyllic village, let alone anything remotely similar to George Bailey's Bedford Falls. But, perhaps especially because Jersey City doesn't normally inspire such sentiments, a place like the Hamilton Park Ale House seems that much more magical.

title: Adding an Energy Surcharge to Rent
description: Q -- The lease I have with my tenant stipulates that utilities are included with the rent and that the rent shall remain at the same level for 24 months. We are now in the second year of that lease.

title: Caution in the Adirondacks
description: On the whole, this has been a positive year for the Adirondacks. Apart from the Adirondack Park Agency's inexplicable fondness for ugly and wholly unnecessary cell towers (known locally as Frankenpines), government agencies generally gave the park the protective affection it deserves.

title: Recoloring Thanksgiving
description: Thanksgiving floral offerings like stiff orange chrysanthemums and spiky maroon gerbera daisies are last year's potpourri. This season albino pumpkin arrangements brighten restaurants like Fiamma Osteria in SoHo, and an installation of green apple pumpkins occupies a wall of the Butterfly Studio in the Flatiron district. Meredith Waga-Perez, an owner of Belle Fleur floral design studio, said requests for small albino pumpkins (also known as Caspers or Baby Boos) have been pouring in. A centerpiece of pumpkins, hydrangea, freesia and cabbage roses like this one starts at $100 (212-254-8703). PULSE

title: One War Lost, Another to Go
description: IF anyone needs further proof that we are racing for the exits in Iraq, just follow the bouncing ball that is Rick Santorum. A Republican leader in the Senate and a true-blue (or red) Iraq hawk, he has long slobbered over President Bush, much as Ed McMahon did over Johnny Carson. But when Mr. Bush went to Mr. Santorum's home state of Pennsylvania to give his Veterans Day speech smearing the war's critics as unpatriotic, the senator was M.I.A.

title: A Doctor For the Future
description: The discovery of "pretzel syndrome" was certainly expedited by the availability of the whole human genome sequence, but that does not make it "genomic" per se. In contrast to genetic medicine, true genomic medicine will require a new breed of physician, trained to address the more genetically complex diseases that are alluded to in the article -- Alzheimer's disease, arthritis, heart disease, hypertension, stroke and cancer -- with tools that are capable of whole genome interrogation. These conditions generally result from multiple genes (perhaps hundreds or even thousands) interacting with the environment to cause disease. True genomic medicine seeks to understand both the underlying causal genes and environmental factors in order to provide more precise predictions of health outcomes, as well as more tailored and effective therapies. Despite its greater complexity, genomic medicine, like genetic medicine, will require champions similar to Holmes Morton, who understand both the patient and the science, and who can help us focus on the right questions the genome awaits to answer.

title: The Remix; Camera Obscura
description: When Paris Hilton starts making the rounds at Sundance, you know it's time to find a new film festival. Camerimage, Poland's celebration of cinematography, might be a cinaste's best hope. The Lodz-based festival (Nov. 26 to Dec. 4) draws students, cinematographers and world-cinema A-listers like Sophie Marceau and John Malkovich. David Lynch, a regular, loved the town so much that he shot his coming film, "Inland Empire," there. In a Lynchian (or is it a Kafkaesque?) twist, cinematographers compete for the Golden Frog, an award inspired by a plague of frogs, part of the local mythology. PAUL L. UNDERWOOD

On a recent rainy evening, Mr. Murray surveyed the lot and said matter-of-factly, "Here's the scene of the crime."

title: Boogie Noches
description: Not long after we had arrived in Buenos Aires, we crossed one of the bridges connecting the Puerto Madero district to the rest of the enormous eastward-spreading city and began to stroll along the quay. It was a bright, clear afternoon, blustery in that housecleaning way of early spring, and the city appeared to be populated exclusively by young people. (Later we discovered the university nearby.) In New York it might be fall, but here it was spring; my good friend and I may no longer be a romantic couple, but for now we were traveling companions; and I might have plenty of other work to do, but for the moment my job was to report on the night life of Buenos Aires. Duty compelled me to dine at fine restaurants, dance all night long with my beautiful ex-girlfriend and keep the bottles of malbec coming. And all for the sake of the story.

title: Cry Wolf
description: AH, fall. This is the season when suburban males grab their rifles and don fluorescent-orange caps to pursue the whitetail deer in the sweet-smelling woods of the Adirondacks. What's odd about this -- besides the hats -- is that most of the deer are in the suburbs the hunters have left behind.

Memorial Mass will be at St. Agnes Cathedral, Monday, November 21 at 11:00 A.M., 29 Quealy Place, Rockville Centre, NY. In lieu of flowers, Lillian and Peter would like you to consider a donation to: St. Agnes Outreach Center, 29 Quealy Place, Rockville Centre, NY 11570, attention: Sister Kathleen Murphy.

title: The Remix; Ski Patrol | Eastern Mountain Sports
description: A freshly minted Chinese middle class has a new hobby to match: skiing. The best slopes are at the Yabuli resort in Dongbei, a remote northeast region between Siberia and North Korea. The government has approved plans for a ski-specific airport that would link it to Beijing, Shanghai and Hong Kong. But don't go there expecting Aspen-style amenities. Since this is chain-smoking China, men sometimes slalom with cigarettes in their mouths. Accommodations are basic at best, and the black-diamond-rated trails will bore daredevils. At least the fees are thrilling: $35 a day. And don't worry about making a fashion statement. Most visitors rent the resort's yellow snowsuits. Here are three slopes to ski. MARK ELLWOOD

title: The Literary Darwinists
description: D.T. Max's article (Nov. 6) made me blink because academic discourse in literary studies so often propels itself forward with some version of the rejoinder "Actually, it's more complicated/nuanced/intricate than that." Here we have a supposedly new way of looking at things that says, "Actually, it's all more simple than everyone thinks." The warriors of the "Iliad" engage in fierce competition for social dominance. The women in "Pride and Prejudice" compete to find mates whose status will assure the success of their offspring. So what? What can Literary Darwinism tell us about literature that a fourth-grade student can't tell us?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GILBERT, SUZANNE STATER
description: GILBERT--Suzanne Stater. Songwriter, actress, died October 29, 2005, of cancer at hospital in New York City. Born January 29, 1924 in Portland, Oregon, Sue Gilbert grew up on the West Coast and graduated from the University of Oregon. She became a stewardess for Pan Am, flying to Africa, Europe and Asia. In 1954, she married Craig Gilbert. After studying acting with Stella Adler, Sue found roles off-Broadway and on television. In recent years Sue found her calling as activist for environmental issues and protecting the animals. She composed and sang her own songs, and, together with her story-telling partner, Nick Cokkinos, performed for audiences throughout the northeast. At 77, Sue produced a CD, "The Spirit Rises, The Songs of Sue Stater." Sue will be sadly missed by Craig, her brother Wayne Stater, his wife Sylvia, two nephews, a niece, by Nick and a wide circle of friends. A gathering will be held in Sue's honor November 27 at 4 PM at 481 West 22nd Street, NYC. Remembrances to The Wilderness Society.

title: The Unwhole Truth
description: It was during a winter of long, dreary parties to which the same people came week after week. My best friend and my boyfriend and I went to the parties hoping there would be new people, but there were always only the old people. And always, when I saw them again, my heart would sink at the realization that this party would be a thankless repetition of the last party, at which nothing of note occurred.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORGENTHAU, JANE, WERTHEIMER
description: MORGENTHAU -- Jane, Wertheimer. Age 94 died November 14, 2005. Wife of Charles S. (deceased) and mother Kate (deceased). Jane, a graduate of Connecticut College was a lifetime avid reader of books, though born with greatly impaired eyesight. She worked at The Book Store in her hometown of Saint Louis, MO and in New York City at the Cokesbury Bookstore and the McBurney School Library. Friend, confidant and frequent hostess to her many cousins and dear friends, Jane always shared her interest and love in the lives of these individuals. A memorial gathering in her honor will be held on December 4, 2005 at 2PM at her home, 40 East 88th Street. Contributions in her memory may be made to The Kate Morgenthau Library Fund of Connecticut College.

title: In Their Adopted Land, Discovering the Land of Their Birth
description: Valhalla - THE seven girls and two boys paying close attention to a language class at the Huaxia Chinese School of Westchester Community College one recent morning were English-speaking Chinese-Americans ranging in age from 3 to 9. Chinese was as foreign to them as it was to their non-Chinese adoptive parents, who sat in the back of the class and joined the children in reciting the Chinese words for fruits and numbers as taught by the teacher, Cao Hong. Later, the parents would gather for their own language class while the children played outside.

title: After 2004 Holiday Woes, Airlines Make Changes
description: A record number of travelers hit the skies for the holidays last year and the Air Transport Association expects even more this year, with an estimated 21.7 million people flying over the 11 days surrounding Thanksgiving. In 2004, Thanksgiving travelers faced weather delays, while the Christmas rush saw a virtual meltdown at some airlines.

title: Their Highbrow Hatred of Us
description: James Traub (Oct. 30) observes correctly that it is impossible to "dissuade implacable ideologues, any more than you can an implacable jihadist." His prime example of the highbrow "anti-Americanism" that reigns beyond our sober shores is Harold Pinter, who even descends so low as to describe "NATO's 1999 air war in Kosovo" as "a criminal act" designed to consolidate "American domination of Europe," though all right-thinking people know that "the bombing was essentially a last resort in the face of Slobodan Milosevic's savage campaign of ethnic cleansing." At home, Traub continues, "it is hard to think of anyone save Noam Chomsky and Gore Vidal who would not choke on Pinter's bile."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORROW, ALISON
description: MORROW--Alison, 91. Died peacefully at home in New York City on October 26, after a short illness. She was born on April 15, 1914 in New York City to the late Dr. Albert Sidney Morrow and Marjorie Wyld Morrow. Growing up in Garden City, Long Island, Alison graduated from Cathedral School of St. Mary in 1931. Trained as a librarian, Alison worked as head librarian at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Research Center in Rye, New York. She retired in 1984. During World War II she joined the American Red Cross and served overseas in Belfast, Northern Ireland, then after the war, in Germany. Her father was a prominent New York surgeon who published two early twentieth century medical texts: "The Immediate Care of the Injured" in 1906, and "Diagnostic and Therapeutic Technic: A Manual of Practical Procedures Employed in Diagnosis and Treatment" in 1911. Never marrying, Alison had a gift for friendship and her optimism and good spirit and humor were treasured by all who knew her. She enjoyed sailing along the coast of Maine with friends each summer. A longtime member of the Hasbrouck Family Association of New Paltz, New York, Alison was a descendant of the Huguenots who settled in Ulster County to escape religious persecution in Europe. She especially loved the Hudson Valley, where her family long owned a summer home in Cornwall-on-Hudson, and Central Park, which she enjoyed by wheelchair until two weeks before her death. She was predeceased by her brother, Albert Sidney Morrow Jr., of Cornwall, New York. Survivors include nephews Christopher and Ian Marrow, Ian's wife Patricia O'Reilly, sister-in-law Barbara Morrow, all of Cornwall, goddaughters in the United States, England and South Aficia, and cousins. In her last years she got great joy and amusement from her grandniece, Cliona Morrow, and grandnephew, Cian Morrow, both of Cornwall. She lived a long, full life with great spirit, good humor and grace. Ally is greatly missed by her family and friends. Graveside service and burial will be at the convenience of the family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEYERSON, BEATRICE
description: MEYERSON - Beatrice, 81. Rockleigh, NJ. Devoted wife of the late Frank, beloved mother of Barbara (Boe) and George, adored grandmother of Lesley and Jill, who were her greatest joy. Her family will miss her open hearted caring.

title: The Ticket; 60 Arcade Games To Keep Your Teenager Amused At Sea
description: Not long ago, teenagers stuck on a cruise ship would face a death sentence of shuffleboard. No more. Today, large commercial lines have floating teenage Edens -- giant game rooms-cum-discothques featuring a mix of theme parties, karaoke, the latest arcade games and whatever else market researchers say teenagers are into this week. And they're virtually free of adults except for some peppy activity coordinators. They can get their groove on at these hot spots. Fuel, Royal Caribbean International. Think South Beach with Miami-futuro styling and a built-in tanning deck (www.royalcaribbean.com). Without Batteries, Carnival Liberty. This toy-themed club features 60 arcade games (www.carnival.com). The Caboose, Carnival Valor. Bookish types can tuck into "Harry Potter" in the library (www.carnival.com). The Loft, Holland America. The room resembles a New York City artist's loft, complete with hot tub (www.hollandamerica.com)

title: The Remix; Au Courant
description: A quick trip on the TGV train to Lyon, France, this winter will titillate your gastronomic and your visual appetites. While other European countries (Italy, Switzerland, Germany) have trumped France in the contemporary art scene, the Lyon Biennial of Contemporary Art proves that the French are interested in paintings beyond the Monet-Manet-Matisse trifecta. This year's theme focuses on temporality in art (the slowness of painting, the speed of digital art) and features work from a liberal range of artists, including Andy Warhol, Josephine Meckseper ("Untitled," left), Gordon Matta-Clark and the French resident R. Crumb. The show, curated by Nicolas Bourriaud and Jrme Sans, of the cutting-edge Palais de Tokyo in Paris, is spread among five venues within city limits and runs through Dec. 31. MAURA EGAN

title: Cheney renews attack on prewar-data critics
In the Senate, a Chorus of Three Defies the Line
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 - On a July evening in the Capitol, Vice President Dick Cheney summoned three Republican senators to his ornate office just off the Senate chamber. The Republicans -- John W. Warner of Virginia, John McCain of Arizona and Lindsey Graham of South Carolina -- were making trouble for the Bush administration, and Mr. Cheney let them know it.

title: Innocents as Targets
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran Parliament Votes to Close Atomic Sites to U.N. Monitors
description: TEHRAN, Nov. 20 - The Iranian Parliament on Sunday approved the outline of a bill that would bar United Nations inspectors from its nuclear sites if the agency referred Iran's case to the Security Council for possible punitive measures.

title: The Neediest Cases; Desire to Help Family Motivates Young Cancer Survivor
description: Aileen Wu lifted her long sleeve over her left shoulder, revealing a three-inch scar that looked like a train track. Though she doesn't mind showing the mark, Aileen, 16, says she will not wear tank tops in the summer because someone will inevitably ask what happened.

title: Life in Balance, Featuring Plates, Hoops and Ladders
description: Men climb high up tall poles and jump between them to the sound of drums. A woman in a shining gray python-colored body stocking balances a lamp as she twists upside down on a pedestal, her body bending like cooling taffy so that it is hard to see where her limbs begin and end. Paper umbrellas twirl effortlessly, held by a pair of upturned, kneading feet; plates spin three at a time atop long, slender sticks; and a man juggles balls at the top of a three-man pyramid, effortlessly dropping down to the ground afterwards to screams from the audience.

title: India plans ski resort in the Himalayas
Arts, Briefly; Rare Violin in the Spotlight
description: A violin competition backed by a wealthy Russian collector, who recently paid more than $1 million for a violin once owned by Paganini, began in Moscow yesterday. The third Paganini Moscow International Violin Competition, held at the Moscow Conservatory, has 24 contestants, half of whom are Russian, competing for a top prize of $25,000 given by the private Violin Art Foundation. The organization's chairman, Maxim Viktorov, a lawyer, has been buying up rare violins, collecting 15 so far. His latest acquisition is a Bergonzi, left, made in Cremona, Italy, around 1720 and purchased at Sotheby's in London on Nov. 1 for $1.05 million. The instrument is to go on display today through the end of the month at the Pushkin State Museum of the Arts in Moscow, and will be played by Sergei Stadler, the chairman of the competition jury, in Paganini's First Concerto on Dec. 1, when the prizes will be awarded. SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY

title: Rail strike in France is new test for leaders
1955 Vision of an 2005 City: Times Square Dies but 2nd Ave. Has a Subway
description: TV antennas were beginning to sprout on rooftops like spindly metallic weeds, the alternate-side parking minuet was just being choreographed and air raid sirens still rumbled daily at noon in 1955 when New Yorkers paused briefly to contemplate a city "strained almost to bursting" after the "tensest quarter century" in its history.

Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENBERG, HAROLD JAY
description: GREENBERG--Harold Jay. The United Cerebral Palsy Association of Nassau County, Inc. deeply regrets the loss of a devoted Board member and tireless supporter of our agency, Harold Jay Greenberg. Harold's affiliation with ucpn began over 40 years ago. He served as ucpn Board President from 1970-76. Mr. Greenberg was an at-large member of the CP-NYS Corporation Board of Directors. The ucpn Torch of Leadership was awarded to him this November. We express our deepest sympathies to his family and friends. Thomas Connolly, President

title: An American in Asia: Bush finds respite, briefly, in Ulan Bator
Dayton, 10 Years After
description: Belgrade, Serbia - A DECADE after the end of the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina, the country's development remains hamstrung by the very Dayton peace agreement that rescued it from destruction and saved the lives of many of its people.

title: Lessons in Life and Basketball, Now on a Reservation
description: Many Americans might not realize that November is National American Indian and Alaska Native Heritage Month; I say this because I had no idea. The executives at Showtime were aware, however, and chose to pay tribute with a two-hour original film tonight called "Edge of America," a treacly, unexamined look at race and will, at determination lost and regained; a film that might have come with the tag line " 'Hoosiers' -- but on a reservation."

title: Popular Demand
description: The mystery surrounding Valerie Wilson, a former covert C.I.A. operative, expanded last week when Bob Woodward, a star editor and reporter at The Washington Post, said he, too, was told about her identity before it was reported in the news media.

description: PERRY--Evelyn. On November 19, 2005. Beloved wife of Irwin of 48 years, adored mother of Susan, James and David, cherished grandmother of Deborah, Zachary, Jessica, Robert and Isabel, loving sister of Roslyn and Marilyn, nieces, nephews and friends. The light in our house has gone out. Services were held.

Luxottica Retail operates eyewear chains like LensCrafters, Pearle Vision, Sears Optical and Sunglass Hut.

title: Do You Hear the People Sing? Isn't That Puccini? Or Pink Floyd?
description: ROME, Nov. 18 - Aging rockers don't fade away; nor, apparently, do their followers. So two decades after Roger Waters broke with Pink Floyd, as bassist, lead singer and composer, fans flew here from across Europe to hear his latest creation. And it seemed to matter little that he had written a 19th-century-style opera called "a Ira," or "There Is Hope."

title: Bringing Privacy Out in the Open
description: To the Editor:

title: Why the United States Should Look to Japan for Better Schools
description: The United States will become a second-rate economic power unless it can match the educational performance of its rivals abroad and get more of its students to achieve at the highest levels in math, science and literacy. Virtually every politician, business leader and educator understands this, yet the country has no national plan for reaching the goal. To make matters worse, Americans have remained openly hostile to the idea of importing strategies from the countries that are beating the pants off us in the educational arena.

title: AMERICAN BOBSLED TEAM CRASHES
description: Todd Hays, the top bobsled driver for the United States, crashed in a World Cup four-man race yesterday in Lake Placid, N.Y. Hays's team was disqualified and earned no points in the competition. The Russian team, piloted by Alexandre Zoubkov, won the gold. John Eligon SPORTS BRIEFING: WINTER SPORTS

title: Former aide to DeLay admits role in bribery
Paid Notice: Deaths  HAMMERSTEIN, CHRISTINA LIND
description: HAMMERSTEIN -- Christina Lind. Passed away peacefully November 19th at home in Durham, NC surrounded by her three beautiful girls, Pat (Patricia Hammerstein Benner), Marty (Martha Hammerstein) and Dinie (Diana Hammerstein). Born February 4, 1919, Ms. Hammerstein was an actress and singer who started her career in radio and the fashionable nightclubs of New York in the early 1940's. She appeared on Broadway and in summer stock productions of many Rogers & Hammerstein musicals including "The King & I," "Showboat" and "South Pacific," and remained active in the arts throughout her life. She will be greatly missed by her loving family including her daughters, son-in-law Tom Benner, six grandchildren and three great-grandchildren as well as the many friends and colleagues who remember her for her warmth, talent and beauty. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Actors Fund of America.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: A Retired Officer, Haunted by a 30-Year-Old Search
description: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 17 - More than 30 years have passed since Austin Avery, a detective with the White Plains Police Department, set out to find a 24-year-old aspiring journalist who had vanished from a boarding house here on a frigid winter night.

title: Head of Psychotherapy Institute Resigns in Dispute With Founder
description: The executive director of a renowned Upper East Side psychotherapy institute said yesterday that he was resigning amid a bitter and increasingly personal feud with the institute's founder, Dr. Albert Ellis, considered by many to be one of the most provocative and influential figures in modern psychology.
