description: Boeing, the world's second-largest aerospace company after Airbus, won orders yesterday worth a total of $13.7 billion for 112 aircraft from Emirates Airlines and China. The deals extend Boeing's gains in new business this year over its larger rival.

title: Consistency and Caution Give Stewart Second Title
description: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Nov. 20 - His nickname is Smoke, but Tony Stewart left mostly dust behind him in 2005. He won five races. He was a consistent presence in the top 10. Week after week, Stewart made it clear that he was the premier driver in Nascar's Nextel Cup.

title: High prices fuel a nuclear power revival in U.S.
LOOKING AHEAD
description: TURKEY TIME -- Fears of avian flu don't seem to be denting demand for turkey this Thanksgiving, industry executives say. In fact, tight supplies and strong exports have nudged prices up about 6 cents a pound from last year. Even so, the National Chicken Council is trying to reassure consumers, proclaiming on www.avianinfluenzainfo.com that you can't get the disease from "properly handled and cooked food." Europe is sending mixed signals on the issue; a poultry group plans to ask the European Union today for increased export subsidies to offset sagging sales it blames on bird-flu concerns.

title: Loss Is Just the Latest Setback for the Floundering Eagles
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 20 - A season of discontent continued Sunday for the Philadelphia Eagles. Confronted by a series of distractions, defensive breakdowns, key injuries and crushing defeats, they seem headed for a premature off-season rather than a postseason defense of their National Football Conference championship.

title: Confrontation With Italy  Looms at the Met
description: In its pristine glass case at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, a small black terra-cotta vase with red figures depicting Zeus cradling Dionysus says little to the casual viewer about its origins. As string music filtered into the Greek and Roman galleries on Friday night, tour groups who stopped to glance at its label saw only that the vase, known as an amphora, is attributed to a painter from the fifth century B.C. and that it arrived at the Met in 1982.

title: Treasury Bills Scheduled for This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

title: Long Before MTV, There Was Streisand TV
description: Some pop stars (the Beatles, Bruce Springsteen) inspire love. Others (Frank Sinatra, Barbra Streisand, Madonna) demand worship. Between love and worship, there is a world of difference. Love is warm, trusting and generous and allows for forgiveness. Worship is cooler. It involves an exchange of power in which adoration is shadowed with fear.

Paid Notice: Deaths   DUBERSTEIN, CONRAD B.
description: DUBERSTEIN -- Conrad B. Died peacefully at his home on November 18, 2005 at the age of 90. Beloved husband of Anne (nee Saggio), loving father of Elysa Belessakos and father-in-law of Elias; devoted grandfather of Nicole Chemtob (Mark), Josephine and Dimitri Belessakos and Angie Allison; adoring brother of Barbara Roberts and the late Kathryn Goldberg; United States Bankruptcy Judge for the Eastern District of New York; former Chief Bankruptcy Judge of the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Eastern District of New York, 1984-2005; Courtrooms and Chambers of the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Eastern dedicated in his honor; namesake and guiding spirit of the Judge Conrad B. Duberstein National Bankruptcy Moot Court Competition established by St. John's University School of Law and the American Bankruptcy Institute; served in the 91st Infantry Division of the 5th Army from 1943-1945, saw combat in Italy and was awarded the Bronze Star Medal, the Purple Heart and the Combat Infantry Badge; graduated from Brooklyn College and St. John's University School of Law (class of 1942), admitted to the practice of law in 1942; former partner in Otterbourg, Steindler, Houston & Rosen, P.C. and Schwartz, Rudin & Duberstein; former Judge Advocate General of the Military Order of the Purple Heart for the State of New York; recognized for his outstanding academic and professional achievements including an honorary Doctor of Laws from St. John's University School of Law; awarded Medal of Honor by St. John's University recipient of the Brooklyn Bar of Association's Annual Award for Outstanding Achievement in the Science of Jurisprudence and Public Service; recipient of the Emory University School of Law Lifetime Achievement Award; Fellow American Bar Association and the American College of Bankruptcy. Funeral services will be held at Park Avenue Synagogue, 50 East 87th Street, New York, NY 10128, on November 21st at 1 PM. Those who wish to contribute in his memory to the Park Avenue Synagogue or Congregation Mount Sinai of Brooklyn Heights, New York. Further questions please call Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 212-769-4400.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NECHEMIAS, JILL LEVINGSON
description: NECHEMIAS--Jill Levingson. Loving and beloved wife of of Dr. Charles Nechemias, daughter of the late Alfred and Ruth Weinstock Levingson; devoted sister of Abby and Robert Levine and adoring aunt of their children David and Nancy and their daughter Lauren, and Peter and Lindsey and their son Spencer. Services Monday November 21st 12:30 PM at Temple Shaaray Tefila, 250 E. 79 St. NY 10021. Shiva at her late residence Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday 6:30-9:30 PM with services at 7:00 PM. Contributions to Temple Shaaray Tefila would be appreciated.

Dear sister Barbara (Dr. Irving) Breiter; adoring grandchildren Allyson (Adam) Sklar, David & Adam Liss. Cherished great-grandchildren Mason & Ian Sklar and loving step-children Susan (Brad) Waite and Fred (Jan) Bayer. Service in FL.

title: Bomb Kills 15 Civilians and a Marine in Restive Iraqi Province
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 20 - The Marine Corps said Sunday that 15 Iraqi civilians and a marine were killed Saturday when a roadside bomb exploded in Haditha, 140 miles northwest of Baghdad. At least 11 other Iraqis were killed or discovered dead on Sunday in various incidents, and military officials reported the deaths of two more Americans and a British soldier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMOLER, IRWIN CHARLES
description: SMOLER--Irwin Charles, 82, President of the 106th Infantry Division Association and former President of Wicker Park LP and Smoler Bros. of New York and Chicago, died on November 18th, 2005, in New York-Presbyterian Hospital. Beloved husband of Elsie R. Smoler and loving father of Fredric, Michael and Arlene Smoler, he is mourned by family and friends. Between December 17th and December 23rd, 1944, he and his comrades helped defend St. Vith, Belgium, thereby creating a salient which threatened the Fifth Panzer Army's northern flank and for a critical week prevented the movement of Sixth SS Panzer Army. A funeral service will be held at noon, November 22nd, at the Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVIES, GARLAND HUNTER
description: DAVIES--Garland Hunter, 76, of Watch Hill, RI, and formerly of Atlanta, on November 17, at the Westerly Hospital, after a short illness. Widow of Nicholas Edward Davies, M.D., whom she married in 1950. She was born in NYC, raised in Rock Hill, SC, and after graduating from National Cathedral School and Sweet Briar College, lived for many happy years in Atlanta, where she was especially proud of being Dean of the Department of English as a Second Language at Georgia State University, from which she obtained her Masters in English. She traveled extensively with her husband and family, and frequently visited former students. She moved in 1998 full-time to Watch Hill, where, a member of the Misquamicut Club, she enjoyed golf and bridge with many new friends. She is survived by three children, Nicholas Davies of Manhattan; Elizabeth Davies Sanders of Wyndmoor, PA; and Sally Davies Halsey of Mystic, CT; and five grandchildren. Donations in her memory may be made to Sweet Briar College, PO Box G, Sweet Briar, VA 24592.

title: Special Is Back in Special Teams as Tyree's Punt Block Turns Game
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Nov. 20 - There are 11 players on each of the Giants' kicking units. It apparently takes David Tyree to make them special.

title: Time to Leave
description: Not long ago wise heads offered some advice to those of us who had argued since 2003 that the Iraq war was sold on false pretenses: give it up. The 2004 election, they said, showed that we would never convince the American people. They suggested that we stop talking about how we got into Iraq and focus instead on what to do next.

title: A Fence on the Border
description: The anti-immigration politicians certainly know how to get attention. Representative Duncan Hunter, a Republican from California, attracted a full battery of TV cameras the other day with his latest proposal to build a big strong fence along the Mexican border. The idea is to stop the illegal immigrants who enter the country mostly to take hard, low-paying jobs that Americans refuse. Only as a bumper sticker does this "fence 'em out" plan work. As immigration policy, it will just cost billions.

title: Hal Anger Dies at 85; Invented Diagnostic Cameras
description: Hal O. Anger, an electrical engineer in the field of nuclear medicine who invented diagnostic cameras allowing doctors to view metabolic processes occurring inside the human body, died on Oct. 31 at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 85.

Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, JEANETTE
description: SILVERMAN - Jeanette. Amazing yoga, tai chi and chi gong teacher, dancer, story teller and political activist, died peacefully on Friday, November 18, at 94 years of age. Her beloved husband Robert died in 1988. Jeanette was much loved by her daughters Ann Aviles and Rosalind Andrews, as well as by her sons-in-law, Anthony Aviles and Jim Andrews. Her deep interest in dance, as well as movement for health, influenced her two granddaughters, Elizabeth Evans and Erika Gamel, who adored their grandma as she did them. Her love extended to her grandson Michael Beinhorn, and her great-grandchildren, Nawal and Magdy Gamel, and Mia and Tae Shin Beinhorn. She was an inspiration to all who knew her. To celebrate her memory donations to Amnesty International would be appreciated.

title: Arts, Briefly; Tears on the Canvas
description: Eddie Guerrero, below, a 38-year-old World Wrestling Entertainment star, was found dead on Nov. 13 at a hotel in Minneapolis. The next night, before a tearful crowd, "WWE Monday Night Raw" interlaced tributes to Mr. Guerrero throughout its live broadcast. The wrestlers wore Mr. Guerrero's signature "I'm Your Papi" T-shirt and shared memories of him, often ending up sobbing. The show drew 5.61 million viewers in Nielsen's estimates, its largest audience since wrestling returned to the USA Network on Oct. 3. On UPN, "Friday Night Smackdown!" offered a second tribute, which included segments from previous broadcasts of Mr. Guerrero talking about both his family and wrestling. "Smackdown" delivered an audience of 4.89 million, its highest ratings of the season. The cause of Mr. Guerrero's death has not been announced. KATE AURTHUR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEROY, MAXIMILIAN WARNER
description: LeROY--Maximilian Warner. During his all too short life Maximilian (universally known as Max) Warner LeRoy--beloved son of Kay LeRoy and precious brother to Bridget Warner LeRoy, Carolyn Plum LeRoy and Jennifer Oz LeRoy--embraced an extraordinary number of people with a singular charisma during his 30 years; a life ended by a motorcycle accident in Los Angeles on November 3rd. He was a literal, as well as figurative, embrace. Max was a hugger par excellence, a habit that started in early childhood when his parents tried to teach him how to shake hands in greeting; he preferred hugging. Visitors to the LeRoy household were routinely assaulted by a dark-haired, dark-eyed ball of energy who threw himself at them, hugging whatever body parts he could best reach. After what became his signature hug (just a little longer, just a little tighter and just a little more loving than anyone else's), Max would step back to ask the hug-ee's name. He embraced life just as ferociously and with as much abandon. And he had an enormous capacity for living, because he was so prodigiously talented. The word "best" always surfaced when Max was discussed by his family and friends. He was the best musician, the best writer, the best cook, the best at getting the party going, the best at getting the girls, the best son, the best brother and the best friend. Most of all, he was the best at loving those same family and friends, the latter an always increasing circle of people he embraced--literally! Without that special Max love, reinforced by that patented Max hug, the world is a colder, harsher and lonelier place for all who knew him. The solace is that Max will now always be so young, so handsome and so vital, while the rest of us will not be so lucky.

Endangering Yellowstone's Grizzlies
description: The recovery of the grizzly bear population in the greater Yellowstone region is a triumph of human restraint. Thirty years ago, after a long period of mismanagement, the bears were listed as a threatened species. Now, their numbers have risen from perhaps as few as 200 to perhaps as many as 600. That has led the Interior Department to consider removing them from the endangered species list -- a proposal that has split the conservation world. The National Wildlife Federation, for instance, believes that the original goals of protecting the bears have been met. But other groups -- including the Natural Resources Defense Council -- believe the bears should still be protected. We agree.

title: The Battle Against Fraud
description: It's sad just how predictable it was that the reconstruction of Iraq would be marred by fraud, dishonesty and profiteering. title: The Internet Gambling Genie Is Out of the Bottle

So the gambling-site operators have simply set up shop overseas, where they enjoy the patronage of 12 million Americans spending $10 billion a year. Countries like England and Germany are sucking in our money, tax-free, unlicensed and unregulated, while our lawmakers pretend this white-hot craze simply doesn't exist.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: U.S. Attorney Supports Bag Searches
description: The United States attorney in Manhattan has filed legal papers supporting the Police Department's policy of searching bags and packages taken into the subway. "Balancing the limited nature of the intrusion resulting from random bag searches against New York City's legitimate attempts to deter terrorist attacks on the subways leads to the conclusion that the Container Inspection Program is reasonable," Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney, wrote in a brief filed on Friday in Federal District Court, where a trial over the legality of the searches began last month. Yesterday, the New York Civil Liberties Union, which is challenging the policy, and the city's Law Department and the Washington Legal Foundation, which support the searches, filed their final briefs. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: New Military Procurement Rules
description: European Union defense ministers have approved a new system of military procurement intended to encourage cross-border competition. The system, which is voluntary among the European Union's 25 member states, specifies that contract tender offers worth more than 1 million euros ($1.2 million) will be posted on a single online portal with transparent criteria. "It is a vital step for ensuring that our defense industries remain globally competitive," Javier Solana, above, the head of the European Defense Agency, said in a written statement. The system, which has been termed a "code of conduct," will rely on "transparent and objective criteria for selecting bidders and awarding contracts," the agency said.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 - Ten years after the end of the traumatic civil war in Bosnia and Herzegovina, its leaders agreed here today to press for constitutional changes creating a stronger national government.

title: Quit Iraq, or Stay? The Debate Rages
description: To the Editor:

title: Women to get no niche in the Vatican's Swiss Guard
7,400 Bills Fit in Shoebox, a Detective Proves in Court
description: Anthony Castiglia, a detective in the New York Police Department's elite Intelligence Division and a 20-year veteran of the force, spent his weekend squeezing 7,400 $1 bills into a shoebox that once held a pair of black Adidas Midseason low-top basketball shoes.

title: Damon's Agent Eager for Stats to Be Binding
description: The statistical dissection of Johnny Damon began months before he played his final game of 2005 with the Boston Red Sox.

title: National Briefing | Washington: New Chief For Women's Health Office
description: A seven-year veteran of the Food and Drug Administration will lead the agency's Office of Women's Health, whose previous director quit after the F.D.A. delayed a decision on the "morning after" contraceptive. The new director, Dr. Kathleen Uhl, 43, consults within the agency about labeling products for use by pregnant and lactating women. She replaces Susan F. Wood, who resigned three months ago. Ms. Wood suggested that the Bush administration disregarded scientific evidence when it postponed the decision. The F.D.A. said it needed more public comment.

title: Google's Shopping Service to List User's Local Stores
description: Google executives said last night that the company planned to move quickly to capitalize on its new Google Base database service, adding a feature that lets merchants provide local shopping information.

title: New Orleans, Renewed: Elections and Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: A Little Nostalgia and a Lot of Unruly Trombone
description: The big, braying sound of Roswell Rudd's trombone has been a prominent feature of jazz's avant-garde landscape for more than 40 years. It still has a way of turning up in strange places: Mr. Rudd's latest album, "Blue Mongol" (Sunnyside), puts him in touch with Buryat throat singers from Mongolia. On Sunday afternoon at the Rubin Museum of Art in New York, he went for something more familiar -- although, in a way, almost as uncommon. For a celebration of his 70th birthday, he reunited with Eli's Chosen Six, the Dixieland band from his student days at Yale.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: New Haven: Football Fans Hospitalized
description: Twenty-eight people were taken from parking fields around the Yale Bowl to hospitals during the Yale-Harvard football game on Saturday for alcohol-induced illnesses, said Lt. Mike Patten of the university's police department. On Nov. 5, Yale issued its first restrictions on tailgate parties to curb binge drinking. But during halftime in Harvard's 30-24 victory, young adults danced atop U-Hauls, drank beer from funnels and lingered in the parking lots after the end of halftime, all activities banned under the new rules. Several officers at the game said there were too few of them there to enforce the rules. There were no arrests, Lieutenant Patten said. He said most in the crowd of 50,000 were cooperative. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: No Conspiracy Evidence Seen in Leak Case, Journalist Says
description: Bob Woodward of The Washington Post said yesterday in a television interview that he had not seen any evidence that the Bush administration conspired to discredit Joseph C. Wilson IV, a former ambassador who had publicly criticized the administration's rationale for the war in Iraq.

title: Retail Group Raises Forecast for Holiday Shopping Season
description: With gas prices falling, the National Retail Federation yesterday raised its sales forecast for the holiday shopping season, a rare upward revision for the generally cautious trade group.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Cartel Leader Captured
description: Prosecutors said they had dealt a mortal blow to the infamous Ciudad Jurez drug cartel with the capture of a little-known mobster they said had been running it since last year. Attorney General Daniel Cabeza de Vaca said his agents had made 11 arrests in the last month, dismantling what was left of the cartel. He said the new leader, Ricardo Garca Urquiza, known as the Doctor because he is a physician, was arrested this month in Mexico City. He is accused of moving five tons of cocaine a month into the United States. After Rudolfo Carrillo Fuente was gunned down in a turf war with a rival gang last year, Mr. Garca Urquiza quickly rose to become the cartel's leader, the authorities said. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

title: 18-year-old high school student sworn in as mayor of U.S. city
The Power of the Bump
description: With most planes flying full in the holiday season now beginning, airlines could be in for an unpleasant surprise: a passenger revolt against their tried-and-true system for keeping everybody happy if too many bodies show up at the gate.

title: Cheney Sees 'Shameless' Revisionism on War
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 - Vice President Dick Cheney stepped up the White House attacks on critics of the Iraq war on Monday, declaring that politicians who say Americans were sent into battle based on a lie are engaging in "revisionism of the most corrupt and shameless variety."

Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, EDWIN VINCENT
description: SMITH--Edwin Vincent. On November 21, 2005. Beloved husband of the late Anne M. (nee Seitz). Dear brother of the late James J. Smith. Loving uncle of Stephen E. and James M. Smith, and greatuncle of Ryan, Matthew, Sarah and Alison Smith. Longtime executive of Eastern Airlines. Past-president of the Cathedral Club of Brooklyn, Emerald Association of Long Island and the St. Patrick's Society of Brooklyn. Secretary of the Catholic Child Care Society of Brooklyn. Board member of the Angel Guardian Home and Community Board 10. Member of the Knights of the Holy Sepulcher and CYO Man of the Year. Visiting Wednesday 2-4PM and 7-9PM at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian burial Friday 10AM at St. Anselm's R.C. Church. In memoriam, donations in Edwin's name to St. John's Residence for Boys, 144 Beach 111th St., Rockaway Park, NY 11694.

title: Attack on Police Convoy in Kirkuk Kills at Least 16
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 22 - A suicide bomber plowed a car into a convoy of police vehicles in the northern oil city of Kirkuk today, killing at least 16 people and wounding at least 28, police officials said.

title: Lawmaker Returns Home, a Hawk Turned War Foe
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa., Nov. 21 - Representative John P. Murtha, the hawkish Democrat who spent his political career as a staunch Pentagon supporter, came home Monday as something entirely different: an antiwar symbol.

title: Storm Forces a Hard Look at Troubled Public Housing
description: NEW ORLEANS - For years, cities across the nation have been declaring old-style public housing complexes a social experiment gone awry, emptying the buildings and, with a good-riddance press of the plunger, blowing them up.

title: A Model Fight Against Malaria
description: This month the rains come to southern Africa, and with them, death from malaria. In Zambia, though, where 30,000 people die a year of malaria, almost all of them children, things are about to change. With the help of the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, Zambia is embarking on a campaign to cut malaria deaths by 75 percent over three years.

title: Behavior: Harsh Review for Cigarettes With Candy Flavor
description: Flavored cigarettes sold under names like Twista Lime, Midnight Berry and Warm Winter Toffee may be undermining restrictions aimed at stopping tobacco companies from marketing their products to youths, new research from Harvard says.

title: E.ON abandons plan to take over Scottish Power
Spitzer Calls for Nonpartisan Districting
description: ALBANY, Nov. 21 - Attorney General Eliot Spitzer said Monday that if elected governor he will end a practice that many say is at the root of Albany's dysfunctional government: the power of state lawmakers to draw legislative districts so that incumbents are perennially re-elected.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Woman Killed In Fire
description: A fire yesterday morning in a 13th-floor apartment in Morningside Heights killed one person, the Fire Department said. The victim, Gersuila Carter, 93, was identified by the police. The fire, at 70 La Salle Street, began shortly before 1 p.m., and was under control approximately 30 minutes later, the Fire Department said. No other injuries were reported. Michael Wilson (NYT)

description: More infants were born last year by Caesarean section, more were born prematurely and more were born with a low birth weight in 2004 than in 2003, according to statistics released last week by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: This Is Your Brain Under Hypnosis
description: Hypnosis, with its long and checkered history in medicine and entertainment, is receiving some new respect from neuroscientists. Recent brain studies of people who are susceptible to suggestion indicate that when they act on the suggestions their brains show profound changes in how they process information. The suggestions, researchers report, literally change what people see, hear, feel and believe to be true.

title: Knicks-Rangers Bid Rejected
description: The Cablevision Systems Corporation, the biggest cable television provider in the New York metropolitan area, confirmed yesterday that it had rejected a $700 million offer from an investment group to buy the Knicks and the Rangers.

title: Roush Expects Team to Chase Stewart for the Next Cup
description: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Nov. 21 - While Tony Stewart was raising the No. 20 Chevrolet banner to the top of the champion's flagpole at Homestead-Miami Speedway on Sunday night, Jack Roush was already raising expectations for the deepest race team in Nascar.

title: Mix of Shock and Resignation on G.M. Shop Floors Set to Close
description: LANSING, Mich., Nov. 21 - When Dan Fairbanks received word from General Motors early Monday morning that his plant had been tagged for closing next year, there were few people in the factory to tell.

title: Sudan's Department of Gang Rape
description: KALMA CAMP, Sudan - When the Arab men in military uniforms caught Noura Moussa and raped her the other day, they took the trouble to explain themselves.

title: Nature, Man and Politics at the Center of the Storm
description: Tonight, back-to-back episodes of "Nova" and "Frontline" pull together the strewn facts of Hurricane Katrina and put them in working order, with lessons for any city under meteorological, seismological or even terrorist siege. As is often the case, these two workhorse PBS series stare hard at complexity, explaining the natural and political systems that caused and exacerbated catastrophe.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Alcatel Silent on Bid for Thales
description: Alcatel, the world's largest provider of broadband Internet gear, said the French government held the decision on the future of the military contractor Thales, after a report that Alcatel is considering a bid. Alcatel is considering an $8.6 billion bid for Thales, The Sunday Times of London reported, citing unidentified London bankers. The French government owns 31.3 percent of Thales.

title: Letters
description: Choosing Intelligently

title: National Briefing | Washington: Warning On Scam F.B.I. Messages
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said it had not sent e-mail messages to the public warning that it was monitoring recipients' Internet use, and urged people to be wary of such unsolicited messages that say they are from the government. "These scam e-mails tell the recipients that their Internet use has been monitored by the F.B.I. and that they have accessed illegal Web sites," the agency said. "These e-mails did not come from the F.B.I." The bureau said it would investigate the matter. Officials said recipients of the messages should contact the bureau's Internet Crime Complaint Center at www.ic3.gov. John Files (NYT)

title: European Rebuffs Talk of Series of Rate Rises
description: The president of the European Central Bank, Jean-Claude Trichet, said yesterday that the bank had no plan to embark on a series of interest rate increases, but would assess the need for them over time.

title: Liszt, Haydn and Brahms, With a Touch of the Nightclub
description: It was clear early in Angelika Kirchschlager's recital at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon that something was not quite right. This Austrian mezzo-soprano's tone, usually warm and supple, seemed off its center in an opening group of Haydn songs. The reason became apparent just before the last piece in the set, which she preceded with a cough that sounded serious. Later, when the audience's coughing covered the end of a Liszt song, occasioning a torrent of shushing, Ms. Kirchschlager empathized with the coughers, announcing, "I have a cough, too."

title: 'a Ira,' opera witha dash of Pink Floyd
Sharon's New Party Sets Off a Scramble for Israeli Elections
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 21 - Ariel Sharon, the Israeli prime minister, set off what could be a major realignment in Israeli politics on Monday by quitting the Likud Party, which he helped found. President Moshe Katsav said early elections would probably be held in March, and Parliament took a preliminary vote to disband itself.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIEGEL, ANN L.
description: SIEGEL--Ann L. The American Cancer Society mourns the passing of our dear and dedicated "family member," volunteer, fund raiser and contributor, whose commitment and compassion to the fight against cancer for nearly 15 years were unmatched. Ann worked tirelessly to raise awareness about our organization's mission and supported our research efforts. She served as a member of the national Foundation Board of Trustees and was a member of the Eastern Division's Special Events Comittee. Ann was the proud founder and chair of the Holiday Card Collection Program, currently in its 13th year. She raised nearly $3 million for the Society through this effort. In addition to being a strong supporter of our annual special events, she chaired the Gala honoring Tony Bennett in 1990. In 1993, she received the distinguished Alfred P. Sloan, Jr. Memorial Award. In one of her collection catalogs for the American Cancer Society, Ann summarized her commitment to our cause by stating, "by helping to fight this devastating disease, you will help to make a world free from cancer for us and our future generations." While we celebrate her life and our many memories of her, we will deeply miss her passion, her presence, and her caring spirit. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Ann's husband and best friend, Herb, and the entire family. American Cancer Society Donald Distasio Eastern Division CEO Karen Radwin Eastern Division Senior VP and staff and volunteers $(6$)SIEGEL--Ann L. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the passing of our cherished member, Ann L. Siegel. To her family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. Rabbi David M. Posner Robert A. Bernhard, Pres. George Asch, Sec'y $(6$)SIEGEL--Ann L. Your smile will always be the sunshine of our lives. We shall miss you forever and send our warmest love always to you and your "Herbie." Richard and Diana Feldman

title: Germany Passes Torch to New Generation
description: BERLIN, Nov. 21 - At long last, two months after one of the strangest elections in Germany's modern history, Parliament seems certain on Tuesday to elect Angela Merkel, the leader of the conservative Christian Democratic Party, as chancellor, the first woman to hold the position.

Now, for the first time, the agency is hiring a chief executive to help attract additional clients, particularly those seeking campaigns -- like the television commercials for which Freeman is known best -- that go beyond the realm of traditional media.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMOLER, IRWIN CHARLES
description: SMOLER--Irwin Charles, 82, President of the 106th Infantry Division Association and former President of Wicker Park LP and Smoler Bros. of New York and Chicago, died on November 18th, 2005, in New York-Presbyterian Hospital. Beloved husband of Elsie R. Smoler and loving father of Fredric, Michael and Arlene Smoler, he is mourned by family and friends. Between December 17th and December 23rd, 1944, he and his comrades helped defend St. Vith, Belgium, thereby creating a salient which threatened the Fifth Panzer Army's northern flank and for a critical week prevented the movement of Sixth SS Panzer Army. A funeral service will be held at noon, November 22nd, at the Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Ecuador: Ex-Leader Seeks Coup Charges
description: Former President Lucio Gutirrez, in jail in Quito since his return last month on charges of threatening national security, filed a criminal complaint against President Alfredo Palacio accusing him of orchestrating a coup. Mr. Gutirrez was forced to resign in April in the face of mounting protests and left for asylum in Colombia. Congress appointed Mr. Palacio, his vice president, to fill out his term. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Merkel elected as Germany's first female chancellor
BET Founder Is Moving On to Hedge Fund
description: Robert L. Johnson, who became a billionaire after selling Black Entertainment Television, is starting a hedge fund venture with Deutsche Bank with the aim of developing the largest money management firm owned by black Americans, he said yesterday.

Two Ejected From Bush Event in Denver File Federal Suit
description: DENVER, Nov. 21 - Two people who say they were ejected from a taxpayer-financed appearance by President Bush in March because of an antiwar bumper sticker filed a federal lawsuit here on Monday, charging that event staff members and federal employees broke the law.

title: Europe Moves Toward Delay of Iran Referral
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 - The leading countries of Europe conferred about Iran on Monday, with growing indications that they would not move later this week to refer Iran's recent actions in its nuclear program to the United Nations Security Council for possible sanctions.

title: Vote in Iraq is Once Again Fraught With Peril
description: BAQUBA, Iraq, Nov. 22 - In a burst of flame and smoke, a roadside bomb exploded today next to an American military convoy carrying a top electoral official from Baghdad, Izzadin al-Muhammadi, as he rode through Baquba to a meeting with local politicians. The blast wounded no one, but it shook up Mr. Muhammadi.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Wet And Warm In 2005
description: The northeastern United States had the wettest October since reliable records began in 1880, federal climate scientists said. The global average temperature for the month also hit a modern record, driven by unusual warmth in places as widespread as Brazil, Canada and Russia. Several teams of climate researchers have concluded that 2005 will at least tie, and probably surpass, 1998 as the planet's warmest year since records began. The previous record was achieved in part because of a strong natural push from a cyclical El Nio warming of the tropical Pacific Ocean. There is no El Nio warming this year, and most climate scientists say the continuing warming is being driven mainly by accumulating emissions of heat-trapping smokestack and tailpipe emissions. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: A Texan Gets a Friendly Reception on the Steppes
description: ULAN BATOR, Mongolia, Nov. 21 - If you are an American president in need of just a few hours of temporary political asylum -- no debate about Iraq, no Chinese leaders resisting the American agenda and plenty of adulation -- here is an approach: Come to the endless steppes that Ghengis Khan made famous.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHARPE, TIMOTHY
description: SHARPE--Timothy, 72, on November 9, 2005. Survived by his sisters Tippy, Sidney, Carla, and Hilary; sons Jason and Amory; daughters-in-law Liz and Marybeth; and grandchildren Emily and James. He was a graduate of Stanford University and served with distinction in Korea with the U.S. Army. He was a respected and well-known Advertising Executive, specializing in direct response, and founded the boutique advertising agency, Sharpe Associates. He will be remembered for his kindness, intelligence, and great sense of humor. His family and many friends will miss him. Private memorial services to be held in New York and Phoenix.

title: Iraqi Factions Seek Timetable for U.S. Pullout

title: Why the Chicken Virus Crossed the Border
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh - POOR countries are failing in their efforts to stop avian flu from spreading to humans. Yesterday, Indonesian doctors reported an eighth human death from the disease in that country; if confirmed, it would be the 68th avian flu death worldwide. In Bangladesh, we have yet to see the virus on our poultry farms. When we do, we will have to confront the same public health crisis that Indonesia and other countries face now.

title: Corrections

He is Yasuo Nagayama, a Japanese author who has written on popular culture during that war.

description: Pioneer said its president, Kaneo Ito, would step down to take responsibility for losses at the company, which makes electronics. Tamihiko Sudo, 58, a vice president in charge of business strategy, will succeed Mr. Ito, 69, on Jan. 1, Pioneer said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ARKIN, TESSIE
description: ARKIN--Tessie. April 10, 1912November 22, 2000. Mom, I have talked to you recently, as though you were here. I love you. Joan

title: Mix Lost-Love Words With Metal Trappings and Fans Are Drawn Like Goths to a Flame
description: It's easy to sympathize with anyone who hates HIM, the Finnish goth-rock band. The group's logo is a risible emblem called a heartagram (a heavy-metal pentagram, with two points rounded to echo the group's lovelorn lyrics). And the group's sentimental hard-rock songs are full of lyrics about burning in water and drowning in flame and covering the carcass of time with flowers. (Why? To send the scent of blame to the grave, of course.)

title: Heeding Warnings
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANKEL, JUSTIN
description: FRANKEL--Justin. The faculty, students, trustees and administration of the New York College of Podiatric Medicine express their profound sorrow at the sudden and untimely passing of the son of our longtime Dean, Bruce J. Frankel, D.P.M., and his wife, Bobbi. We send our heartfelt condolences to them and to their entire family at this most difficult time. William F. Ward, Chairman Louis L. Levine, Pres. & CEO Michael J. Trepal, D.P.M., VP, Academic Affairs & Dean Loretta M. Logan, D.P.M., Pres., Faculty Council

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KUPERBERG, DAVID S.
description: KUPERBERG--David S. 85, of Freehold, NJ (formerly of Brooklyn, NY) on November 20, 2005. He was predeceased by his wife of 61 years Etta Kuperberg. Surviving are two sons, Mitchell Kuperberg and Nelson Kuperberg; a daughter, Roberta Rosenfeld; two sisters, Florence Friedman and Beatrice Montross; two grandchildren; and six great grandchildren. Memorial donations may be made to Deborah Hospital, Browns Mills, NJ. Funeral services will be held at the Higgins Memorial Home, Freehold, NJ on Tuesday, November 22, at 9AM.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Saturday with an article about how much people spend on entertainment misstated the amount spent on "food eaten at home" in the top income quintile. It was $4,503, not $9,039 (which is the total spending on all food in the top quintile).

title: Merkel Takes Over as Germany's Chancellor
description: BERLIN, November 22 - In a ceremony mixing solemnity with a bit of humor, Parliament today elected the conservative political leader Angela Merkel to the post of chancellor, making her the first woman to head a German government and the first chancellor to have grown up under the Communist regime of the former East Germany.

title: John Campo, Trainer of 1981 Derby Winner, Is Dead at 67
description: John Campo, a New York-based trainer for three decades who saddled Pleasant Colony, the winner of the 1981 Kentucky Derby and Preakness Stakes, died on Nov. 13 at his home in Hewlett, N.Y. He was 67.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about violence during the second round of parliamentary elections in Egypt misstated the timing of elections in the city of Alexandria. They were in the second round on Sunday, not the first round.

title: Baby Dreams
description: Q. Do babies dream?

title: Carter Injures His Back, And Nets' Rally Fizzles
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 21 - For two decades, the Nets have taken their annual Thanksgiving trip out West and have ended up tripping into a black hole.

title: TechBrief: EDS to pay 71 million in U.K. case
Quit Iraq, or Stay? The Debate Rages
description: To the Editor:

title: Taxing an Unfriendly Church
description: Shortly before the last election, a former rector at All Saints Episcopal Church in Pasadena, Calif., gave a fiery antipoverty and antiwar sermon. He did not endorse a presidential candidate, but he criticized President Bush's policies in Iraq and at home. Now the Internal Revenue Service has challenged the church's tax-exempt status. It's important to know just how the tax police have chosen this church -- and other congregations -- to pursue after an election that energized churchgoers of most denominations.

title: Student Convicted of Plotting With Al Qaeda to Kill Bush
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 - An Arab-American student from Virginia was convicted today of plotting with Al Qaeda operatives to assassinate President Bush and hijack airplanes, concluding a terrorism trial that the government has called one of the most important since the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Former DeLay Aide Pleads Guilty to Conspiracy
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 - Michael Scanlon, a former business partner of the lobbyist Jack Abramoff and a former top aide to Representative Tom DeLay, pleaded guilty on Monday to conspiring to bribe a member of Congress and other public officials.

title: U.S. Bans Imports of Some Canadian Poultry
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 - Federal agriculture officials banned poultry imports from mainland British Columbia on Monday after Canadian officials reported finding a duck at a poultry farm that was infected with the flu.

title: Defining Science
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Genocide Trial For Iraq Gas
description: A Dutch businessman, Frans van Anraat, who is accused of supplying the government of Saddam Hussein with ingredients for chemical weapons, went on trial in The Hague, accused of complicity in the killing of thousands of Kurds and Iranians. He is the first Dutch citizen to be tried for complicity in genocide. The prosecution accuses him of supplying thousands of tons of chemicals to Iraq between 1984 and 1988 and says they were used in weapons deployed against Iraq's Kurdish population and during the war against Iran. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Screening for Abnormal Embryos Offers Couples Hope After Heartbreak
description: After enduring six miscarriages and undergoing six artificial inseminations and two in vitro fertilizations, Kelly Santos, at the age of 35, was dealt the final blow.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: Strike Halts Trains; Mtro Is Next
description: France's railway unions began a strike their leaders predicted would last well into the week, if not beyond, challenging a government already wounded from weeks of violence in suburban housing projects. The worst could be felt today, with the national railway network, SNCF, estimating that two of three domestic trains would be canceled, and the country's largest union, the CGT, calling for a 36-hour strike for the Paris Mtro. Union leaders cited a fear of privatizations as a main reason for the action. But the core of the dispute appeared to be the European Union's plans to open the market for rail freight to outside competition next year. Thomas Fuller (IHT)

title: Bosnians reach deal to modify charter
Asteroid Poses Tiny Danger, but It May Be Lured Away
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   IMRE, EDITH
description: IMRE--Edith. Beloved wife of the late Julius. Devoted daughter of the late Moses Fischel & Sara Freund. Sister of Magda Levy, and the late Eugene Fischel. Survived by nieces, Lillian Johnson and Diana King, and nephews, Joseph Levy and Daniel Fischel. Interment, Holon, Israel. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Calvary Hospice, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461, appreciated.

title: Red Sox Near Deal For Marlins' Beckett
description: The last time the Yankees faced Josh Beckett, he was blowing fastballs by them for the Florida Marlins in Game 6 of the 2003 World Series. Beckett pitched a shutout at Yankee Stadium and made the out that clinched the championship, tagging Jorge Posada, on the way to receiving most valuable player honors.

title: G.M. Announces Decision to Cut 5,000 More Jobs
description: DETROIT, Nov. 21 - General Motors, the world's largest auto company, announced details on Monday of a three-year blueprint to revive its fortunes, including 5,000 job cuts on top of 25,000 previously announced. Analysts immediately questioned whether the plan was enough, saying it lacked the speed and breadth that had helped rivals make comebacks.

title: An Internet Lifeline, in Search of a Kidney
description: On Dec. 23, 1954, a 24-year-old Coast Guard veteran, Richard Herrick, received from his identical twin a remarkable present, a kidney. On that day, doctors at Peter Bent Brigham Hospital in Boston performed the first successful kidney transplant on Mr. Herrick.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBERSTEIN, JUDGE CONRAD B.
description: DUBERSTEIN--Judge Conrad B., St. John's University notes with sorrow the passing of a most distinguished alum, supporter, and special friend Judge Conrad B. Duberstein, United States Bankruptcy Judge for the Eastern District of New York. As a distinguished graduate of St. John's, Judge Duberstein was honored by the University with the University Medal of Honor (the highest award given to a graduate) in 2001 and an honorary Doctor of Laws degree in 1991. Judge Duberstein's love for the law was eclipsed only by the true and everlasting love for his wife Anne, his daughter Elysa and his grandchildren. Donald J. Harrington, C.M. President

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: 3 Sinai Bombing Suspects Killed
description: The police fatally shot three men involved in the terrorist attacks on tourist resorts in Sinai this year that killed more than 100 people, the Interior Ministry said. The three, carrying machine guns and grenades, were planning to attack security bases, the ministry said. It said one man, Salem Khedr el-Shenoub, was a suspect in the "planning, preparation and execution" of the attacks. A total of 37 suspects have been arrested and 11 have died in clashes with the police. A ministry official said the bombings appeared to be the work of a "limited local cell." Mona el-Naggar (NYT)

title: Other Views: The Independent, Christian Science Monitor, The Australian
Southwest, Mid-Atlantic, New England, Washington, and Science and Health
description: SOUTHWEST

title: Two Big Games, One at a Time, Loom for Giants
description: Giants Coach Tom Coughlin reviews the National Football Conference East standings with his players each Friday as part of a PowerPoint presentation. For all the tireless one-game-at-a-time talk, the team's lot, at least once a week, is viewed through a bigger prism. Players truly may not know which team they play in two weeks, but they know where they stand in the division.

title: Two Officers Found Dead
description: WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 21 - A Newington police officer and a state police officer were found shot to death in a house here on Monday night, the West Hartford Police said.

title: Moscow vote mirrors a nationwide dispute
Chronicles of a self-styled goddess
Defining Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Oracle Chief to Pay Millions in Legal Fees
description: The chief executive of Oracle, Lawrence J. Ellison, has agreed to pay $22 million in legal fees as part of a settlement of a shareholders' lawsuit that already included a $100 million donation to charities, according to court documents.

title: Planning for When the Fun and Games End
description: TURIN, Italy, Nov. 18 - Beyond the city skyline on a misty autumn day, the mountains lurked invisibly behind the clouds. Turin's grayest season obscured its lovely backdrop. So instead of snow-capped Alps, people here saw a horizon of construction cranes, the omnipresent markers of an Olympic city busily remaking itself for February's Winter Games.

title: Ariel Sharon, as the Centrist
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel offered up several tantalizing morsels yesterday to explain his decision to dump the Likud Party. He said he wants to "lay the foundation" toward "the permanent borders of the state." That, of course, hints that he is willing to engage in the territorial compromise necessary for achieving peace with the Palestinians, something members of the right wing of Likud can't get their heads around. He said he has "no intention of allowing anyone to miss" the "historic opportunity" brought by Israel's withdrawal from Gaza last summer. Again, another hint at territorial compromise.

title: Bierbaum of Columbia Settles for a Runner-Up Finish
description: TERRE HAUTE, Ind., Nov. 21 - With about a kilometer remaining in the N.C.A.A. Division I cross-country championships Monday, Caroline Bierbaum of Columbia could tell that her ultimate goal, winning a national title, was out of reach. Johanna Nilsson, a junior at Northern Arizona, was too far ahead, on pace for a course-record time in the six-kilometer (3.7-mile) race.

title: Bosnia Needs To Claim Its Future
description: To the Editor:

title: New York, New Jersey and Connecticut
description: NEW YORK

title: With Little Fanfare, an Anchor Says Goodbye
description: Leave it to Ted Koppel to quit "Nightline" in the same wry, superior way he began it 25 years ago. His choice for a valedictory broadcast is not a video scrapbook crammed with slow-motion clips and misty testimonials from world leaders. Nor is it a foreboding look forward at what network news will be like without him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PFAFF, HENRY C.
description: PFAFF--Henry C., Jr. Age 91 on November 17, 2005 of Waverly Heights, Gladwyne, PA. Formerly of Summit, NJ and Nantucket, MA. Predeceased by his wife Martha M. Pfaff survived by his daughter Gretchen P. Riley. For more information please call Stuard Funeral Home, Ardmore, PA., 610-649-0243.

title: Heart Device Subpoena
description: Accellent Inc., a contract manufacturer for heart device makers including the Guidant Corporation, said yesterday that it had received a Justice Department subpoena for information related to an inquiry into Guidant defibrillators.

title: Country Preserves
description: BARBARA BRUMMER recently found herself doing the naturalist's version of checking a house's faucets: she kept turning over rotting logs. Dr. Brummer, executive director of the Nature Conservancy in New Jersey, was looking for salamanders, particularly the threatened long-tailed variety.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CREEDON, JEREMIAH (JERRY)
description: CREEDON--Jeremiah (Jerry), 72. Died peacefully at his home on November 20, 2005 after struggling with pulmonary fibrosis that robbed him of breath and sapped his considerable strength. A proud graduate of Fordham ('53) and Columbia (MBA, '58). Jerry served as an officer in the U.S. Army ('54-'56). He loved his career in marketing almost as much as he loved travel; there are few places Jerry did not visit nor leave without a new friendship. Jerry's concern for the world's poor, esteem for education, love of children and strong Catholic faith prompted great generosity. A fine man, he will be missed. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., Tuesday 2-4PM and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian burial, St. John Nepomucene Church, Wednesday 10AM. Interment Calvary Catholic Cemetery (Fla).

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Warner Settles With Spitzer on Radio Payoffs
description: The Warner Music Group, the country's No. 3 record company, agreed today to cease using pricey gifts and promotional giveaways to buy radio airtime for its artists. It was the second settlement to emerge from the New York attorney general's investigation into such pay-for-play arrangements.

title: Is Most Dangerous City in U.S. Turning Around?
description: CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 21 - For the second year in a row, Camden has been ranked the most dangerous city in America, but this year Camden's leaders refused to take the news without hitting back.

title: Microsoft to license 'open' Office formats
Sharon quits 'squabbling' Likud
Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Putin Promises Oil Pipeline for Japan
description: TOKYO, Nov. 21 - Japan won a promise on Monday from President Vladimir V. Putin to establish within a year a construction timetable for a pipeline that would carry Siberian oil to the Sea of Japan.

title: World Briefing: Europe, Americas, Middle East, Asia
description: EUROPE

title: A Hedge Fund for Anyone With $10,000
description: For as little as $10,000, you, too, can invest in a hedge fund -- or, to be precise, in a mutual fund run by a hedge fund manager.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Automaker to Renovate Plants
description: DaimlerChrysler said that it would spend 768 million Canadian dollars ($647 million) to renovate its Canadian assembly plants. The decision, the Chrysler Group said, had hinged on receiving loans from the government of Canada and the province of Ontario totaling 122.8 million Canadian dollars; those loans were granted yesterday. Most of the investment, 610 million Canadian dollars, will be used to revamp a 77-year-old factory in Windsor, Ontario, that currently produces minivans and station wagons. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Camps on Cyprus May Have Belonged to Earliest Open-Water Seafarers
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 - Two ancient campsites on the coast of Cyprus, found this year by archaeologists, may be the earliest evidence of long-distance, open-water seafaring in the Mediterranean, long before the Greek frescoes of sailing craft in antiquity and the legendary peregrinations of Homer's Odysseus.

title: Those Drones in a City Jungle are Both Artful and Natural
description: Animal Collective started its set on Sunday night at Webster Hall with rough scraping sounds, a loop of a shout and a swelling chordal drone. It was the latest variant of the drone that runs through great primitivist New York art-rock. And Animal Collective harnessed it in ways all its own: not the ominous fixations of the Velvet Underground, not the oceanic expanses of Sonic Youth, not the jittery stasis of TV on the Radio, but something at once joyful, obsessive and oddly pastoral.

title: Cleaning Needed, in the Worst Way
description: It would be safe to assume that the man in 6-F did not have many friends or relatives, or at least none who called or visited regularly. No one, not even his neighbors, noticed his absence for a number of weeks. That is, not until a putrid odor began filling the hallways of the Queensbridge Houses in Long Island City.

title: Link Wray, 76, a Guitarist With Raw Rockabilly Sound, Dies
description: Link Wray, a rockabilly guitarist whose raw sound and inventive techniques influenced musicians from the early days of rock 'n' roll into the punk era, died on Nov. 5 at his home in Copenhagen. He was 76.

title: Iraqi Minister Brushes Off Allegations of Torture Center
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 21 - For a man at the center of a furor over allegations of torture of Sunni Arab detainees, Bayan Jabr, the 59-year-old interior minister in a government dominated by Shiite religious parties, cuts an improbably nonchalant and stylish figure.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MERRILL, GEORGE
description: MERRILL--George. 84, Cornwall, NY, died November 19, 2005. Visitation 2-4 & 7-9PM November 25 at Quigley Brothers Funeral Home, 337 Hudson St, Cornwall-on-Hudson, NY. Funeral services 10AM at St. John's Church, Cornwall, NY, 10AM.

Accountant Is Fatally Stabbed Near His Apartment in Queens, Police Say
description: A Queens accountant was stabbed to death last night on the sidewalk near his Forest Hills apartment building, and the police were still looking for his killer.

title: Is Your Plane Half Full or Half Empty?
description: I'VE recently been tossing around some fancy allusions about travail -- from "annus horribilis" to Dante -- to underscore the idea that 2005 has been a particularly grueling year on the road.

title: Radisson Ends Internet Charges
description: RADISSON ENDS INTERNET CHARGES -- Responding to growing complaints from business travelers about charges for in-room Internet access at upscale hotels, Radisson Hotels and Resorts said that starting Jan. 1, high-speed Internet access will be free in rooms at all its 186 hotels in the United States and 21 hotels in Canada.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (ABC) 2005 AMERICAN MUSIC AWARDS -- The Rolling Stones perform live from Salt Lake City. The awards show itself is live from Los Angeles, with Cedric the Entertainer as host. Mariah Carey, Kenny Chesney and Rob Thomas are among the performers. Nominees for favorite album include Green Day's "American Idiot," T.I.'s "Urban Legend" and Tim McGraw's "Live Like You Were Dying." Above: the Stones' Keith Richards (left) and Mick Jagger.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: State Republicans Schedule An Election Meeting
description: State Republican leaders will gather early next month to select candidates to run for governor and the United States Senate next year, party officials announced yesterday. Although the Republican Party's nominating convention is scheduled for May, party leaders hope the new meeting, scheduled for Dec. 12, will allow them to build early support for their 2006 political lineup. Party leaders support Jeanine F. Pirro for the Senate and William F. Weld, the former Massachusetts governor, for governor. They are encouraging Rick Lazio, a former congressman, to run for attorney general in 2006, and Mr. Lazio has told Republicans that he will decide by the end of the year. If he declines, Michael Balboni, a state senator from Nassau County, is likely to enter the race, Republican officials said. Raymond Hernandez (NYT)

title: Senses: Zing Went the Strings of Whose Harp?
description: How do conductors instantly know which musician has let loose with an offending note? The answer may lie in their brains.

title: AOL Joins Start-Up Company to Offer Web Video Distribution
description: America Online reached an unusual arrangement yesterday with a start-up company that will allow almost any producer of video content to distribute programming on its service, splitting revenue from advertising or fees.

description: In separate legal actions yesterday, the Electronic Frontier Foundation, an influential digital rights advocacy group in California, and the Texas attorney general filed lawsuits against the music publisher Sony BMG, contending that the company violated consumers' rights and traded in malicious software.

Kenyans Roundly Reject Ruler's Revamped Constitution
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Nov. 22 - Kenyan voters, long under the thumb of their rulers, rebelled against their president in election results released today, handing him a stinging defeat in a referendum on a revamped constitution.

description: Kenji Jojima agreed to a three-year, $16.5 million contract with the Seattle Mariners yesterday, completing plans to become the first Japanese catcher to play in the major leagues. Jojima is considered one of the top players in Japan. Ben Shpigel

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Anatomy' a Hit
description: "Grey's Anatomy" continued its ratings ascent on ABC Sunday night, as a lovelorn Meredith (Ellen Pompeo) moped away Thanksgiving, only to be cheered by the prospect of a one-night stand. It sent the hospital drama, which also features Kate Walsh and Patrick Dempsey, below, to new season highs in Nielsen's estimates, drawing 20.8 million viewers in total; it also had its best showing in the 18-to-49 demographic since its season finale last May. Between that and "Desperate Housewives" (26 million), ABC had no problem winning Sunday night, as it often does. CBS was closer second than usual because of an N.F.L. spillover into prime time. But NBC's three-hour remake of "The Poseidon Adventure" did not draw many more viewers than its regular Sunday night lineup usually does. Though the network's ratings were preliminary on Monday because of a Nascar overrun on the East Coast, it appeared that "Poseidon" delivered an audience of 9.6 million. For the night, NBC finished in third place among viewers and fourth place -- behind Fox -- among adults 18 to 49. KATE AURTHUR

title: Quit Iraq, or Stay? The Debate Rages
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Sexual Assault In Chelsea Store
description: A man carrying a knife robbed a pet supply store in Chelsea yesterday and then sexually assaulted a 23-year-old clerk, the police said. They said that the man entered the store around 1 p.m. yesterday and browsed for about two hours before buying several items with a large bill. The clerk telephoned a colleague to verify the authenticity of the bill, the police said. The male co-worker arrived, said the bill was acceptable and left. The man then revealed a knife, took all the money from the register and led the clerk to the back room, where he assaulted her, the police said. The man, who was described as black, about 6 feet 2 inches tall, weighing 180 pounds and wearing a black leather jacket, a green baseball cap, a white Dodgers baseball shirt and khaki pants, remained at large last night. MichelleO'Donnell (NYT)

title: Rail Station Looks West to Find Tenant
description: The long-running project to make an expanded Pennsylvania Station into a majestic transit hub in Midtown has finally secured its first and most important tenant: New Jersey's state-operated commuter railroad.

title: In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
Quit Iraq, or Stay? The Debate Rages
description: To the Editor:

title: Run With Scissors? And Then Some
description: LONDON - Over the last decade, the choreographer Matthew Bourne has carved a popular niche between dance and theater, starting with his 1995 version of "Swan Lake," in which the women in tutus were replaced by hunks in feathers, and continuing with restagings of ballet classics like "Cinderella" and "Nutcracker."

title: Columbia Seeks Leader to Transform Program
description: How can Columbia's football program be repaired? Coach Bob Shoop did not appear to have the answer, and he was fired Sunday after his team failed to win a game in the Ivy League this season. Columbia Athletic Director Dianne Murphy said yesterday that someone out there had the skills to turn the Lions into a winner, and she was intent on finding him.

title: Run With Scissors? And Then Some
description: LONDON - Over the last decade, the choreographer Matthew Bourne has carved a popular niche between dance and theater, starting with his 1995 version of "Swan Lake," in which the women in tutus were replaced by hunks in feathers, and continuing with restagings of ballet classics like "Cinderella" and "Nutcracker."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMPSON, ANNE LORRAINE
description: SIMPSON -- Anne Lorraine. Age 87, on November 18, 2005. Beloved wife of Joseph C. Simpson. Visiting at St. James Church, Madison Ave at 71 St, Tuesday, November 22nd, 3-4PM with services at 4PM. Interment St. Louis, Mo.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   PRICE, BARRY
description: PRICE--Barry. Beautiful boy, away from us 30 years, you're always in our hearts. Love and kisses, Mommy, Daddy, Jodi, Blair and Mark

title: Just Like That Big Ape, He Couldn't Be Tied Down
description: Merian C. Cooper, a Floridian of stocky build and self-proclaimed middling intelligence, remains an obscure figure in the history of American manhood. After watching "I'm King Kong! The Exploits of Merian C. Cooper," an absorbing documentary about his life to be presented this evening on TCM, it's hard to imagine how that could be so.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Spain: 56 On Trial As ETA Supporters
description: Fifty-six people went on trial in Madrid on charges of belonging to or aiding the armed Basque separatist group ETA. The defendants are accused of forming groups that defended ETA in the news media, advanced its agenda through political channels, raised money to finance its operations, and conducted other activities not directly related to terrorism. The trial, one of the largest in Spanish history, is expected to last six to eight months. Renwick McLean (NYT)

title: Quit Iraq, or Stay? The Debate Rages
description: To the Editor:

title: Politician's Trial in Disarray as His Star Witness Balks
description: The defense in the corruption trial of Clarence Norman Jr., the former Brooklyn Democratic leader and assemblyman, was thrown into disarray yesterday when his star witness refused to testify unless she was granted immunity from prosecution.

title: He Wants to Die Alone, but First . . .
description: Memories of My Melancholy Whores By Gabriel Garca Mrquez Translated by Edith Grossman. 115 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $20.

title: Movies: From boxing ring, a director is born
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Cautions Against Strike
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg warned yesterday that a strike by 38,000 subway and bus workers next month "would be a very big problem for this city." The workers' three-year contract with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority expires on Dec. 15. Yesterday, Roger Toussaint, left, president of the Transport Workers Union, Local 100, said little progress had been made at three negotiating sessions. A fourth meeting is scheduled for today. Mr. Toussaint, citing an estimated surplus of $1 billion this year, said authority officials "have spent all their waking moments since discovering this surplus trying to find a way to spend it." An authority spokesman, Tom Kelly, called the accusation "ludicrous" and said the authority had a "carefully calibrated" plan to use the surplus for pension payments, fare discounts and other purposes. Mr. Toussaint said the authority had called for a greater employee contribution toward health care expenses and for a longer period of service before new workers can receive pensions. Mr. Kelly said it was too early to comment on negotiations. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; David, Oprah
description: David Letterman would seem to be able to get just about any guest he wants, but as his "Late Show" audience well knows, among the few who have resisted his pleas is Oprah Winfrey. Now it appears that Mr. Letterman's persistent invitations to Ms. Winfrey have paid off. Mr. Letterman was scheduled to announce during the taping of last night's show that Ms. Winfrey, right, has agreed to appear on the "Late Show" on Dec. 1. It will be her first appearance on Mr. Letterman's show since he moved from NBC to CBS in 1993, and her first since he famously transposed her name with that of Uma Thurman -- "Uma, Oprah" -- for a bit he did, to little laughter, as host of the 1995 Academy Awards telecast. Ms. Winfrey will be in New York, where Mr. Letterman tapes his program, for the premiere of the Broadway show "The Color Purple," of which she is a producer. JACQUES STEINBERG

title: Defining Science
description: To the Editor:

title: Louisiana Sees Faded Urgency in Relief Effort
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 18 - Less than three months after Hurricane Katrina ravaged New Orleans, relief legislation remains dormant in Washington and despair is growing among officials here who fear that Congress and the Bush administration are losing interest in their plight.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HECTOR, LOUIS J.
description: HECTOR -- Louis J. Died peacefully on November 19th, one month before his 90th birthday. Predeceased by his first wife, Dorothy Anne Dooley, in 1973, he is survived by his wife, Nancy Bean Hector, his sons, Denis H. Hector (Joanna), William F. Hector, Louis J. Hector, Jr. (Hilde), and his daughter, Anne Hector; his stepchildren, Heyden White Rostow (C. Nicholas) and David F. White (Margaret), four grandchildren and three stepgrandchildren. A Memorial Mass will be held at St. Hugh Catholic Church, 3460 Royal Road, Coconut Grove, Florida, Friday, November 25 at 3:30 P.M. Contributions may be made to The Nancy B. and Louis J. Arts, Briefly; Greece to Pursue Getty Over Antiquities
description: The Greek government said yesterday that it was taking legal action against the J. Paul Getty Museum, left, in Los Angeles in a fresh bid to win back four ancient artifacts it says had been stolen before the museum purchased them in 1993. The culture minister, Kostas Karamanlis, said in a statement that "orders had been given for the immediate start of legal proceedings" against the Getty, the only American museum to face such legal action from Greece. It did not give further details. Greece first challenged the Getty nine years ago about the four objects, dating from the fourth century B.C., and renewed its efforts for their return last May. This month, the Getty returned three artifacts to Italy shortly before the opening of the criminal trial in Rome of Marion True, the museum's former antiquities curator, who is charged with conspiring to import looted antiquities. American museums with big antiquities collections, like the Getty, the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, are coming under growing pressure from countries that are the source of many archaeological relics to disclose specific details of how they acquired such works and to open talks on their return. ANTHEE CARASSAVA

His friends heard him arguing with someone outside, looked out a window and saw him lying between parked cars in front of 412 St. Mark's Place, the police said. He was pronounced dead at Kings County Hospital Center. Detectives were investigating possible motives yesterday and had made no arrests. Al Baker (NYT)

Ms. Grinell was a graduate of Lehman College and received her Master's in education from Columbia Teachers College. She taught grade school in New York City for 15 years. Ms. Grinell had a passion for learning; for literature, biblical archeology, Yiddish (her first language) and the arts. She was a gifted jeweler and watercolorist and had a deep faith in God. Her loving kindness, her wisdom, her generosity of spirit, her wit will be sorely missed by all who knew and loved her. She is survived by her beloved daughters, Sheila Grinell Johnson and Barbara Grinell and her cherished grandson, Michael Martin Johnson.

title: The Crocodilian Past
description: It had a head like a bullet with jaws, the body of a crocodile and 52 serrated teeth, and it lived 135 million years ago. But perhaps the most surprising thing about this ancient crocodile -- whose name is Dakosaurus andiniensis and whose discovery was announced in the current issue of the journal Science -- is that there must also have been a world to which it was peculiarly fitted, a niche to which it had adapted. That world is as long gone as Dakosaurus itself. Like all such prehistoric beings, confronting us out of the depths of time, Dakosaurus is yet another reminder that most of the life that has ever lived on Earth has gone extinct.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BALDWIN, BLAIR FAHNESTOCK
description: BALDWIN--Blair Fahnestock. 58, of 236 Coggeshall Avenue, Newport, RI, formerly of New York City, NY, died Monday, November 21, 2005 at Newport Hospital. Born in New York City, New York, on April 27, 1947, he was the son of Helen (Michalis) Winslow and the late W.Barton Baldwin and a step-son of John G. Winslow of New York City, NY. Mr. Baldwin was a graduate of Brooks School of North Andover, MA, Lake Forest College in Lake Forest IL., and received his MBA from New York Univ. in New York City. Mr. Baldwin was the creator and owner with his brother of Biosyrex a company which manufactored medical devices. Mr. Baldwin was a talented inventor, designer, and artist. He was also an avid gardener and a lover of nature. He was a member of the Spouting Rock Beach Association and a former member of the Newport Reading Room. Blair was a devoted son, father and brother. Besides his mother and stepfather he is survived by a son Blair Fahnestock Baldwin of Boston, MA, and his brother W. Barton Baldwin of Newport, RI. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, November 26, 2005 at 11:00AM, in Trinity Church, Queen Anne Square, Newport. Burial will be private. Memorial donations may be made to the Brooks School, c/o The Blair Baldwin Memorial Fund, 160 Great Pond Road, North Andover, MA 01845.
