description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 - With Vice President Dick Cheney at his side, President Bush pardoned two Thanksgiving turkeys, Marshmallow and Yam, on Tuesday and sent them off first class on a United Airlines flight to live out their lives at Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif.

title: German Utility Abandons Plan to Acquire Scottish Power
description: LONDON, Nov. 22 - Germany's giant power and gas company E.ON said Tuesday that it was abandoning plans to take over Scottish Power after its 11.3 billion ($19.4 billion) offer was rebuffed.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about Conexant Systems' hiring of research engineers in India included an outdated reference to the number of engineers graduating in the United States. According to the American Association of Engineering Societies, about 76,000 engineering degrees were awarded in the 2003-2004 school year, not "fewer than 60,000."

title: Reacting to change of heart on Iraq
Extension Schools: Cheaper but Still Serious
description: To the Editor:

title: Inquiry Finds Flaws, but No Fault, in Reopening of Statue of Liberty
description: In a postscript to the controversy surrounding the partial reopening of the Statue of Liberty, an internal government report has concluded that the National Park Service did nothing wrong by asking a charity to handle the long-delayed project but that it inappropriately favored the nonprofit group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREENSTONE, MARION
description: GREENSTONE--Marion. On Monday, November 21, 2005. Her death is a profound loss to her family: Cora Hahn; Elaine Greenstone; Adam Greenstone; Willa and Demetrius Papanikolas and their children; and the many friends who loved her dearly. Memorial services to be held at a later date.

title: World Businesss Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Talks Seen on Old Russian Oil Deals
description: The government that forms after parliamentary elections in Iraq on Dec. 15 will quickly open negotiations with Russian oil companies about contracts concluded with Saddam Hussein's regime, the Iraqi foreign minister said in an interview published yesterday in the Russian daily Izvestia. "There is room in our country for Russian companies," the minister, Hoshyar Zebari, said, according to the newspaper. Andrew Kramer (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BALLEN, DORIS MILLER
description: BALLEN--Doris Miller. Died peacefully at her home on November 22, 2005 at the age of 83. Beloved wife of Frederick. Loving mother and mother-in-law of Marjorie and Eric Whitman, Edward and Sharon Ballen, Ram Ballen and Anne Black-Ballen and Kenneth Ballen. Devoted grandmother of Andrew Whitman, Lauren Ordower, Joshua and Rachel Ballen, Nicholas and Cecilia Ballen and great-grandmother of Nathan, Sam and Ellie Whitman and Sadie Ordower. She had boundless energy and dedication to charitable causes. Her enduring love and loyalty to her husband, children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren and friends is her legacy. Funeral services will be held Friday, 12 noon, at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. Interment Mt. Pleasant Cemetery. Donations in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Warner Music Settles With Spitzer For $5 Million Over Radio Practices Warner Music Group has reached a $5 million settlement with the New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer, to resolve accusations that it made payoffs to persuade radio programmers to play certain songs. [Page C1.]

title: Clooney and a Maze of Collusion
description: Correction Appended

title: After Complaints, FEMA Extends Deadline for Evacuees in Hotels
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 - Responding to an outpouring of criticism, the Federal Emergency Management Agency announced on Tuesday that most of the estimated 150,000 hurricane evacuees still living in hotel rooms would have an extra month to find other housing before the federal government stops footing the bill.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MENKES, WILLIAM B.
description: MENKES--William B., 90. On November 21 in North Miami Beach, Fla. Survived by his beloved wife Olga; devoted children Dr. Alan Menkes, Marjorie (Michael) Rockman, Michael Menkes, Andrew (Cynthia) Menkes and the late Rachel Menkes. Adored grandfather and great-grandfather; loving eldest brother and brother-inlaw; and beloved Uncle Billy. We will love you and miss you always.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Sports of The Times column on Monday about the dedication of the Muhammad Ali Center in Louisville, Ky., referred incorrectly in some copies to Michael J. Fox, the president of the center. He is a veteran museum director, not the actor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIEGEL, ANN
description: SIEGEL--Ann. The Board of Directors & the Medical Advisory Board of The Breast Cancer Research Foundation mourn the loss of Ann Siegel and extend deepest condolences to her devoted husband, Herb, and the entire family. She was beloved by all and will be greatly missed. Evelyn H. Lauder, Chairman Myra J. Biblowit, President Larry Norton, MD, Scientific Director

title: Bare-Knuckle Democracy in Iraq Rebel Territory
description: BAQUBA, Iraq, Nov. 22 - In a burst of flame and smoke, a roadside bomb exploded Tuesday next to an American military convoy carrying a top Baghdad electoral official, Izzadin al-Muhammadi, as he rode through Baquba to a meeting with local politicians. The blast wounded no one, but it shook up Mr. Muhammadi.

title: Weather Threatens to Continue to Disrupt Holiday Travel
description: The Thanksgiving exodus started today with snow in the Midwest causing delays of up to two hours at some airports, while a large tanker fire on a busy stretch of highway near Washington snarled traffic for eight hours.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about opposition to a New York City zoning change that would allow a developer to build a theater for Cirque du Soleil at 42nd Street and 10th Avenue misstated the name of the neighborhood. It is Clinton, not Clinton Hill.

title: Holiday on Thursday: Thanksgiving
description: NEW YORK

title: Election in Moscow testsnational issues
Head of Group for Designers Denies Theft
description: The defendant, Bride Whelan, wore brown, or rather, an ankle-length, all-enveloping faun-colored cloth coat. Ms. Whelan is an expert on the meaning of color, and a respected figure in the design world.

title: Mr. Cheney, Who's the Revisionist?
description: To the Editor:

title: Crisp Autumn Flavors, By the Glass
description: FOR a holiday rife with rituals, it's surprising that Thanksgiving doesn't have a trademark drink -- something to look forward to sipping while waiting for the little plastic timer to pop out of the turkey.

title: Ex-Cable Official Set to Plead Guilty
description: Michael J. Rigas, the former executive vice president of Adelphia Communications, is scheduled to plead guilty today before Judge Jed Rakoff in Federal District Court in Manhattan, according to the judge's law clerk, Andrew Woolf.

title: School Financing Is Focus of Lawsuit in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 22 - Fifteen students from eight Connecticut communities, backed by mayors, local education officials, teacher unions and activists, sued the state on Tuesday seeking to force Connecticut to revise the way it pays for public education.

title: S/he, colliding/colluding with history
In Legal Shift, U.S. Charges Detainee in Terrorism Case
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 - The Bush administration brought terrorism charges on Tuesday against Jose Padilla in a criminal court after holding him for three and a half years in a military brig as an enemy combatant once accused in a "dirty bomb" plot.

title: Obituary: Hugh Sidey, 78, profiled U.S. presidents for Time across 4 decades
Boston Bank Is Fined Over Bond Trades
description: A unit of the State Street Corporation, a Boston bank, was fined $1.4 million yesterday by NASD for its failure to report thousands of corporate and municipal bond trades over a 17-month period.

title: New Tenants in Tinseltown
description: Ever since it opened in 1996, "Rent," Jonathan Larson's rock 'n' roll updating of "La Bohme," has inspired passionate adoration, as well as its share of derision. The lyrics to one of its frenetic, show-stopping songs celebrate the idea of "being an us -- for once -- instead of a them," and the world around "Rent" may be similarly divisible, into those whose hearts beat faster as soon as the lights go down, and those whose heads begin to ache before the first note has even sounded.

title: Tentative Deal Brings Delgado to Mets
description: In Omar Minaya's first weeks as general manager last fall, he constructed a plan that he believed would spur the Mets' revival. It called for signing the Latin American free-agent trinity of Pedro Martinez, Carlos Beltran and Carlos Delgado, the best starting pitcher, outfielder and power hitter available.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Election Date Set As Polls Point To Sharon Victory
description: Israel plans to hold parliamentary elections on March 28 after a compromise reached between President Moshe Katsav and lawmakers, the Israeli media reported. With Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's coalition government crumbling, legislators moved to disband Parliament in a preliminary vote on Monday, with a final vote expected any day now. Although the president and lawmakers were reported to have worked out the election date, there was no official announcement. Mr. Sharon announced Monday that he was quitting the dominant Likud Party to form a new one. Three opinion polls in leading newspapers all indicated that his new party, which had yet to announce a name, was favored to win the most seats in Parliament.

title: Nassau Cuts Pay of Officials in Police Union
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., Nov. 22 - The Nassau County executive, Thomas R. Suozzi, has ordered substantial cuts in pay for the top seven officials in the county's police union, who receive from $149,000 to $171,000 a year, all paid by county taxpayers.

title: Those Photos of Bush
description: To the Editor:

title: Plan to Dissolve Nation's Only Public Women's College Stirs Debate at Rutgers
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 21 - With Douglass College, the nation's only publicly financed women's college, facing the possibility that it will be converted into a less autonomous campus of Rutgers University, a passionate debate is under way here about the value of a separate education for women.

title: March 28 vote in Israel seen
Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about the major role of Chinese companies in the industrial development of Brazil's eastern Amazon region omitted the full name and background of an author who was quoted as saying the main beneficiary will be China. He is LAocio FlAvio Pinto, editor of Amazon Agenda, the leading newsletter that covers the region. (Go to Article)

title: Titans of Tie-Ins, Buoyed by Attention
description: FOR marketers aiming at the lucrative children's audience, there are few opportunities more valuable than the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade. More than 50 million viewers watch the three-hour parade on network television, while 2.5 million line the parade route, from Central Park West to Herald Square, to watch the event in person, according to Macy's estimates.

title: Bomber kills 17 in Kirkuk
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A new biography of Laurence Olivier, authorized by his family, celebrates his genius as an actor without overlooking his flaws as a human being. Page 12.

title: Sybil Shearer, 93, Dancer of the Spiritual and the Human, Dies
description: Sybil Shearer, an unpredictable individualist of modern dance, died on Thursday in Evanston, Ill. She was 93 and lived in Northbrook, Ill.

title: Nonaligned nonstarter
In Times Sq. These Days, Naked Ladies Have Causes
description: EVERY morning without fail, The Associated Press publishes a schedule of the day's events in this city, real and contrived. Meant as a service of convenience to publicists and reporters, it also provides a rough measure of who we are, and what is required to hold our -- ooh, look at the pretty lights -- attention.

title: Embattled With Landlord, Dance Studio May Lose Its Home
description: The Broadway Dance Center, which has shaped the dreams -- and the legs -- of Broadway-bound hoofers for more than two decades, may lose its home at 221 West 57th Street, becoming the latest example of how the heated real estate market is squeezing arts groups in the city.

title: War Zone 'It Girl' Has a Big Future at CBS News
description: Since joining CBS News as a correspondent in 2002, Lara Logan has been periodically told that her relentless knack for gaining access to dangerous places is reminiscent of a young Dan Rather or Mike Wallace.

title: Fluent in Baseball, if Not English
description: Speaking in his native tongue, in Japan, Kenji Johjima announced yesterday that he had signed a three-year contract with the Seattle Mariners. He will be the first Japanese catcher to play in the major leagues.

title: A One-Man Musical Journey in a Tortured Giant's Shadow
description: At the start of the revival of Phillip Hayes Dean's play "Paul Robeson," which opened on Sunday at the Abrons Arts Center at the Henry Street Settlement, a recording of Robeson's own voice, apologizing that he can't be present, fills the auditorium.

title: A Hint That Fed's Rate Increases May End Soon
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 - The Federal Reserve offered its first hint on Tuesday that its long series of interest rate increases could be drawing to an end. Some analysts said the minutes confirmed that the Fed was closing in on a "neutral" rate that neither stokes inflation nor slows economic growth.

title: By Fits and Starts, Africa's Brand of Democracy Emerges
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Nov. 18 - One way of judging the repressive nature of an African president is by standing in the center of that leader's capital city and calling him awful names.

title: British Airways revamps its business-class cabins
Paid Notice: Deaths   TENENBAUM, MIRCEA
description: TENENBAUM--Mircea. On November 22, 2005. Beloved husband of the late Susan. Devoted father of Radu and Rodica and father-in-law of Kathryn Hammer and Steven Dreisin. Cherished grandfather of Alexandra, Rafaela and Philip. Memorial service Wednesday 1 PM at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to The Neighborhood Music School, 100 Audubon Street, New Haven, CT. 06511.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 9 P.M. (NBC) FAITH HILL: FIREFLIES -- Ms. Hill (right) promotes her new album, "Fireflies," with a one-hour concert special filmed partly at the Pantages Theater in Los Angeles and partly in Nashville. She does old hits ("Breathe," "Cry") and new ones ("Mississippi Girl"). Ms. Hill is a Mississippi girl herself, born in Jackson and brought up in a town called Star.

title: Corrections
description: The Inside Art column in Weekend on Nov. 11 misstated the distance between Marianne Boesky's new gallery in Chelsea, which is to open next year, and the Dia Art Foundation's planned future home in the meatpacking district. The gallery is 12 blocks north of the Dia site; it is not adjacent to it.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about the absence of obvious Republican successors to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg referred incorrectly to State Senator Serphin R. Maltese, who questioned whether the party had been too flexible. He is the chairman of the Queens Republican organization, not the chairwoman. A picture caption naming possible Republican successors gave an outdated title for Martin J. Golden and an erroneous spelling in some copies for the surname of the United States representative from Staten Island. Mr. Golden is a state senator, no longer a city councilman, and the representative is Vito Fossella, not Fosella.

title: School Radio Stations Face Competition Over Licenses
description: INDIANAPOLIS - THE week before classes started in August 2004 at Franklin Central High School here, Steve George stopped in to prepare the school radio station for the coming year. As the faculty adviser to WRFT, he wanted to make sure his students were writing and producing public-service announcements. He had to contact a few of Franklin Central's football rivals to arrange for WRFT to broadcast away games. He was pricing replacements for a 20-year-old remote unit.

title: Starve WMD proliferators of financing
Federal Judge Dismisses Challenge to Education Program
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 _ A federal judge in Michigan on Wednesday dismissed a major challenge to the Bush administrationAs signature education program, No Child Left Behind, saying the federal government has the right to require states to spend their own money to comply with the law.

title: Letter from New York: Europeans urged to celebrate and remember
U.N. Cites Progress on Opium in Afghanistan, but Renews Warning
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 23 - Afghanistan has made some progress in cutting back on opium poppy cultivation in the past year, but is still in danger of becoming a "narco-state," the director of an annual United Nations survey said today.

title: Cinderella and Her Popular Stepsister
description: YOU don't hear people talk much about Compass, which famously defied its name by so often losing its way. But you would if more of them tried its crispy skate appetizer, an expertly cooked indication that Compass is finally on course.

title: Judge Restricts Use of Calpine Money
description: The Calpine Corporation, owner of the largest United States network of gas-fired power plants, was barred yesterday by a judge from using $400 million in a frozen account to buy natural gas for its generators. Calpine shares fell to a record low.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MIKELL, MIKE
description: MIKELL--Mike. All our love, prayers and condolences go to Pat and Monique Mikell. Mike will be missed by all of us who had the good fortune to have known him at Mikell's. Christopher & Gingy Parker

title: Hockey in June. Mistletoe in October. Fruitcakes Are Forever.
description: Years ago, Santa Claus would not have dared show his whiskered face in stores until the fourth Friday in November. But that was before the holiday shopping season became as elastic as his waistband.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Mayor Unveils Housing Program
description: Low-income housing will be created from 360 foreclosed properties under a new program announced yesterday by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Housing Secretary Alphonso Jackson. The city and nonprofit developers will buy dilapidated homes from the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development at a steep discount, renovate them and then sell them to families at prices below market value. Families will be chosen by a lottery, with preference given to military veterans who have served on active duty since Sept. 11, 2001, and to nearby residents of the property being restored. The program will start with $15 million in city money and $130 million in private investments, and will be financed through the sales of the properties. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: World Businesss Briefing | Americas: Canada: Chairman of Chip Maker Resigns
description: K. Y. Ho, the co-founder of the computer graphics chip maker ATI Technologies, has resigned as chairman, the company said. Mr. Ho, who was also chief executive until last year, linked the timing of his departure to the end of an investigation by the Ontario Securities Commission. Last month, the Canadian regulator cleared Mr. Ho and his wife, Betty Ho, of insider trading charges. James D. Fleck, an emeritus professor at the University of Toronto and the chairman of Fleck Management Services, has been named chairman. ATI is based in Markham, Ontario. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Still Searching for a StrategyFour Years After Sept. 11 Attacks
description: Four years after the terrorist attacks of 2001, the government has yet to settle on a consistent strategy for holding and punishing people it says are terrorists. Its efforts remain a work in progress, notable for false starts and a reluctance to have the executive branch's broadest claims tested in the courts.

title: On a Noir and Stormy Night Stir Losers and Hustlers
description: Crammed with barflies, strippers and assorted reprobates, "The Ice Harvest" easily takes the honors as this holiday season's biggest and dirtiest lump of coal. Directed by Harold Ramis from a neo-pulp novel by Scott Phillips, this pitch-black thriller concerns a mob lawyer, Charlie Arglist, who as played by John Cusack is himself something of a lump. In search of a quick fix for a broken life, Charlie has just ripped off several million, a crime for which he and various others will have to pay. On Christmas Eve in Wichita, Kan., all the creatures are stirring and hustling, none more frantically than Charlie.

title: EU readies new bill on chemicals
Mr. Cheney, Who's the Revisionist?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bomber Strikes Police Convoy in Northern Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 22 - A suicide car bomber plowed into a convoy of police vehicles in the northern city of Kirkuk on Tuesday, killing at least 16 people and wounding at least 28 others, police officials said.

title: A Jolt of Caffeine, by the Can
description: Every day Tom Cabrera, a 27-year-old auto mechanic who lives in Middletown, R.I., drinks a can of SoBe No Fear energy drink on his way to work. Later in the day, if he goes to the gym, he downs another before his workout.

title: Arts, Briefly; NBC's Stunts Don't Draw Crowds
description: Thanks to a ratings sweeps stunt by NBC's "Medium," viewers now know that 3-D technology is as feeble as ever. Parts of Monday night's episode -- the psychic visions of Patricia Arquette's character, left -- were broadcast in 3-D; a TV Guide insert provided the glasses. The show was introduced with old footage of Rod Serling of "Twilight Zone" fame, his voice digitally altered to say, "You are now entering the 'Medium' zone." NBC's "Las Vegas" also made mischief to draw more viewers: Lara Flynn Boyle's character was blown off a roof by high winds and died. Despite such tricks, NBC placed third in the pecking order, which is where it usually stands on Mondays. Both "Medium" (13.26 million) and "Las Vegas" (12.16 million) performed slightly better than their averages, but neither one drew its best 18-to-49 ratings of the season. In that age group, ABC was No. 1 for the night, with its combination of "Wife Swap" and "Monday Night Football." CBS's lineup drew the most viewers over all. Its "CSI: Miami" was the night's most-watched show, delivering 18.83 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

title: In Everglades, High Season Is a Casualty After Storms
description: EVERGLADES NATIONAL PARK, Fla. - This is normally the splendid season at Everglades National Park, when mosquitoes relent (sort of), the humidity lifts and the trails through remote cypress stands and saw grass sloughs become South Florida's finest escape.

title: Immigration and Labor
description: To the Editor:

title: Ground Zero Memorial Cost Estimated at $490 Million
description: The price tag for the World Trade Center memorial and memorial museum will approach a half-billion dollars, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation said yesterday as it offered the first glimpse of budget estimates in almost two years.

title: Six Degrees of Jack Abramoff
description: No one has ever documented the full universe of influence peddling in Washington, but dogged inquiries into the affairs of Jack Abramoff, the indicted Republican superlobbyist, are beginning to map out some alarming inner-sanctum orbits. Mr. Abramoff's partner, Michael Scanlon, pleaded guilty Monday to plotting with him to bribe government officials and defraud Indian casino tribes by promising special federal favors in exchange for some of the more than $80 million in fees the two Capitol insiders gulled from the tribes.

title: Ruthlessly Practical, Undeniably Brilliant
description: Olivier By Terry Coleman Illustrated. 595 pages. Henry Holt & Company. $32.50.

title: World Businesss Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Founder Raises Stake in Adecco
description: The billionaire Klaus J. Jacobs tightened his grip on Adecco, the world's biggest provider of temporary workers, by acquiring a $1 billion stake from his co-founder, Philippe Foriel-Destezet, and ousting the chief executive. Mr. Jacobs, 68, said he would increase his holding to 29 percent from 16 percent and become chief executive and chairman of the company, based in Glattbrugg, Switzerland. Jrme Caille will step down as chief executive. Mr. Foriel-Destezet, 70, is ceding control of the company he created with Mr. Jacobs, left, in 1996 after the stock failed to advance in the last three years. Mr. Jacobs, who stepped down as chairman in 2002, rejoined the Adecco board two years later amid an accounting scandal that wiped 35 percent off the market value in a day.

title: Fed members worry about too-high rates
World Businesss Briefing | Europe: Farm Ministers Oppose Cuts in Sugar Aid
description: Plans by the European Union to phase out subsidies to sugar farmers and cut the price of sugar 39 percent met with resistance at a meeting of farm ministers yesterday. The Netherlands, Finland and Poland were quick to demand changes to a new proposal presented by the secretary of state for the environment, food and rural affairs, Margaret Beckett of Britain. She stuck to European Commission plans that aim for prices to fall 39 percent, but proposed that the measures be phased in over four years starting in 2006. The original proposal recommended the cut in prices be done over two years.

title: Delphi Chief Fights Battle of Detroit
description: DETROIT, Nov. 22 - Robert S. Miller started off as the Oracle of Delphi, handing down dire pronouncements about the auto industry from his lofty post as chief executive of the parts supplier.

title: Web Site Agrees to Help Curb Access to Movies
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 22 - The creator of software used by millions of computer owners to download movies agreed on Tuesday to prevent his Web site from linking to illegally available movies online, the latest result of a bid by Hollywood to gain control of a growing piracy problem.

title: Bush Spoke of Attacking Arab News Channel, British Tabloid Says
description: LONDON, Nov. 22 - The Arab satellite channel Al Jazeera urged Britain and the United States on Tuesday to investigate a British newspaper report that Prime Minister Tony Blair had dissuaded President Bush from bombing the station's headquarters in the Persian Gulf.

title: Paul Roazen, 69, Scholar Who Found Flaws in Freud, Dies
description: Paul Roazen, a political scientist and chronicler of the development of psychoanalysis who explored Sigmund Freud's complex relationships with his family, students and adherents, died Nov. 3 at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 69.

title: Extension Schools: Cheaper but Still Serious
description: To the Editor:

title: Rice Seems to Nod to Calls to Reduce Troops in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 - Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice has offered assurances that the United States may not need to maintain current troop levels in Iraq "very much longer," a seeming nod toward those in Congress who are calling for a reduction in the coming year.

title: Black's Arraignment Postponed a Week
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 22 - The arraignment of Conrad M. Black, the former chairman and chief executive of Hollinger International, who was indicted last week on federal fraud charges, was postponed until Nov. 30 to give him more time to choose who will represent him.

title: Virus tied to bogus FBI and CIA e-mail spreads globally
The Xbox Has Arrived; Let the Game Playing Begin
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 22 - Around 2:30 a.m. Tuesday, Mike La was scoping out a darkened Target store in nearby Daly City, Calif., on his Honda motorcycle when a police officer pulled up. The officer knew exactly what was going on.

title: Kenyans hand president stinging defeat on charter
The Yankees Are Keeping Their Seats
description: There was almost no chance the Yankees could have made a successful trade for the ace pitcher Josh Beckett this week. All along, the Florida Marlins were seeking to deal with the Boston Red Sox, who had the prospects they wanted and the willingness to assume the rest of Mike Lowell's contract.

title: Staying Connected, With the Internet at Bay; Orthodox Jews Grapple With the Web
description: Correction Appended

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "In one respect I'm thrilled by this decision because, from Day 1, I've been saying, 'Indict my client."'

title: Turkey With a Dash of Bitters
description: New Orleans - I DON'T recall much about last Thanksgiving. Happy days tend to blur together, I guess. But I'll remember for the rest of my life every detail of the bitter holiday we'll celebrate tomorrow.

title: Income Off 35%, but Deere Tops Expectations
description: Deere & Company, the world's largest maker of farm equipment, posted fourth-quarter results yesterday that were better than expected and said this year's sales and earnings would increase more than some analysts forecast. The shares had their biggest surge in more than three years.

title: Are youths the market for flavored cigarettes?
Freed by DNA, Now Charged in New Crime
description: MADISON, Wis., Nov. 17 - As three men sat nervously on a stage, preparing to recount their nightmarish journeys through a justice system that had sent them away for crimes they had not committed, the moderator had a plea for the crowd in an auditorium here.

title: A Mighty Wind and a Lucky Goal for St. John's
description: The good fortune for St. John's started with Dartmouth's inability to play host to an N.C.A.A. tournament game because of an inadequate home field.

title: Korea approves rice-market liberalization plan
U.S. and Europe Put Off Referral of Iran Case to Security Council
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 - The United States and Europe will not seek a referral this week of their case against Iran to the United Nations Security Council, American and European diplomats said Tuesday. Instead, the diplomats said, they will allow more time for China, Russia, India and other countries to persuade Iran to stop its nuclear activities.

title: Closing the Gap Between City and Suburban Students
description: GERMANTOWN, Tenn. - After serving the children of affluent parents for 40 years, St. George's Independent, a private elementary school here in a suburb of Memphis, decided to expand into higher grades.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEE, KELVIN, M.D.
description: LEE--Kelvin, M.D. The faculty, residents and staff of the Department of Otolaryngology mourn the passing of colleague and friend Kelvin C. Lee, M.D. A graduate of Yale University and University of California, San Francisco, Dr. Lee was recruited to NYU School of Medicine as Associate Professor of Otolaryngology, Director of Residency Education and as Associate Chief of Service at Bellevue Hospital Center. He was internationally renowned for his innovations in rhinology and sleep surgery. Dr. Lee was a compassionate physician, a superb teacher and a wonderful colleague who left a positive impact on all of our lives and will be deeply missed. Anil K. Lalwani, M.D., Chair Dept Otolaryngology, NYU School of Medicine

title: Teenage Nightmare: He Likes It Hot, but She Loves It Cordial
description: "Just Friends" hangs its crude, clobbering sense of humor on a dubious theory. Once a boy and a girl have entered the "friend zone" in a relationship, there's no turning it into sweet romance. Translated into the movie's loutish high school mentality, that means no you-know-what.

title: Sharon's new politics
Politicking, Iraqi style
Other Views: Chicago Tribune, The Age, Straits Times
Mr. Cheney, Who's the Revisionist? (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KING, JAMES
description: KING--James. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of the distinguished dramatic tenor, James King, a beloved artist and friend. He made his Met debut in 1966 as a noble Florestan in "Fidelio" and holds the record for most Met performances of two of the most challenging roles in the tenor repertory, Bacchus in "Ariadne auf Naxos" and the Emperor in "Die Frau ohne Schatten" which he sang in the work's company premier. His repertoire with us also included works by Puccini, Wagner, Berg, Bizet, and Britten. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family and friends. Joseph Volpe, Gen'l Manager James Levine, Music Dir

title: World Briefing: Middle East, Asia, Americas, Europe
Gone but Not Forgotten, at Least by One Receiver
description: CHAD JOHNSON emerged from Paul Brown Stadium in Cincinnati, moments after a meeting of the Bengals' wide receivers.

title: National Briefs
description: MIDWEST

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Landmark Building Saved

title: North Korean reactors canceled
U.S. finally indicts 'enemy combatant'
Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the fatal stabbing of Danny L. Harrison, a music executive, in his Upper East Side apartment misstated the address of the building. It is 530 East 89th Street, not 536.

title: Insert Object, and Out Comes an Artful Replica
description: Sometimes -- never often enough -- there's magic in new art. You'll find a sweet, rude shot of it, at least until 10 tonight, at Leo Koenig in Chelsea, where the Vienna-based collective Gelitin is in residence. Over the past week, the group has turned the gallery into a sociable, raunchy, pixilated all-night version of Santa's workshop, pumping out free art on demand, and turning the image of a money-choked, object-clogged New York art world on its head.

title: It's No Ploy: The Marlins Are Looking to Move On
description: SEVERAL years ago, when contraction was the hot topic in baseball, I figured I would help Bud Selig in his quest to eliminate two teams. At no expense to the commissioner, I offered what I called a modest proposal: lop Florida off the major league map. "No one will miss it," I suggested.

title: Close to the Slopes in Bushwick
description: Correction Appended

title: Student From Virginia Is Convicted of Plotting With Al Qaeda to Assassinate Bush
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 - An Arab-American student from Virginia was convicted Tuesday of plotting with operatives of Al Qaeda to assassinate President Bush and hijack airplanes.

title: Arcelor bids to control Canadian steel maker
Um, About That Dirty Bomb?
description: Almost three and a half years ago, the Bush administration announced that it had arrested a Chicago-born man named Jose Padilla while he was entering the United States to explode a "dirty bomb" and blow up apartment buildings. The attorney general, John Ashcroft, said Mr. Padilla was a Qaeda-trained terrorist so dangerous that he was being tossed into a Navy brig and the key was being thrown away.

title: Sun-Dried, Without the Chew
description: When is a sun-dried tomato less leathery and chewy? When it is semi-dried.

title: His Soul Creates Art His Body Can't
description: When Ami Ankilewitz was barely 18 months old, his mother was told that he had a rare motor neuron disease called spinal muscular atrophy and that he was unlikely to live beyond 6. Now 34, Mr. Ankilewitz lives in Tel Aviv and works as a 3-D animator, despite weighing only 39 pounds and being able to move only one finger on his left hand.

title: Loral emerges from reorganization
Merkel Takes Office in Germany and Announces Coalition Cabinet
description: BERLIN, Nov. 22 - Mixing solemnity with a bit of humor, Parliament elected Angela Merkel chancellor on Tuesday, making her the first woman to lead a postwar German government and the first chancellor to have grown up under the Communist government of East Germany.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Action Against 8 Guards In Jail Escape
description: A deputy was fired and seven disciplined in the escape of a convicted killer who walked past them to freedom from the Harris County Jail in Houston, Sheriff Tommy Thomas said late Monday. An eighth jailer resigned, said Sheriff Thomas, who declined to identify the officers. The inmate, Charles V. Thompson, escaped on Nov. 1 using street clothes that he had hidden and an improvised identification card to persuade guards that he was a government employee. Mr. Thompson, 35, was captured four days later in Shreveport, La., and returned to a state prison, where he is under a death sentence for two murders.

title: Coach Sues Over Right to Pray With Team
description: The East Brunswick High School football coach who was barred by his school district in New Jersey from praying alongside his players has filed a lawsuit alleging that the district's action infringed on his constitutional rights.

title: Drug Costs Run Free Under New York Medicaid
description: Penlac Nail Lacquer rarely cures the nail fungus it is designed to treat, yet it costs $130 a thimbleful. As a result, more than 20 state Medicaid programs and dozens of private health insurers require doctors to get advance permission to prescribe it. But not New York Medicaid, which spent $12 million on the drug last year, more than eight times as much as any other state.

title: In Strong Terms, Rome Is to Ban Gays as Priests
description: ROME, Nov. 22 - A new Vatican document excludes from the priesthood most gay men, with few exceptions, banning in strong and specific language candidates "who are actively homosexual, have deep-seated homosexual tendencies, or support the so-called 'gay culture.' "

title: An Argentine Institution Sees Hope Amid Chaos
description: BUENOS AIRES - As a show of appreciation to the theater where she made her debut at the age of 11, the pianist Martha Argerich organizes and plays in a festival at the Teatro Coln here each year. But when she arrived one evening in September, she and her audience found themselves locked out of the hall by workers who had suddenly decided to go on strike.

title: Heras Awaits Result of a Second Test for an Illegal Drug
description: PARIS, Nov. 22 - Professional cycling's sputtering campaign against doping could be coming up against its most difficult test.

title: Native Foods Nourish Again
description: LAST week, Noland Johnson pulled the season's final crop of tepary beans from the piece of desert he farms on the Tohono O'odham Reservation, about 120 miles southwest of Tucson.

title: Wagner Wraps Up Visit, and Mets Make Initial Pitch
description: On a blustery, miserable day, the Mets introduced their top free-agent priority in a dingy former locker room in the bowels of Shea Stadium. Billy Wagner, the hard-throwing lefty reliever, sat on a stool, fingers intertwined in his lap, with a microphone in front of him. It looked as if he were preparing for either a lounge act or an interrogation.

title: Metro Briefs
description: NEW YORK

title: One Night in 1970, the Revolution Was Televised
description: There was a time before "Monday Night Football," but that was an eon ago, when prime-time sports were rare and CBS and NBC carried the only professional football they believed they ever needed, on Sunday afternoons.

title: World Businesss Briefing | Europe: Britain: Copper Prices Fall on Rumor
description: Copper futures fell more than $100 a ton in London yesterday, after rumors circulated that a possible short position believed to be held by the Chinese government would not expire on Dec. 21, as was previously thought. A trader for the Chinese government is believed to have made a bet, involving 100,000 tons of copper, that the price would decline; if that does not happen by expiration, he or the government would have to buy copper to cover the position, pushing prices up. Copper prices hit records last week, as buyers traded on that belief. Many traders now say the Chinese have been able to push back the due date for several months. Copper for delivery in three months fell $103 a ton in London, to $4,112 a ton. Heather Timmons (NYT)

title: The Pension Bill Is Bad for Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Road to Redemption Starts With Repentance
description: ONE spectacular supertalent once fought the system the way he would a stiff steering wheel, stubbornly maintaining resistance, always wrestling for control not only of the machine, but of his world, of himself.

title: Square Feet; TRANSACTIONS
description: Recent Sale

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a legal strategy common to the prosecution and the defense in the corruption trial of Clarence Norman Jr., the former assemblyman and Brooklyn Democratic Party leader, misstated the middle initial of one of the assistant Brooklyn district attorneys trying the case. He is Kevin S. Richardson, not Kevin H.

title: It's Cheese With a Crunch
description: IT took me until midlife to realize that the beloved Cheez-Its of my childhood (or the inferior but still pretty good Cheese Nips) were based on a real pastry: cheese cracker, commonly called cheese straws. These can be as simple as Cheddar cheese, flour and a little binder, or as elaborate as puff pastry with cheese folded into it. When I finally did "discover" cheese straws, I was so thrilled that I pursued the most difficult recipe possible, and stuck with that for years.

title: White House Says Alito Was Assuring on Districting
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 - Moving to defend the Supreme Court nominee Samuel A. Alito Jr. against attacks on his stance on civil rights, the White House said Tuesday that he had assured senators last week of his commitment to the principle of one person one vote.

title: The Judgment of Paris, This Time at Home
description: BERKELEY, Calif. - ANTICIPATION ran high as we took our places around two tables in the comfortable living room of Dwight M. Jaffee, a finance professor at the University of California, Berkeley, and Lynne LaMarca Heinrich, a fund-raising consultant. From bottles concealed in brown paper bags, Mr. Jaffee poured measures of red wine into the eight glasses arrayed before each of the 10 participants. Of the eight wines, we knew that four were Bordeaux and four California, all produced from 1975 to 1986, all donated by the participants. Our task was to taste the wines, to identify them as French or American, at least, and then to rank them in order of preference.

title: Israeli Troops and Hezbollah Fighters Clash Again
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, Nov. 23 - Israeli troops and Hezbollah fighters clashed for the second time in three days today after an Israeli hang-glider crossed the border with Lebanon and landed in the town of Meiss el-Jabal, Israeli officials and Hezbollah reported.

title: The Trade-Offs in Zoning Trade-Offs
description: It has become common in New York City for real estate developers to offer public amenities in exchange for the right to put up buildings that are taller than the zoning ordinarily would allow or to garner public support for projects that might stir controversy. But those amenities -- parks, plazas or atriums, for example -- sometimes fail to live up to expectation, fall into disrepair and are occasionally scrapped altogether.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KANE, MARY J. OF BRONXVILLE
description: KANE--Mary J. Of Bronxville. Formerly of Co. Derry. On November 22, 2005. Mother of Stephen, John and Barbara. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath and Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 4 to 7PM Friday. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville on Saturday, Nov. 26 at 10AM.

title: Return of Former Palace to Sovereignty of Iraqis Offers Glimmer of Hope
description: TIKRIT, Iraq, Nov. 22 - For the two most powerful Americans in Iraq, Gen. George W. Casey Jr. and Ambassador Zalmay Khalilzad, as for the Iraqi dignitaries who had gathered here, it was a symbolic moment: a ceremony on a bluff high above the Tigris River at which the Americans formally returned the largest of Saddam Hussein's palace complexes to Iraqi sovereign control, 31 months after invading troops had seized it for use as an American base.

title: Weighing Race and Ethnicity in Picking Corzine's Successor
description: TRENTON, Nov. 22 - Since winning a convincing victory to become New Jersey's next governor, Senator Jon S. Corzine has remained coy about whom he will select to replace him in Washington. That has not stopped several Democratic hopefuls from campaigning aggressively for the post and suggesting recently that race and ethnicity should be factored into Mr. Corzine's decision.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Man Pleads Guilty To Rape
description: A 47-year-old convicted sex offender pleaded guilty yesterday to kidnapping and raping a 12-year-old Yonkers girl in April 2004, the Westchester County district attorney, Jeanine F. Pirro, announced yesterday. The man, Eddie W. Cordero Sr., had previously served three years in prison for sexually abusing a 10-year-old girl, and the subsequent charges against Mr. Cordero prompted Ms. Pirro to ask the State Legislature for a civil confinement law. The measure, which passed the Senate but is stalled in the Assembly, would require sex offenders to be confined in psychiatric institutions after completing their sentences. Ms. Pirro said Mr. Cordero abducted the girl from a bus stop near her home, dragged her into a wooded area, and then repeatedly raped and sodomized her. He faces 27 years in prison. Anahad O'Connor (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPECTOR, CHARLOTTE
description: SPECTOR--Charlotte. Peacefully left us after a long and beautiful life. Adoring wife of the late Charles. Caring mother of Michael and Joan, Bobby & Laurie. Loving Nana of Scott and Abbe, Marc and Karen, Jolie and Marc, Johanna and David, and Zachary. Special GiGi of Alex, Charlie, Jake, Kellie, Keith, Adam, Amy, Eli, Sammie, Jackson and Isabel. Services 9:30AM November 23, Temple Beth-El, Great Neck.

title: Another Day of Trade Talks, but the Same Old Impasse

title: Criticized Levee Boards Survive in Louisiana
description: BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 22 - In the crucial battle of a post-hurricane special legislative session that ended Tuesday, Louisiana lawmakers voted down an effort to reshape the state's fragmented levee protection system, which has long been criticized as a bastion of patronage.

title: Organic and Then Some
description: WHEN I first sold my family's vegetables at farmers' markets in Virginia in 1980, Slow Food hadn't been born, and the phrase "local foods" was not yet in the lingo. The word "organic," however, was in vogue, and our customers always asked the same question: Are you organic? Nine years old and barefoot, I tried not to appear flummoxed. I stumbled over answers, most of them beginning, "No, but"

title: Bosnia's 3 Groups Reach Unity Agreement
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 - Leaders of the major ethnic groups in Bosnia and Herzegovina, seeking to unify their country after years of sectarian hatred, pledged Tuesday to overhaul their constitutional and government system for the first time since the Bosnian war ended a decade ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDMAN, SAMUEL (SID) E.
description: FRIEDMAN--Samuel (Sid) E. A well known resident of Great Neck, New York (formerly of Seagate) at age 94. Loving husband of Reva. Devoted father of Mitchell (Jill), Justin (Linda), and Bruce (Paula). Adored grandfather of Pamela (Scott), Jocelyn (Elliot), Jeffrey, Julian, Allison, Jordan and Ruchell. title: Deaths After Abortion Pill to Be Studied by Officials
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 - Federal drug regulators have discovered that all four women in this country who died after taking an abortion pill suffered from a rare and highly lethal bacterial infection, a finding that is leading to new scrutiny of the drug's safety.

title: George Bush's Third Term
description: President George W. Bush has just entered his third term. That's right. He's a three-term president. His first term was from 2001 to 2004, and it was dominated by 9/11, which Mr. Bush skillfully used to take a hard-right Republican agenda on taxes and war with Iraq, which was going nowhere on 9/10, and drive it into a 9/12 world.

description: After hearing the New York New Music Ensemble's concert called "Music Mirroring the Moment" on Monday night, you might have deduced that the moment was dissonant and fractured, with occasional tendencies toward violence. These at least were the qualities that united a challenging program assembled by this stalwart and adventurous group at Merkin Concert Hall.

description: Three former brokers at Merrill Lynch who complained of sexual discrimination were awarded more than $2 million by NASD, the regulatory organization for the brokerage industry, after two years of arbitration.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Hunger Grows In New York
description: The number of New Yorkers who cannot adequately provide food for themselves has increased steadily over the last few years, according to data from advocacy groups, government agencies and food pantries. The largest concentration of hunger is in the Bronx, according to the New York City Coalition Against Hunger. The percentage of New Yorkers living in households that were inadequately fed rose to 14.56 percent in 2003-4 from 12.9 percent in 2001-2, according to the federal Department of Agriculture. City-financed pantries and soup kitchens provided almost 20,000 more meals in the first eight months of this year compared with the same period last year, according to city officials. And the percentage of low-income households that have used a soup kitchen or pantry has doubled in the last two years to 39 percent, according to a telephone survey released earlier this fall by the Community Service Society. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A sports article in some copies on Sunday about Brown's 52-21 football victory over Columbia misstated the given name of the Brown running back who set Ivy League career records for touchdowns, rushing touchdowns and points. He is Nick Hartigan, not Kevin.

description: So you think you are hewing to tradition by serving cranberry relish and pumpkin pie tomorrow? Think again. Oliver and the Plimouth Plantation (Clarkson Potter, $22.50), sets the record straight in a delightful fashion.

title: Denial and Deception, Revisited
description: Im trying not to write too much about the Iraq war these days. Its an issue Im passionate about, and there was a long time when I felt I had to speak out, even though I have no special expertise in national security, because it seemed that so few people in major news organizations were willing to say the obvious. But now there are many voices talking about how we got into this disastrous war and how we might get out, so by and large it makes sense for me to focus more on the economic issues The Times originally hired me to cover.

title: The Sports Editor on Sports Coverage
description: An enthusiastic New York Islanders fan from East Northport, New York, complained in an e-mail message last week about what he felt was a paucity of coverage of his favorite hockey team by The Times. He got a response the same day from Tom Jolly, the sports editor.

New balloons this year are Dora the Explorer, Scooby-Doo, JoJo and Healthy Mr. Potato Head (seriously).

description: ALBANY, Nov. 23 - Seeking to tamp down a war of words among state Republicans, Gov. George E. Pataki said on Wednesday afternoon that the party should not yet close its door on some of the potential candidates to succeed him.

description: The New York Stock Exchange's proposed purchase of Archipelago Holdings is fair, according to an evaluation by Citigroup, which was commissioned to settle a lawsuit that sought to block the transaction.

title: Is This the Most Trusted Man in Fashion?
description: YOU probably didn't notice, what with all the excitement about the return of "Project Runway," the release of a survey by a marketing company last week noting that Donald J. Trump had beat out Giorgio Armani and Donna Karan as one of the most trusted fashion names in America. That's right: Donald Trump, the real estate mogul, television star, hair aesthete and confessed "germ freak." Even the editors of Women's Wear Daily seemed to be in a state of disbelief, since their report of the news was buried on the inside.

title: Gay Officer, Dying, Is Pulled Into Rights Issue
description: POINT PLEASANT, N.J., Nov. 22 - The cancer in Laurel Hester's lungs keeps her voice to a whisper, so a noisy public dispute over gay marriage was the last thing she wanted at the end of her life.

description: Optical disc drives for recording CD's and DVD's are a bit like long-distance runners: there is always another speed threshold to conquer, fresh terrain to explore.

On The Street: Then
description: ROCKERS, bikers and renegades of every stripe were just a few of the American archetypes whose sartorial insignia, the rugged leather jacket, was resurrected in the fall of 1987. That year style-besotted New Yorkers were quick to embrace a killer look that owed a debt to professional hard guys, from Chuck Yeager to Sid Vicious and, most memorably perhaps, to Marlon Brando.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Others Criticized Over Trade
description: The trade minister of France, Christine Lagarde, left, criticized the United States, Brazil, and India for what she called their failure to respond to a European Union offer on farm aid and tariffs ahead of next month's World Trade Organization summit in Hong Kong. "We have unveiled a very complete proposal," Ms. Lagarde said at a meeting of business executives in Paris yesterday. "For the moment, we don't see anything coming" from others. "We would like to see what India is ready to do in terms of services, Brazil in industrial goods, and what the U.S. is really hiding before the announcement of agricultural reforms." On Oct. 28, the European Union made what the European trade commissioner, Peter Mandelson, called a bottom-line offer for the deepest cuts ever in European farm import levies in an effort to spur discussions on the rest of the W.T.O. agenda, ignoring opposition from President Jacques Chirac of France.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HARRIS, ETHEL
description: HARRIS--Ethel. It's been one year without you. Your warmth, kindness and humor live on forever. We miss you and love you. Your children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

title: Now, Accounting Can Get Its Gun
description: HIGHLAND LAKES, N.J. - This past summer, members of a Manhattan law firm went on a field trip to Danbury, Conn., where they spent an entire day at a range without swinging bats or golf clubs. The members of Kobre & Kim LLP were there not to hit and hack, but to lock and load, and to experience the thrill of firing pistols, rifles and even submachine guns.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CRONIN, MICHAEL THOMAS IGNATIUS, M.D.
description: CRONIN--Michael Thomas Ignatius, M.D. Died on November 23, 2005 in Branford, CT after a long battle with Parkinson's disease. Born on February 1, 1924, he came to the United States in 1952, becoming a citizen in 1958. He received a Doctor of Veterinary Medicine degree from University College, Dublin in Ireland in 1945 and from Trinity College, Dublin in Ireland he earned a Master's of Science in Bacteriology in 1946 and a Ph.D. in Pathology and Bacteriology in 1948. He received his M.D. degree from Georgetown University in 1965 with postgraduate training at Yale University. His medical career spanned 30 years with Yale University, St. Raphael's Hospital, New Haven and Memorial Hospital, Meriden among others. From 1971 to 1989 he was a Consulting Editor for the "American Scientist." A longtime resident of New Haven, Dr. Cronin moved in 1995 to Branford. He leaves his wife of 55 years, Carmel Sheridan Cronin, and eight children, Ingrid Cronin of Wilkes-Barre, PA, Agnes Cronin of San Francisco, Geraldine Burke of Rutland, VT, Charles Cronin of New York, Arthur Cronin of Hummelstown, PA, Carmel Cronin Gill of Lafayette, CO, Brenda Cronin of New York, and Michael Cronin of Littleton, CO. His son, Tom Cronin, died in 1975. His sister, Deirdre MacDonald of Ireland and his brother, David Cronin of France, also survive him. In addition, he has fifteen grandchildren. A Mass will be celebrated Saturday at 10AM at St. Mary's Church, Hillhouse Avenue, New Haven, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WINICK, FLORENCE NEE SHAPIRO
description: WINICK--Florence nee Shapiro. Of Manhattan, NY and Boca Raton, FL on November 22, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Philip, devoted mother of Eugene Winick and Ann Sendar, cherished mother-inlaw of Ina. One of eleven children she is survived by her sister, Ruth Raskin. Loving grandmother of Janet Winick Rubinstein, Leigh Ann Winick, Elizabeth Winick, Suzette Sendar Bluto and Jordan Sendar. Great-grandmother to nine. Service Friday, 1 PM, at Wien & Wien, Hackensack, NJ. Contributions may be made to the Simon Wiesenthal Center www.wiesenthal.com. Information 800-322-0533.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article yesterday about Eddy Curry of the Knicks misstated the injury that has limited his playing time recently. It is a strained left calf, not a strained left hamstring.

title: To Help Tune the TV, a High-Tech Arachnid
description: One nice thing about watching TV on a plain old analog set is that not much can go wrong with its relatively low-resolution image. But the new crop of digital sets is less forgiving. Regular adjustments to color, brightness, contrast and other parameters can make a big difference in picture quality.

title: Next for global trade talks
The Katrina Housing Debacle
description: The Bush administration's mishandling of the Katrina housing crisis is shaping up as an epic policy failure. Nearly three months after more than half a million people were displaced by the hurricane, most are still at loose ends in provisional housing -- many in isolated trailer parks. The government has no apparent plan for getting them settled in places where they might find jobs and schools.

title: Bring in the brainpower
Chris Whitley, 45, Songwriter Whose Music Blended Genres, Dies
description: Chris Whitley, an innovative songwriter and guitarist who played traditional blues as well as hybrids made with the sounds of electronic dance music, died on Sunday at a friend's home near Houston. He was 45 and lived in New York.

title: Turkey Set, Guests Seated. Something You Want to Say?
description: Before the turkey is carved today, Amy Scherber's family in Minnesota will sing a Christian blessing to the tune of "Edelweiss." Jeong Jun of Los Angeles will offer a Methodist grace in Korean to about 40 of his relatives and guests before they eat the rice-stuffed turkeys prepared by his wife, Hye-Sun. And in Wyomissing, Pa., the Kanes "will be grateful to hear my brother Brendan say grace in Irish Gaelic, even if we don't understand it," said Sibyl Kane, a New York lawyer.

Millions Face a Deadline for Choosing a New Medicare Plan
description: Decisions, decisions. The clock is ticking for millions of elderly and disabled people, who must decide whether and when to enroll in one of the new Medicare Part D drug plans that start Jan. 1, 2006.

title: Tracking the Scent of Self-Promotion
description: FEW designers manage to court controversy, or relish making headlines outside the style pages, with such consistent hubris and inconsistent nicknames as Sean Combs, who now prefers to be called Diddy. Last week Mr. Combs was in the news because the National Legal and Policy Center filed a complaint with the Federal Election Commission asserting that his attempt to rally America's youth during the 2004 presidential election, under the slogan "Vote or Die," was a veiled marketing effort for his clothing brand and may also have violated rules of nonpartisanship. Mr. Combs denies this, but more on that later.

title: A German Auto Supplier Delphi Might Envy
description: FRANKFURT, Nov. 23 - When Manfred Wennemer talks about the American auto industry these days, he sounds like a driver thankful to have survived a nasty pileup with a few scratches.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BALLEN, DORIS MILLER
description: BALLEN--Doris Miller. Died peacefully at her home on November 22, 2005 at the age of 83. Beloved wife of Frederick. Loving mother and mother-in-law of Marjorie and Eric Whitman, Edward and Sharon Ballen, Ram Ballen and Anne Black-Ballen and Kenneth Ballen. Devoted grandmother of Andrew Whitman, Lauren Ordower, Joshua and Rachel Ballen, Nicholas and Cecilia Ballen and great-grandmother of Nathan, Sam and Ellie Whitman and Sadie Ordower. She had boundless energy and dedication to charitable causes. Her enduring love and loyalty to her husband, children, grandchildren, great-grandchildren and friends is her legacy. Funeral services will be held Friday, 12 noon, at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. Interment Mt. Pleasant Cemetery. Donations in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MURPHY, MARY E. (MAUREEN) (NEE HEALY)
description: MURPHY--Mary E. (Maureen) (nee Healy) of Northport, L.I. Age 70. Wife of Daniel J., mother of Maureen, Danny, Timmy, Brian & Jean Ellen, daughter of Ellen & the late Thomas Healy, sister of Michael Healy & Msgr. Thomas J. Healy. Reposing Nolan & Taylor-Howe Funeral Home, Northport Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Mass Saturday 11AM St. Philip Neri Church, Northport. In lieu of flowers donations to Help Research & CIRE A.L.S. (Lou Gehrigs Disease) to Ride for Life, Mary Murphy, 50 WInkle Pt. Dr., Northport, NY 11768 or www.rideforlife.com

title: It's 9 A.M. Do You Know Where the Turkey Line Begins?
description: THEY are an amusing sort, really, if one can get past the sheer bafflement over their existence: the scores of New Yorkers who pour into Citarella on the Upper West Side on the Wednesday before Thanksgiving, their faces twisted into shock as they sweep in from the cold and into the madness ensuing over the pints of brussels sprouts, realizing they are not the only ones who had the clever idea of buying a turkey for Thanksgiving.

description: RUTHERFORD--William A., Sr. The Trustees and staff of the Storm King Art Center express profound sorrow at the loss of their dear friend and landscape architect since the Art Center's inception in 1960. Over the years his vision and creativity guided the shaping of our landscape and its integration with our sculptures. Our heartfelt condolences go to his beloved wife Joyce and his family.

Gift From Out of the Blue: A Home Is Made Livable
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 23 - Responding to a domestic violence call last April at an apartment in this city's largest housing project, Officer Joe Poggioli Jr. flipped on his flashlight, peered into a bedroom, and saw two boys huddled together on a bed. Cockroaches were crawling all over one wall and the bedsheets. One inched across the face of the younger boy.

title: Rapunzel, Rapunzel, Let Down Your Window Panels
description: Nicolette Brunklaus, a Dutch designer, has come up with silk window panels called Blond, printed with photos of long tresses. "When a woman throws her hair in front of her face, she creates her own introverted world," Ms. Brunklaus said. The panels, 110 by 118 inches, come in pairs ($900), mirror images of each other, like tresses parted down the middle. She also uses photo prints to make lampshades ($120 to $240), placing the prints inside so that they are revealed only when lighted. The panels and shades are at Space Downtown, 276 West 25th Street (Eighth Avenue), second floor, (212) 352-9968. CURRENTS: FURNISHINGS

Putin Defends Russia's Right to Regulate Private Groups
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 24 - President Vladimir V. Putin today defended Russia's right to scrutinize any political activity by foreign and domestic charities and nongovernmental organizations, even as he promised that "civil society in Russia should not suffer."

title: In Utah, Trying to Undo a Federal Claim Bit by Bit
description: Correction Appended

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Dividing Up Milosevic's Trial
description: Judges trying Slobodan Milosevic are evidently anxious to safeguard at least one part of his war crimes trial, which continues to be bogged down by the poor health of the former Yugoslav president. They propose to split up the enormous trial and to carve out the part, nearly complete, dealing with the 1999 war in Kosovo. This could lead to an early judgment. The rest of the case, dealing with the wars in Bosnia and Croatia, would then follow. Mr. Milosevic's high blood pressure and vascular problems once again forced the trial to stop this week, and judges have called hearings to discuss the proposed division of the trial on Tuesday.

title: Ratings for Retailers
description: Attention, holiday shoppers! "Retailing powerhouses Best Buy, Circuit City, and Wal-Mart may not be the best places to buy electronics," says the December issue of Consumer Reports. "Those chains rated only middling to below average on price, selection, and service."

title: French lawmakersdebate antiterror bill
This One Meal
description: Somehow Thanksgiving always recalls the past. The question is which past. For most of us, the Pilgrims and their sufferings are no more real than the thought of a cold November day without central heating. The richest part of our imagination is bounded by childhood, and when we think of an authentic, historical Thanksgiving, we tend to mean the kind of feast we ate when the adults all seemed so much bigger and wiser and funnier -- a feast that is authentic right down to the Jell-O salad, if you come from the Jell-O salad part of the country.

title: 2 Sisters Injured as Parade Balloon Crashes Into Lamppost
description: A giant balloon in the Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade, swinging out of control in sudden bursts of wind, struck a light pole in the heart of Times Square today, injuring two spectators and scaring scores of others in an eerie replay of a 1997 accident that had prompted pledges of safety reforms.

Corrections
description: An article on Monday about rulings by Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. on cases related to the separation of church and state misstated a word in the First Amendment. It says that "Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof" -- not the establishment of religion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLOCH, CHARLES B.
description: BLOCH--Charles B. The Cantors Assembly mourns the loss of one of its earliest members. Fondly remembered for his glorious voice and friendship to colleagues, Hazzan Bloch served four leading American congregations including Temple Ansche Chesed in Manhattan. His first cantorial experience was as chief alto soloist for the incomparable Yossel Rosenblatt. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Evelyn, children, Robert and Heni, and his many grandchildren. May Hazzan Bloch's memory remain as a blessing to all who were inspired by the beauty of his prayers, and touched by his goodness. Hazzan Steven Stoehr, President Hazzan Stephen J. Stein, Executive Vice President

title: An Exhaustive Indie Spoof
description: "My Big Fat Independent Movie" is a frenetic attempt to spoof every major art-house film of the last decade. Loosely framed by a goofy narrative featuring two hit men, an amnesiac and a kidnapped salesgirl, the movie tries to skewer every clichA in the Sundance playbook, from self-conscious camera angles to irrelevant lesbian interaction. The dialogue is often sharp ("We're going to forge an unlikely bond," explains one hit man when asked what he plans to do with his kidnapping victim), and the pace is relentless, but as our antiheroes navigate a "Reservoir Dogs"-style torture scene and dodge various "falling symbolic devices," the hyperactive style and uneven performances begin to grate. By the time the dwarf appears, the movie has worn itself out.

description: Manhattan

description: Correction Appended

title: Bobcats Have What Knicks Seem to Want
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Nov. 23 - Two reclamation projects crossed paths Wednesday night, one a carefully planned rebirth, the other a haphazard reconstruction. Without the uniforms, it would be difficult to say which was the expansion team and which was the storied franchise in search of itself.

title: They Held Their Noses, and Ate
description: San Marcos, Tex. - NO contemporary American holiday is as deeply steeped in culinary tradition as Thanksgiving. Not only is the day centered on a feast, but it's also a feast with a narrowly proscribed list of foods -- usually some combination of turkey, corn, cranberries, squash and pumpkin pie. Decorated with these dishes, the Thanksgiving table has become a secular altar upon which we worship America's pioneering character, a place to show reverence for the rugged Pilgrims who came to Plymouth in peace, sat with the Indians as equals and indulged in the New World's cornucopia with gusto.

title: Arts, Briefly; Big Night for 'S.V.U.'
description: "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit" delivered its largest audience of the season on Tuesday and led NBC to a victory in the night's Nielsen estimates. The episode drew 16.93 million viewers and was Tuesday's most-watched program. ABC's broadcast of the 33rd annual American Music Awards from 8 p.m. to 11 p.m. brought in an average of 11.68 million viewers, which was good enough for second place among total viewers and among adults 18 to 49, but it was down in double-digit percentages compared with last year's show. Cedric the Entertainer, above, was the host of the show. On CBS, the alien invasion series "Threshold" made its debut in its new Tuesday slot. ("Close to Home" has taken "Threshold's" Friday time period.) It fared quite poorly, bringing in only 6.38 million viewers, despite a guest appearance by Elizabeth Berkley ("Showgirls") as a woman infected by the aliens. KATE AURTHUR

title: Huge new wave of blogging in China
Physical Culture; Best In Gym
description: WALK into most gyms, and it is obvious which cardio machines are the favorites. Quite often rows of treadmills are parked on prime real estate in front of the televisions. Close by, stationary bikes also crowd the floor. And rightly so: these are the two most popular machines for a cardiovascular workout at health clubs. Lately their dominance has been challenged by a newcomer, the elliptical motion trainer, at right, a machine that aims to replicate running without the stress on joints.

title: Judge Rejects Challenge to Bush Education Law
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 - A federal judge in Michigan on Wednesday dismissed a major challenge to the Bush administration's signature education program, No Child Left Behind, saying the federal government had the right to require states to spend their own money to comply with the law.

title: An Understated Duet Seizes the Spotlight
description: The audience was glittering on Tuesday night when the New York City Ballet opened its winter season at the New York State Theater. But the program was pretty much business as usual. Still, sandwiched between a signature work by the company director, Peter Martins, and a Jerome Robbins classic was a new duet by Albert Evans called "In a Landscape" that was the highlight of the evening. Scheduled for this one performance only, it is a small ballet that deserves a larger audience.

title: Sexual Offender Is Arrested in Killing of Ex-Companion
description: A convicted sex offender facing charges of raping his former companion's mother killed the daughter on Tuesday and then set fire to her New Paltz apartment building, the Ulster County district attorney said yesterday.

title: Three Sizes of Data to Go, All in the Same Small Package
description: The race to cram more data into less space has led Memorex to increase the capacity of its tiny Mega TravelDrive hard drives from four gigabytes to as much as eight gigabytes.

title: A Party Girl Leads China's Online Revolution
description: SHANGHAI, Nov. 23 - On her fourth day of keeping a Web log, she introduced herself to the world with these striking words: "I am a dance girl, and I am a party member."

title: Usher Makes Some Friends Who Are Mobsters
description: The newspaper advertisement for "In the Mix" is a large photograph of the R&B star Usher in a pinstripe suit, being attended by five hands. Two hands seem to be caressing him, two are grooming him and one gives the definite impression of grabbing him with intent to commit violence.

title: Crooning and Rap, in Harmony
description: What does a hip-hop heartthrob look like these days? Often, he looks a lot like Juelz Santana, the 21-year-old Harlem rapper who has a knack for seeming boyish without ever quite seeming harmless. He has dimples, a mischievous smile and a rude but charming habit of eschewing come-ons in favor of let's-gos. He once famously barked, "Get in the car/ And don't touch nothing, sit in the car"; this was his idea of smooth seduction. And he's not shy about telling potential lovers exactly what he wants -- and, while he's at it, exactly what his friends want, too.

title: Pinochet Held on Charges Linked to Bank Accounts
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 23 - Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the former military dictator of Chile, was arrested Wednesday in Santiago on tax fraud and passport forgery charges arising from secret bank accounts holding millions of dollars that he maintained under false names in the United States and elsewhere.

title: In France, Artists Have Sounded the Warning Bells for Years
description: PARIS, Nov. 23 - So life often imitates art. Yet with the recent uprisings in some French immigrant neighborhoods, this clich came with a new twist: art, in the form of movies and rap music, has long been warning that French-born Arab and black youths felt increasingly alienated from French society and that their communities were ripe for explosion.

title: You Are What You Overeat
description: Ithaca, N.Y. - WHEN Thanksgiving rolls around, my thoughts turn to stuffing. I don't ordinarily stuff the birds I roast. But planning a turkey dinner for 20, I reflect on my options. I could make the stuffing with chestnuts, but I'd have to roast and peel them -- a tedious business. I could make it with dried fruit and bread crusts, but meat with fruit is a bore. I like cornbread in my stuffing, but it's a bother to bake and a risk to buy. I love the chicken liver and ricotta recipe, but Aunt Helen doesn't. What to do?

description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 24 - The South Korean pioneer in cloning research acknowledged today that he had lied about how he obtained human egg cells used in his work, which has been embroiled in a growing ethical controversy over the last two weeks.

description: TATTOOS have long since spread from the steely biceps of sailors and longshoremen to the shoulders, necks, ankles and lower backs of nearly everyone else. Today 1 in 10 Americans has at least one tattoo -- including 9 percent of people ages 40 to 64 -- according to a national survey published a few years ago in American Demographics magazine.

title: James King, 80, Tenor Known for Strauss and Wagner, Dies
description: James King, an American heldentenor whose bright, ringing voice and fluent high notes captivated critics and audiences in leading European opera houses in the 1960's, died on Sunday in Naples, Fla., where he had retired. He was 80.

title: Jets Owner Says Edwards Will Remain
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 23 - After being buffeted for days by rumors that their coach may bolt for Kansas City after this season, the Jets received a welcome reprieve Wednesday. The team's owner, Woody Johnson, usually a behind-the-scenes presence, stepped forward after practice to vigorously reassure his players that Coach Herman Edwards was not going anywhere.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend on Friday about the "Frequency" exhibition at the Studio Museum in Harlem misidentified the creator of the cutout wallpaper work. She is Jina Valentine, not Lester Julian Merriweather, another artist included in the show. The review also misidentified the substance slathered on an image of the artist's head in "Till," by Demetrius Oliver. It is chocolate frosting, not ketchup.

title: Rhythm, Among Other Things, Is Their Business
description: The last time Brad Mehldau's trio played at the Village Vanguard, at the end of 2003, Jorge Rossy was still its drummer. That job has now shifted to Jeff Ballard. A working band with a strong, original sound is a rare thing in jazz, and when it changes a member there can be a minor trauma; it's suddenly a different organism. The Mehldau trio with Mr. Rossy and the bassist Larry Grenadier had stayed intact for 10 years, becoming more and more of a standard-bearer of new jazz as it went along.

title: Does Putting Up a Glass Galleria Count as Bringing Back a Street?
description: CORTLANDT -- the street that was but isn't -- may not be again.

title: Storm-Swept Yucatn Hotels Fixing Up as Season Nears
description: CHIQUIL, Mexico, Nov. 17 - Porfirio Guzmn Vzquez does not need a politician to tell him how long it will take to recover from Hurricane Wilma. He just looks out the hole that used to be his living room wall at the four oceangoing fishing boats beached and broken on the road outside his house.

title: Corrections

It is the Survivors Network of Those Abused by Priests, not the Survivors Network of Priest Abuse.

Jeweled Halls Echo The Jeweled Lights Below
description: Crystals reflect skyline views through the halls of Top of the Rock, the new observation decks at Rockefeller Center. In the elliptical entry stairwell (far right), Michael Gabellini, the interior designer, hung a 35-foot-tall wire chandelier, which dangles 15,000 Swarovski prisms. Around the elevator core (right), Mr. Gabellini wrapped 654 triangular panes of glass or Swarovski crystal, so that the faceted surface resembles a geode. Fiber-optic lights inside the chandelier and the walls shift color continuously, from amber to smoky gray, rose and amethyst. "We used the colors of different kinds of quartz," Mr. Gabellini said. "It creates the effect of these glowing, shimmering embers inside the limestone rock of a building." At 30 Rockefeller Plaza, West 50th Street, 8:30 a.m. to midnight daily; tickets: $14; $12 for those 62 and older; $9 for 6 to 12; (877) 692-7625, www.topoftherocknyc.com.
