World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Air France-KLM Profit Triples
description: The Air France-KLM Group, Europe's biggest airline, increased its full-year forecast after second-quarter profit more than tripled on demand for overseas flights. Earnings before interest and tax will climb more than 50 percent for the full year, Pierre-Henri Gourgeon, chief operating officer, said yesterday. Air France, which combined with KLM Royal Dutch Airlines in May 2003, is outperforming Deutsche Lufthansa, the German airline, and British Airways by attracting passengers from across Europe for international flights from its bases at Charles de Gaulle Airport, serving Paris, and Schiphol, serving Amsterdam. Second-quarter net income rose to 717 million euros ($848 million), or 2.73 euros a share ($3.23), in the quarter ended Sept. 30. Profit included a net gain of 419 million euros ($495 million) from the sale of a stake in Amadeus Global Distribution, a travel reservation company. "Demand for air travel is relatively good and Air France-KLM is progressing better than the average because of the merger," Mr. Gourgeon said. Air France, based in Roissy, France, said second-quarter passenger traffic rose 9 percent as the airline increased seating capacity by 5 percent.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about Medicis Pharmaceutical's rejection of a takeover proposal by Mentor misstated at one point the company that was the bidder in a similar deal. Allergan seeks to acquire Inamed, not the other way around.

title: She'll Get By With a Little Help From Her Kids
description: For a pop star with such a hit-filled career, Carly Simon has only rarely performed live. But her famous stage fright has always seemed a little mysterious. The candor of her songs would seem to belie it, as would her interviews, full of easy flowing opinions on love, aging, motherhood, her marriage to James Taylor in the 1970's, his drug addiction, her bout with cancer and, of course, her music. Nonetheless, she leaned on her children for support on Tuesday night at Rose Hall, her son, Ben, and daughter, Sally, both musicians, joining their famously performance-shy mother onstage.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Transit Union Sues City
description: The Transport Workers Union, Local 100, sued New York City in Federal District Court late yesterday, trying to bar the city from seeking an injunction that would prevent 32,000 subway and bus workers from going on strike next month. The union's three-year contract with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority expires on Dec. 15. State law already prohibits public employees from striking, but in 1999 and 2002, the city went to court to impose exorbitant fines on any employee who walked out. In both instances, a settlement was reached and no strike occurred. The new lawsuit contends that both suits violated union members' right to free speech and that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg abused his authority by filing the 2002 suit. A spokeswoman for the city's Law Department said last night that it had not seen the complaint. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: Air France-KLM's profit triples
Paid Notice: Deaths   HECTOR, LOUIS J.
description: HECTOR--Louis J. The Trustees, faculty, and staff of The Rockefeller University deeply mourn the loss of our beloved friend, Louis J. Hector, Esq., an esteemed member of the Board of Trustees for twenty-five years. Louis Hector joined The Rockefeller University Council in 1977 and was elected to the Board in 1981. He became an emeritus trustee in 1991. Louis will be remembered for his generosity of spirit, wise counsel, and the enormous personal integrity that guided all aspects of his long and productive life. His enthusiasm for basic science encouraged Lucille P. Markey, one of the prominent clients of his law firm, Steel Hector & Davis, to become a benefactor of many research institutions, including this one. Following Mrs. Markey's death, he was instrumental in establishing the Lucille P. Markey Charitable Trust as an organization dedicated to the advancement of biomedical research. Under his chairmanship, the Markey Trust had a profound impact on the quality of scientific research in the United States, shining a bright light on the need for philanthropic investment in science and serving as a model for many foundations which followed. In 1994, The Rockefeller University recognized Louis Hector's enormous contributions to the advancement of science and medicine with an honorary doctoral degree. We will miss his keen intelligence, astute judgment, and inspiring optimism. His influence and legacy will be felt throughout the University for many years to come. We extend our condolences to his wife, Nancy; their beloved children; and the entire Hector family. Paul Nurse, President Joshua Lederberg and Torsten Wiesel, Presidents Emeritus Russell Carson, Chairman Richard Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman The Rockefeller University

title: An Ordinary Jordanian Clan, Caught in an Ideological Cross-Fire With Jihadists

title: Hughes 'Hoax,' a tall tale retold
Young and Privileged, but Writing Vividly of Africa's Child Soldiers
description: POTOMAC, Md., Nov. 21 - Uzodinma Iweala's brutal debut novel, "Beasts of No Nation," is filled with the stink of violence. Its narrator, who goes by the name of Agu, is somewhere between 9 and 12 years old when he is kidnapped and forced to fight in the civil war of a nameless African country. He watches as a man who is about to be killed by a machete loses control of his bowels in terror. He sees maggots crawling over the corpse of a dead soldier. He is raped by the commander of his guerrilla unit, "the way the man goat is sometimes mistaking other man goat for woman goat," he says.

That was the fear that Jawole Willa Jo Zollar, the executive director of Urban Bush Women dance troupe, had when she considered choreographing dances around the kind of thorny issues that even academia has largely given a pass.

title: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: 12 Arrested In Protest Near Bush Ranch
description: Twelve opponents of the Iraq war were arrested on charges of violating McLennan County ordinances that forbid camping and roadside parking within seven miles of President Bush's ranch near Crawford. Those arrested included Daniel Ellsberg, who leaked the Pentagon Papers in 1969, and Mary Ann Wright, who resigned in 2003 as the State Department deputy chief of mission in Mongolia in protest against the war. The protesters said the ordinances abridged their right to free speech. The ordinances, enacted after hundreds of antiwar activists amassed near the ranch in August, are being challenged in federal court.

The Dangerous World of Drugs
description: "Down to the Bone," which won a Special Jury Prize at last year's Sundance Festival, is the kind of movie most independent films strive in vain to be: a small, beautifully faceted gem. Vera Farmiga gives a pitch-perfect performance as Irene, a mother of two who works as a supermarket cashier in upstate New York. Though she appears to be a competent employee and loving wife and mother, Irene's life is precariously built around a cocaine addiction. When she finds herself trying to cash her son's birthday check to pay off her dealer, Irene decides to check herself into rehab. But an affair with a charismatic male nurse (Hugh Dillon) threatens to drag her into the even more dangerous world of heroin.

description: Board-a-Match is the toughest form of bridge. It is a team event, and on each deal the two pairs compare their scores. If they have a net plus, whether it is 10 points or 1,000, they win one board (one point). An exact tie counts a half. And a net minus is worth zero. One must not only fight for every trick but also try to judge what the contract will be at the other table.

Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Woman Found Dead In Kitchen
description: A Bronx woman was found dead in her kitchen by her 12-year-old daughter early yesterday, investigators said. The woman, Erica Robertson, 28, appeared to have been stabbed in the chest, they said. Ms. Robertson, a security guard in East Harlem, lived in her apartment, on the second floor of 1246 Grant Avenue, for just under a year, said a friend, who gave her name only as Ms. Thompson. The police yesterday were waiting for the medical examiner to determine a cause of death. The owner of her apartment, Jerome Blount, said Ms. Robertson also cared for the 15-year-old daughter of her companion, who lives in Ohio. Kareem Fahim (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Peru: No Progress in Trade Talks
description: The United States and Peru failed to reach an agreement to remove barriers to trade and investment, bringing talks on a broad free trade agreement to a close without a breakthrough, trade officials said. Talks with Colombia and Ecuador ended Tuesday, and negotiators for each government said they pulled out of the discussions because they could not accept American demands that they stiffen patent protections and allow more farm imports from the United States. "This seems likely to delay a signing, but I doubt it ends prospects for an agreement," said Peter Hakim, president of the Inter-American Dialogue, a research center based in Washington. The Bush administration is trying to lower trade and investment barriers to improve the economies of Colombia, Peru, Ecuador and Bolivia to halt the cultivation of coca, the main ingredient in cocaine.

title: Codey Rejects Consideration to Complete Corzine's Term

Codey announced on Wednesday that he had withdrawn his name from consideration to succeed Jon S. Corzine, the governor-elect, in the United States Senate.

description: Modern musicians, even those not yet out of grade school, are increasingly multitaskers, juggling computers and musical instruments. The combination can be a fruitful one, but bouncing between keyboard and, well, the other kind of keyboard requires a bit of a rubber-arm act.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Morgan Stanley Chief Executive Said to Be Looking at Hedge Fund Deal Five months into his term as chief executive of Morgan Stanley, John J. Mack is stepping up efforts to add businesses and possibly bolster his management team. Yesterday, Morgan Stanley severed ties with three former executives who were forced to leave the firm by Philip J. Purcell during his management shake-up earlier this year. While making such a break with executives whom some had hoped might return, Mr. Mack has stepped up his search to acquire a hedge fund. Within the last month, he offered to buy FrontPoint Partners, a hedge fund manager with more than $5 billion in assets, according to people who were briefed on the discussions. [Page C1.]

title: The Old Ferryboat and the Sea: A Parable Updated as a Landlord-Tenant Dispute
description: The first thing the people who own the Yankee ferry will tell you is that they are ready to shove off. They are willing to collect the chickens that roost on the deck of the 98-year-old boat, round up the squalling puppies that have the run of the ship, and, with regret, cast off in their floating piece of history from Pier 25 on the TriBeCa waterfront in search of a new home.

Alexander, of the Seattle Seahawks, is the N.F.C.'s leader in total yards from scrimmage. The Giants' Barber is second.

title: Israeli Troops and Hezbollah Clash Again Near the Border
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, Nov. 23 - Israeli troops and Hezbollah fighters clashed Wednesday for the second time in three days after an apparently errant Israeli hang glider flew across the Lebanese border and landed near the border town of Meiss el Jabal, Israeli officials and Hezbollah reported.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: President Dismisses Entire Cabinet
description: President Mwai Kibaki, reacting to voters' rejection of a constitutional referendum on Monday on which he had staked his reputation, dismissed his entire cabinet and said he would name new ministers within two weeks. In a brief statement, Mr. Kibaki said the move was aimed at making the cabinet "more cohesive and better able to serve the people of Kenya." It remains to be seen whether the purge ousts Raila Odinga, the outspoken roads minister who led the campaign against Mr. Kibaki's proposed constitutional changes.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bid for Drax Is Dropped
description: The Constellation Energy Group, the owner of three nuclear plants in the United States, and the Blackstone Group buyout firm dropped a 2.23 billion ($3.84 billion) bid for the British energy company Drax Group, which refused the offer because it was too low. A significant majority of Drax shareholders did not support the bid, the company said yesterday in a statement. The bidders for Drax, which operates Europe's biggest coal-fired power plant and is based in Selby, England, also included the Perry Capital hedge fund and the buyout company, Hellman & Friedman. Drax is the second British utility in two days to reject a takeover offer as inadequate as companies bet that soaring energy prices will raise earnings. Scottish Power, Britain's fifth-largest power provider, said on Tuesday that an 11.3 billion ($19.4 billion) proposal from E.ON of Germany was too low, prompting E.ON to withdraw the bid.

They are a reminder that beauty is more than skin deep." Mr. Zagoory, who studied jewelry at the Fashion Institute of Technology, creates ornately detailed pens, inkwells, card holders and other desk accessories. The T. Rex (in pewter, $50) is at uncommongoods.com; his other products are at jaczagoory.com. CURRENTS: DESKWARE

title: The Met May Settle With Italy
description: ROME, Nov. 23 - For all the saber-rattling before their grueling six-hour meeting on Tuesday, Italy's culture ministry and the Metropolitan Museum of Art have mapped out a potential solution to Italy's claims on antiquities in the museum's collection, officials said Wednesday. In essence, Italy would officially own the works, which it asserts were looted within its borders, but the Met would get to keep them -- or receive objects of equal value as long-term loans.

title: Dcor Has a Family Reunion
description: ALBERT HADLEY hates being the focus of attention, finds cocktail parties a waste of time and doesn't enjoy other people's birthdays, let alone his own. So last Friday night, when the interior designer Brian J. McCarthy and his companion, Daniel Sager, a textile designer, held a well-hors d'oeuvred bash at their Midtown apartment in honor of Mr. Hadley's 85th year, it was the elder man's definition of hell on earth.

title: Letter by 18th-Century Slave Fetches Record Price
description: A signed letter dated Feb. 14, 1776, by Phillis Wheatley, below, a Boston slave and the author of the first book of poetry published by an African-American, fetched a record-setting $253,000 at auction on Tuesday. That price, which includes a 15 percent commission, was the highest ever paid at auction for a letter written by an African-American, and appears to have set an auction record for a letter written by a woman, said Jeremy Markowitz, an autograph specialist at Swann Galleries in New York, which sold it. The two-page letter is considered especially valuable because in it Wheatley talks about the American Revolution, and obliquely about slavery, and because it was written to an enslaved friend, Obour Tanner, in Newport, R.I. "This is a happy day for those of us who love African-American literature," said Henry Louis Gates Jr., chairman of the department of African and African-American studies at Harvard. "Phillis Wheatley is the mother of the African-American literary tradition. Anything that surfaces from her is extremely valuable." The buyer was anonymous, Mr. Markowitz said. The Wheatley letter, the only one known to exist outside the 19 in institutions in America and Britain, had been estimated to sell for $80,000 to $120,000. FELICIA R. LEE

Boys liked the movie for the scene in which Phoebe Cates emerges from the swimming pool in that puckered red bikini, her taut abdomen flashing with water droplets, her lips glossy, her dark hair as sleek as a porpoise's.

title: U.S. Inquiry Into New Jersey Power Broker Is Said to Focus on His Consulting Firm

description: Two United States oil companies, taking an unusual tack, filed arbitration proceedings this week against the government of Yemen for expropriating an oil-producing block with output worth more than $1 billion a year.

title: Redick and No. 1 Duke Hold Off Scrappy Drexel
description: Playing the No. 1-ranked team in the nation for the first time in its history, Drexel showed that it had some pluck last night in the semifinals of the preseason National Invitation Tournament at Madison Square Garden. But Duke had J. J. Redick, a weapon more lethal than a little bit of grit.

World Briefing | Europe: Britain: An End To 11 p.m. Chugging
description: A new law came into force allowing bars, pubs and supermarkets in England and Wales to sell alcohol around the clock. According to the BBC, some 60,000 premises have been granted licenses to extend their hours, although only 359 pubs and clubs are getting 24-hour licenses. Law enforcement officials have warned that extending sales of alcohol beyond the previous cutoff of 11 p.m. will promote binge drinking and alcohol-related crime; the government says the new hours will encourage more responsible, Continental-style drinking. "What we're actually seeing is that at last in this country adults are going to be treated like grown-ups and given a little bit of choice about having a social life beyond 11 o'clock at night," Mark Hastings, a spokesman for the British Beer and Pub Association, told the BBC.

description: In his programs for the New Juilliard Ensemble this season, Joel Sachs is revisiting some of the music composed for his student ensemble over the last 13 seasons, and adding a few new scores to the repertory as well. He is also doing what he does in virtually all his projects, including his work with Continuum and his Summergarden concerts at the Museum of Modern Art: looking beyond Western Europe for unusually inventive, ear-opening works.

description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 23 - Afghanistan made some progress in cutting back opium poppy cultivation in the past year but is still in danger of becoming a "narco-state," the director of an annual United Nations survey said Wednesday.

title: Across From the Met, a Duplex Penthouse for $47 Million
description: The former Stanhope Hotel, at Fifth Avenue and 81st Street, is going co-op. The building, designed by the apartment-house architect Rosario Candela, was built in 1926, and looks much like other pre-World War II buildings in the neighborhood. Inside, though, everything will be new: the hotel's 185 rooms will become 26 private residences designed by John Simpson, the architect of the Queen's Gallery at Buckingham Palace. A proposed scheme for a "drawing room" in one of the new apartments is at left.

title: For Parcells, Little Time for Grieving
description: IRVING, Tex., Nov. 23 - The short turnaround week for the N.F.L. teams involved in the annual Thanksgiving Day games is of little concern to those fans eager for entertainment laced with aromas from a holiday kitchen.

title: In Swing of Fortune, Mets Finally Get Delgado
description: In Omar Minaya's nascent weeks as general manager last fall, he constructed a plan that he believed would spur the Mets' revival. It called for signing the Latin American free-agent trinity of Pedro Martnez, Carlos Beltran and Carlos Delgado -- the best starting pitcher, outfielder and power hitter available.

title: A Soprano Who Is Immersed in Schumann and Strauss
description: Here's the bottom line of any music recital: Is the artist actually saying anything, and do you want to hear him again? There are a number of ways to quantify the answers to these questions: two key distinguishing characteristics, in voice, are technique and expression.

title: A Sale That Cheers: Home for the Holidays
description: A sample sale that cuts the cost of presents by more than half is itself a welcome gift for holiday shoppers. Next week, Mike & Ally, a home accessories company, will sell wares carried by stores like Barneys and Bergdorf Goodman at deep discounts. Woven aluminum wastebaskets (below) are $55 ($120 in stores). Bright-colored enameled wastebaskets, some with stones or crystals, are $50 to $125 (usually $150 to $350). Frames are $25 to $175 (were $65 to $175). The sale runs Monday through Friday, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m., at 350 Seventh Avenue (29th Street), (212) 563-5433. MARIANNE ROHRLICH CURRENTS: WHO KNEW?

title: The Grit Behind Fashion's Glamour
description: Fashion is fabulous when you are armed with a platinum card, but down in the trenches where the stuff gets made, you will find more sweat than silk. A blazer from the cult men's wear label Cloak will set you back $1,200; an unexpected business expense of $150 amounts to a minor budgetary crisis for the man who designed it. While his hipster clientele pose and splurge, Alexandre Plokhov toils in his studio in the meatpacking district and then goes home to an empty apartment, nothing but voicemail for company.

title: Roosevelt in Brazil, With Ticks, Termites and Malted Milk
description: The River of Doubt Theodore Roosevelt's Darkest Journey By Candice Millard Illustrated. 416 pages. Doubleday. $26.

title: A Player Known for His Politics, Too
description: As quickly as they had heard that the Mets were close to acquiring Carlos Delgado from the Marlins, fans and radio talk-show hosts reacted passionately to the news yesterday, devoting as much attention to Delgado's personality and politics as his on-field play.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Eritrea: Threat Of U.N. Sanctions
description: The Security Council threatened Eritrea with economic sanctions if it did not reverse its decision to bar United Nations helicopter flights and end other restrictions on the 3,300-member United Nations peacekeeping mission monitoring its border with Ethiopia. The resolution, adopted by a unanimous 15-to-0 vote, also warned Ethiopia of sanctions if it used force to settle the frontier dispute. An estimated 100,000 people died in a two-year border war between the countries that ended in a peace agreement and a binding boundary commission ruling in 2000. Eritrea is protesting Ethiopia's unwillingness to accept the commission's demarcation verdict.

title: Almost 60 Homeless as Fire Destroys Apartments in Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 23 - Nearly 60 people were left homeless Wednesday when fire devoured their apartment building east of downtown.

title: U.S. Considers Troop Cuts After Iraq Holds Elections
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 - The Pentagon is planning to make modest troop reductions after next month's elections in Iraq and, if security conditions improve, could begin reductions next summer that would drop the American force level below 100,000 by late next year, Defense Department officials said Wednesday.

title: Rail strike in Franceends after weak show
Sometimes, a Tax Cut for the Wealthy Can Hurt the Wealthy
description: WHEN market forces cause income inequality to grow, public policy in most countries tends to push in the opposite direction. In the United States, however, we enact tax cuts for the wealthy and cut public services for the needy. Cynics explain this curious inversion by saying that the wealthy have captured the political process in Washington and are exploiting it to their own advantage.

title: Allies get speedy Merkel visit
Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about rulings by Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. on cases related to the separation of church and state misstated a word in the First Amendment. It says that "Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof" - not the establishment of religion. (Go to Article)

Insider Charge Filed Against Ex-Broker
description: Federal prosecutors have charged a former securities broker, David Pajcin, with insider trading related to information the authorities said he gleaned by illegally obtaining advance copies of Business Week and buying stocks that the magazine was covering favorably.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Man Indicted In Girl's Death
description: A Staten Island man has been indicted in the death of Aniesa Wood, a 2-year-old girl who was found unconscious at her Tompkinsville home in July, Daniel M. Donovan Jr., the Staten Island district attorney, announced yesterday. Julius C. Butler, 32, was charged with criminally negligent homicide and endangering the welfare of a child, Mr. Donovan said in a statement. Mr. Butler was the live-in boyfriend of the girl's mother. Mr. Donovan said Aniesa died on July 23 after suffering blunt trauma to her abdomen.

Thanksgiving
description: NEW YORK GOVERNMENT OFFICES -- Closed. POST OFFICES -- Express Mail only; main post office on Eighth Avenue at 32nd Street is open. BANKS -- Option to close. PARKING -- Alternate-side and parking meter regulations suspended. SANITATION -- No pickups, recycling or street cleaning. SCHOOLS -- Closed. FINANCIAL MARKETS -- Stock and bond markets closed. Tomorrow, the markets will close at 1 p.m. TRANSPORTATION -- New York City buses and subways will operate on a Sunday schedule. Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North trains will operate on holiday schedules.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: U.N. Darfur Resolution Blocked
description: The African Union blocked consideration of a European Union-sponsored resolution in the General Assembly's social and humanitarian committee calling on Sudan to end the culture of impunity and disarm militia responsible for the destruction of communities and massacres in Darfur. Nigeria, representing the African Union, said any condemnatory action would endanger peace talks. Emyr Jones Parry, the British ambassador, said the European Union "deeply regretted" the action, adding, "There can hardly be a situation of human rights in more urgent need of the world's attention than the situation in Sudan."

title: EU data retention measure falls short of British plan
Shift on Suspect Is Linked to Role of Qaeda Figures
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 - The Bush administration decided to charge Jose Padilla with less serious crimes because it was unwilling to allow testimony from two senior members of Al Qaeda who had been subjected to harsh questioning, current and former government officials said Wednesday.

title: Iraqis Getting Together
description: "Iraqi Factions Seek Timetable for U.S. Pullout" is hardly the kind of headline the White House wants to read these days. But it refers to a joint statement by Arab Shiite, Arab Sunni and Kurdish political leaders at a conference sponsored by the Arab League in Cairo this week that represents one of the more encouraging developments in Iraqi politics in quite some time.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Councilmen Criticize Service Changes
description: City Councilmen John C. Liu, left, and Eric N. Gioia, Democrats from Queens, yesterday criticized the frequent diversions that have disrupted service on the No. 7 line on weekends. "More than a hindrance to our hard-working citizens," Mr. Gioia said, "this is a snub to our borough." Mr. Liu, chairman of the Transportation Committee, said he would hold a hearing on Dec. 1. From 10 p.m. last Saturday until noon on Sunday, shuttle buses replaced the No. 7 between the 61st Street-Woodside and Main Street-Flushing stations. This weekend and the next, the Manhattan-bound No. 7 train will make only express stops between Willets Point-Shea Stadium and Queensboro Plaza. Deirdre K. Parker, a spokeswoman for New York City Transit, said vital construction work, including track repairs and the installation of elevators at the Junction Boulevard Station, necessitated doing the work on weekends. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: Pillows, Throws and Rugs in Colors as Intense as the Indian Sun
description: The fashion designer Alpana Bawa (shown in her downtown workshop-apartment) has introduced her first home collection, featuring intensely hued pillows, curtain panels, throws and rugs made in India.

description: GERMANTOWN, Tenn. - After serving the children of affluent parents for 40 years, St. George's Independent, a private elementary school here in a suburb of Memphis, decided to expand into higher grades.

description: A day after the disclosure of a new Vatican directive that deters most gay men from joining the priesthood, some priests say they are shocked by one easily overlooked clause. It says that spiritual directors and confessors in seminaries "have the duty to dissuade" any candidates "who show deep-seated homosexual tendencies" from joining the priesthood.

description: In 1996, Derek Mercer founded Recruitmax Inc., a maker of software for human resources professionals, with $100,000 in capital and the conviction that his product's simple design would make it a winner.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Inquiry Into 1985 Air India Bombing
description: The Canadian government will have the former Ontario premier, Bob Rae, conduct a policy-based inquiry into federal officials' role in the 1985 Air India bombing, which killed all 329 people on board. Flight 182, carrying mostly Canadian citizens traveling to India to visit relatives, blew up off the coast of Ireland and plunged into the Atlantic. A second attack on an Air India flight killed two baggage handlers at a Tokyo airport. The police said the bombings were revenge by Sikh extremists for the Indian government's storming of a Sikh shrine in India.

Great grandmother of Jaclyn, Jacob, Jessica, Jennifer, Maggie and Aaron. Sister of Jessie and Murray. Graveside service 1 PM Friday, November 25 at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: TV Beyond the Tried and True
description: What were they waiting for? It's just over a month since the Apple chief executive, Steven Jobs, and Robert Iger, head of Disney, announced that they would be selling hit shows like ABC's "Lost" for viewing on the new iPod. Now it seems like every big company in the industry has come up with a nontraditional twist on delivering television shows -- a quantum leap in barely six weeks.

title: Arts, Briefly; Paintings Returned to Russia
description: Three trucks bearing precious French paintings have returned to the Pushkin State Museum of Fine Arts in Moscow, left, after being held briefly by the Swiss police in an effort by a Swiss businessman to collect a 14-year-old debt, the RIA Novosti news agency reported. Fifty-four paintings, including works by Czanne, Manet, Poussin and Renoir, had been on display at the Pierre Gianadda Foundation in Martigny, Switzerland, for five months before the businessman, Nessim D. Gaon, obtained a court order to have them confiscated. Mr. Gaon said the Russian government had reneged on loans made by his company, NOGA, which had grown from an original debt of $60 million to nearly $900 million, plus interest. The paintings were the latest Russian state property to be sought by Mr. Gaon, and their seizure prompted an outcry in Russia. Museum officials were concerned that the paintings, insured for more than $1 billion, might be damaged since the truck drivers had to turn over their keys, deactivating the climate control. Specialists are to inspect the paintings. A final delivery is expected tomorrow. SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY

title: Europe's Turn to Wrestle With Obesity
description: BRUSSELS, Nov. 23 - Europe's food industry and consumer groups are to submit ideas to the European Union on Thursday on how to confront obesity, urging clear labeling of nutritional hazards and warning against aggressive marketing to children, but also allowing food producers to regulate themselves.

title: Iran's Parliament Rejects President's 3rd Pick for Oil Post
description: TEHRAN, Nov. 23 - Iran's Parliament on Wednesday rejected President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad's third nominee for oil minister, a major defeat for the president.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIEGEL, ANN L.
description: SIEGEL--Ann L. The Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center community mourns the death of Ann L. Siegel, a committed and caring friend and a thoughtful supporter of this institution for more than a quarter century. An inspiration to all who knew her, she touched countless lives with her enthusiasm and energy. We extend heartfelt condolences to her husband, Herb, and to the entire family at this time of loss. Harold Varmus, President Douglas A. Warner III Chairman, Boards of Overseers and Managers Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

title: In Hartford, a Plea for No More Shootings
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 24 - Wind whistled through the bullet hole in the front door of 40 Vine Street, an apartment building here in the city's North End where four men began a 24-hour hunger strike at 9 a.m. Thursday. On a day devoted to eating, they decided not to -- and instead sat in a drafty lobby talking about gun violence and the shootings of five teenage boys in the neighborhood last Saturday.

Devoted mother of Thomas, and his wife Mary Alice, Frank, William and Mary Ann. Loving grandmother of Brendan, Thomas, Kelly Anne and Christopher. Dear sister of Cecelia and the late Edward. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDFARB, SEYMOUR
description: GOLDFARB--Seymour. "What a guy." Seymour passed away on Tuesday, November 22, 2005 at the age of 87. He was the oldest of five brothers, all previously deceased, and one surviving sister. Seymour served in the US Army from 1943 through 1946 as an X-ray technician. After leaving the Army he founded the Simon Agency and Finance Company; starting as a storefront in Brooklyn, it became one of the largest insurance agencies in the New York area. His career spanned 30 years. Seymour retired at 55 to Boynton Beach, FL where he was an avid tennis and golf player. His sense of humor, warmth, intelligence and kindness will be dearly missed by all who knew him. Seymour is survived by his beloved daughter, Linda, devoted sister, Ethel Sanders, and nephew, Alan Pecar, and loving and caring companion of 14 years, Suzy Saltzman. Also survived by cousins, nieces and nephews and his precious "Belle." Memorial service Sunday, November 27, 3:30 PM, 11242 Westland Circle, Boynton Beach, FL. Donations can be made to Hospice by the Sea, Boca Raton, FL. We will forever love and miss him.

title: In Deal for New Tower, Protection for Old One
description: The city's Landmarks Preservation Commission has approved the transfer of unused development rights from the venerated Seagram Building on Park Avenue to an adjacent site on Lexington Avenue that will allow for construction of a large hotel and condominium building there.

title: A Widower on a Mission, Armed With the Classics
description: When you learn that James Earl Jones is starring in a Hallmark original movie about literacy and good will, about the betterment of grim lives through Melville and Twain, fear emerges as the only sensible response. When you discover that the film was developed in partnership with the Campbell Soup Company and that Mr. Jones plays a man named Campbell, hopelessness over the ever imperiled future of free-thinking consumerism clashes with the seductive voice of Mr. Jones rising in your head, reminding you that Verizon will save you money on your long-distance cellular phone service.

title: The day the sea came
INSIDE
description: China Says Oil Company Caused Chemical Spill The Chinese government blamed the country's biggest oil company for a pollution spill that allowed a 50-mile slick of toxic benzene to reach the northern city of Harbin, with almost four million people, on the river that normally supplies it with running water. PAGE A16

title: Nostalgic for an East Village That Eludes the Big Screen
description: The first bar I ever went to in New York was a woody, grungy and completely addictive spot on the corner of Avenue B and East Seventh Street called Horseshoe Bar. Or 7B. Or, sometimes, Vazac's. The bar's name, you see, seemed to change depending on which regular you talked to: I, for example, called it U Bar, for reasons I can't remember. That was in 1988, when I was a bright-eyed drama student at New York University with big dreams of becoming the next Marlon Brando. Or Sam Shepard. Or both.

title: Palestinians Take Control of Key Border Crossing
description: RAFAH, Gaza Strip, Nov. 25 - The president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas, formally reopened the Gaza Strip's border crossing with Egypt today, giving Palestinians control over one of their frontiers for the first time.

Representatives from the Securities and Exchange Commission, the New York Stock Exchange, the New York attorney general's office, the North American Securities Administrators Association, and state regulators, were present. Only Sheriff Rosco P. Coltrane of Hazzard County seemed to be missing.

title: On-the-Job Training for Robinson at the Knicks' Point
description: The comment came in a cloud of postgame frustration and probably sounded more insulting than Coach Larry Brown intended. The Knicks had just lost to an expansion team and Brown was bemoaning the state of his backcourt when the discussion shifted to Nate Robinson, the smallish guard with the largish persona.

title: The Good, the Rare and the Nostalgic in Boxed Sets
description: In past pop eras, a disc was an album: a limited group of tracks presented in a certain order. Not anymore. The digital era has made the disc an information archive: audio, video, perhaps something interactive. Boxed sets released this year reflect that change. Along with the musical hits, misses, outtakes and second thoughts, more boxes include DVD's with something to watch: a vintage television appearance, a concert, studio moments, home movies. As storage capacity grows, it is easy to extrapolate the ultimate boxed set: one that holds every minute of a musician's career, and takes another lifetime to hear and see. For the moment, boxed sets still make choices -- luckily.

title: Sarkozy and Villepin draw battle lines over "positive discrimination"
Around the World: Chinese urban art
A New Orleans Bank Faces Mold, Ruins and Tough Choices
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 21 - At one bank branch, vandals whacked futilely at a vault with what must have been a crowbar. At another, looters worked over an outdoor cash machine, stripping its plastic molding and exposing the metal and wire innards but never reaching the stack of bills locked inside. After smashing through a glass door, the intruders took a sledgehammer to the cinderblock wall housing the bank vault. They bashed a hole large enough to crawl through--if not for the thick steel plate on the other side.

title: Joining the Red Cross and Crescent: A Red Crystal
Roundup:West Indies' Lara hits double century
Rate Rise Is Opposed in Europe
description: FRANKFURT, Nov. 24 - The European Central Bank has settled the debate over when it plans to tighten credit in Europe by signaling a rate increase next week. Yet the debate over whether the bank should do so rages on.

title: Adults Playing Children's Scary Games
description: The Los Angeles veteran Mike Kelley's latest show is a sprawling, scabrous spectacle of noisome installations and hilarious videos, occupying the whole of the cavernous Gagosian Gallery in Chelsea. Ingratiating Mr. Kelley's work never has been, nor is it now. But serious it is, in its brainy, abrasive, black-humored way, and this is by far his most ambitious and perversely entertaining effort, an attempted Gesamtkunst-werk of satanic rituals and advertising jingles mingled with allusions to Godard, German Expressionist cinema and Stockhausen.

title: Aceh can't forget the 'ghost in the sea'
A Noble With Big, and Fatal, Appetites
description: To watch Johnny Depp's titular voluptuary in "The Libertine" take a mincing step around a dead rat whisker-deep in mud is to appreciate that the life of a 17th-century hedonist was rough going, at least out of the sack. As if that rat weren't bad enough, buckets of oozing dun-colored mud inform the visual scheme as well as the tone of this aggressively unpleasant gloss on the life and bad-boy times of the second Earl of Rochester (born John Wilmot), which tracks the down-, down-, downward spiral of the satirist, poet and rake whose name became synonymous with debauchery.

description: A giant balloon in the Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade, swinging out of control in sudden bursts of wind, struck a light pole in Times Square yesterday, injuring two spectators and scaring scores of others in a replay of a 1997 accident that had prompted changes in the handling of the balloons.

title: Kingsbury Browne, Land Preserver, Dies at 82
description: Kingsbury Browne, a prominent Boston tax lawyer and outdoorsman whose initiative and knowledge of land trusts spared large and small swaths of the American landscape from headlong development, died on Nov. 11 in Kennebunk, Me. He was 82 and lived in Kennebunkport.

title: Children of Nuggets; Original Artyfacts From the Second Psychedelic Era, 1976-1995
description: Lenny Kaye's two-LP set, "Nuggets," collected mid-1960's one-hit wonders that were blasts of garage-rock on the verge of psychedelia. Released in 1972, it was activist rock criticism: a fuzz-toned counterattack against overblown 1970's rock. And it worked, stimulating both punk-rock and widespread 1960's revivalism. The revival once called the Paisley Underground -- mingling garage-rock, folk-rock and power pop -- fills this collection. It mixes long-running bands (Flamin' Groovies, the Fleshtones, the Posies, Teenage Fanclub) with side projects (XTC as the Dukes of Stratosphear) and obscurities. As on "Nuggets," the songs are terse and catchy, the equipment is vintage and distortion-happy, and the recording budgets sound minimal; girl trouble is still the perennial subject. The difference is a broad streak of self-consciousness, but it rarely takes the fun out of the songs. Rhino. Four CD's. $64.98. JON PARELES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAIZNER, HARRIET
description: MAIZNER--Harriet. Age 94, youngest daughter of Rose and Herman Weiss. Born August 20, 1911, died peacefully early in the morning on November 21, 2005. She was both the irresistible force and the immovable object: when she tilted at windmills, the windmills fell. The youngest daughter of immigrants, she used her beauty, brains and force of will to transcend a difficult childhood and made life conform to her vision and aspirations. Never bound by the strictures and regulations of others, she was a truly liberated woman long before women's lib. Working throughout her life, she was a clothes model, a successful entrepreneur, and a very savvy investor. Harriet was unstintingly generous and always there, and at her best for those in need. Once you met Harriet you never forgot her. Undaunted, undeterred and indominable, she really in the words of her favorite crooner, "did it my way". Survived by her daughters Helen Bernstein and Nancy Raskind, her son Andrew, and her beloved grandchildren Steven Bernstein, Valerie Bernstein Melony, Matthew and Brent Raskind, and Rose Maizner. We all will miss Nana's generosity, eccentric spirit and sense of humor. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to: Dorot, 171 West 85 St., New York, NY 10024. www.dorotusa.org

title: Money, politics, oil
Palestinians celebrate opening of Gaza border
Attrition and Infighting Sap Conservative Party's Power
description: Perhaps no minor party has shaped modern-day politics in New York as profoundly as the state's Conservative Party, sending a little-known candidate to the United States Senate in 1970 and helping orchestrate the defeat of a Democratic star, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, a generation later.

title: Some See Gift From the M.T.A. as an Opportunity to Cash In
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has begun handing out commuter train passes as holiday gifts, and the festive response from some recipients has been: "Hmmm. I wonder how much I could get for this."

title: The Band; A Musical History
description: The profound, rootsy, mysterious songs the Band played on its two great albums (its first two) and five worthy follow-ups were part of a longer career as collaborators and catalysts that is recognized on "A Musical History." The bulk of the set is the Band at its best, with one foot in history, the other in roadhouse. But the collection also reaches back to the group's days as the Hawks, when it made the Canadian rockabilly singer Ronnie Hawkins sound dangerous, and its breakthrough alliance with Bob Dylan, including combative live tracks from their much-booed 1966 tour and their 1974 reunion. Rare studio outtakes reveal how carefully the Band pondered its albums, while the live tracks -- including a DVD of concert and television performances -- are richly, incurably rowdy. Capitol. Five CD's. $89.98. JON PARELES

title: People: Elton John, Russell Crowe, Frida Kahlo

description: It started out as just another Chamberlain family outing, beginning at 3 a.m. in Albany, in the mist and snow.

title: Marlins' Deals Are Completed
description: The Mets made it official yesterday, acquiring first baseman Carlos Delgado and cash considerations from the Florida Marlins for first baseman Mike Jacobs and the minor leaguers Yusmeiro Petit, a right-hander, and Grant Psomas, a third baseman.

title: Down to the Bone
description: "Down to the Bone," which won a Special Jury Prize at last year's Sundance Festival, is the kind of movie most independent films strive in vain to be: a small, beautifully faceted gem. Vera Farmiga gives a pitch-perfect performance as Irene, a mother of two who works as a supermarket cashier in upstate New York. Though she appears to be a competent employee and loving wife and mother, Irene's life is precariously built around a cocaine addiction. When she finds herself trying to cash her son's birthday check to pay off her dealer, Irene decides to check herself into rehab. But an affair with a charismatic male nurse (Hugh Dillon) threatens to drag her into the even more dangerous world of heroin.

title: Little Towns of Bethlehem
description: IF you'd like to celebrate Christmas in Bethlehem, you don't have to go all the way to the West Bank. There are more than a dozen little towns of Bethlehem right here in the United States, and many of them hold Christmas celebrations that take full advantage of the biblically resonant name.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MOORE, DR. DAVID B.
description: MOORE--Dr. David B. Age 86 in Bryn Mawr, PA. Survived by his beloved wife, Barbara; loving children Eric, Melissa, and Amanda; and his six grandchildren. He was a WW II veteran of the Navy. He enjoyed a long career as a practicing obstetrician and gynecologist at Presbyterian Hospital and on the faculty at Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons, where he was revered by his patients, his students, and his colleagues. He was a member of numerous professional societies; a Professor of Obstetrics and Gynecology; a Life Trustee at Columbia; and a past President of the New York Obstetrical Society. He will be missed, and long remembered, by his devoted family, friends, and patients. Funeral will be at Brookside Cemetery Chapel, Englewood, New Jersey, Saturday November 26 at 1 PM.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: In Europe, Disagreement Continues Over Whether Interest Rates Should Rise The European Central Bank has settled the debate over when it plans to tighten credit, signaling a rate increase next week. The debate over whether it should do so rages on. The bank's president, Jean-Claude Trichet, left, has invoked the specter of rising inflation as the main reason to lift rates from 2 percent -- a level, he notes, that is historically low. Inflation in Europe is running at roughly 2.3 percent, above the bank's threshold of 2 percent. Some economists, however, forecast that it will fall back below 2 percent by next summer. [Page C1.]

title: Where Life Means Getting a Little Sand in Your Shoes
description: IF you were visiting Sanibel and Captiva Islands for the first time, you would see no evidence that they were still recovering from the devastation of Hurricane Charley, which hit this part of Florida hard in August 2004. Debris has been cleaned up and buildings newly roofed. The islands' white sand beaches, famous for their extraordinary crops of seashells, ring interiors of sturdy-looking palms, sea grapes, cactuses and wild grasses. Gnarly mangroves in swamps and lagoons camouflage the usual alligators, blubbery manatees, river otters, bobcats, loping turtles and abundant waterfowl.

title: Demolition
description: Now that it's winter outside -- wind chill in the single digits, ice and snow on the ground -- I can feel again where the cold air leaks into this house. A couple of weeks ago, I began pulling apart the walls in the oldest part of the house, the mudroom and the laundry room. What I felt, as I worked, was a forensic hostility. The laundry room, for instance, had been built around the washer and dryer, making it impossible to replace them without taking the room apart. So I took the room apart. I found what appears to be the oldest beam in the house, dating, perhaps, back to the late 18th century. I found miles and miles of BX electrical cable. And I found the cold spots, which I am slowly plugging.

title: Putin Defends Reining in Private Groups
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 24 - President Vladimir V. Putin on Thursday defended Russia's right to scrutinize any political activity by foreign and domestic charities and nongovernmental organizations, even as he promised that "civil society in Russia should not suffer."

title: The Listings | Nov. 25 - Dec. 1; ORNETTE COLEMAN QUARTET AND THE BAD PLUS
description: The alto saxophonist and composer Ornette Coleman, above, has updated the definitions of his music more than a few times since he first turned heads as the chief provocateur of 1960's free jazz. His latest bit of terminology, Sound Grammar, builds on the Harmolodic theory that he introduced in the early 1970s; it is a holistic ideal of improvised group communication that is easier to recognize than define. Mr. Coleman, above, has been enacting these principles lately with an excellent ensemble including two bassists (Tony Falanga and Greg Cohen) and a drummer (Denardo Coleman, his son). The quartet had its premiere at Carnegie Hall at the 2003 JVC Jazz Festival, with an uninterrupted concert-length whorl; returning to the same setting one year later, the band took the opposite tack, with discrete compositions as skeletal and scintillating as Zen haiku. Both concerts hinted at the way in which Mr. Coleman's aesthetic had gradually, and sometimes grudgingly, been absorbed by jazz's mainstream in recent years: Jazz at Lincoln Center has paid homage, and the Bad Plus, a puckishly unconventional piano trio (Ethan Iverson, pianist; Reid Anderson, bassist; and David King, drummer), has been earning standing ovations with an explosive rendition of Mr. Coleman's "Street Woman." The Bad Plus took part in a three-day tribute to Mr. Coleman at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis this spring, and Mr. Coleman later praised their efforts -- so it is possible that tomorrow's concert in Newark will include an intergenerational collaboration. Even if it doesn't, one suspects that, as is usually the case when Mr. Coleman performs, bridges will be crossed. (Tomorrow at 8 p.m., New Jersey Performing Arts Center, 1 Center Street, Newark, (888) 466-5722, www.njpac.org; $20 to $56.) NATE CHINEN

36 Hours in Astoria, Ore.
description: STEEPED in local history and situated a leisurely two-hour drive from Portland, the small city of Astoria, Ore., doesn't have the ticky-tacky tourist infrastructure that dominates many Pacific Coast towns. Instead, it's a quiet place, a former timber port and cannery town where huge container ships glide past on their way through the mouth of the Columbia River. That setting has always guided Astoria's destiny, from Lewis and Clark's expedition of discovery, through its years as a fur-trading and fishing outpost financed by John Jacob Astor (hence the name), to its long tenure as a working-class port. Now the city is reinventing itself as a getaway destination by capitalizing on its well-preserved Victorian architecture and rugged beauty. Oregonians are happy to spend a warm bed-and-breakfast weekend, fogbound or not, among the ghosts of Astoria's past.

title: The Million-Year Health Standard
description: The Environmental Protection Agency's proposed radiation standard for a planned nuclear waste site at Yucca Mountain in Nevada took a severe battering during a comment period that ended this week. The standard is supposed to protect future residents of the area from hazardous radiation doses for the next million years, but critics, led by the State of Nevada, skewered E.P.A.'s often sloppy justifications and complained bitterly that no other radiation standard now in force would allow the public to receive such high doses.

title: It's the Jets vs. the Saints: Helpless vs. Homeless

title: Jelly Roll Morton: The Complete Library of Congress Recordings by Alan Lomax
description: In 1938, the New Orleans pianist and composer Jelly Roll Morton talked and sang into a microphone for about a month and a half, in an oral history project conducted by Alan Lomax at the Library of Congress. He knew keenly, at that point, how powerful jazz had become -- the music that in his old days wasn't even called jazz -- and how much fame he had been denied.

title: Columbia Small Group Swing Sessions, 1953-62
description: It was the high period for jazz in New York, and a time when practically everyone who had ever played the music was still alive. Columbia Records was in a privileged position to record it, and around its bigger artists -- Louis Armstrong, Miles Davis and so on -- the producers John Hammond and George Avakian set up one session after another with other first-rate soloists of the swing era, from Ruby Braff to Buck Clayton to Illinois Jacquet, along with face-offs between Coleman Hawkins and Clark Terry, as well as Ben Webster and Sweets Edison. Twenty-two of these sessions are represented here, and many are sharply turned out, not particularly inspired evidence of the working life of jazz in the 50's. Some sessions stand out, though: a couple of Braff's, and the superb pairing of the gruff, feral Webster and the concise, gentle Edison. Available only from Mosaic: mosaicrecords.com or (203) 327-7111. Four CD's. $136. BEN RATLIFF

title: Ray Charles; The Complete Atlantic Recordings, 1952-1959
description: "I believe I done did some of everything, man, just about," Ray Charles tells Ahmet Ertegun in a formerly unreleased bit of studio dialogue from this set. Charles's pioneering 1950's recordings forged soul music from blues, jazz, country, gospel, pop and mambo. At Atlantic, the young Charles grew up fast, trading the suavity of Nat King Cole for something rawer and bluer, more cantankerous and more jubilant. He soaked up regional ideas from every place he visited; he touched down regularly in jazz and transformed any song he chose, finding sorrow and redemption. Unreleased material includes Charles toying with songs on solo piano -- it's all he needs -- and a low-fi DVD of a 1960 Newport Jazz Festival set that moves from swing-band elegance to full-tilt, house-rocking soul. Rhino. Seven CD's, one DVD. $149.98. JON PARELES

Charles Tolliver; Mosaic Select 20
description: In the 1970's, the trumpeter Charles Tolliver was a righteous force in New York straight-ahead jazz. He pushed his energy to sustain sets of long, wending tunes with his quartet, which didn't include another horn player. The music -- created in tandem with the pianist Stanley Cowell -- was based on middle-period Coltrane: dark, modal, hard-driving, springy. Mr. Tolliver released it on his own label, Strata-East, setting an early and effective example of self-reliance in the jazz business. This set collects three out-of-print albums from Strata-East from 1970 to 1973, recorded live at Slugs' in New York and at a concert hall in Tokyo, and they're hard bop with a vengeance. Available only from Mosaic: mosaicrecords.com or (203) 327-7111. Three CD's. $39. BEN RATLIFF

Bosnia, 10 Years Later
description: Anniversaries have the effect of forcing people to take stock of neglected problems. Ten years ago, an agreement cobbled together at an Air Force base near Dayton, Ohio, put an end to a brutal civil war in Bosnia. The war among Bosnian Muslims, Catholic Croats and Orthodox Serbs left 200,000 dead and millions homeless, so the agreement was hailed as a triumph. But the price of peace was to leave Bosnia a broken country of two entities and 10 cantons, with three presidents. One reason it has muddled along since then is that a lot of power is still vested in a foreign overseer backed by foreign troops.

description: Although box sets are often presented as serious scholarly enterprises (the better to justify the serious scholarly list price), most of them are quite obviously silly: real collectors already own all the obvious stuff, and novices would probably be better off just buying the best album, or a good single-disc greatest-hits compilation.

title: Seamless
description: Fashion is fabulous when you are armed with a platinum card, but down in the trenches where the stuff gets made, you will find more sweat than silk. A blazer from the cult men's wear label Cloak will set you back $1,200; an unexpected business expense of $150 amounts to a minor budgetary crisis for the man who designed it. While his hipster clientele pose and splurge, Alexandre Plokhov toils in his studio in the meatpacking district and then goes home to an empty apartment, nothing but voicemail for company.

title: 36 Hours in Astoria, Ore.
description: STEEPED in local history and situated a leisurely two-hour drive from Portland, the small city of Astoria, Ore., doesn't have the ticky-tacky tourist infrastructure that dominates many Pacific Coast towns. Instead, it's a quiet place, a former timber port and cannery town where huge container ships glide past on their way through the mouth of the Columbia River. That setting has always guided Astoria's destiny, from Lewis and Clark's expedition of discovery, through its years as a fur-trading and fishing outpost financed by John Jacob Astor (hence the name), to its long tenure as a working-class port. Now the city is reinventing itself as a getaway destination by capitalizing on its well-preserved Victorian architecture and rugged beauty. Oregonians are happy to spend a warm bed-and-breakfast weekend, fogbound or not, among the ghosts of Astoria's past.

title: Talking Heads; Brick
description: Most bands are happy to be recognized for one style and cling to it. Not Talking Heads, who changed radically for every album: from spindly bubblegum new wave ("77") through ominous multileveled funk ("Fear of Music") to countryish rock ("Little Creatures") and supple world-beat ("Naked"). As the songwriter David Byrne mellowed from quizzical, flinty outsider to jovial humanist, his band grew and shrank, the music darkened and lightened, and every phase -- especially 1977-84 -- yielded memorable songs. All eight Talking Heads studio albums are in this box, with outtakes that are often wilder than the cooler-headed, more deadpan versions chosen for posterity. The discs also include surround-sound DVD-audio remixes and rare video, for a body of work that makes arty younger bands sound timid, even without live material. Individual albums will be released separately in January; grab "Remain in Light" for its extended funk-Minimalist jams. Rhino. Eight Dualdisc CD/DVD's. $149.98. JON PARELES

description: HARD by the half-timbered, half-cultivated slopes of the Catskill foothills, the tiny village of Hobart, N.Y., perches above the ice-edged West Branch of the Delaware River, looking from a distance like a classic sleepy hill town. description: Shafts of ancient ice pulled from Antarctica's frozen depths show that for at least 650,000 years three important heat-trapping greenhouse gases never reached recent atmospheric levels caused by human activities, scientists are reporting today.

title: The Listings | Nov. 25 - Dec. 1; ASHLIE ATKINSON
description: There are two plausible explanations for why Ms. Atkinson could be cast as the title character in Neil LaBute's "Fat Pig" in 2004 and then follow that acclaimed performance by playing the ultimate sex symbol, Marilyn Monroe, in "Making Marilyn." The first is that the ideal body type of movie stars and models has slimmed down so radically in the last few decades that Monroe would now be considered too well padded. The other is that Ms. Atkinson, above, is just a wonderful actress. Certainly, her heartbreaking turn opposite Jeremy Piven last year did a beautiful job of illustrating the multiple lines of defense built up by an emotionally bruised woman before the actress, devastatingly, stripped them away. Ms. Atkinson found a romantic core to the cruel world of Mr. LaBute, and for that impressive trick she was rewarded with rave reviews and nominations for the Lucille Lortel and the Outer Critics Circle awards. As for her new piece, which runs only through Dec. 8, some may wonder if we need another play about Marilyn Monroe. (The last one, "The Marilyn Tapes," opened in October.) But this new memory play by the Canadian writer Ken Cameron, produced by the Bridge Theater Company, does not cover familiar ground. It focuses on an unlikely friendship between Monroe and a lonely teenager that develops while Monroe is filming "River of No Return" in the early 1950's. Superficially, it may seem as if Ms. Atkinson is taking on a very different part but, knowing Monroe's tragic life, don't be surprised to find that the two insecure, lonely and sensual women have more in common than you think. ("Making Marilyn" opens on Wednesday at Theater 54, 244 West 54th Street, 12th floor, Manhattan, (212) 868-4444; $15.) JASON ZINOMAN

A Country House? Let Renters Pay the Mortgage
description: KENNETH GAYLE is not the typical 28-year-old Manhattanite. Fresh out of Fordham Law School, he is not even sure he wants to practice law, but he is already mapping out a plan to retire to a wooded place in the country.

title: Try for the Sun; The Journey of Donovan
description: The much discussed (if less often heard) freak-folk revival has made indie rock stars of obscure old murmurers like Vashti Bunyan and Gary Higgins. A new boxed set attempts to share the spoils with a singularly un-obscure old murmurer: Donovan. Inside the purple velvety box (which also contains a brief documentary on DVD), you'll find a clue about the intended audience: there are tributes not only from Jimmy Page and Alice Cooper but also from indie rockers like James Mercer (of the Shins) and Devendra Banhart. And the three CD's include a well-pruned selection of Donovan's music, focusing on his marvelous late-60's run; only five of the songs here were recorded after 1973. Donovan was once caricatured as a symbol of 60's self-absorption run amok, but decades later his best hits (the grand "Sunshine Superman") and not-quite-hits (the mischievous "Clara Clairvoyant") make a gentle but unsettling noise: a mellow, mesmerizing collision between acute self-consciousness and its opposite. Sony BMG. Three CD's, one DVD. $49.98. KELEFA SANNEH

title: The Listings | Nov. 25 - Dec. 1; PEDRO RUIZ
description: Mr. Ruiz has danced everything from sleek jazz-flavored modern-dance abstractions to Columbus in his 20 years with Ballet Hispanico, which opens its 35th-anniversary season on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater. He also began a choreographic career with the company, starting in 1999 with "Guajira," a tribute to the hard-working rural women of his native Cuba. On Dec. 6 Ballet Hispanico will celebrate Mr. Ruiz, above, in his final season with the troupe. Mr. Ruiz came close to not having a career in dance at all. He had studied folk dance and classical ballet as a child in Havana and continued his training when the family moved to Venezuela. Then came another move, to the United States and New York. "I was accepted at the School of American Ballet, but I had to work," Mr. Ruiz, who is 42, recalled. "I found a job in an insecticide factory in New Jersey. They put me in a line, hammering plastic in a bottle. Lucille Ball in the chocolate factory? That happened to me." A friend introduced him to Tina Ramirez, the founder and director of Ballet Hispanico, and soon he was studying at night at the company school. Dancing lead roles from the start as a company member, the Bessie Award-winning Mr. Ruiz became known for the heart-stealing warmth and subtlety of his performing. He began to think about choreographing when he worked with the Catalan modern-dance choreographer Ramn Oller in the late 1990's at Ballet Hispanico. "He started giving me an opportunity to be spontaneous and put myself into solos," Mr. Ruiz said. In 1998, Ms. Ramirez saw and liked a duet he was working on and asked him for a full piece. Mr. Ruiz's dances for the company have ranged from "Club Havana," a sultry, stylized ballroom piece, to "Cecilia," a ballet about incest. He has also choreographed for the Luna Negra company in Chicago and will present a new work in New York in May at the TriBeCa Performing Arts Center. Dancing has taught him about himself, Mr. Ruiz said. And choreography, he added, "is a way to pass on my knowledge of my life and who I am." (Ballet Hispanico performs Tuesday through Dec. 11 at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800 or www.joyce.org) JENNIFER DUNNING

description: EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 24 - In small towns across the land, high school football is a slice of Americana served up on Thanksgiving before the pumpkin and pecan pies.

title: China Blames Oil Company for Benzene Spill in River
description: HARBIN, China, Nov. 24 - The Chinese government on Thursday blamed the country's biggest oil company for a pollution spill that allowed a 50-mile slick of toxic benzene to reach this northern city of almost four million people on the river that normally supplies it with running water.

title: Risk Management, for the Highest Stakes
description: Thomas A. Russo, the general counsel of Lehman Brothers, was working out one October morning when he got a call from Marty Evans, chairwoman of the American Red Cross and a member of Lehman's board. The two briefly discussed Lehman before shifting to New Orleans, where Ms. Evans was on the ground dealing with the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina. She said the situation was dire, but added that the effects of a bird flu pandemic would dwarf even the devastation caused by a storm like Katrina.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GELLMAN, CHARLES
description: GELLMAN--Charles. Greater New York Hospital Association (GNYHA) mourns the passing of Charles Gellman, former GNYHA Chairman and a true legend in the annals of New York health care management. From a champion boxer in his youth to a champion of Jewish Memorial Hospital to, in his retirement, a champion for the needs of former boxers, Charles was always charismatic, compassionate, and deeply committed. He was a one-of-a-kind person who helped shape New York's health care system. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Ruth and the entire Gellman family. Kenneth E. Raske President, GNYHA

title: George Best, 59, Soccer's First Pop Icon, Dies
description: George Best, an Irish soccer star who captivated the public with his flamboyant skill on the field and his playboy exploits off the field, died today in London's Cromwell Hospital of multiple organ failure, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Canada Proposes Large Aid Package for Its Lumber Industry
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 24 - In a pre-election move, the Canadian government outlined an aid package of 1.5 billion Canadian dollars ($1.3 billion) for its softwood lumber industry on Thursday, an action that may exacerbate Canada's long-running trade dispute with the United States.

title: Chinese Town Still Without Water After Toxic Spill
description: HARBIN, China, Nov. 25 - A toxic 50-mile slick of contaminated river water slowly washed through this frigid provincial capital today, leaving schools and many businesses closed, forcing millions of people to spend a third consecutive day without running water and raising fears of a long-term environmental disaster.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday on Russian legislation to impose new controls on charities and other nongovernmental agencies misspelled the surname of the Ford Foundation's representative in Moscow. He is Steven Solnick, not Solnik.

title: County Executive Sticks to What He Knows
description: WHITE PLAINS - AFTER cruising to victory for a third time as Westchester County executive, Andrew J. Spano, a Democrat in an increasingly Democratic county, a man whom even detractors call "decent" and "charming," seemed at peace.

Correction
description: An article last Friday about the decline of gay-only inns in Key West misstated the origin of the annual Fantasy Fest there. It began in 1979 as an effort by businesses to promote tourism. It was not an AIDS fundraiser.

title: Iraqi Official Says He Received Call From Resistance Leader
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 25 - A senior aide to Iraq's president said today that some insurgent groups had contacted him to discuss joining in the American-backed political process.

The Listings | Nov. 25 - Dec. 1
description: Selective listings by critics of The New York Times of new and noteworthy cultural events in the New York metropolitan region this week.

title: Op-Art; Bright Lights, Slick City
description: A gala black-tie Madison Square Garden benefit performance of "The Iceman Cometh Follies," America's first Eugene O'Neill musical on ice, recently kicked off fund-raising for a renaissance of outdoor skating in New York City. A new temporary venue in Bryant Park has already joined the long-established Wollman and Rockefeller Center rinks this winter to serve Manhattan's skating throngs. Critics' charges of a mere election-year sop notwithstanding, the city's new Department of Fun is busily considering other possible

title: The World of Warhol (Children Are Welcome)
description: The World of Warhol (Children Are Welcome)

title: W.T.O. Chief Won't Count on Consensus
description: HONG KONG, Nov. 23 - Just before Christmas in 1991, Arthur Dunkel distributed what by international trade standards was a radical document.

title: Arts, Briefly; Borat Responds
description: The threat of legal action from the government of Kazakhstan has not deterred the British comedian Sacha Baron Cohen from ridiculing that Central Asian country. Mr. Baron Cohen provoked the anger of Kazakhstan's foreign ministry last week after serving as the host of an MTV Europe awards show in character as Borat Sagdiyev, above, a boorish Kazakh television correspondent who portrays the country as a backward place where women are fifth in the natural pecking order, below horses and dogs. In a video response posted late Wednesday to his Web site for the character, www.borat.kz, Mr. Baron Cohen, appearing as Borat, teased that "Kazakhstan is as civilized as any other country in the world. Women can now travel on inside of bus, homosexuals no longer have to wear blue hats and age of consent has been raised to 8 years old." Representatives at the Kazakh Embassy in Washington could not be reached for comment. JOEL TOPCIK

title: Tommy Dorsey; The Sentimental Gentleman of Swing: Centennial Collection
description: History remembers Tommy Dorsey more for the starchy professionalism of his orchestra than for the measured croon of his trombone playing, although the two things are more or less inextricable. This compilation takes aim at that small injustice, devoting the first of its three discs to Dorsey's sideman work with the likes of Paul Whiteman, Ethel Waters and the Boswell Sisters. The parade of early performances is often intriguing, but it inevitably pales next to the Dorsey Orchestra material that follows. The band sounds especially vital on the third disc, an assortment of radio air checks that benefits greatly from the sterling contribution of Frank Sinatra. (Legacy has also recently issued a strong two-disc compilation, "The Essential Frank Sinatra and Tommy Dorsey.") Another contributor, Elvis Presley, sits in with "Heartbreak Hotel" -- the only inclusion from the 1950's, and a mismatch that closes the set on a note of mild embarrassment. Bluebird/Legacy. Three CD's. $39.98. NATE CHINEN

title: A Bayou Thanksgiving, With the Queen of Sheba
description: SLIDELL, La., Nov. 24 - There was never going to be a traditional Thanksgiving on Salt Bayou, not after Hurricane Katrina picked up Liz LaBue's house and pushed it across U.S. 11 as if it were a stalled car.

title: Melancholy No More, Dayne Runs Wild
description: IRVING, Tex., Nov. 24 - The Heisman Trophy came years ago, and the aura that surrounded it had faded long before Ron Dayne arrived in Denver this year after five seasons with the Giants.

title: Political Donations, Bribery and the Portrayal of a Nexus
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 - The American system of underwriting political campaigns is often derided as legalized bribery. Now the Justice Department is contending that it can amount to illegal bribery as well.

title: Suicide Bombing in Iraq Kills 30 and Wounds Dozens
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 24 - A suicide car bomb exploded Thursday near an American convoy at the entrance to the main hospital in the volatile town of Mahmudiya, killing at least 30 Iraqis and wounding dozens of others in a burst of fire and shrapnel.

title: The Neediest Cases; On 48th Try at Rehabilitation, an Alcoholic and Addict Finally Meets With Success
description: Douglas Moye, 44, talks about the 47 other times he has found himself in an alcohol detoxification program, and why, on the 48th try, something began to sink in.

title: The Good, the Rare and the Nostalgic in Boxed Sets
description: Correction Appended

title: Olivier
Arts, Briefly; Good Week for Nickelodeon
description: In the advertiser-supported cable rankings for the week that ended last Sunday, 16 of the 24 most popular shows were on Nickelodeon. An episode of "SpongeBob SquarePants" drew the largest audience of the Nickelodeon shows, 4.26 million viewers, and ranked No. 6. Ahead of it were ESPN's Sunday football game (6.81 million), two episodes of "WWE Monday Night Raw" on USA (5.72 million and 5.51 million), ESPN's Saturday college football (4.68 million) and MTV's "Laguna Beach" season finale (4.34 million). In Nickelodeon's 6-to-11 and 2-to-11 demographic targets, the channel dominated the list. An episode of "Jimmy Neutron" on Nov. 18 was the top-ranked show among children 6 to 11; a "Fairly OddParents" on Sunday won in the 2-to-11 group. But in the teenage demographic, "Laguna Beach" placed first by a wide margin. An audience of 1.38 million 12- to 17-year-olds watched the formerly hard-hearted Kristin, the show's lead, turn to mush when faced with leaving Laguna and all her friends as the summer ended. KATE AURTHUR

title: Far From Home and Far From Settled
description: POINT LOOKOUT, N.Y., Nov. 23 - The six Louisianans lingered over their hot chocolates and coffees after breakfast at a Long Island diner on the morning before Thanksgiving. They had a long list of things to do, but nowhere really to go.

title: Heaven Must Have Sent You; The Holland/Dozier/Holland Story
description: This is one of those sets that might help even knowledgeable listeners think about the music in a slightly different way. Many of the songs here are familiar, some hugely so: anyone with even a passing interest in soul music has probably memorized chestnuts like Freda Payne's "Band of Gold" and the Supremes' "Stop! In the Name of Love." But these three discs spotlight not the singers but the songwriters: Eddie Holland, his younger brother Brian, and their partner Lamont Dozier, who churned out an astonishing number of Motown classics (and sang a handful, too). The three had a knack for writing buoyant melodies that only hinted at melancholy and lyrics that emphasized a particular sort of heartache: not the feeling of love's absence but the feeling of its overabundance. Part of the fun of this set is hearing that spirit echoed in recordings by such a wide variety of performers, from Dusty Springfield to Michael Jackson to the Band. The only gripe is the liner notes, which trace the trio's biographies without ever explaining how, exactly, they did what they did. Hip-O/Universal. Three CD's. $39.98. KELEFA SANNEH

title: Picking up wherethe Soviets left off
THE CHURN
description: Deal Makers

title: European Shares Fall in Tandem With World Markets
description: European shares paced declines by stocks worldwide yesterday after a measure of German business confidence fell more than economists had predicted. DaimlerChrysler and Siemens were among the shares that fell.

title: Thatched Irish Roofs Are Falling Down
description: DONABATE, Ireland - Seamus Heaney, enthralled with the work of a roof thatcher, wrote that the man worked for days above the rafters, "pinning down his world, handful by handful. And left them gaping at his Midas touch."

description: Events

Investing: Defying gravity
