title: Prisoner Is Released Despite Evidence of Role in Bombing
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 - In January, American military and law enforcement personnel discovered evidence connecting a 25-year-old Iraqi detainee, Abass Hussein Alwan al-Amry, to a roadside bomb that had detonated in Baghdad, wounding several Iraqis.

title: Chatterin the skies
Progressions; 100 Years of Jazz Guitar
description: Spanning a full century of recordings, this survey puts forth almost a century-long chronology of jazz guitar, and with it an appealingly skewed take on jazz history. Its principles are canonical, but anti-purist (a couple of Depression-era Hawaiian guitarists make the grade, as do Jimi Hendrix and Carlos Santana), and its process strictly egalitarian: each of the 78 guitarists included makes only one appearance, with a recording identified as somehow emblematic. This policy creates some strange imbalances, although there's a refreshing justice in John Scofield, one of the set's producers, receiving the same track allotment as, say, the obscure swing player Otto (Coco) Heimel. A glossy and informative booklet, with several solo transcriptions, underscores the package's target audience. One only hopes that not every guitarist who picks up the set will fall for the title's promise of linear evolution, a notion that the music undermines repeatedly. Columbia/Legacy. Four CD's. $49.98. NATE CHINEN

title: Whatever; The 90's Pop & Culture Box
description: Wrapping this boxed set in coffee beans and calling it "Whatever" effectively conjures the 90's image of the knit-capped Northwestern cafe slacker. This seven-CD collection prefers the music of that milieu -- the "alternative rock" of the decade's first half -- over the hip-hop, alt-country, electronica, rap-rock and teen-pop that also provided the soundtrack for the span from Nirvana to Y2K. Unfortunately, grunge dominates, with Tad, Mudhoney and Screaming Trees crowding out hip-hop beyond novelties like "O.P.P." and "They Want EFX." Oddly, the Northwestern stalwarts Sleater-Kinney and Mudhoney are represented by second-rate songs, though the box does right by grunge knockoffs like Bush and Stone Temple Pilots. Thankfully, there are happy glimpses of postalternative quirkiness that briefly passed as mainstream pop, like the Cardigans' "Lovefool," Fountains of Wayne's "Radiation Vibe" and Len's "Steal My Sunshine." But this overview may not sound like the 90's to anyone who followed electronic music beyond the Sneaker Pimps, alt-country past Wilco or hip-hop deeper than "Whoomp! (There It Is)." Rhino. Seven CD's. $105.98. LAURA SINAGRA

title: Fire in Brooklyn Injures Four
description: At least four people, including a city firefighter, were seriously injured early yesterday in a blaze at an apartment building in Brooklyn that forced a 16-year-old girl to jump out of a third-floor window, the authorities and residents said.

title: Europeans Rebuke Israeli Jerusalem Policy
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 24 - The European Union's diplomatic representatives in East Jerusalem and Ramallah have sharply criticized Israel's policies in East Jerusalem, saying they "are reducing the possibility of reaching a final-status agreement on Jerusalem that any Palestinian could accept."

title: Microsoft Ups the Console Ante
description: There is a saying in technology circles, often delivered with rueful respect, that if you give the folks at Microsoft enough chances, they will eventually deliver a compelling product. They did it with spreadsheets. They did it with Web browsers. And now, with the new Xbox 360, the Bill Gates team has delivered a legitimately excellent gaming and home media system. And there is nothing rueful about that.

title: One Kiss Can Lead to Another: Girl Group Sounds Lost and Found
description: The biggest girl-group hits aren't on this collection; try Rhino's "Girl Group Greats" and "The Best of the Girl Groups" (Vols. 1 and 2), or greatest-hits albums by the Crystals, the Ronettes, the Shirelles and the Supremes. These four discs are filled with also-rans, and without the glow of oldies nostalgia, they're more revealing now than when they were recorded four decades ago.

title: How to Botch a Share Sale, French Style
description: FRENCH investors take hope. Maybe the Socialists will bail you out of your folly and buy back the shares you so eagerly purchased.

title: European Soccer: 3 clubs gain UEFA Cup's final 32
The Propensity for Intensity Is Still His Style
description: GLENDALE, Ariz. - More than a month into his first season as an N.H.L. coach, Wayne Gretzky said, he is asked most often whether he has the urge to jump over the boards. Gretzky, the greatest offensive player in the history of the game, is coaching one of the league's most offensively challenged teams, the Phoenix Coyotes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JAEGER, PATRICIA
description: JAEGER--Patricia. Born in Lynbrook, NY in 1925. Beloved mother of Richard, Leslie, Keith and Jan. Devoted grandmother to Sean, Max, Laura and Joanna. Dear sister to Richard Maher and Kathleen Davis. Contributions to the Coalition for the Homeless appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANK, GLORIA
description: FRANK--Gloria. Died on Monday, November 21, 2005. Beloved mother of Laura Jeanne (Steven), beloved wife of Martin Schickler. Great friend to many, a humanitarian for many great causes and she will be deeply missed. Funeral services will be held Sunday, November 27 at 10 AM at "The Riverside Memorial Chapel", 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY 10023. 212-362-6600.

title: Buddha Machine
description: Who says a boxed set has to include CD's? "Buddha Machine" is, literally, a small plastic box with a built-in speaker, a headphone jack and a little switch you use to toggle between nine different and quite lovely ambient electronic compositions. It's the product of FM3 (www.fm3.com.cn), the Beijing-based duo of Christiaan Virant (who compiled the recent Sublime Frequencies CD "Radio Pyongyang") and Zhang Jian. The members say their device is a modified version of a popular Chinese gadget that intones Buddhist prayers; this new model is a weird, mesmerizing, beautifully useless thing. Available in the United States through forcedexposure.com. $23. KELEFA SANNEH

title: The real problemwith statistics
Saints Pray That Help Is on Its Way
description: The ideas sounded good in theory. The N.F.L. would give the New Orleans Saints extra money to entice the team's free agents to stick with the Saints while their future was in flux in the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina. There would be bonuses and other extras, and the league would try to eliminate as much uncertainty as possible by announcing the Saints' 2006 schedule early in the off-season.

title: My Lives; Billy Joel
description: After more than three decades, it's easy to imagine that we've experienced all of Billy Joel's moods and incarnations: Tin Pan Alley piano man, bridge-and-tunnel striver, muscular balladeer, headline historian, Broadway dance inspiration, classical dabbler. But a new sweetness emerges with "My Lives," four CD's and a DVD of clips from a 1994 Frankfurt show. Starting with youthful forays into folk, British Invasion pop and jazz-rock, the set mingles demos with the hits they later became, candidly exposing clunky scrapped lyrics that accompanied budding melodicism. Even if some covers showcase Mr. Joel's taste rather than his talents (Brian Wilson works well; Bob Dylan not so much), "My Lives" is sequenced for listeners, not archivists. A loose-limbed live version of the goofy tough-guy proclamation "I Go to Extremes" finds Mr. Joel at his least chameleonic. After Disc Four's vigorous live run through hits like "Goodnight Saigon" and "Movin' Out," you almost owe him a spin through the set's final classical numbers. Columbia. Four CD's, one DVD. 59.98. LAURA SINAGRA

title: Spotlight: Capitalizing on change
At Eclectic Zankel Hall, One Thing Rarely Varies
description: Two and a half seasons into the life of Zankel Hall, the evidence is in. One of the newest auditoriums in New York, built into the bedrock below Carnegie Hall, has added a dose of richness to the concert scene.

title: Staten Island Man Finds Body
description: A body found in the woods on Staten Island yesterday may be that of a man who has been missing for two months, his family said. The body was discovered by the man's father, who since the disappearance had relentlessly searched areas frequented by his son, investigators said.

title: Off the Charts: Golden comparison
NFL: Broncos halt Cowboys in OT, 24-21
Bill Evans; The Complete Village Vanguard Recordings, 1961
description: Two great albums were picked from the recordings of these five sets during one single afternoon-into-evening at the Vanguard -- "Sunday at the Village Vanguard" and "Waltz for Debby." But if you've heard those, you will understand why you might want whatever else there might be, and in the order they really unfolded, to replicate that day. Bill Evans's chords, nearly all fascinating and unmoored by the expected root notes, motored along in muted drift. No single statement sounds complete; he's always gesturing ahead toward what's to come. His trio, with the bassist Scott LaFaro and the drummer Paul Motian, was operating at its peak: bass and drums working around and sometimes above the piano, not just beneath it; everyone melodically improvising. The set was released in Japan in 2003 and last year in Europe, but it's new to the American market. With the remastering, both the music -- particularly Mr. Motian's cymbals -- and the low crowd rumble are clearer. At one point there is a minute and 43 seconds of milling about. ("You want some ice in that?" "I'm gonna run out and go get something to eat." "I'll come with ya.") It's all of a piece. Fantasy. Three CD's. $29.98. BEN RATLIFF

title: Placing Ads in Some Surprising Spaces
description: THE parade of mainstream advertisers starting to use nontraditional media is growing almost as long as that march through Manhattan yesterday sponsored by a certain department store.

title: Such Sound and Fury! Tradition! Einsteins in Food Fight of Words
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 24 - The international law expert declared hamantaschen a violation of the Geneva Conventions, symbolizing the eating of an ancient enemy. But the linguistics professor, posing as Plato, said Hermogenes, a k a hamantasch, "clearly had the better idea" than Cratylus, stand-in for latkes.

title: Johnny Cash; The Legend
description: The somber-voiced country singer Johnny Cash was almost a mythological figure during his lifetime; two years after his death, his legend has assumed Mount Rushmore proportions. Yet, as the biopic "Walk the Line" asserts, the Cash mystique had as much to do with human fallibility as with faith and redemption. That might explain why the deluxe version of this set feels so formal, despite an abundance of snapshots, testimonials and scrapbook reproductions: it captures the legend better than the man. The musical selection on both editions is unassailable, although most of it has already been thoughtfully repackaged in recent years. Previously unreleased material -- including, in the deluxe edition, an early radio broadcast and a DVD with highlights from a 1980 CBS special -- reinforces Cash's workmanlike professionalism, which is no small thing. But for a more intimate portrayal, turn to the 2003 collection "Unearthed" (American Recordings), which undercuts its monumentalizing tendencies with a chilling mortal clarity. Columbia/Legacy. Five CD's, one DVD and a limited-edition coffee-table book. $199.98. (Also available as just four CD's. $39.98.) NATE CHINEN

title: EU critical of Israelis on East Jerusalem
So Just Keep the Faith in That Little Red String
description: Toward the end of "Kabbalah," a dreadful, mind-numbing show presented by the Jewish Theater of New York, the character of Madonna threatens to call in her lawyers. The real Madonna may want to consider that advice.

title: Looking for the real 1968 revolution
A Widower on a Mission, Armed With the Classics
description: When you learn that James Earl Jones is starring in a Hallmark original movie about literacy and good will, about the betterment of grim lives through Melville and Twain, fear emerges as the only sensible response. When you discover that the film was developed in partnership with the Campbell Soup Company and that Mr. Jones plays a man named Campbell, hopelessness over the ever imperiled future of free-thinking consumerism clashes with the seductive voice of Mr. Jones rising in your head, reminding you that Verizon will save you money on your long-distance cellular phone service.

title: My Big Fat Independent Movie
description: "My Big Fat Independent Movie" is a frenetic attempt to spoof every major art-house film of the last decade. Loosely framed by a goofy narrative featuring two hit men, an amnesiac and a kidnapped salesgirl, the movie tries to skewer every clich in the Sundance playbook, from self-conscious camera angles to irrelevant lesbian interaction. The dialogue is often sharp ("We're going to forge an unlikely bond," explains one hit man when asked what he plans to do with his kidnapping victim), and the pace is relentless, but as our antiheroes navigate a "Reservoir Dogs"-style torture scene and dodge various "falling symbolic devices," the hyperactive style and uneven performances begin to grate. By the time the dwarf appears, the movie has worn itself out.

title: Indonesia to produce Tamiflu
Baseball: Cost-cutting Marlins complete trade of 4 key players
Jazz in Paris; Champs-lyses/Montmartre/Saint-Germain-des-Prs/Rive Gauche, Rive Droite
description: Universal France has combed through its archives to lay out a selected history of a recorded jazz in France up to the early 1960's. Francophiles will be interested in the subject tout court -- the music as well as the pictures and booklet commentary (in English and French) put some documentary truth behind the legends of an urbane, foreign Eden for jazz culture. The recordings go back to Josephine Baker, Jean Cocteau reading poetry over Dan Parrish's jazz orchestra in 1929, and Django Reinhardt, extending all the way up to the early 60's with the Algerian-born pianists Errol Parker and Martial Solal. But Americans abroad are more than equally represented: Benny Carter, Don Byas, Lucky Thompson, Miles Davis and Chet Baker among them, playing with the cream of the French musicians. Gitanes/Verve. Four boxed volumes of three CD's each. $30 per volume. BEN RATLIFF

title: Atomic Agency Delays Action on Iran
description: VIENNA, Nov. 24 - The International Atomic Energy Agency delayed taking any action on Iran's nuclear program on Thursday, even as the British delegate, speaking for Europe, said that a process described in documents offered to Iran, which came to light last week, "has no other application other than the production of nuclear warheads."

title: Briefly: Council of Europe starts inquiry on terror claims

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIEGEL, ANN L.
description: SIEGEL--Ann L. The Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center community mourns the death of Ann L. Siegel, a committed and caring friend and a thoughtful supporter of this institution for more than a quarter century. An inspiration to all who knew her, she touched countless lives with her enthusiasm and energy. We extend heartfelt condolences to her husband, Herb, and to the entire family at this time of loss. Harold Varmus, President Douglas A. Warner III Chairman, Boards of Overseers and Managers Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

title: It's stingray, dahling!
This Year, Running Champ Lacks Element of Surprise

So when Aislinn Ryan returned to Warwick Valley High School last year after winning the national high school cross-country championship, she was unprepared for the welcome that awaited her.

title: Korean Leaves Cloning Center in Ethics Furor
description: TOKYO, Nov. 24 - The South Korean researcher who won world acclaim as the first scientist to clone a human embryo and extract stem cells from it apologized Thursday for lying over the sources of some human eggs used in his work and stepped down as director of a new research center.

description: ROME, Nov. 24 - The United States intends to close one of its two foreign naval bases that service nuclear submarines, a Navy spokesman confirmed Thursday.

description: ROBERTS--Alfred B. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Alfred B. Roberts, associated with The Times from February 1961 until retiring in September 1991.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JONES, ROY H. JR., MD
description: JONES--Roy H. Jr., MD, was born December 4, 1930 in Washington DC. He was the only child born to Edna and Roy Jones. Roy attended high school at Boys High School in Brooklyn, NY and went to College at the City College of New York in New York City. He then pursued his Doctor of Dental Surgery degree at Howard University in Washington, DC. After graduation he received a commission from the Army Dental Corps, as a Captain, where he was stationed in Orleans, France and Fort Dix, New Jersey. While stationed in France he married Anne Greene from Murfreesboro, Tennessee on the 8th August 1958. After leaving the military in 1963 he completed a residency in anesthesiology at the Jewish Chronic Disease Hospital in Brooklyn, New York. He later pursued a clinical professorship at the New York Medical College as the Director of the Dental Clinic. Prior to retiring to Lawrenceville, Georgia in 1995 Roy maintained a private dental practice for many years in Mt. Kisco, New York. He is survived by his wife Anne E. Jones of Lawrenceville, GA, his eldest son Roy Jones III and his wife Tamara of Northbrook, IL and their children Natalie and Nicholas. A daughter, Faun M. Branch of Loganville, GA and her son Xavier and his other son Peter S. Jones of London, England. In lieu of flowers send donations to Howard University Dental School at www.howard.edu

title: Imperfect Day Doesn't Derail Perfect Record
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Nov. 25 - As quarterback Vince Young slowly exited Kyle Field after Texas' 40-29 victory against Texas A&M, a crush of Longhorns fans mobbed him in the end zone.

title: Arts, Briefly; Jolie Visits Pakistan
description: Angelina Jolie, left, the actress and good-will ambassador for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, traveled to Pakistan this week to visit survivors of the Oct. 8 earthquake and to urge speedy delivery of promised international aid as winter approaches. She surveyed devastated regions in northern Pakistan on Thursday with the actor Brad Pitt and spoke yesterday at a news conference in Islamabad. "There are so many wonderful pledges of money that could come in the next few years," she said, according to news reports. "But this winter is in the next few weeks, and so many people are in danger of possibly freezing to death." Ms. Jolie, who has adopted children from Cambodia and Africa, also warned against hasty adoptions of children orphaned by the quake. "When there has been a disaster or war situation," she said, "you are still hoping to locate families; you don't exactly know the situation." She added, "People sometimes jump in."

title: Caring for Parents at the End of Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Dawn Rush Hints at Strong Start to Holiday Sales
description: At 12:05 a.m. yesterday, moments into the earliest store opening on the busiest shopping day of the year, the beleaguered employees at the CompUSA on 57th Street in Manhattan laid down some ground rules: no more pushing and no more grabbing deeply discounted merchandise out of the hands of other customers.

title: Small Leak at Indian Point Eludes Diver and Cameras
description: BUCHANAN, N.Y. - A drop of radioactive water leaks every minute from the pool that stores the spent fuel rods at Indian Point 2 here. The water is captured in a plastic sheet and then channeled into a plastic bottle for disposal. It adds up to a quart or two a day.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 2,093 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Wireless Moves the Cash Register Where You Are
description: When Michelle Dub, a golf instructor in Rancho Santa Margarita, Calif., finishes a lesson, she whips out her BlackBerry wireless device -- to schedule the next appointment, sure, but also to swipe the student's credit card for payment right there on the driving range.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUTHERFORD, WILLIAM A., SR.
description: RUTHERFORD--William A., Sr. The Trustees and staff of the Storm King Art Center express profound sorrow at the loss of their dear friend and landscape architect since the Art Center's inception in 1960. Over the years his vision and creativity guided the shaping of our landscape and its integration with our sculptures. Our heartfelt condolences go to his beloved wife Joyce and his family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, MICHAEL M.
description: COHEN--Michael M. November 23, 2005. Born 1912 in Brooklyn. Former General Counsel NYC Housing Authority. Wonderful husband, father, grandfather, brother and uncle. Lover of libraries, museums, movies and martinis. Mike's intelligence, humor and spirit inspired everyone he met. Services Sunday 11:30 AM at "The Riverside", 76th and Amsterdam Ave. Donations to The Democratic Party. We love you, Mike!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVINE, EDWARD J.
description: LEVINE--Edward J. Passed away November 24, 2005. Services Sunday, November 27, 2PM, Parkside Chapel, Flatbush Ave. at Ave V.

title: Spirit of Thanksgiving
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VENTURA, VINCENT J.
description: VENTURA--Vincent J. July 13, 1915--November 23, 2005. Loving husband of the late Anastasia Ventura. Survived by daughter and son-in-law, Annette and Daniel Hayde; son and daughter-in-law Anthony and Lucy Ventura; granddaughter and grandson-in-law Stacey and Paul Stapleton; great - grandson Austin. Visiting at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave. at E. 81 St. Saturday and Sunday, 25pm and 7-9pm. Mass at St. Joseph's Church of Yorkville, Monday, 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Fresh Air Fund, 633 3rd Ave., 14th Flr, NY NY 10017.

title: U.S. Skiers Aim for Another Strong Season
description: LAKE LOUISE, Alberta, Nov. 25 - The head coach of the Austrian men's ski team is not worried these days. Sitting for an interview this week on the top floor of a palatial hotel in Banff National Park, Toni Giger could not even say which nation finished second behind his last year in the Alpine skiing World Cup.

title: Designer of Supercomputers Leaves Cray to Join Microsoft
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 25 - Burton Smith, a longtime supercomputer designer and chief scientist at Cray, has resigned to take a position at Microsoft.

title: Barrett's Eye Keeps Him Out
description: A poke in the eye will keep David Barrett, a starting cornerback for the Jets, sidelined for a third consecutive game. He sustained the injury Nov. 6 against the Chargers, and has been unable to practice.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 7 P.M. (Cinemax) THE THIN RED LINE (1998). With "The New World," Terrence Malick's fifth film in 36 years, scheduled to open on Christmas Day, this is a good time to look at his last one. The story is set at and around the Battle of Guadalcanal. The almost-all-male cast includes Sean Penn, Adrien Brody, Jim Caviezel, George Clooney, Woody Harrelson, John Cusack, Ben Chaplin, Jared Leto, Nick Nolte and John C. Reilly. Reviews were mixed, but Mr. Malick (above) was named best director by the New York Film Critics Circle.

title: Love, Neruda and the Mezzo Who Returned to the Spotlight
description: BOSTON, Nov. 25 - The mezzo-soprano Lorraine Hunt Lieberson has a special relationship with Boston. It was from this city that she emerged as an artist, first as a valuable freelance string player and then as a splendid singer. So you can understand why the audience at Symphony Hall on Friday afternoon was eager to hear her perform "Neruda Songs," a new work written by her husband, Peter Lieberson, with the Boston Symphony Orchestra conducted by James Levine.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "For an outsider, this must seem nuts. But for us, it's perfectly natural."

title: Panel Created to Examine How Balloon Went Awry
description: Correction Appended

title: A Whitebait Feast Begins With a Cast Net
description: One of the rewards of growing old is rediscovering pleasurable endeavors long neglected. My latest such experience involved capturing and devouring whitebait.

title: World War II, Refracted Through an Anxious Lullaby
description: A lullaby is not a bad way to remember the bombing of Dresden 60 years ago. The justifiable anger from both sides of World War II will never really go away, but after so much time those terrible events have become cool enough to the touch to pick up and examine with a little less pain.

title: The Thrill of Video Games, Applied to School
description: To the Editor:

title: Telling Tale of Afghan Wars by Any Means Necessary
description: What do we want from political theater, the kind that lays bare the social realities we are shielded -- or shield ourselves -- from?

title: Union Steps Up Drive to Organize Starbucks
description: Correction Appended

title: Out of the Sea and Into the Oven
description: The fish that go into whitebait -- silversides and sand eels -- are eaten whole and ungutted. Reject specimens more than 2 3/4 inches long. Whitebait is best eaten the day the fish are caught, but a day or two in the refrigerator before cooking does little harm.

title: Venezuela's Leader to Send Heating Oil to South Bronx
description: A group of South Bronx residents will soon receive a large -- and inexpensive -- shipment of heating oil, courtesy of President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela, a frequent thorn in the side of the Bush administration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DE WILDE, EDY
description: DE WILDE--Edy. We note with sorrow the passing of Edy de Wilde, extraordinary long-term director of the Stedelijk Museum, Amsterdam; friend of many contemporary artists; and a founding member of our board of directors. He was a man of unusual intelligence and courtesy. We offer our sympathy to his wife Nono Reinhold and to the family. The Greenwich Collection, Ltd.

title: The Deadly Shot
description: Millions of people in poor countries get sick and die from a common tool for getting well: the hypodermic syringe. In some countries, most injections are done with needles that are reused without sterilization. Twenty-one million people each year get hepatitis B this way, two million get hepatitis C and 650,000 get infected with H.I.V.

title: George Best, Soccer Star and Pop Icon, Is Dead at 59
description: George Best, an Irish soccer star who captivated the public with his flamboyant skill on the field and his playboy exploits off it, died yesterday in London after a long struggle with alcohol abuse. He was 59.

title: Battle Lines Set as New York Acts to Cut Emissions
description: ALBANY, Nov. 23 - New York is adopting California's ambitious new regulations aimed at cutting automotive emissions of global warming gases, touching off a battle over rules that would sharply reduce carbon dioxide emissions while forcing the auto industry to make vehicles more energy efficient over the next decade.

title: A Dispute of Great Spirit Rages On
description: GRAND FORKS, N.D. - Embedded in the granite floor inside the main entrance to Ralph Engelstad Arena, an enormous American Indian-head logo spreads like a welcome mat in front of the larger-than-life statue of Engelstad himself.

title: Images of the Great Beyond, No Reality Check Required
description: In 1515 the German artist Albrecht Drer made a woodcut of a rhinoceros, an ominous-looking creature with a sharply pointed horn on its snout. It wore a duded-up suit of armor from which emerged four scaly legs with cloven feet. Drer had never seen the real thing; neither had most other Europeans.

title: A Revolutionary Channels His Inner Michael Moore
description: TEHRAN - FOR years, Massoud Dehnamaki was known widely as the feared enforcer of conservative rules that restricted freedom for women and society.

title: Busy Mets Are Waiting for Wagner to Decide
description: Omar Minaya had just returned from a walk along the beach in Punta Cana, Dominican Republic, where, for the second consecutive year, he spent Thanksgiving doing business. Last year, he ate dinner with Pedro Martnez. This year, he finalized details with Marlins executives to acquire first baseman Carlos Delgado for Mike Jacobs and two prospects.

title: Austria Refuses Bail to Briton Accused of Denying Holocaust
description: VIENNA, Nov. 25 - An Austrian judge on Friday denied a request for bail for the British historian David Irving, who is accused of violating the country's laws against denying the Holocaust.

title: World Briefing | Mideast: Egypt: Crackdown On Islamists
description: Egypt arrested 20 members of the largest Islamic opposition group, the Muslim Brotherhood, a day before the runoff in the second round of legislative elections, an Alexandria spokesman for the banned group said. The arrests were seen as an attempt to curb the group's successes in two rounds of the three-stage election. It has gained 47 seats this year, compared with 17 in 2000. Abeer Allam (NYT)

title: Seeks Love and a Guarantee
description: It almost seems a conspiracy against singles that the holidays come as days get shorter and nights longer, so very much longer. For those who find themselves singing the lyric "One is the loneliest number," nature should by all rights come to the rescue. But sometimes prodding is in order. And so singles try dating services that dangle a chance for happiness, at a price.

title: Christopher Durang Explores the Afterlife, Including His Own
description: In Christopher Durang's farcical new play, "Miss Witherspoon," the middle-aged woman of the title commits suicide as a delayed reaction to the Skylab space station's falling to earth. She wakes up in the bardo, the place where a soul awaits reincarnation in Tibetan Buddhism. The character Veronica (Kristine Nielsen) does not want to be reincarnated: "Why can't I just be left alone to fester and brood in my bodiless spirit state?"

title: An Architect Cuts Corners, and Shakes Japan's Faith
description: TOKYO, Nov. 25 - No buildings have collapsed, yet. No one has been hurt. But the case of the architect caught cheating on earthquake building codes has transfixed Japan.

title: The Neediest Cases; New Start in America Is Marred by Son's Tragic Fall
description: On a Friday earlier this month, Kateryna Komarovskyy walked down a hospital corridor, her eyes moist with tears. She said a collective hello to the staff, entered a room, squeezed some sanitizing liquid on her hands and walked over to her son.

title: In a Shadowy Nightmare, Fear Is a Dead Certainty
description: The Successor By Ismail Kadare 207 pages. Arcade Publishing. $24.

title: Arts, Briefly; Jewish Culture in Berlin
description: A performance tomorrow of Brecht and Weill's "Mahagonny Songspiel" will open the annual Jewish festival in Berlin, which has a Roaring Twenties theme this year. The two-week festival, called Jewish Cultural Days, features plays, concerts, dancing and art exhibitions, ranging from a performance on Monday of "Tangele," a Yiddish tango, to the "Long Night of Synagogues" next Saturday, with concerts and presentations throughout Berlin. For the first time since it began in 1987, the festival will have its own central location, behind the New Synagogue on Oranienburger Strasse, above. "Today, Jewish life and Jewish culture are blossoming again," Klaus Wowereit, the mayor of Berlin, said in a statement. "This is evidence of the self-confidence of a growing Jewish community that can feel safe and home in the city of Berlin."

title: From the Mind of a Poet, Turning Words to Images
description: If there were a Nobel Prize for visual artists, it is a safe bet that Derek Walcott would not win one -- and not only because he has already received a Nobel, for literature in 1992. Mr. Walcott, who divides his time between Saint Lucia, New York and Boston, where he teaches at Boston University, does paint. But judging by "Another Life," an exhibition of his work from the last decade at the June Kelly Gallery in SoHo, he is more of a devoted hobbyist than an accomplished professional.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GROSS, SIDNEY
description: GROSS--Sidney. Time cannot steal you from us. Your love and caring are in our hearts always. Zenith and Family

title: Caring for Parents at the End of Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Memphis Picks Its Poison as Williams Leads Duke
description: There are ways to slow Duke's lethal shooter and top scorer, J. J. Redick. It won't do a team much good, though, if it cannot also contain Shelden Williams, the other half of Duke's sensational pair of seniors.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Brown, Who Knows Iverson Well, Notes That Marbury Is No Iverson
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., Nov. 25 - If there is a model for how to thrive under Larry Brown -- a reference point for the willful guard bonding with the willful coach -- then Allen Iverson is probably it.

title: Students Ace State Tests, but Earn D's From U.S.
description: After Tennessee tested its eighth-grade students in math this year, state officials at a jubilant news conference called the results a "cause for celebration." Eighty-seven percent of students performed at or above the proficiency level.

title: Caring for Parents at the End of Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Arts, Briefly; Russian News Anchor Barred From Studio
description: Olga Romanova, below, a sharp-tongued anchor for Ren-TV, the only major Russian channel with news not influenced by the Kremlin, was blocked by security guards from entering the studio for her program on Thursday night, she said. Former President Mikhail S. Gorbachev called it a blow against freedom of the press. "Such an attitude to Olga Romanova is a sign that the last channel that remained independent and impartial in covering events at least to some extent has been lost," the Interfax news agency quoted him as saying. Ms. Romanova said she had also recently been prevented from broadcasting a report about how charges were dropped against Alexander Ivanov, the son of Defense Minister Sergei B. Ivanov, who struck and killed a pedestrian while driving. Ren-TV, founded as an independent channel and known for its incisive news coverage and documentaries, was bought this year by the oil company Surgutneftegaz; RTL, a German television network; and Severstal, a Russian industrial conglomerate with close ties to the Kremlin. The new chief executive, Alexander Ordzhonikidze, said last month that the new shareholders and management had no plans to alter the channel's format, and on a recent radio program, Ms. Romanova defended the change in ownership as a normal business deal. She returned to the studio yesterday to prepare for her next broadcast but said she planned to sue the channel, according to Gazeta, a Russian news Web site.

title: Isles Can't Stop Ottawa's Top Line or Beat Hasek
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., Nov. 25 - If the Ottawa Senators had a question mark about this season, it was at goaltender, where Dominik Hasek was attempting a comeback after spending most of the past three years in retirement.

title: Fighting Crime and Saving Lives With the Xbox 360
description: Ethan Thomas is an F.B.I. agent hunting serial killers and Kameo is a princess who must save her family, but both have a much more important objective: to persuade gamers to spend $300 on Microsoft's new game console, the Xbox 360.

title: Palestinians Taking Control of a Gaza Border
description: RAFAH, Gaza Strip, Nov. 25 - Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, formally reopened the Gaza Strip's border crossing with Egypt on Friday, giving Palestinians control over one of their frontiers for the first time.

title: World Briefing | Mideast: Accord Near On Relief Groups
description: The Palestinian Red Crescent and Israel's equivalent, the Magen David Adom, are expected to sign an agreement in Geneva next week, and the Swiss news media reported that it would be tantamount to formal mutual recognition by the two organizations. The Swiss Foreign Ministry, in a statement, said the agreement would be signed about one week before a conference, also in Geneva, that is expected to pave the way for Israel to join the Red Cross movement by approving an additional emblem, a red crystal, for use in Israel, in addition to the red cross or red crescent now in use. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Moscow Show Pits Art Against Church and State
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 25 - After last year's terrorist attack on a school in Beslan, Russia, and President Vladimir V. Putin's subsequent steps to strengthen his political power, Marat Guelman formulated a response of sorts. It was an artistic doctrine and a political declaration, a social and cultural challenge to the state of what he called Russia 1.

title: Of Dollars, Deficits and Destiny
description: The United States' gap in trade and other international transactions is on track to reach an unprecedented $788 billion in 2005. The federal budget deficit, meanwhile, remains intractable. Normally, that would make investors wary of holding dollars. But the dollar, which had been in a long swoon, has unexpectedly recovered in the second half of this year.

title: Christopher Durang Explores the Afterlife, Including His Own
description: In Christopher Durang's farcical new play, "Miss Witherspoon," the middle-aged woman of the title commits suicide as a delayed reaction to the Skylab space station's falling to earth. She wakes up in the bardo, the place where a soul awaits reincarnation in Tibetan Buddhism. The character Veronica (Kristine Nielsen) does not want to be reincarnated: "Why can't I just be left alone to fester and brood in my bodiless spirit state?"

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FECHT, AUDREY ANN
description: FECHT--Audrey Ann. On November 22, 2005 at age 75. Beloved aunt of Deborah J. Doyle and Dorothy F. Luntey. Great aunt of Michael Doyle and Elizabeth Doyle. Sisterin-law of Dagny M. Fecht. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave (at 20th St) Monday 9:30 AM. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 11 AM at Epiphany Church, 22nd St at 2nd Ave. Interment will be private.

title: A Friendship Sealed by the Scalpel
description: NIDHA MUBDI needed a kidney and Derek Ivery had one to spare. It was that simple, that complex. Now they lay in adjacent operating rooms, being prepped for a transcendent transfer of ownership.

title: 2 Years of Dinnertime Quiet, Thanks to the Do-Not-Call Registry
description: WE all know the feeling. It's dinnertime, or bedtime for the children, or the middle of a good television show and the phone rings. Is it your mom? Your work?

title: Frank Gatski, 84, Hall of Fame Lineman for Powerful Browns, Is Dead
description: Frank Gatski, the Hall of Fame center on the Cleveland Browns teams that played in 10 consecutive professional football championship games in the decade after World War II, died Tuesday at a nursing home in Morgantown, W.Va. He was 84.

title: Big Store, Little Town
description: MIDDLEFIELD, Ohio - If you've seen the anti-Wal-Mart documentary playing at churches and colleges and union halls, you have learned about the people here in Amish farm country who couldn't stop Wal-Mart from ruining their simple way of life.

title: In Meeting With Rival Factions, U.N. Envoy Paves Way for Kosovo Talks
description: BELGRADE, Serbia and Montenegro, Nov. 23 - The United Nations took a step closer to starting talks on the future of Kosovo, perhaps the most intractable issue remaining from the Balkan wars of the 1990's, with a visit by its chief negotiator to the region this week.

title: Republicans Are Deeply Split Over How to Apportion New Tax Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 - Republicans of all stripes want to cut taxes, but rarely have they been in so much disarray about whose to cut.

title: The Anger and Shock of a City's Slave Past
description: They have the awkwardness of amateur home videos: background noise, long silences, people looking away from the camera. But inside a booth at the New-York Historical Society, visitors to the exhibition "Slavery in New York" are recording their reactions, creating snapshot reflections on race and history in the nation's largest city.

title: Spill in China Brings Danger, and Cover-Up
description: HARBIN, China, Nov. 25 - A toxic 50-mile band of contaminated river water slowly washed through this frigid provincial capital on Friday, leaving schools and many businesses closed, forcing millions of people to spend a third straight day without running water and raising fears of a long-term environmental disaster.

title: From the Mind of a Poet, Turning Words to Images
description: If there were a Nobel Prize for visual artists, it is a safe bet that Derek Walcott would not win one - and not only because he has already received a Nobel, for literature in 1992. Mr. Walcott, who divides his time between Saint Lucia, New York and Boston, where he teaches at Boston University, does paint. But judging by "Another Life," an exhibition of his work from the last decade at the June Kelly Gallery in SoHo, he is more of a devoted hobbyist than an accomplished professional.

title: To Survive or to Gather Chips, That Is the Question
description: A no-limit hold 'em tournament, which continues until one player has all the chips, is the form of poker that most lavishly rewards an aggressive approach. Not surprisingly, the most successful demographic group, including 7 of the top 10 in the Card Player rankings, are men in their 20's or early 30's. Nick Schulman, a lanky Manhattanite who won $2,167,500 last week at the World Poker finals at Foxwoods Resort Casino, vaulting from nowhere to No. 50, turned 21 only two months ago.

title: Fake Physician Attacks Woman
description: A 24-year-old woman was sexually assaulted yesterday afternoon by a man claiming to be a doctor in the vestibule of her doctor's office building in Mill Basin, Brooklyn, the police said.

title: He Donated Sperm. Is He a Father?
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire in House in New Jersey Claims Life of Disabled Woman
description: A disabled 41-year-old woman died in a fire in her bedroom in Union, N.J., shortly before 6 p.m. yesterday while her live-in caretaker was out walking the dog, the fire department and neighbors said.

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Canada: No-Confidence Vote Set For Monday
description: The opposition introduced a no-confidence motion in the House of Commons intended to bring down the Liberal government of Prime Minister Paul Martin. The vote is scheduled for Monday, and Mr. Martin does not seem to have the votes to survive. An election is expected in January, and a Liberal Party money laundering and campaign financing scandal is sure to be a major issue. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

title: The New York Cauldron Awaits a Man of Conviction
description: MIDWAY through a conference call with members of the news media yesterday, someone asked Mets General Manager Omar Minaya a loaded, but not unexpected, question about sports, patriotism and Carlos Delgado, the newest Met.

title: Caring for Parents at the End of Life (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Are Banks Still the Place to Put Money?
description: SHARES of banks and other financial companies have enjoyed stellar returns this fall, but one investment adviser is unimpressed. Richard Bernstein, chief United States equity strategist at Merrill Lynch, warns that the sector may be heading for a bout of weakness.

title: Competitive Early-Bird Shopping Becomes a Holiday Norm
description: PARAMUS, N.J., Nov. 25 - As his wife and two children slept, John Rudd made himself a large thermos of coffee, got into his blue minivan shortly before midnight on Thursday and drove to the Best Buy in Paramus. Mr. Rudd had his eye on a $379.99 Toshiba laptop, marked down from $749.99, and a Kodak digital camera, regularly $249.99, for $129.99.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   INDURSKY, DAVID
description: INDURSKY--David. On November 24, 2005. Beloved husband of Anne of 65 years. Dear father of Arthur and Deanne Indursky. Father of the late Howard Indursky. Father-in-law of Ellen Indursky. Cherished grandfather of Blake, Amy and Michael. We will miss his wonderful sense of humor, his warm smile and loving heart. He loved his family dearly. Services Sunday November 27, 12:45 PM at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: World Briefings: Asia, Mideast, Africa, Europe, Americas
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WALDENBERG, PHILIP
description: WALDENBERG--Philip. Beloved husband of the late Gertrude. Devoted father of Carol Testa (Michael), Stefani Weiss (Steven) and Adair Waldenberg (Jon). Cherished grandfather of Matthew Testa, Marlisse Testa-Shrode (Jason), Jonathon Weiss, Jeremy Weiss (Amy), Pearce Peck-Walden (May), and Shannon Peck-Walden, and great-grandfather of Lexi Shrode. Loving brother of Harold Waldenberg. He was the first treasurer of Great Neck Synagogue and past president of Anshei Emuna Congregation, Delray Beach, FL. Services Sunday 12 Noon at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Interment at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOROWITZ, LEWIS J.
description: HOROWITZ--Lewis J. Aged 70, November 25, 2005. Beloved husband of Jo Ann Malkin Horowitz, loving father of Jay (Suzanne) and Stephen (Dorsey), dear stepfather of Harold Malkin (Jennifer) and Jill Addeo (Geoffrey) and adored grandfather Max, Ben, Leo, Ryan and Olivia. Born February 13, 1935, graduated Barnard School For Boys and Brown University '56. Partner in specialist firm of Phelan, Silver until 1982. Past Chairman of New York Futures Exchange and an Executive Vice-President of The New York Stock Exchange. Retired in 1995, and became a full time volunteer on the pediatric floor of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center where he has spent the past ten years. Former President of Ramapo Anchorage Camp, ex board member of Downtown Hospital and active in Junior Achievement and Principal for a Day. During his financial career, Lew was known for his electric neckties and during his volunteer career, for his collection of fabulous hats. Lew brought smiles and good humor everywhere he went. He is loved by so many and will be deeply missed by all whose lives he touched. Donations in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (MSKCC) for the Lewis Horowitz Pediatric Recreation Fund, 1275 York Ave., NY, NY 10021 attention Nina J. Pickett. Memorial service, Wednesday, November 30, at 4PM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St. $(6$)HOROWITZ--Lewis J. Goodbye, good friend! We were all your kids and will miss your love and care. Wear a wonderful hat!! Manny, Skippy and all the children $(6$)HOROWITZ--Lew. Lew, how will I spend my Sundays? No longer two hours of tennis singles followed by a long lunch of intimacy, humor and warmth. Lew, you were the most unforgettable man I ever met. Everyone returned your warmth with love and admiration. I miss you big Lew. David Caplan $(6$)HOROWITZ--Lewis J. Lew Lew, we love you so much. You were the most fun in our lives. Lots of love and hugs to the world's best grandpa. Max, Ben, Leo and Ryan $(6$)HOROWITZ--Lewis. You will be greatly missed. Special condolences to Joann. Sandy, Fran, Ken, Carol and Jack

title: Privatizing the American West
description: While lawmakers are in recess, it is worth reflecting on one particular part of the mess they have left behind. Last week, a budget bill scraped through the House, 217 to 215. Democrats and moderate Republicans had already stripped a provision to allow drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. But the House bill left intact an evil trap to be sprung on the American public: Richard Pombo's plan to put a few hundred million acres of publicly owned land up for sale in the American West.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: Opposition Leader Sent To Court-Martial
description: Authorities sent the jailed opposition leader Kizza Besigye to a military court to face charges of terrorism and illegal weapons possession, on top of the treason and rape allegations he already faces in civilian courts. The switch from the High Court to a military tribunal was seen by his backers as aimed at excluding him from next year's presidential elections. Mr. Besigye returned to Uganda last month from exile to challenge President Yoweri Museveni, a former rebel leader who took power in 1986. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Staying Connected on Long Stays Abroad
description: TECHNOLOGY is supposed to make our lives more flexible. Unfettered from our cubicles, we can journey with our laptops and cellphones to the coffee shop around the corner, or halfway around the world. At least that is the general idea.

title: A Rabbi, a Van and 28 Temples in 12 States
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 25 - When Rabbi Debra Kassoff shows up to lead Friday night shabbat services in McGehee, Ark., she is a bit of a star. People have been known to drive 90 miles to hear the slight 33-year-old read from the Torah and lead prayers. Sometimes, she says, there are even more Christians in attendance than Jews.

title: Big Google Becomes Big Target
description: IN 2001, about a dozen of Google's founding employees sat in a conference room trying to come up with a set of corporate values. After a while, one of them, an engineer, Paul Buchheit, said everything they were saying could be summed up by a simple phrase: "Don't Be Evil."

title: Back Home, Injured Sisters Grin and Bear Media Glare
description: ALBANY, Nov. 25 - The Chamberlain family's telephone rang yet again. This time the call was from a producer from the "Today" show. Stephen Chamberlain, whose two daughters were slightly injured by a falling light fixture during the Thanksgiving Day parade on Thursday, put the caller on hold and turned to his eldest daughter, Mary, whose forehead bore a dime-size scab.

title: Government and Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: To See How Gold Is Doing, Check the Rest of the Market
description: GOLD is in a bull market, approaching $500 an ounce for the first time since 1987, and there is talk that the move shows renewed fears about inflation. Gold bugs say it may be that people are starting to lose faith in central banks to preserve the value of paper currencies, while others see evidence of growing demand for gold jewelry as Asia grows richer.

title: At a North American Championship, Bidding and Signaling Prove the Key
description: At the Fall North American Bridge Championships in Denver on Thursday night, the Edgar Kaplan Blue Ribbon Pairs had an exciting conclusion. With two boards to play, the German internationals Sabine Auken (who lives in Denmark) and Daniela von Arnim led by 9 match points. In that last round, the Germans scored only 6 of 76 match points. This permitted Jenny Ryman from Sweden and Gavin Wolpert from Canada to leapfrog into first place by 18.04 match points. Third were Zia Mahmood of New York and Howard Weinstein of Sarasota, Fla.

title: Escaping Demolition, Landmark Home by Early Black Architect Will Take to the Road
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 24 - Paul Revere Williams, who designed the Morris Landau House, could not have lived in the tony Holmby Hills section of Los Angeles when the home was built there.

title: Shares Up for 7 Straight Days and 5 Consecutive Weeks
description: Stocks rose yesterday for the seventh consecutive trading session as speculation that holiday sales would exceed earlier estimates lifted the shares of retailers, including Best Buy.

title: Bears' Defensive Line Has Style and Substance
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 24 - The Chicago Bears' defensive line showed up eight deep for its weekly group dinner at a trendy downtown restaurant. The young, boisterous players, who are the key to the N.F.L.'s stingiest defense, reveled the same way they arrived -- without reservations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUBIN, SHIRLEY
description: RUBIN--Shirley. In everlasting memory of a devoted sister and aunt who passed away November 23, 2005. You will always be in our hearts. With love Jessie and Lynne. $(6$)RUBIN--Shirley. The best grandmother and great grandmother anyone could wish for. You will forever hold a special place in our hearts. We will miss our Nana today, tomorrow and always. Jodi, David, Jessica and Jennifer $(6$)RUBIN--Shirley. When we said our goodbyes the tears in our eyes said it all. The love and respect we had for each other cannot be measured. I am proud to be your daughter and will treasure you. Barbara

title: Better Isn't Quite Good Enough as Nets Drop to 0-3 Out West
description: PHOENIX, Nov. 25 - There were signs of hope for the Nets on Friday night.

title: Arts, Briefly; Computers 8, Humans 4
description: Chalk up another victory for the machines. A chess tournament on Thursday pitting three previous champions of the World Chess Federation against three chess-playing computers ended with a clear victory for the computers. "II People vs. Computers World Chess Team Match," in Bilbao, Spain, featured Rustam Kasimdzhanov of Uzbekistan, Ruslan Ponomariov of Ukraine and Alexander Khalifman of Russia. The electronic contenders were Hydra, a supercomputer developed by the Pal Group in the United Arab Emirates, and two commercially available programs, Deep Junior and Fritz 9. The final score was computers 8, humans 4. A similar tournament last year with Mr. Ponomariov; Veselin Topalov, a Bulgarian who is the current world champion; and Sergey Karjakin of Ukraine also ended in victory for the computers, with a final score of 8.5 to 3.5.

title: As Corporate Ad Money Flows Their Way, Bloggers Risk Their Rebel Reputation
description: When Anita Campbell started her Web log about small-business trends two years ago, she thought it would simply be a service for her clients and help her consulting business grow.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 - Congress was fairly generous with Amtrak in the transportation budget it passed just before it went home for Thanksgiving, but the package has some unusual strings attached.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Small Business section on Nov. 16 about the business strategies of nanotechnology companies misstated the use of the product sold by Aspen Aerogels and the company's pricing practice. The company sells its nanoporous insulating material for oil pipelines, not water pipelines. The insulation is sold per square foot, with the price negotiated before delivery; it is not sold on the basis of how much money a company will save by using the insulation in its pipelines.

title: INSIDE

description: In John Tierney's column of Nov. 12 about Amtrak, the railroad's share of intercity travel has not been declining for 50 years. Amtrak is only 34 years old.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: More Arrests In Civil Unrest
description: The police arrested 1,540 people as part of investigations after the wave of civil unrest that swept the country this month, in addition to the 3,200 people arrested during the events, Interior Minister Nicolas Sarkozy said. "The arrests won't stop with the end of the riots," Mr. Sarkozy said in a speech to France's mayors. "Those who ransacked, those who behaved like delinquents will have to account for their actions to our country's judicial system." Of those arrested, 650 have been jailed, the national police say. Ariane Bernard (NYT)

title: Merger Talks by WPP and Aegis End
description: LONDON, Nov. 25 - The WPP Group, a London-based advertising company, said on Friday that it had decided not to bid for a rival, the Aegis Group, as a battle of news releases showed that the talks between the companies had broken off with substantial disagreements.

title: BUSINESS BRIEFS
description: G.E. Will Record $3 Billion After-Tax Loss For Sale of Reinsurance Unit The General Electric Company said yesterday that it expected to record a $3 billion after-tax loss in the fourth quarter for the sale of most of its reinsurance business to Swiss Re, $200 million more than it projected when it announced the sale Nov. 18. In a regulatory filing, the company, based in Fairfield, Conn., said its General Electric Capital Services unit would record the loss, which includes a write-off for good will. When it announced the Swiss Re transaction, which is worth up to $7.6 billion, G.E. had projected a $2.8 billion after-tax loss. The transaction will make Swiss Re the world's largest reinsurer, surpassing Munich Re. (Reuters)

title: A Last Chance to Reach for World Cup Tickets
description: FIFA, the international governing body for soccer, releases its last batch of 300,000 World Cup 2006 tickets on Dec. 12, offering a final chance to buy tickets to the games, held June 9 through July 9 in stadiums all over Germany. The opening game will be in Munich's new Allianz Arena, while the final -- won by Brazil in Japan in 2002, right -- will be in Berlin's Olympic Stadium. Among the 12 cities with early matches are Frankfurt, Hamburg, Leipzig and Gelsenkirchen.

The Last Days of the Little Guys
description: AS shopping districts go, the corner of Dey Street and Broadway, in Lower Manhattan, hardly carries the prestige of Madison Avenue or the relentless bustle of Herald Square. Still, for a certain brand of merchant, one who relies partly on tourists and impulse buys, this is one of the city's best locations. Because the A, C, 2 and 3 trains, among others, stop nearby, there is plenty of foot traffic. The popular discount department store Century 21 is a block west, and a bus carrying ground-zero-bound tourists stops on the corner.

title: Corrections
description: The Square Feet article last Sunday, about the design of the Jay Monahan Center for Gastrointestinal Health in Manhattan, referred incorrectly to a facility being erected opposite it on East 70th Street. It is a new center for ambulatory care and medical education, not for ambulatory care alone, and it is being built by Weill Medical College of Cornell University, not by New York-Presbyterian Hospital.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   THOMPSON, BRUCE GENE
description: THOMPSON -- Bruce Gene. (1929-2005) Age 76, loving husband and father, went home to be with the Lord on November 24, 2005 at his home in Toledo after a battle with cancer. Mr. Thompson was born on September 4, 1929 in Mount Vernon, NY. He was the second son of Robert Sydney Thompson and Verda Irene Burt. Mr. Thompson is survived by his wife, Peggy (Rupp) Thompson, with whom he shared ten loving years of marriage; by his children Bruce R. of Houston, TX; Alison Calandra of Saline, MI; Linda Reinstadtler of New York City; Christopher R. of Toledo and stepdaughter Corrie (Calipetro) Jones of Lantana, FL. He is survived by seven grandchildren: Katie, James, Ellie, Robert, Caroline, Joshua and Grace. He was predeceased by his brother, Robert S. Thompson, Jr. of Fairborn, OH and by his former wife, LaWanda Mockbee Thompson of New York City. In 1947, Mr. Thompson graduated from Choate-Rosemary Hall secondary school in Wallingford, CT, where he excelled as a wrestler. He then entered Yale University in New Haven, CT and graduated in 1951 with a B.A. in economics. After Yale University, Mr.Thompson proceeded to the University of Virginia Law School in Charlottesville, where he served as the editor-in-chief of the prestigious Virginia Law Review. He received his law degree in 1954 with honors. Mr. Thompson's expansive business career began with his association with the Shearman & Sterling law firm in New York City in 1958. For several years his legal practice focused on domestic and international financing matters. In 1966, Mr. Thompson accepted a position with the United States State Department as an Investment Advisor to the Government of Pakistan. Based in Karachi, Mr. Thompson and his young family lived the experience of a lifetime in this culturally exotic, developing region of the world. In 1970, after returning stateside, Mr. Thompson founded Health Care REIT, Inc. along with Frederic D. Wolfe, to finance developers and operators of nursing homes, assisted-living facilities and related healthcare projects. Health Care REIT, Inc., based in Toledo, is now a billion-dollar company that is listed on the New York Stock Exchange (symbol ?HCN?). From 1970 until 1996, Mr. Thompson served as Founder, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Health Care REIT, Inc. Friends may call at the Coyle Funeral Home, 1770 South Reynolds Road Toledo, OH. on Monday, November 28th from 5pm to 8pm and on Tuesday, November 29th from 2pm to 8pm. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, November 30th at 11am at Cornerstone Church at 1520 Reynolds Road in Maumee, OH. where the family will receive friends beginning at 10am. Interment will be privately held at a later date. Mr. Thompson requested that any who wish to make a donation in his name please consider Cornerstone Church Children's Ministry. Please view and sign the guest registry at www.coylefuneralhome.com

The Red Sox had just lost Game 2 in their playoff with the Yankees. He was from Boston and I always root for the underdog, and we mourned the continuation of the Curse. title: Hollywood Goes To War!; The Narnia Skirmishes
description: I agree with Charles McGrath that "The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe" is better without a reach for religious subtext. I first read it while attending a Lutheran elementary school. Though it was assigned reading and passages were discussed in class, I have no memory of my teachers commenting on any biblical parallels. Whatever the rationale for omitting the theological analysis, it allowed me to enjoy the book for its characters and magnetic world. I am certain that my happy memories of crunching snow and Turkish delight would not exist had I been directed to find Jesus on every page.

title: Not for Edward Scissorhands
description: TO describe the two customary ways to cut a swath of gift wrap, Scott Pearson uses a pair of onomatopoeic names: "clip clip" and "zip zip." The clip-clip method involves slowly snipping one's way across the paper with a pair of scissors, opening and closing the blades every few inches. The zip-zip technique consists of keeping the scissors' blades ajar and sliding them forward -- a swifter option, but also one prone to error.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HUTCHINGS, HEATHER MACMILLAN
description: HUTCHINGS--Heather MacMillan. 52, of Deerfield Beach, FL, passed away suddenly at her home on Sunday, November 20th, 2005. Beloved daughter of Charles Stewart MacMillan and Elizabeth Ann Davin, she was born July 26, 1953, in New York City, NY. She was a member of St. Gregory's Episcopal Church, Boca Raton, FL. She attended Michigan State University. She had a long career in advertising and retailing, most recently, the last ten years, for Talbot's in Boca Raton. She was a wonderful friend, a generous and devoted aunt, loyal and loving sister who touched many lives, and she will be truly missed by all who knew her, especially her family and friends in the United Kingdom and United States. She is survived by her husband, Paul E. Hutchings; sisters Bernadette Dale Stewart Burner MacMillan, Geneva, Switzerland, and Adele Stewart MacMillan of East Hampton, NY; nieces Alixandra MacMillan Fiedel of Geneva, Switzerland, and Elizabeth Ann Stewart Meyers of East Hampton, NY; nephew Scott Stewart Meyers of East Hampton, NY; stepmother Marianna Maleeva MacMillan of Geneva, Switzerland, and Sofia, Bulgaria; a stepson, Todd Hutchings of Doylestown, PA; a stepdaughter, Amy Hutchings Gursky of Honeybrook, PA. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, December 1, 2005, 10:30 AM, at St. Gregory's Episcopal Church, 100 NE Mizner Blvd, Boca Raton, FL. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation. For information, Lorne & Sons Funeral Home, Delray Beach, FL.

The signs directed customers who had bought the items to return them for a refund.

title: Little Engines That Still Can

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEIR, MAURICE
description: WEIR--Maurice. Our beloved friend died in Palm Beach November 21 at age 92. He was unable to survive a cancer operation of six weeks ago. An interior designer in practice for over fifty years, he was a distingushed Fellow of the ASID, highly respected by his colleagues and clients, and deeply loved by his friends. We shall miss his humor, generosity, and warm friendship. Bob, Bob and Bobbie

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WILSON, KATHERINE STERN
description: WILSON -- Katherine Stern. Age 79, died on Friday, November 25, surrounded by members of her devoted family. Death was due to complications of cancer and came only after a long and courageous fight. She is survived by her husband Philip, two daughters: Lucy and Elizabeth Watson; three sons: William Watson, Patrick and David Wilson; and ten grandchildren, all of whom are overcome by their loss, and struggling with the reason as to why. Kit was a delightful, caring person who made the world a better place in which to live. She was an avid reader, but enjoyed social interaction and had a quick wit. She could exchange jokes with the best. She was also proficient in many athletic pursuits, but the game of tennis, the skills of which she acquired as a teenager from the incomparable teachings of Dorothy Wightman, was her first love. She practiced it artfully and effectively much to the dismay of opponents, the gratitude of partners and the admiration of all. Kit also derived much pleasure from the intimate and enduring friendships she maintained with many persons from all over. These relationships were of utmost importance to her and remained at the top of her mind until the bitter end. Were she able, she would be the first among her family to thank all those dear friends for their tender condolences, for which the severity of her illness impaired direct and timely acknowledgement; likewise to express her and our gratitude to the loving and tireless caregivers who comforted her and her family during her passing. No burial service is planned.

title: A culture war
Leftover Myths From Playing On Thanksgiving
description: The Lions, the Cowboys, the Falcons and the Broncos had to work on Thanksgiving, which means that today they can stay home, rest and prepare for next week's opponents. Conventional wisdom says playing on Thanksgiving gives teams an edge. An examination of the record shows it does not.

title: DEALS & DISCOUNTS
description: NEW MEXICO SAVINGS -- The Home for the Holidays package at the 219-room Eldorado Hotel and Spa in Santa Fe, N.M., offers guests a special $109 a night rate (a 45 percent discount) until Jan. 31. Taxes of 14.5 percent are extra. For reservations, call (800) 955-4455 or see www.eldoradohotel.com.

title: A Good but Puzzling Drug Benefit
description: The enrollment period for Medicare's new prescription drug benefit opened this month amid complaints about its complexity, its drawbacks and its seemingly irrational structure. Many of the critics are right. But the new program is still an important new benefit -- the largest expansion of Medicare in decades and a vital step to bringing Medicare into the modern era. The problems, while irksome, can be remedied later.

title: Just Try to Sleep Tight. The Bedbugs Are Back.
description: They're the scourge of hobo encampments and hot-sheet motels. To impressionable children everywhere, they're a snippet of nursery rhyme, an abstract foe lurking beneath the covers that emerges when mommy shuts the door at night.

title: A Merlot Benchmark
description: IF Long Island is, first and foremost, merlot country, then Raphael is a leading index of merlot's promising future here. Its 2001 First Label merlot illustrates why.

title: Merck Set to Announce Details of Restructuring Plan
description: Merck, under pressure from investors and analysts to cut costs and pare thousands of employees from its payroll, said today that it would soon announce details of its long-awaited restructuring plan.

title: BETTER LATE THAN
description: You might call this a late check-in with the shareholders. Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide disclosed to investors last week the terms of an eight-month employment agreement that it had struck with a senior executive, Robert F. Cotter, who said last February that he would retire on Dec. 31. But the contract, signed in mid-November, covers a period that began on May 1 and will expire at year-end.

title: Based on an Untrue Story
description: LASSE HALLSTROM recently shot a film that retells a decades-old story some of the players would rather forget. Speaking by phone from New York, Mr. Hallstrom, the highly regarded Swedish director, was clear about one thing: to make a movie about Clifford Irving isn't necessarily to love him.

title: Hedge Funds Work for Yale, but Will They Work for You?
description: DEEP-POCKETED investors have done famously well by depositing some of their surplus millions in hedge funds. The Yale University endowment, for example, has relied heavily on hedge funds over the last two decades to earn annual returns of more than 16 percent a year.

title: The Seahawks Prefer a Snip to a Total Makeover
description: Correction Appended

title: Tulum Beach, Mexico: Sueos Tulum
description: THE BASICS As with most of the modest eco-resorts and cabanas on Tulum Beach, Sueos Tulum has no traditional electricity. The kitchen appliances and water heaters run on butane gas; solar panels generate the lights and electricity in the office and kitchen. This off-the-grid aesthetic, coupled with the pristine white-sand beaches of the Yucatn Peninsula, is what has lured yoga and wellness practitioners to the area in recent years.

title: 'The Truth of the Matter'
Swiss Ban Genetically Modified Crops
description: GENEVA, Nov. 27 -Swiss voters today supported a five year-ban on the farming of genetically modified crops, offering a further sign of widespread distrust in Europe of scientifically enhanced foods.

title: In Winter, an Old City Is a Nouvelle Ville
description: STROLLING the ramparts of a centuries-old walled city, where the main language is French and the view encompasses castle turrets, famous battlefields and a mighty frozen river, it's easy to feel that you've traveled farther than Canada. For children, whose only exposure to fortifications and historic buildings may have come at a medieval theme park, Quebec City offers an experience that, in the Old Town, at least, is almost untouched by minimarts, chain stores and fast-food restaurants.

title: Hollywood Goes To War!; Beverly Hills Coup?
description: Matt Bai's article (Nov. 13) was crackling smart, just what I have come to expect regularly from this refreshingly original political writer. He comes the closest I've yet seen to pointing out the true limitation of Hollywood liberalism -- that none of these wealthy, charismatic people are actually willing to do the dirty work of running for and holding political office while their conservative counterparts are. From Fred Grandy to Sonny Bono to Schwarzenegger to Reagan, it's always the right-wing entertainers who decide they want to make policy instead of just complaining about it. That's why, although I happen to share his political bent, I'm disgusted when Rob Reiner tries to compare senatorial responsibilities with his own; making a hard decision about film locations is not the same as making a hard decision about Social Security. Politics may be show business for ugly people, as the old saying goes, but that's because politics is much uglier and riskier than show business.

title: Under the Spreading Willow Tree

But on Sixth Street near Fifth Avenue in Park Slope, Brooklyn, there stands -- looms, really -- a notable exception: a gargantuan weeping willow tree whose canopy cloaks four full yards and tickles the airspace of a fifth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOROWITZ, LEWIS J.
description: HOROWITZ--Lewis J. Aged 70, November 25, 2005. Beloved husband of Jo Ann Malkin Horowitz, loving father of Jay (Suzanne) and Stephen (Dorsey), dear stepfather of Harold Malkin (Jennifer) and Jill Addeo (Geoffrey) and adored grandfather Max, Ben, Leo, Ryan and Olivia. Born February 13, 1935, graduated Barnard School For Boys and Brown University '56. Partner in specialist firm of Phelan, Silver until 1982. Past Chairman of New York Futures Exchange and an Executive Vice-President of The New York Stock Exchange. Retired in 1995, and became a full time volunteer on the pediatric floor of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center where he has spent the past ten years. Former President of Ramapo Anchorage Camp, ex board member of Downtown Hospital and active in Junior Achievement and Principal for a Day. During his financial career, Lew was known for his electric neckties and during his volunteer career, for his collection of fabulous hats. Lew brought smiles and good humor everywhere he went. He is loved by so many and will be deeply missed by all whose lives he touched. Donations in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (MSKCC) for the Lewis Horowitz Pediatric Recreation Fund, 1275 York Ave., NY, NY 10021 attention Nina J. Pickett. Memorial service, Wednesday, November 30, at 4PM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: Nov. 27 -- Dec. 3; TELEVISION
description: In "CREATURE COMFORTS" (BBC AMERICA, Friday at 11 p.m.) NICK PARK, the creator of "Wallace & Gromit," has expanded on one of his first projects. The original "Creature Comforts," which won the Oscar for best animated short in 1991, featured animated zoo animals speaking the words of ordinary people interviewed about mundane topics. Years later, he's made more shorts using this format, which will run as a nine-episode series. In one snippet of the first episode, a droll hamster named Fluffy says: "If you're looking for a disco-dancing spring rabbit, then you would find me a bit boring. But if you are the kind of person who likes to sit around and moan a lot, then you could say I'm a fairly good companion."

title: Pardon Me, but the Art Is Mouthing Off
description: IT was late in the day, rain was streaking the windows of a converted warehouse in San Francisco and the robot was not behaving. Represented by a talking head on a flat-screen monitor, and equipped with voice-recognition software, the artificial intelligence computer -- known as DiNA -- was designed to chat with visitors about current affairs. She is supposed to be a political animal, or more precisely, machine. But at this point in early November, just a few weeks before making her New York debut, she sounded rather clueless. When asked her opinion of the war in Iraq, she called it a "silly question." When asked whether she supported President Bush, she didn't recognize his name.

title: 'Mirror to America'
description: Living in a world restricted by laws defining race, as well as creating obstacles, disadvantages, and even superstitions regarding race, challenged my capacities for survival. For ninety years I have witnessed countless men and women likewise meet this challenge. Some bested it; some did not; many had to settle for any accommodation they could. I became a student and eventually a scholar. And it was armed with the tools of scholarship that I strove to dismantle those laws, level those obstacles and disadvantages, and replace superstitions with humane dignity. Along with much else, the habits of scholarship granted me something many of my similarly striving contemporaries did not have. I knew, or should say know, what we are up against.

Fred Hill won't be scoring points on the court this year, but he will be found in homes, high school gyms or wherever else talented young basketball players spend their time while deciding where to go to college.

description: During three anxious minutes outside a Brooklyn police station early yesterday, a man aimed his gun at police officers three times -- apparently hoping for a spectacular death, investigators said.
