title: Hollywood Goes To War!; Behind Foreign Lines
description: In 1984 I went to the 40-year reunion of my brigade, which had fought in Europe from Normandy to the end of the war. I found it a sad spectacle. There was this group of men, most in their early 60's, men who seemed old. They walked around with their fruit-salad ribbons, reminiscing on what had been "the best years of their lives." In Manohla Dargis's essay, the reason for this is described as feelings of greatness, strength, purity, of loving danger. Later in the article, there is a mention of feeling like a band of brothers. That comes closer to the essence. What we found was an intimacy. Men, whom in civilian life we might not exchange a word with, in war became soul brothers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CASCIEGNA, JILL P.
description: CASCIEGNA--Jill P. You fought a valiant battle. We will always cherish the years of friendship. Rest in peace. You will be sorely missed. Our heartfelt condolences to her husband Sal, her brother Jon Paton, and family. Jane and Michael Wind

At 21, she had a 10-month-old baby to care for, a full-time job and little aid, financial or otherwise, or resources to help manage a laundry list of growing responsibilities.

title: Miller and Rahlves Lose Battle With Conditions in Downhill
description: LAKE LOUISE, Alberta, Nov. 26 - It will take about 110 seconds for someone to win the men's downhill at the Olympics in February. But it will take closer to 20 minutes for a skier to prove to his peers that he is the best downhiller in the world.

title: Situation Wanted: Driver, Fast Car Required
description: STEVE PARK is looking for another fast ride, and not just any fast ride will do. Park, a veteran Nascar driver who grew up in East Northport, is looking for a job racing a stock car or a pickup truck that will run at the front of the pack. Nothing less.

title: Paperback Row
description: ARMAGEDDON: The Battle for Germany, 1944-1945, by Max Hastings. (Vintage, $16.95.) This splendid account of the last year of World War II ranges from the Allies' failure to capture the bridge at Arnhem in mid-September 1944 to the final extinction of German resistance in May 1945. Hastings's central question about the war's final phase is not why the Allies won, but why it took the Germans, against overwhelming odds, so long to lose. "Armageddon" is a sequel to Hastings's "Overlord" (1984), which reconstructs the Normandy landings; our reviewer, James J. Sheehan, said both books display the author's "clear, uncluttered style" and "absolute mastery of the technical details of combat."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELNICK, JACQUELINE
description: MELNICK--Jacqueline. 80, cofounder of the Musicorda Summer String Festival, died on November 22, 2005 in South Hadley, MA, of complications from cancer. "Jackie" Melnick taught at The Juilliard School of Music, and at Mount Holyoke College, where she founded the Artist's Recital Series, served as Chair of the Music Department, and retired as Professor of Music on the Alumnae Foundation. In 1986, Melnick and her husband, Leopold Teraspulsky founded the Musicorda Summer String Festival, dedicated to providing intensive training and community performance opportunities to the world's best student string players. She is survived by her husband "Terry" Teraspulsky; three children, Ron, Marjorie, and Susie Melnick; six grandchildren and a great-grandson. A memorial service and concert is planned for February 2006.

title: War-ravaged Chechnya chooses a parliament
The Making of the President, 1797
description: GILBERT STUART'S purse-lipped, powdered-hair portrait of George Washington stares out from every $1 bill and hovers over American classrooms. Although Washington probably sat for Stuart only once or twice, the painter reproduced the original almost 100 times, in half- and full-length variations for wealthy patrons here and abroad.

title: Saving Face and How to Say Farewell
description: IN the old popular song about the rout by Americans at New Orleans during the War of 1812, the British "ran so fast the hounds couldn't catch 'em." Even allowing for patriotic hyperbole, it can hardly be argued that the British extricated themselves with a great deal of dignity, particularly given that another battle in the same war inspired the American national anthem.

Next Jaguar Draws on a Rich Tradition of Design
description: AMONG enthusiasts, the arrival of a new Jaguar sports car is an occasion worthy of a toast -- with the 1982 Mouton Rothschild. The debuts of the SS 100 of 1936, the XK 120 of 1949 and the XKE of 1961 were significant turning points in automotive design and innovation; each provoked gasps of admiration from onlookers, awed the technically minded and drew the envy of competing carmakers.

title: LOOKING AHEAD
description: A SCROOGE FOR EUROPE -- The European Central Bank is expected to raise its key interest rate a quarter of a percentage point on Thursday, to 2.25 percent. The bank's chairman, Jean-Claude Trichet, below, defended the decision to seek higher rates as a precaution against inflation, but some European politicians and industrialists don't like it. Mr. Trichet indicated this would not be the first of a series of increases, but economists polled by Reuters predicted rates would climb to 2.75 percent by the end of 2006.

A Theater Sings Pages From Its History
description: The Public Theater is singing, dancing and raising money for its 50th anniversary celebration. On Jan. 30 at City Center, the theater will feature an evening of artists performing selections from signature Public Theater musicals. Imagine songs from "Hair;" "A Chorus Line;" "Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk;" "The Wild Party;" "Caroline, or Change;" "Ghetto Superstar (The Man That I Am)," among others. They're calling it "The Public Sings," and the lineup of stars scheduled to appear includes Savion Glover, Eartha Kitt, Tonya Pinkins, Rosie Perez, Natalie Portman, Billy Porter, Meryl Streep and Zack Braff.

title: The Neediest Cases; Becoming Even More Self-Sufficient, With a Little Help
description: On a rainy afternoon, Aida, a 5-year-old black Lab who still has the excitement of a puppy, is getting anxious, stuck inside the house. Usually, this is a dog's biggest worry, but Aida probably has more to worry about than most. Aida is Rita Pulsoni's guide dog, and Ms. Pulsoni is the first to tell you that this is no easy dog's life.

But on the road to pro football's draft of college talent on April 29, the game might turn out to have been a critical crossroad in each franchise's future.

Spending for a campaign, planned for the first quarter of 2006, has not been determined. Print advertising is handled internally. DeVito/Verdi and Frank worked together when Frank owned Grey Goose vodka, which changed agencies under its new owner, Bacardi.

title: Other Views: The Economist, Gulf Times, Miami Herald
An Army for the Day After
description: Iraq has been a sobering experience for the United States military. It needs to be an educational one as well. Out of it must come an understanding that there is a lot more to regime change than unleashing the most powerful war-fighting machine in human history for a few weeks against an overmatched third-world army. The indispensable next step is nation-building, a long-term, large-scale project that requires willing allies and a differently trained and configured American military force.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Fatally Shot
description: A Georgia man was killed early yesterday morning outside a building in the Polo Grounds Towers in Harlem. The man Edward Alfonso Dickey, 25, of Savannah, Ga., was shot once in the head, the police said. The police said they arrested a 25-year-old man in connection with the shooting, and charges were pending yesterday afternoon. The shooting occurred just after midnight outside 2991 Frederick Douglass Boulevard. Later yesterday, a single blue prayer candle sat next to the spot, with bits of stray police tape.

title: Is a Free Tuition in Music Worthwhile? An Argument For
description: The news that anonymous donors had promised the Yale School of Music $100 million came too late for Stephanie Teply, a violinist who graduated from the school with a master of music degree in 2003. The gift, announced this month, will enable the school to offer free tuition to all students starting next year.

title: New York City Police Officer Dies After Shooting
description: A New York City police officer, fatally shot through the heart in a car chase in Brooklyn, kept driving for blocks in pursuit of the gunman before realizing he had been hit, officials said. The officer, Dillon Stewart, was then taken by fellow officers in his own bullet-riddled car to a hospital, where he died hours later.

description: AIKEN--David. Beloved cousin, intrepid traveler and insouciant spirit, adventerous cook and dapper dresser, witty and wry; New Yorker by birth, California desert dweller by choice. David treasured the many generations of his Gallatin family. We will always remember and miss you, dear David. A memorial wil be held in Stonington, CT, this spring. Jean Gallatin Crocker Lisa Gallatin Ehrenkranz

title: No-Confidence Vote Topples Canada's Government
description: TORONTO, Nov. 28 - Canada's three opposition parties voted in the House of Commons tonight to bring down the Liberal government of Prime Minister Paul Martin, contending that the governing party is corrupt.

title: Being Quoted 'on the Record' on What You Might Have Said
description: The journalistic phrase "off the record" seemed to lose all meaning last week at an event featuring Justice Antonin Scalia of the Supreme Court.

title: Messages Written on Flesh as Art Flirts With Politics
description: Fresh Tracks, a long-running program devoted to promoting new artistic voices at Dance Theater Workshop, isn't always fresh, but it's always worth seeing. The latest installment, performed Saturday, resulted in the usual mixed bag.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUTHERFORD, WILLIAM A., SR.
description: RUTHERFORD--William A., Sr. The Trustees and staff of the Storm King Art Center express profound sorrow at the loss of their dear friend and landscape architect since the Art Center's inception in 1960. Over the years his vision and creativity guided the shaping of our landscape and its integration with our sculptures. Our heartfelt condolences go to his beloved wife Joyce and his family.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Dix Hills: Police Break Up Illegal Racing
description: Suffolk County police officers broke up illegal street racing on Deer Park Avenue over the weekend, arresting four participants and impounding three vehicles, the police said yesterday. On Saturday night, the officers saw three races at speeds from 75 to 95 miles per hour, the police said. The arrests are part of an effort to stop illegal racing on suburban roads, the police said. Officers seized a 2005 Nissan 350Z, a 2002 Ford Lightning pickup truck and a 1993 Cadillac Eldorado, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SULZBERGER, MAYE (NEE DORFMAN)
description: SULZBERGER--Maye (nee Dorfman). Died Saturday night, November 26th, with her daughter and grandson at her bedside. She is survived by her daughter, Susan Sulzberger Rolfe, grandson Myron Sulzberger (Mickey) Rolfe, granddaughters Joanne (Jody) Quinn and her husband Roger, and Penny R. Sullivan and her husband Tim. Also survived by three great grandsons, Billy and Teddy Quinn, and Tommy Sullivan. Reunited at last with her adored late husband, Edward, from whom she was widowed for 17 years. The daughter of the late Louis and Anna Dorfman, and predeceased by her sister, Paula Bulm, Maye is also survived by her sister, Charlotte Rosenfield, and by nieces and nephews, and by many friends and bridge partners in New York City. She was a member of the Regency Whist Club, the Harmonie Club and the Quaker Ridge Country Club. Our family is indebted to Sophia Sanchez for her steadfast care and love for 30 years, and, more recently, to the four wonderful nurses who tended to Maye as if she was their own. We will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street on Tuesday from 6-9 P.M. with services Wednesday, 11;30 A.M. Interment private. Family will be at Susan Rolfe's home on Thursday from 2-7. Memorial contributions, if desired, to Mount Sinai Medical Center, attention Dr. Alvin Teirstein, 1 Gustav Levy Place, NY, NY 10029. She was fierce and brave, a boss, and we loved her.

title: Another Bronx Borough President Weighs Mayoral Bid
description: It had been only two weeks since a former Bronx borough president lost the mayoral election in a lopsided race. But already his successor as borough president, Adolfo Carrin Jr., was musing about the mayoral election four years from now, insisting that the 2005 election was no harbinger of his own prospects.

title: The New Rwanda
description: Who says George W. Bush and Bill Clinton have nothing in common? Just as President Clinton did on Rwanda, President Bush is doing precious little to try to stop a genocide in Darfur. Indeed, this entire generation of world leaders has a dismal record at intervening in this kind of wholesale murder, and now they are failing to stop the elimination of entire African tribes in the Sudan countryside.

Brave Spirit Under the Unsheltering Sky
description: Trailers for the HBO film "Yesterday" are both true and totally misleading. Blurbs describing "the transcendent power" of one woman's "courage and compassion" conjure "Oprah Winfrey Presents" or worse, the movie "Beaches." And while "Yesterday" is, in fact, a tribute to the transcendent power of one rural South African woman who confronts H.I.V. with courage and compassion, it is more than that.

title: What Google Should Roll Out Next: A Privacy Upgrade
description: At a North Carolina strangulation-murder trial this month, prosecutors announced an unusual piece of evidence: Google searches allegedly done by the defendant that included the words "neck" and "snap." The data were taken from the defendant's computer, prosecutors say. But it might have come directly from Google, which -- unbeknownst to many users -- keeps records of every search on its site, in ways that can be traced back to individuals.

title: Familiar Ending for St. John's
description: For the second year in a row, St. John's season ended with a loss to Maryland. The top-seeded Terrapins beat the Red Storm yesterday, 3-1, in College Park, Md., in the third round of the N.C.A.A. Division I men's tournament to advance to the quarterfinals.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WILLETT, THORNTON WIN SLOW
description: WILLETT -- Thornton Win slow, of Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. Died peacefully on November 25, 2005. Beloved husband of the late Martha Leah Miller Willett. Beloved father of Georgia Rogers Willett and Tamosin Rose Barsdley of Brooklyn, Benjamin Charles Willett of Seattle and the late David Winslow Willett. Beloved grandfather of Austin Miller Bardsley and Ian Winslow Bardsley. Beloved son of the late Francis Winslow Willett and Katherine Terry Thornton Willett of Dedham, Massachusetts. Born December 4, 1928, in New York City. Attended St. Thomas Choir School in New York and went on to Avon Old Farms and The Choate School. He received his undergraduate degree in Philosophy from Harvard College and his Masters Degree in Business Administration from Polytechnic University. He had a long career teaching computer systems at Empire Blue Cross Blue Shield in New York and was an adjunct professor at Pace University. Prior to Blue Cross he had worked at Raytheon, IBM and Riverside Research. He was very active in community affairs for many years in his much beloved Brooklyn. Funeral arrangements are private.

title: Congressman Resigns After Admitting He Took Bribes
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 28 -A Representative Randy Cunningham, a Republican from San Diego, resigned from Congress on Monday, hours after pleading guilty to taking at least $2.4 million in bribes to help friends and campaign contributors win defense contracts.

title: Korean Cloning Pioneer Is Popular Despite Ethical Lapses
description: SEOUL Nov. 28 - Days after his televised fall from grace, Hwang Woo Suk, South Korea's cloning pioneer, re-emerged today as a hero as the country rallied around him in an outpouring of nationalism and sympathy for the humanitarian goals of his stem cell research.

title: China Resolves a Water Crisis in the North, Then Pivots to a Major Earthquake in the South
description: BEIJING, Monday, Nov. 28 - Chinese officials announced on Sunday that water had been restored in the northeastern provincial capital of Harbin after a tide of toxic river water had forced the closing of the municipal water system for five days.

title: Royal Ahold to Pay $1.1 Billion to Settle Shareholder Lawsuit
description: Royal Ahold, the Dutch food retailer whose holdings include the Stop & Shop supermarket chain, said today that it had agreed to pay $1.1 billion to settle a shareholder lawsuit accusing it of violating securities laws for more than two years.

title: Somebody Wake Up the Sugar Plum Fairy; It's That Time of Year Again
description: George Balanchine's production of "The Nutcracker" is the gold standard, with high-tech stage effects imbued with homespun magic and a believable portrayal of a loving family. The purity of Balanchine's choreography adds to the production, too, from his first-act evocation of the ordered turbulence of a snowstorm to vivid character dances and the pristine classicism of the second act.

description: PREZIOSO--Silvio. We note with sorrow the passing of Silvio Prezioso on November 24, 2005, at the age of 94. Beloved husband of Jennie for 70 years. Father to Sylvia, MaryJane and Geraldine. Beloved father-in-law to Silvio and Danny, grandfather of seven and great-grandfather of twelve. description: JOHANNESBURG, Nov. 27 - To nobody's surprise, the governing party of Zimbabwe on Sunday appeared assured of an overwhelming victory as officials tallied the results of this weekend's election of candidates to a newly created upper house of Parliament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GARDNER, JANET H.
description: GARDNER--Janet H. On November 25, 2005, at age 68. Loving wife of Allan, whose bold proposal after a sixweek courtship led to 44 rich and rewarding years together, two children and six grandchildren. She was elegant, opinionated, extraordinarily well-read, witty in person and on paper, and interested in everything. She was a loyal and devoted friend, respected editor, gracious hostess and expert knitter. Her many talents notwithstanding, Janet's most cherished role was as mother to Elisabeth and Andrew, motherin-law to Jeffrey Ostrow and Kimberley Harris, and grandmother to her beloved Robbie, Annabel and Charlotte Ostrow, and Kyle, Jake and Juliet Gardner. Funeral at Congregation B'nai Yisrael, Armonk, NY, Tuesday, November 29, at 11 am.

Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Charged With Trying To Bribe Officer
description: A Washington Heights man who was arrested on drunken driving charges yesterday faces an additional charge of attempted bribery after he offered officers $15,000 to let him go, the police said. The man, Flores Gomez, 27, was arrested shortly before 6 a.m. when he drove his Mercedes-Benz into three parked cars at Broadway and 192nd Street, investigators said. Officer Johnny Diaz, who saw the collision and made the arrest, said it was clear that Mr. Gomez was drunk when he got out of his car uninjured but staggering. Officer Diaz said Mr. Gomez offered the bribe in a holding cell at the 34th Precinct, setting the amount at $10,000, then raising it to $15,000. Officer Diaz said that he refused the bribe, but that Mr. Gomez insisted, and Sgt. Joseph Kourakos was called into the holding cell, where Mr. Gomez repeated his offer. Detectives from the Internal Affairs Bureau were called in, and fitted Sergeant Kourakos with a concealed tape recorder. Investigators said Mr. Gomez was led to think his bribe would be accepted, and was recorded as he called an acquaintance, telling her to bring $15,000 to the precinct. The woman, who was not charged, arrived with neatly packed stacks of $20 and $50 bills in a grocery bag, believing the money was for bail, the police said.

Arts, Briefly; Holiday TV
description: Though fewer viewers were watching television from Wednesday to Friday because of the Thanksgiving holiday, those who did favored CBS. The network was No. 1 on Thursday and Friday among total viewers and adults 18 to 49. And on Wednesday, its lineup -- "Still Standing" (8.24 million), "Yes, Dear" (8.46 million), "Criminal Minds" (12.84 million) and "CSI: New York" (14.28 million) -- drew more total viewers than ABC's, which relies almost exclusively on "Lost" (19.14 million). But the dominant ratings enjoyed by that plane crash mystery (with Matthew Fox, above) among adults 18 to 49 were strong enough to lift the network into first place on Wednesday in the demographic. On Thanksgiving, CBS broadcast new episodes of its regular Thursday schedule -- "Survivor" (19.41 million), "CSI" (25.33 million) and "Without a Trace" (19.58 million) -- which fared nearly as well as usual. The "CSI" episode, seemingly designed to torture viewers satiated by holiday dinners -- it was about a man who died after an eating competition -- was the most-watched program of the three-day period. KATE AURTHUR

Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Survives Fall Onto Tracks
description: A man who fell onto the tracks at the Chambers Street subway station last night survived without any serious injuries when a car passed over him, officials said. The man, whose name was not released, may have been intoxicated when he landed on the tracks around 7 p.m., the police said. One car of an A train passed over him before the train stopped. A station agent said that passengers panicked when the train passed over the man, but that by the time she arrived at the platform, he had been pulled from the tracks and was talking to the police. The man was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital Manhattan, where he was treated for minor cuts and bruises, the police said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Woman Fatally Stabbed
description: A 21-year-old woman was found stabbed to death in her Upper East Side apartment last evening, the police said. The woman, identified by neighbors as Katherine Woods, was found with several cuts in her neck, face down in a pool of blood in her bedroom, the police said. Her boyfriend called the authorities around 7 p.m. after he said he discovered Ms. Woods's body in her second-floor apartment on 86th Street between First and Second Avenues. Police declined to release the boyfriend's name. He was being questioned late last night, but had not been identified as a suspect. The police said that there was no sign of forced entry, but that the woman's bedroom had been ransacked.

The Getty's Italian Job
description: Charlottesville, Va. - PAOLO FERRI, the Italian prosecutor who is investigating the purchases of antiquities by major American museums, has hit hardest at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., which in recent decades rapidly built up an impressive collection of Greek and Roman art. The Getty's troubles -- compounded last week by legal action from Greece for the recovery of four works -- offer a useful lesson for museums and collectors. But it is unfortunate that a chief target of the prosecution is the Getty curator who has done the most to clean up the practices of her institution in this murky trade, Marion True.

Paid Notice: Deaths   PERLOFF, PEARL
description: PERLOFF - Pearl. Died Thanksgiving morning, Thursday, November 24, 2005. She wanted everyone to know that she had a wonderful life and was grateful for everything she received. Married in 1933 to Frank Perloff, she was immensely proud of and completely loyal to her husband. The couple enjoyed more than 60 wonderful years together. Only after her children Michael and Bonnie completed college, did Pearl return to Adelphi College to achieve her own degree. When her plans to continue on to law school were thwarted, she returned to helping others, devoting much time and energy to charitable works at The Brookdale Hospital Medical Center and the Jeri Finesilver Cancer Foundation. When her daughter, Bonnie Perloff Fowler, died of colon cancer, Pearl established the PerloffFowler fund for the prevention of cancer to help those who could not otherwise afford the expense of testing and preventing colon cancer. An eager student and lifelong learner herself, the Lifelong Learning Society on the Jupiter Campus of Florida Atlantic University, where she continued to be an avid student, will dedicate two buildings to be named in her honor on January 8, 2006. She was a proud and adoring mother of her son Michael, her late daughter Bonnie Perloff Fowler, and her son-in-law Sanders Fowler III. The lights of her life were her granddaughter Sarah Fowler Bird, her great - granddaughter Eli zabeth Bird, and Sarah's husband Christopher Bird. She will be missed by all who knew her. Donations may be made to the Perloff-Fowler Fund for the Prevention of Cancer at the Jupiter Medical Center, Jupiter, FL.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOROWITZ, LEWIS J.
description: HOROWITZ--Lewis J. Aged 70, November 25, 2005. Beloved husband of Jo Ann Malkin Horowitz, loving father of Jay (Suzanne) and Stephen (Dorsey), dear stepfather of Harold Malkin (Jennifer) and Jill Addeo (Geoffrey) and adored grandfather Max, Ben, Leo, Ryan and Olivia. Born February 13, 1935, graduated Barnard School For Boys and Brown University '56. Partner in specialist firm of Phelan, Silver until 1982. Past Chairman of New York Futures Exchange and an Executive Vice-President of The New York Stock Exchange. Retired in 1995, and became a full time volunteer on the pediatric floor of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center where he has spent the past ten years. Former President of Ramapo Anchorage Camp, ex board member of Downtown Hospital and active in Junior Achievement and Principal for a Day. During his financial career, Lew was known for his electric neckties and during his volunteer career, for his collection of fabulous hats. Lew brought smiles and good humor everywhere he went. He is loved by so many and will be deeply missed by all whose lives he touched. Donations in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (MSKCC) for the Lewis Horowitz Pediatric Recreation Fund, 1275 York Ave., NY, NY 10021 attention Nina J. Pickett. Memorial service, Wednesday, November 30, at 4PM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St.

title: Defending My Country
Dallaire in Darfur
description: In Darfur I ran into Romeo Dallaire, the retired Canadian general who was in Rwanda for the genocide there. He sat down in the Unicef guest house for a video interview.Theres one major thing I disagree with him on: Dallaire says the word genocide does not now fit what is going on. I take his point that the slaughter was much worse a year ago, and its not like Rwanda where 800,000 people were butchered in three months, but I still think that whats happening easily meets the test of the 1948 Genocide Convention, just as the State Department lawyers concluded.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Nov. 21 about an Italian documentary film accusing the United States of misusing white phosphorus munitions in Iraq referred imprecisely to footage of napalm use in Vietnam. The film shows United States Air Force jets dropping napalm on Vietnamese villages and includes famous footage from 1972 of Kim Phuc Phan Thi, a 9-year-old girl, fleeing after napalm burned her clothing off. But the aircraft that dropped the napalm on her village in 1972 was South Vietnamese, not American.

The W.M.D. myth undermined the credibility of United States intelligence and President Bush himself, and the abuse of prisoners stole America's moral high ground.

The piece was about a foot square and heavy enough to have caused serious injury. The building, which dates to 1935, is undergoing a major renovation, but the incident did not appear to be connected to that project. The architect of the Capitol, whose office supervises the court building, was investigating. Linda Greenhouse (NYT)

title: What's to Be Done About Darfur? Plenty
description: In 1915, Woodrow Wilson turned a blind eye to the Armenian genocide. In the 1940's, Franklin Roosevelt refused to bomb the rail lines leading to Auschwitz. In 1994, Bill Clinton turned away from the slaughter in Rwanda. And in 2005, President Bush is acquiescing in the first genocide of the 21st century, in Darfur.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Oct. 27 about the fruit of the threatened Moroccan argan tree, used to produce an oil for gourmet cooking and cosmetics, omitted a complete explanation of how exported Argan oil is produced. While some Moroccans make oil from argan pits that have been excreted by grazing goats, none of those pits are used to make the oil that is exported. Because of that error, the article also carried a misleading headline. While goats do climb Argan trees to eat the fruit, they are not "doing their bit for gourmands."

title: New York City Transit Shows Off New Subway Cars
description: Nicholas Malave, a 19-year-old Brooklyn high school senior, entered a subway car today and let out a breath of delight. This is not something he normally does during his regular trips on the A and J lines.

title: Corrections

Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANKLIN, BEN A.
description: FRANKLIN--Ben A. The trustees and staff of the Public Concern Foundation mourn the passing of our great friend and colleague Ben A. Franklin, who served with quiet distinction for more than 12 years as the editor of the Washington Spectator. We extend our deepest sympathies to his widow, Jane, whom we admire for her tenacity, courage and wit, and to his daughters Abigail, Betsy and Clare. We are grateful beyond words to Ben for his constant intelligence, his integrity, his well-aimed indignation, and his gift for language. We will miss him always. Hamilton Fish, President Public Concern Foundation

title: Sunnis Accuse Iraqi Military of Kidnappings and Slayings
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 28 - As the American military pushes the largely Shiite Iraqi security services into a larger role in combating the insurgency, evidence has begun to mount suggesting that the Iraqi forces are carrying out executions in predominantly Sunni neighborhoods.

title: Glamorizing the Progress of a Notorious Rake
description: The Restoration, the textbooks tell us, was the era when England became a kind of public theater. The playhouses reopened, to great acclaim, and gentlemen began wearing costumes on the street -- foppish coats and pantaloons and long Frenchified wigs. Even politics became a kind of stage play, with the king and Parliament enacting elaborately contrived roles in a lengthy melodrama about power and succession.

title: Bush Renews Push toOverhaul Immigration
description: TUCSON, Nov. 28 - President Bush kicked off a new effort on Monday to unite Republicans behind an overhaul of immigration laws. He emphasized the need to choke off the flow of illegal immigrants while trying to address conservatives' concerns about his plan to grant temporary legal status to millions of illegal workers already in the United States.

description: Kristi S. Anseth, a professor of chemical and biological engineering at the University of Colorado, likes to break barriers. She does this almost obliviously, and in doing so, she is helping to change the culture of science.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLACKWELL, ELSIE WILSON
description: BLACKWELL--Elsie Wilson, 93. Of Basking Ridge, New Jersey, formerly of Dorset, VT, Short Hills, NJ, and Point O'Woods, NY, on November 26, 2005. Daughter of Susie M. and Edward T. Wilson of Denver, CO, she graduated from Mt. Vernon Seminary where she later served as a trustee and Sarah Lawrence College. Her husband of 71 years, Edward S., Jr. predeceased her in July. She is survived by her brother, Robert B. Wilson, her children, Janet Bent, Edward S. Blackwell III, and Marion Meserole, nine grandchildren and ten great grandchildren. Memorial service at Christ Church, Short Hills, NJ at 10 A.M. on Friday, December 2. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Southern Vermont Arts Center, P.O. Box 617, West Road, Manchester, VT. 05252.

title: Official at stem cell hubsees harm from scandal
Paid Notice: Deaths   FEINBERG, ARTHUR W. M.D.
description: FEINBERG--Arthur W. M.D. Age 82, died on November 28, 2005. Loving husband of Harriet Newman Cohen Feinberg, and before that of Jean Dilbert Feinberg, the wife he lost in 1973, devoted father of Nancy Rheingrover (Jim), David Feinberg (Madeleine), Martha Cohen Stine (Carl), Amy Ziegelbaum (Michael), Susan Hirsch (Bruce), Patricia Epstein (Stephen) and doting grandfather of Jennifer, Andrew, Gillian, Matthew, Eric, Benjamin, Ezra, Zachary, Gabriel, Sarah, Jonathan, Jacob, Oliver and Natalie, brother of Martin Feinberg, he was a man without equal in any century. Beloved by all, a brilliant physician (internist and geriatrician), he leaves this world in deep mourning. A proud graduate of Boys High School, Columbia College and Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, he served as an Army doctor in the Philippine Islands at the end of World War II. A founding doctor of North Shore University Hospital and a leader in medical education, he was the Associate Director of the Department of Medicine from 1974 until 1989. He received a Federal grant to establish one of the first primary care training programs in the country. Dr. Feinberg was also Dean of Admissions at Cornell University Medical College, was involved with the medical students for many years and was honored with AOA membership. When asked by NSUH, he became the first Director of the NSUH's Center for Extended Care and Rehabilitation upon its opening and the first Chief of the Division of Geriatric Medicine at NSUH. He was a founding father of the Division of Ambulatory Care that brings home care to the frail and elderly. His commitment to the problems of vascular disease led to his establishment of the Vascular Diseases laboratory at NSUH. The CECR's Home Visit program for the elderly was created by Dr. Feinberg. He was also a leader of the American College of Physicians, where he chaired their Postgraduate Education Committee, was a leader of their Ethics Committee and served as a Regent of the College. He was honored by being named a Master of the ACP. Dr. Feinberg was the Chair of the NSUH Ethics Committee and at the time of his death, he held the rank of Professor of Clinical Medicine at NYU School of Medicine. He wrote extensively, including a medical column for Newsday and hosted a television program on Lifetime Medical Television. At the time of his death, Dr. Feinberg was teaching medical interns at Long Island Jewish Medical Center, writing articles for continuing medical education, working for the New York State Office of Professional Medical Conduct, giving his sought after medical lectures and providing counsel and comfort to all, professionally and personally. His loss to vascular disease is profound and unspeakable. We will love you and miss you forever. Funeral Services Wednesday, November 30th, at 1:15 p.m., "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENFIELD, HARRIET COPELIN
description: GREENFIELD -- Harriet Copelin. Formerly of Hartland, VT and New York City, died Friday, November 25, 2005 in Palm Beach Gardens, FL, after a long illness. She was 82 years old. She is survived by her five children; Juliet G. Six & Faith G. Lewis both of Washington, DC, Gordon K. Greenfield Jr. of Norwich, VT, Hope Greenfield of Oldwick, NJ, and James D. Greenfield of New York City; by a brother, Donald E. Copelin of Ketchum, ID; and by 8 grandchildren. Her husband of 60 years, Gordon K. Greenfield, died this past January. Harriet Greenfield was best known for her dedication to charitable causes, especially those involving children. In 1995 she received the Helenka Pantaleoni Award from the U.S. Committee for UNICEF for her work as Founder and CoChair of the New York City Chapter. She served on the Board of the Youth Counseling League and the World Adoption International Fund (WAIF). In the 1980's she was Chairman of the Women's Division of The New York Chapter of the Arthritis Foundation. She joined the staff of The National Red Cross in 1984 to develop their Jr. Committee where she earned The Steuben Apple Award. She also joined her husband as a patron of music in New York, as a key fundraiser for the Opera Orchestra Society. Additionally, she served as President of the Board of Immigration and Refugee Services of America (IRSA), and its subsidiary, The U.S. Committee for Refugees (USCR), from 1993-1997, and on its Board from 1989 to 2001. In Vermont, she served on the Boards of Historic Windsor and Lebanon College, Lebanon, NH. Harriet Greenfield, born in Philadelphia, was a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, 1943. A burial service will be held in December in Hartland, VT. Please send donations to Hospice of Palm Beach County, Florida.

description: WILSON -- Katherine Stern. The Board of Trustees, Medical Staff and Administration of Hospital for Special Surgery mourn with profound sorrow the death of Katherine (Kit) Wilson. She captured the essence of elegance and was a pillar of support for the Hospital. She exemplified the tradition of leadership among her peers which has long been a hallmark of the relationship of the Wilson family to HSS. She will be greatly missed. To her husband, Dr. Philip D. Wilson, Jr. our Surgeon-in-Chief Emeritus, and her entire family, we express our profound sympathy. Dr. Wilson has requested donations in Mrs. Wilson's honor be made to the Nursing, Research and Education Program at Hospital for Special Surgery. title: Keeping the Old Cabaret Alive in the Land of 'Cabaret'
description: BERLIN - In the grand style of performers from Germany's Weimar Republic, Max Raabe likes to party like it's 1929. A recent concert by Mr. Raabe and his Palast Orchester at the Leipzig Opera House included a selection of songs from the 1920's and 30's, witty banter between numbers and the occasional appearance of eight dancing girls in diaphanous skirts. At various points in the show, members of the band took the stage in traditional Bavarian dress and suits that looked tailored for Chicago gangsters, and kneeled in their shoes to appear as if they were about four feet tall.

title: A Victory for Education
description: A federal judge in Michigan took exactly the right action last week when he dismissed a transparent attempt by the National Education Association, the nation's largest teachers' union, to sabotage the No Child Left Behind education act. The ruling validates Congress's right to require the states to administer tests and improve students' performance in exchange for federal education aid. Unfortunately, it will not put an end to the ongoing campaign to undermine the law, which seeks to hold teachers and administrators more closely accountable for how their schools perform.

title: Think Inside the Box
description: THIS week President Bush will seek to focus the nation's attention on border security and immigration reform. But the president's proposals won't protect Americans from our gravest cross-border threat: the possibility that a ship, truck or train will one day import a 40-foot cargo container in which terrorists have hidden a dirty bomb or nuclear weapon.

Dakota Fanning (left, with Ms. Walters) screamed when the Martians invaded. Teri Hatcher enjoyed her big career comeback on "Desperate Housewives." title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Merck to Close Five Plants And Lay Off 7,000 Employees Merck, the drug maker, plans to close five manufacturing plants by 2008 and lay off 7,000 employees, about 11 percent of its work force, as it struggles with falling sales and profits. The cuts follow a similar announcement from Pfizer in March and are the latest sign of the crisis faced by major drug makers as patents on some of their most profitable medicines expire. In June, Merck will begin to face low-priced generic competition on Zocor, a cholesterol-lowering drug that is its top-selling medicine. [Page C1.]

Paid Notice: Deaths   SULZBERGER, MAYE (NEE DORFMAN)
description: SULZBERGER--Maye (nee Dorfman). Died Saturday night, November 26th, with her daughter and grandson at her bedside. She is survived by her daughter, Susan Sulzberger Rolfe, grandson Myron Sulzberger (Mickey) Rolfe, granddaughters Joanne (Jody) Quinn and her husband Roger, and Penny R. Sullivan and her husband Tim. Also survived by three great grandsons, Billy and Teddy Quinn, and Tommy Sullivan. Reunited at last with her adored late husband, Edward, from whom she was widowed for 17 years. The daughter of the late Louis and Anna Dorfman, and predeceased by her sister, Paula Blum, Maye is also survived by her sister, Charlotte Rosenfield, and by nieces and nephews, and by many friends and bridge partners in New York City. She was a member of the Regency Whist Club, the Harmonie Club and the Quaker Ridge Country Club. Our family is indebted to Sophia Sanchez for her steadfast care and love for 30 years, and, more recently, to the four wonderful nurses who tended to Maye as if she was their own. We will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street on Tuesday from 6-9 P.M. with services Wednesday, 11;30 A.M. Interment private. Family will be at Susan Rolfe's home on Thursday from 3-7. Memorial contributions, if desired, to Mount Sinai Medical Center, attention Dr. Alvin Teirstein, 1 Gustav Levy Place, NY, NY 10029. She was fierce and brave, a boss, and we loved her.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Gazprom Chafing at Ukraine Deal
description: The Russian natural gas company Gazprom indicated yesterday that its patience was wearing thin with a decade-old barter deal that gave Ukraine cheap energy in place of transit fees on gas shipments. In a statement, Gazprom accused Ukraine of "sabotaging" natural gas supplies to Western Europe by demanding subsidies in the 2006 contract. This month, Russia's prime minister canceled a trip to Kiev as negotiations unraveled. Ukraine now pays $50 a cubic meter, about 30 percent of the market price. Andrew Kramer (NYT)

title: Holiday Travel Report
description: HOLIDAY TRAVEL REPORT -- Despite record crowds and reduced capacity, airport security checkpoint systems performed well over the Thanksgiving holiday travel period, according to an annual survey by the online booking site Travelocity. As one example, Travelocity said, monitors at security checkpoints at the 25 busiest airports in the United States reported "slightly shorter wait times than in 2004 and minimal delays over all."

title: New chip from TI to lower costs
Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the 92nd Street Y's decision to reverse its longtime policy of closing its gym for the Sabbath misstated the location of the Jewish Community Center in Manhattan, whose gym has always remained open then. It is on Amsterdam Avenue at West 76th Street; it is not on West 86th. (The Jewish Center on West 86th, an Orthodox synagogue, has an exercise room for children, but it is closed for the Sabbath.)

title: France fines 5-star Paris hotels for collusion on room rates

Across the U.S., Debate Over the President's Plan
description: At a 7-Eleven in Farmingville, N.Y., where security guards chase the immigrant day laborers from the parking lot, a husband and wife stopped their shopping long enough yesterday to disagree over President Bush's two-edged plan for such workers: to stop them at the Mexican border if they cross illegally, or to offer them temporary guest worker visas if they follow the rules.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Campaign Totals Filed
description: The final number was $75 million. That was what Sen. Jon S. Corzine and Douglas R. Forrester spent, combined, out of their fortunes in the most expensive governor's race in state history. According to finance reports submitted yesterday by the campaigns, Mr. Corzine, a former chief executive of Goldman Sachs who defeated Mr. Forrester by 9 percentage points, spent $39 million in the general election, and $5 million in an uncontested primary. As for the $310 million spent by Mr. Forrester, a founder of a pharmacy benefits management company, $19 million was spent during the general election, and $12 million in a hotly contested primary.

title: The Neediest Cases; Outlook Brightens After a New Kidney and Some Help With the Rent
description: Noemi Pinto and Frank Talavera shared an unusual honeymoon. Several hours after exchanging vows at City Hall in late September, Mr. Talavera held his wife's hand as she was wheeled into an operating room for a kidney transplant. He had asked her to marry him several times during their seven-year relationship, and Ms. Pinto had always refused, saying their relationship didn't need a piece of paper for validation. This time, it was she who popped not the question, but the answer.

title: 'New York, New York,' Queens Style
description: IT felt odd to eschew the special glasses usually required to view the Mets' splashy off-season moves and weird to stare right into the sunny disposition of Carlos Delgado without the shadow of the Boss moving over Queens.

title: Ahold to Pay $1.1 Billion to Settle Fraud Suits
description: NIJMEGEN, the Netherlands, Nov. 28 - Royal Ahold, the Dutch supermarket giant, said Monday that it would pay shareholders worldwide $1.1 billion to settle class-action lawsuits that were threatening to derail the company's turnaround.

title: Thomas Oliphant: Slouching toward withdrawal
Q & A
description: Battered Brains

title: The iPod Invisa and the iPod Flea
description: A number of friends have asked if I saw the "Saturday Night Live" spoof of Steve Jobs premiering ever-smaller iPod models, all the way down to the iPod Invisa.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEINGART, VIVIEN
description: WEINGART--Vivien. Age 59 years, on November 28, 2005 of leukemia. Preceded in death by her husband Laurence. Survived by her son Michael, her sister Gloria Merker, as well as aunts, nieces, nephews, cousins and in-laws. She loves her family, her friends, her cats & all the beauties of nature. She went forth in peace & joy. May her memory be for a blessing.

title: Virginia Governor Commutes Death Sentence
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 - Gov. Mark R. Warner of Virginia granted clemency today to a convicted killer, declaring that the loss of a crucial piece of evidence had persuaded him that the defendant should not be put to death as scheduled on Wednesday.

title: Arts, Briefly; Political Dramas and Documentaries at Sundance
description: The lineup for the 2006 Sundance Film Festival will include documentaries about racial politics and the war in Iraq, and feature films about issues in American society, like drugs and divorce. It also includes a feature called "Wristcutters -- A Love Story," billed as an offbeat comedy, in which everybody's dead. The festival is to announce its slate of 64 feature films today in competition for four main categories: American documentary and dramatic categories, and foreign documentaries and dramas. Geoffrey Gilmore, its director, said the festival would feature more risky films than it has recently. A number of the films "may not play very broadly in the mainstream," he said in an interview. The full lineup of 120 films, to be announced in coming weeks, was chosen from 3,148 submissions, a rise from 2,613 last year, and a sign that the festival continues to attract aspiring filmmakers in a digital age. Three documentaries deal with Iraq, including one focusing on the effect of the war on returning American veterans, and another on ordinary Iraqis. One thriller in the dramatic competition imagines a day in which dirty bombs are detonated in Los Angeles. The festival will be held Jan. 19 to 29 in Park City, Utah. SHARON WAXMAN

title: At Rio Grande, Bush Stresses Border Security
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 - President Bush stood next to the Rio Grande in El Paso today, a stone's throw from Mexico, as he spoke out again for his immigration policies, declaring that border security is essential for national and economic security.

title: Fires Kill Man in Brooklyn and Injure 14 Firefighters and 4 Others in Queens
description: A fire in Elmhurst, Queens, tore through the top of an apartment building last night, injuring 4 civilians and 14 firefighters, including one who was hospitalized on a respirator.

title: The Ever-Ready Martin Is a Textbook in Humility
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., Nov. 28 - There are professional football players who sulk if they reach a milestone -- say, 100 touchdown receptions -- and a big production is not made of it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLAND, MICHAEL BUCKNER
description: KELLAND--Michael Buckner, 62. Died peacefully at his home in New York City on November 27 with his family at his side. He fought a courageous battle and ultimately succumbed to cancer. Beloved husband of Lisa Cobey Kelland and loving father of three children, Jennifer Pierson Kelland of Providence,RI, Michael Cobey Kelland, 14, and William Buckner Kelland, 13. He is also survived by two brothers, Thomas Kelland of Sottsdale, AZ and James Kelland of Palm Desert, CA and an uncle, Horace Kelland, of Charleston, SC. Michael was born on March 29, 1943 in Phoenix, Arizona to Mary Buckner and Thomas Smith Kelland. He graduated from The Westminster School, Stanford University and the Wharton School of Business and went to work for Citibank, where he spent his entire career. He served on Citicorp's Policy committee and was in charge of Investment Banking activities for South America and Japan/Australia until his retirement in 1990. At his retirement, Michael became a painter, concentrating on narrative forms and architectural compositions in oil. He was a resident of New York City, Shelter Island, NY and Hydra, Greece. His wry humor and memorable insights will be fondly remembered and greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. Bernard's School, 4 East 98th Street, New York, NY 10029 or Calvary Hospital Hospice, 1740 Eastchester Rd, Bronx, NY 10461.

title: Best Had Chance to Play for Cosmos
description: Thirty years ago, George Best was a signature away from coming to the United States to play for the Cosmos.

title: Drugs Found to Have Effect on Alzheimer's Disease
description: A new study suggests that cholesterol-lowering drugs like statins and fibrates may slow the course of Alzheimer's disease.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the "Arts, Briefly" column yesterday about the top-grossing movies over the Thanksgiving holiday misstated the Wednesday-through-Sunday totals of "Chicken Little" and "Just Friends," and of the top 12 movies. "Chicken Little" and "Just Friends" took in $16.7 million and $13.6 million; $12.4 million and $9.3 million were their Friday-Sunday totals. The top 12 films grossed $218 million; $151 million was their total for Friday through Sunday.

description: ALLEN--Allen S. We all miss you for always. Love and Happy Birthday. Fay

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Uribe Announces Re-Election Run
description: A month after the country's highest court ruled he could run for a second consecutive term, President lvaro Uribe formally announced that he would seek re-election in May and continue the tough security policies that have rolled back the Marxist rebel groups that have waged war here since 1964. Mr. Uribe will be hard to beat; his popularity rating is above 70 percent. His opponents charge that he has been soft on right-wing paramiltary groups, permitting them to consolidate their hold in much of northern Colombia. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Knicks Hit a Roadblock on the Way to Progress
description: MIAMI, Nov. 28 - The fantastic chasm that separates the Knicks from the league's elite teams was glaring Monday night, as stark and as imposing as Alonzo Mourning's biceps and as devastating as Dwyane Wade's gravity-defying hops.

title: Militants in Iraq Threaten to Kill German Archaeologist
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 29 - A prominent German archaeologist and aid worker who had lived and worked in Iraq for years has been kidnapped, the German government confirmed today as images of her surrounded by masked, armed men were broadcast on international television.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COOK, CLAIRE ROSE KEHRWALD
description: COOK--Claire Rose Kehrwald. Died peacefully at home on November 23, 2005 at age 78. Author of "Line by Line: How to Edit Your Own Writing" (Houghton Mifflin/ MLA), editorial director for the Modern Language Association from 1976 until her retirement in 1992. She delighted in words, language, literature, crossword puzzles, and double crostics; she loved rewriting; she celebrated grammar for its service to the clarity of expression. Raised in Cranford, NJ; alumna of New Jersey College for Women (Douglass College); Master's in literature from Syracuse University. Widow of H. James Cook, beloved mother of Karen and Cassandra, mother-in-law of Bill Tivenan. We will miss her. Any contributions in her memory may be made to the New York Restoration Project.

description: OMAR MINAYA had already gained a reputation among his baseball brethren as an aggressive general manager, and yesterday he demonstrated his aggressiveness twofold.

description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 - As a lawyer in the Reagan Justice Department, Samuel A. Alito Jr., the Supreme Court nominee, played an active role in advancing the administration's efforts to expand law enforcement powers and limit restrictions on prosecutors, documents released Monday by the Justice Department show.

description: THE Momentum Worldwide division of the McCann Erickson Worldgroup is bolstering its creative ranks. The move underscores the growing attention paid by big agencies to realms outside traditional advertising, like promotions, public relations, sponsorships and event marketing.

description: THE madeleines rest on the baker's rack, pastry feathers with a dusting of powdered sugar. A chocolaty cupcake with flamingo pink frosting is perched under a glass dome, not too far from the jar of coffee toffee cookies, all practically begging to be tasted.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with an article on Thursday about efforts by Kane County, Utah, to claim roads under federal control at the Grand Staircase-Escalante National Monument and to encourage the use of recreational vehicles there misspelled the name of a park where riders raced all-terrain vehicles. It is the Coral Pink Sand Dunes State Park, not Coral Pin.

title: As the Winter Looms
description: Members of Congress left Washington before Thanksgiving and don't plan to return until mid-December. They took off without approving any money to help poor Americans pay their heating bills this winter. They failed to pass the bill that included $2 billion in home heating subsidies that they had agreed to allocate as long ago as last spring. They also failed to come up with the additional $3 billion that is needed to cover the big price jumps in various fuels since Hurricane Katrina.

title: Pole blames Blair for EU budget woes
Gold prices test highs not seen since the 1980s
Is There a Link Between Stress and Cancer?
description: Christina Koenig found out she had breast cancer on a Friday afternoon. She was just 39 years old.

title: 'Idol' Star and Producer Settle, Clearing Way for Future Shows
description: Simon Cowell, the star of the Fox network's biggest hit, "American Idol," cleared the way for his continued participation in the show yesterday when he settled a lawsuit brought by Simon Fuller, the producer of the series.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the creation of a task force to determine why a giant balloon knocked a light fixture onto two spectators at the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade referred incorrectly to the response of an NBC publicist who was asked about its coverage, which did not mention the accident. The publicist, Lauren Kapp, replied "none are reachable today" when asked by a reporter whether the announcers could be reached for comment; she was not asked whether they knew about the accident at the time of the telecast.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: $2 Billion Arms Deal With Spain
description: Snubbing American concerns, President Hugo Chvez signed a $2 billion arms deal with Spain to buy 8 patrol boats and 12 military transport and patrol planes. His government is also seeking to obtain combat aircraft from Brazil and 100,000 assault rifles from Russia. American officials had warned Spain that the Bush administration was mulling over whether to restrict the transfer of American technology used in the planes, but Madrid moved forward on the deal.

title: In Egypt, a Vote More for Change Than Faith
description: MAZGHOUNA, Egypt, Nov. 28 - When the Muslim Brotherhood says, "Islam is the Solution," Osama Imam hopes they are talking about unemployment.

title: Mexican Leader Plans to Broaden Antidrug Enforcement Offices
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 28 - In an effort to fight harder against a growing domestic drug problem, President Vicente Fox announced Monday that the Constitution had been amended to allow local officials to investigate certain federal crimes, including drug trafficking.

description: Correction Appended

Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Charged With Subway Killing
description: A Brooklyn man has been charged with murder after his friend was killed by a subway train on Sunday at the 51st Street and Roosevelt Avenue station in Woodside, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. The man, Richie Molina, 19, of Humboldt Street, was charged with second-degree murder in the death of his friend, Edison Guzman, left. In a statement, Mr. Brown said that Mr. Molina had beaten Mr. Guzman, 22, after a dispute in the station early on Sunday morning and rolled him onto the subway tracks. A No. 7 train struck Mr. Guzman as it entered the station.

title: Maurice S. Paprin, 85, Builder and Advocate for Liberal Causes, Is Dead
description: Maurice Sanford Paprin, a retired New York builder and property owner with another life as a liberal social activist, died on Friday at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital in Manhattan. He was 85 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Chairman of Beleaguered Liquor Authority Retires
description: ALBANY, Nov. 28 - The chairman of the State Liquor Authority stepped down on Monday, leaving an agency that has come under fire recently from critics who say it has not done enough to enforce the state's liquor laws.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "In my life, I have known great joy and great sorrow. And now I know great shame."

title: What's the Buzz? Rowdy Teenagers Don't Want to Hear It
description: BARRY, Wales - Though he did not know it at the time, the idea came to Howard Stapleton when he was 12 and visiting a factory with his father, a manufacturing executive in London. Opening the door to a room where workers were using high-frequency welding equipment, he found he could not bear to go inside.

title: Combative Saddam back in court
Paid Notice: Memorials  NIMITZ, MCDANIEL, MARY LOUISE
description: NIMITZ - McDANIEL -- Mary Louise, 1909--1995, was born in San Angelo, TX, to Mary Ella Holland & Louis Otto Nimitz. She was sister to Ernest, Susan, Theresa and Louis Nimitz and wife of Hugh Hines McDaniel. Louise lovingly raised her children in Demarest, NJ. She was a dedicated and caring Director of Volunteers at Milwaukee Children's Hospital (1961-1978). She also created lovely flower gardens and restored antique furniture. Louise was an angel of kindness and purity who now "dwells in the house of the Lord forever..." and is lovingly remembered today and always by her daughter Susan McDaniel of Woburn, MA

title: In Calcutta, creaking toward privatization
Florida School Is Target of Inquiry
description: The Florida High School Athletic Association announced yesterday that it was starting an inquiry into University High School, a correspondence school where several students quickly improved their grades to gain college eligibility.

title: People
description: Tim Love, president for global clients at the Tokyo office of TBWA Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, was promoted to a new post, vice chairman at Omnicom, based in New York and responsible for working with Omnicom agencies to help Omnicom's largest global clients. Mr. Love is expected to focus his efforts on clients like Procter & Gamble.

title: New Jersey Man Is Killed in Fire
description: WHARTON, N.J., Nov. 28 - A man died Monday afternoon when a fire broke out in a house stuffed with boxes filled with videos and DVD's of old movies, the authorities said.

title: Corrections
description: The "Really?" column in Science Times on Nov. 22, about the relationship of colds to cold weather, misstated the location of a research center that subjected study participants to icy water on their bare feet and found that they appeared more susceptible to the cold virus than their counterparts who were kept dry. The facility, the Common Cold Center, is in Wales, not England.

An Ordinary Day, and a Welcome One, at Ben Franklin Elementary
description: NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 28 - A sound unusual in this still-emptied city echoed through an old brick school building here Monday: the noise made by chattering, scampering children.

description: With two weeks to go before its contract with 33,738 subway and bus workers expires, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is asking for more flexibility in work assignments, tighter sick leave rules and less substantial health care and pension benefits for future employees.

description: When the 30-year-old accountant at WNYC told his co-workers at the public radio station that he was leaving his job of nine years for a new career, they were shocked.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOROWITZ, LEWIS J.
description: HOROWITZ--Lewis J. Aged 70, November 25, 2005. Beloved husband of Jo Ann Malkin Horowitz, loving father of Jay (Suzanne) and Stephen (Dorsey), dear stepfather of Harold Malkin (Jennifer) and Jill Addeo (Geoffrey) and adored grandfather Max, Ben, Leo, Ryan and Olivia. Born February 13, 1935, graduated Barnard School For Boys and Brown University '56. Partner in specialist firm of Phelan, Silver until 1982. Past Chairman of New York Futures Exchange and an Executive Vice-President of The New York Stock Exchange. Retired in 1995, and became a full time volunteer on the pediatric floor of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center where he has spent the past ten years. Former President of Ramapo Anchorage Camp, ex board member of Downtown Hospital and active in Junior Achievement and Principal for a Day. During his financial career, Lew was known for his electric neckties and during his volunteer career, for his collection of fabulous hats. Lew brought smiles and good humor everywhere he went. He is loved by so many and will be deeply missed by all whose lives he touched. Donations in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center (MSKCC) for the Lewis Horowitz Pediatric Recreation Fund, 1275 York Ave., NY, NY 10021 attention Nina J. Pickett. Memorial service, Wednesday, November 30, at 4PM, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St.

title: Questioning the War, Not the Valor
description: To the Editor:

title: Fight for votes starts after Canada government falls
Stent vs. Scalpel
description: After Linda Packer, a 64-year-old social worker in Manhattan, fell twice over the Memorial Day weekend and felt vaguely unwell, a series of tests revealed a serious problem: one of the two main arteries carrying blood to her brain was more than 80 percent blocked by plaque.

title: At Hussein Trial, First Testimony and New Bluster
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Nov. 28 - Saddam Hussein returned to court on Monday and quickly seized the floor for a verbal assault on the American military guards who, he said, had treated him and the Koran he was holding disrespectfully on his way to the courtroom.

title: Soft Spot for Americans, Endorsed by Rabbits and Puddle-Ducks
description: AMHERST, Mass. - Whoa, those of you who think that Potter in children's books means only Harry. There is another Potter in the field, by the name of Beatrix (1866-1943), and that Harry character has a long way to go before topping her more than 100 years of success. Her "Tale of Peter Rabbit," first published in 1902, is still picking up new readers.

title: Giants-Seahawks Pulls In Viewers
description: The Giants' 24-21 overtime loss to Seattle on Sunday generated a 17.6 preliminary overnight Nielsen rating on Fox, making it the most-watched regular-season N.F.L. game on any network since Fox's broadcast of the Jets-Green Bay game in December 2002. That game had a rating of 19.2. The Seattle market posted a 28.9 rating, the highest for a regular-season N.F.L. game on Fox. The New York market generated a 19.7 rating.

title: F.A.A. Calls for Mediation in Talks With Controllers
description: Correction Appended

title: South Koreans Rush to Defend Cloning Researcher Against Criticism
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 28 - Days after his televised fall from grace, Hwang Woo Suk, South Korea's cloning pioneer, re-emerged Monday as a national hero as the country rallied around him in an outpouring of nationalism and sympathy for the goals of his stem cell research.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PETTY, HENRY L.
description: PETTY--Henry L. In Westport, CT. Husband of Lois Petty, stepfather of Giulietta Ryan, beloved son of the late William and Helen Petty, brother of William C. Petty of Bronxville, New York, Michael Petty of Silver Springs, Maryland, Dr. Barbara Heuer of NYC, Deborah Dalton of Cooperstown, NY & Connee Young of Petaluma, CA, grandfather of Hazel Ryan. Memorial service Sunday, December 4, 2 PM, St. Paul Lutheran Church, Westport, CT.

title: Putin's Candidates Sweep Chechnya Elections
description: Chechnya's parliamentary elections on Sunday, the first since Russian forces started a second war in the republic in 1999, proceeded as expected. A party loyal to President Vladimir V. Putin won an overwhelming majority of votes, according to preliminary results announced yesterday, and will control the two chambers of a newly created Parliament. Mr. Putin praised the vote as the final step to constitutional order in the republic, while Chechnya's separatists denounced it as a farce. Rights organizations and international monitors reported flaws and evidence of manipulation in the count. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Stockbroker Sentenced For Fraud
description: A stockbroker who used his purported celebrity connections to woo clients was sentenced to 4 to 12 years in prison yesterday for defrauding clients and ordered to make $5.8 million in restitution. The stockbroker, Calvin R. Darden Jr., 31, pleaded guilty in August to four counts of grand larceny and a count of scheming to defraud 11 clients and employers. Victims included the N.B.A. star Latrell Sprewell. Prosecutors said Mr. Darden used the money to buy a mansion in Glen Cove, on Long Island, and to purchase a $200,000 aquarium, a home theater, a $93,000 piano, a harp, artwork and jewelry and to lease a Lamborghini and a Porsche. Anemona Hartocollis (NYT)

title: Mothballed legend gets a 2nd chance
Gunfire, Fraud and a Stolen Lion: In Gaza Voting, Chaos Wins
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 28 - Palestinian gunmen, shooting into the air, pushed their way into polling places in Gaza on Monday and forced the postponement of primary elections for the main Palestinian party, Fatah, led by President Mahmoud Abbas.

title: Nuclear Waste Plan For Yucca Mountain
description: To the Editor:

title: The Autobiography of Donovan: The Hurdy Gurdy Man
The Hunt for Hercules N8183J
description: A bitter debate over torture has erupted in Europe. Washington is believed to have used EU countries as transit points for moving terrorism suspects to clandestine locations where they may have been tortured. The Council of Europe and other organizations are now demanding answers -- from the US and European countries who looked the other way.

title: Strangling freedom in its cradle
A Baritone and a Pianist in a Harmonious Conversation
description: The Frick Collection presented an uncommonly elegant young German baritone on Sunday afternoon. Singing Schumann, Ravel, Wolf and some other music you might not know, Christian Immler formed a satisfying partnership with his pianist, Silvia Fraser.

title: Questioning the War, Not the Valor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Line of Sand Gets Thinner
description: BEACH HAVEN, N.J. - Robert Pacicco has owned the two-story house on the end of Merivale Avenue for a decade, but the Atlantic Ocean now seems poised to move in for the winter and beyond. Last winter, the waves broke over the foundation slab, from which the house rises on stilts. This year, half the pilings under the foundation have been exposed by the tides.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Death On Tracks Shuts Down Train Line
description: An apparent suicide by someone who jumped in front of a New Jersey Transit train a mile west of the Convent Station stop resulted in delays on several trains on the Morristown Line beginning about 7:30 p.m. yesterday, the authorities said. Dan Stessel, a New Jersey Transit spokesman, said last night that the engineer on a westbound train that had left Penn Station in Manhattan at 6:16 p.m. saw someone jump on the tracks about 7:25 p.m. The person, whose identity had not been determined late last night, was declared dead at the scene. Mr. Stessel said the 100 passengers on the train that hit the man were transferred to another train, and several other westbound trains were delayed until 10:30 p.m. Eastbound train service was suspended, he said, and passengers were offered bus service between Summit and Dover.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Shelter Conditions Criticized
description: A 335-room city homeless shelter in South Ozone Park was infested with roaches and had water-damaged walls, broken doors and peeling paint, according to an audit City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. released yesterday. "In every unit we checked," Mr. Thompson said, "we found horrible conditions." The auditors visited the shelter in 2004. It has since closed for lack of residents, the audit said. In a written response to Mr. Thompson's office, the Department of Homeless Services agreed that the shelter, which was managed by the Salvation Army, had some problems, but said its own inspectors "found no immediate health or safety threat at the facility."

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Groups File Papers To Stop Bear Hunt
description: Two animal rights groups, the New Jersey Animal Rights Alliance and the Bear Education and Resource Group, yesterday asked the state Superior Court to block next week's scheduled black bear hunt. Kevin Barber, a lawyer representing the groups, said the justification for the hunt was not based upon proper scientific research. If the court permits the six-day hunt, set to begin on Dec. 5, it will be New Jersey's second in 35 years. Karen Hershey, a spokeswoman for the state Department of Environmental Protection, would not comment on the lawsuit.

title: Roundup: Mets to add Wagner in $43 million deal
Paid Notice: Memorials   MAXIM, LESLIE M.
description: MAXIM--Leslie M. 11/29/17-6/23/96. Happy Birthday, Dear Husband. Loving remembrances of a charming, dynamic super-gentleman. Your loving wife, Pearl

title: Justices Reject F.B.I. Translator's Appeal on Termination
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 - The Supreme Court refused on Monday to hear an appeal by a former F.B.I. translator of Middle Eastern languages who asserted that she was terminated for trying to expose ineptitude and espionage within the bureau's translation section.

title: Home Sales Fall 2.7%, Suggesting a Drag on '06 Economy
description: Sales of existing homes fell 2.7 percent last month and the inventory of houses and condominiums on the market rose to the highest monthly level in more than two years, an industry trade group reported yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLACK, DONALD MILLER
description: BLACK--Donald Miller. Passed away on Nov. 6, 2005 in Redding, CT. Born Denison, TX. April 18, 1922. Husband of Elizabeth for 58 years. Graduate of RPI (BS 1942), recruited to the Manhattan Project from MIT to which he returned after W.W. II (PhD 1947 and Sigma Xi Honorary Society); then embarked on a 40 year career in the chemical industry. Survived by his wife, sister Barbara Boyd, sons Donald and Thomas, daughters Holly Grillo and Barbara Quinn, nephew John Boyd, niece Nina Mahaffey, nine grandchildren and one great grandchild.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Judge Rejects Leniency Plea
description: A state judge yesterday rejected a plea for leniency from a former construction executive who admitted to stealing millions of dollars from a Trump Tower interior renovation while he was on probation for a conviction in a previous kickback scheme. Justice Edward J. McLaughlin of State Supreme Court in Manhattan angrily told the executive, Ted Kohl, whose company was called IDI, for "I Deserve It," that it was "offensive" for him to expect special treatment because he was middle class and had committed a white-collar crime. In October, Mr. Kohl pleaded guilty to stealing $2.5 million during the renovation of the Asprey luxury goods store in Trump Tower. In exchange, he was sentenced to 4 years, 4 months, to 10 years in state prison. His lawyer had asked for a shorter sentence so Mr. Kohl would not be sent to a medium-security prison.

title: AIDS Goal Missed, but Effort by U.N. Branch Is Praised
description: The World Health Organization's failure to meet a goal of treating three million H.I.V.-infected people by the end of this year owes to inadequate international coordination and lack of national leadership, a group of leading advocates for AIDS patients said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ETKIN, ALEX J.
description: ETKIN--Alex J. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Alex J. Etkin of Detroit, whose six decades of devotion to our organization stand as a beacon of unflagging support. He served in multiple leadership positions, including on the ATS Board of Directors, Board of Regents, and as vice president of the Detroit Chapter. In 2000, his son Douglas established the annual Alex J. Etkin Young Leadership Award in his honor to encourage new chapter leaders. Together with his wife, Toby, Mr. Etkin established academic chairs and the A.J. Etkin International Seminar on Strategic Planning in Construction at the Technion. The annual seminar was an outgrowth of Mr. Etkin's successful career in construction, having developed some of Detroit's most important buildings. A Technion Guardian who reached the highest level of support for Israel, the Technion and the ATS, Mr. Etkin was awarded an honorary fellowship from the Technion in 1995. We extend our condolences to his wife Toby, sons Douglas and Bruce Etkin, daughter Barbra Alter, and the entire Etkin family. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Stephen A. Laser, President Evelyn Berger, Chairman Melvyn H. Bloom Executive Vice President Scott Leemaster Detroit Chapter President Matthew T. Engelbert East Central Region Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FILER, SANTINA M. (TINA)
description: FILER--Santina M. (Tina) November 27, 2005. Beloved wife, mother, sister, aunt, godmother and Gammy. Visiting Wednesday 2-5 & 7-9pm McLaughlin Funeral Home, Third Ave at 97 St, Brooklyn.

title: Arts, Briefly; Big Week for 'Rent' On Broadway
description: Call it a happy Thanksgiving or a case of well-timed synergy, but "Rent," the musical, set a box office record last week even as "Rent," the movie (starring Idina Menzel, right, among others), was opening to somewhat disappointing sales. The Broadway show, which has been playing at the Nederlander Theater for more than nine years, grossed $744,496, while playing to nearly 97 percent capacity. The movie, meanwhile, brought in a little more than $18 million from Wednesday to Sunday, according to studio estimates. "Rent" was far from the only show to take advantage of the tourist-rich turkey holiday in New York; producers for several other Broadway productions, including "Jersey Boys," "Monty Python's Spamalot" and "Mamma Mia!" were also reporting record sales. JESSE McKINLEY

title: Lawyers Protest Soldiers at High Court in Uganda
description: Lawyers demonstrated in black robes outside the High Court in Kampala, the capital, to protest the government's use of a heavily armed antiterrorism squad to round up members of an opposition group on trial at the court. The soldiers, left, wearing camouflage pants and black T-shirts and named the Black Mambas by the local press, surrounded the court on Nov. 16 to ensure that 14 people being tried with the jailed opposition leader Kizza Besigye did not get away after being granted bail. The protesting lawyers likened the soldiers' actions to the 1972 abduction and murder of a chief justice during the rule of the late dictator Idi Amin.

description: BERTIN--Sidney. On November 25, 2005. Loving husband of the late Dorothy Bertin. Loving father of Michael & Susan; loving grandfather of Amy, Laura, Sarah, and Anna; great-grandfather of Ted, Allison, Nathan, and Jeffrey. Sidney was a beloved brother and uncle. He was kind, loyal, fun-loving, and devoted to his family and friends. Sidney was a hard worker, a generous provider, and rightfully proud of his achievements. He loved life. Sidney, we will miss you. Funeral services will be November 30, 2005 at 12:30 PM at "Wien & Wien," 402 Park St, Hackensack, NJ 800-322-0533
