title: Think Inside the Box
description: THIS week President Bush will seek to focus the nation's attention on border security and immigration reform. But the president's proposals won't protect Americans from our gravest cross-border threat: the possibility that a ship, truck or train will one day import a 40-foot cargo container in which terrorists have hidden a dirty bomb or nuclear weapon.

title: Arts, Briefly; ABC's Sunday
description: Despite football spillovers into primetime on both CBS and Fox, ABC won another Sunday night in Nielsen's estimates. "Desperate Housewives" (25.73 million) and "Grey's Anatomy" (19.77 million) won their hours in total viewers and adults 18 to 49, and put ABC on top for the night. Fox's football overrun, which lasted until 8:15 on the East Coast, gave the network a particularly strong second-place finish in the 18-to-49 demographic; in fact, it had the network's best Sunday ratings in that age group since the Super Bowl in February. CBS also benefited from a late-running football game, and was No. 2 in total viewers for the night. Its "Cold Case" delivered its largest audience of the season, with about 19.2 million viewers. And "Silver Bells," a CBS made-for-television movie with Anne Heche and Tate Donovan, also did well, with an audience of 16.17 million. KATE AURTHUR

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Vincor Rejects New Offer
description: Vincor, Canada's largest winemaker, rejected an increased hostile takeover bid of $944 million from Constellation Brands, saying the price "falls short." Constellation, already the world's largest winemaker with brands like Robert Mondavi and Opus One, raised its cash tender to 33 Canadian dollars ($28.19), a share from 31 Canadian dollars after Vincor rejected previous proposals three times. Neither the 31-dollar offer nor the 33-dollar bid carried a contingency that Vincor open its books for a due-diligence examination. On Friday, Constellation had made an offer of $35, conditioned on an examination of Vincor's books. Vincor, which is based in Mississauga, Ontario, rejected that offer.

title: Russian Report Faults Rescue Efforts in Beslan
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 29 - The first government investigation to announce its findings on the terrorist attack on School No. 1 in Beslan in September 2004 criticized law-enforcement agencies for a confused and uncoordinated rescue effort and blamed them for allowing the attack in the first place, a lawmaker who led the inquiry said today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, the David Pogue column in Business Day on Thursday, about a small notebook computer called the Flybook, misstated the model number of a competitor from Fujitsu. It is the LifeBook P1510D, not 1501D. The column also referred incorrectly to the storage on the Fujitsu model. In addition to a 30-gigabyte hard drive, a 60-gigabyte version is available, but the Flybook's comparable options, 40 and 80 gigabytes, offer more.

title: Kenya Government Opponents Reject Protest Ban
description: Politicians in a standoff with President Mwai Kibaki vowed to flout his ban on political protests, announced last week after voters overwhelmingly rejected his government's proposed new constitution. The vote has emboldened Mr. Kibaki's critics and prompted the president to dissolve his cabinet and send Parliament home. "Our rallies will go on," said William Ruto, a spokesman for the group of renegade politicians, describing Mr. Kibaki's government as one "in panic." Meanwhile, the country awaits Mr. Kibaki's announcement of his new cabinet. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Honduras: Opposition Candidate Wins Election
description: Manuel Zelaya, left, a logging magnate from the opposition Liberal Party who promised to expand social programs by cutting government spending and rooting out corruption, will be the next president, elections officials announced, even as ballots in the Sunday election were still being counted and final results were not expected for at least 48 hours. Manuel Orozco, a Honduras expert at the Washington-based group Inter-American Dialogue, said the preliminary results seemed to indicate that voters had rejected the platform of Mr. Zelaya's National Party challenger, Porfirio Lobo Sosa, built mostly on strengthening law enforcement efforts against youth gangs, in favor of Mr. Zelaya's promises to fight the poverty and unemployment that have driven young people into gangs. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: Young Players Address Composers of the Past and Future
description: The New York Youth Symphony is the kind of invaluable organization that was plentiful in the 1950's and 60's, but seems anomalous today, when young people supposedly have no interest in classical music. Yet this ensemble, which was founded in 1963, seems not to lack participants. It has a roster of 185 musicians, ages 12 to 22, half from public schools, who rehearse and perform full-fledged repertory works, from Beethoven to Stravinsky, as well as new scores commissioned for them.

title: Arts, Briefly; Friends, Enemies, Colleagues
description: Paris Hilton, below at left, and Nicole Richie, at right, aren't letting a little thing like a bitter feud keep them from working together. Both celebutantes will return for a fourth season of "The Simple Life," which, after being dropped by Fox, will now be shown on the E! cable channel. Ten new half-hour episodes of the series -- now called "The Simple Life: Till Death Do Us Part" -- are to be presented in the spring. E! will pay approximately $700,000 an episode, Variety reported. It has also acquired syndication rights for all of the show's past episodes. In the new season, shot in Los Angeles, Ms. Richie and Ms. Hilton will live as homemakers, competing to see who can better juggle family and household chores. Ted Harbert, the president and chief executive of the network, said he had not tried to broker a truce between the former best friends. "I would never even dream of getting in the middle of these people's lives," he said. Meanwhile, Nick Lachey, the soon to be ex-husband of the singer Jessica Simpson, is also looking to return to television next year. The star of MTV's defunct "Newlyweds: Nick & Jessica," he is set to play a newlywed baseball star in an upcoming pilot for the WB network. Shooting of the half-hour pilot is scheduled to begin in April.

title: Unions and City Spar Over After-School Tutoring

Daughter of the late Max Ehrlich & Gussie Heidecorn. Beloved wife of the late Louis E. Medow. Devoted mother of Dr. Michael J. Fellner and stepmother of Phyllis Jassey & Lyn Medow. Grandmother of Richard Jassey, Jonathan Fellner, Esq., Melinda Fellner Bramwit, Esq., Robin Zimmerman Masiello & Edward Zimmerman. Great-grandmother of Cory Masiello, Nathaniel & Nicholas Fellner, Elle Zimmerman and Harry and Miles Bramwit. Services and interment in Menorah Gardens Memorial Park, Southwest Ranches, Florida. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SYMONETTE, LYS
description: SYMONETTE--Lys. The staff and trustees of the Kurt Weill Foundation mourn the loss of beloved colleague Lys Symonette, who died on Sunday, November 27, at age 90. Musical assistant to Kurt Weill 1945-50, accompanist and advisor of Lotte Lenya 1962-1979, and Musical Executive of the Foundation following Lenya's death in 1981, Lys's contributions to the performance and understanding of Weill's legacy are irreplaceable. Her translations of librettos, editions of Weill's music and correspondence, mentorship of performers, and passionate advocacy for the composer's oeuvre live on as lasting monuments. A gentle, self-effacing, and generous colleague, she was much loved. We extend our deepest sympathies to her son Victor and his family. Kim H. Kowalke, President The Kurt Weill Foundation for Music

title: Chancellor says Germany will not be "blackmailed"
Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Music Producers Rest Their Case
description: Lawyers for Irv and Christopher Gotti, the hip-hop record producers charged with laundering more than $1 million in drug money through their company Murder Inc., rested their case yesterday after calling one witness. Chief Judge Edward R. Korman of Federal District Court in Brooklyn told jurors they might begin deliberations after both sides give their summations, which could be as soon as this afternoon. A forensic accountant and retired Internal Revenue Service investigator testified for the defense that the money in the brothers' accounts was a result of legitimate business transactions. The accountant, John Ryan, acknowledged under cross-examination that he had not analyzed all the deposits. Prosecutors say that the two men took cash from their friend Kenneth McGriff, a Queens drug dealer, and wrote him checks in return.

title: An Interview With Kai Meyer
description: Kai Meyer is the author of many books for children and adults. His novel "The Water Mirror," which was a best seller in his native Germany, is the first book in the Dark Reflections trilogy. Vol. 2, "The Stone Light", will be published in fall 2006, and Vol. 3, "The Glass Word," will be published in 2007 (both from Simon & Schuster). "The Water Mirror" is set in Venice, where orphans toil as apprentices in guilds making enchanted mirrors, and mermaids with sharp teeth patrol the canals. As the story begins, the city is under siege by the flying ships of the Egyptian Empire.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Milosevic Opposes Plan To Speed Trial
description: Slobodan Milosevic and the prosecutors at his war crimes trial argued vehemently at a hearing against a suggestion by the judges to speed up the case by breaking it into two parts. The judges want to render an early judgment on the portion dealing with the war in Kosovo, which is almost ready. They would then deal with the half-finished proceedings linked to the wars in Bosnia and Croatia. The nearly four-year-long trial has been held back by the scope of the charges, relating to three wars spanning a decade, and by the recurring ill health of Mr. Milosevic, 64, the former Yugoslav president, who acts as his own lawyer.

title: U.S. Set to Loosen Rules on Objects Allowed on Airliners
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 - The Transportation Security Administration will announce later this week that passengers will again be able to carry small tools and scissors aboard commercial airplanes, as it tries to focus its security efforts on more serious threats, like explosives, two Homeland Security officials said Tuesday.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Assembly Minority Leader Named
description: James N. Tedisco, 55, a Schenectady Republican, was elected minority leader of the State Assembly yesterday. With 42 Assembly Republicans against 105 Democrats, his party does not have enough votes for a veto. "I'm not sure how bills are passed here; I ask the elevator operator sometimes," Mr. Tedisco said at a news conference. "Look, I've got to be realistic," he added. "We're outmanned. We win a lot of debates and never win any votes; I understand that. We don't have the numbers."

title: Intense Storms of '05 May Become the Norm
description: MIAMI, Nov. 29 - One of the most extraordinary hurricane seasons on record will end Wednesday, but while a six-month respite awaits, forecasters are warning that the period of intense storms could continue for years to come.

title: New U.S. Efforts to Ready Iraqis to Take Control
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 - President Bush on Wednesday will put forward for the first time a public version of what the White House calls a comprehensive strategy for victory in Iraq.

title: The Scorpion's Gate
Peres Voices Support for Sharon in Israeli Elections
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 30 - Capping a month of political upheaval in Israel, elder statesman Shimon Peres announced today that he was leaving the left-leaning Labor Party and would back Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's centrist movement in parliamentary elections in March.

title: One big art party in Miami Beach
U.S. envoy sees bias by Seoul regulators
Disapproval grows over ECB's plans
Paid Notice: Deaths   OSHINSKY, STEPHEN WARREN
description: OSHINSKY--Stephen Warren. 64. Died November 23 surrounded by his family at home in Georgia after a courageous battle with pancreatic cancer. Steve is survived by his wife Carolyn, children Joshua, Allison and Sarah, daughter - in - law Christina, sons-in-law Chris and Rod, grandchildren Zachary and Nathan and brother David and sister-in-law Jane who miss him more than words can possibly describe. Services are scheduled at Anshe Emeth Memorial Temple in New Brunswick, New Jersey, on November 30. In lieu of flowers contributions can be sent to the American Cancer Society.

title: Vic Power, 78, Pioneer Latino And First Baseman With Flair
description: Vic Power, the stylish-fielding first baseman who was one of the first Latino stars in the major leagues in the decade after World War II, died yesterday at a hospital in Bayamn, P.R. He was 78.

title: Holiday Ribbons of Sweet and Sour
description: Candied grapefruit peel, which holiday cooks can use to enhance a citrus semifreddo or a souffl, is virtually impossible to find: it is not in the repertory of commercial manfacturers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZYLBERBERG, EVELYNE
description: ZYLBERBERG--Evelyne. A memorial service for Evelyne Zylberberg will be held Friday, December 2 at 1:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Constance Cummings, a stage and screen actress, misspelled the surname of the co-star of the film "The Devil to Pay!" (1930), in which she was replaced by Loretta Young. He was Ronald Colman, not Coleman.

title: AIDS, and Homophobia, in Jamaica
description: Jamaica took a tentative step in the right direction recently when two government officials suggested that the country actually debate longstanding laws that criminalize gay sex among consenting adults. The suggestion, by Health Minister John Junor and Deputy Education Minister Donald Rhodd, may seem no big deal to those who live in Europe or North America. But it was revolutionary for Jamaica, where homophobic behavior is pervasive in just about every aspect of public life.

title: Pole blames Britain for budget woes
Girl, 6, Dies After Collapsing in Classroom
description: Correction Appended

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about efforts by ultra-Orthodox Jewish leaders to restrict their followers' access to the Internet misstated the address of a Web site for gossip about marriages, engagements and births. It is onlysimchas.com, not onlysimachas.com.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the "Arts, Briefly" column on Nov. 12 about "Aberlady Links," a tune composed by Robert Louis Stevenson, referred incorrectly to the rarity of his music. He composed more than a dozen pieces; "Aberlady Links" is not his only musical work.

title: Little to cheer on Chirac's birthday
Panel Urges Britain to Raise Retirement Age
description: LONDON, Nov. 30 - After three years of studies, an authoritative panel urged today that Britain's retirement age should be raised to 67 years old, from 65, and possibly higher as part of a major pension overhaul that would also include the introduction of individual investment accounts.

title: Stan Berenstain, Co-Creator of Those Fuzzy Bears, Dies at 82
description: Stan Berenstain, who with his wife, Jan, churned out more than 250 books showing how the warm and fuzzy Berenstain Bears -- Mama, Papa, Brother and Sister -- confronted and learned from life's little crises, died on Saturday in Doylestown, Pa. He was 82.

title: De Beers reaches settlement in U.S. price-fixing cases
An Old Cinema in Pakistan Has New Life After Quake
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Nov. 25 - Tucked inside a popular bazaar, there once was a place where women shimmied their hips in full Technicolor splendor. Today, it is a refuge for women who can barely lift their legs.

title: Urban oases for a nap or sauna
Corrections
description: A picture caption on Nov. 19 with an obituary of Red Sarachek, the longtime Yeshiva University basketball coach, misidentified a member of the Workmen's Circle team shown with him and Red Holzman in 1941. The player at the far right was Monroe Edelstein (then known as Chili Edelstein), not Norm Drucker.

title: A Laid-Back Partner Suited to a Varied Field
description: AT some tastings the wines display great consistency, which simplifies the choice of a dish to serve alongside. But at others, the styles of the wines are all over the map. This situation seems to come up more often with white wines than with reds. Our tasting of Rhone-style blendings of the roussanne and marsanne grape from California was a good example.

title: Altantic Ocean current shows weakening signs
The Flu's Second Front
description: THE possibility of an avian flu pandemic is real. President Bush has sensibly proposed a substantial investment to detect, identify and contain the virus, when and where it begins human-to-human spread. This strategy is appropriate, and may save millions of lives. But success requires excellent science, flawless human response and no small amount of luck.

title: Modest River, Wide Chasm, With Europe 'Over There'
description: LVIV, Ukraine - "Beautiful but poor" is a common shorthand description of Lviv, a city of 800,000 people in western Ukraine, and it takes only a few hours here to sense the accuracy of the phrase.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: From Screen to Stage

title: Attention All Employees: Ford Is Serious About Change
description: My way or the highway, Ford Motor's chief executive has told the company's employees.

title: A German is seized in Iraq
Downtown's Boosters Say Bargain Rents Won't Last
description: Downtown Manhattan today is much like Times Square in the mid-1990's, argues Kent M. Swig, the president of Swig Equities, which owns four office buildings in the financial district and has contracted to buy another.

title: U.S. welcomes opposition leader
Redskins Boss Close to Running Six Flags
description: Six Flags Inc., the theme park operator, said yesterday that the owner of the Washington Redskins, Daniel Snyder, and two associates were elected to the board, moving his group one step closer to control of Six Flags.

title: How to Eat a Pomegranate On a Stick
description: Sheer Bliss, an ice cream company in Hallandale Beach, Fla., now enrobes its ultra-rich pomegranate ice cream in good dark chocolate and sells these confections-on-a-stick in boxes of three. The somewhat tart flavor of the ice cream is perfectly balanced by its dark cloak.

title: Bush defends embattled war policy
Group of Private Equity Firms Launches $12 Billion Bid for TDC
description: A group of private equity firms reached a deal today to buy Denmark's dominant telephone company, TDC, for $12 billion in what could set a new benchmark for leveraged buyouts in Europe.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about political and military pressures on President Bush regarding Iraq misstated the position of Senator Carl Levin, the ranking Democrat on the Armed Services Committee. While Senator Levin did say that an open-ended American military commitment takes the pressure off Iraqis to make political compromises, he has not endorsed the call by some in Congress to set a specific deadline for withdrawing American forces. (Go to Article)

title: NBC Names Ex-Producer to Head News Unit
description: Nearly a year after shepherding the handoff from Tom Brokaw to Brian Williams as the executive producer of "NBC Nightly News," Steve Capus was promoted yesterday to president of the network's news division.

title: Practical Advice for Doctors on How to Respond When It's the Patient Who's the Problem
description: Doctors are not the only ones with bad manners, irritating personalities and ridiculous agendas. Out there in waiting rooms everywhere sit the counterparts of the difficult doctor: the impossible patients whose names on the schedule make the doctor cringe.

title: Metro Briefs
description: NEW YORK

title: In Colorado, Making a Downhill Course to Perfection
description: BEAVER CREEK, Colo., Nov. 29 - Starting on Thursday, the Beaver Creek mountain resort high above Vail will be host to four World Cup ski races in four days. It will be the only home stand of the year for the United States men's ski team and its enfant terrible, Bode Miller, who will be a five-medal contender in February at the Olympic Games in Turin, Italy.

title: Juggling Words and Languages With a Caribbean Lilt
description: In "The Penguin Book of Caribbean Verse in English," the editor, Paula Burnett, separates several centuries of poetry into two traditions, the oral and the literary. Writers like Derek Walcott and the Dominican novelist Jean Rhys are included in the longer literary section, while the dub poet Linton Kwesi Johnson and the Jamaican-language poet Louise Bennett are put in the oral, along with the song lyrics of Jimmy Cliff and Bob Marley.

title: Arts, Briefly; Still in Prison, And Drawing Viewers
description: Well, the "Prison Break" gang will remain incarcerated for at least a few more months. The fall finale of Fox's get-out-of-jail adventure ended with a cliffhanger, as Michael, played by Wentworth Miller, below, was thwarted in his escape plans by an unexpectedly thick pipe. The series drew the highest ratings of its 13-episode run, with an estimated audience of 12.14 million viewers. It finished behind only ABC's football broadcast among adults 18 to 49. After the show, Fox announced that "Prison Break" would return to its schedule in March with new episodes. On ABC, the undefeated Indianapolis Colts helped deliver an overall victory for the network on Monday night in both total viewers and the 18-to-49 demographic. On "Monday Night Football," the Colts' win over the Pittsburgh Steelers beat second-place CBS.

title: A play's infanticide, and its singalong
Paid Notice: Deaths  ASKANAS, ALEKSANDRA
description: ASKANAS--Aleksandra. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center family joins with the physicians and staff of The Division of Cardiology and The Department of Medicine in acknowledging with sadness the passing of Aleksandra Askanas, beloved wife of our dear friend and long-time colleague, Alexander Askanas, M.D., Director of the hospital's EKG Department. To Alexander, his family, and all of his wife's loved ones, we extend heartfelt condolences. David J. Shulkin, M.D., President and CEO Stephen P. Haveson, M.D., President, Medical Board and President, Doctors Alumni Association Stephen G. Baum, M.D., Chairman, Dept of Medicine Steven R. Bergmann, M.D., Ph.D., Chief Division of Cardiology

title: A summaryof the plan
Judges and Ideology
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SULZBERGER, MAYE (NEE DORFMAN)
description: SULZBERGER--Maye (nee Dorfman). Died Saturday night, November 26th, with her daughter and grandson at her bedside. She is survived by her daughter, Susan Sulzberger Rolfe, grandson Myron Sulzberger (Mickey) Rolfe, granddaughters Joanne (Jody) Quinn and her husband Roger, and Penny R. Sullivan and her husband Tim. Also survived by three great grandsons, Billy and Teddy Quinn, and Tommy Sullivan. Reunited at last with her adored late husband, Edward, from whom she was widowed for 17 years. The daughter of the late Louis and Anna Dorfman, and predeceased by her sister, Paula Blum, Maye is also survived by her sister, Charlotte Rosenfield, and by nieces and nephews, and by many friends and bridge partners in New York City. She was a member of the Regency Whist Club, the Harmonie Club and the Quaker Ridge Country Club. Our family is indebted to Sophia Sanchez for her steadfast care and love for 30 years, and, more recently, to the four wonderful nurses who tended to Maye as if she was their own. We will receive friends at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street on Tuesday from 6-9 P.M. with services Wednesday, 11;30 A.M. Interment private. Family will be at Susan Rolfe's home on Thursday from 3-7. Memorial contributions, if desired, to Mount Sinai Medical Center, attention Dr. Alvin Teirstein, 1 Gustav Levy Place, NY, NY 10029. She was fierce and brave, a boss, and we loved her.

title: U.S. Is Urged to Raise Rates
description: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said yesterday that the Federal Reserve should keep raising interest rates but urged central banks in Europe and Japan to keep rates low to foster economic growth.

title: World Briefing: Europe, Americas, Africa, Asia
description: EUROPE

title: The Neediest Cases; Taking Deep Breaths to Inflate the Positive and Deflate the Negative
description: For Kendesha Maxwell, being hooked up to an intravenous line is as routine as putting on earrings.

title: No-Roll Crusts Leave Little Room For Disappointment
description: AT this time of year, even reluctant cooks can find comfort in the kitchen.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Vice Premier Resigns
description: President Viktor A. Yushchenko said he had accepted the departure of another high-ranking member of his government, Deputy Prime Minister Roman Bessmertny. The announcement came some two and a half months after Mr. Yushchenko dismissed his prime minister and entire cabinet amid a flurry of corruption allegations. In his resignation letter, Mr. Bessmertny said he was leaving at the request of Mr. Yushchenko's party to focus on parliamentary elections in March.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Ecuador: A New Supreme Court
description: After seven months without a Supreme Court, an independent four-member committee has elected 31 new judges who are to be sworn in today in Quito, the capital. Congress disbanded the court in April as protests picked up against President Lucio Gutirrez, who was accused of engineering the dismissal of the court last December and installing a court packed with allies. Anger over Mr. Gutirrez's actions prompted his resignation, but bitter divisions in Congress had prevented Ecuador from deciding on a new court until now.

title: Schwarzenegger Names Top Democrat as New Chief of Staff
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30 - Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, who suffered an indirect drubbing at the polls last month, today named a top Democratic official from the administration he ousted two years ago as his own chief of staff.

title: Documents Reveal More About Court Pick's Views
description: Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. once urged the Reagan administration to use a circuitous approach to challenging Roe v. Wade, arguing that promoting and defending state regulations on abortion would have a "mitigating effect" on the 1973 Supreme Court ruling that established a constitutional right to abortion.

title: White House Unveils Holiday Decorations
description: The White House ushered in the holiday season today by unveiling its lush Christmas decorations, a panoply of fresh tulips and azaleas, amber glass balls, garlands strung with lemons and a partridge in a pear tree - or, at least, a partridge on a bay topiary hung with pears.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: M.T.A. Honored For Hybrid Buses
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Peter S. Kalikow, accepted an award yesterday from WestStart-Calstart, a nonprofit group that promotes vehicles that run on cleaner fuel. Last month the authority approved a $249 million contract with Orion Bus Industries, part of DaimlerChrysler, to build 500 Orion VII hybrid diesel-electric buses by mid-2007, with an option for 389 more. The authority began using hybrid buses in 1998 and has 325 in service.

title: Free flow: Frankfurt seeks 4th runway success
Paid Notice: Deaths   MANDEL, DAVID J.
description: MANDEL--David J. Of Manhattan, on November 29, 2005. Son of Zelda and Victor, brother of Gloria. Survived by his beloved wife, Judith, and daughter, Nancy. Also survived by his loving niece and nephew, Carole and Bruce, and their children. Services Thursday 11:30 AM at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Austria plans to delay EU services legislation
Paid Notice: Deaths   GELLER, HENRY
description: GELLER--Henry. Of Boca Raton, FL, died Sunday, November 27, 2005, in his home. He was born in the Bronx, NY, on July 16, 1925. He is survived by his wife, Carol Geller and his three children, Laura, Robert and Janet and his grandson, Daniel Geller. Henry Geller was not only a loving and supportive father and husband, he was a dedicated business man who worked in the men's wear industry in New York City for almost 50 years. After he moved to Florida he volunteered and donated his time to the many causes he believed in. Private funeral was held in New York City. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made in Mr. Henry Geller's memory to the American Diabetes Association.

title: Thoughts on Food, For Those Who Like to Digest Ideas
description: Alimentum, a new journal about food, is small enough to carry with you for mental and aesthetic nourishment breaks. Paulette Licitra, the publisher and editor, has gathered the prose, poetry and nonfiction of 29 writers, few of whom are food writers but all of whom have something distinct to say.

title: Prepare the O.R. (and A.A.): Dr. Drake Is Back
description: When it comes to getting viewers' attention, soap operas have always favored the spectacular over the subtle.

title: Fox Reaches Five-Year Deal With Star of 'American Idol'
description: The Fox network solved its most worrisome problem yesterday, announcing that it had signed its most important star, Simon Cowell of "American Idol," to a five-year contract. The deal means that Fox will keep intact the elements of the show, which has been the most powerful draw in television for the last two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DOMENITZ, ARNOLD
description: DOMENITZ--Arnold. March 10, 1915--November 28, 2005. Survived by his wife Rosalind, daughter Ellen Levin & son Andrew. Beloved grandfather and great-grandfather. Loved and adored by all who knew him.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Holiday Spending on Internet Shows Increase Over Last Year American consumers spent 26 percent more money online over the holiday weekend than they did in 2004, according to newly released figures. And after a long weekend of pointing and clicking, millions kept right on shopping at work Monday, beginning at 9 a.m., retailers said, validating the holiday shopping season's latest buzz phrase, Cyber Monday. [Page C1.]

title: Official Says American Delay of U.N. Budget Would Cause Crisis
description: UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 29 - The chief budget officer of the United Nations said Tuesday that an effort by the Bush administration to delay approval of the institution's budget next month in order to push through reforms would cause a crisis in the organization and cut into essential operations.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Vows to Respond On Detentions in Europe Responding to growing alarm over reports that the United States held terror suspects at secret camps in Europe, Bush administration officials said that international laws were not violated and that they would respond to inquiries.

title: Upon Further Review, Islanders Fail to Tie, and Lose
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., Nov. 29 - Simon Gagne scored the Philadelphia Flyers' final two goals Tuesday night, which was not surprising. He leads the N.H.L. with 23 goals.

title: 'General Hospital': In 1983, and Now
description: PAST

title: Security Flaw Allows Wiretaps to Be Evaded, Study Finds
description: The technology used for decades by law enforcement agents to wiretap telephones has a security flaw that allows the person being wiretapped to stop the recorder remotely, according to research by computer security experts who studied the system. It is also possible to falsify the numbers dialed, they said.

title: People: Paul McCartney, George Michael, Kevin Costner
What downed Gambia's air safety chief?
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Reversal Of Landmark Status Advances
description: In two votes closely watched by city preservationists, a City Council subcommittee and full committee voted yesterday to reverse a decision by the Landmarks Preservation Commission. The Council acted to reverse the designation of landmark status for the Austin, Nichols & Company Warehouse, a 1915 building in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The owner wants to change the facade. The vote in the subcommittee was 4 to 0 in favor of reversal (with 3 absent) and 16 to 3 in the full land-use committee (with one absent). A vote by the full Council is scheduled for 1:30 p.m. today.

title: Ferrer Adviser Cites a Failure by Democrats
description: A senior adviser to Fernando Ferrer, the defeated Democratic mayoral nominee, said yesterday that nationally prominent Democrats who deserted Mr. Ferrer's candidacy had done a disservice not only to him, but also to the party's efforts to woo Hispanic voters.

title: China Declares City's Water Supply Fit to Drink
description: BEIJING, Nov. 29 - Water drawn from the Songhua River to supply almost four million people in Harbin, in northern China, was fit to drink Tuesday, the state news media reported, almost a week after pumping was suspended because of a vast chemical spill. But the slick continued to threaten communities downstream.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Lunch Boxes Recalled
description: The attorney general's office yesterday announced a voluntary recall of thousands of soft vinyl lunchboxes imported by Fast Forward, a wholesaler of consumer products. The plastic and mesh lunchboxes have lead levels that exceed state environmental packaging regulations, which raised concerns about their eventual disposal, the attorney general's office said. The executive director of the Center for Environmental Health, a nonprofit group that sued Fast Forward and other sellers of lunchboxes, said parents should not panic if their children used them. The director, Michael Green, said the amount of lead would not cause acute toxic exposure by itself, but parents should have children's blood tested during checkups because lead exposure can come from many sources. The Fast Forward label can be spotted inside the boxes. Consumers who bought them between March and September this year can return the boxes by Feb. 28, 2006, to the retailer or to Fast Forward with a refund request form available from the New York attorney general's office.

title: National Briefing | South: Georgia: Prisoner Escapes In Atlanta, Again
description: For the third time in a year, Atlanta law enforcement officials were searching for an escaped prisoner, this time Elton Daniels. Mr. Daniels, 23, was being transported by the Atlanta Police Department to Fulton County Jail to be charged with possession of drugs and concealed weapons when he kicked open the door of the van and ran off, said Sylvia Abernathy, a spokeswoman for the police. It is unclear whether he was restrained, Ms. Abernathy said. The Atlanta police and the Fulton County Sheriff's Department were faulted for lax prisoner transport procedures in a July 2005 report by the United States Marshals Service that was ordered after a man escaped custody at the Fulton County Courthouse and killed three people. Both agencies pledged to tighten prisoner security.

title: A Shot at Justice
description: PRESIDENT Bush's recently proposed $7.1 billion plan for pandemic flu protection is admirably ambitious. It is also remarkably self-defeating in two vital areas: manufacturer liability and victim compensation.

title: New Cable Network Isn't Responsible for the Open-Wallet Policy of Minaya
description: When the Mets signed Pedro Martnez a year ago, it was easy to declare that his arrival, followed by the addition of Carlos Beltran, were moves that anticipated the 2006 spring debut of the team's new cable network and, if they should play so long, the eventual opening of a new ballpark.

title: Arts, Briefly; Rostropovich Quits Moscow Opera
description: Mstislav Rostropovich, below, has refused to conduct a new staging of Prokofiev's opera "War and Peace" that had been scheduled to have its premiere at the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow next Tuesday. Mr. Rostropovich, who said six years ago that he would no longer perform in Russia because he felt underappreciated in his homeland, has refused to comment, but his spokeswoman in Moscow confirmed the accuracy of a report in the newspaper Izvestia, which said, "He was dissatisfied with everything: the unlearned parts of the singers, the level of the orchestra, the necessity of repeating everything several times that occurred because the composition of the orchestra was constantly changing and everything that was achieved at the last rehearsal with one group had to be reworked with the next." Alexander Vedernikov, the Bolshoi's chief conductor, will replace Mr. Rostropovich, who was especially passionate about the production because of his friendship with Prokofiev. The premiere has been moved to Dec. 9.

title: Following Santa to the Ends of the Earth
description: Nicholas The Epic Journey From Saint to Santa Claus By Jeremy Seal Illustrated. 236 pages. Bloomsbury. $24.95. It's not yet December, but Santa Claus has already emerged from his annual hibernation. There he is, ringing his bell for the Salvation Army, taking children on his lap at department stores across the land and endorsing a host of consumer products that have included, over the years, everything from Coke to Norelco electric razors. But who is this man, really?

title: A Star Chef at Your (Expensive) Stove
description: ONE evening in early October, Daniel Boulud and a small staff of sous-chefs and servers dressed in formal white restaurant attire stepped off an elevator and into the spacious TriBeCa apartment of Michel Wallerstein and Gary Garrison. They rolled in crates of peekytoe crab, Colorado lamb, Maine halibut and tuna tartare, and enough fixings for a five-course feast to help the couple celebrate their 10th anniversary with a group of their friends.

title: EU and U.S. join to protect copyrights
Men Posing as FedEx Workers Rob Jewelry Wholesaler
description: Two men posing as Federal Express employees breezed through security at a tightly guarded building in the city's diamond district yesterday, rode the elevator to the sixth floor and robbed a jewelry wholesaler of goods valued at $4 million, the police said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Financial Museum Moves To Wall Street
description: The Museum of American Finance will move to a new location on Wall Street, one block from the New York Stock Exchange, museum officials said on Monday. The museum, now at 26 Broadway, will lease 30,000 square feet in the Bank of New York Building at 48 Wall Street. The new museum is scheduled to open by the end of next year, said Kristin Aguilera, the museum's spokeswoman. The landmark 34-story building, which is topped with a giant eagle statue, was built in 1927. The museum, founded in 1988, exhibits collections related to American financial history.

title: Italian bishops get signal on Muslims
Techbrief: Advanced Micro plans big presence in India
Jaguar considers selling plant in England
TRANSACTIONS
description: Recent Sale $13.75 million 275 and 295 Greenwich Street Manhattan

title: U.S. to Respond to Inquiries Over Detentions in Europe
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 - The Bush administration, responding to European alarm over allegations of secret detention camps and the transport of terror suspects on European soil, insisted Tuesday that American actions complied with international law but promised to respond to formal inquiries from European nations.

title: Corrections
description: A report and headline in the Metro Briefing column on Nov. 22 about a man's conviction in Westchester County for trying to arrange a sexual encounter with a former student misstated his employment status. The man, Paul E. Wicht, is no longer a teacher at Bronxville High School.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOROWITZ, GEORGE Q
description: HOROWITZ--George Q on November 28, 2005. Beloved husband of Renee. Loving father of Seth, his wife Lori and Robin. Devoted son of Libby. Dear brother of Don, Linda, Ruby and Jackie. George became CEO and Chairman of Everlast Worldwide Inc., in October 2000 after spending over 30 years in the apparel business, prior to which he was an educator in the NYC school system. He was very active in charitable organizations and a board member at the American Heart Association and the S.G.M.A. He left an everlasting impression on everyone he met with his dynamic personality and warm heart. A memorial service will be held Monday, December 5, 2005, 10:00 A.M. at Temple EmanuEl, Fifth Ave at 65th St. Contributions may be made to Dr. Theodore A. Atlas Foundation, PO Box 140998, Staten Island, NY 10304 and SloanKettering Kidney Cancer Research, New York City.

title: Honey, We Forgot to Raise the Kids!
description: To the Editor:

title: Soccer: UEFA threatens ban for clubs with racism
Busiest Hurricane Season on Record Ends
description: The busiest hurricane season on record ends today with 26 named storms, including a tropical system that formed on Tuesday over the central Atlantic.

title: Chasing Fraud in Medicaid
description: MINEOLA, N.Y., Nov. 29 - Nassau County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi urged the state on Tuesday to crack down on managed care companies that process fraudulent applications for Medicaid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CHILL, POLLY (PINSKER)
description: CHILL--Polly (Pinsker). Age 76. Beloved wife of the late Lester Blickstein, died peacefully November 25, 2005 after a long illness, surrounded by her loving family, at her son's home in Connecticut. A 1950 graduate from Swarthmore College, Polly enjoyed successful careers as a book editor at Random House and freelance, and as a union negotiator for District Council 37 of AFSCME before attending NYU Law School at age 50. After admission to the bar in 1982, she continued to work to promote social justice as a lawyer for the National Labor Relations Board and later as a child advocate for the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children. A great lover of music and the arts, she sang for many years with the New York Choral Society and was an accomplished pianist. But her greatest joy was being with her family and friends. She leaves her children, Paul Chill and his wife Brigid Donohue, Carol Adinolfi and Nina Chill and partner Chris Donnelly; her brother and sister-in-law Adam and Judith Pinsker and her nephew Joel Pinsker; her step-children Kate Blickstein and partner Lynn Howell, and Joel Blickstein and his wife Bonnie Blackwell; and the five grandchildren she cherished so much, Madeleine, Camille, Declan and Deidre Donohue Chill, and Kai Chill Donnelly; her step-grandson Jason Blickstein and his wife Jennifer and step-great-grandsons Cyrus Blickstein and Nicholas and Anthony Pagano. A memorial service celebrating Polly's life will be held January 14 at 2 PM at the Quaker Meeting House on Rutherford Place and 15 St. NY NY. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Jacob Perlow Hospice, 1775 Broadway, Suite 300, NY, NY 10019.

title: Old Leftist Friend Is to Join Sharon's New Party
description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 29 - Shimon Peres plans to quit the left-leaning Labor Party, his political home for decades, and back Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's new centrist party in parliamentary elections in March, Israeli television reported Tuesday night.

title: Clemency Stops an Execution in Virginia
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 - Gov. Mark Warner of Virginia granted clemency Tuesday to a convicted killer, declaring that the loss of a crucial piece of evidence had persuaded him that the man should not be put to death as scheduled on Wednesday.

title: Criticizing Bush's new Iraq strategy, Democrats call for 'real plan'
Mexico's Leader Says He'll Persevere on Migration
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 29 - A day after President Bush announced steps to increase border security, President Vicente Fox said Tuesday that his government would cooperate but would also persevere in pushing to expand legal channels for Mexican immigrants seeking work in the United States.

title: When the Doctor Is in, but You Wish He Weren't

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column on Saturday about Indonesia's move to bar Sidney Jones, an American expert on terrorism in that nation, from entering the country referred incorrectly in some editions to her stance on the government's antiterrorism efforts. Ms. Jones recently commended the government for its efforts; she has not been a frequent critic of them.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about political and military pressures on President Bush regarding Iraq misstated the position of Senator Carl Levin, the ranking Democrat on the Armed Services Committee. While Senator Levin did say that an open-ended American military commitment takes the pressure off Iraqis to make political compromises, he has not endorsed the call by some in Congress to set a specific deadline for withdrawing American forces.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Factory Output and Household Spending Rise
description: Japanese industrial production and household spending rose in October as higher exports and wages sustained growth. Production increased an adjusted 0.6 percent from September, as companies met demand by reducing inventories. Production of general machinery, including semiconductor-related devices, rose 5.2 percent, while electric machinery, including air-conditioners and chip-measuring equipment, increased 3.2 percent, the trade ministry said. Spending by households climbed 1.2 percent, a separate government report released in Tokyo showed. Households spent 18.1 percent more on clothes and footwear, and spending for furniture rose 10.6 percent. Income for households in the survey rose 0.6 percent.

title: New Subway Cars Promise All Kinds of Information
description: Nicholas Malave, a senior at Pacific High School in Brooklyn, entered a subway car yesterday and let out a cry of delight. This is not something he normally does during his regular trips on the A and J lines.

title: 3 Anti-Chvez Parties Pull Out of Election
description: BOGOT, Colombia, Nov. 29 - Accusing Venezuelan electoral officials of favoring that country's populist government, three opposition parties announced Tuesday that they would pull out of congressional elections scheduled for Sunday.

title: Taking the pain out of sharing
Having Your Ethics and Eating Them, Too
description: TO appreciate how far eating has evolved from a matter of survival to a statement of values, take a trip to Cookshop and a look at its chalkboards.

title: Letter From China: Beijing fails to deliver on promise of honesty
Goodbye City Streets, Hello African Wilderness
description: "The Boys of Baraka" gives a poignant human face to an alarming statistic: 76 percent of black male students in Baltimore city schools do not graduate from high school. The documentary, directed by Heidi Ewing and Rachel Grady, tells you why. A toxic poor-neighborhood environment destroys hope and undermines self-esteem.

title: Buses to Keep a Seat Open in a Tribute to Rosa Parks
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority will leave on the headlights of about 6,000 buses tomorrow to mark the 50th anniversary of Rosa Parks's decision not to surrender her seat to a white man on a city bus in Montgomery, Ala.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOROWITZ, LEWIS J.
description: HOROWITZ--Lewis J. Lew Lew we love you so much. You were the most fun in our lives. Loads of hugs and kisses to the world's best grandpa. Max, Ben, Leo and Ryan

title: Corrections
description: A report by The Associated Press in the Sports Briefing column in some copies yesterday about Christopher Noteboom, who said he was spreading his late mother's ashes when he ran onto Lincoln Financial Field in Philadelphia during the Eagles game and was arrested on Sunday, misstated his age. He is 44, not 33.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Protection For The European Sturgeon
description: The nearly extinct European sturgeon, once so widespread it was known as the common sturgeon, has received a measure of protection that may help it survive. Meeting in Nairobi, Kenya, the Convention on Migratory Species, a United Nations agency, added it to a list of threatened wild animals, which means it can no longer be fished in the shallow waters of Europe's coastlines, where it lives most of its life.

title: Few Minorities Get Best High School Diplomas
description: Fewer than one in 10 black or Hispanic students who enter New York City high schools graduate four years later with a coveted Regents diploma, education officials testified yesterday.

title: Animation Mania
description: Scott Bateman has got himself quite a mission: to create a new Web animation every single day for 365 days. He's been at it for 104 days so far.

title: Justices Consider Abortion Case on Parental Notification
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 - The New Hampshire attorney general asked the Supreme Court today to restore her state's abortion law, and in so doing she encountered sharp questions about a facet of the statute's requirement that doctors notify a pregnant teen-ager's parent before performing an abortion.

title: Cull of the Wild
description: Schuylkill Haven, Pa. - WITH a wary eye on the clouds, I hurried through a few last outdoor chores at my old farmhouse before the rain and snow arrived. But even in my haste, one faint sound stopped me -- braying whoops high overhead, the telltale knell of autumn's final retreat. All but hidden in the clouds, a flock of tundra swans was riding the storm front, aiming for the sheltered coves of the Chesapeake more than 100 miles to the south.

description: In the vice president's new, more fortified bunker, inside his old undisclosed secure location within the larger bunker that used to be called the West Wing of the White House, Dick Cheney was muttering and sputtering.

title: Sudan Refugees Going Home With 1.5 Million Cattle
description: Thousands of Dinka cattle herders displaced by Sudan's long north-south civil war are preparing to move as many as 1.5 million cows across the White Nile at a bridge in the southern town of Juba later this week as they finally trek back home, the United Nations said. The World Food Program plans to assist the children, elderly and sick in the group by providing food assistance and transport up the river by barge as the young men manage the huge herd of livestock, said Simon Crittle, a spokesman for the international food agency.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Bank Workers Held In Robbery
description: The police arrested two employees of a Belfast bank that was robbed of $50 million in cash last December, a 22-year-old woman and a 24-year-old man whose family had been taken hostage by masked gunmen during the theft. They have not been charged. The man, Chris Ward, had said he expected to be treated as a suspect because he comes from a Roman Catholic neighborhood that supports the Irish Republican Army. The province's police chief, Hugh Orde, has said since the robbery, at Northern Bank, that the I.R.A. was responsible; the I.R.A. denies it. In addition to the two bank workers, the police have questioned 10 people in connection with the robbery; three have been charged.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOUGHLIN, DR. WINIFRED C.
description: LOUGHLIN--Dr. Winifred C. Born in NYC in 1913, graduated from McDonnell High School, City University of N.Y. (Brooklyn College) and Tufts University School of Medicine. After internship, residencies and a fellowship in NYC, she practiced Internal Medicine in Manhattan for almost 40 years while being an Attending Physician at NYUBellevue Medical Center and University Hospitals, and an Associate Professor of Clinical Medicine at NYU Medical School. She was a past president of the N.Y. Diabetes Association. She was a life member of the A.M.A and the N.Y. State and County Medical Societies. She was also a member and/or fellow of the American Federation for Clinical Research, the American Diabetes Association, The American Association for the Advancement of Science, the N.Y. Academy of Science and Alpha-OmegaAlpha Honor Society. She wrote and published ten medical journal articles, most concerning clinical research matters, especially in metabolic disorders. She had lived on Cape Cod since 1995 and pursued painting as a dedicated amateur. She was the widow of Benjamin Shapiro, engineer, and is survived by three stepchildren (Phyllis Foley and Michael and Stephen Shapiro), five stepgrandchildrenand six stepgreat grandchildren. There will be no funeral services.

description: Intel is expected to announce today that it has entered into partnerships with several movie, music, and game providers around the world to introduce content that would work with its new Viiv technology for home media centers.

title: The Next Abortion Decision
description: In the abortion rights case set for argument today, the Supreme Court is taking up the most contentious social issue in the country at a moment of transition in its own membership. The theatrics could be fascinating. But what makes the case truly compelling is the substance. The case, Ayotte v. Planned Parenthood of Northern New England, challenges two longstanding pillars of abortion rights jurisprudence, reproductive freedom and the authority of the courts. Both have real-world consequences for the lives of women and the rule of law.

title: Upbeat Signs Hold Cautions for the Future
description: Gasoline is cheaper than it was before Hurricane Katrina slammed into New Orleans. Consumer confidence jumped last month and new- home sales hit a record. The stock market has been rising. Even the nation's beleaguered factories seem headed for a happy holiday season.

title: After Uneven Trip, Nets Prepare to Settle In
description: DENVER, Nov. 29 - The Nets have 68 games remaining in the regular season, and Jason Kidd is not yet ready to make definitive statements. He has led the Nets to two N.B.A. finals appearances, so he knows that his team's standing when the trees are lush with leaves, not bare to the branches, is what counts.

title: Bats May Play Role in Spread of Ebola Virus, Study Says
description: The Ebola virus has caused a small number of deadly outbreaks among people and primates in Africa since 1976 that health workers have contained. But because the virus poses continuous threats scientists are concerned that they do not know the virus's hiding place in nature.

description: Patience is a lot to ask from the victims of a bloody tyrant who have waited decades for justice. But patience is exactly what is needed now from the judges in the trial of Saddam Hussein, from Iraqi political leaders and from ordinary Iraqi citizens.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Honduras to Challenge Banana Ruling
description: Honduras said that it would lodge a World Trade Organization challenge against the European Union's plan to more than double the tariff that Latin American banana exporters pay to sell their fruit in the 25-nation bloc. The European Union, the world's biggest banana importer, said Friday that it would replace quotas with a duty of 176 euros ($208) a metric ton. The bloc is trying to end a nine-year squabble with the largest exporting countries, including Ecuador, Panama and Costa Rica, as well as the United States, which filed the original W.T.O. complaint. Latin American producers say the planned tariff, which will take effect Jan. 1, is too high. European governments backed the levy.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Police Investigate Double Homicide
description: Police investigators are seeking suspects in the deaths of two men who were shot in the parking garage of a Bedford-Stuyvesant apartment building on Monday night. The men, Christian Throne, 18, and Terrell Huggins, 28, were shot about 10 p.m. in the garage of 280 Herkimer Street. Investigators found two 9-millimeter shell casings in the private garage. The motive of the shooting is unknown, the police said yesterday.

If you squint -- or had enough to drink -- you can almost see the ghosts of Andy Warhol, Halston or a teenage Brooke Shields, wobbly legs rolling in endless circles at 3 a.m. as a spangled beauty descends from the ceiling through a cloud of smoke.

Learning-Disabled Students Blossom in Blended Classes
description: SARAH JACOBS' son Jed, 9, has a learning disability. He's easily distracted and, if asked to do too many things at once, panics. At his former school, a private academy that cost $20,000 a year, his mother says Jed got into trouble daily ("kicking and even some biting") and stopped learning. "He was reading 'Captain Underpants' in kindergarten and he was in third grade and still reading 'Captain Underpants,"' she says.

title: Correction
description: The $25 and Under column last Wednesday, about the restaurant Northeast Kingdom in Bushwick, Brooklyn, misspelled the surname of an owner. He is Paris Smeraldo, not Smeroldo.

title: Playing the Goldbergs With a Schubertian Touch
description: Bach's "Goldberg" Variations cover enormous musical ground, and when played with all the repeats, as Simone Dinnerstein did on Monday evening at Weill Recital Hall, the set has the heft and spaciousness to stand alone on a program and leave both listener and performer sated. It has everything: a graceful Aria at the start and finish, a varied and increasingly challenging set of canons, and gently but deeply involved variations alternating with virtuosic, fantasia-like ones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEINBERG, ARTHUR W. M.D.
description: FEINBERG--Arthur W. M.D. Age 82, died on November 28, 2005. Loving husband of Harriet Newman Cohen Feinberg, and before that of Jean Dilbert Feinberg, the wife he lost in 1973, devoted father of Nancy Rheingrover (Jim), David Feinberg (Madeleine), Martha Cohen Stine (Carl), Amy Ziegelbaum (Michael), Susan Hirsch (Bruce), Patricia Epstein (Steven) and doting grandfather of Jennifer, Andrew, Gillian, Matthew, Eric, Benjamin, Ezra, Zachary, Gabriel, Sarah, Jonathan, Jacob, Oliver and Natalie, brother of Martin Feinberg and the late Evelyn and Doris, he was a man without equal in any century. Beloved by all, a brilliant physician (internist and geriatrician), he leaves this world in deep mourning. A proud graduate of Boys High School, Columbia College and Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, he served as an Army doctor in the Philippine Islands at the end of World War II. A founding doctor of North Shore University Hospital and a leader in medical education, he was the Associate Director of the Department of Medicine from 1974 until 1989. He received a Federal grant to establish one of the first primary care training programs in the country. Dr. Feinberg was also Dean of Admissions at Cornell University Medical College, was involved with the medical students for many years and was honored with AOA membership. When asked by NSUH, he became the first Director of the NSUH's Center for Extended Care and Rehabilitation upon its opening and the first Chief of the Division of Geriatric Medicine at NSUH. He was a founding father of the Division of Ambulatory Care that brings home care to the frail and elderly. His commitment to the problems of vascular disease led to his establishment of the Vascular Diseases laboratory at NSUH. The CECR's Home Visit program for the elderly was created by Dr. Feinberg. He was also a leader of the American College of Physicians, where he chaired their Postgraduate Education Committee, was a leader of their Ethics Committee and served as a Regent of the College. He was honored by being named a Master of the ACP. Dr. Feinberg was the Chair of the NSUH Ethics Committee and at the time of his death, he held the rank of Professor of Clinical Medicine at NYU School of Medicine. He wrote extensively, including a medical column for Newsday and hosted a television program on Lifetime Medical Television. At the time of his death, Dr. Feinberg was teaching medical interns at Long Island Jewish Medical Center, writing articles for continuing medical education, working for the New York State Office of Professional Medical Conduct, giving his sought after medical lectures and providing counsel and comfort to all, professionally and personally. His loss to vascular disease is profound and unspeakable. We will love you and miss you forever. Funeral Services Wednesday, November 30th, at 1:15 p.m., "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations may be made to the Arthur Feinberg Medical Education Fund, North Shore LIJ Foundation, A/C #

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. They're the hosts as the tree (a 74-foot Norway spruce from Wayne, N.J.) is officially lighted and guests including Rod Stewart, Sheryl Crow, Regis Philbin and Earth, Wind & Fire perform. description: Scientists say they have measured a significant slowing in the Atlantic currents that carry warm water toward Northern Europe. If the trend persists, they say, the weather there could cool considerably in coming decades.

title: U.S. TEAM WILL ADD TO SCHEDULE
description: The United States men's national team is expected to add two games to its schedule next year: Jan. 22 against Canada at a site to be determined on the West Coast; and Feb. 10 against Japan in San Francisco. The matches have not yet been officially announced, but news of the games was sent to subscribers to ussoccerfan.com in an e-mail message about ticket sales for the World Cup. Earlier, the United States announced a Jan. 29 match against Norway at the Home Depot Center in Carson, Calif. The United States will find out its three first-round opponents in the World Cup at the Dec. 9 draw.

World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: President Lifts Ban On Terror Expert
description: President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono intervened decisively to overturn a decision by immigration authorities to bar the American terrorism expert Sidney Jones from entering the country, thus quickly ending what was a growing international embarrassment to his fledgling democratic government. Ms. Jones, 52, who has devoted most of her career to studying and writing about Indonesia and is considered a leading authority on the radical Islamic group Jemaah Islamiyah, was barred from entering last Thursday. In recent days, several senior government officials have publicly said the ban was justified for security reasons, without being specific. Mr. Yudhoyono's action was a rare rebuke of the Indonesian bureaucracy, which often acts as a power unto itself.

title: Correction

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: High Court Overturns Extraditions Ban
description: In a decision that clears what is widely considered the biggest legal obstacle to extraditing suspected felons to the United States, the Supreme Court ruled that Mexico could no longer deny extradition requests from countries where the suspects face life in prison. The 6-5 vote reflected Mexico's deep divisions over this issue, but also represents an important victory for President Vicente Fox, who has arrested dozens of high-level drug traffickers in recent years and has expressed his interest in seeing them face charges in the United States. Prisons in Mexico remain so rife with corruption that many traffickers had been able to manage their illegal businesses from behind bars, and courts have proven too weak to deliver swift, substantial sentences.

description: Strolling in the Pike Place Market in Seattle a few months ago, I stopped at Beecher's Handmade Cheese, right, drawn to the cups of macaroni and cheese that were being grabbed by shoppers as soon as they were set out. I bought a creamy portion and scarfed it down.

description: It is the kind of problem most governments could only wish for: After several years of budget surpluses, debt is headed to zero and a huge privatization next year will add billions of dollars more to the treasury.

description: WASHINGTON - For a while, Gabe Klein could easily keep track of every car in his territory simply by sticking pins on the wall-size map of the Washington metropolitan area in his office. No longer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLACKWELL, ELSIE WILSON
description: BLACKWELL--Elsie Wilson, 93. Of Basking Ridge, New Jersey, formerly of Dorset, VT, Short Hills, NJ, and Point O'Woods, NY, on November 26, 2005. Daughter of Susie M. and Edward T. Wilson of Denver, CO, she graduated from Mt. Vernon Seminary where she later served as a trustee and Sarah Lawrence College. Her husband of 71 years, Edward S., Jr. predeceased her in July. She is survived by her brother, Robert B. Wilson, her children, Janet Bent, Edward S. Blackwell III, and Marion Meserole, nine grandchildren and ten great grandchildren. Memorial service at Christ Church, Short Hills, NJ at 10 A.M. on Friday, December 2. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Southern Vermont Arts Center, P.O. Box 617, West Road, Manchester, VT. 05252.

title: E.P.A. Changes Cleanup Plans Near Ground Zero
description: Abandoning an ambitious cleanup plan for Lower Manhattan and parts of Brooklyn, federal environmental officials said yesterday that they would clean, at no cost, any apartment south of Canal Street with unacceptable levels of contaminants from the collapse of the World Trade Center.

description: Money managers have been stepping up their search for Wall Street's holy grail: an investment that consistently generates "alpha."

title: Newark's Longtime Mayor Sends Mixed Signals on Plans
description: Mayor Sharpe James of Newark has met repeatedly with Essex County College officials over the past few months to discuss a teaching job. He has tossed out the names of several potential successors, and this week, two city officials said that a "legacy committee" to honor his achievements had already been formed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEWART, DILLON
description: STEWART--Dillon. The staff of WNYC, New York Public Radio, mourns the untimely loss of our friend and former colleague, Dillon Stewart, who spent nearly a decade as a staff member in our finance department. We will forever admire his courage and sense of duty. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family. Laura Walker, President

description: BOSTON, Nov. 29 - Harvard Law School announced Tuesday the creation of a center to study legal issues raised by advances in genetics, health care and technology.

description: JERUSALEM, Nov. 29 - Shimon Peres plans to quit the left-leaning Labor Party, his political home for decades, and back Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's new centrist party in parliamentary elections in March, Israeli television reported Tuesday night.

title: Attention Turns To Child Welfare
description: Jon S. Corzine, the governor-elect, said on Tuesday that he would meet in the next few days with members of an advocacy group to try to avert a federal takeover of New Jersey's child welfare system.

title: The Duke Shames the Capitol
description: When Representative Randy Cunningham confessed to taking at least $2.4 million in bribes from government contractors, he shed tears before the cameras and vowed to atone. That could take some time. Mr. Cunningham, a California Republican known as Duke, had greedily accepted gifts for years from military contractors -- including bribes that helped pay for a yacht, a Rolls-Royce and a Louis Philippe commode. When he reciprocated with scores of millions of dollars in government contracts, the public paid the bill. It was a symbiosis between an ethically challenged lawmaker, who resigned on Monday, and easy-money boosters that might still be under way had San Diego newspapers not discovered a suspicious home sale by the congressman that concealed a payoff.

title: Invisible New Yorkers
description: Angelo Painu is a former waiter who lives in Brooklyn. As a young immigrant from Italy, he would ride the Coney Island parachute jump on the weekends. It has closed, but he still visits, and reminisces with friends. LENS

title: A Life in the Culinary Front Lines
description: MANHATTAN, Kan. - CLEMENTINE PADDLEFORD was the Nellie Bly of culinary journalism, a go-anywhere, taste-anything, ask-everything kind of reporter who traveled more than 50,000 miles a year in search of stories in a day when very few food editors strayed far from their desks.

title: Chief of Russian Utility Warns of Possible Winter Blackouts
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 29 - Moscow could face rolling blackouts during periods of extreme cold this winter, the head of the electricity monopoly said Tuesday, dramatizing the need for fresh investment in the country's crumbling electrical grid.

title: Juggling Words and Languages With a Caribbean Lilt
description: In "The Penguin Book of Caribbean Verse in English," the editor, Paula Burnett, separates several centuries of poetry into two traditions, the oral and the literary. Writers like Derek Walcott and the Dominican novelist Jean Rhys are included in the longer literary section, while the dub poet Linton Kwesi Johnson and the Jamaican-language poet Louise Bennett are put in the oral, along with the song lyrics of Jimmy Cliff and Bob Marley.

title: Pirro Is Advised Not to Oppose Mrs. Clinton
description: ALBANY, Nov. 29 - Jeanine F. Pirro's bid to unseat Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton suffered an embarrassing setback on Tuesday when the State Legislature's most powerful Republican said she should call the whole thing off and run for state attorney general instead.

title: Dubai to Buy P&O, British Shipping Line, for $5.7 Billion
description: LONDON, Nov. 29 - Dubai, the upstart sheikdom of the United Arab Emirates, agreed Tuesday to purchase the storied British shipping company Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation for 3.3 billion ($5.7 billion), strengthening Dubai's position as a center of commerce and transport.

title: Tussling With Readers
description: On Darfur, Sascha from Chapel Hill, NC writes: There is one thing I take issue with in your discussion of the Darfur crisis, that is the compartmentalization of the two sides into African and Arab. Everyone in this situation is African and often one cannot tell the difference between the two sides by simply looking at the people. I think it is very dangerous to portray the evil side as Arab, when Arabs are perpetually portrayed as evil in every way in our media and our society. I wish you would be more sensitive to this issue.

description: The 2006 biennial's two foreign-born curators have ventured across the Atlantic to include European artists in their show of contemporary arts.

title: The Worst Hellhole on Earth
description: Dorn Townsend, who is actually based in El Fasher in North Darfur, writes: Certainly Arab militias have committed outrageous crimes in devastating, beheading, and enslaving: the horror stories we hear in camps and villages reek of raw truth. My own visits to areas controlled by the janjaweed suggests a startling and more complex picture. Darfurs nomad population may be suffering from a parallel ethnic cleansing carried out by rebels. More specifically, sheiks from a dozen clans say theyve lost an average of 20 percent of their members at the hands of rebels and from malnutritionPresently theres just about no group or organization thats made contact with that other group which could provide a supplemental perspective on this element of whats happening here.
